fields.headline: Grandad ready for Leeds
fields.standfirst: David O'Leary often talks of his 'babies' but  Alex Simpson finds a Spanish child minder
fields.trailText: Leeds United against Deportivo La Coruña... the match that neither club really wanted. Leeds manager David O'Leary wanted Bayern Munich while Deportivo's president, Cesar-Augusto Lendoiro, fancied Manchester United.
fields.body:
Leeds United against Deportivo La Coruña... the match that neither club really wanted. Leeds manager David O'Leary wanted Bayern Munich while Deportivo's president, Cesar-Augusto Lendoiro, fancied Manchester United.

'I'd have preferred to be facing Bayern,' O'Leary admitted. 'I think the Spanish League is the best in Europe and Deportivo won it last year. They might not have the name of Barcelona or Real Madrid but they are an excellent side with some really talented players. We have not got the name of Manchester United or Arsenal, but we are not a bad side either.'

True enough. Neither club have aristocratic soccer pedigree and in centre-back Donato, a roly-poly Brazilian who looks to have a girth never approached by Maradona or Paul Gascoigne at their weightiest, Deportivo have an unlikely campaigner who spells trouble for O'Leary and his side.

Donato may not be skipper - that's Fran Gonzalez, arguably the weakest link of the side - but he holds everything together around his ample frame. At 38 he is Spain's oldest outfield player at the top level, and although he may look podgy, slow and unwieldy, and glories in the nickname of Abuelo , or Grandad, he reads the game superbly and makes the issue of speed irrelevant. He has already been offered a contract extension.

Donato packs one hell of a free-kick so comparisons with Ian Harte's technique will be interesting. His thunderbolts are known as 'Donatazos' by his adoring fans. And it was Donato's headed goal that broke the deadlock, settled his side and sent them on their way to their title in the final game of last season. There were those who raised eyebrows when Deportivo paid Atletico Madrid £400,000 for the old boy eight years ago and it is remarkable that he keeps up to the standard after a career spanning more than 20 years - which began with Vasco da Gama in his native Brazil.

He's part of a Brazilian-spiced side that has Spaniards at its core after Lendoiro decided to go local and buy only Spanish players or those already settled in the league. This followed a disastrous flirtation with buying cheap foreigners - the accompanying passport scandal still haunts the club - and within a year of the new policy, the dividend came with the Liga title.

Directing team affairs is coach Jabo Irureta, backed by Lendoiro's ability always to turn a profit on a transfer deal (notably, £4 million pocketed from the sale of Sylvain Wiltord to Arsenal from a sell-on clause - he never kicked a ball for Deportivo). Between them they have created a small-town force, drawing on a population of just 240,000, with the ability to kick big-city ass in the time-honoured style of Nottingham Forest, Aston Villa and, more recently, Blackburn Rovers. Provincial clubs, previously languishing, who pop up to win their national title.

Deportivo deserve even more credit because they have done it in the ultra-modern era of huge TV deals, concentrating cash among the well-heeled elite. These days Barca and Real Madrid constantly check over their shoulders.

Irureta, a disciplinarian, is true to his 4-2-3-1 style and requires players to fit this formation, never vice-versa. Not all approve - Eighties Liverpool star Michael Robinson's Monday night TV show in Spain recently screened footage of two Deportivo squad players ripping into their coach on the bench - but he gets results.

Donato is flanked at centre-back by the Moroccan Nourredine Naybet, shielded by the two midfield anchors, Mauro Silva, a World Cup winner, and Bryan Robson's Brazilian pal Emerson. They supply a trio of attacking schemers, one of whom is the outrageously gifted Djalminha, who, on his day, is worth the admission price alone.

But they are vulnerable in the air at the back. Goalkeeper Paco Molina flaps when he ventures for a cross and Irureta could opt to bring Helder - loaned to Newcastle last season - into the heart of the defence and move Donato into a holding role in midfield. But Molina is convinced his side will prevail.

'It's the most important game in Depor's history,' he says, '_until the next round.' Emerson, who had a passing acquaintance with the Premiership, agrees. 'Depor are favourites,' he declared. 'There's no need to worry. We'll show we're better and that the league in Spain is superior.'

Such talk will not faze Leeds - words don't impress O'Leary or his players. Midfielder Olivier Dacourt was asked: can Leeds win the Champions League? He said: 'Why not? We have beaten some good teams. But it will be presumptuous of us to say we will win the Champions League.

'The Anderlecht manager said we were the worst team they had played. Maybe he can watch us in the quarter-final on television! We don't care what people say about us. All that matters is getting a result. Deportivo are a good team. You don't get to the quarter-final on luck, you get there with quality. When we conceded four goals at the Nou Camp against Barcelona everyone said Leeds were finished. But we learned a lot from that experience and that has helped us this season.'

O'Leary, a master at talking down his own young team's chances, is hardly going to change his approach now. He said: 'It has been a fantastic adventure. We've beaten the Italian champions, we've played the champions of Europe and now we have to take on the Spanish champions. No one expected us to get past the first group, then no one expected us to reach the quarter-finals. If we get through it will be beyond belief.'

fields.bodyText: Leeds United against Deportivo La Coruña... the match that neither club really wanted. Leeds manager David O'Leary wanted Bayern Munich while Deportivo's president, Cesar-Augusto Lendoiro, fancied Manchester United. 'I'd have preferred to be facing Bayern,' O'Leary admitted. 'I think the Spanish League is the best in Europe and Deportivo won it last year. They might not have the name of Barcelona or Real Madrid but they are an excellent side with some really talented players. We have not got the name of Manchester United or Arsenal, but we are not a bad side either.' True enough. Neither club have aristocratic soccer pedigree and in centre-back Donato, a roly-poly Brazilian who looks to have a girth never approached by Maradona or Paul Gascoigne at their weightiest, Deportivo have an unlikely campaigner who spells trouble for O'Leary and his side. Donato may not be skipper - that's Fran Gonzalez, arguably the weakest link of the side - but he holds everything together around his ample frame. At 38 he is Spain's oldest outfield player at the top level, and although he may look podgy, slow and unwieldy, and glories in the nickname of Abuelo , or Grandad, he reads the game superbly and makes the issue of speed irrelevant. He has already been offered a contract extension. Donato packs one hell of a free-kick so comparisons with Ian Harte's technique will be interesting. His thunderbolts are known as 'Donatazos' by his adoring fans. fields.headline: Mind that lizard
fields.standfirst: No sandals or sun cream, no camping. No evenings on the beach. Oh, and the animals have right of way. Travel Editor  Jeannette Hyde  finds herself under the eagle eye of the eco-police on the islands of Fernando de Noronha
fields.trailText: No sandals or sun cream, no camping. No evenings on the beach. Oh, and the animals have right of way. Travel Editor Jeannette Hyde finds herself under the eagle eye of the eco-police on the islands of Fernando de Noronha.
fields.body:
I'm dozing when something odd brushes against my stomach. Something very odd. Maybe I'm dreaming. Suddenly, I feel a second brush, this time against my legs and I'm sure it's more of a scamper than a brush. I pa nic, jump out of bed and fling back the pink nylon sheets to reveal a 10-inch mubuya maculata , better known as a lizard to you and me.

I shouldn't really be surprised. This is Fernando de Noronha, a group of 21 islets off the coast of north-east Brazil, with some of the strictest rules in the world to keep touris m numbers down to a bare minimum and wildlife flourishing to the full.

There are animals everywhere. Hundreds of spinner dolphins play in the bays and stingrays greet you as you snorkel in the Atlantic. Lizards dart everywhere. Every time I feel a wriggle on my toes it's yet another mubuya maculata . At one point there are 10 in conference at my sandy feet, plus a local mouse.

The islands are grand, green and mountainous with yellow sand fringes. Having once been volcanic they aren't the pretty, turquoise, paradise images associated with the Maldives or Bahamas, but rocky masses with attitude.

This is a shock to me. I'm looking forward to the 16 untouched beaches. A band of male divers all with hairy wrists with watches the size of bricks and wearing matching black T-shirts are more fascinated by the underwater sea turtles, octopuses and jewfish and finding out about the 14 species of shark that inhabit the waters.

While islands around the world are knocking up luxury resorts, this is a place where nature stays as it is.

The guardian of these islands is Ibama, the environmental protection agency that administers Brazil's national parks. Until 1987 Brazil's armed forces had a base here. When they pulled out, discussions raged about building luxury resorts and golf courses. After a huge battle between environmentalists and the government, the eco-warriors won and Fernando was decreed a national park.

Only 420 tourists can stay in Fernando per night (that's the size of one hotel in other parts of the world). When that number is reached, you go on a waiting list with the tour companies that go there.

You also have to pay an eco-tax in cash in the arrivals hall (or rather shed) to get in, ranging from £7 for one night to £585 for a month. You are financially encouraged not to outstay your welcome.

I scan a big booklet of rules handed to me at the airport. They include: no swimming with dolphins; no access to beaches between 6pm and 8am, no camping, no feeding animals and the one that really catches my eye - no footwear or suntan cream on Atalaia Beach (to protect marine life).

We jump into a beach buggy taxi which scrambles up a dusty hill, round a bend and into a clearing where most of the 420 people staying the night have gathered. Many are draped on rocks, gazing into the bay with jagged mountains behind, waiting for the big show sunset. It's only six o'clock. In minutes, people turn into silhouettes and one by one get back into their buggies (the only transport, which is limited, of course) and roar away. We are staying in Casa das Pedras, which is a stone self-catering house, up a dusty road in the most populated part of Fernando. That said, there is nothing much there other than a few small houses with decks at the front, a few rooms to rent at the back and a small hall where weekly eco-lectures are held. Back at the house the fridge is bare. The road is dark (no street lighting in paradise) and no restaurants in sight. No supermarkets either. And absolutely no humans. My husband, Markus, goes out hunting for food and a 20-minute walk later finds the only pizzeria in town. I fall asleep hungry. The windows smeared with salt water stains rattle in the wind and the bed's sponge mattress has seen better days. We wake up with the dawn. There's a small frog in the bathroom sink (this sort of thing is no longer a surprise).

If you like your creature comforts, this is not the place for you. There's only one hotel - a corrugated iron ex-army barracks - and a bunch of basic B&Bs run by locals. It's impossible to get a decent meal. Most meals consist of a few bits of locally caught fish and a pile of salad stuff from tins.

But the payoff for keeping tourism small is pristine beaches and clear underwater diving (up to 50 metres). And the locals benefit directly from tourism by being the sole providers of food, beds and taxis. Just three registered companies run the diving. We go down to the island's busiest beach, Praia do Cachorro, where local kids run in the sand and jump in the waves. This is not a good place to feel thirsty - no beach huts serving cocktails here. But the view is wonderful.

We explore the island - driving down dusty tracks lined with coloured dustbins for rubbish separation and notices telling you not to throw litter. We come out on to a beautiful beach, Praia do Leão. A woman called Eliane is standing under a beach shade with an ice box and a cake with a mosquito cover. We gratefully buy a couple of cans of ice-cold Guarana (the Brazilian national fizzy drink) and a piece of cake.

'There is no unemployment here,' she says. 'Everyone does something. Fishing, cooking, running B&Bs. I bake cakes.' She loves it here. 'You can leave the door unlocked, nobody steals anything.' Commit a crime and you are deported. 'One guy who was high on marijuana once robbed the island shop. He was on the next flight out of here, banned forever.'

The next day we try the famed Atalaia Beach. It's obviously rush hour on Fernando. A long queue of beach buggies with bronzed girls in skimpy bikinis hanging off the backs wait patiently in front of a tiny caravan with a countdown sign saying how many visitors can still enter (daily quota is 100 people).

Eventually our buggy is let in, we drive down a dirt track where we park and walk down to the beach. An Ibama policeman blows his whistle, orders us to abandon our flip-flops and tiptoe to the small natural water swimming pools in the sand, blocked off from the sea by natural rocks. The Ibama guard blows again and barks commands: 'No stepping on that area!' 'Do not touch the coral.' He picks up a handful of soggy sand, whips out a magnifying glass and beckons us forward. Through the glass are huge lumps of pink coral. He picks up a tiny shell - inside is a crab-like creature called Aratú, the size of a finger nail. He places it back on the sand and the shell scampers away. Lying face forward with a snorkel, I look into the pool, my shoulders fully exposed to the sun - no suntan lotion is allowed, it might kill the fish, says Mr Ibama - and cruise the ocean bed. The reef is full of huge fish, shoals of purple finned, silver ones, electric green ones, stripy black and yellow ones. Suddenly the mirage is interrupted by the screech of a whistle.

'All out.'

As I walk across the sand, a huge multicoloured crab scurries to my feet and inspects me before scurrying off. I watch the other groups leaving the beach, a group from Argentina and a couple and their two children from Sao Paulo brimming with the kind of excitement normally associated with illegal substances. And I realise that although I'm no animal lover, I just had the best date of my life with nature.

Two days later, back on mainland Brazil, I unpack my rucksack in a new hotel room, the choking traffic of Recife humming in the background. The adjustment to civilisation is hard. Strange, green, slimy stuff covers my clothes. It's everywhere. It looks like some kind of animal excrement. And then out of the corner of my eye, I notice something.

A very familiar Fernando mubuya maculata darts out of my luggage.

Fact file

Getting to north-east Brazil: From August you will be able to fly direct to Recife on a charter flight from Gatwick in nine hours on Unijet (08706 008009 from £399 return). Otherwise fly to Recife from London via Lisbon on TAP Air Portugal (0845 6010932).

Getting from Recife: The 340-mile flight from Recife takes 90 minutes and can be bought as part of a package at Recife airport or from operator Sevagtur in Recife (0055 814626060), $330 (£220) for three nights full-board including return flights from Recife.

UK-based Trips Worldwide (0117 987 2626) offers a three-night package from Recife full-board including a boat excursion for £615. Or book flights as part of a five-journey Varig internal Brazil air pass, which together with international flights to Recife via Sao Paulo costs £772 from South American specialist Veloso Tours (020 8762 0616). Allow around £25 per room per night (which can be booked in advance through Veloso). You can also get to Fernando via Natal.

Getting in: You must pre-book your accommodation and pay an environmental tax to be allowed entry. Eco-tax is £7 for the first day; £14 for two days; £21 for three; one week £43; two weeks £117; one month £585.

When to go: Avoid the rainy season, May to August.

Diving: Atlantis Divers.

Tourist info: Brazil tourist office (020 7629 6909); Fernando de Noronha.

Reading: Brazil (Lonely Planet, £12.99); Brazil (Rough Guides, £14.99)

webTitle: Old port in a new bottle

fields.headline: Old port in a new bottle
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt enjoys the changing face of Oporto, Europe's new City of Culture
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt enjoys the changing face of Oporto, Portugal's second biggest city and Europe's new City of Culture.
fields.body:
Clinging to the steep banks of the River Douro as it opens into the sea, Oporto is Portugal's second biggest city, a bustling, cosmopolitan place that has long served as a crossroads for world trade.

By the riverside in the Cais de Ribeiro, overlooked by the grand nineteenth-century metalwork of the two-tier Pont Luis I bridge at one end and the contemporary glass box of the popular Café do Cais at the other, the dark cobbled lanes and tall, narrow houses have barely changed for centuries. At night, the signs light up on the port houses in Vila Nova de Gaia opposite: familiar names such as Cockburn, Taylor's, Sandeman reflect prettily on the water as bars spring to life.

A relaxed mixture of old and ultra-modern, African and European, Oporto is a seductive city, easy to fall in love with - but not at first sight. At the airport, signs announce that it is Europe's City of Culture for 2001. Outside, you'll see why instead locals are calling it 'European city of construction'. As well as building an airport extension, an underground line is being dug through the centre, a new bridge is edging across the Douro, roads and squares are being improved and an ambitious new music venue is taking shape. The city is a building site, and it's a tribute to its vibrancy how little this matters once you're inside it.

In terms of tourist sights, there's nothing much to do in Oporto. Which is fine because it's a wonderful place to do nothing much in. My five-year-old son Liam and I strolled around the park at Jardim do Palácio de Cristal, with its modern sports centre nestling on top like a stranded concrete UFO, admiring the peacocks, the fountains and the stunning view of the river far below.

Through an archway there, in the lower floor of the Museu Romantico, is the Port Wine Institute, where port is sold by the glass for anything from 70p to £30 - and served with the same ceremony no matter what the cost. We took a boat trip under the five bridges that span the Douro, shivering with cold as we faced the wind whipping off the sea, then basking in sunshine as it turned up river.

We climbed the extraordinary red, curved double staircase at the 1906 art nouveau bookshop, Nouveau & Irmao, in Rua das Carmelitas. We enjoyed good coffees, thick hot chocolate and sublime pastries in friendly cafés and explored narrow, cobbled streets that tumble down the hill from the cathedral to the Ribiero and feel like a living museum, full of dusty shops with antique fittings.

The pedestrianised mosaic walkway of Santa Caterina is the main shopping area, still free of chain stores. At the faded Art Deco Majestic café, time seems to have stopped somewhere around 1950: shoppers take coffee and cakes as a piano tinkles. Along nearby Rua Formosa, dusty old delis sell salt cod, pigs' trotters and, of course, port.

Then there's the sea. The city's only remaining tram line clanks beside the river to the rocky Atlantic coast, where dirty beaches are redeemed by fresh sea air and excellent cafés. The scruffy-looking exterior of Veranda do Sol, near Castelo do Foz, hides an upmarket Italian restaurant where I had one of the lightest, finest pizzas I've eaten.

Later, we ate at Transmontana II, on the quay in Vila Nova de Gaia (Av Diogo Leite 80), a new restaurant with a stunning river view. Children were effortlessly accommodated: my son's octopus and chips was not on the menu, but was rustled up with a smile. In the taxi back to the hotel that night, he announced that he wanted to learn Portuguese. Why? 'Because I want to live here.'

Where to go after dark...

Nightlife is centred on the Ribeiro, by the beach at Castelo de Foz and in the industrial area of Matosinhos. Bars at Foz are scattered along Avenida do Brasil: Origo, Praia da Luz and Caffé Indy have wooden decks reaching out over the beach; Quando Quando caters to a preppy crowd into labels and casual chic; Bonaparte appeals to the city's young British population. The Ribeiro attracts a more alternative, bohemian crowd. Locals go to the restaurants for the fado music many places play after dinner. Meanwhile, alleys off Plaça de Ribeiro have a crowded bar scene to rival that of Ibiza Town. Rowdy drinkers are sometimes silenced by an irate resident four floors up emptying a chamber pot out of the window.

Aniki Bóbó (Rua Fonte Taurina 36- 38) is named after an early film by the celebrated director Manuel d'Olivera, and attracts musicians and designers. O Meu Mercedes é Maior que o Teu (My Mercedes Is Bigger than Yours), at Rua da Lada 30, is an underground bar whose resident DJ, Zequinha, is a legend for his alternative rock set. Later he plays harder dance tracks at the Blá Blá club, in Matosinhos. The hippest dance club is the Via Rapida , off the motorway to the airport. It's open on Fridays and Saturdays until after dawn. Nearby, Tomate keeps similar hours, playing rock and Eighties pop to a younger crowd. The Hard Club, in Cais de Gaia, is the biggest live venue. Open Wednesday to Saturday, it's full of local talent. There's a chic jazz club, B-Flat, in Matosinhos.

 Three nights' B&B with Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) in a three-star superior hotel costs £342 from Mar 16-Oct 31. Sunvil (020 8758 4722) charges £367 for three nights' B&B at a five-star hotel, excluding bank holidays and peak season. Both prices include flights and transfers.

The city is a building site, and it's a tribute to its vibrancy how little this matters once you're inside it. In terms of tourist sights, there's nothing much to do in Oporto. Which is fine because it's a wonderful place to do nothing much in. My five-year-old son Liam and I strolled around the park at Jardim do Palácio de Cristal, with its modern sports centre nestling on top like a stranded concrete UFO, admiring the peacocks, the fountains and the stunning view of the river far below. Through an archway there, in the lower floor of the Museu Romantico, is the Port Wine Institute, where port is sold by the glass for anything from 70p to £30 - and served with the same ceremony no matter what the cost. We took a boat trip under the five bridges that span the Douro, shivering with cold as we faced the wind whipping off the sea, then basking in sunshine as it turned up river. We climbed the extraordinary red, curved double staircase at the 1906 art nouveau bookshop, Nouveau & Irmao, in Rua das Carmelitas. We enjoyed good coffees, thick hot chocolate and sublime pastries in friendly cafés and explored narrow, cobbled streets that tumble down the hill from the cathedral to the Ribiero and feel like a living museum, full of dusty shops with antique fittings. The pedestrianised mosaic walkway of Santa Caterina is the main shopping area, still free of chain stores. At the faded Art Deco Majestic café, time seems to have stopped somewhere around 1950: shoppers take coffee and cakes as a piano tinkles. Along nearby Rua Formosa, dusty old delis sell salt cod, pigs' trotters and, of course, port. Then there's the sea. The city's only remaining tram line clanks beside the river to the rocky Atlantic coast, where dirty beaches are redeemed by fresh sea air and excellent cafés. The scruffy-looking exterior of Veranda do Sol, near Castelo do Foz, hides an upmarket Italian restaurant where I had one of the lightest, finest pizzas I've eaten. Later, we ate at Transmontana II, on the quay in Vila Nova de Gaia (Av Diogo Leite 80), a new restaurant with a stunning river view. Children were effortlessly accommodated: my son's octopus and chips was not on the menu, but was rustled up with a smile. In the taxi back to the hotel that night, he announced that he wanted to learn Portuguese. Why? 'Because I want to live here.' Where to go after dark... Nightlife is centred on the Ribeiro, by the beach at Castelo de Foz and in the industrial area of Matosinhos. Bars at Foz are scattered along Avenida do Brasil: Origo, Praia da Luz and Caffé Indy have wooden decks reaching out over the beach; Quando Quando caters to a preppy crowd into labels and casual chic; Bonaparte appeals to the city's young British population. The Ribeiro attracts a more alternative, bohemian crowd. Locals go to the restaurants for the fado music many places play after dinner. Meanwhile, alleys off Plaça de Ribeiro have a crowded bar scene to rival that of Ibiza Town. Rowdy drinkers are sometimes silenced by an irate resident four floors up emptying a chamber pot out of the window. Aniki Bóbó (Rua Fonte Taurina 36- 38) is named after an early film by the celebrated director Manuel d'Olivera, and attracts musicians and designers. O Meu Mercedes é Maior que o Teu (My Mercedes Is Bigger than Yours), at Rua da Lada 30, is an underground bar whose resident DJ, Zequinha, is a legend for his alternative rock set. Later he plays harder dance tracks at the Blá Blá club, in Matosinhos. The hippest dance club is the Via Rapida , off the motorway to the airport. It's open on Fridays and Saturdays until after dawn. Nearby, Tomate keeps similar hours, playing rock and Eighties pop to a younger crowd. The Hard Club, in Cais de Gaia, is the biggest live venue. Open Wednesday to Saturday, it's full of local talent. There's a chic jazz club, B-Flat, in Matosinhos.  Three nights' B&B with Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) in a three-star superior hotel costs £342 from Mar 16-Oct 31. Sunvil (020 8758 4722) charges £367 for three nights' B&B at a five-star hotel, excluding bank holidays and peak season. Both prices include flights and transfers.

fields.headline: Demand for heli-skiing grows
fields.standfirst: Adrenaline junkies unlikely to be deterred by death of Briton
fields.trailText: Adrenaline junkies unlikely to be deterred by death of Briton.
fields.body:
Heli-skiing is banned in France, but that is not stopping growing numbers of Britons flying to the far flung corners of the earth, from Alaska to Iran, for this ultimate in extreme adrenalin sports.

And only last week a doctor died after being caught in an avalanche on a heli-skiing trip in the central Asian republic of Kyrgyzstan. It appears that he and his wife used local operators to arrange their flight into the mountains, although they had Western guides with them.

But ski enthusiasts insist that the danger is not much greater than on-piste skiing. Heli-skiing is becoming more popular as snowboarders take over the slopes and more skiers in traditional resorts head off piste.

'If people go with an official company, they have qualified mountain guides who take safety seriously,' said a spokeswoman for the Ski Club of Great Britain. 'It is not dangerous.' Though heli-skiers are dropped on to deserted mountains by helicopters, the slopes they ski down are sometimes gentler than resort slopes. Beepers are worn in boots and clothes to indicate a skiier's position if they are caught in an avalanche.

According to some operators, the increased interest in heli-skiing is largely the result of the improvement in ski technology. Skiers reach a better standard more quickly and are more eager to ski on powder.

Heli-skiing is banned in France for ecological reasons, but other areas of Europe all have increasing amounts of heli-skiing. Prices for a day's heli-skiing vary from £60 to £200 a day, although fans are paying up to £3,000 a week to carry out the sport in remoter spots. The latest trend is for skiers to go to more exotic places, such as Iran, and specialist operator Momentum Travel said heli-skiing was likely to catch on there.

Canada is still one of the top heli-skiing destinations. Meanwhile, those seeking specific heli-ski trips are heading to the Alaskan resorts of Alyeska and Valdez.

'It's a great dinner-party conversation to say you've been skiing in Alaska,' said Keith Betton, spokesman for the Association of British Travel Agents.

Other areas opening up are Turkey and the Himalayas - specifically Manali in the state of Himachal Pradesh, about 500km north of New Delhi.

How to do it

The Ski Club of Great Britain (020 8410 2000).

Specialist ski operators can be found through the Association of Independent Tour Operators (0870 751 8080).

Momentum Travel (020 7371 9111) can arrange heli-skiing in Chile from £43pp.

fields.headline: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports
fields.trailText: Conditions have not been cold then sunny enough in most places to produce real, flattering 'corn' snow as overnight ice melts in the sunshine.The last few ski seasons have seen some large late falls in the Alps, but there's no sign of them yet this year.
fields.body:
Conditions have not been cold then sunny enough in most places to produce real, flattering 'corn' snow as overnight ice melts in the sunshine. The last few ski seasons have seen some large late falls in the Alps, but there's no sign of them yet this year.

Andorra: In Soldeu (35cm lower slopes and 100cm upper) and other centres there was 'some good snow to be found'.

AustriaA: Mayrhofen (0/130cm) has been good on piste in the mornings but slushy later and there have been a few accidents. Kitzbühel (10/75cm) was suffering with 'wet' pistes and slushy resort runs. Things were much better at higher, colder Obergurgl (35/190cm) where pistes were good and off-piste varied. Söll is closed for the season.

Canada: Whistler (mid-mountain 204cm) had had 17cm of snow in seven days and was expecting more. Pistes were 'soft packed'. In Alberta, Banff Norquay (50cm), Sunshine (130cm) and Lake Louise (79cm) all lifts were operating and reported excellent skiing.

France: The world speed skiing championships start today in Les Arcs (45/150cm). After snowy white-out days Val d'Isère (75/355cm) had perfect skiing weather early in the week with good pistes but 4/5 avalanche risk off them. Serre Chevalier (50/350cm) still has good snow up high but resort runs are poor. Méribel's (20/125cm) lower runs are badly worn. Chamonix (10/206cm) was best well above the resort.

Italy: I was skiing in the Dolomites last weekend and although there is still plenty of snow, warm temperatures produced deep, heavy slush after lunch. First day we skied to Arabba (80/250cm) from Canazei (50/100cm). Plans to ski the Sella Ronda were abandoned for better snow higher up on the Marmolada, and on the third day we skied high in the Val di Fassa, where the pistes were fine till lunchtime. Elsewhere Cervinia (140/250cm) has good higher pistes and 'spring' snow off them.

Norway: It is still cold and sunny with great piste skiing in Geilo (110/130cm), Lillehammer (50/115cm) and Voss (90/110cm).

Switzerland: St Moritz (150/ 300cm) was nicely chilled and it had good skiing on well-groomed pistes. Davos (45/220cm) had good piste running, but lower pistes to Klosters (0/80cm) were closed. Zermatt (10/220cm) had hard runs turning slushy. At Wengen (5/60cm) higher north-facing runs were the best bet.

US: After a great hullabaloo today's the day when Aspen (mid-mountain 145cm) opens its main mountain, Ajax, to snowboarders. Elsewhere in Colorado there had been fresh snow but warmer temperatures, mid-mountain depths were Beaver Creek (173cm), Breckenridge (142cm), Telluride (158 cm), Vail (142cm) and Winter Park (173cm). In California, Heavenly (66/152cm) with calm winds and warm, partly cloudy days boasted great spring skiing while across Lake Tahoe, Alpine Meadows (243cm mid-mountain) - where 'corn snow and short sleeves abound' - stages the Wayne Wong Freestyle Classic next weekend. In the East, Killington (113/250cm) had excellent pistes and powder off them. Smuggler's Notch (70/180cm) had similarly great pistes but conditions were wind-blown and dangerous off them.

On the slopes: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands and Victor Emanuel, the 63-year-old head of the House of Savoy, both keep chalets in Gstaad, though the resort is trying to develop a younger image and attracted Geri Halliwell (below left) and Robbie Williams earlier this year. Kiss FM has been in Mayrhofen for the British Snowboard Championships.

Best skiing: St Moritz, four nights B&B in the four-star Hotel Belvedere, flying from Heathrow to Zurich on Thursday 5 April, £569pp sharing, self-drive car included. Momentum Travel (0207 371 9111).

 The AITO directory of ski operators, whose reps help with this report, is available free by calling 020 8607 9080.

fields.headline: Ask the experts
fields.standfirst: We answer your travel queries
fields.trailText: We answer your travel queries.
fields.body:
I am going on an Easter holiday and will be leaving on 13 April. I read in Escape a month ago that air traffic controllers were balloting to strike. Is there an update on this?
Zuveir Jameer, London

Last week's decision by the Government to sell off 46 per cent of Air Traffic Control to the Airline Group has in effect cancelled any strike action planned for Easter. The controllers' union had said its members would probably strike if the Government chose alternative bidder, Serco, in the part-privatisation of the industry. A union official said they supported the Airline Group's bid as long as safety was not compromised.

My mum, sister and I are going on holiday to Majorca in May. Where is the best place to go snorkelling, preferably right off the beach?
Charlotte Rastan (by email)

Specialist operator The Real Spain says Majorca isn't a key area for snorkellers. There are neither major coral formations nor a large variety of fish. However, fish can be seen, particularly off the rocky north coast of the island. On the south coast, sandy beaches mean visibility is worse, but you can wade out to sea with a snorkel.

Are there any travel insurance companies that would insure my mother for a trip to Canada next Easter - she is in her eighties and has diabetes?
Rosi Cross (by email)

The number of older travellers has mushroomed over the past 10 years and it shouldn't be too hard to find a company offering travel insurance. Based on your mother's description, Matthew Gerard (01483 729952) offers two weeks' comprehensive cover for £37, including VAT. This is subject to a telephone health check. Try also Saga travel insurance (0800 056 5464).

Canada is a great destination for over-65s. Parks and museums often offer a price reduction. It's important your mother takes extra supplies of any medication and has a prescription so she can get it through customs and replace it with the Canadian equivalent.

My partner and I are getting married in July and are planning a honeymoon in Amalfi. We are finding it difficult to obtain information about mid-range hotels in the area. Do you have any suggestions?
Gillian Foster, London

The Amalfi coastline, between Sorrento and Salerno, is one of the most beautiful in Europe. The picturesque towns of Positano, Amalfi and Ravello are popular in high season. Making reservations independently and booking well in advance can improve your chances of ensuring a reasonable deal. Positano is probably the most charming town in the area and has a wealth of mid-range hotels. The Villa Maria Luisa (00 39 089 87 50 23, Via Fornillo 40) has large doubles with en suite bathrooms for about £50 per night. For more information on the area contact the Italian Tourist Board (020 7408 1254).

 Our experts at Escape and Lonely Planet will try to reply to as many of your questions as possible. Email us at travel.tips@observer.co.uk or write to Escape, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Web gives boost to green tourism

fields.headline: Web gives boost to green tourism
fields.standfirst: Eco-tourism special report
fields.trailText: A new website launches for eco-friendly travellers.
fields.body:
If you're concerned about damaging the environment but love to travel, a new web address called www.responsibletravel.com claims to have the answer.

Labelling itself as an information broker, the site groups together tour operators and hotels screened to ensure they meet minimum environmental standards and make social and economic commitments to local communities.

Would-be travellers can choose trips from yak trekking to tiger conservation and book hotels which practise recycling and benefit the local community. Prices are as diverse as the trips - from a £6,850 cruise in Antarctica to a hotel in India costing £11.50 a night.

One of the things that makes this hotel 'responsible' is the fact it uses hand washing to boost employment of local people and is economical with the amount of detergent used. Bookings cannot be made online, but visitors to the site can request a brochure.

 Young travellers are being invited to attend a conference organised by Tourism Concern in Manchester on 7-8 April. Speakers from around the world will give talks on issues such as sensitive photography and safety. Contact Tourism Concern on 020 7753 3330.

fields.headline: Alfresco anti-insect moisturizer
fields.trailText: Slip this bottle of moisturiser into your luggage for an end to being munched on by mosquitoes. Unlike some insect repellents, Alfresco shouldn't eat into watch straps or camera cases either, because it uses natural ingredients rather than chemicals.
fields.body:
Slip this bottle of moisturiser into your luggage for an end to being munched on by mosquitoes. Unlike some insect repellents, Alfresco shouldn't eat into watch straps or camera cases either, because it uses natural ingredients rather than chemicals. With a scent a bit like Old Spice aftershave with a hint of talcum powder, Alfresco can be worn by men and women. It's safe for children too, with a recommendation from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. Insects might not be attracted to it but film stars certainly are - Robert Redford and Jodie Foster use Alfresco and it's been on the set of both Captain Corelli's Mandolin and The Beach . From June, Alfresco will be joined on the shelves by a bug-fighting eau de toilette - Acqua D'Alfresco.

 Available from www.alfresco.uk.com, 020 8348 6704 and some Boots stores.

fields.headline: Book ends
fields.standfirst: Which? Holiday destination
fields.trailText: Which? Holiday destination.
fields.body:
Want to spice up your choice of holiday destination? Then flick to the end of Which? Holiday Destination , where Zanzibar is featured for the first time. It's among 30 lesser-known places including Bolivia, Estonia and Oman that have been added to this edition. Travel gems include where to see inter-tribal wrestling in Gambia, when it's best to go to Latvia and where to take a thermal bath in Budapest. There are also more traditional destinations - the section on France has a regional breakdown with year-round holiday choices. To help you find the right brochure, each destination is followed by a list of tour operators, including specialists. There are also tips on getting there independently, the weather and cost of living.

If you want help deciding where to go, or just fancy daydreaming, this book lives up to its title, but once you've plumped for a country, chances are you'll need more detailed information.

Published by Which? £12.99.

fields.headline: You must be nuts
fields.standfirst: In small-town America you can find everything from the Testicle Festival to the Redneck Games.  Jo Smalley lists 12 outrageous festivals that beggar belief in their attempts to attract visitors. In the spirit of April Fool's Day, he's included a made-up one. If you can spot it, you could win a free flight for two to a US city
fields.trailText: In small-town America you can find everything from the Testicle Festival to the Redneck Games. Jo Smalley lists 12 outrageous festivals that beggar belief in their attempts to attract visitors. In the spirit of April Fool's Day, he's included a made-up one. If you can spot it, you could win a free flight for two to a US city.
fields.body:
1 The Arctic Man Ski & Sno' Go Classic
12-15 April, Paxson, Alaska

What: The planet's strangest winter sports event.
Why: Excess testosterone. Men outnumber women by 10 to one in rural Alaska, so any snow-bound machismo followed by heroic drinking is deemed acceptable. In reality, the only thing that makes sense about the Arctic Man is where it was dreamt up: on a bar stool.
Highlight: The contest. Competitors ski down a mountain, catch a towrope on the fly and then get hauled around by a snowmobile at 80mph. 'Survivors' can win $50,000.
Other attractions: Risqué hot-tub parties and 'high-marking' - driving a snowmobile straight up a mountain until gravity takes over. Last year, this pastime earned one unfortunate the Darwin Award: after surviving one self-inflicted avalanche, he went back for more and died in the second.
Contact: 001 907 456 2626; www.alaska.net/arcticmn

2 World Cow Chip Throwing Contest
21 April, Beaver, Oklahoma

What: People - and flies - descend on this Panhandle town to watch cow dung flung.
Why: For nineteenth-century pioneers, chucking dried cow 'chips' into their wagons meant something to burn come winter. In 1970, Beaver revived this lost art.
Highlight: Some people really can shoot the shit. In 1979, Leland Searcy set the world record by slinging a chip 182ft 3in.
Other attractions: Be photographed with a 10ft statue of a beaver holding a cow chip.
Contact: 001 580 625 4726

3 The World Grits Festival
20-22 April, St George, South Carolina

What: A three-day celebration of grits, the tasteless goop made from boiled ground corn.
Why: God only knows. Frankly, a mouthful of glue is more edifying than a bowl of grits. Cross the Mason-Dixon line, however, and people go mad for it. In tiny St George, locals spoon down more grits per capita than anywhere else. The town decided to cash in: now 30,000 people (15 times the town's population) show up to eat 3,000lb of grits.
Highlight: Rolling in the grits. You dive into a pool filled with cold grits, and whoever gets the most stuck to their body wins.
Other attractions: A corn-shelling contest and the Miss Grits beauty parade.
Contact: 001 843 563 4366

4 The Summer Redneck Games
Early July, East Dublin, Georgia

What: Bubbas, Billy-Rays and Billie-Jeans go for gold in true Southern style.
Why: Started as a joke to complement the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Locals hated it at first but were gradually won over by the tongue-in-cheek portrayal of Southerners as beer-swillin', hog-callin', belly-floppin' hicks.
Highlight: The beer-can torch procession. Guaranteed to put a tear in the eyes. Or is that just the smoke from the barbecue pit?
Other attractions: The mud-pit belly flop, bobbing for pig's feet, a dive into a dumpster and the armpit serenade. One past winner produced a stirring rendition of Dixie.
Contact: 001 800 688 0096; www.wqzy.com

5 The Annual Wayne Chicken Show
14 July, Wayne, Nebraska

What: Feel like a chicken tonight? Come cluck in front of 15,000 people.
Why: This was an arts and crafts fair, but the inaugural chicken theme stole the show.
Highlight: The Cluck-Off Championship (hear previous winners on the web).
Other attractions: The 'best chicken legs on a human' contest and the Chickendale male dancers' revue.
Contact: 001 402 375 2240; www.chickenshow.com

6 The Great Texas Mosquito Festival
27-28 July, Clute, Texas

What: Up to 23,000 people celebrate tiny, whiny bloodsuckers.
Why: Clute has a hell of a lot of them. 'It's our only natural resource,' says the spokeswoman.
Highlight: A 25ft mosquito named Willie Man-Chew, which sports a Stetson, boots and a mighty big stinger. This is Texas, after all.
Other attractions: A Ms Quito pageant and a mosquito-calling contest. Go swimming and learn the Clute 'one-stroke', where you swim with one arm and slap 'skeeters' with the other.
Contact: 00 1 800 371-2971; www.ci.clute.tx.us

7 The Great American Duck Race
23-26 August, Deming, New Mexico

What: Duck racing in the desert.
Why: Deming lacked ducks (and tourists).
Highlight: A duck breeder won so many times that professionals have now been banned. His name? Robert Duck.
Other attractions: Rent-a-duck, outhouse racing and a royal duck pageant.
Contact: 001 505 546-2674; www.demingduckrace.com

8 Sta-Bil National Lawn Mower Race Championships
1 September, Indianapolis, Indiana

What: Grown men (and a few women) race ride-on lawn mowers at up to 60mph.
Why: An April Fool's joke in 1992 has turned into a fully fledged, televised sport. The cheeky organisers are even applying to Athens for Olympics status.
Highlight: Watching the lumbering machines - with names such as Sodzilla, Turfinator and the Lawn Ranger - attempting to corner hay bales at high speeds and remain upright.
Other attractions: A special push-mower race set up specially for the Brits.
Contact: 00 1 847 729-7363; www.letsmow.com

9 The Testicle Festival
13-17 September, Clinton, Montana

What: America's nuttiest event. Two tonnes of 'Rocky Mountain Oysters' (bull testicles) are sliced off, marinated in beer, battered, deep-fried and served to 15,000 visitors.
Why: No other festival draws such diversity, everyone from grandmothers, biker gangs, comely university co-eds and leather-faced ranch-hands. 'Cowboy caviare' must be powerful - all of the above behave badly and tend to 'get naked'.
Highlight: 'Bite the Ball', where motorcycle passengers attempt to bite a testicle dangling from a fishing pole.
Other attractions: The Nut Queen pageant, Co-ed Naked Pool and Bullshit Bingo, where you bet on one of 20 squares in a corral. A calf is set loose and if it does the business on your square you win.
Contact: 001 406 825 4868; www.testyfesty.com (warning: website, like festival, contains gratuitous nudity).

10 Emma Crawford Coffin Festival
26-27 October, Manitou Springs, Colorado

What: Macabre funereal fun.
Why: Emma Crawford came here in the late 1800s seeking relief from tuberculosis... and died. According to her wishes, her body was buried on nearby Red Mountain. In the early 1900s, a storm washed her coffin straight down the hillside. The town decided to pay homage in the poorest possible taste.
Highlight: The Coffin Race. Teams of four pallbearers and wheeled coffins (each with a pale, costumed 'Emma' inside) assemble near the town clock then sprint down Main Street.
Other attractions: Manitou Springs also hosts the messy Great Fruitcake Toss in January.
Contact: 001 719 685-5089; www.manitousprings.org/events.htm

11 The World Championship Punkin' Chunkin' Contest
2-4 November, Millsboro, Delaware

What: Boffins build sophisticated devices that hurl 8lb pumpkins into the air. The only rule: no explosives.
Why: Started as a simple wager between farmers in 1986. The first winner managed 128ft; the current record is 4,109ft.
Highlight: Watching hundreds fly at speeds up to 400mph.
Other attractions: The Heath Robinson-type ingenuity that designers bring to their demented hurling contraptions.
Contact: 001 302 8561444; www.punkinchunkin.com

12 The Molasses Disaster Festival
15-16 December, Sucarnoochee, Mississippi

What: A Mississippi town remembers a sticky moment.
Why: In 1932, a distillery tank exploded at the local sugar plant, releasing two million gallons of unrefined black treacle into the streets. Over three days, the unstoppable 15ft tidal wave of molasses levelled the place.
Highlight: The 'Run For Your Lives' Sugar Race. A good part of the town's Main Street is fenced off with interconnecting hardboard walls, the participants line up and a 10,000-gallon cauldron of fast-running corn syrup is tipped behind them.
Other attractions: Molasses-swallerin' contest and the Stuck On You Strutters Ball.
Contact: http://home.swbell.net/dietricj/molasses

fields.headline: Tax halved on Europe flights
fields.trailText: Travellers will pay less for flights within Europe from today as the Air Passenger Duty is cut from £10 to £5.
fields.body:
Travellers will pay less for flights within Europe from today as the Air Passenger Duty is cut from £10 to £5.

The decision by HM Customs and Excise to halve the tax on flights from the UK to destinations in the EU has been welcomed by low-cost carriers, which have long been campaigning against a tax that often takes up a large proportion of their fares. For example on £29 returns, the £10 tax is a third of the ticket price.

A spokesperson for Buzz said: 'This is good news for consumers as it allows us to offer lower fares. We think it is wrong that Air Passenger Duty - which does not get rechannelled into aviation and goes straight to the Exchequer - applies to flights and not to Eurostar, which is a major competitor and has already benefited from large amounts of public subsidy.'

David Magliano, sales and marketing director for no-frills airline Go, said: 'Any move that helps to keep fares low is beneficial to customers, to our business and to the entire aviation industry.'

However, passengers travelling in business and first class will still have to pay the full duty and a tax of £20 will still apply to passagers travelling on all flights outside the EU.

 Drew Mikhael is from Children's Express, a progamme of learning through journalism for eight- to 18-year-olds.

fields.headline: Aid team to my rescue
fields.standfirst: Martin Buckley  continues his adventures hitch-hiking by light aircraft around the globe. This week he arrives in Africa
fields.trailText: Martin Buckley continues his adventures hitch-hiking by light aircraft around the globe. This week he arrives in Africa
fields.body:
I was the last thing Bernard Terlouw needed. The manager of Mission Aviation Fellowship in Nairobi was in the midst of coping with his organisation's first crash in a decade, a forced landing in rural Tanzania that left the engine some distance from the rest of the plane and its five occupants in hospital. Just as he was trying to organise an air ambulance to take them to Europe, dealing with all the stress and red tape, a British journalist turned up looking for a free ride.

It's a tribute to his patience - or Christian charity - that he didn't throw me out. Instead he let me accompany him to the hospital where Marit Bu Oppedal was strapped in a surgical corset, her injured face resembling a harvest moon. Yet she seemed to have experienced a kind of epiphany. 'We were flying down a valley under the cloud, and we realised we were locked in. A massive downdraught caught us, because suddenly the pilot couldn't keep the plane in the air any more. I just remember climbing out of it, drenched with blood, then villagers approaching, covering us with blankets. I remember thinking, "yes, human nature is essentially good". And all the time in the background, there were female voices singing a kind of lament.'

St John ambulances arrived, and rocketed through the streets of Nairobi at 80mph, lights flashing, with Bernard racing to keep up, muttering: 'Don't they realise these people have back injuries ?' At last, the patients were transferred on to British Airways stretchers. As Bernard and I drove away, we passed a dented car and the body of a dead pedestrian. We pulled over, but others were already helping. We drove on in silence. At last Bernard said: 'I wouldn't want you to think this is an ordinary day for me. On the other hand, it's not that unusual...'

Terlouw, 40, is a Dutchman who until three years ago was studying theology. Then he and his wife Margriet - a pastor - and their three children received a calling. Now they work with MAF, an organisation created in the late 1940s by two RAF pilots who wanted to turn their wartime skills to good use. Today, a MAF plane takes off some where in the developing world every four minutes.

I had hoped MAF might help me fly into Sudan. Bernard was hesitant. 'You know the parable of the good Samaritan? Well, without his donkey, he couldn't have carried the injured man. MAF is a donkey; people do aid, relief and mission work all over the world, and we exist to carry them, fly them over war zones, take them into places it would need days to reach by land.' He grinned. 'Are you doing any good works, Martin?' In the end he agreed to carry me - if there was space.

Marcos Habtetsion, an Eritrean ex-fighter pilot, has flown with MAF for 15 years. Our flight last Tuesday began with a prayer. Then we headed north to Marsabit, an oasis built on volcanic slopes in the middle of the Karoli Desert. Much of the 400-mile road to Marsabit is lawless; you either go by armed convoy - or fly in. The passengers were two officials from the UN's World Food Programme. A thunderstorm loomed, carrying before it an apron of red dust 2,000ft high. We diverted, but reached the volcanic cones of Marsabit just as the storm did. As we dropped towards the airstrip, a black cloud suddenly came over a ridge and bore down on us, engulfing the town. Marcos threw the plane into a steep bank, but the cloud swallowed us. I glimpsed rooftops close enough to touch - then grey. We were flying blind at 300ft, with peaks all around us. Happily, Marcos knows Marsabit well. We burst out of the cloud low over trees, and aimed for a rectangle of sunlit desert. I was laughing with relief as we put down on orange sand. 'So, Martin,' said Marcos, 'maybe your baptism into the life of a bush pilot came a little earlier than you expected?'

 Observer readers can contact Martin Buckley at mbwingingit@hotmail.com, and MAF on 01303 850950.

fields.headline: In with the in crowd
fields.standfirst: If you want to rub shoulders with the jet set, the Indian Ocean is now the hottest spot, writes  Jill Crawshaw
fields.trailText: If you want to rub shoulders with the jet set, the Indian Ocean is now the hottest spot, writes Jill Crawshaw.
fields.body:
Move over Antigua and Anguilla - hello Mauritius and the Maldives. Suddenly, the Caribbean is no longer so cool and its rum punches and conveyor-belt weddings look almost naff.

The latest holiday hotspots are firmly anchored in the Indian Ocean; zooming up the charts this year are Mauritius, the Seychelles and the Maldives. Yet they share the same beach-basking ingredients - sun that shines, aquamarine sea that laps, palms that sway - all the familiar travel clichés plus a dash of the exotic, but not too much seasoning. What's the story?

'There's a fashion in holidays as in everything else,' says Sue Biggs, managing director of tour operator Kuoni. 'Holidaymakers are always looking for something different, and they discovered the Indian Ocean just as it was getting its act together.'

She might have added that the Caribbean has been accused of losing the plot: packing in cut-price all-inclusive hotels and cheap charter flights has tarnished its oh-so glitzy image. And when Caribbean grand-dame Sandy Lane delayed its reopening after rebuilding, the upmarket clientele began to look elsewhere.

They certainly liked what they found in Mauritius, which probably now has the largest concentration of luxurious five-star hotels in the world; it also helps its tourist cred that there is little crime, political stability, full employment, a pretty harmonious racial mix and no malaria. Not bad for an island the size of Surrey with few resources and underwhelming sightseeing (you can visit all its 'tourist highlights' in less than a day).

Consistent government policy unashamedly gives priority to upmarket tourism, and has banned charter flights. 'We can't afford to have holidaymakers paying huge prices sharing a small island with charter clients,' says its tourist board manager for the UK, Toto Ghoorahor, who has seen the number of British holidaymakers rise from 35,271 to 74,488 in the past five years.

Alison Leighton of Classic Connection reports a 'phenomenal' 60 per cent increase in travel to Mauritius, which she attributes to high standards, excellent food, diversity of hotels and hospitality second to none - and not just for 'a bagful of dollars'. All of which, from my own experiences I can second - hotel staff would remove damp towels from your sunlounge without you noticing; even the beach vendors were meticulous with their ' s'il vous plaits' and ' mercis'.

Not surprisingly, given its Indian, Chinese, French and Creole influences, the island's superb cuisine beats most of the Caribbean's bland offerings. A stream of celebrities from France's President Jacques Chirac to the Spice Girls and It girls, Bryan Ferry, Prince William and Terry Venables are recent visitors, no doubt recently enjoying smoked marlin, palm hearts salad and other island specialities.

The island's construction industry must be doing a storm; the five-star Oberoi and the Mauritius Hilton made their debuts last year, the luxury Prince Maurice and the Residence a couple of years before that, while the crème de la crème of Mauritian hotels, the Royal Palm and the Saint Géran, where the cosseting ratio is three staff to one guest, have both had major facelifts. Even standard rooms in the Royal Palm come complete with oriental antiques, Persian carpets and walk-in wardrobes twice the size of the average British bathroom; the wine list would probably bankrupt several South American republics. Due to be unveiled later this year on its own island, the Ile des Deux Cocos, is another top-drawer retreat, Follies, where guests will be transported on old-fashioned rickshaws to suites crammed with executive toys. The personal DVDs and hand telephones can be carried to the beach. The visitors will sleep on 'sea green Irish linen'.

The Seychelles are enjoying a more modest rise in popularity, of between 10 and 15 per cent. Dubbed 'the Garden of Eden' because of the brilliant lushness of their vegetation, teeming wildlife and bewitching charm, these have the best scenery of all the Indian Ocean islands. Adrift 1,000 miles off the African coast, there are more than 100 of them, some coral, some volcanic, all different - an island-hopper's delight.

The snag is that they are not cheap. Where Mauritius is often quoted as a four-star island with five-star hotels, the Seychelles are described as a five-star destination with four-star accommodation - if you're lucky! Tour operators claim that underinvestment in hotels and training plus a flirtation with environmental taxes have made it difficult to justify the high prices. But there are signs of change: there are already a couple of hotel superstars - the two-year-old island-resort of Frégate, where only 40 guests unwind in sumptuous seclusion at nearly £1,000 per night; and last year's new leisure palace, the Mauritian-owned Lemuria, on Praslin, much lauded by new British holidaymakers, though not so popular with old Praslin hands who have lost access to favourite beaches. More intimate new properties are springing up on the islands of Alphonse, Cousine and Felicité, where Tony and Cherie Blair recently spent a quiet holiday.

The Seychelles might well look north-east to the successful eco-tourist policies of the Maldives, whose archipelago is made up of more than 1,000 tiny islands, 100 or so of which are officially designated 'tourist islands'. Another 'new' one is opened up every year in accordance with the Islamic republic's strict development plans. Since 99.66 per cent of the country's area consists of sea, land is the most precious commodity and environmental issues are paramount.

On a recent visit, my group was issued with eco-bags to take our rubbish home, and I witnessed the extraordinary sight of bulging garbage sacks whirling round the carousel at Gatwick airport.

'Government strategy has kept development to a handful of islands rather than hundreds, and restricted flights so that they can keep up quality and prices,' says Biggs of Kuoni.

A quarter of visitors are honeymooners attracted by the desert-island Robinson Crusoe image,but, let's face it, no culture whatsoever. Wannabe Crusoes have it cushy; at the five-star Kurumba, guests dine on sashimi and lobster at candlelit barbecues, while at the glamorous Four Seasons they can snack on French cheese or Chinese porridge.

The stage is set this October for the opening of the Soneva Gili resort and spa, which is already promising that it will be the best water villa property in the world.

The Caribbean may have been the most glamorous destination of the twentieth century, but in the new millennium, the Indian Ocean is on a roll.

Fact file

Weather

Mauritius: If you're heading to a resort in Mauritius (such as the Royal Palm, pictured right), there's less rain and humidity from July to September. The worst time to go is from January to April, when there is the threat of cyclones.

Seychelles: The tradewind season, from May to October, is the best time to avoid monsoons.

Maldives: Peak season is the dry period, from December to April.

Guide books

Mauritius and Seychelles

Insight Guide Mauritius & Seychelles (Lagenscheidt Publishers, £16.99)
Dive Sites of Mauritius (New Holland, £15.99)
Mauritius, Reunion & Seychelles (Lonely Planet, £10.99)

Maldives

Spectrum Guide to the Maldives (Camerapix, £13.99)
Illustrated Guide to the Maldives (Odyssey, £9.95 with www.amazon.co.uk)
fields.bodyText: Move over Antigua and Anguilla - hello Mauritius and the Maldives. Suddenly, the Caribbean is no longer so cool and its rum punches and conveyor-belt weddings look almost naff. The latest holiday hotspots are firmly anchored in the Indian Ocean; zooming up the charts this year are Mauritius, the Seychelles and the Maldives. Yet they share the same beach-basking ingredients - sun that shines, aquamarine sea that laps, palms that sway - all the familiar travel clichés plus a dash of the exotic, but not too much seasoning. What's the story? 'There's a fashion in holidays as in everything else,' says Sue Biggs, managing director of tour operator Kuoni. 'Holidaymakers are always looking for something different, and they discovered the Indian Ocean just as it was getting its act together.' She might have added that the Caribbean has been accused of losing the plot: packing in cut-price all-inclusive hotels and cheap charter flights has tarnished its oh-so glitzy image. And when Caribbean grand-dame Sandy Lane delayed its reopening after rebuilding, the upmarket clientele began to look elsewhere. They certainly liked what they found in Mauritius, which probably now has the largest concentration of luxurious five-star hotels in the world; it also helps its tourist cred that there is little crime, political stability, full employment, a pretty harmonious racial mix and no malaria. webTitle: Cricket: Old guard reap rich reward

fields.headline: Old guard reap rich reward
fields.standfirst: Vic Marks looks at England's lack of youthful talent
fields.trailText: Vic Markslooks at England's lack of youthful talent.
fields.body:
The counties can take comfort that the ECB are not squandering their resources, with the announcement of the 12 players with central contracts for the summer of 2001.

There are none of the long-odds hunches that characterised last year's list - no Schofield, no Flintoff, no Ramprakash and no Hick. Instead 10 of the Colombo Test team are included plus Matthew Hoggard and Dominic Cork, who will have to prove his fitness at the start of the season, presumably in a far more stringent fashion than Dean Headley was required to do last spring.

Graeme Hick may be disappointed, but not surprised. It is trickier to anticipate Robert Croft's reaction. Having had a fine tour of Pakistan, he must have been eyeing a lucrative reward for his efforts. However a tirade from the valleys, like the one he mysteriously delivered last autumn, is unlikely especially if he knows what's good for him. Croft is still behind Ashley Giles in the pecking order, though there's not much in it, and he must recognise that England are highly unlikely to play two spinners with any regularity this summer. But he should also be conscious of the fact the Giles has his Achilles heel, namely his Achilles tendon, and that England will certainly require a second spinner next winter. Good reasons to restrain his hwyl.

We can't quibble with the chosen 12, though it should be a source of increasing concern that seven of them are the wrong side of 30. Within 18 months the England team will be required to evolve pretty rapidly. When England gather for the first Test at Lord's against Pakistan on 17 May, I can guarantee that there will be one name there not included in the list, but I don't know who it will be and I doubt whether the selectors do, either. England will want the option of playing seven batsmen when they start the summer's Test campaign and there are only six on the list. It must worry the selectors that the heir apparents in the batting line-up are so hard to identify.

Just over a decade ago we knew that the likes of Atherton, Ramprakash and Crawley would play for England; they were easily earmarked as potential Test players, even though two of them have failed to fulfil that potential. Today it's ominously difficult to predict the next generation. The most talked about young English batsman is Warwickshire's Ian Bell, still 18, who was drafted into the A team when Aftab Habib was forced to leave the Caribbean through injury.

The blunt fact is that Bell has played just one first-class game for his county - a duck in September 1999 - which hints at the paucity of obvious alternative talent. It is not even guaranteed that Bell will start the season in the Warwickshire XI, though he should do. At the very best, given sympathetic handling and a productive season, Bell just might be a candidate for next winter's tours. It may aid his progress if he's not bundled off to play for the Under-19s again. He has done his stint at that level. Other possibilities from the A side include the trio of Asian born cricketers: Habib, who is already 29, Vikram Solanki of Worcestershire and Nottinghamshire's Usman Afzaal. Ian Ward, 27, who was released by Surrey at the age of 18 before his second coming four years later, was the most prolific runscorer in the West Indies. He's combative and well-organised without oozing class.

And then there was John Crawley in the Caribbean, now part of the older generation, who alongside Mark Ramprakash and - who knows? - Hick might still be pining for another go at Test level. Could Andrew Flintoff graduate into a specialist batsman? Nick Knight could also be a candidate if he enjoys a flying start to the season.

Too many names, but not enough quality. All the above have much to play for in the month of May but the future would be rosier if we were able to pluck out two or three clearcut contenders. Sorry to sound so gloomy at a time when we are all supposed to be luxuriating in another Test triumph, but the time to intensify the search is now, a rare occasion when English cricket does not appear to be under the cosh.

England contracted players:

N Hussain (Essex) M A Atherton (Lancashire) A R Caddick (Somerset) D G Cork (Derbyshire) A F Giles (Warwickshire) D Gough (Yorkshire) M J Hoggard (Yorkshire) A J Stewart (Surrey) G P Thorpe (Surrey) M E Trescothick (Somerset) M P Vaughan (Yorkshire) C White (Yorkshire)

webTitle: Champions League: Dracula calling on United

fields.headline: Dracula calling on United
fields.standfirst: Bayern are talking of 'Revenge' in dripping-blood letters. This week there are scores to settle in Europe
fields.trailText: Bayern are talking of 'Revenge' in dripping-blood letters. This week there are scores to settle in Europe.
fields.body:
'Emotion', mused a wise, old American football coach, 'gets in the way of performance.' It's a message you might expect the normally imperturbable Ottmar Hitzfeld to hammer home to his players in advance of Bayern Munich's renewing of acquaintances with Manchester United. Revenge is one of sport's most compelling and dangerous emotions, and in a rematch with the protagonists responsible for the kind of pain sado-masochists wouldn't dream of inflicting on themselves, too much of it could have a profound effect on the Germans' performance at Old Trafford.

But so bludgeoned were Bayern by having the European Cup snatched so unthinkably from them in the last two minutes of the 1999 Final, even Hitzfeld has succumbed to the powerful pull of retribution. As soon as the draw was made, he growled that the flame had been lit. 'My players,' he said, 'are burning for revenge.' You can bet your last mark it will be raging at the epicentre of every Bayern mind as soon as they clap eyes on Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

This is how psyched they are: on the club's official website every story remotely connected with what they call 'the game of all games' is accompanied by an icon of Carsten Jancker's head (chosen because he is the scariest looking by far) adorned with the message 'The Revenge' spelled out in Dracula-style red letters.

Stefan Effenberg, a man who lives as if he is constantly about to detonate, naturally has a few choice words: 'Tell them we will knock them out this time. Tell them we will concentrate for 95 minutes this time.' (Maybe someone should explain this may not be enough according to Old Trafford time.)

Effenberg cannot forget the feeling of coming out of the doping test some two hours after the finale of finales in the Nou Camp, only to see David Beckham strolling past cradling the European Cup. 'It really hit me,' he said. 'I really felt this should have been our cup and I don't want to experience this pain ever again.'

Meanwhile, over in Manchester, Sir Alex Ferguson could afford to be more sanguine. 'Obviously the Bayern game will evoke lots of memories for both sets of supporters, but we have moved on and progressed since that game and I'm sure Bayern are the same. They have that belief of all German teams. They have seven or eight of the players still around from the European Cup Final in Barcelona [it's actually nine: Kahn, Kuffour, Scholl, Jeremies, Fink, Effenberg, Jancker, Salihamidzic, Linke]. The usual suspects are still there. That helps us in terms of familiarity, but we know they are hard to beat and if you give them an inch, they become a hard side to break down, just as in Barcelona.'

Ferguson went on to point out that United, themselves, have a blow to get out of their system: 'We're still grappling with the disappointment of last season's quarter-final defeat against Real Madrid. I was disappointed with our tactics in that game and that is down to me. We went for Real's throats in the game at Old Trafford when we should really have been more patient. If we had been, we'd have been all right because we hammered them. We were too gung-ho and we need to be more patient.

'You have to move on. It could even have been good in a way because you learn from these things. Our aim on Tuesday night is to win the game without losing a goal. If we do that then we have a major chance. I would have no problem at all with a 1-0 win. That would be great for us. Playing at home first suits us because we have gone away first to places like Monaco and Real Madrid but been knocked out at our place.' Two European institutions colliding, both fuelled with so much impetus, this is one tantalising tie. Hang on to your hats.

Usually, around this time of year, the Anyone-But-United brigade are embroiled in colourful debate about whether or not they should be supporting English football's flagbearers. This season, though, such messy moral squabbling has vanished, but because for once there is more than just United creating a stir.

The presence of four English heavyweights in the latter stages of Europe has an impact more profound than the individual ambition brewing at Manchester, Leeds, Arsenal and Liverpool. It is, according to Arsène Wenger, a significant moment for the English game. United apart, it has been a long, humbling journey back from the exile endured during the five-year Heysel ban. The Arsenal manager believes this journey is coming to an end. Nobody, he says, likes to play against English teams any more. 'It is a sign that English football has made a step forward. It has to be repeated again next season, but at least Manchester United won the Champions League, we were in a final - now Liverpool are in a semi-final, Leeds are in there, we are in the last eight.

'I am surprised it took such a long time. When you are not confronted with foreign football you think you are doing all right, and then you are confronted with different football, different thinking. When you play only Premier League clubs and suddenly go into Europe you think, OK, we can play like we play against Southampton and Middlesbrough. Now the players know to be careful, it is a different game, we have to play a different way. That takes time. Since I arrived in '96, English football has changed in a huge manner. We don't realise it because we live in there on a daily basis, but it has changed for the better in every club.'

Those changes were difficult to detect in Arsenal when they performed so dismally against Bayern in their last Champions League outing. Wenger is certain there will be no repeat performance against Valencia. 'Honestly, I still can't understand our performance in Munich. The only thing I know is that the Valencia game will be completely different and the players will show that the way they played in our last game was not good enough for Arsenal. Valencia are favourites, we play at home and we know to qualify we need to make sure we don't miss the first game.' Extra incentive comes from the fact old Arsenal heads are still smarting about the heartbreak of losing the Uefa Cup Final on penalties 21 years ago. To Valencia.

Scores to settle all round, then.

webTitle: Observer review: Chairman Blair's Little Red Book by Steve Bell and Brian Homer

fields.headline: A message from our leader
fields.standfirst: Steve Bell and Brian Homer have written Chairman Blair's Little Red Book. It's blue
fields.trailText: Steve Bell and Brian Homer have written Chairman Blair's Little Red Book. It's blue
fields.body:
Chairman Blair's Little Red Book
Steve Bell and Brian Homer
Methuen £6.99, pp192
Buy it at a discount at BOL

It is possible to illuminate the dark underbelly of the world in which we live in one of two ways. You could a) use the trusty weapons of searing political discourse, an encyclopedic knowledge of philosophy, a close reading of Greek tragedy and deep understanding of the battle between Keynesian economic determinism and the neo-liberalism of Milton Friedman. Or b) tell a few jokes.

Option A involves reading lots of lengthy tomes, years of academic study and, let's face it, brains. Option B involves no more research beyond reading a very short book which actually makes you laugh out loud. The book is by Steve Bell, the Guardian cartoonist, and co-author Brian Homer. It is called Chairman Blair's Little Red Book. It's blue. It's that kind of book.

On the back is a little explanation for those who never bothered with Option A. For younger readers (or Option B-ers, as I like to call them), the book advises: 'Chairman Mao was the communist leader in revolutionary China. We have Blair on the fuel crisis ('fat blokes, we feel your pain'), a homage to Blair's humility ('it is no exaggeration to say that he towers above ordinary men but not by too much. It involves stuffing the book down the said sneerers throat and getting him or her to 'eat his words', that is, Blair's. Maybe that should be his with a capital H.

The Quality of Newness - in which Blair's thoughts on the subject of modernity are laid out over a grinning, cracked smile drawn by Bell. 'New is fresh. New is clean. Britain today. Let's face it. The Long Walkies of J. Dog Du (aka Prescott) - in which a bandaged and grumpy-mouthed Prescott (rendered as a neutered bulldog by Bell) tells of his life being dragged on a trolley behind Blair's bicycle (now held in trust for the nation in the Tate Blair Museum). Such bon mots can be used to repulse those sneerers who insist on revealing their huge knowledge of Greek tragedy etc when discussing politics over dinner and undermining the New Labour project.
