fields.bodyText: It is late afternoon and I am perched on a stool at the Phat Phuk noodle bar. The appropriateness is not lost on me. I have come in search of long, slithery dough in a bowl of savoury broth. Had I been in Soho I would have eaten Japanese, but I'm not, so I plump for Thai. Who cares? It is the slurpy comfort of noodles I crave. They could just have easily have been smooth Chinese Hokkein, transparent Vietnamese beanthread or delicate Japanese somen. All I know is that the wind is icy, the rain is dripping off my nose, the handles of my shopping bag are about to break and I am so hungry I am in a state of suppressed panic. We are not generally good at fast food here. Sure, there was once fish and chips and there are now those revolving doner kebabs that look and taste like a table leg on a spit. But we do not have the history of drawing up a stool and tucking in for 10 minutes while the world walks past. It has nothing to do with the weather. It is more to do with being a nation brought up to believe that it is a bit common to eat in the street. But the noodle bar may be our salvation. You can rush in, attempt to get the cook to understand you and tuck into whatever he thought you asked for in less time than it takes to buy a BLT in Pret A Manger. Noodles are cheap, fast and as hot and spicy as you want. You can eat them gracefully or like a labrador at a water bowl. And when people ask me what is the food of the future, I have just one word. Noodles. I would hate the world to be turned into one big wheat field, but noodles are a cheap and ultimately comforting way to feed. They are, though, the food of the lone eater, either at home or on the sidewalk. Just as it feels right to dole out lasagne verde to a whole table, there is something appropriate about tucking into a bowl of noodles when you are alone. Like Harrison Ford in Blade Runner . There is something complete, almost territorial about a bowl of food all to yourself. Thin noodles don't work as a centre-stage dish to be doled out, earth-mother style, to an assembled crowd. At home I tend to cook more Japanese noodles - udon, ramen, soba and somen - than Chinese or Thai. This is partly due to the ease of the accompanying seaweed and bonito broth (the dashi) that now comes in bottles and sachets from supermarkets and can be ready in seconds. Noodles in a dashi broth spiked with dark soy, coriander, mirin, sake and ginger offer fast, fat-free gustatory satisfaction. Now there's a sentence I never thought would come from my pen. Noodles are as diverse as pasta. Briefly, and sticking to the most popular Japanese varieties (I am not short-changing you, this is a Japanese issue): udon are the coarse-featured peasants of the noodle world. They plump up in a bowl of boiling broth and are as warming and satiating as a baked potato. I try to eat them cold, but feel like a contestant in Endurance , being forced to eat stir-fried worms. For me they are the winter noodle, perfect to pad out a thin chicken broth. Legend has it we must slurp our udon loudly - the reason becomes apparent when the heat sustained in the fat noodles meets a chapped lip. Air drawn in as you slurp helps cool the noodles. Somen are slim, pale, elegant, polite. In noodle terms they are expensive. Bound in thin bundles with black ribbon, they are almost too beautiful to cook. You roll them over in your hands as if they were made of fine porcelain. If they could walk, they would have the tight shuffle of a geisha. These are the noodles I want curled up in a waxed takeaway carton, tossed with matchsticks of cucumber, dark soy and pink pickled ginger. Somen are difficult to negotiate in soup, slipping away from spoon and chopstick. Soba lie somewhere between the sophisticated somen and the proletariat udon. Sharp-edged, nutty soba get their cardboard hue and texture from the buckwheat added to the wheat. Traditionally served cold in a loose pile, they come with a soy and mirin dipping sauce spiked with the heat of green horseradish and the sweetness of white sugar. Then there are the green 'cha' noodles. I am not talking of the dark-spinach green of Italian fettucine, but a green somewhere between sage and jade; the soft matte green that comes from the green-tea powder in the dough. Few lunches are as elegant as a minimalist dish of chilled green soba with a fragile bowl of dashi dipping sauce. But I am happy to eat hot udon like a peasant, sitting on a stool, reading my rain-sodden paper, wolfing down my noodle fix. Japanese elegance and minimalism are fine, but not when it's past my lunchtime and my blood-sugar level is getting dangerously near the 'eat now or pass out' stage. I make the broth in the pan in which I make the teriyaki sauce and cook the spinach in the broth, thus saving two pans. You will still need a dish to marinate the mackerel, a pan to make the sauce, and another to boil the noodles. But this warming soup with its sweet savour is worth it. In the same saucepan (I am only trying to save washing up here, but use a new one if you wish), pour the water and add the dashi granules, the soy and the mirin. Peel the ginger, cut it into thin slices, then shred into fine matchsticks and add to the pan. Bring to the oil, then turn down to a simmer. Put a large pan of water on to boil, salt it as you would for pasta, then add the noodles and boil vigorously for about 8 minutes or until the noodles are firm but tender. fields.headline: Noto Sushi,  London NW9
fields.standfirst: Oriental City, located in the quintessential suburb of Colindale, houses a sushi bar so Japanese it makes you forget you're in north London. Jay Rayner finds he can't say no to Noto
fields.trailText: Oriental City, located in the quintessential suburb of Colindale, houses a sushi bar so Japanese it makes you forget you're in north London. Jay Rayner finds he can't say no to Noto.
fields.body:
Telephone: 020 8200 1189
Address: Noto Sushi, Oriental City, 399 Edgware Road, Colindale, London NW9.
Lunch for two costs £30, if you try really hard.

What can I say about Colindale that has not already been said? That its hanging gardens are a wonder to behold and its rococo architecture a delight; that it has spawned many of the nation's dreamers and provided inspiration for its artists and poets. Colindale: Edgware's Latin Quarter. There. None of that has been said before. Mind you, it's all complete cobblers, which probably explains why. There's nothing wrong with Colindale. It's just that, were you to flick through the guidebooks in search of a good day out, you would find the chapter detailing thrilling things to do in Colindale on the short side. There's the British Museum's newspaper library. It's not far from Stanmore. Er, that's it. Colindale is the suburbs in spades. It's on the edge but not at all edgy.

Curiously, it is that very suburbanness, that utilitarian city blandness which detaches Colindale from the London of which it is a part, which makes it the perfect location for Noto Sushi. You want to eat good sushi in a place that is not noticeably British, and Colindale does the trick. It helps, of course, that this bar which serves nothing other than raw fish - no teriyaki, no tempura, no dumplings - should occupy a site in the middle of Oriental City, a large, no-frills shopping centre dedicated to the food and culture of the Far East. The place is as in-yer-face Asian as it can be and, while local office workers use its impressive food court at lunchtimes, there's no doubting that it is really designed for the expat Japanese, Korean, Chinese and Indonesian communities. The rest of us are mere interlopers, though very welcome ones.

Noto sits off to one side of that food court, an elegant little shack with its own seats at its own marble bar beneath its own unnecessary roof of authentic Japanese ceramic tiles. Behind it is the cavernous Oriental supermarket, complete with a huge Japanese fishmonger's where you can buy the raw materials of the lunch just eaten. All the food is produced to order by Japanese chefs and is quite simply some of the best sushi I have ever eaten. For those of you who wanted to see me sentenced to eat at an Angus Steak House for the rest of my life for refusing to condemn the pricing at Ubon in my review a month or two back - my, how that made you cross - Noto also happens to be eye-poppingly good value.

I went with my brother Adam, a regular visitor to Japan who adores the food and who comes here to get a fix of what he swears is the real thing. I have no reason to doubt him. There's a long list of various nigiri and maki sushi as well as sashimi and hand rolls, all priced at between 90p and £2.80 per piece. There are also a number of set meals, and from these Adam chose the Tokujo-chirashi, at £15. It was one of the two most expensive dishes on the menu. (I had the other one.) Even so, the value was immense: a large bowl filled with chirashi rice, sprinkled with toasted sesame seeds and then layered with every kind of fish in the chilled counter. There was salmon and sweet prawn, surf clam and sea urchin, vinegared snapper and tiny orange fish roe. There was even some oily tuna, which sells for almost £70 a kilo up at the fishmonger's. It looked beautiful and, Adam said, it tasted terrific.

I went for the lunchtime special menu (also at £15), which laid down the kind of challenge I cannot resist: you may order anything you like from an extensive list which includes almost everything, bar the oily tuna. However, you may do so for only an hour and, if there is anything left over at the end of those 60 minutes, you must pay for it at the piece meal rate (so to speak). It is, depending on your view, either an incentive to over-eat or an incentive not to over-order. It gave me the opportunity to order four pieces of one of my passions, grilled eel, tied to the rice with a ribbon of seaweed and glistening with a slick of sweet, soy-based sauce.

What distinguishes the sushi here - the tuna and salmon, scallop and clam and snapper, all of which I tried - is not just the glorious freshness of the fish but the rice. All too often the rice in British-bought sushi, particularly the stuff found in those pre-packed supermarket containers, is in a cold, solid lump. Here it is just warm, and the grains are almost separate, yet clinging to each other as if for company. A maki roll becomes a set of distinct textures as your teeth first break through the taut membrane of the seaweed, then find the yielding rice and finally hit the soft fish at the centre. The spicy tuna rolls, the fish glazed with a light salty chilli sauce, were particularly good.

It was almost revelatory and, as I say, heroically good value. You would find out how good if you went to Harrods, where Noto has a similar stand. There the chirashi costs a whopping £39. A piece of oily tuna sushi costs £3.50 instead of £2, and scallops cost £2.50 instead of £1.40. Doubtless that is Harrods taking its cut rather than Noto inflating its prices. In my book, it simply makes Colindale far sexier a destination than Knightsbridge could ever be.

Contact Jay Rayner on issuejay.rayner@observer.co.uk.

fields.headline: Alan's 10 years of lonely torment
fields.standfirst: Plight of elderly man locked in unheated attic and ignored by authorities exposes failure in care laws
fields.trailText: The plight of an elderly man locked in unheated attic and ignored by authorities exposes failures in care laws.
fields.body:
If Alan could have shouted for help, there were plenty of people nearby who would have heeded his call: the police kept an eye on the quiet town of Kettering from their HQ opposite his bedroom window, the magistrates' court was next door and the church on the corner offered counselling and home visits to anyone who asked.

But Alan, who has a mental age of 18 months, could not tell anyone about his misery or the pain he was in. For 10 years he was locked in an unheated attic room at the London Road residential care home, left curled up on a plastic-covered chair in a small, ripped T-shirt, lying in his own urine and faeces.

When he was found during a routine annual inspection by Northamptonshire council in February 1999, one officer said she had never seen even an animal kept in such an appalling state. Another said his condition was an affront to human dignity.

Alan, dumped by his own county of Essex in the Northamptonshire home in 1989, was an 'out-of-county placement' - one of Britain's elderly abandoned, forced into isolation and vulnerable to abuse.

This was not an isolated case. Hundreds of highly vulnerable people are moved hundreds of miles without their informed consent to an alien neighbourhood where friends, family and carers find it hard to visit. These people are forced to rely on social workers from their home county travelling across the country frequently enough to spot any abuse before it starts.

But a total lack of legislation dictating the duty of care owed to out-of-county placements by their home authority means that these people are all too often failed both by their social workers and their host county.

Despite a recent White Paper forcing through a number of positive changes in the standard of care all residents can expect, the Department of Health admits the care owed to out-of-county placements is still obscured by 'very muddy water'. 'The home county has responsibility to keep an eye on adults in foreign care homes,' said a spokeswoman. 'But in practice, if someone moves far away, it's not very practical to send a social worker all the way across the country to check on them.'

Essex has about 240 people living in residential care homes as far away as Aberdeen, Cornwall and North Wales.

'We already know that abuse in residential care homes is far more common than most people like to admit,' said Ginny Jenkin, director of the campaigning organisation Action on Elder Abuse. 'But when vulnerable people, especially those who may have difficulty expressing themselves, are moved away from anyone who has direct responsibility for them, you increase the possibility of abuse enormously.' Alan had not received a single visit or inquiry from Essex since his care package was agreed with the Northamptonshire home 10 years ago. Routine and announced annual inspections by Northamptonshire council into the Kettering home concentrated on the home's administration record rather than on the quality of life of the residents and failed to discover Alan.

The Registered Home Tribunal established after Alan's discovery also found that the owner of the home, Edwin Freeman, had appropriated £19,000 of residents' money, had treated other residents in unacceptable ways and falsified medical records.

In addition, they reported that Freeman's wife, Sara, should never have been registered to run the home and was 'clearly unfit' to continue as a registered person.

'The conditions in which this resident was kept were an affront to human dignity,' the tribunal reported in January. 'For years, local authorities who should have been in a position to protect his human rights had ignored him and appear to have failed in their duty of care.

'He was subjected to degrading treatment; he was deprived of his liberty; his dignity was ignored, his right to property was compromised because of the way his finances were dealt with. He was in pain with a dental abscess and no effective action was taken to treat him.' The Freemans and their daughter, Charlotte Goodwin, manager at the home, were deregistered.

Both Northamptonshire and Essex authorities have set up an independent inquiry into the case. Alan has now moved into a small residential home in Essex with three other inmates. His condition, which Freeman claimed was hopeless, has improved considerably under intense training.

fields.headline: Tea and sympathy
fields.standfirst: The quiet simplicity of a Japanese tea house garden brings a whole new meaning to an afternoon cuppa
fields.trailText: The quiet simplicity of a Japanese tea house garden brings a whole new meaning to an afternoon cuppa.
fields.body:
Here's a funny thing. I went to a Japanese tea ceremony in a housing estate on the edge of Cardiff last week. I've scarce done anything stranger. It was not so much the cultural dislocation of the tea ceremony itself - although that takes some accommodating. I've been to a tea ceremony before but that was a full-on experience, heavy with the confused seriousness of the student. This was an entirely private affair being held by a group of Japanese women living in Cardiff. Their solemnity was punctuated by smiles and a lightness that tiptoed around the intricately cramped ritual.

I had been instructed to wear a suit and collar and tie (this latter detail the first time for five years) as a mark of respect, but after the briefest of introductions to my hosts - the mistress of the tea ceremony and her two assistants, all dressed in exquisite flowered kimonos and as exotic and tiny as hummingbirds, I was taken into a dining room engulfed by its table and perfectly aligned chairs and told to get my suit off and put on a navy-blue kimono. I don't know what it looked like, but it felt lovely.

The ceremony took place in the sitting room, three-piece suite pushed back against the wall and the carpet covered with tatami mats. Everything to do with the tea ceremony, every imaginable detail, was weighted with significance. I commented on the vase with a spray of chaenomeles and Viburnum tinus , both from the entirely occidental and, by any standards, rather dull garden out the back through the French windows.

The gardens outside the front windows were entirely accidental and dull. This was, it seemed, not a Japanese thing but a second-rate British landscaper thing. I was struck by the random, plodding quality to the front gardens, devoid of delineation or demarcation, just chance meetings of grass, shrubs and birches with a sad fringe of daffodils. This was a garden as soft pavement - garden as mowable sidewalk, or as vehicle/domestic interface. I was embarrassed, in the way that one is, lest my Japanese hosts should think that this was an English garden and that I, as professional English gardener, would be swallowed in the same bland mouthful.

While ladling water from the pot into the delicate bowls, the tea-mistress said she had considered using daffodils as a nod towards the arrival of spring, but there were so many daffodils in Wales and everything about the tea ceremony should be refined and special. Hence Viburnum tinus , which is a refined and special plant in Japanese gardens.

The sweets, of course, had import beyond their taste. In Japan the harbinger and star of spring is the cherry. Cherry flowers seem to work on the Japanese psyche in the same way that cow parsley or the May blossom does on the rural English. The heart leaps. These economic migrants, wives of Japanese businessmen at some of the 56 Japanese factories in Wales, were quietly pining for cherry blossom and sweet spring, just as I have wept bitterly in November for May. Maybe I should make bluebell, cow parsley and primrose sweets to see me through the dark days. In Japan, tea-house gardens - called roji - were designed partly to be appreciated while sitting in the house and partly as a passage that led to the building. The tea ceremony is a form of meditation, and the view of the garden is part of that process. Just as the tea houses are carefully rustic, the garden is likely to be deliberately gentle and unimposing, expressing the same spirit as the ceremony itself. A dynamic is often created by planting or placing objects on an imaginary diagonal line, creating a pleasing visual tension. Trees and shrubs are carefully planted to create veils or layers of view, often with larger trees, stones or bushes in the foreground and smaller ones at the margins, creating the impression of infinite horizons. The plum or cherry blossom dominate in spring, but not overpoweringly so. There would certainly not be any daffodils or other bulbs to compete or dilute the effect of the blossom.

Like the ceremony itself, every branch, stone or bush is contrived and controlled to attain the desired effect - which is of a completely natural landscape. The Japanese understand what the West sometimes struggles with - namely that all gardening is simultaneously a celebration and a perversion of nature. In Britain, we have a tendency to use the garden as a stage on which to enact the performance of the gardener as much as that of the plants. 'Good' gardeners achieve obviously difficult and spectacular results. But in the best Japanese gardens, man works ceaselessly in order that no work should appear to have taken place at all.

Shintoism determines that there is parity between man and nature - including inanimate objects such as stones and water. Thus the reverence for special stones, cherry blossom, maple leaf, moss and gravel as water. All work is aimed at capturing the essence of the plant, the stone, the place itself.

The path to the tea house will always be winding or zigzagged and made of irregular slabs or wooden blocks. Before the ceremony, the tea master will apparently carefully wet the stones of the path, so the guests can appreciate their natural beauty. That this makes the slabs slippery and awkward is considered a virtue, because it helps concentrate the mind on the approach to the ceremony - or else you fell flat on your backside. By slowing you down and forcing you to concentrate fully on the matter in hand - walking - you empty yourself of extraneous mind-clutter. The path is marked by objects of contemplation to create the sense of pilgrimage. Unlike the famous Zen gravel gardens, these markers are unlikely to be stone groups or water features. They might be a bush or stone in among moss. There would be very few flowers and never the massed florification of the archetypal English midsummer border.

For myself, the most important reminder I get from Japanese gardens is to value the space between things as much as the things themselves. Once, when I was officially loopy and seeing a psychotherapist, the mind-doctor got very excited by my account of how the significance of the space between inanimate objects would sometimes take on more apparent life and meaning than the objects themselves. But now, officially sane, I see this in my own garden every day.

We all define what things are by what they are not as much as anything else, and in a garden the gap between two trees, hedges and plants in a border will tell you as much about the plants as its physical self. In some Japanese gardens, such as the kare-sansui 'dry' gardens of which Ryoan-ji is probably the best known, space becomes the strongest element in the garden. Nothing is more profound or beautiful to the enlightened Zen mind than emptiness. The Japanese have learnt how to fill a garden with emptiness better than anyone else.

Every gardener has experienced moments that in any culture translate into enlightenment. I was interested to read in Roger Phillips and Nicky Foy's excellent A Photographic Garden History (£14.99, Macmillan) that the kare-sansui gardens were not made as contemplative aids to but were created by those who had attained enlightenment and had tried to express that experience in their gardens. This raises them to art as well as humanising what might otherwise seem impenetrable.

fields.headline: A blow struck for dignity
fields.standfirst: The Health Secretary's pledge to protect older patients is welcome. But it is scandalously overdue
fields.trailText: The Health Secretary's pledge to protect older patients is welcome. But it is scandalously overdue, writes Martin Bright.
fields.body:
On a bleak September day three-and-a half years ago, my 88-year-old grandmother, Irene Emmings, lay fighting for her life in a Bath hospital. After suffering a stroke, she had been rushed into the accident and emergency department where doctors stabilised her condition. At this point, she was abandoned by a system that had lost the will to care.

After hours on a trolley in a corridor, she was eventually placed on a mixed ward where nurses had no idea that she needed a drip to help her diabetes or drops for her glaucoma. For five days, she was left without food or drink because a speech therapist was unavailable to test her swallowing reflex.

Things were little better when she was eventually transferred to a women's geriatric ward. On one occasion, relatives found her with her head on a pillow sodden from a leaking drip and on another lying in her own faeces. Unable to speak, in her desperation, she left notes by her bed about the neglect and abuse she had endured. She wrote of how telephone calls from relatives were left unanswered as the phone was left ringing all night and how staff tried to force-feed her through the nose without her consent.

What she didn't know was that doctors had written 'Do Not Resuscitate' on her file; if she had had another stroke or heart attack, the hospital would not have tried to save her.

When this newspaper published details of her experiences, we thought it was an extreme case, but the response from hundreds of readers showed that her treatment was horribly and scandalously unexceptional. The 'Dignity on the Ward' campaign which followed, backed by Help the Aged, led the then Health Secretary Frank Dobson to intervene directly. He promised immediate reform of the way older people were treated. In an article in The Observer, he pledged to establish a National Service Framework for an end to ageism in hospitals.

Last week, to the joy and genuine surprise of campaigners for older people, the framework appeared, backed by £120 million to refurbish wards for older people. Dobson's successor, Alan Milburn, has called it a 'radical blueprint' and for once those tired words appear to be borne out by the document. By the end of 2004, the NHS will undertake an additional 70,000 cataract operations, 16,000 hip and knee replacements and unclog 3,000 arteries - all on patients over 65.

Most profoundly, the framework commits the NHS to provide care 'regardless of age and on the basis of clinical need alone'. By October, all hospitals will be expected to end rationing on the basis of age, a welcome return to the founding principles of the health service.

But behind the scenes, the health professionals and charities which backed the Dignity on the Ward campaign are worried. Where will the extra nurses come from to care for the 88-year-olds who no longer have 'Do Not Resuscitate' written on their files? Who will pay for the doctors to carry out thousands of extra operations?

A devastating report published on the Department of Health website last week outlined the monumental nature of the task ahead. The Standing Nursing and Midwifery Advisory Committee said that over-65s were still being denied the basic rights to privacy and independence. It also voiced 'great concern' at persistent negative attitudes to older patients, the motivation behind The Observer 's new campaign - the Elderly Abandoned.

Alan Milburn knows that it will need far more than a lick of paint on geriatric wards to improve conditions for older patients. Last week's report made it clear that the NHS was still 'failing far too often to meet their basic needs for food, fluid, rest activity and elimination [going to the toilet]. Their psychological, mental health and rehabilitation needs are often ignored... it remains the case that staff lack the basics - clean bed linen, pillows and dressings - to allow for the humane treatment of older patients.'

We should not belittle the genuine attempt at reform represented by the National Service Framework, but many specialists now believe ageism is so entrenched that it will take more than a blueprint, however radical, and a set of targets, however ambitious, to transform the culture of a lack of respect for the elderly.

It is a sign of how far we have drifted from the idea of universal health care that the Secretary of State needs to make a public statement that older patients in the NHS should have equal rights. Two-thirds of those using the NHS are over the age of 65. Instructing hospitals to take their needs into account is not far removed from telling those who run Disneyland that it would be good if they catered for the needs of children.

fields.headline: That's entertainment...
fields.standfirst: A leading Harvard professor has blamed commercial TV for the collapse of civic life in the US, Steve Barnett asks if deregulation will lead us down the same path
fields.trailText: April 1: A leading Harvard professor has blamed commercial TV for the collapse of civic life in the US, writes Steve Barnett.
fields.body:
In one of those whirlwind celebrity tours that American scholars are so good at, Harvard professor Robert Putnam was doing the rounds of chat shows and conferences last week to promote his book, Bowling Alone.

His basic thesis, that civic life in the US is falling apart, is supported by a prodigious collection of statistics demonstrating that Americans volunteer less, socialise less, eat together less and generally have less interest in community and political life than at any time in living memory.

And why are Americans no longer leading scout troops, joining bowling leagues or inviting folks round for dinner? Because they're watching the box. With an equally impressive array of facts, figures and experimental evidence, Putnam demonstrates that TV is probably the main culprit for the collapse of American community life.

Moreover, we are talking specifically about entertainment shows. Putnam says: 'It is precisely those Americans most marked by this dependence on televised entertainment who were most likely to have dropped out of civic and social life.'

He names names: Miami Vice, soap operas such as Dallas - both still being rerun - and reality TV shows, such as America's Most Wanted.

Put to one side the question of whether the figures would stack up in Britain. The basic issue of broadcasting's ability not just to inform but to stimulate involvement in civic and political life has always been one of the driving arguments for a public service framework. It is impossible to prove, of course. But what Putnam has done is to demonstrate that the opposite case - a system of completely deregulated, commercialised, entertainment-driven television contributing to political apathy - appears to hold.

Where does that leave the Government's deregulatory White Paper on communications? Here we have a Government eager at every opportunity to emphasise good citizenship, to raise levels of participation, to make us community-minded, to get the vote out. Yet one of the primary means, apparently, for achieving just that is being progressively thrown open to the marketplace.

It gets worse. Apart from the consequences of reducing the public service requirements on commercial television, there is another factor directly affecting TV content: who will actually own commercial TV in Britain? I raise this question because of a little-noticed recommendation in the culture select committee's report two weeks ago. It wants to abolish controls on cross-media ownership unless 'the case for such controls is overwhelming and enduring'. At the press conference to launch the report, Labour MP John Maxton said they could think of no overwhelming objections.

What was even more astonishing was Gerald Kaufman's response when asked the inevitable 'M' question. Would he not be concerned about Rupert Murdoch - who is currently banned from owning a terrestrial TV licence because he controls more than 20 per cent of the national press - launching an immediate takeover bid for Channel 5, or even ITV?

Kaufman was unmoved. BSkyB's share of TV viewing was declining, he said. Sky News was at least as impartial as other broadcasters. And (I wrote this bit down to be absolutely sure): 'Murdoch's proportion of newspaper circulation is not that big.' He didn't quite go so far as to say that Murdoch was really a philanthropic sweetie who is always kind to animals, but did insist that he was 'often introduced as the ogre' into such debates.

I don't think Murdoch is an ogre, though I am intrigued that a committee with seven Labour MPs out of 11 members appears to be so unconcerned about a man who spent the best part of 18 years heaping poisonous vitriol on their party being allowed to control parts of mainstream British television. They have clearly been lulled into a false sense of security by fulsome expressions of current newspaper support for Labour.

For the moment, I am less interested in Murdoch's politics than in his concept of what TV is about. If his Fox Network is anything to go by, it is entirely entertainment- driven. Not just entertainment, but mindless, often violent and socially pointless entertainment, which is pure escapism.

His contempt for the notion of public service is well known, and his TV executives are under no doubt about their obligations: push out the boundaries of social acceptability, be brash, be loud, be gruesome, cause a stir, do whatever it takes to grab and hold your audience. Even in the cultural wasteland which is (with a few magnificent exceptions) American TV, Fox stands out as particularly vacuous.

Putnam is, it is said, being courted by Downing Street. If so, I hope they are listening to his conclusions about the socially corrosive influence of American entertainment television. Perhaps then they will pay a little more attention to how we can bolster TV's role in the nation's civic life.

A very good start would be resisting any ill-informed siren calls to let that nice, supportive Mr Murdoch have a slice of our television cake.

Steve Barnett is Professor of Communications at the University of Westminster.

fields.headline: My date with Oscar
fields.standfirst: Nominated as best screenwriter for Billy Elliot, I had my acceptance speech ready. Then Tom Hanks ruined everything...
fields.trailText: Nominated as best screenwriter for Billy Elliot, I had my acceptance speech ready. Then Tom Hanks ruined everything...
fields.body:
13 February

I get a call from my mate Max, who got a call from our mate Trevor, who got a call from Joe who was watching Sky. I have been nominated for an Oscar.

15 February

Home. The buzzer rings and I let in a Fed Ex man. He comes bow-legged up our stairs with a huge box. It is a present from Universal Studios. I am delighted. This is pay day. The film has made about $100 million worldwide and I've not seen a penny, but now the famous largesse of Hollywood studios will act as some compensation. Now they realise my worth.

I rip open the immense box, expecting a telly, a case of wine or something comparable. I discover a water pistol, some banana-flavoured Curious George chewable 'candy' and some dominoes. I wonder if the box was meant for Jamie Bell. I quickly calculate the combined value of the gifts and realise it is a small fraction of the cost of shipping. I tip out all the polystyrene stuffing in a vain search for a book token. Nothing, except a letter telling me the person who makes the shortest acceptance speech on the night will win a telly.

21 February

Every single person I have met in the last week has asked what I will be wearing. What the fuck do they think I will be wearing? I tell people I will don a miner's lamp and carry a canary. No one finds this funny. I am approached by Angela who tells me she will help fix me up with some designer togs for the main event - she got a complete wardrobe for Guy Ritchie and the blokes from Snatch so I shouldn't be a problem. She says she'll be back in touch.

I go home and give the box of toys to the children next door. Their excited faces drop when they pull out the banana-flavoured Curious George chewable 'candy', and they disappear without a thank you.

17 March

Only a week to go. I suddenly realise I still have nothing to wear. I call Angela who explains that she has called all her usual designers. After the initial excitement that they have the opportunity to dress an Oscar nominee, they suddenly find themselves short on stock when they discover I am a writer. Maybe Oswald Boateng will do something at cost. I get excited until I realise exactly what Oswald will cost. While I'd love a proper Boateng suit, I get queasy about shelling out for a dinner jacket. Anyway, I'd have to go in for a fitting which is impossible as I am in Newcastle.

21 March

I leave for LA tomorrow. I still have nothing to wear. I panic and go to an ex-hire shop. For 90 quid, I get a tin flute, bow tie and cummerbund. What's more, being 100 per cent polyester, it is creaseproof and stands up on its own. The proprietor warns me against naked flames. Talk to Stephen Daldry who tells me his filming is running over and he might not make it out. He will try to get there at the last minute.

22 March

We fly to LA. There is a telly you can watch when you're on the bog. I have a gander at the local news. The stand outside the Oscars has fallen down and a few of the Mexican labourers are in intensive care.

24 March

We discover a stretch limo has been booked to ferry us to the Universal nominees' party at Il Ceilo's. As we are getting into the limo, I see Il Ceilo's - it is right across the street. I realise that because of the one-way system, it would take about five minutes to get there by stretch limo - and about 30 seconds to walk. We decide to walk but agree not to tell the car company so the driver can get a full night's wages.

At the party, I find Julie Walters and Jamie Bell. While I chat with Julie, Jamie works the room. One minute he is joshing with Russell Crowe, the next Julia Roberts is stroking his cheek. I get stuck with a part-time dentist who used to rewrite scripts for Roger Corman. He tells me we should collaborate on a script about football hooliganism. I take his card and promise to email. Jamie, by this point, has been invited to a party at DreamWorks. Even though I spent all last year writing a script for Mr Spielberg, I had no idea of this party's existence. Though Jamie insists I should come anyway, I decide to have an early night.

25 March

The big day. Stephen Daldry arrives on a cargo plane from Frankfurt having only finished his filming at 7pm yesterday night. I wake at 11am and stick the TV on. ABC is running a 24-hour Oscar show. Apparently, people have been queuing for 11 days to sit on the stands to watch people go in. I fish around in my haversack and retrieve my DJ. It emerges completely uncreased.

My girlfriend Christine and I go downstairs for the limo. The driver tells us that although the Shrine Auditorium is 15 minutes away there is an expected journey time of two hours. However, there is some lukewarm champagne in an 'Oscar box' in the back. We crack it open. As we get close to the auditorium, the traffic slows to a jam. I look out of the sunroof and see rows of limos four abreast stretching into infinity. Along the route, there are lines of fans waving banners. I see groups of bearded men with posters of Jamie Bell. Then groups of fundamentalist Christians with signs saying: 'Go to the Oscars, Burn in Hell.' I wind down my window to get a better look. A man in a devil suit shouts at me to 'repent now'. We move slowly past an indigent man with no teeth bearing a sign saying: 'Out of work - will do anything. Business cards accepted.' His hopeful look sends a shiver down my spine. I wind the window up and return to the hermetic world of over-indulgence and conspicuous privilege.

We finally arrive. Unfortunately, we've got split up from Jamie and Julie but we can hear people screaming their names. After the metal detectors and the body search, we are ushered on to the red carpet, which is a sort of corral. We shuffle off inside and the tawdry reality of the event kicks in. The airy glitz of the cakewalk gives way to the gloom of the Shrine Auditorium foyer. Then you realise that while there may be, say, 100 stars here, maybe double that if you include the character actors, there are 6,000 neckbenders all aggressively jostling for canapés and warm wine. I try to find Stephen and Jamie but it is impossible in the crush, so we take our seats.

I have not had time to be nervous as the surface detail of the trip has been so diverting. Now it actually hits that there is a one-in-five chance that I will have to get up in front of a billion people and say something cogent, and I have not prepared a speech. I decide to go for the free TV so to calm my nerves I repeat the mantra: 'Thanks very much. Please send me the telly.'

The ceremony starts. The usual twaddle but I am excited that I'll get to see Randy Newman. The first half-hour is remarkably pleasant, until I realise we are only on to Best Sound Design and there are 20 more categories to go. The speeches are interminable. Most winners have thrown caution to the wind and are thanking dead relatives and defiantly shouting over the band as it sweeps in to usher them off. I can take no more. I go off for a pee. The lobby is filled with disgruntled nominees drowning their sorrows or nervously sneaking off for a pee. I hurry back to discover I've missed Randy Newman.

Several hours pass. Björk comes off stage wearing a swan costume and sits in front of me. I am now beginning to get genuinely bored. Around the hall are several TV screens and you see how much better everything looks on telly. The rather scruffy reality is somehow transformed into glitz.

Bob Dylan is announced and I sit up hopefully. Unfortunately, he is in Sydney. Before I know it, Tom Hanks is announcing my category. A camera is stuck in my face, but before I have time to be sick, Hanks reads out the name Cameron Crowe. Relief sweeps over me, accompanied by a vague sense that I'd been conned. How could I have taken it all so seriously? I'd even prepared a speech, for god's sake.

Then off to the Governor's Ball. After Daldry has done sufficient networking, we all head off to the Vanity Fair party. Stephen immediately passes out and Jamie and I watch the party on the television. Just a few feet away, we could see impossibly hip people having the time of their lives - Tom Hanks, Puff Daddy, you name them - but we seemed stuck in another stationary stretch of limos. The driver thought it'd only be another half-hour and he'd have us in.

Half an hour later, we decide to wake Stephen and risk walking. We fight our way through the crowds and get to the entrance. The security team bars our way. To my delight, Harvey Weinstein joins us in the queue and is also refused entry. Luckily, Stephen's friend Lucy knows one of the doormen from a club in New York and we are then ushered through.

We stand like someone's parents at a teenage birthday party. I'm next to a tall black man who appears to be in drag. Jamie points out that this is Whitney Houston. Puff Daddy and Snoop Doggy Dog come over and give their 'respect' to Jamie, who handles it all with great aplomb. For some reason, Zoe Ball is there and also gives her respect to Jamie, but by this time we'd had had enough. We struggle to get out through the people struggling to get in and emerge into the night.

The men with beards are there shouting for Jamie. We decide to ignore them. One bearded man tries to make a run for it, but is wrestled to the ground by security. The limo arrives and we all collapse into the hotel, exhausted.

I wake promptly at five in the morning. The telly's still on and there is Stephen Daldry still at the party. I look across the room and my suit is standing in the corner. I vow that if I ever get nominated again I'll be doing it in front of the telly with a take-out curry.

webTitle: Prescott blasts free-rider Bush for Kyoto pull-out

fields.headline: Prescott blasts free-rider Bush for Kyoto pull-out
fields.trailText: The Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott has launched a powerful attack on President George W. Bush for pulling out of the Kyoto agreement on climate and pollution, accusing the United States of 'free-riding' on the rest of the world and sitting in 'glorious isolation'.
fields.body:
The Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott has launched a powerful attack on President George W. Bush for pulling out of the Kyoto agreement on climate and pollution, accusing the United States of 'free-riding' on the rest of the world and sitting in 'glorious isolation'.

The angry attack came as a European Environment Ministers' meeting in Sweden declared that they would go ahead with the Kyoto agreement to cut greenhouse gases with or without America. Protests against the US erupted across European cap itals, with calls for boycotts against US oil companies. Bush also faced mounting opposition at home.

Writing in today's Observer, Prescott, who led the UK's delegation in the climate change talks, said the US 'must know that it cannot pollute the world while free-riding on action by everyone else'.

Bush last week formally confirmed that the US - the largest greenhouse gas polluter in the world - would pull out of the international effort to cut emissions of the gases that lead to global warming, particularly carbon dioxide.

His main reason was concern about the effect on jobs in America, which has 4 per cent of the world's population and emits a quarter of the world's carbon dioxide.

In Sweden, Ministers insisted that they would push ahead with or without the US. 'The Kyoto protocol is still alive, contrary to what has been said from the other side of the Atlantic,' said Sweden's Environment Minister, Kjell Larsson. 'No individual country has the right to declare a multilateral agreement dead.'

The 1997 treaty calls for countries to agree on legally binding targets for curbing heat-trapping greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels.

webTitle: Vaz collapse rules out election role

fields.headline: Vaz collapse rules out election role
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the beleaguered Europe Minister, will be out of action during the election campaign having been ordered to rest following a health scare.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the beleaguered Europe Minister, will be out of action during the election campaign having been ordered to rest following a health scare.

Vaz collapsed in his office after an interview on Thursday and has been undergoing tests on his heart.

Although he was discharged from hospital yester day, he has been relieved of all official duties by the Foreign Office and by party whips for eight weeks.

His duties are being shared out among other Ministers in his department and he will not carry out engagements.

Labour party sources said Vaz was likely to receive help on the campaign trail in his own seat, Leicester East, as he is not expected to be fit again until June. He has a safe majority of more than 18,000.

The health scare will increase speculation about Vaz's political future. He has been under intense pressure for months, both over a report by parliamentary sleazebuster Elizabeth Filkin into allegations about his business dealings and over his involvement in the saga of the millionaire Hinduja brothers and their passports.

Although he was cleared by the Hammond inquiry into the passports affair and cleared of all but one allegation by Filkin, insiders expected him to be sacked or demoted after the election. There has been speculation he might even give up his seat.

Last night Labour party sources said Vaz had made 'absolutely no move towards even thinking of standing down'. Support would be provided on the stump in Leicester if he was unable to go out campaigning properly himself, they added.

fields.headline: Environment
fields.standfirst: The greenest election yet - or just so much hot air?
fields.trailText: The greenest election yet - or just so much hot air?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground
With Tony Blair leading the 'greenest-ever' British government, the Conservatives' new 'blue-green' agenda and the LibDems' claim to be ahead on the issue, the parties are taking the green vote seriously. A coalition of green groups - with a combined membership of two million - has set a five-pledge test for candidates, but it looks too tough for the mainstream parties.

Success: Climate-change levy on business has reduced emissions.
Failure: Timidity in seeking consumer change.

Labour: Michael Meacher
 Sixty per cent of new homes on 'brownfield' sites.
 Double energy-efficiency spending, with government support for new renewable energy markets.
'Britain can lead in the coming green industrial revolution - being green can be good for business'

Conservatives: Damian Green
 Scrap national house-building targets.
 Give local councils new powers to stop unwanted greenfield development. Abolish climate change levy on business.
'Labour wants to pour a million tonnes of concrete over our countryside'

LibDems: Don Foster
 Create 'green tax' commission and audit the Budget for environmental impact.
 Not replace nuclear power stations when they reach the end of their operating life.
'We need to safeguard our future by taxing pollution, not taxing people'

But what's the real issue?
Charles Secrett, Director, Friends of the Earth
'A lot of the most controversial issues have been environmental - GM foods, collapse of the railways and fuel protests. The fact that the Government has not seen it like that is one of the reasons why they have failed to convince the public that they have a grip on the situation. Our greatest fear is that the main parties will continue in this vein in the election campaign and wrongly assume that the environment ranks low on people's list of priorities.'

fields.headline: Blair's other woman
fields.standfirst: If, as expected, she becomes the Prime Minister's political secretary after the next election, it will make her the most powerful unelected woman since Lady Falkender ruled Harold Wilson's kitchen cabinet
fields.trailText: If, as expected, she becomes the Prime Minister's political secretary after the next election, it will make her the most powerful unelected woman since Lady Falkender ruled Harold Wilson's kitchen cabinet
fields.body:
An aquaintance of Anji Hunter was once standing idly in the Central Lobby of the Houses of Parliament, the busy hub of public and political life at Westminster, when he spotted a cameo being enacted across the large and crowded hall. The Prime Minister's special assistant, a tall and striking woman with considerable presence, was talking to an elderly trade union leader - but there was more to their encounter than that. He could see from their mutual body language that she was exuding a physical charm and it was obvious that the man with whom she was in conversation was enchanted. The unnoticed observer smiled ruefully to himself. 'She was doing the job on him,' he said, 'and I smiled because until then I had thought she liked me.'

He had witnessed a perfect illustration of the social skills and political usefulness of Anji Hunter, confidante and trusted aide to Tony Blair. She has a chameleon's ability to go anywhere, to meet anyone and to delight them, middle-aged men a speciality. People instinctively like her because she is lively and fun and vibrant and, in consequence, they want to do what she wants them to do because they want to please her. She has a confident and very un-English sexuality.

There is testimony that formerly right-wing men so adore Anji that they have been won round to Tony. They see a woman with a mischievous grin and a pert line in asides who is so obviously genuine and truthful that they cannot help but be impressed in turn by the man to whom she offers her loyalty.

It is the most important public role she performs for the Blair administration and the brilliance with which she executes it is what everyone mentions in their second breath. That is when they have already spoken of the depth of that personal loyalty to the Prime Minister.

She is called 'the other woman in Tony Blair's life', 'the second most important woman in Downing Street', 'the gatekeeper' - because she decides who gets in to see Tony Blair and who does not - and 'Marcia Falkender without the politics'.

One senior party figure calls her 'Tony's comfort blanket' because she tells him he's wonderful when he's feeling down. She is the 'office wife'. One man who has worked in 10 Downing Street since 1997 says: 'She occupies a zone in which there are no other occupants in terms of Blair's psychological map.'

Angela Margaret Jane Hunter is also, of course, one of Tony Blair's oldest friends. They met more than 30 years ago in Scotland when she was a rebellious 15-year-old pupil at St Leonard's. She had lived in Malaya, where her father was a tea-planter, until the age of 11 when the family returned to Brechin in Scotland. Her mother was killed in a car accident when Anji and her brother, John, were still children. Their father, who had a distinguished war in the Malayan Defence Force, died aged 76 in the early 1980s. He was a popular, energetic man and seems to have passed on this joy of life to his daughter.

Blair and Anji remained in touch after they both left school and at Oxford, where she was taking her A-levels at sixth-form college. While he had started his degree, she went out with the bass guitarist from his rock group, Ugly Rumours.

There has never been a whisper of romance between them, although interestingly enough, her own husband, a landscape gardener named Nick Cornwall whom she married in 1980 when she was 25, is said to look like the Prime Minister. Perhaps inevitably she is not particularly close to Cherie Blair. Mr Blair and his wife both have their own courtiers. Mrs Blair is close to the head of the political office, Sally Morgan. Ms Morgan and Ms Hunter do not get on.

Anji Hunter has worked for Tony Blair longer than anybody. She and her husband have two children and when they were small she went back to college to read English and History at Brighton Polytechnic. She still found time to work for Blair in her holidays and acquire a First. After graduating in 1988, Anji Hunter worked for him full-time. She had a break to spend more time with her family, returned to help in Neil Kinnock's office in the 1992 election, and then once again joined the Blair office.

She is said currently to occupy a role within Downing Street which is at least as powerful as the press secretary, Alastair Campbell, and the chief of staff, Jonathan Powell. Yet this is still not quite enough. It has emerged that she is apparently seeking a formal promotion after the election to the post of political secretary, in order to underline her status. As well as attracting a salary reported to be around £120,000, it would have the added advantage of seeing off her critics within Number 10 - of whom there are plenty.

It would also ensure the departure of Sally Morgan, perhaps to the House of Lords, an outcome she has tried to secure before - two years ago, when Cherie Blair is said to have intervened with her husband on Sally's behalf. But it is a move that would attract controversy within the Labour Party and from the Civil Service, and is fraught with potential political difficulty.

Anyone in politics with Anji Hunter's access and degree of power is bound to attract jealousy and enmity. The main charge against her is that, like a number of others who are close to the Prime Minister - indeed, some would say it of the man himself - she does not really understand the Labour Party, she was not born or raised within its culture, she is not of it. This lack of Labour roots is resented by party stalwarts, but actually misses the point about the woman. It is precisely her intuitive understanding of Middle England, of the soft Conservative vote, of ordinary people who do not live and breathe politics, that makes her so important to the Blair project. People mention the Daily Mail when they speak of Anji Hunter, and it is pertinent. Tony Blair's broad coalition needs to understand readers of the Daily Mail .

But sometimes the reverse is also true. When Downing Street was gripped by the crisis surrounding Peter Mandelson's enforced resignation in January, it was Anji Hunter who was given the task of making sure that Tony Blair's position was correctly conveyed to the Daily Mail. She 'charms, cajoles and corrals' - in that order - but like her friend Margaret McDonagh, the party general secretary whose appointment to that post she secured against other advice, she will use the thumbscrews when necessary. A man with reason to know also suggests that her use of charm is extended only to those over whom she has no other power.

Her relationships within the political world are thus far more difficult than might otherwise appear. Her promotion along the lines suggested would cause a considerable stir. Present job: Tony Blair's special assistant and 'gatekeeper'

Salary: £120,000

He could see from their mutual body language that she was exuding a physical charm and it was obvious that the man with whom she was in conversation was enchanted. webTitle: Blair orders rush Bill to clear way for June poll

fields.headline: Blair orders rush Bill to clear way for June poll
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: The Government is to rush through emergency legislation in the next 48 hours to delay the local elections due on 3 May, the final admission that the general election will be postponed.
fields.body:
The Government is to rush through emergency legislation in the next 48 hours to delay the local elections due on 3 May, the final admission that the general election will be postponed.

The local and general elections are now likely to take place on 7 June.

With the Prime Minister taking final soundings today, Downing Street sources said Tony Blair has ordered the Home Office to draw up a short Bill which will have to be put through the House of Commons before Thursday.

The Bill will halt the council elections across the country, which were due to be held next month, because of the foot-and-mouth epidemic. It is the first time since the Second World War that the democratic process has been suspended in Britain because of a national crisis. Blair decided to postpone the general election, which was also due to be held on 3 May, because he is concerned that the public will react badly if he is seen to be putting the fortunes of the Labour Party above the fortunes of the country.

He has told key advisers that he needs at least another week in charge of the foot-and-mouth crisis before it will be totally under control. The deadline for calling an election on 3 May falls on Thursday but Blair wanted to be in a position to call the election tomorrow. 'We have simply run out of time,' said a Labour official. 'The Prime Minister is worried that he would be seen dealing with the foot-and-mouth crisis in the morning and then out campaigning for the party in the afternoon. It would send out the wrong signal.

'It will now take a huge change in fortunes for him to change his mind over the next 24 hours.' The official stressed that no 'absolutely final' decision had been taken.

Downing Street hopes that by 7 June all the control measures needed to eradicate foot and mouth will be in place.

Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, will consult officials today about the sort of legislation that is needed to postpone the council elections. It is believed that the motion could be moved and passed in one day on the floor of the Commons as long, as seems likely, the opposition parties agree.

Senior government sources said that Blair actually decided to postpone the general election more than a week ago after visits to the countryside revealed the full extent of the suffering among farmers. Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland Secretary and still a close friend of the Prime Minister despite his resignation, is believed to have advised Blair that he should agree to a 'short pause' in his election plans. Other key figures urging caution were Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office Minister and one of Blair's oldest friends, and Philip Gould, Blair's personal polling adviser.

Although Gould's focus group work showed mixed feelings about an early election among the public, he feared that the electorate would respond negatively if they thought they were being 'bounced' into a campaign.

A poll for The Guardian on 21 March revealed that more than half of the electorate thought the general election should be postponed. Although other polls showed that Labour still had a 19-point lead over the Conservatives, Blair has told colleagues that moving into campaign mode this week would lead to a 'perception problem'.

Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, and Gordon Brown, the Chancellor, all moved towards the June date last week despite originally believing that it would send out a negative message that Britain 'was closed for business'.

Government sources pointed out that tourism was already struggling and that it was more important to beat foot and mouth.

webTitle: Tragic tycoon seeks solace with Aids victims

fields.headline: Tragic tycoon seeks solace with Aids victims
fields.standfirst: After a family suicide, Britain's second richest woman is joining a hospital ship in West Africa
fields.trailText: After a family suicide, Britain's second richest woman is joining a hospital ship in West Africa.
fields.body:
She is the nurse who became Britain's richest businesswoman, turning a £25,000 redundancy payment into a £1 billion international empire.

When she left her council house and moved into a £3 million castle, Stagecoach boss Ann Gloag had it all. But two years ago her life was devastated when her 28-year-old son, Jonathan, hanged himself in a forest near her home. Bewildered and distraught, Gloag disappeared from public life and quit the company she founded.

Now she is going back to her roots. She is swapping her Highland estate for a hospital in one of the world's poorest countries where she will treat Aids and cancer patients.

Ann Gloag, 58, arrived yesterday in Benin to start working for Mercy Ships, a charity that provides ship-based hospitals offering free medical and dental care to some of the world's poorest people. She decided to take the unpaid job on the 12,000-tonne SS Anastasis, moored off Cotonou, after a visit to West Africa last year.

Friends say she wants to 'start a new chapter' after 20 gruelling years which made her Britain's second-richest woman - only the Queen is wealthier - but which have cost her her marriage and, some say, the life of her son.

'She is still deeply traumatised by Jonathan's death, but getting back to work is her way of getting on with life,' one said. 'It is her way, perhaps, of acknowledging what has happened and of starting again and showing that some benefit can come out of it all.'

As she prepared to treat her first patient since she quit her job as a theatre nurse in Bridge of Earn hospital, near Perth, 20 years ago, Gloag said: 'I've been very fortunate in many ways. I enjoyed my years as a nurse. I enjoyed my years in business. Maybe if I can do something for these charities for a few years, it wouldn't be a bad idea.'

She has donated £4m of her fortune to buy a new hospital ship, the African Mercy, moored at Newcastle upon Tyne. She wants to raise £15m to refit and equip the ship. 'For me it's quite a big challenge to buy this ship and see the conversion through. I think I'll get a real buzz the day they launch it.'

It is more than a quarter of a century since Gloag began her nursing career at Glasgow's Royal Hospital for Sick Children. Her qualifications are now out of date, so she will spend this week carrying out basic duties, such as sterilising equipment or feeding undernourished babies so they are strong enough for surgery.

Conditions on the boat could not be more different from life in 24-bedroom Beaufort Castle, the baronial seat of the Clan Fraser, which Gloag bought 10 years ago. Temperatures can reach 35C, with near 100 per cent humidity. Food and water on board are strictly rationed.

During the day Gloag will treat Aids and cancer victims. Chronic eye infections, cataracts and cleft lips and palates are common. The ship has four operating theatres and beds for 100 patients. At night she will sleep in a bunk in quarters that also hold 400 doctors, nurses and crew. 'I am a terrible sailor, but I should be OK while the boat is moored,' she said.

Her return to the wards is the latest chapter in the remarkable life of a woman born in poverty in Perth. She left Perth High School with no qualifications, but enrolled as a trainee nurse and rose to become a sister. She quit her job in 1980 and used her bus driver father's £25,000 redundancy money to set up Stagecoach with her brother, Brian Souter.

They exploited Tory legislation deregulating the bus industry to undercut rivals. As Stagecoach began expanding rapidly, she let nothing stand in her way - not even her husband. Robin Gloag was on the Stagecoach board when the company was set up, but she and Souter voted him off after repeated clashes. The couple later divorced.

Gloag's ruthlessness earned her a £200m personal fortune which she spent lavishly. She holidayed with Richard Branson on his Caribbean island and drank Bollinger with Rupert Murdoch at his Christmas parties. She bought her yellow Bentley - registration 1Ann - from the Princess Royal.

But the good life came to a tragic end on the night of 18 September 1999 when her son left his Perthshire home, walked a few miles towards his mother's home, tied a rope to a tree and hanged himself. The suicide of a young man with a wife, three sons and the prospect of a vast inheritance all but destroyed Gloag. As she put it on the wreath of white lilies she laid at his funeral: 'From your heartbroken mum, I loved you so much. Till the day dawns and the shadows flee away.'

Afterwards she shunned all publicity. Friends say she was haunted by the thought that she could have prevented his death. 'She knew her son believed he could not live up to her success and she knew he had been badly affected by the divorce,' one said. 'She had all that money at her disposal, and was able to help complete strangers with her charitable instincts, but not Jonathan.

'She is a driven woman. Even when her business tactics were being criticised, she was convinced she had done no wrong. But after Jonathan's death I think she felt - for the first time - as if she might have made a terrible mistake.'

Last year she announced that she had had enough of big business and was quitting as executive director of Stagecoach. She was seen only a few times in public before she announced last week that she was going to Africa.

The Anastasis will remain off the coast of Benin until May. During that time doctors hope to carry out more than 1,000 operations and provide dental treatment for 3,000 people.

webTitle: Tory and Lib Dem futures - beyond the election

fields.headline: Beyond the election - Tories and Lib Dems
fields.standfirst: The rising stars - and the future challenges
fields.trailText: The rising stars - and the future challenges.
fields.body:
Tory rising stars

Andrew Lansley (Cambridgeshire South) : With a formidable reputation within Central Office, though almost unknown outside it, the 40-year-old MP for Cambridgeshire South could be a future party leader. The former Whitehall high flyer, praised as the brains behind the 1992 tax bombshell campaign, will support Michael Ancram at central office. Accused of playing race card after arguing that immigration was an issue with more 'potential to hurt'.

Oliver Letwin (Dorset west) : Brainy former banker with impeccable right-wing pedigree, having served as a special adviser to Keith Joseph and in Margaret Thatcher's policy unit. Part of 1997 intake, but quickly promoted, he is already shadow chief secretary to the Treasury. Reluctant dope rebel, who made Clintonesque claim - 'some friends put some in my pipe' while at university.

Lib Dem rising stars

Mark Oaten (Winchester) : Elected with a majority of just two votes in 1997, the court ruling to re-run Winchester election probably saved Oaten from a one-term stint. Byelection triumph with easily the Lib Dems' largest majority (25,336) was achieved through constituency hyperactivity as Oaten made a virtue of spending more time at local charity events than in a 'distant and out-of-touch' House. Ultra-moderniser with popular touch, sponsoring campaigns on adoption and war graves. Rewarded with job as PPS to Charles Kennedy.

Lembit Opik (Montgomeryshire) : Bright 36-year-old, born in Ulster of Estonian parents, is keen to take on the 'Chat-show Charlie' role. Good at putting pro-euro case but obsessed with asteroids, telling the Commons: 'The last huge asteroid to hit Earth wiped out the dinosaurs. We are next in line. I'm sure New Labour does not want to be responsible for wiping out humanity.'

Party futures:

Conservatives: The Tory party will hope to make enough progress in this election to at least set themselves up for victory next time. But two fundamental questions will define the party's approach to the decade ahead.

Social policy: : The battle between the Portillo-Maude and traditionalist Widdecombe camps will determine how far the party adopts a more libertarian and individualistic approach, which could prove an attractive counterweight to New Labour among the next generation of voters.

Europe: : The Conservatives do not favour a euro referendum, but at least it should finally end the Tory trauma. The party can either lead a famous victory over New Labour or finally put their worst decade behind them. But hardline europhobes resist the idea of any retreat in the event of defeat, proposing that the Tories would fight an election pledging a new vote to reverse the result before the changeover is completed. Surely that way lies electoral oblivion.

Liberal Democrats: : Charles Kennedy will want his party to do more than strengthen their local government base and hope for a close Westminster result one day. That will mean developing policies that can lead political debate - especially on green issues - in the way the non-party Charter '88 campaign did in the late Eighties.

fields.standfirst: Rising stars and policy challenges
fields.trailText: Rising stars and policy challenges
fields.body:
Oona King:The 33-year-old MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, elected in 1997, was chosen to launch Labour's £800 million urban renewal programme with Blair. The daughter of an American civil rights activist, King is instinctively liberal and pluralist and a strong supporter of PR. The former aide to Glenys Kinnock is also an active member of the international development committee. With Mo Mowlam bowing out, she would add some much needed life to Labour's male-dominated top team.

David Lammy:The baby of the house at 28 but likely to take his first step on the ministerial ladder soon. A committed Christian, his powerful maiden speech called on the government to 'invest in people's souls as well as their skills'. He succeeded Bernie Grant in Tottenham, one of the country's most deprived constituencies, and has the potential to be a powerful voice on social inclusion.

Five future cabinet hopefuls

Charles Clarke (Norwich South):Effective Home Office minister who served as Neil Kinnock's chief of staff for nine tough years.

Peter Hain (Neath): Welsh base helps former anti-apartheid activist to give modern voice to heartland concerns. Impressed as minister for Africa before shift to energy beat.

Ruth Kelly (Bolton West): Labour is delivering: Kelly has given birth no less than three times in her first parliamentary term. Former Bank of England economist and Guardian journalist tipped for the top.

Yvette Cooper (Pontefract and Castleford): Public Health Minister and former Independent economics correspondent. Will make headlines as the first minister to take the full five months maternity entitlement this summer. And will then resume rapid political rise.

Patricia Scotland (Baroness Scotland of Asthal): Eloquent QC and Foreign Office minister. Born in Dominica, she may just overtake better-known colleagues to become Britain's first black cabinet minister.

Future policy challenges

'Events' are the politician's nightmare. Nobody expected the countryside or Kosovo to be central issues in Labour's first term. So expect the unexpected - but here are some issues that might demand ministerial attention:

The euro: A referendum on the euro would be the defining event of a Labour second term and perhaps of post-war British politics. Ministers may not decide for two years, but the debate will hot up from the day after the election, and the positive case for Europe will need to be made.

Immigration policy: Since Enoch Powell and Margaret Thatcher, Labour has feared being seen as 'soft on immigration'. But concerns about an 'ageing population' and a 'skills gap' constraining economic growth may make a more liberal policy on 'economic migrants' necessary. Home Office Minister Barbara Roche has called for a rethink.

Reviving government: Post-devolution changes to the Scottish and Welsh offices may prove the cue for a broader overhaul of Whitehall in an attempt to overcome the turf wars that have hampered 'joined-up government'. Achieving local regeneration will require moribund local government to be transformed. Expect a broader debate too about the role of the voluntary sector and social entrepreneurs in delivering change on the ground.
