webTitle: Tories may stoop but they won't conquer - Andrew Rawnsley

fields.headline: Tories may stoop but they won't conquer
fields.standfirst: I don't think William Hague is a racist. Which makes his tolerance of Conservative bigots even more disreputable
fields.trailText: I don't think William Hague is a racist. Which makes his tolerance of Conservative bigots even more disreputable
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, Columnist of the Year
fields.body:
'If you want a nigger for a neighbour, vote Labour.' The chant of Tory supporters during the notorious Smethwick campaign was described by the Conservative candidate, Peter Griffiths as 'a manifestation of popular feeling'. And there must have been some truth in that. Though he was widely condemned - the then Prime Minister, Harold Wilson branded him 'a leper' - Griffiths won the seat in 1964. He lost it after two years, but later returned to Parliament for a different constituency and sat as a Conservative MP for the plump total of 20 years. He finally retired from the Commons only at the last election. Not a bad living from the Tory party for a leper.

They have come on a little in the four decades since Smethwick Man was given his racist head. It is unlikely that a contemporary member of the Conservative Party would use that sort of language. Not, at any rate, in front of a microphone. When the ghost of Enoch Powell foams with blood, these days even he deploys euphemisms.

Here is the Powell-worshipper, John Townend, Conservative MP, unburdening himself to his local party: 'Our homogeneous Anglo-Saxon society has been seriously undermined by the massive immigration, particularly Commonwealth immigration, that has taken place since the war.' Commonwealth, incidentally, is a cosmetic for 'coloured', the word in his original draft. The MP for Yorkshire East continues: 'Illegal immigrants have got a new ploy. They call themselves asylum-seekers. In my view, the only way to deal with the problem is to send them back quickly. Many of them come from violent societies.'

Come on, Mr Townend, don't be shy of your bigotry. Spit those prejudices out, man. Say what you really feel. Stop being so politically correct. Why not go the whole hog and tell us we don't want niggers as neighbours?

Anyway, we do not need the services of GCHQ to decode him. Note the suggestion that all asylum-seekers are bogus. Not one of them is to be considered a genuine refugee from persecution. To a man, woman and six-month-old baby they are parasitical leeches on Britain's classy health service, superb transport facilities and a benefits system globally renowned for its generosity. Observe how his speech slyly elides asylum-seekers with black and Asian Britons who have been making a contribution to our society for many generations. Register how his call for instant deportation of asylum-seekers may provoke in his audience the thought that sending them home is what should have been done with all immigrants. Smell the rancid implication that immigrants are universally villainous. It will not have occurred to him that, if being a product of 'a violent society' is to become a bar to remaining in Britain, then the first people to be repatriated will be Americans.

Now, it would be easiest and most comforting to dismiss these repugnant views as of no account. This amoeba at the base of the political food chain will not be an MP in the next parliament. Even taking him on his own terms, his argument is so much nonsense on stilts. We are all immigrants. The only difference between us is when we arrived on these islands' shores. We are all racial mongrels. The genes of my children are a delicious cocktail of Angle, Saxon, Viking, Norman, Celt (Scottish and Irish branches) as well as a large fraction of two noisy ethnic minorities occasionally prone to bad behaviour, Liverpudlians and Yorkshire folk.

The Anglo-Saxon idyll of Mr Townend's fantasy suggests a man who yearns to wind back the clock a mil lennium or so. Medieval Britain was tremendously white, as pale as the Moon. What it was not was homogeneous. So unhomogeneous, in fact, that king and court spoke a different language from the rest of the population.

The temptation is to toss Mr Townend aside, but I think it better to take him head on. Condemnation is not enough. Bigotry has to be argued into the oblivion it deserves, not least because this MP speaks for more than himself. Another Tory MP has popped up to echo his attack on immigrants. And I quite believe him when he says that his speech 'went down a bomb' with his constituency party. I am sure it would have gone down a bomb in the many local Tory parties which are still heavily impregnated with prejudice.

William Hague was swift to assure us that he 'wholly repudiated' his fellow Yorkshireman's 'totally unacceptable' remarks. But not so totally and wholly that Mr Hague will be throwing him out of the Tory party or even removing the whip for the twilight of his parliamentary career. Sounding quite unrepentant and thoroughly unrebuked, Mr Townend shrugged: 'William has to say that.' He implies that the Tory leader secretly rather agrees with him.

That, I think, is unfair to William Hague. I first got to know the Tory leader a bit when he entered the Commons, and he struck me then as belonging to the tolerant tendency of his party. One of Mr Hague's best friends is gay. And no, I do not mean Michael Portillo. I do not believe that Mr Hague is a racist. In the early phase of his leadership, he spoke eloquently about the need for the Conservatives to become an inclusive party, embracing Britons of all colours and creeds. This was during Mr Hague's Carnival period when he took Ffion to Notting Hill to get multicultural.

Then he panicked over his plunging poll ratings. Alas for his party, for the tone of public life and for the Tory leader's self-respect, he recast himself as Skinhead Hague. This incarnation's nastiest outing was the recent speech to the Tory spring conference when he mashed Europhobia together with immigration-bashing into a rave about Britain becoming 'a foreign land'. I repeat, I don't think the Tory leader is actually a racist. Which makes his truckling to prejudice even less reputable. When Enoch Powell made his lurid forecasts of racial war and Margaret Thatcher shuddered about being 'swamped', at least they believed it. William Hague lurched into this basest denominator stuff out of a desperation to rouse the hardcore right-wing vote.

One of the astuter members of the Shadow Cabinet observed to me the other day that his leader's biggest mistake was to get his strategy 'the wrong way round.' Instead of securing the Tory core and then using the run-up to the election to reach out, Hague's leadership began by reaching out and has now shrivelled back to the core.

We shouldn't kid ourselves. There are votes to be grubbed up in the gutter. But the Tory party loses - and deservedly so - much more than it gains. Asian entrepreneurs are just one group who could be natural Tory supporters if it did not express such repellent attitudes. Narrow intolerance also does the Conservatives great damage with the wider electorate. The As and the Bs - the top of the social ladder - have swung most markedly away from the Conservatives to Labour since the last election. This is for several reasons, but one of the most important is that the more affluent tend to be more socially liberal. Skinhead Hague has not even won over his target audience. The Daily Mail , not a paper on the Commission for Racial Equality's recommended reading list, winced at the Harrogate harangue. The Sun , hardly the foreigners' friend, told the Tory leader he was flirting with extremism.

So you can appreciate why the likes of John Townend have come to believe that they have a fellow traveller in the Tory leader. The MP can be forgiven for thinking that he was only pushing a little further along the trail which William Hague has blazed. The great majority of the country has no desire to follow. Britain has let go, even if the Tory party has not, of Smethwick Man.

fields.headline: New election, new gurus
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair sets great store by faith-based communities. Sadly for him, no one wants to live in them
fields.trailText: Tony Blair sets great store by faith-based communities. Sadly for him, no one wants to live in them
fields.body:
LIKE PLOTTING Shakespearean dukes, the Anglican bishops ponder the affairs of the realm. The election must be in June, say York, Canterbury, Hereford and Carlisle, while Durham and Oxford plump for May. Quite why the timing is suddenly part of the ecclesiastical calendar is uncertain. Just as politicians would not presume to fix the date of the Church of England Synod meeting or the Nether Wallop parochial church-hall bring-and-buy sale, church leaders should have no leverage on when the country goes to the polls. Still, you have to admire their opportunism.

Tony Blair had barely finished his speech to the Christian Socialist Movement, in which he advocated power and influence for faith-based groups, before the bishops, their flocks decimated by forces more pernicious than foot and mouth, invoked this proffered clout. The Prime Minister might not have meant his call for government tie-ups with religious bodies to be interpreted quite so literally, but once you start rendering unto God those things that used to be Caesar's, odd mutations follow.

The perils of mixing religion and politics are already apparent in the United States, where George W. Bush's plan to channel government aid to faith-based groups has stalled amid internecine rivalry on the religious Right and concern elsewhere about the spectre of taxpayers funding the Rev Sun Myung Moon's sexual abstinence programme in schools. Fusing private faith and public policy is rarely wise.

William Hague's attempt to annexe the religious vote is not a worry. His unworkable plan, based on the thinking of the Bush bible-basher, Marvin Olasky, to hand over parts of the welfare state to church groups, was pure expediency. Hague is to high theology what Heddon-on-the-Wall pigswill is to River Café minestrone, which makes his never-to-be-implemented brand of God-bothering wholly unthreatening. Blair's Christianity, genuine and heartfelt, is more disturbing, despite, or because of, the fact that he has no need to court the religious vote. He already has it in the bag. There was no overt zealotry in a sermon acknowledging the good work done by some faith groups and promising them a greater role in health projects and work with the young and the elderly, with offenders and ex-offenders.

But if the language was careful, the aim was not so different from Hague's. The Conservatives' God squad would substitute for state agencies, while Labour's volunteers will be partners. Many, like MP Martin O'Neill, worry legitimately about funding being skewed towards religious groups, about possible job discrimination between believers and non-believers and about services being delivered with a side order of preaching. As for the planned proliferation of church schools, Blair should know better than most people that parents are seduced not by 'moral emphasis' but by the un-Christian wish that their kids get a better education than everyone else's.

BLAIR'S SUBTEXT, including the implicit and erroneous notion that religion has a monopoly on altruism, is equally disturbing. As he also made clear, his religious faith is indivisible from his political judgment. Or, as he put it: 'Politics without values is sheer pragmatism .The two must go together.' Only up to a point. Religion, as David Hume argued against the consensus of eighteenth-century deists, is not rationally based but bound up in our emotional responses to life's glitches. Thus, when Euan Blair was found drunk in Leicester Square, his father reread 'The Village Church' and mused on God and how 'for thine own purpose, thou has sent/ the strife and the discouragement'.

One imagines that, with each heaven-dispensed dose of S&D, from the Hindujas to foot and mouth, the Downing Street copy of Longfellow becomes ever more thumbed. Although Blair affects to be a scholarly theologian lurching between the (perfectly compatible) natural law theories of Thomas Aquinas and the utilitarianism of Bentham and Mill, he appears more at home with comfort-blanket Christianity. Like other forms of private succour, such as Valium, Horlicks or a litre tub of chocolate-chip ice-cream, religion has limited use in the public domain.

Faith, as Hume understood but Blair may not, takes off at the point where logic stops. For that reason alone, religion is the least useful spanner in the political toolbox. Piety is not, as Blair suggests, synonymous with values. In addition, for such an events-driven Prime Minister to claim that religion is a prescription against pragmatism is as specious as his suggestion that lack of faith has led to national cynicism. Voters are sceptical now not because they had too little belief in what this government might deliver but because they had too much.

However, you do not have to be very cynical to worry about the social tinkering enshrined in Blair's paean to religion, to marriage and to community; a holy trinity that acquired a new legitimacy last week, when Robert Putnam, the latest Labour guru (and the occupant of this slot last week), arrived for breakfast at Downing Street, puffed up on the stupendous banality that attaches to being what Bryan Appleyard breathlessly calls 'the most influential academic in the world today'.

The Putnam doctrine is a lament for the decline of faith-based and civic groups and for the demise of community. Blair is impressed. But why? We might as well bemoan the fact that we no longer aspire to be like Barney and Betty Rubble from The Flintstones. Community, like marriage, is often anachronistic and always over-romanticised. From the Mafia to the Krays, from the Ku Klux Klan to the juvenile knife gangs of Peckham, society's most destructive forces are imbued with the warm glow of community and tribalism.

Inclusive groups are, de facto, exclusive, too, and the traditional outsiders are women, the carers and nurturers whose efforts allowed men to construct sub-communities based round the office, the pub, the Freemasons, the golf course or the 10-pin bowling club whose demise gave Putnam his Albert Camus meets David Vine book title of Bowling Alone .

WHAT HE FAILS to see is that society is evolving away from old, faith-based communities not because of malign pressures but because people don't want to stay in Claustrophobia Mansions with the vicar and an extended family presiding over their lives. The Putnam dream has not been squandered but spurned by a generation to whom Labour's fondness for this reheated mush must seem barely comprehensible.

Six years have passed since the first wave of communitarian waffle, peddled by Amitai Etzioni, percolated Labour thinking. Etzioni's credentials were clonishly similar to Putnam's. He, too, was a distinguished American academic, beloved of Bill Clinton, admired by Blair and, according to his publishers, an influential force in the rewriting of Clause IV.

Whether or not that is so, it is certain that the ubiquitous mantra of 'rights and responsibilities' tracks back to Etzioni, whose contribution evoked some puzzlement from the outset. It seemed doubtful then that an anti-liberal, authoritarian movement uncluttered by worries over civil rights or individual autonomy, could ever take root in a Labour government answerable to a secular society.

It could. A parliamentary term on, we have an Identikit guru and yesterday's gospel of faith-based communitarianism rehashed for tomorrow's election. Who can blame the bishops for calling the date when politicians are busy dressing up dodgy social engineering as eternal verity?

We might as well bemoan the fact that we no longer aspire to be like Barney and Betty Rubble from The Flintstones. Community, like marriage, is often anachronistic and always over-romanticised. From the Mafia to the Krays, from the Ku Klux Klan to the juvenile knife gangs of Peckham, society's most destructive forces are imbued with the warm glow of community and tribalism. Inclusive groups are, de facto, exclusive, too, and the traditional outsiders are women, the carers and nurturers whose efforts allowed men to construct sub-communities based round the office, the pub, the Freemasons, the golf course or the 10-pin bowling club whose demise gave Putnam his Albert Camus meets David Vine book title of Bowling Alone . WHAT HE FAILS to see is that society is evolving away from old, faith-based communities not because of malign pressures but because people don't want to stay in Claustrophobia Mansions with the vicar and an extended family presiding over their lives. The Putnam dream has not been squandered but spurned by a generation to whom Labour's fondness for this reheated mush must seem barely comprehensible. Six years have passed since the first wave of communitarian waffle, peddled by Amitai Etzioni, percolated Labour thinking. Etzioni's credentials were clonishly similar to Putnam's. He, too, was a distinguished American academic, beloved of Bill Clinton, admired by Blair and, according to his publishers, an influential force in the rewriting of Clause IV. Whether or not that is so, it is certain that the ubiquitous mantra of 'rights and responsibilities' tracks back to Etzioni, whose contribution evoked some puzzlement from the outset. It seemed doubtful then that an anti-liberal, authoritarian movement uncluttered by worries over civil rights or individual autonomy, could ever take root in a Labour government answerable to a secular society. It could. A parliamentary term on, we have an Identikit guru and yesterday's gospel of faith-based communitarianism rehashed for tomorrow's election. Who can blame the bishops for calling the date when politicians are busy dressing up dodgy social engineering as eternal verity?

fields.headline: Children pay for political errors
fields.standfirst: Commmentary  by John  	 Prescott, secretary of state for the environment
fields.trailText: When I came out of The Hague Conference on Global Warming last December I said I was 'gutted' that we had not reached agreement. Why? First, because I felt we had missed a great chance to tie down a practical deal - after all, we had done the hard part of setting legally binding targets in Kyoto three years earlier. Second, because I feared this would give the incoming US administration an opportunity to pull away from it. Sadly, this seems to be so.
fields.body:
When I came out of The Hague Conference on Global Warming last December I said I was 'gutted' that we had not reached agreement. Why? First, because I felt we had missed a great chance to tie down a practical deal - after all, we had done the hard part of setting legally binding targets in Kyoto three years earlier. Second, because I feared this would give the incoming US administration an opportunity to pull away from it. Sadly, this seems to be so.

Earlier this year there were signs of hope. Only a month ago President Bush's new Environmental Protection Agency director agreed at the G8 meeting in Trieste that Kyoto was the way ahead. However, President Bush now seems to have unilaterally rejected the Kyoto Protocol 'because it exempts many countries from compliance and would cause serious harm to the American economy'.

The fact that climate change is taking place is now accepted by the scientific community. The latest UN scientific report says that temperatures could rise by up to 5.8 C over the next 100 years if no action is taken. The consequence will be rising sea levels inundating our coasts and more severe weather - floods, hurricanes and droughts.

Climate change is caused by industrial emissions. Today's biggest polluters were the first to industrialise and they have responsibility to take the first action to tackle climate change. The Rio Convention - signed by G.W.'s father President George Bush in 1992 - and the Kyoto Protocol both recognise this.

Kyoto was possible because Europe, the US and Japan in particular dedicated themselves to securing an agreement - encouraged by the courageous stance taken by Vice-President Gore.

But it is not true that developing countries are exempt from the Protocol. It calls on them to develop programmes to address climate change. In future decades all countries must do more. And many developing countries are already taking active steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, as I have seen for myself in India, China and South America. They recognise that environmental problems are a major concern for their populations, just as they are for ours, and that energy efficiency is good for the economy.

Bush doesn't want to destroy American jobs. We don't want to destroy British, German, Japanese or Chinese jobs. We want to tackle global warming in ways which will benefit our standard of living.

And the US cannot sit in glorious isolation. Europe has reached an agreement on fuel efficiency with the car manufacturers which applies to every firm in the global market. Fridges and freezers in European shops have energy efficiency markings which mean consumers can choose products which use less energy and are cheaper to run. US manufacturers ignore these measure at their peril, and Europe will introduce further measures in the future.

The ultimate irony is that just as Bush - the President of the world's most polluting nation - is rejecting Kyoto, Premier Zhu Rongji - President of the world's most populous nation - has recognised that the environment is a priority. China's latest five-year plan commits it to take 'measures contributing to slowing down the change of global climate'.

The challenge for the rest of the world is to persuade the American people that the threat of global warming is real and that the Kyoto targets are realistic because there are flexible ways to achieve them.

The challenge for America is to show it is a responsible nation, which will work with the rest of the world to beat this problem in ways that help the economy as well as the environment.

Some people have talked about immediate trade sanctions. That would be counter-productive. But the US administration is feeling the force of international opinion. It must know it cannot pollute the world while free-riding on action by everyone else. A vigorous debate is developing in the US and that, in itself, is a good sign.

All politicians have to live with their consciences, but whether American, European, African or Asian, it is children who have to live with their decisions. We owe it to our children to pass on our planet in better shape than we inherited it.

webTitle: Queen asks Big Breakfast's creator for image makeover

fields.headline: Queen asks Big Breakfast's creator for image makeover
fields.standfirst:
Royals want men who gave us Chris Evans and 'Cool Britannia' to stop them falling out of touch, reports Ben Summerskill

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Royals want men who gave us Chris Evans and 'Cool Britannia' to stop them falling out of touch, reports Ben Summerskill.
fields.body:
The Queen is being advised by the inventor of 'Cool Britannia' and the creator of The Big Breakfast on how to modernise the monarchy.

Their involvement comes weeks after a private Mori poll carried out for Buckingham Palace showed that fewer than one in 10 people thinks the royal family is relevant and more than one in three think it is 'out of touch'.

The move is a dramatic attempt to open up the family to fresh outside advice. Mark Leonard, a policy adviser close to New Labour, and Lord Alli, the multi-millionaire TV producer, attended their first lunch meeting with royal officials at Buckingham Palace last Monday.

Sir Robin Janvrin, the Queen's private secretary, and Simon Walker, her communications secretary, are now considering their suggestions. A key subject on the 'informal agenda' was plans for the Queen's golden jubilee celebrations next year.

'Mr Leonard and Lord Alli are two key figures we have been happy to hear from,' confirmed a senior palace official yesterday. 'We approached them to talk to us about ideas for reaching young people and how to do that effectively. Reaching a youth audience is jolly important and gets more important as the more senior members of the royal family become older.'

Changes had already been discussed at the palace, including the introduction of interactive internet sites for family members. Courtiers are considering a proposal that the Queen should recruit pageboys and girls from around the country to accompany her on state occasions such as the opening of Parliament.

Leonard, 25, now director of the Foreign Policy Centre, made his name as a researcher for Demos, the think-tank close to the Labour Party. In 1997, he was credited with the creation of 'Cool Britannia', a proposed rebranding of Britain for the New Labour age. He said then that young people were 'more likely to think of Noel Gallagher than the Queen, or maybe Eric Cantona'.

The Queen's willingness to allow Leonard to advise her staff is remarkable. In Modernising the Monarchy, a Demos report published in 1998, he accused the royal family of being 'out of touch and out of date'. The monarchy 'has no idea of how the ordinary man in the street lives or the problems he faces,' he said.

He recommended sending Princes William and Harry to state schools and proposed that members of the royal family be treated in NHS hospitals. Leonard was brought up in Belgium, where a slimmed-down 'bicycling monarchy' already exists.

Alli, 35, brought The Big Breakfast and its original host Chris Evans to British TV screens on Channel 4. His production company Planet 24, which he later sold to Carlton, also made Gaytime TV, a pioneering chat show for BBC2.

Guests at his Kent mansion, which he shares with his personal and business partner Charlie Parsons, have included Peter Mandelson, Mo Mowlam and Tony Blair. As the only openly gay member of the House of Lords, Alli has been an outspoken campaigner against Section 28, which forbids the 'promotion' of homosexuality in schools.

Buckingham Palace staff are understood to be 'extremely nervous' that public events arranged for the jubilee could be ignored.

Lord lieutenants throughout the country have been asked to propose local events for members of the royal family to attend. Early proposals, including a national day of prayer suggested by the Queen's former private secretary Lord Fellowes, have been quietly dropped amid concerns that they might be regarded as 'fuddy-duddy'.

'We are keen to be modern and forward thinking,' said the palace official. 'However, we are equally keen not to do anything silly.'

The Government has already announced there will be an extra 'Jubilee bank holiday' next June.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText:
Marje and the aliens
Diary's four readers (up a soaraway 33 per cent on last month) are used to treating its stories with huge pinches of salt, and this one is no exception. Having bet the farm on developing Pearson's internet potential only to find the City has lost its thirst for dotcommery, Marje Scardino wants out, apparently. A 'top' source, ahem, says AOL/ Time Warner is keen to secure her talents. There is even wild talk of Marje helping AOL buy the FT. Next week in the bonkers story corner: Aliens found running a webzine on the moon. In a B52 bomber.

Marje and the aliens
Diary's four readers (up a soaraway 33 per cent on last month) are used to treating its stories with huge pinches of salt, and this one is no exception. Having bet the farm on developing Pearson's internet potential only to find the City has lost its thirst for dotcommery, Marje Scardino wants out, apparently. A 'top' source, ahem, says AOL/ Time Warner is keen to secure her talents. There is even wild talk of Marje helping AOL buy the FT. Next week in the bonkers story corner: Aliens found running a webzine on the moon. In a B52 bomber.

Toujours in charge
Avid Diary reader Andrew Neil is making improvements to his villa in the south of France. At no little cost, the pugnacious publisher of the Barclay brothers' newspaper titles has installed nothing less than a duplicate of the computer system that produces Sunday Business back in Blighty. Now our Andrew doesn't even have to come into the office to meddle with the paper's production - he can do it from 800 miles away. Probably good news for all concerned.

Jay-ded memories
Auntie Beeb must have thought she was on to a winner when it came to covering the Maxwell report. After all, Peter Jay, the Beeb's economics editor, was the fat fraudster's right-hand man before he went skinny dipping in the Atlantic. But strangely enough, Jay declined invitations to share his Cap'n Bob stories.

Price of a promise
An ad in the FT for PricewaterhouseCoopers' Business Recovery Service team boasted: 'Our professionals have helped more companies and their financiers through this challenging process than anyone else.' The ad was below an article on the Maxwell report stating: 'Coopers & Lybrand - now part of PwC - which audited Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers, is heavily criticised'. The ad urges readers: 'Whatever your ambitions, why not contact us and find out how we can help you achieve them.' Diary suggests readers ring PwC and try the following. 'I am a crooked media tycoon with a cashflow problem...'

Maff off
It is Diary's civic duty to point out that the phone number for Maff's Northern Region press office in Cumbria - the epicentre of the foot and mouth disease - published in the Government Information Directory is wrong. And poor Dennis Butler, a Carlisle senior citizen, isn't happy. 'I've had four calls today,' Butler wails. 'It's only 9.30am. I'm a civil man, but enough is enough.' So Diary launches a Mirroresque campaign to help. The right number is 01228 640369. We thank you.

Give him a gong
Big thanks to Diary's great friend, Sun City editor Ian 'trust my column' King. For it was Ian who found the gong awarded to Observer Sport Monthly at last month's Press Gazette awards some time after it parted company with the mag's ed, Matt Tench. With the sort of probity you would expect from a top tipster, King handed the award to the event's sponsor, Diageo, 'for safe-keeping'. The drinks giant has now made contact with Tench to reunite him with the award.

fields.headline: FilmFour aims for the Sky
fields.standfirst:
C4 wants to build on the success of Big Brother, Sarah Ryle reports

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: C4 wants to build on the success of Big Brother, Sarah Ryle reports
fields.body:
Shuffle up and make some room, Mr Murdoch, here comes Channel 4. Or so it hopes. The publicly owned network aims to cash in on its FilmFour brand in order to join Sky at the head of the digital media field. This week it will launch its latest venture, multiplexing.

It is also preparing a new development unit, the cross-platform content project. Remember that phrase: C4's director of strategy, David Brook, uses it a lot. This is, he says, the key to C4's future.

'The cross-platform content project is a real leader,' he claims. 'We have, along with other original terrestrial channels, played catch-up in the multichannel world. Now we have to make sure we are out in front.'

On Saturday C4 will launch three film strands on its FilmFour channel. Subscribers to Sky Digital will be the only ones able to view them at first, because only Sky Digital has the bandwidth capacity to screen them. No matter, says Brook, the other suppliers are catching up, and one day soonish the multiplex will be available to all.

In the meantime, non-Sky subscribers will miss out on FilmFour Plus One (for those who came in late it will show FilmFour films an hour later), FilmFour World (foreign-language cinema) and Extreme (eyebrow-raising violence). They will, however, be able to access the revamped website, which will offer engaging features such as the violent or sexy bits cut by the censors from films such as Trainspotting, as well as a postcode-targeted listings service and industry gossip. That is where the cross-platform branding comes in.

C4 tested the concept last summer with Big Brother and was astonished by its success. 'We did more traffic for Yahoo! than anything else has,' says Brook. 'Big Brother was a huge cross-platform brand in the UK. There was the TV, the web, and we were offering people the choice of voting over the phone. You can't go through an experience like that without learning something.'

The theory is, if branding works for retailers such as Levi's (Like the jeans? You'll love the T-shirt, the bag and the jacket), why not for television?

But in all of this there lurks a danger. Brook calls it the 'so what factor'. New channels come along all the time. Packages of programmes are confusing. One of the new multiplex strands, Four Plus One, is a straight copy of Discovery Plus One and the American giant Home Box Office's time-shifting offerings.

FilmFour World will be the first foreign-language service in Europe. 'There will be people out there waiting for that,' Brook believes. Research suggests these are mostly middle-class liberals who regret the decline of the subtitled art-house experience in mainstream cinema.

Extreme is the strand C4 hopes will spark controversy. As Brook says, 'sex, drugs and rock and roll'. But it is hindered by broadcasting rules that say films on television must be the video, not cinema, version.

'If you pay for something to watch in your own home, you should be entitled to watch the full cinema version,' says Brook. 'People can tune in to porn channels at any time of day, but we can't show 15-certificate films before 8pm.'

If it works, C4 will undoubtedly use the film channel as a model for other projects, notably sport.

With 400,000 subscribers, FilmFour may not have Murdoch shaking - but he will be keeping a watchful eye.

webTitle: Growing pains for Fleet Street's enfant terrible

fields.headline: Growing pains for Fleet Street's enfant terrible
fields.standfirst:
'Slickergate' could be the least of Mirror editor Piers Morgan's problems, says Alan Ruddock

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: At this month's UKPG press awards, Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan was in his usual ebullient form. Under the indulgent eye of his chairman, Sir Victor Blank, Morgan barracked his rivals, poked fun at his most vocal detractors and played to the full his self-created role as mischievous child among pompous elders.
fields.body:
At this month's UKPG press awards, Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan was in his usual ebullient form. Under the indulgent eye of his chairman, Sir Victor Blank, Morgan barracked his rivals, poked fun at his most vocal detractors and played to the full his self-created role as mischievous child among pompous elders.

It is a high-octane act that Morgan has maintained ever since he became Fleet Street's youngest editor, taking control of the News of the World at just 28. Now 35, and with more controversy behind him than any of his Fleet Street peers, the act is wearing thin.

Morgan has so far survived the Slickergate shares scandal, although he awaits the verdict of the Department of Trade and Industry inquiry into allegations that he and others under his command bought shares in companies that were then ramped in the Mirror's City pages. An internal Mirror inquiry cleared Morgan of wrongdoing and his management stood resolutely behind him when the Press Complaints Commission found that he had broken both the letter and the spirit of the editors' code of conduct.

That Morgan remains in charge is, say his supporters at the paper, testimony to his excellence as a tabloid editor and a reflection of the dearth of national newspaper experience within Trinity Mirror, the Mirror's publisher. 'When Piers is on song, he is the best editor in the country,' says one of his senior lieutenants. 'His instincts can be superb, he is popular with the staff and he has brought the Mirror back to life.' Morgan is too good to let go, whatever his flaws, they say.

Until recently, this view that went almost unchallenged. Morgan's eclectic blend of worthy campaigns, celebrity news, occasional scoops and loyalist New Labour politics had halted the Mirror's seemingly remorseless circulation decline.

Revitalised by the brief reign of his former mentor, Kelvin MacKenzie, as head of newspapers at the old Mirror Group, Morgan tried to steer the Mirror away from head-to-head competition with the Sun and carve out a new niche: a tabloid with heart.

Now, however, the brief respite provided by limited circulation success has been replaced by a fresh circulation war. Morgan and his management masters are under attack from all sides, and the strains are evident. Sales in January and February have slipped year on year, and below the surface of the headline figures the picture is even more alarming. Last month, full-price sales of the Mirror were just over 1.5 million (almost exactly half the Sun's full-price sales and 600,000 behind the Daily Mail), compared with a headline figure of 2.212 million.

The Mirror's problems are manifold. At the bottom end of its market it is threatened by the resurgence of the Star, the only Express Group title to have responded positively to Richard Desmond's ownership. At the top end it faces the relentless rise of the Daily Mail and a daily battle with the Sun. Layer on top of that the extra threat posed by a celebrity-filled Daily Express, however enfeebled, and the Mirror faces the mother of all battles. The question is whether Trinity Mirror has the stomach for the fight.

'There is a very real and depressing possibility that the Mirror will end up like the Express - slipping away year after year because its owners lack the wherewithal or the courage to do anything other than run it for cash,' says one media analyst. 'It can, as the Express has done, survive that way for years, but it is hard to see it reversing the trend against such committed and highly professional rivals as News International and Associated Newspapers.'

At the same time, Morgan has faced mounting criticism from his rivals for a lack of judgment and for his often craven support for the New Labour government.

'Piers can, on occasions, get things brilliantly right. But too often, far too often, he misfires,' says one editor.

Critics point to Morgan's 'worthy eccentricities' as proof that he is as likely to confuse as entertain his core readers. In the final week of the US election, the Mirror decided to highlight the plight of death-row Texans: an issue unlikely to shift copies off the newsstand in a market where a good celebrity splash can put on more than 50,000 sales. His closeness to Alastair Campbell has also caused irritation, both within and outside the paper.

With an election campaign drawing closer, the Mirror's determined cheerleading becomes more strident. An interview with Keith Vaz, the highly criticised Minister for Europe, becomes a stout defence. Partisan political coverage is nothing new in British newspapers, and the derision of his peers will count for nothing: what matters to Morgan is the Mirror's circulation, and his ability to affect it positively.

And that is where his real challenge lies. An editor, no matter how brilliant, can only be as successful as his managers allow. Trinity Mirror has a track record of excellence in regional newspapers. It is the largest newspaper publisher in the country and the second largest in Europe. But it lacks a senior manager with any experience of the national newspaper market. Morgan has nowhere, internally, to turn for advice. Strategically, Trinity Mirror must decide how much of its hard-earned profits can be invested in fighting the Mirror's corner - especially since its other two national titles, the People and the Sunday Mirror, are in steady long-term decline.

For a public company with restless investors it is an uncomfortable choice - and not unlike that faced by Lord Stevens at the Express when he contemplated the prospect of fighting the Mail pound for pound and reader for reader. Instead, he carefully managed the circulation decline of his titles, extracted as much profit as he could for his shareholders and then engineered an honourable sale.

If Trinity Mirror opts for the lowest-cost strategy, Morgan faces an uncomfortable year, whatever the DTI inquiry says. And his editorial skills, taken for granted a year ago, will undergo their sharpest examination yet.

fields.headline: Political reform
fields.standfirst: Can political passions stir voters to action?
fields.trailText: Can political passions stir voters to action?
fields.body:
Can political passions stir voters to action?

Campaign battleground:Normally a Lib-Lab fringe enthusiasm, this time it is the Conservatives who seek to make the consitution a central electoral theme. Labour has passed a raft of reforms, occasionally half-heartedly, but doubts voters are particularly interested. The LibDems will, as usual, promise wholesale change but don't want to be seen as a one-issue party and, like Labour, will focus instead on hospitals and schools.

Success: Human Rights Act empowers citizens to sue the state.
Failure: Going soft on freedom of information once in power.

Labour: too many to mention
 Likely to consolidate Scots, Welsh and constitutional affairs in a single Whitehall ministry.
 Take forward Royal Commission recommendations on further Lords reform.
 All government services online by 2005.

'People have sought home rule and Lords reform for a century - we have delivered'

Conservatives  'English votes on English laws' in House of Commons.
 No English regional assemblies; fewer Ministers, advisers and MPs.
 Independent Commission for appointments to the House of Lords.

'Labour has vandalised the constitution - only we believe in Britain'

LibDems  Referendums to introduce electoral reform, regional assemblies and a written constitution.
 Allow 16-year-olds to vote and run for office.
 New Supreme Court to replace Law Lords.

'Labour promised new politics - we still need to clean up the mess'

But what's the real issue?
Professor Stuart Weir, Director, Democratic Audit, University of Essex
'The public wants deeper democracy, but it's not in the interests of either big party to give it to them - and the LibDems don't have the guts to make a big issue of it. So I fear it will be all quiet on the constitutional front during the election - but certainly not afterwards.'

fields.headline: The countryside
fields.standfirst: The countryside has lurched from crisis to crisis into the political spotlight
fields.trailText: The countryside has lurched from crisis to crisis into the political spotlight
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: After BSE and foot and mouth, the countryside will feature as never before. The Conservatives will voice many Countryside Alliance grievances - with fox hunting, rural crime and the impact of fuel tax linked as 'urban Labour's rural failures'. Labour says it is 'the party of the countryside' with the most rural MPs but its range of initiatives may not tackle a more general unease. Heavy LibDem rural presence makes this an important issue for the third party too.

Success: Legal right to roam has opened up 4m acres despite landlords' protests.
Failure: Restoring confidence in British food will require major rethink.

Labour: Nick Brown
 Extend 50 per cent rate relief for village shops, pubs and garages.
 Revitalise parish and town councils, and powers to levy full council tax on second homes.
'The Conservatives will hit rural schools, hospitals and transport again'

Conservatives: Tim Yeo
 Cut red-tape for farmers.
 Ban imports of food that does not meet safety standards for British-produced food.
'Labour has no feeling for the countryside or our rural way of life'

LibDems: Colin Breed
 Campaign to replace Common Agricultural Policy with Common Rural Policy, putting agriculture in context of rural development.
 Promote local exchange trading schemes.
 Introduce rural transport regeneration fund.
'A sustainable rural economy needs a fresh look at how we manage the countryside'

But what's the real issue?
Richard Burge, Chief Executive, Countryside Alliance
'We want the next Government to have a bold, coherent and inclusive vision for the countryside; to have a clear plan for creating and maintaining rural livelihoods; to be statesmanlike in defending rural diversity, culture and traditions against social and political prejudice; and to treat rural Britain as part of One Nation rather than another country.'

fields.headline: Europe
fields.standfirst: Is it 'make our mind up' time for Britain at last?
fields.trailText: Is it 'make our mind up' time for Britain at last?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: 'Save the pound' versus 'Don't mention the euro' - an uneven battle but Labour hope Tory obsessiveness will put voters off, and that voters will assess the economic tests later. Labour will argue that constructive engagement in Europe can deliver for Britain better than hand-bagging did, but are they making the positive case heard?

Success: Britain taking lead on European defence and economic reform.
Failure: Have not led public debate or successfully challenged Eurosceptic script.

Labour: Robin Cook
Assessment of economic tests on euro within two years, followed by referendum if Government recommends joining. Democratic reform, including European Parliament second chamber of national MPs. 'A choice between Tony Blair leading in Europe and William Hague leaving Europe, risking three million British jobs'

Conservatives: Francis Maude
Renegotiation of Nice Treaty, to include flexibility clause so countries 'decide for themselves which EU laws make sense for them'. European defence force to be brought under Nato command. 'We will stop the slide to a superstate - Britain should be in Europe, not run by Europe'

LibDems: Menzies Campbell
Support European constitution to make Europe more transparent and democratic. Freedom of Information for EU institutions 'The Government must make the case for the euro now, and ensure Britain is ready to join'

But what's the real issue?
Heather Grabbe, Research Director, Centre for European Reform
'The real issue is how we make Europe work for everybody. We should be less hung up on symbols, as in the British euro debate, and more concerned about what Europe can do for us as consumers, employees and citizens. It's time to move beyond "knocking copy" to a constructive debate about EU reform.'

fields.headline: International
fields.standfirst: What should Britain stand for on the global stage?
fields.trailText: What should Britain stand for on the global stage?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: Francis Maude will enjoy mocking Robin Cook's 'ethical foreign policy'. But Labour will play the leadership card, arguing that it has delivered results - from landmines to debt relief - and that the inexperienced Conservatives' obsession with sovereignty would prevent them from delivering for Britain in a multilateral world.

Success: Fall of Milosevic did much to vindicate Kosovo war.
Failure: Explaining exactly what is an ethical foreign policy.

Labour: Robin Cook and Clare Short
 Second-term bill to regulate arms trade.
 Increase development spending progressively towards the UN's target of 0.7 per cent of GDP. .
'Tory isolationism and narrow nationalism would turn Britain's back on the world'

Conservatives: Francis Maude and Gary Streeter
 Participate in US missile defence plans.
 Realise potential of Commonwealth - 'a force for good in the world'.
 More of aid budget to be distributed through development charities. .
'Labour talked about an ethical foreign policy but have squandered Britain's moral authority'

LibDems: Menzies Campbell and Jenny Tonge

 Support 'Tobin Tax' on international financial transactions.
 End all links between aid and trade.
 End tax subsidies for arms sales. .
'The ethical dimension must be central to foreign policy - we will not let the Government forget what they promised'

But what's the real issue?
Mark Leonard, Director, The Foreign Policy Centre
'This election will focus on domestic issues but political parties must explain how only international engagement can deliver the things that we elect politicians for - more jobs, lower crime and a cleaner environment. Democratising multinational organisations, defining their values and making them work effectively should replace Johnny Foreigner-bashing in the political vocabulary.'

webTitle: Hit, miss and maybe - New Labour's record

fields.headline: Hit, miss and maybe
fields.standfirst: The rights and wrongs of New Labour.
fields.trailText: The rights and wrongs of New Labour.
fields.body:
Hit

The Economy
'You can't trust Labour' won the Tories the 1992 election. But Brown has turned Labour's Achilles heel into its strongest electoral card. The next phase is to rewrite the language of economic policy - government should seek not to 'spend' but to 'invest'.

Redistribution
They haven't shouted about it, but the worst-off have done best under Labour. Incomes for the poorest 10 per cent have gone up by 9 per cent - the direct result of government action - from the minimum wage to the working family's tax credit.

Northern Ireland
The most intractable issue in British politics. Has taken up more time than any other issue but has been contained, with genuine prospects of hope. Devolution stalled twice but the referendum showed what the voters expect.

Clare Short
Many thought she would be the most gaffe-prone member of the Government. Her 'golden elephant' diplomacy towards Montserrat in 1997 showed a lack of tact. But the new Department for International Development has done much to reshape debate and delivery. The White Paper on 'Making Globalisation Work for the Poor' makes more sense than almost anything else written in the post-Seattle fallout. There has been progress on redeeming debt - though more is needed.

Miss

The Dome
Never again - not in a thousand years.

The trains
The Tory campaign poster 'You paid the tax - so where are the trains?' may reach new levels of political cheek but John Prescott certainly hasn't fixed the crisis. Most commuters would like the train companies to get a good kicking - but the Government also wants to increase rail travel in the hope of reviving the 'integrated transport policy'.

Asylum and immigration
Fear of being out-Widdecombed has seen the Government fail to explain clearly to the public the case for a principled stand on Britain's international obligations. Should do better.

'Ethical foreign policy'
Robin Cook claims he never said the above words - he certainly never explained what they meant. The Kosovo war was the biggest risk taken in the first term but not regulating the arms trade left room for charges of hypocrisy.

Football
'Have you noticed how we only win the World Cup under a Labour government?' said Harold Wilson. But failure in France 98 and Euro 2000 can't be covered up by a few golds in Sydney.

Maybe

Delivery, Delivery, Delivery
The test of a second term will be whether Labour can improve schools and hospitals. For all the controversies about sticking to Tory spending plans for two years, departments have struggled to allocate cash now free.

New Politics
'Are you a control freak or a pluralist?' as Paddy Ashdown asked after Blair spurned marriage in favour of casual sex. Devolution has been delivered, albeit marred by trying to hold on too strong. Only a more relaxed second term would give Labour the creativity to renew itself in office.

Europe
Hard decisions can't be evaded. A euro referendum would be New Labour's biggest risk but would define Blair's place in history.

There has been progress on redeeming debt - though more is needed. Miss The Dome Never again - not in a thousand years. The trains The Tory campaign poster 'You paid the tax - so where are the trains?' may reach new levels of political cheek but John Prescott certainly hasn't fixed the crisis. Most commuters would like the train companies to get a good kicking - but the Government also wants to increase rail travel in the hope of reviving the 'integrated transport policy'. Asylum and immigration Fear of being out-Widdecombed has seen the Government fail to explain clearly to the public the case for a principled stand on Britain's international obligations. Should do better. 'Ethical foreign policy' Robin Cook claims he never said the above words - he certainly never explained what they meant. The Kosovo war was the biggest risk taken in the first term but not regulating the arms trade left room for charges of hypocrisy. Football 'Have you noticed how we only win the World Cup under a Labour government?' said Harold Wilson. But failure in France 98 and Euro 2000 can't be covered up by a few golds in Sydney. Maybe Delivery, Delivery, Delivery The test of a second term will be whether Labour can improve schools and hospitals. For all the controversies about sticking to Tory spending plans for two years, departments have struggled to allocate cash now free. New Politics 'Are you a control freak or a pluralist?' as Paddy Ashdown asked after Blair spurned marriage in favour of casual sex. Devolution has been delivered, albeit marred by trying to hold on too strong. Only a more relaxed second term would give Labour the creativity to renew itself in office. Europe Hard decisions can't be evaded. A euro referendum would be New Labour's biggest risk but would define Blair's place in history.

fields.headline: So farewell then
fields.standfirst: On their way out - by choice
fields.trailText: MPs on their way out - by choice
fields.body:
A record number of MPs retired before the last election but few - beyond Lords Hattersley and Baker - had made an impact on the national consciousness. This year sees a smaller but more distinguished crop depart.

Tony Benn: It is decades since Harold Wilson quipped that Benn 'immatures with age' but he is now leaving the Commons 'to spend more time in politics'. Has spent 47 years as an MP since first being elected in 1950, interrupted by his historic quest to renounce his hereditary peerage and loss of seat in 1983. Argued that party's worst-ever result marked 'eight-and-a-half-million votes for socialism' and modernisers still see his razor-edge defeat by Denis Healey in 1981 deputy-leadership election as a turning-point for Labour's fortunes.

Edward Heath, 84, is the outgoing Father of the House, having spent 51 unbroken years in Parliament. The history books will record that he took Britain into Europe. Resented 'the peasants' revolt' of 1975, which made Margaret Thatcher leader instead, and is thought unlikely to accept invitation to join his former nemesis in the Lords.

John Major would still be an MP in 2023 if he chose to remain as long as Heath did after losing the party leadership. But the former PM, who will be 58 at the election, would prefer to choose from the wide range of commercial, speaking and writing options open to him. But he will keep a political role too - Major has been teaching A-level politics students part-time at a local school, and could well feature in a euro campaign.

Michael Heseltine's Oxford envelope nearly got it right, with the millions and the Cabinet post, but he fell one step short of the top job. Post-election heart attack in 1997 finally ended political ambition: he will now spend more time with his trees at his Oxfordshire home.

Paddy Ashdown is pleased to retire with the shambolic party he inherited in its best state for over 70 years, but is disappointed he didn't manage to get it into the New Labour big tent. The second volume of his memoirs promises to reveal the most explosive details of the Tony-Paddy affair, but he may also still take on an international political role.

Former Tory Defence Secretary Tom King (Bridgwater) will perhaps now be best remembered for a starring role in Alan Clark's diary. The eurosceptic ranks may dominate the post-election party, but it is hard to think they will ever quite replace Theresa Gorman (Billericay) or Sir Richard Body (Boston and Skegness) who were perhaps the most bonkers supporters of the John Redwood 'barmy army' leadership campaign.

Labour's Dale Campbell-Savours (Workington) was an assiduous campaigner for Commons probity, while Giles Radice (Durham) is among the last members of his generation of the europhile Fabian old-right to depart. Robert Maclennan (LibDem, Caithness) is perhaps the least heralded British party leader ever, having nursed the SDP through to the merger with the Liberals after Lord Owen left.

Ulster Unionists Ken Maginnis and John Taylor depart after 18 years apiece, costing David Trimble a level of experience and loyalty he can ill afford to lose.

Home to home rule: First Ministers Rhodri Morgan and Henry McLeish are off to focus fully on running Wales and Scotland. Former Welsh Secretary Ron Davies and Scots LibDem leader Jim Wallace are leaving too.

Early departures: Tess Kingham (Gloucester, 38 ), Judith Church (Dagenham, 47) and Jenny Jones (Wolverhampton SW, 43) have decided there are better places to work than the Commons. David Faber (Westbury, 39) decided to make money instead. Mo Mowlam (Redcar) will be among those most missed.

Five things we're glad to have seen the back of (we hope):
1 The Millennium Experience
2 Peter Mandelson popping in and out of the Cabinet
3 Kevin Keegan managing England
4 17-year-old entrepreneurs with 'second-round funding'
5 The 'stars' of Big Brother - remember them?

And five more we wouldn't miss:
1 Rabble rousing on asylum
2 Farming crises
3 Darius from Popstars
4 Six-year-olds using mobiles
5 Railtrack

webTitle: You must remember this - key moments 1997-2001

fields.headline: You must remember this
fields.trailText: The key political moments of 1997 to 2001
fields.body:
1997 Landslide! Seven Tory Cabinet Ministers lose their seats. 'It is a new dawn, is it not?' says Tony Blair at the South Bank as Labour parties away 18 years of hurt. John Major off to watch cricket, Paddy Ashdown's Liberal Democrats celebrate 20 gains. Will 101 'Blair babes' revolutionise Parliament?

Chancellor Gordon Brown stuns and delights the City by granting independence to the Bank of England.

June

Labour signs the Social Chapter as our European partners hope for a new approach.

The Cabinet gives green light to the Dome - £750 million later, 6m visitors are missing.

Tory leadership battle: Anne Widdecombe knifes Michael Howard - there is 'something of the night' about him. The late 'Stop Hague' deal from John Redwood and Kenneth Clarke is compared by one backbencher to the Nazi-Soviet pact - but William Hague wheels out Maggie and clinches it.

The flag goes down in Hong Kong.

July

Brown's first Budget - windfall tax and £3 billion for education and health.

Blair's frenetic first 100 days end with increased Tory majority in Uxbridge by-election.

August

Death of the 'People's Princess' in Paris. Palace calls New Labour in to dampen insurrectionary fervour.

September

Devolution referendums: Scotland says an emphatic 'Yes, Yes'; Wales 'well, if we must'.

Blair tells jubilant Labour in Brighton to 'make this the giving age'.

In Blackpool, a new caring, sharing Portillo reaches out to single mothers and the poor.

Labour's worst week - 1 Brown's man Charlie Whelan sends the City spinning by rewriting euro policy from his mobile in The Red Lion. Blair and Brown patch it up; Brown's 'five tests' will decide.

November

Labour's worst week - 2 Labour gives Bernie Ecclestone his £1m back after reversing tobacco ad ban. PM asks voters to keep the faith: 'I think I'm a pretty straight kind of guy.'

December

Hague humiliated as Lord Cranborne does a secret deal with Labour to reprieve 91 hereditary peers, to be chosen in the first election of their lives.

Winchester by-election turns May's two-vote Tory defeat into 21,536 LibDem majority.

Biggest backbench revolt as 47 Labour MPs vote against cuts in single-parent benefit.

1998 January

Launch of Food Standards Agency: no more BSE-style repetitions then.

March

Brown's Budget introduces working family's tax credit and promises to 'modernise entire tax and benefits system of this country'.

The Good Friday Agreement offers Northern Ireland an historic chance for peace.

Lobbygate: 'There are 17 people that matter - and to say that I am intimate with every one of them is the understatement of the century.' Derek Draper's pitch for business to an undercover Observer journalist shakes New Labour badly with accusations of sleaze. Plus ça change?

First reshuffle. Mandelson comes out of the shadows and gets a portfolio at the Dti. Margaret Jay becomes Leader of the Lords. Four Cabinet sackings as a tearful Harriet Harman leaves the Government. Arch-rival Frank Field sacked, too.

August:

Real IRA bomb in Omagh kills 29.

Pinochet arrested in London. Red Mandelson finds him 'gut-wrenching'.

September Labour delegates stuck on Virgin trains to Blackpool conference. Blair tells party of 'tough choices' ahead but is interrupted by ovation for Mo Mowlam.

Hague wins an election - as Tory party backs his Eurosceptic line.

October

'A moment of madness' on Clapham Common brings down Welsh Secretary Ron Davies.

The Jenkins Report recommends electoral reform. But resistance from the Labour tribe postpones the promised PR referendum to the second term at least.

November

Victory in Europe. The beef ban is lifted after 27 months.

December

Labour's Worst Week - 3 When two tribes go to war. Geoffrey Robinson's secret loan to Mandelson is revealed. They both resign. Blair tells Mandelson, 'You will achieve much, much more with us.'

1999 January

The 11 countries of 'Euroland' celebrate the birth of a new currency. The euro starts trading at $1.16. Britain will wait and see.

February

Lawrence report: Police chief Paul Condon expresses 'deep shame' at failures. But a right-wing backlash claims Sir William Macpherson's report has besmirched and demoralised the police.

March

Brown wins praise from all sides for his Budget: a penny off the basic rate, new 10p starting rate but abolition of mortgage-tax relief.

European Commission resigns en masse after corruption row. President Jacques Santer replaced by former Italian PM Romano Prodi.

Nato bombing of Serbia begins. Blair proposes a new interventionist doctrine for the international community. He also goes to a Macedonian refugee camp and, in shirt sleeves, tells the refugees he is committed to ensuring their return home. Seventy eight days later, despite coalition wobbles and the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in May, Milosevic backs down. Ground troops finally enter Kosovo unopposed on 12 June.

April

Minimum wage takes effect - £3.60 an hour for 1.9m workers. And a 10p rise the following February.

London nail-bombings in Brixton, Brick Lane and Soho. 'The bombers are the real minority in Britain today,' says the PM.

June

Hague triumphs in the European elections, on a 24 per cent turnout. But a crushing defeat by the LibDems in Romsey takes the shine away. The first devolved assembly elections see Labour stung badly in Wales, but the SNP's bark proves worse than its bite, with a Lib-Lab coalition in Holyrood.

Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones get hitched. Not the most exciting of royal weddings.

Greg Dyke becomes Director-General of the BBC.

Passport Agency computer chaos leaves 530,000 on the waiting lists. Home Office Minister Mike O'Brien promises to do better but nobody resigns. Troublesome things, passports.

The reshuffle that never was - Northern Ireland Secretary Mowlam won't go. Blair calls the whole thing off.

August

'Chat-show Charlie' Kennedy wins LibDem leadership.

September

Conference 1999. Ashdown's fond farewells.

Blair claims Martin Luther King, Nelson Mandela and Stephen Lawrence are on his side in the argument over the 'forces of conservatism'.

Prescott chauffeured 300 yards to make speech about cutting car usage. His excuse: 'The wife doesn't like having her hair blown about.'

October

Turkeys finally vote for Christmas as Lords pass reform Bill. Earl of Burford, seizes the woolsack, crying, 'This Bill, drafted in Brussels, is treason.'

November

Portillo is back as MP for Kensington and Chelsea despite attack of candour over 'youthful homosexual liaisons'.

The Battle of Seattle propels the World Trade Organisation to centre-stage as the trade talks collapse.

December Disgraced Tory Neil Hamilton loses libel trial again: will he give up?

2000 January

The millennium brings a moment of peace and reconciliation - except for those stuck on the Jubilee Line.

May

May Day protests in London.

In the London mayoral race, Labour's Frank Dobson comes third as even the Mirror says 'Vote Tory'. LibDem Susan Kramer walks every high street in London without anyone noticing. And, in the end, Citizen Ken is finally back: 'As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted 15 years ago'

June Labour's worst week - 4 Only the Women's Institute could find Third-Way Blair 'too political' - he is booed off at Wembley.

July Blair worried that his government is seen as 'out of touch' with 'gut British instincts'.

Perhaps a populist measure on crime could help. But PM's policy of cashpoint fines for drunken yobs falls foul of Euan Blair's GCSE celebrations.

Comprehensive Spending Review, £43bn extra for public services promised over next three years. But when will voters notice?

August Hague boasts to men's magazine GQ that he can down 14 pints.

September

Labour's worst week - really. Panic at the pumps as Britain runs dry. 'We will listen but we will not be intimidated,' says rattled PM. But three-quarters of voters back the fuel protests.

Poll shock as Mori gives Tories first lead for eight years. Could it be a contest after all?

The Tories in Blackpool throw it all away. Widdecombe ditches hard-line soft drugs policy as a third of Shadow Cabinet admits to occasional past puff - but only Tim Yeo says he enjoyed it.

October

Human Rights Act becomes law.

Death of Donald Dewar, much-loved First Minister of Scotland.

November

Tragic train crash at Hatfield exposes cracked rails across the network.

Prescott storms out, as climate talks collapse, blaming the French.

Nice summit: no superstate in sight as leaders squabble about reweighting votes.

2001

January

It won't be him. Sir Richard Branson loses the lottery.

After Labour funding controversies, Tories delighted to unveil a £5m donor of their own - bookmaker Stuart Wheeler, whose IG Index quotes a triple-figure Labour majority.

February

After 16 months back in, the curse of the Dome finally catches up with Mandelson. He's out for the second time - this time for good?

Blair visits US President George W Bush after bombing Baghdad. They have the same taste in toothpaste, so leadership of the free world seems safe.

PM sets out second-term vision of 'a Britain which breaks down barriers to opportunity'.

Yet another food crisis as foot-and-mouth disease strikes.

March

Hague uncovers secret Labour 'plot' to turn Britain into 'a foreign land' - 'we will give you your country back.'

Brown opens - or half-opens - the war chest with a family-friendly Budget. But Mr Prudent argues that it's no pre-election give away, since he also pays off a sizeable amount of national debt.

'It's in the bag, Tony,' says the Sun, but he's still not sure he can name the date.

fields.headline: Birmingham Edgbaston
fields.trailText: Can the Tories regain an urban foothold in the leafy suburbs?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Tory urban revival would need to start in leafy Edgbaston. After Longbridge closure, economic debate about Europe may start sooner here.

The form: The first of Labour's 147 gains last time, the 10 per cent swing confirmed that a famous night lay ahead. Labour has never before held Edgbaston.

Local landmarks: Test cricket ground, Birmingham University, BBC Pebble Mill.

Key voters: 18,000 pensioners will form a high proportion of voters. Women excluded from pension rights have been a key issue for Labour's Gisela Stuart.

Local issues: Closure of nearby Longbridge made Labour majority look more precarious.

The verdict: Any genuine Conservative challenge would need to win here. Tories think their man Nigel Hastilow has the popular touch that's required and Stuart will have to work hard to argue that the Midlands economy can't afford Euroscepticism. If Tories win, Hague is heading towards safety.

The candidates
Gisela Stuart (Labour): Munich-born law lecturer enjoys the irony of representing Neville Chamberlain's old seat. Pro-European Blairite, now naturalised citizen, has fenced for adopted country.

Nigel Hastilow (Conservative)
Maverick former editor of Birmingham Post. Only new candidate to win starring role at Prime Minister's questions, as Blair taunted Hague in January with quotes from Hastilow's website - calling Tories 'a lost cause' in a 'time of crisis'.

Nicola Davies (LibDem)
The 28-year-old former teacher may struggle to make an impact. Stuart will hope to squeeze her 4,691 votes even further.

1997 result:
MP: Gisela Stuart (Labour)
majority 4,482
Labour 23,554
Conservative 18,712
LibDems 4,691
Referendum 1,065
(10 per cent swing)

Tory target no 79
Swing required: 5 per cent

fields.headline: Leeds North-West
fields.trailText: Can Labour get the student vote out?
fields.body:
The lowdown
Affluent trendy Leeds is a key Conservative Party target - and they will take it if Labour cannot mobilise the student vote.

The form
One of two traditionally safe Tory Leeds seats lost in 1997, which saw them wiped out across the city. Labour leapt from third place to win.

Local landmarks
Headingley cricket ground.

Key voters
About 20,000 students concentrated in Headingley complicate the electoral geography in a seat otherwise dominated by some of the city*s wealthiest suburbs.

Local issues
Student loans, tuition fees and Jack Straw, for students. Conservatives will campaign to protect the green belt in the north of the constituency.

The Verdict
Reduced student turnout could see Labour's Harold Best defeated. The Tories desperately need to regain an urban foothold - the party lost its last seats in Leeds, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh, having already been wiped out in Manchester, Liverpool and Glasgow.

The candidates

Harold Best (Labour)
Surprisingly un-Blairite figure for a usurper of Tory territory, the bearded 61-year-old former councillor is an active humanist and has deep New Left roots.

Adam Pritchard (Conservative)
Worked for local manufacturing components firm as marketing manager. He plans to focus first parliamentary campaign on law and order.

David Hall-Matthews (LibDem)
Lecturer in Development Studies would win with an 8.1 per cent swing from Labour; while that is out of reach, LibDems want to make it a three-way fight next time.

webTitle: Hague - They think its all over ..

fields.headline: They think its all over ...
fields.standfirst: ... but could William Hague still pull off a shock?
fields.trailText: ... but could William Hague still pull off a shock?
fields.body:
Reasons for William Hague to be cheerful

The electorate is more volatile than ever before
The fuel crisis provoked one of the biggest shifts in poll history, beaten only by the ERM crisis and the winter of discontent - as Labour slumped before recovering just as quickly. Party identification has fallen decade by decade - only 16 per cent describe themselves as strong party identifiers and 21 per cent of voters claim to make up their mind in the final week.

The polls over-estimate Labour support
Since 1997, Labour has done incredibly well in the polls, and much worse in local, European and devolved assembly elections. Even in 1997, Labour's opening poll lead of 22 per cent fell to 16 per cent in the final polls, and 13 per cent in the vote.

Conservatives are more likely to vote
Apathy - or 'differential turnout' - is Labour's greatest fear. A 29 per cent Euro election turn-out saw the Tories win 36 per cent of the vote to Labour's 28 per cent, despite Labour being ahead by 52 per cent to 28 in the polls at the same time.

The longest honeymoon is finally over
Blair's Government had an even higher approval rating three years in than on the day it was elected. But normal service has been resumed - voters are finally more dissatisfied (49 per cent) than satisfied (39 per cent).

But don't order the removal van yet

Undecideds don't want the Tories back
The Conservatives have almost flatlined in the polls since the 1992 European exchange-rate crisis. From the fuel crisis to Peter Mandelson's resignation, they have failed to capitalise on Labour's troubles. Voters believe the party is out of touch with ordinary people (40 per cent) and will promise anything to win votes (48 per cent), while only 11 per cent describe the party as moderate.

Behind on the issues that matter to the mainstream
The opposition campaign may chime with voters disappointed by Labour's claims of delivery - but few trust the Tories more than Labour on schools, hospitals or trains. 'Save the pound' will enthuse a sceptic core vote, but may turn off most voters for whom Europe is not a central concern.

Little appeal for young voters
John Major's biggest coup in 1992 was to gain more votes than Labour among 18- to 29-year-olds. But young voters swung most heavily to Labour (by 17 per cent) in 1997 and few Tories believe they can make major inroads.

Electoral double whammy
The Tories may back the first-past-the-post system, but it discriminates against them. Major won only a 21-seat majority in 1992 despite a 7 per cent lead in the vote. If the parties achieved the same share of the vote, Labour could win 80 seats more and a clear majority. The Tories need to be 7 per cent ahead to have more seats than Labour and would need a 10-point lead for a majority.

Finally, is William Hague himself the weakest link in the Tory campaign?51 per cent of voters are dissatisfied with his leadership, while 23 per cent think he's doing a good job.

webTitle: Campaign - what will the papers say?

fields.headline: What will the papers say?
fields.standfirst: Blair won over the Tory press in 1997. Can he do it again?
fields.trailText: Blair won over the Tory press in 1997. Can he do it again?
fields.body:
In 1997, more than 20 million people read a Labour newspaper each day, with only 10m reading Tory papers. This was almost exactly the reverse of the 1992 figures when the Tory press mugged Neil Kinnock. But what will the papers be saying this time?

Labour-leaning papers

The Sun
Then: 'The Sun Backs Blair' shock in 1997.
Now: A more muted campaign but has already endorsed Labour.
Key issue: As anti-Europe as ever.

News of the World
Then: Switched to Labour, but with much less fanfare than Sun.
Now: Don't expect much politics on the front page. However, editor Rebekah Wade has enjoyed good contacts with Number 10, and paper will back Labour again.
Key issue: Is Hague ready?

Daily Mirror and Sunday Mirror
Then: Loyal to Labour throughout the wilderness years and Gordon Brown*s biggest fans.
Now: Labour of course; will focus on Tory threat to schools and hospitals.
Key issue: Hague dangers.

The Star
Then: The least political daily.
Now: Will probably back Labour again, but few readers will notice.
Key issue: Where to put the rosettes on the election pin-up?

The Observer
Then: Backed Labour and a strong LibDem performance.
Now: Along with critical support of the government, there might be room to boost a few LibDems and Greens.
Key issue: Environment.

The Guardian
Then: Key role in exposing Tory sleaze but New Labour likes to kick against its 'critical friend'.
Now: Will back Labour again but would prefer a bolder second term.
Key issue: Public services.

The Independent
Then: First electoral endorsement - broadly backing Blair, but also some LibDems and Europhile Tories.
Now: Likely to be much harsher on Hague than Major, and more critical of New Labour. Expect another composite endorsement.
Key issue: The case for Europe.

The Independent on Sunday
Then: Backed Labour with anti-Tory tactical voting.
Now: May flirt with LibDems but probably not Alastair Campbell*s biggest concern.
Key issue: Apathy.

Financial Times
Then: Backed Labour in 1997 - citing, as part of its rationale, irrational Tory Euroscepticism.
Now: Labour should retain an endorsement valued more for its boost to credibility than votes.
Key issue: It*s the economy, stupid.

Daily Express and Daily Express
Then: Both Express titles backed Major in 1997 but switched to Blair after election.
Now: New owner Richard Desmond has pledged to stick to Labour but depleted political team will be competing with the celebs from OK!.
Key issue: How will Posh *n* Becks vote?

Tory-leaning papers

Daily Mail
Then: Tory to its bootstraps but anger at John Major meant a mostly Eurosceptic campaign in 1997. Now: Happier with Hague: Labour has sold out on family values and thinks Jack Straw has gone soft on crime. Key issue: Euroscepticism - and asylum soft touch.

Mail on Sunday Then: Backed Major without much conviction. Now: Right-wing columnist Peter Hitchens, who argues that New Labour wants to turn Britain into a one-party state, will help to influence the editorial line. Key issue: New Labour arrogance.

The Daily Telegraph and The Sunday Telegraph
Then: Found case for Tory fifth term 'overwhelming'.
Now: Outraged by New Labour, from fox-hunting to Europe, but will keep close eye on Tory internal politics.
Key issue: Euroscepticism.

The Sunday Times
Then: A strongly partisan campaign in 1997 endorsed the Tories 'warts and all'.
Now: Unhappy with New Labour but moderate Tory editor John Witherow feels Hague is a huge letdown too.
Key issue: Which is the lesser of two evils?

The Times
Then: Endorsed Eurosceptics including Sir James Goldsmith, Tony Benn, Diane Abbott and LibDem Nick Harvey.
Now: Will combine acerbic Eurosceptic commentary with fairly straight news and keep its powder dry until the final week. A key battleground for Portillistas and Hagueites if Tories are in trouble.
Key issue: Euroscepticism.

Famous election ambushes

Daily Mail 1924: The Zinoviev Letter As Labour's first-ever Government went to the polls, the Daily Mail produced 'evidence' that it was in league with Russian spies. A forgery - but the Tories won.

Daily Mirror 1951: Whose Finger on the trigger? Churchill may have won the war, but the shock Mirror splash argued he was too much of a maverick for the nuclear age. It didn't save a tired Attlee Government - Labour won most votes, but the Tories had a majority.

The Sun 1992: Nightmare on Kinnock Street Pages of anti-Welsh diatribes and dystopian fantasies intended as a history lesson for those too young to remember 1979. It was the Sun 'wot won it' they crowed.

The Observer 1997: Portillo: Was it 'the Obs wot won it'? A constituency-based poll on the final Sunday showed how tactical voting could bring about Tory defeats. Labour won from third place in a number of seats.
