fields.headline: Croydon Central
fields.trailText: Can former Tory MP reverse his 1997 defeat?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Suburban snapshot of Britain's electoral battleground in miniature.

The form: Is it the concrete citadel of Croydon that best sums up Britain 2001? The key town-centre marginal is squeezed between the thumping 18-vote Labour majority in Croydon North and a 12,000 Tory lead in Croydon South. Naturally Majorite suburbs swung angrily to Labour last time.

Local landmarks: Few obvious postcard shots, but Croydon's shiny new millennial Tramlink comes closer to an integrated transport strategy than anywhere else.

Key voters: The grim 'fifties New Addington estate, just out of town, houses 20,000 people. If Davies can't get Labour's vote out there he will be swamped by Tory suburbia.

Local issues: It's the economy, stupid. Croydon is booming at full employment but the Conservative Party will hope tax cuts tempt voters back.

The verdict: Both candidates know the local turf inside out. Davies will hope the national economy is decisive, but Labour's heartlands vote is vital in the marginals, too.

The candidates

Geraint Davies (Labour): Economically literate Blairite helped Labour take Croydon council after a century of Tory control before winning on third shot at one of Croydon's parliamentary seats.

David Congdon (Conservative): Was MP here from 1992 to 1997 with a 14,661 majority, but suffered from re-distribution and an above-average swing. Local councillor for 16 years and former deputy leader.

Paul Booth (LibDem): Bromley councillor, aged 50. Came third there last time and no chance of improving on that this time.

1997 result MP: Geraint Davies
Labour - majority 3,897
Labour 25,432
Conservatives 21,535
Liberal Democrats 6,061
Referendum 1,886
(15.5 per cent swing C to L)

Tory target no 53
Swing required: 3.5 per cent

fields.headline: Enfield Southgate
fields.trailText: Can Labour's unlikely hero defy political gravity?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Tory revenge should be simple and sweet - but can the hero of 1997 hold out against the swing?

The form: Astounding 17.4 per cent swing to Labour overturned Michael Portillo's 15,500 majority in 1997. The third-safest seat lost by the Tories. Unless Labour is set for another 150-seat plus majority, Stephen Twigg should not stand a chance of holding on.

Local landmarks: Hadley Wood known for affluence - and celebrity residents Dennis Bergkamp and Lennox Lewis.

Key voters: Sizeable Asian and Cypriot communities will help Labour.

Local issues: Two-thirds of Enfield voters commute; if the 18.13 train from Liverpool Street gets stuck too often, the man who epitomises the euphoria of 1997 might pay the price.

The verdict: Portillo's defeat was voted the third most memorable TV moment of all time by Observer readers, and Twigg is locally more popular still. The pro-PR, openly gay Twigg is very much on his party's liberal wing - the Labour candidate most likely to retain tactical support. A surprise hold?

The candidates

Stephen Twigg (Labour): Tipped for Cabinet Ü would be the first choice of many Labour by-election committees if he lost. But the 34-year-old former NUS president plans to hang on.

John Flack (Conservative): Eurosceptic who used to work for Norman Tebbit. Has been told by Central Office that he should win without much back-up. Should he be worried that Blair set out his second-term vision in a local school?

Wayne Hobam (LibDem): Late selection raised allegations of an informal Lib-Lab 'understanding'.

1997 result
MP: Stephen Twigg (Labour)
Majority 1,433

Labour 20,570
Conservatives 19,137
Liberal Democrats 4,966
Referendum 1,342
(17.4 per cent swing Con to Lab)

Tory target no 23
Swing required: 1.5 per cent

fields.headline: Dartford
fields.trailText: Can Labour stop 'Bluewater woman' shopping around?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Can Labour retain foothold in true blue territory?

The form: Labour's frontline election trench now digs deep into the 'garden of England'. Having won nothing in the county since 1979, Labour was astonished to win eight of Kent's 17 seats in 1997. Some Labour losses seem inevitable but Dartford was usually Labour before 1979 - a 24-year-old Margaret Roberts (later Thatcher) lost here in 1950.

Local landmarks: Bluewater shopping centre - Europe's largest - took over £770 million last year.

Local issues: Kent Conservatives have sought to win support on asylum fears.

Key voters: Forty per cent of voters commute, but many still blame the Conservatives for the state of the railways.

The verdict: The Tories must recover Gillingham, Sittingbourne and Chatham. They would take Dartford too if they were serious about winning. But Stoate will hope that Labour's economic performance will stop Bluewater man and woman shopping around.

The candidates:

Howard Stoate (Labour):Blairite former Dartford councillor and GP who continued to hold surgeries for patients as well as constituents after election. Governor of local grammar school which his children attend.

Bob Dunn (Conservative): Held this seat for 18 years after 1979, although never rose higher in government ranks than parliamentary under-secretary for education.

The LibDems have yet to select a candidate for Dartford, suggesting that the seat is a low priority for the party.

1997 result
MP: Howard Stoate
Labour - majority 4,328

Labour 25,278
Conservatives 20,950
Liberal Democrats 4,827
British National Party 428
(11.5 per cent swing)

Tory target no 63
Swing required: 4.2 per cent

fields.headline: The Battleground
fields.standfirst: Kamal Ahmed on the tests of success and failure
fields.trailText: Kamal Ahmed, Political Editor, introduces The Observer 2001 Election guide. Plus how the parties will judge success or failure.
fields.body:
The Labour Party has its attack unit. The Tories have their battle plan, scrutinised, and tweaked to make sure each issue is exploited to its full potential. Each day of the election campaign is mapped out in the war book, the political bible on who will be saying what during the election campaign.

For Blair the plus points are clear - the economy, education and health. He worries about attacks on crime and Europe, the 'arrogance factor' and asylum seekers. But the voter also needs to examine two key aspects of the result.

First, the majority: more than 120 would be a vindication of the last four years; under 40 would be a severe jolt to the system. Second, the turnout: if one in five Labour voters doesn't bother to vote, the party could lose 60 marginal seats.

For Hague the plus points are harder to nail down - Europe works well for some, the asylum issue for others - but he has been criticised for failing to map out a coherent Tory philosophy. He will have done well if he produces any evidence, however slim, of a fightback. If Labour's majority falls below 60, Hague is almost guaranteed another election; if it stays above 100, it's probably curtains.

For the Liberal Democrats, Charles Kennedy will need to hold on to what he's got and try and position the party in second place in as many seats as possible for the big push in 2005. As ever it will be a messy, bloody affair, with weeks of claims and rebuttals, statistics and dirty tactics. Keep your wits about you and use our guide to unpick the political spin.

The Battleground

Labour

Winning will not be enough for Tony Blair. A working majority of 30 or 40 will seem as much of a setback as the achievement of an unprecedented second Labour term. The apparent inevitability of victory may cost Labour votes and seats. New Labour was built on the belief that the secret of success was to keep expectations in check - but perhaps the party should resist the temptation to view its accidental landslide as a millstone. It provides the foundation to win big again, which may be essential to Labour's historic ambitions.

Secure the Second Term The Blairite mantra since 1997. Having secured the trust to govern, the promise is of a radicalism developed in office. Accounts of the Thatcher second and third terms have been much-thumbed in Downing St.

Get the voters out - keep turnout above 65 per cent Labour's real opposition is apathy. What seems a predictable re-election may well see turnout below 1997's 70 per cent historic low. Every percentage point below that could cost Labour 10-15 seats.

Prepare to win on the euro The Government's recommendation on the euro may be up to two years away, but Gordon Brown's sixth test is whether or not Labour can risk it. In this campaign, Labour will focus on people's right to vote on the euro later. But Labour will want a majority of at least 70-80 to feel confident of turning public opinion around.

But ... the Labour Left would prefer a smaller majority. Mark Seddon, editor of Tribune, thinks a majority of around 30 would mean a return to 'proper politics'.

Conservatives

Even if William Hague matches the party's record postwar swing (5.2 per cent), Labour would still expect a comfortable majority of up to 50 seats. He may always have seen the Conservative recovery as a two-term task, but will need to survive a highly personalised campaign to get another shot. What used to be Europe's most ruthless and formidable election-winning party will demand real progress.

Save Hague - by cutting Labour majority to 70 A Labour majority of under 60 would certainly save Hague. In the danger-zone, between 60 and 100, much will depend on whether anybody wants to take the job on. Hague will certainly need to do better than Neil Kinnock did with his first shot in 1987 - a 1.7 per cent swing which failed to prevent the Tories winning another three-figure majority.

Except ... for those Shadow Cabinet rivals who think they could do better.

Kill off the euro A recovery in Tory fortunes would increase the chances of Labour ducking the issue. But the dream Conservative scenario is for the party to fight and win a 'Keep the Pound' campaign. Except for the Tory Europhiles.

Win the English election - a swing of 7.6 per cent Having accepted devolution, Hague hopes to make constitutional mischief with a 'English votes for English laws' call. If he can take all the English seats up to Erewash in Derbyshire, he will have a majority in England. But that requires a 7.6 per cent swing from Labour and a Tory lead of 2.2 per cent.

Win seats in Scotland and Wales Any serious Conservative attempt to win a future election cannot just be an English strategy. Recovering all of the last 10 Scottish and six Welsh seats lost in 1997 is highly unlikely - but the Conservatives need to show they can win back 'Middle Scotland' in Eastwood, Edinburgh Pentlands and Perth, and gain a foothold in Wales, if they want to go beyond limiting the damage to challenging for power.

Liberal Democrats

With 'the project' of closer Labour ties stalled and no prospect of overtaking even the Tories, Charles Kennedy again faces the perennial question 'What are the LibDems for?'. The party will fight a defensive campaign to hold its south-west gains, but nationally needs a more edgy liberal and youth-focused campaign if it is to restore a sense of purpose in its ranks.

Hold their 1997 gains Having won 26 extra seats in 1997 without increasing their vote, the LibDems will be mostly defending ground won. The south-west is the key battleground, where they defend 14 seats, having gained six last time.

Increase share of first-time and young voters The LibDems held steady last time while voters under 30 switched heavily - on a 17 per cent swing - from Conservative to Labour. Student loans and liberal principles should make this fertile ground against Labour in power.

Develop an urban presence In their various guises, Liberal parties have always fallen back severely whenever Tory oppositions recover. Kennedy will also be looking to develop the ability to win by-elections against Labour in its urban heartlands if things turn sour for Blair.

fields.headline: Command HQ
fields.standfirst: Inside the campaign boiler-room
fields.trailText: Inside the campaign boiler-room
fields.body:
Labour: The Millbank war room

Labour staffers are rather proud of the mythology that surrounds Millbank. The mundane reality is a standard two-floor, open-plan layout, which will be overflowing as regular staff are joined by top spinners and wonks.

The Generals

Gordon Brown will enjoy being in sole command after sharing the role with Peter Mandelson last time.

Douglas Alexander MP Role: MP for Paisley South, who will support Brown's command.
Inside track: Brown protege and rising star at the heart of the Scottish Labour establishment: sister Wendy is Scottish Enterprise Minister.

The Spinners

Alastair Campbell Role: PM's press secretary, who will be out on the road with Blair. Inside track: After the election, will the former tabloid bruiser and 'the real deputy PM' be tempted by a million for his memoirs? Or would he would miss the lobby after all?

David Hill Role: Veteran Labour spinner will be Campbell's key link man.
Inside track: Worked for the party for 25 years before a private-sector spell with Sir Tim Bell; highly respected in both politics and the media.

The Party Machine
Margaret McDonagh Role: Party General Secretary, will oversee the national campaign. Inside track: Criticised for abrasive style Ð but the most powerful woman in a highly traditionalist party. She will want to regain credit with activists after taking the rap for the London Mayor fiasco.

The Wonks
David Miliband Role: Head of Downing St policy unit.
Inside track: Responsible for manifesto and the 'vision thing'. Expected to leave wonkery for Westminster.

Ed Balls Role: Special adviser to Gordon Brown.
Inside track: Once immortalised by a Heseltine attack on Labour economic jargon - 'it's not Brown, it's Balls' - and half of New Labour power couple with Yvette Cooper.

The Conservatives: Hague's Kitchen Cabinet
William Hague has ruthlessly purged Central Office of staffers suspected of loyalty to his potential rivals, allowing him to assemble the team he wants for his toughest political fight.

The Generals
Michael Ancram Role: Party Chairman.
Inside track: Brian Mawhinney had a nightmare in 1997. Anything Ancram can do is an improvement.

Seb Coe Role: Chief of Staff.
Inside track: Former Olympic star who lost Falmouth seat to LibDems in 1997. Middle-distance world-beater may lack political stamina. More a judo partner and confidant than key electoral strategist, and likely to leave sometime soon for athletics politics.

The Spinners
Amanda Platell Role: Director of Communications.
Inside track: Glamorous Australian former editor of Sunday Express viewed with suspicion by party grandees. Astonishingly loyal to lost cause, but should follow her media bonkbuster Scandal with the Tory inside story.

Nicholas Glieve Role: Press Secretary.
Inside track: Mysterious former accountant, but now Hague's closest confidant. An almost constant presence in William and Ffion TV documentary.

The Wonks

Danny Finkelstein Role: Director of the Policy Unit and Harrow West candidate.
Inside track: Former SDP brain behind 'common sense revolution' standing for the first time. Writes many Hague jokes, but comedy talent may be underused as leader fears seeming 'unstatesmanlike'.

The Liberal Democrats

Dick Newby Role: Chief of Staff.
Inside track: Ex-SDP Peer was Ashdown's press officer on 1992 campaign trail. Caught Labour spies listening in on Kennedy's Commons office.

Tim Razzall Role: LibDem peer and election campaign chairman.
Inside track: Known as 'Lord Razzall of Dazzle' for his love of the high life and West Indies villa. He has promised that the party will not run a single negative poster or ad.

fields.headline: The ad-men: LibDems
fields.standfirst: Banc - the LibDem campaign
fields.trailText: Banc - the LibDem campaign
fields.body:
Key player: Peter Harold. Previous work includes campaigns for American Express and BMW.

The brief: Niche player seeks market expansion, looking for professional support after 1997's in-house work.

Budget: around £3m.

The pitch: 'We'll get the LibDems noticed Ð using plenty of attitude and not much cash to set a relevant new agenda.'

Inside track: LibDems hope the agency's success in popularising Covent Garden Soup with a youth audience will help them shed 'lentils, beards and sandals' image.

The form: Newcomers to the political arena but first effort, 'I jump on injustice. Not on bandwagons' poster signals how it hopes to stand out.

Chances of success: a sparky liberal campaign could see off the old 'wasted vote' argument but Banc should beware - KnightLeachDelaney, the last agency to work for the LibDems, went bust.

fields.headline: The ad-men: Conservatives
fields.standfirst: Yellow M - the Conservative campaign
fields.trailText: Yellow M - the Conservative campaign
fields.body:
Key player: Ronnie Duncan. First advertising job was on the 'Thank you very much' Roses chocolate campaign.

The brief: The toughest relaunch in advertising history. Traditional leading brand has lost its way. Current customer base puts new consumers off.

Budget: £10 million.

The pitch: 'We'll be hard-hitting and hip, cutting through 'beltway politics' to the issues people care about.'

Inside track: Little-known Edinburgh agency. 'Saatchi & Saatchi of the twenty-first century,' says Michael Ancram, Tory chairman. But major agencies didn't want the contract.

The form: Controversial Scottish Assembly campaign led by one-word posters 'Bliar'. Hard-hitting 'You paid the tax' campaign got noticed, although 'Where are the trains?' was a step too far.

Chances of success: Low - but no great shame in failing to deliver Hague to Number 10. The media exposure should do the agency no harm, but inexperienced and may try too hard to shock.

fields.headline: The big hitters
fields.trailText: Who packs the biggest punch?
fields.body:
Labour

Tony Blair No PM has been more popular at this stage, but Blair still seems underdefined and unloved. His 1997 watchword was reassurance. Now as he leaves Whitehall to reconnect with voters, can he show that he is delivering and is as impatient for change as they are?

The inside track: No problem out-punching William Hague in leadership stakes but wants Labour elected with enthusiasm, not by default.
What he wants: A big enough majority to go for the euro and secure his place in history.
Personal majority: 25,143 in Sedgefield.

Gordon Brown The Chancellor will mastermind Labour's campaign with an enviable record of success. Brown also wants to win the argument over the role of government for a generation.

The inside track: Brown the strategist has had the Tories dizzy with U-turns. His supreme self-confidence looks justified.
What he wants: The top job by 2007, if not next time.
Personal majority: 18,751 in Dunfermline East.

Jack Straw The bogeyman of the liberal press will face the Tory charge that Labour is 'soft on crime'.

The inside track: Brown's closest rival for the succession. Instinctively New Labour, but his reputation within the party has suffered.
What he wants: To get those liberals off his back - perhaps as Foreign Secretary?
Personal majority: 14,451 in Blackburn.

Conservatives

William Hague The video clip of a precocious 16-year-old will haunt him throughout the campaign. Talking confidently of victory, his first concern will be to keep control of the campaign and keep colleagues focused on this election, not a leadership contest to follow.

The inside track: Publicly confident but steeled for defeat. Unlikely to turn dissatisfaction with Labour into a belief that his team could do better.
What he wants: To survive - and look like he could just be PM one day.
Personal majority: 10,051 in Richmond.

Michael Portillo The battle with Brown may define his post-election reputation.

The inside track: Unsure of his ability to convince his own party that more liberal Toryism is essential. If he can't make the Tory case for lower taxes convincing, could he really lead the party to victory?
What he wants: A leadership contest to revive his interest in politics.
Personal majority: 6,706 in Kensington and Chelsea.

Francis Maude The Shadow Foreign Secretary will try to show that Blair and Robin Cook can't be trusted with Britain's interests in Europe.

The inside track: Well placed to win rave reviews from Eurosceptic press, even if banging the Eurosceptic drum leaves voters cold. But personal advancement will depend on developing a public profile.
What he wants: Sees himself as leadership material, but more likely to be key player in Tory modernisers' team.
Personal majority: 14,862 in Horsham.

Liberal Democrats Charles Kennedy Paddy Ashdown's reputation with the voters outstripped that of his party. Kennedy now needs to establish a national profile and make the case for a different type of politics.

Inside track: The LibDems' success in 1997 came from targeting. Can Kennedy defend ground already won and win new votes elsewhere?
What he wants: That LibDems should be setting the political agenda again.
Personal majority: 4,019 in Ross, Skye and Inverness West.

Simon Hughes Matthew Taylor may well be a spectator in the big tax-and-spend debate, but Hughes needs to show that a liberal approach to crime, justice and asylum issues can be effective.

Inside track: Key player in providing LibDems outside south-west with urban appeal.
What he wants: If Ken Livingstone falls short, might Hughes run for mayor next time?
Personal majority: 3,387 in Southwark North and Bermondsey.

fields.headline: Eastwood
fields.trailText: Can the Scottish Tories win a seat?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Formerly true blue bolthole in middle Scotland.

The form: The most surprising of the 10 defeats in 1997 that wiped out the Scottish Tories. They had held this seat uninterrupted for 73 years. But they need to more than triple the weak 0.75 per cent swing that saw Labour hold the seat in the 1999 Scottish Assembly election.

Local landmarks: Dormitory suburbs notable for little except evident affluence.

Key voters: With a Lib-Lab coalition running Scotland, Murphy will court 6,000 LibDem voters.

Local issues: Scots commuting classes want good schools and trains while keeping taxes in check.

The verdict: A Hague majority would require at least 11 Scottish gains, but the Scots Tories have flatlined since 1997. Must at least take Eastwood. If not, would make the charge that the Conservatives have become an English national party hard to refute.

The candidates

Jim Murphy (Labour): The ferociously Blairite former NUS President - described by some as a Scottish 'Peter Mandelson' - was 29 years old in 1997 and saw this seat as a dry run for something safer.

Raymond Robertson (Conservative): Abrasive right-wing Scottish party chairman came a poor third in losing his Aberdeen South seat last time. Eastwood defeat would mark disaster for his controversial leadership role.

Stewart Maxwell (SNP) and Allan Steele (LibDem) compete for third place.

1997 result:
MP: Jim Murphy (Labour)
majority 3,236

Labour 20,766
Conservatives 17,530
Scottish National Pty 6,826
Liberal Democrats 6,110
(14.3 per cent swing C to Lab)

Tory target no 43
Swing required: 3.1 per cent

fields.headline: Tax and Spend
fields.standfirst: Can Gordon Brown make 'Tory cuts' the equivalent of 'Labour's tax bombshell'?
fields.trailText: Can Gordon Brown make 'Tory cuts' the equivalent of 'Labour's tax bombshell'?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: Labour won a number of pre-election skirmishes - the Tory tax-cut guarantee is dead and Labour has sought to stretch spending guarantees beyond credibility. Polls have long shown that voters say we want to pay for better services - but can Michael Portillo make the case for tax cuts in prosperous times? LibDems will propose additional taxes for extra spending - that was an innovative policy back in 1992,but have they kept up with the changing debate?

Success: Shifting focus of debate from tax cuts to public service.
Failure: Did Labour need to stick to Tory spending plans for two years?

Labour: Gordon Brown and Andrew Smith
 Large real-term increases for health (6.1 per cent per year), education (5.4 per cent) and police spending (3.8 per cent) per year.
 Baby bond scheme with money invested for every new-born baby.
'Tory sums just don't add up - they are offering a £16 billion cuts guarantee

Conservatives: Michael Portillo and Oliver Letwin
 Spending guarantee to match Labour's spending plans for the NHS, schools, transport and law and order .
 £8 billion tax cuts funded from identified savings.
 Abolish IR 46 tax change that hits net entrepreneurs.
'Only the Conservatives believe in lower taxes'

LibDems: Matthew Taylor and Edward Davey
 1p on the basic rate of income tax, with new 50 per cent band on earnings over £100,000.
 End 'stealth taxes' by sending a Citizens Tax Contract to every taxpayer.
'We'll end stealth taxes - with us, what you see if what you get'

But what's the real issue?
Michael Jacobs, General Secretary, Fabian Society
'The public clearly wants higher spending more than tax cuts. But Labour still have to convince people that higher taxes are worth paying and that more spending does achieve better services. The real battle will occur not in this but in the 2005 election. Will we have by then "world-class public services"? If not, we may have to face the hard question: are we paying enough?'

 Each of the parties will say only that they can be believed on tax and spend - but what's the truth behind their claims?

Labour charge: 'Black hole' means Tory cuts.
Labour say Conservative spending plans leave a £16 billion 'black hole' in public finances, threatening schools, hospitals and policing. The Tories say they will fully identify the savings needed for their £8bn tax-cut plan, which include £1bn from welfare fraud and 'red tape', £400m by replacing the 'New Deal' and £2bn from selling Channel Four. Labour retorts that 'red-tape' savings are optimistic, while changes to the New Deal and university funding would cost rather than save money. While the parties' plans imply scientific pre-election budgeting, much depends on whether forecasts of growth and government income are accurate. Gordon Brown found an extra £9bn down the back of the sofa this year, while predecessors have been over-optimistic.

Tory charge: Brown is the high-tax Chancellor.
Though Labour has kept its promise not to increase the higher or basic rates of income tax, the Conservatives claim that, stealth taxes amount to a breach of faith. Overall taxation has risen under Labour - from 35.2 per cent to 37.2 per cent of GDP.

Kenneth Clarke has said that the Tories would not have stuck to the 'eye-wateringly tight' spending limits that Labour maintained for the first two years. But Brown's prudence has allowed him to pay off more debt this year than his predecessors did in the previous 50, bringing a permanent benefit of £4bn to the public finances every year.

Polls have long shown that voters say we want to pay for better services - but can Michael Portillo make the case for tax cuts in prosperous times? fields.headline: Health
fields.standfirst: Labour will be attacked on delivery - but would the NHS be safe in Tory hands?
fields.trailText: Labour will be attacked on delivery - but would the NHS be safe in Tory hands?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: Alan Milburn will make the NHS central to Labour's 'Tory cuts' campaign - although health is top of the list of Conservative 'spending guarantees'. Tory Liam Fox's plan to encourage private provision to ensure the NHS can succeed will be attacked as privatisation by stealth. LibDem Nick Harvey will offer even more money than Labour. All will compete with proposals on patients' dignity and the quality of care - from hospital food to mixed-sex wards.

Success: NHS Direct dealt with more than 3.5 million patients' calls.
Failure: Little sense of real change in wards and hospitals.

Labour: Alan Milburn
 Biggest-ever increases in NHS spending - 6.1 per cent a year to bring Britain up to the European average by 2005.
 No mixed-sex wards; a bedside TV and telephone for every patient.
'The Tories' two-tier NHS means privatisation by the back door'

Conservatives: Liam Fox
 Match Labour's health-spending commitments, with £500 million in tax relief to encourage private provision.
 Patient's Guarantee: maximum waiting times for treatment, beginning in cardiac and cancer services.
'Labour have made the sickest people wait longest'

LibDems: Nick Harvey
 Train an extra 5,000 doctors and 20,000 nurses over three years.
 Scrap eye-test and dental-check charges by putting 10p on a packet of cigarettes.
'Only investing in better pay can recruit and retain the staff the NHS needs'

But what's the real issue?
Julian Le Grand, Professor of Social Policy, LSE 'The Blair Government has put plenty of money into health and made institutional changes, but improvements have yet to appear - the second term is crucial for that. Health ought to be a major issue, but probably won't be. Nobody has any good alternatives; the Tories are forced into a feeble "me too" approach on spending or wild-eyed rightwingery.'

webTitle: The issues - economy and social justice

fields.headline: The economy and social justice
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown's success provides the firm base for Labour confidence - but are the government delivering social justice too?
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's success provides the firm base for Labour confidence - but are the government delivering social justice too?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: The lowest inflation for 30 years, the lowest unemployment for 16, strong growth, falling interest rates - what more could a Chancellor want as he prepares to face the country? The Tories can do little except claim that they laid the foundations for which Labour reaps the rewards, but will warn that a 'real Labour' second term would stifle business and cut growth.

Success: First Labour government to avoid an economic crisis.
Failure: High pound has squeezed manufacturing.

Labour: Gordon Brown
 Maintain independence of Bank of England.
Assess five economic tests within two years, and decide whether to recommend euro in referendum.
'No return to boom and bust'

Conservatives: Michael Portillo Cut inflation target from 2.5 per cent to 2 per cent.
 Maintain British control of interest rates and keep pound throughout Parliament.
Campaign for EU/North Atlantic free trade agreement. 'Businesses can't plan: they don't know if Labour will scrap the pound'

LibDems: Matthew Taylor

Develop new indicators of sustainable growth and quality of life for use alongside GDP
Lower age qualification for minimum wage to 16, replacing current lower rate for 18- to 21-year olds.
Strengthen Bank of England independence.
'The high pound has cost a quarter of a million manufacturing jobs'

But what's the real issue?
Evan Davis, Economics Editor, Newsnight
'The campaign debate is likely to exaggerate the role of politicians, and how far Westminster is actually running the economic show. The good news for the Tories is that good economic conditions predate this Government, but the bad news is that Labour has done nothing to upset that. The parties may now agree on the fundamentals of a stable economy but they still diverge on the size of government and on intervention in the private sector.'

What about social justice?:

So, the economy is doing well but is Britain a fairer society?

Pensions: Despite the '75p row' over the measly 2000 increases, Gordon Brown's Minimum Income Guarantee to pensioners will cost the Government more than 'restoring the link' between earnings and pensions while focusing help on the worst-off. The guarantee of at least £92.15 for every pensioner from April 2001, and £100 by 2003, should take all pensioners above the poverty line, but critics worry that the complexity of the scheme will mean that poor pensioners may miss out.

The low-paid: The minimum wage, the working family's tax credit and the new 10 per cent starting rate have seen those at the bottom of the income range benefit most under Labour, with an increase of 12 per cent to 2001 compared with 1.4 per cent for the top 30 per cent.

So is it working? The Government has made its attack on social exclusion one of the issues on which it will be judged. But there is little visible sign yet of change. In the electoral balancing act between Labour's core vote and its 1997 converts, in future it may not always be the heartlands that are told of the 'tough choices'. Blair's claim that, in the 'knowledge economy' social justice and economic prosperity now go together, may see the Government needing to spend more to lock in economic growth: raising productivity will depend on tackling the poor quality of the country's infrastructure and improving the workforce's skills base.

fields.headline: Transport
fields.standfirst: Britain isn't moving
fields.trailText: Britain isn't moving.
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: From the trains to tax on fuel, opposition parties will seek to make much of Labour's discomfort. Populist Conservative measures for motorists will be opposed by LibDems on green grounds. Labour will plead for time for its £180 billion plan to work - and trust we remember who sold off the trains in the first place.

Success: Finally abolishing fuel duty tax escalator, but not much else.
Failure: 'I will have failed in five years if there aren't fewer journeys by car,' said John Prescott. There won't be.

Labour: John Prescott and Gus MacDonald
 £180bn 10-year plan to tackle underinvestment.
 Introduce 'Transport Direct' for information and tickets across all forms of transport.
'We can't reverse years of underinvestment overnight - Tory cuts would neglect transport again'

Conservatives: Bernard Jenkin
 80 mph speed limit on motorways and 3p off fuel tax.
 BRITdisc scheme to make foreign lorries pay to use British roads.
'Labour thinks a car is something you tax, not something you drive'

LibDems: Michael Moore
 Extend free off-peak local travel to over-60s, disabled and under-19s in full-time education.
 Improve public transport with funding from urban congestion charges on motorists.
'Only proper funding of public transport can cut car use and protect the environment'

But what's the real issue?
Stephen Joseph, Director, Transport 2000 'Transport isn't a comfortable issue for any of the parties. We need to talk about how to cut traffic, reduce roadbuilding, and improve public transport. Too much is going to be said about the costs of motoring and building new roads because of pressures from unrepresentative motorist groups. But I hope we'll see some new ideas on public transport and a real commitment to reduce car use.'

fields.headline: Culture
fields.standfirst: A fierce war of words over the finer things in life
fields.trailText: A fierce war of words over the finer things in life.
fields.body:
Campaign battleground:The Dome will sum up New Labour waste and arrogance for the Tories, who will constantly repeat Tony Blair's claim that the Dome would be 'the first line' of his re-election manifesto. Culture is usually a low political priority, but Labour will claim that the 'Tory cuts guarantee' will endanger everything from school sport to future British success at the Olympics and Oscars.

Success: Olympic medal haul - both parties claim to have helped.
Failure: Lottery contract fiasco may lead to nationalisation next time.

Labour:Chris Smith
 Sixty per cent real terms increase in arts spending.
 New Opportunities Fund with extra £750 million for school sport.
 Free access to museums by changing VAT rules.
'Culture is top of the list for Tory spending cuts'

Conservatives: Peter Ainsworth

 'Set cultural institutions free' through voluntary one-off endowments.
 Privatisation of Channel Four, raising £2 billion.
 Create new partnership schemes for tourism.
 Promote school sport.
'Only the Conservatives believe in the British way of life'

LibDems: Robert MacLennan

 Double public spending on the arts.
 Make art quangos more representative.
 Review allocation of National Lottery funds.
'We will put the arts at the heart of a liberal society'

But what's the real issue?
Philip Hedley, Artistic Director, Theatre Royal, Stratford East
'Let's hope the recent £25 million investment in theatre is a good sign. It will pay back a hundred-fold in national prestige, international profits and local community well-being. The system should trust the artists more. Chris Smith says all the right things but bureaucracy still means the money does less when it lands. And I hope they don't get rid of the culture department - it would be terrible if it were subsumed into industry or education.'

fields.headline: Law and order
fields.standfirst: Battle between Widdecombe and Straw may generate more heat than light
fields.trailText: Battle between Widdecombe and Straw may generate more heat than light
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: Crime is always an opposition favourite. From the Tony Martin case to the risk of racism charges, the Conservatives have seen it as a vote-winner. Rows over crime levels and police numbers will probably be fought to a no-score draw. With everyone being so tough on crime, it will be up to Simon Hughes to ensure the causes get a look-in. All three parties will promise to 'put victims first'.

Success: Stephen Lawrence inquiry led to police and justice reform.
Failure: Early pledge on speeding up youth justice couldn't be met.

Labour: Jack Straw
 3,000 more police, 3,000 more prison places and extra money for victim support.
 'Superbobby' cash bonus to encourage police to stay on the beat.
'Crime would rise under the Tories as they cut spending on fighting it'

Conservatives: Ann Widdecombe
 Cut police bureaucracy and increase numbers.
 Victims First initiative - including new legal rights to 'self-defence'.
 National youth cadet force for 15- to 19-year-olds. 'Labour are soft on crime - we will go to war on the criminal as never before'

LibDems: Simon Hughes
 Retain jury trials, and new Ministry of Justice to ensure access for all.
 Make more use of community sentences.
'There is a crisis of confidence on crime - but the public deserves more than kneejerk responses'

But what's the real issue?
Juliet Lyon, Director, Prison Reform Trust
'All the parties agree prison has to be a useful experience, with training for work and education. But no party is prepared to say that prison is a last resort, and all are too ready to use it too early on. At election time, they all talk tough, but nobody says they mind about the rise in prison numbers, no policy is geared to reducing them, which is very disappointing: we need to tackle overcrowding and build up credible alternatives.'

webTitle: Animal pyres pumping lethal toxins into the air

fields.headline: Animal pyres pumping lethal toxins into the air
fields.trailText: Britain is facing a pollution disaster because of the hundreds of thousands of carcases being burned or buried as the Government fights foot and mouth.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed, Anthony Browne and Paul Harris
fields.body:
Britain is facing a pollution disaster because of the hundreds of thousands of carcases being burned or buried as the Government fights foot and mouth.

Environmental bodies have warned the Government that the use of kerosene, creosote and red diesel to ignite the pyres is pumping lethal dioxins into the air.

There are also concerns that burying thousands of sheep in pits will pollute the water table. The Agriculture Secretary, Nick Brown, announced last night that cattle less than five years old will also be buried.

David Manning of Nanovapor Systems, which tackles pollution problems around the world said: 'We are storing up huge problems for our children and their children,'

As the crisis moves into its sixth week with no sign of abating, the environmental issue comes as a fresh headache for the Government. Yesterday Maff announced 51 more cases of foot and mouth on Friday, revealing that the rate of increase is not slowing down. The Government is now so concerned about the environmental issue it has launched an inquiry into the effects. The National Environmental Technology Centre has been asked to monitor the hundreds of pyres that have been filling the countryside with acrid smoke.

Last week in its first report to Michael Meacher, the Environment Minister, the centre said there was evidence of dangerous levels of dioxins entering the atmosphere, particularly in the 3km radius around the fires. Dioxins are among the most deadly pollutants. At minute concentrations in the air they can cause cancer, changes in the the body's genetic make-up and fertility problems.

Mike Childs, campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, said: 'The release of so many dioxins is especially of concern, given that dioxin exposure can lead to cancers, reduced fertility, genital malformations and learning difficulties.'

The Environment Agency said in a briefing document: 'Contamination of groundwater can be difficult to detect and difficult, sometimes impossible, to remedy.'

Tim Brown, the deputy secretary of the National Association for Clean Air, said: 'Coal and old sleepers covered in bitumen ... will produce a range of pollutants, including dioxins and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, which are carcinogenic.'

More than 100 protesters yesterday blockaded an army firing range ear-marked for burning slaughtered animials in Sennybridge, Powys, mid Wales, a disease free area. They claimed burning increased the risk of spreading foot and mouth.

fields.headline: Independent's day
fields.standfirst: Voters are finding that it doesn't matter if it's New Labour or Tory, the song remains the same
fields.trailText: Middle England is patronised as well as pampered.
fields.body:
Middle England is patronised as well as pampered. Focus groupies and market researchers strain to probe and manipulate its passions. Élite politicians and pundits drop their aitches and pose as its tribunes. What's left of the Left confirms its impotence by moaning from the sidelines about a wretched political system driven by the imperative to do nothing that might upset Worcester Women and Mondeo Men as they raise 2.5 children in pebble-dashed houses.

Middle Englanders are animated by doltish complacency and irrational fears. Gestures on asylum and crime are created to placate them. They are a greedy, rootless tribe who don't give a damn for public services and the common good. Their acquiesence can be bought with a few tax cuts and cheaper petrol. These are the last people on the planet you would expect to revolt against the Private Finance Initiative. To be honest, you wouldn't expect them to have heard of the Private Finance Initiative. Yet, marvellously, Worcestershire is defying every slander and is in open, furious rebellion. There is a fair chance that it will return one of the few independent MPs to be elected since 1945 because it can't stand what Gordon Brown has done to the NHS.

The candidate, Richard Taylor, is the most refreshing and unlikely politician I've met. The 66-year-old retired rheumatologist holds a quaint belief in the power of democracy to challenge the status quo. New Labour MPs who triangulated with Old Tories, and Old Tories who triangulated with New Labour, lost that years ago and are greeting the prospect that he may well take the Wyre Forest seat with incomprehending panic. The game of British politics isn't meant to produce results like that. Independents are meant to be eccentrics who are lucky if they can save their deposits.

Taylor never wanted to be an MP. He left Kidderminster Hospital after 23 years' service with the expectation that he would fill his days by indulging his passions for classic cars and ornithology. He was transformed from a retiring twitcher to avenging angel by what should have been a nugget of cheering news. In 1997 Tony Blair pledged that if he came to power he would build a new hospital in Worcester. Political junkies will remember that Worcester women were all the rage at the time. They were the English version of Bill Clinton's soccer mums; aspiring types who didn't like paying taxes but worried about the state of the schools and hospitals.

They had plenty to worry about. For decades, pretty much everyone who needed treatment in Worcester had complained that the infirmary was split across ancient buildings on three sites. A new hospital had been promised repeatedly but never appeared. webTitle: The rich aren't cleverer, just richer - Will Hutton

fields.headline: The rich aren't cleverer, just richer
fields.standfirst: Excessive wealth threatens democracy and we must challenge the notion that governments are powerless to spread it around a bit
fields.trailText: Excessive wealth threatens democracy and we must challenge the notion that governments are powerless to spread it around a bit
fields.body:
It began in the 1970s, but I don't think any of the conservative intellectuals at the forefront of what they then called the counter-revolution ever believed that their success could be so complete. Yet, as Carol Galley, the famous fund manager and playmaker of any number of City deals, announced her retirement last week from a job with an annual income of more than £8 million and having assembled up to £100 million in personal wealth, you have to rub your eyes.

Wealth beyond any reasonable person's imagination for quite ordinary jobs is no longer unusual in the upper echelons of society. To enjoy an incredible income is not merely a validation of individual success - it is proof positive that conservative ideas have triumphed.

These incomes are not the returns for entrepreneurialism, especial talent or hard work. Galley, with her colleague, Stephen Zimmerman, who also retired last week with similar wealth, did nothing cleverer than join a City bank after university, keep their noses clean, display moderate competence and climb the hierarchy. They were beneficiaries of the 25-year boom in share prices and the associated growth in pension funds. The archaic fee structure meant that profits from fund management exploded. In this environment, monkeys could have got wealthy.

They were little more than what the Japanese disparagingly call 'salarymen' - dutiful and slightly unimaginative officers of a private-sector organisation but lucky enough to be in the right place at the right time. But today's salarymen are doing better than ever before. The executives at the top of our large companies enjoy habitual remuneration packages of £1m, but with little relation to competence or performance, as is underlined by the DTI's report into how City institutions - all mega-payers - failed to prevent Robert Maxwell from ripping off his pension funds.

Britain is in the middle of a building boom, but of Palladian country houses; £5m houses are a regular feature of the central London property market. There are waiting-lists for yachts costing tens of millions of pounds. Shops specialising in the sale of ludicrously priced art, porcelain, jewellery and designer clothes proliferate. And whatever is happening here is but a pale shadow of the baroque patterns of income and luxury spending in the United States. Indeed, Britain is only just beginning. The ratio of chief executives' remuneration to average workers' salaries stands at 35 to one in this country, roughly where it was in the US 15 years ago. In the States, it has climbed to 450 to one - and there is nothing to stop the same evolution in Britain.

The last vestiges of Old Labour's post-war settlement, such as that most people if they worked sufficiently hard would be able to buy a decent house in a decent part of town, are being swept away. Soon, only the super-rich will be able to live in central London, for example, another success for New Labour.

The question is whether it matters. For the conservative Right, it is a manifestation of successful capitalism. If you think profit is the sole motivating force, you might complain about the taste of the new super-rich but not that they are rich. There can be no constraint on what they earn. Indeed, the more they make, the more they display the creativity and embrace the modernity that benefits us all. To wish for them to have less is ignoble and jealous.

Herein lies the ultimate confusion. The super-rich aren't any more creative than the rest of us - they just have more money. What is intriguing is not how well they spend it, but how badly. William Randolph Hearst's castle at San Simeon in California is a wonderful expression of fantasy and creativity, but I can't think of another example in the US and not one in the UK. And while the US has a long tradition of its rich entrepreneurs giving their fortunes back to the community via foundations and trusts, the British rich think only of keeping their money offshore and avoiding obligations to the commonwealth. They are about as creative as sharks, but with plummier accents.

Unless the rich have crazy hobbies, there is no obvious way to spend the cash ladled out to 'incentivise' our second-rate and modestly talented chief executives and directors. They have no idea either, and so they reliably spend the money on the one thing that is dear to them - their children.

Which is why excessive riches matter in a democracy. Wealth is the foundation of a self-perpetuating aristocracy, an élite whose entry is denied to those without the entry fee, the heart of the famous critique on equality made by Tawney. A fair society, he wrote, requires 'not only an open road but an equal start'. A just civilisation in which we can all be at ease with ourselves is built not on the possibility of having the right to attain happiness, but on the unequivocal right to happiness. We must spread wealth around, as Tawney saw, otherwise we reinvent the structured injustice of medieval Europe. It is our children, facing sky-high property prices and no chance of ownership in the élite's part of town unless their parents are super-rich who will feel Tawney's warnings about injustice much more than us.

The Third-Way consensus is that the best we can do is to alleviate these trends. We have no contemporary Tawney, whose basic argument is dismissed as impractical and unrealistic. Who can tax or obstruct the march of the super-rich in an age of globalisation?

Yet last week saw hope from an unexpected quarter. Adair Turner, former director-general of the CBI and vice chair of the same City bank from which Galley and Zimmerman are departing, has robustly dismissed the idea that governments are helpless and cannot redistribute income as Tawney would want. In his new book, Just Capitalism , he argues that successful capitalism is much more subtle than simply permitting a Darwinian struggle in which the rich run off with all the prizes. It is about being embedded in a civilisation that works, where judges and permanent secretaries are valued no less highly than those who superintend financial transactions in the City.

It is even more than that; friendship, solidarity and even kindness rest on the notion that we share. As Aristotle said, there is no friendship among the unequal. It is a measure of how far we have fallen that not one ranking politician in the Labour Party dares to make this argument. One day, surely, someone will.

webTitle: Christianity dies in bigotry - Henry McDonald

fields.headline: Christianity dies in bigotry
fields.standfirst:
Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterians will happily preach at the pulpit before they set out to burn
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterians will happily preach at the pulpit before they set out to burn
fields.body:
Last weekend Ian Paisley's Free Presbyterian Church celebrated its fiftieth anniversary. The Free Ps' birthday bash was held in the Odyssey Arena on the banks of the River Lagan. It was an incongruous setting, with 5,000 or so faithful souls locked in the mindset of the seventeenth century inside a twenty-first-century stadium. The media, including some national newspapers, covered the event as if the Church was some kind of harmless, quaint, mildly eccentric sect like the Amish of North America.

What was absent from the reporting was any sense of how this fundamentalist, deeply sectarian institution has had a disastrous impact on all aspects of Northern Irish life.

Instead this bigoted sect responsible for so much reaction was treated with a folksy portrait, a religious sub-culture not exactly at one with the modern or post-modern world. It was a picture which did not correspond with the reality of Free Presbyterianism.

First there is the theology. According to Free Presbyterians anyone who is not 'born-again' is doomed to the fires of hell. Catholics in particular, living in Free P's minds in the darkness of Popery, are all going to burn with Satan. What this twisted vision entails in practise is that any Catholic, even a young child dying of leukemia in hospital tonight, will be burned for eternity once they pass away because they have not been 'saved'. Anyone with even an ounce of humanity would find this kind of arrogant presumption nauseating and, yes, downright evil.

If Catholics are theological untermenchen, following the Whore of Babylon in Rome to damnation, is there anything wrong with burning the followers of the Beast in this life? Why worry for instance about the Quinn children burning in their home in Ballymoney during Drumcree when in a few minutes time they were bound to burn in hell because they were not 'saved'?

The loony extreme of loyalism may be a repellent shower of misfits but they are following a consistent path set down by Free Presbyterianism when they argue that their armed struggle is God's work.

In political terms the Free Presbyterians are the Irish version of the Dutch Reform Church, the religious wing of the South African Apartheid regime. Free Presbyterians form the backbone of the Democratic Unionist Party, which opposes power sharing and equality with Catholics. Again there is consistency here between the theocratic and the political. If Catholics are spiritual unequals then what is the point granting them equality in the temporal world?

Free Presbyterians are among the most vocal in opposing the Good Friday Agreement. Many church members cite the early release of terrorist prisoners as one of the main reasons why they detest the peace accord. For church members opposition to the Agreement is a moral imperative, the freeing of convicted murderers and bombers an abomination in the eyes of God.

This air of moral superiority, however, has the whiff of hypocrisy about it. One has only to look into the history of the Free Presbyterian Church and note how many of its members were involved in loyalist terrorism.

The earliest example of this was in 1969 when Thomas McDowell read the morning lesson at the Free Presbyterian Church in Kilkeel before setting off to Donegal where he planned to blow up a power station and black-out the Republic's western seaboard. McDowell, a Free Presbyterian and member of the reconstituted Ulster Volunteer Force, died placing a series of bombs on pylons at Ballyshannon ESB station. Ironically, a Catholic priest who assumed he was a republican bomber gave McDowell, a follower of Paisley, the last rites.

There have been scores like McDowell throughout the Troubles, willing to kill and maim to preserve a Protestant Ulster and who were never excommunicated from the Free Presbyterian Church. Protestant fundamentalists have always had an à la carte attitude towards terrorism.

Protestant fundamentalists are dangerous, deluded people whether they be in Northern Ireland or in the United States where many of their leaders hold influence on the Bush administration and want to blow up the world for Jesus.

(By the way, would those Irish commentators such as Eoghan Harris who have been singing Bush's praises lately, in the wake of his environmentally reckless rejection of Kyoto, please wise up!)

On a brighter note, it was wonderful to sit in Windsor Park eight days ago and hear Northern Ireland fans cheering rather than booing Neil Lennon. The IFA's 'Give bigotry the red card' campaign clearly had some success, the bigots appeared to have stayed away from the game. It just goes to show that when you stand up to bigotry you can score victories.

Ironically, a Catholic priest who assumed he was a republican bomber gave McDowell, a follower of Paisley, the last rites. There have been scores like McDowell throughout the Troubles, willing to kill and maim to preserve a Protestant Ulster and who were never excommunicated from the Free Presbyterian Church. Protestant fundamentalists have always had an à la carte attitude towards terrorism. Protestant fundamentalists are dangerous, deluded people whether they be in Northern Ireland or in the United States where many of their leaders hold influence on the Bush administration and want to blow up the world for Jesus. (By the way, would those Irish commentators such as Eoghan Harris who have been singing Bush's praises lately, in the wake of his environmentally reckless rejection of Kyoto, please wise up!) On a brighter note, it was wonderful to sit in Windsor Park eight days ago and hear Northern Ireland fans cheering rather than booing Neil Lennon. The IFA's 'Give bigotry the red card' campaign clearly had some success, the bigots appeared to have stayed away from the game. It just goes to show that when you stand up to bigotry you can score victories.

webTitle: The real leader of the opposition -Robert McCrum

fields.headline: The real leader of the opposition
fields.standfirst: It's compelling television - and the most biting political satire for a generation. A celebration of Rory Bremner and his dazzling team.
fields.trailText: It's compelling television - and the most biting political satire for a generation. Robert McCrum celebrates Rory Bremner and his dazzling team.
fields.body:
The day a Downing Street minion asked Rory Bremner: 'How do you know Tony Blair likes to eat an apple in his office?' was the moment the impressionist knew his latest series - Bremner, Bird and Fortune - had finally scored a direct hit.

His team discovered that No 10 was so disturbed by Bremner's devastating portrait of the Prime Minister's subservient relationship to his all-powerful and laconic press secretary, Alastair Campbell (played by Andrew Dunn), that it had authorised a paranoid mole-hunt.

'They seriously thought,' Bremner said last week, with undisguised glee, 'that we had access to CCTV footage of Tony and Alastair.'

New Labour is probably right to take Bremner seriously. It's his unplugged Sunday night TV satire that's landing significant political punches, leading to a growing sense of outrage. As John Fortune's regular character 'George Parr' put it in the opening episode: 'I'm not talking about people bribing the Government - that's corruption. I'm talking about Government bribing the people - that's democracy.'

As well as persuading heavyweight journalists such as John Humphrys, Channel 4's Jon Snow and Sky's Adam Boulton to participate in cod-interviews, the show has persuaded some people it's the only serious opposition Labour has got. To Snow, the show has 'just got stronger and stronger.

It's all the more potent because Rory is attacking from the radical side. He's inside the tent, but he's also urinating all over it. It's become a political show more than an entertainment show.'

If, by some surreal quirk of psephology, Bremner could reach beyond his regular two million viewers on Channel 4 to a more significant portion of the electorate, Blair might even have a fight on his hands.

The new lease of life experienced by Bremner and his collaborators, John Bird and John Fortune, is as much of a surprise to them as to their audience. This is, after all, the show's ninth series.

When it started in 1993, Bremner was simply the most gifted impressionist in the business. In those days, he worked from scripts prepared by freelance sketch-writers. There was every reason to be leery of hard-boiled satire. Spitting Image had run out of steam and lost its way. Bremner's commission from C4 was to mix alternative comedy with variety, and, of course, to entertain. Initially, his show's only connection with the satire of the 1960s came from the presence of 'the two Johns'.

Ripple-dissolve to the long, dark spring of 2001, and a farrago of innuendo and old-fashioned abuse chiefly directed at Labour humbug. What's happened, it seems, is that Bird and Fortune's influence has slowly sharpened Bremner's political appetite and tuned his comedian's antennae into decoding the confusing political static that surrounds the Government. 'I think it's fair to say,' observed Fortune carefully, 'that we have radicalised him.'

Bird and Fortune have had to evolve, too, to speak to the Friends generation. Snow said: 'What's amazing is the way the two Johns have made the transition from Macmillan to Blair... What they're implicitly saying is, "Nothing has changed. The chaps who ran Suez are the same chaps who now run Maff".' >BR>

Bremner's own anger has evolved alongside the voters' disillusion. Now he's found his subject, he is both shaping and contributing to the debate about Labour's failure to deliver on its promises and the growing perception that it has become a Conservative government in all but name. 'I mean,' said Bremner, 'Winston Churchill would be thrown out of New Labour for being too left wing.'

It's taken four years. After the satirical bonanza offered by the dying days of Tory rule, the show took a while to get to grips with New Labour, and for popular disenchantment with the new Government to give Bremner an audience responsive to his own deep sense of anger at the shift 'from ideology to ruthless pragmatism'.

'The key to the series now,' he said, 'is that it's engaging with what's happening.' So is he now a satirist? 'That's a label you can never give yourself. What we do is we observe.' He adds: 'The show has become like a column, or like a commonplace book, in which we respond to anything that's caught our eye.'

He's been lucky with his timing: Mandelson, the Hinduja brothers, Keith Vaz, Gordon Brown's Budget ('Let's not pretend it was anything to do with economic policy') and now foot and mouth and the improbable spectacle of the Defence Minister and top military brass deployed in the killing fields of Cumbria. You couldn't make it up. 'We are simply sifting through the facts and translating it into satire. We operate in the gap between rhetoric and performance. That's where we live. I cannot believe the pomposity of New Labour.' His writing partner Geoff Atkinson says much the same. 'We have found a voice, though I can't quite put my finger on why.'

Part of the explanation may lie in Bremner's own obvious delight in his material. 'It's the writing that takes precedence now,' he says. 'I spend much more time writing than I used to. I came out of light entertainment, and the show used to be a show of impressions. Now it's different and now I get real pleasure in being truthful. Bird and Fortune are writers, too. The two Johns have this fantastic eye for absurdity.'

Bird's weekly improvised interview with Fortune is one of the highlights of the show, a well-researched and often blisteringly funny exposé. It's this moment in Bremner, Bird and Fortune that recalls the satire of the Sixties.

It's clear that the example of 'the two Johns' has become important to Bremner. In earlier series, Bird and Fortune had a lower billing than Bremner. Now they are an integral part of the show. It's the two Johns (and the star actress Frances Barber) who write and perform the 'dinner party' sketches that have become a vital ingredient in Bremner's satirical portrait of 'the way we live now'.

Nonetheless, all those who are close to the show make clear that it's Bremner who holds the ring. Will Hutton, former editor of The Observer and now chief executive of the Industrial Society, who has briefed Bremner on economic policy for years, says: 'It's Rory who calls the shots. It was Rory who first saw through New Labour. What's impressive about him is that he takes no prisoners. He's nobody's ally.' Bremner himself likes to boast that he's only said 'eight words to the Prime Minister in the past five years'. ('You are making it too easy for me.')

Those, like Snow, who work opposite him, testify to the 'eerie experience' of finding the man they know morphing into 'Gordon' or 'Tony'.

Combined with a natural independence, Bremner is hard-working and well-informed. 'He has a very good network,' says another insider. 'He does his homework. He cultivates politicians and civil servants. You see him on the circuit, finding things out.'

Talk to Bremner for more than a few minutes and you find his outrage at the 'shamelessness' of the Government breaking through. 'Can you believe it?' he says. 'They are actually taxing more and spending less than the last Conservative Government.'

Still, trying to pin down Bremner's own political allegiance is hard. Fortune, who says he cannot bring himself to vote in the next election, identifies him as a libertarian. Hutton thinks Bremner is, at heart, an old-fashioned British liberal 'who has become angered by the present Government. But like all the great comics, his work has a real humanity. It's not enough for satire simply to attack.'

The show itself exemplifies this. Tune into the series and you will find the familiar range of comic impressions drawn from a close observation of contemporary politics and media - Chris Tarrant, Jeremy Paxman, Des Lynam et al. But what distinguishes Bremner's caricature of, for instance, Robin Cook, is that behind the know-all demeanour and squeaky, argumentative voice, there's a devastating portrait of the Foreign Secretary's vanity.

Similarly, Bremner seems to understand Brown's broodiness, and Blair's obsessive anxiety to please. His perception of Blair's 'niceness' has what he calls the all-important 'hinterland' to his caricature - Blair is a sincere man who is also incredibly manipulative.

Geoff Atkinson believes that part of the show's secret now is that 'we've narrowed it down. We've eliminated stuff that in the old days could have gone into Weekending '. The streamlined team that produces New Bremner is similarly lean.

Apart from Bremner and 'the two Johns', there's Atkinson, Bremner's longtime collaborator John Langdon, a couple of researchers and 'a woman called Val who researches the archive footage'. The show is put together from week to week on the hoof.

An important element is the time Fortune and Bird spend together at the beginning of the week, and the half day Fortune spends with Bremner as the recording session approaches.

'I watched it last week,' said Martin O'Neill, Labour MP for Ochil and chairman of the DTI select committee. 'It's good fun and, like all satire, it makes us [the Labour Government] feel uncomfortable. He wouldn't be doing his job if he did not cause us to feel as much annoyance as he did the previous Tory administration.

'In the Blair-Campbell exchanges he has got the body language of both down to a tee - you almost don't need any dialogue. It's well observed, good fun, and not really driven by any malicious intent. It does its job, and pricks all the right bubbles.'

'People have got a sense of humour,' said Charlie Whelan, former adviser to Brown. 'We used to get Rory a seat in the Commons so he could watch MPs at work. Gordon Brown was quite happy about [the show]. He does have a sense of humour. One of the problems is that there haven't been any hard satire shows any more. A lot of comedians are Labour these days.'

Not everyone is impressed by New Bremner. 'I'm all in favour of being able to laugh at ourselves and for satire to keep our feet on the ground,' said David Blunkett, Education Secretary. 'What I worry about is when satire masquerades as serious comment.'

As for Campbell, an aide - spokesman for the spokesman - said: 'He has no comment to make on that. No comment at all.'

The Daily Mail 's TV critic, Jacqui Stephens, notes that 'It's quite formulaic in the way that verything, from Big Brother down, becomes a metaphor for New Labour.' But she concedes that it's still the only satire on the scene.

Bremner himself is too self-critical to be easy with the idea that it's a return to the satirical heyday of the early 1960s.

'We're working in a popular medium and producing entertainment. Satire depends on a finely developed sense of irony. If we did a television version of the Modest Proposal we'd have watchdog organisations all over us. Look, I've just filmed a sketch of Des Lynam interviewing Sven Göran Eriksson in the sauna. It's not exactly Swift.'

40 years of television satire :
That Was The Week That Was Harold Macmillan and Sir Alec Douglas-Home bore the brunt of sketches that ran from 1962 until just before the 1964 election. Dennis Potter, David Frost and Christopher Booker all contributed. One of its most memorable sketches was 'What is a Mum' a satirical depiction of the housewife through ad slogans. Macmillan bitterly disliked the show.
Yes Minister and Yes Prime Minister These two pioneering shows of Margaret Thatcher's 1980s introduced Jim Hacker as Minister for the Department of Administrative Affairs. He worked with the unflappable bureaucrat Sir Humphrey Appleby. Thatcher said of Yes PM : 'Its closely observed portrayal of what goes on in the corridors of power has given me hours of pure joy.'
Spitting Image Home Secretary Kenneth Baker was portrayed as a slug. John Major was a grey-skinned robot controlled by Thatcher. At the height of apartheid, the show had a rendition of 'I've Never Met A Nice South African'. It ran from 1984 to 1992. Michael Heseltine tried to buy his puppet. Margaret Thatcher said: 'I don't ever watch that programme.'

fields.headline: Doctors deny Down's babies care
fields.standfirst: Top hospital accused of refusing children surgery to spare parents 'anguish' of looking after them
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading hospitals discriminated against children with Down's syndrome because of the belief that operating on them was not worthwhile given their condition.
fields.body:
One of Britain's leading hospitals discriminated against children with Down's syndrome because of the belief that operating on them was not worthwhile given their condition.

A damning study of the cardiac surgery department at the Royal Brompton Hospital in London says that parents with Down's children were often told that it would be better not to risk heart surgery, because the child's condition would mean it would be stressful to look after them until adulthood.

The report also condemns the treatment of parents whose children died after heart surgery at the Royal Brompton Hospital and its sister hospital, Harefield, on the outskirts of west London. Parents were not 'adequately supported' by the hospitals, were denied facts about key decisions on their child's health, were badly treated when told of children's deaths, and were often left to travel home alone, despite their bereavement.

Two families are now taking legal action against the Royal Brompton. Josephine Ocloo, who heads the parents' group which is involved in the inquiry, said the hospital had treated her shabbily, and that with different medical care her daughter Krista might have survived the heart defect which killed her in 1996 at the age of 17. Ocloo's case will be heard at the High Court next month. Another parent whose son died at the hospital, Debbie Hinds, is also taking action.

The report - which was produced by an inquiry chaired by the former head of the National Consumer Council, Ruth Evans - attacks the Government for failing to fund proper care for families who had suffered the death of a child. It says the Department of Health did not give the hospitals the resources to deal with the problems they were facing.

The report reopens the issue of the medical profession's attitude towards patients and parents of children who are suffering from life-threatening diseases. Alan Milburn, the Health Secretary, has said he wants an end to the 'paternalistic attitude' in the NHS and a better relationship between doctors and the people they treat.

It comes after three other damning studies of the way the medical profession operates: the Alder Hey inquiry in Liverpool, the inquiry into the Marchioness tragedy and the investigation into the controversial cardiac surgery procedures at Bristol.

The inquiry into the Royal Brompton and Harefield Trust was launched in 1999 after criticisms by 49 families with children being treated for congenital heart disease - 42 at the Royal Brompton and seven at Harefield.

Many of the children died during 'post-operative' care, some after having the controversial 'arterial switch' operations that led to the high death rates revealed by the Bristol heart care inquiry.

The report on the Royal Brompton, which has been obtained by The Observer, says: 'We accept RBH [Royal Brompton Hospital] doctors may not have been intentionally discriminatory in the way in which treatment was offered to some [Down's] children, but that was, in our opinion, the effect of their approach.

'We conclude that some doctors at the RBH, by taking into account non-cardiac concerns and the possible future demands on the family, did not focus sufficiently on what was in the best interests of the child as the patient.

'As a result the treatment offered was construed by parents as discriminatory.'

Evidence given to the inquiry team reveals that parents believed their views were ignored or dismissed by hospital consultants and that operations had been can celled after only minimal discussion with the family.

The Evans inquiry is the second into the two hospitals.

It was launched after parents condemned the first investigation - which had cleared the hospitals of poor treatment techniques - as a whitewash. The first report was the result of an independent examination of allegations that the Royal Brompton's death rate in operations on children with Down's syndrome was abnormally high.

Headed by three leading heart specialists, the inquiry cleared the hospital and accused an unidentified whistle-blower of causing 'trouble and pain'.

fields.headline: I bet Tony would put the loo seat down for her
fields.trailText: MONDAY: Churlish of me I know to complain at this time, but Tony does seem to be taking this 'only focused on one thing' stuff a little far. Normally he's fine around the house; no real foibles, other than the fake minor ones like not plumping up his pillows, which come in handy with fawning women's mags and idiot churchy types - but he's becoming unbearable. MONDAY: Churlish of me I know to complain at this time, but Tony does seem to be taking this 'only focused on one thing' stuff a little far. Normally he's fine around the house; no real foibles, other than the fake minor ones like not plumping up his pillows, which come in handy with fawning women's mags and idiot churchy types - but he's becoming unbearable. Loo seat up, dishes undone, forgetting to tape ER - and I bet he'd remember to do that for Anji Hunter - I mean, OK, he's focused on one thing alone, closeted with advisers morn to night, but there must be some more to life than deciding the election date. There's this foot-and-mouth stuff, for instance.

TUESDAY: Which I thought, looking out of the window this morning, had been taken to dire new propagandist lengths by some group of sad extremists - the Ambridge Pro-Pig Wholly Bonkers Nuclear Front, say, or the Official Conservative Party - by leaving on our doorstep a huge pig's carcass stuffed sinisterly into a black suit to represent government or Europe or something, but it turned out Prescott was just bending over to tie his shoelaces. He's worried, apparently, about this perception that we're all just urbanites who know nothing about the details of life in the country. (Um - that'll be because we're urbanites then, of the kind that tend to sometimes live sort of right in the middle of the city?) Anyway, it's rubbish; we know enough. I'm sure we've got a copy of Constable's The Hay Wain upstairs. And Harriet swears she got a Sabatier free-range capon-flenser from Heal's at Christmas, and David's got a doggy thing, and Alastair told a funny joke the other night about what's got four legs and goes 'woof', the answer being something to do with sheep and paraffin, and - yes, well, he might, for once, have a point.

WEDNESDAY: Unlike Robin, who's using a whole day in Parliament to warn that computer hacking could now 'cripple the nation' more quickly than a military strike or a terrorist campaign. Quicker even, presumably, than a microscopic virus, say. Or cracks in a stretch of rail, say. Or maintaining a 'special relationship' with someone whose global environmental policies will at least eradicate foot and mouth by drowning every thing in the country, say. Still, at least we've got the priorities right.

THURSDAY: Or bloody Ken Livingstone and his strikers, say.

I see Hague is thinking of experimenting with a new image, which I imagine will have the same happy effect on affairs as Robert Maxwell's experiments with a new buoyancy.

FRIDAY: Election-date row continues. Tony is determined not to put the interests of the party before the interests of the country, of course - much nodding and hear-hearing and of courseing, and only a couple of nasty loud snorts; well, it's been a bad time for head colds. Much advice, many suggestions, and an air of rational calm throughout, apart from that terrifying moment after Gordon suggested delaying indefinitely, and 'just letting our record speak for itself!' Have you seen the last act of Hamlet ?
