webTitle: Politicians who tell the truth? Please don't make me laugh

fields.headline: Politicians who tell the truth? Please don't make me laugh
fields.trailText: Whenever the unwanted election arrives, intelligent satire is likely to be thin on the ground. Because these days gag writers are regularly employed to write politicians' speeches, instead of making life uncomfortable for them. Even without scripts, Parliament's barmy army of middle-managers already knows how to turn out a class one-liner.
fields.body:
Whenever the unwanted election arrives, intelligent satire is likely to be thin on the ground. Because these days gag writers are regularly employed to write politicians' speeches, instead of making life uncomfortable for them. Even without scripts, Parliament's barmy army of middle-managers already knows how to turn out a class one-liner.

Remember Peter Mandelson after the Hammond report - 'I'd like to thank Sir Anthony for restoring my reputation'. People love a comic who can take the piss out of himself. And what about the Geoff Hoon classic: 'British soldiers will only be in Sierra Leone until the airport is secured?' In comedy, timing is everything - and, by my watch, those soldiers are still there, six months later. And William Hague trumped everyone with this Foreign Land speech corker - 'Tonight Matthew, I'm going to be Enoch Powell'.

But the good news is that as the politicians turn to comedy - so some satirists are turning to politics. This is certainly timely, because with the triumph of neo-liberalism, Britain is now a one-party state. Despite the growing anti-capitalist movement, Britain's Labour Party no longer stands shoulder-to-shoulder with working people. Instead, just like the Tories, it prefers standing alongside big business. This means anyone seeking a world view that isn't framed by the profit motive may well have to divert their gaze from Westminster towards the glitzy plains of Light Entertainment.

Consider the example of asylum seekers. Both major political parties have been equally cowardly in their refusal to explain why this phenomenon exists. That's because it's a direct result of the very global capitalism they drool over. Just as bosses now trawl the globe looking for dirt-cheap labour - so workers from lands which are skint 'get on their bikes' to search for a decent living wage. Imagine their surprise when they're met at Dover by Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe shouting in unison: 'Oi, economic migrants - bugger off!'

In recent months anyone looking for a serious account of asylum-seeking had to turn to a comedian. 'Iraqi kebab shop owner' and Gladiator star Omid Djalili's Channel 4 programme was a humane account of the reality behind the hate-mongering headlines. But then Omid can tell the truth because he's not angling for a gig in the 'Mother of all Parliaments', is he?

That is the crucial difference between good comedians and most politicians. Comedians are paid to say what they think. Politicians only say what they think we want to hear. Though this ingratiation breeds widespread contempt, they persist. The best comedians, however, are more inclined to change minds than to reinforce prejudice. Sure they want to entertain. But an act that consisted of grovelling platitudes would be... well, it would be a Tony Blair speech.

So if ever Britain needed a new breed of satirists, now is the time. There's a myth going round that everyone's so rich and happy they aren't bothered by politics anymore. The irony is that while New Labour swoon over their capitalist mates, 'socialism' - as Westminster bores might say - 'is playing rather well in the country at large'. Look at the success of Naomi Klein's No Logo. The book, which combined dry wit alongside an easy familiarity with pop culture, is a stunning achievement. It's resulted in MTV slackers happily poring over Chomsky-style economic critique, along with their tea and Limp Bizkit.

New Labour politicians don't care for Chomsky or his ilk. But while they have no use for hard-hitting analyses of American capitalist hegemony, we in the world of comedy are, quite literally, gagging for it. So as stalwarts like Mark Thomas, Rob Newman, Mark Steel and Jeremy Hardy receive their Distinguished Service Medals, the time has come for budding satirists to make themselves known. If they don't, Britain's politicians will carry on exactly as they've done for the last 30 years - and that's just not funny.

Nelson David formerly wrote jokes for Week Ending, Spitting Image, Rory Bremner, Johnny Vaughan and Zoe Ball. He's now editor of the webzine, www.spin-on-this.com

fields.headline: Northern Ireland
fields.standfirst: Will voters give peace a chance?
fields.trailText: Will voters give peace a chance?
fields.body:
'Nothing ever changes in Northern Ireland politics'runs the conventional wisdom. The 18 Westminster seats in the province form their own contest - part religious census and part election - with rarely more than two or three results in any doubt. But the new dividing lines of the peace process, a spate of retirements and a stunning by-election result in South Antrim make 2001 the least predictable of all Ulster elections. As many as half the seats could be competitive.

Ulster Unionists:
Leader: David Trimble
Ten seats in 1997 election, now holds nine
Goal: Top the poll and defend their seats

The party had some of its worst results in the 1998 Assembly and 1999 Euro elections. But the biggest shock was September's South Antrim by-election, where it lost a 16,000 majority and its second safest seat to the UUP. Seats held by deputy leader John Taylor (Strangford) and Ken Maginnis (Fermanagh and Tyrone), both retiring after 18 years each, may be vulnerable too. The party has benefited from first-past-the-post, winning 10 of the 18 seats in the past three general elections, but an adverse swing could therefore prove correspondingly costly in terms of seats lost.

Democratic Unionist Party :
Leader: Ian Paisley
Two seats in 1997, now three
Goal: Hold South Antrim and make gains from UUP

In South Antrim, the Rev William McCrea will be pleased to be taking on again the anti-agreement UUP candidate David Burnside, whom he beat in the by-election. And Iris Robinson, wife of deputy leader Peter Robinson, will start as favourite to gain Strangford. Ian Paisley, at the age of 74, has no plans to retire Ê he hopes to demonstrate that a majority of Protestant voters now opposes the agreement.

SDLP :
Leader: John Hume
Holds three seats
Goal: To maintain clear lead over Sinn Fein

The party was delighted to top the poll in the 1998 Assembly elections. But the longer-term trend is a loss of votes to Sinn Fein, brought so painstakingly into the political fold by John Hume. Taking West Belfast back from Gerry Adams is unlikely, even if the party might attract tactical Protestant votes. Hume and deputy Seamus Mallon are fighting on, but the party will need a new generation of leaders for the next election.

Sinn Fein :
Leader: Gerry Adams
Two seats
Goal: Close vote gap with SDLP and gain seats

Will aim to close gap on the SDLP among Catholic voters, and target one Unionist and one SDLP seat. Michelle Gildernew, aged 30, hopes to reclaim Fermanagh, which Bobby Sands won in 1981, in the most equally divided constituency in religious terms.

UK Unionist Party
One MP: Robert McCartney
Anti-Agreement Unionist holds North Down. The party does not compete in other constituencies.

 Elections are not always good news for peace in Northern Ireland. The 1974 election led to the collapse of the last power-sharing agreement. While most voters may still back peace, pro-Agreement candidates are split between parties Ð especially as very few voters would switch from the Ulster Unionists to SDLP or vice versa.

webTitle: Kennedy calls for an end to election uncertainty

fields.headline: Kennedy calls for an end to election uncertainty
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, used his keynote address to Scottish party workers yesterday to urge Tony Blair not to call a general election on 3 May.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, used his keynote address to Scottish party workers yesterday to urge Tony Blair not to call a general election on 3 May.

Speaking at the Scottish Liberal Democrats spring conference in Pitlochry, Perthshire, he said the election should be postponed until the foot and mouth crisis was under control.

'Having spoken to a range of people whose livelihoods are disrupted by foot and mouth, I have come to the conclusion that there should be no general election on 3 May. I believe the Prime Minister should tell the country early next week when he intends to hold the election so the uncertainty ends.'

Kennedy called on all parties to agree a code of conduct on canvassing if an election is called before foot and mouth has been eradicated.

'Everyone needs to be sensitive to the precautions required. So there will have to be a no-go area where there are vulnerable farms and farmland. Whatever our differences on policy, we must all agree to help the farming community at a time when they most need it.'

Kennedy praised Liberal Democrats in the ruling coalition in the Scottish Parliament for setting a 'shining example for the rest of Britain. Because of your work we have a story to tell as never before. Tuition fees: abolished. Schools and hospitals: more money. The police: more resources. Personal care: being delivered for free, for all who need it.'

Kennedy bitterly criticised Labour for 'pretending that they are doing all they can' while failing to deliver.

'We are told that it's all getting better: task forces, numbers and statistics bombard us. Britain wants serious investment in our public services, paid for openly, honestly and fairly. Stealth taxes don't do this. They are an insult to our intelligence and betray a lack of courage.'

john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Education
fields.standfirst: Everybody wants higher standards - who can deliver them?
fields.trailText: Everybody wants higher standards - who can deliver them?
fields.body:
Campaign battleground: Labour's new generation of selective comprehensives has disoriented Conservatives. Theresa May will come under pressure to show that 'free school' plans are workable: what if all schools in an area choose to select? The LibDems will offer more money to teachers and schools and trumpet student tuition-fee success in Scotland.

Success: Literacy, numeracy and GCSE results all up.
Failure: Keeping Chris Woodhead well beyond his sell-by date.

Labour: David Blunkett
 No university top-up fees for the next Parliament, and 50 per cent enrolment by 2010.
 Double number of specialist schools, allowed to select 10 per cent of pupils, over five years.
'We will give every child the chance to flourish'

Conservatives: Theresa May
 Match Labour's spending for schools. Abolish LEAs and give 'free schools' responsibility for admissions, discipline, uniform and pay policies.
 Endow universities with the proceeds of government auctions such as the £20 billion sale of mobile-phone licences.
'We'll rid schools of red tape - teachers will be teachers with the Conservatives

LibDems: Phil Willis
 Scrap university tuition fees and bring back maintenance grant.
 Free nursery education for all three- and four-year-olds.
'Labour's plans mean selection and division with no increase in standards

But what's the real issue?
Tom Bentley, Director, Demos and former adviser to David Blunkett
'With Labour's focus on literacy, numeracy and record public spending, and the Tories' emphasis on bureaucracy and teacher shortages, the real issues will barely get a look in. We should be debating what kind of education our children really need and asking whether our exam system tests the qualities that will prepare them to thrive. A second Labour term will see radical diversification and much greater flexibility in funding.'

fields.headline: The ad-men: Labour
fields.standfirst: TBWA - the Labour campaign
fields.trailText: TBWA - the Labour campaign
fields.body:
Key player: Trevor Beattie, media-savvy Wonderbra man, seen as ideal choice to give Labour turnout a lift.

The brief: Six years after major relaunch, new market leader must renew relationship with traditional purchasers.

Budget: £10m.

The pitch: 'We'll remind people why they voted Labour and show them what it did. If that doesn't work, we'll scare them to death with Tory cuts.'

Inside track: Can irreverent fcuk fashion approach really help to re-elect a government? Or will TBWA revert to a classic negative political campaign?

The form: Has successfully marketed products through focus on identity and community. But first 'thank you' campaign a bit touchy-feely for Millbank tastes.

Chances of success: High, though agency performance will be difficult to judge, as Labour victory is expected. However, any campaign that gets Labour heartland out to vote will win points.

fields.headline: Taunton
fields.trailText: Will LibDems lose their best-known female MP?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Can new LibDem star hold south-west battleground?

The form: The Somerset county town had not elected a Liberal since 1922, despite LibDem local election successes. The 1999 Euro swing would have seen easy Conservative win.

Local landmarks: Constituency contains 1,000 dairy farms.

Key voters: Many Labour voters helped push Ballard to victory after Observer constituency poll showed it was neck and neck. MP is to the left of Labour, so may repeat strong tactical appeal despite her hostility to closer Lib-Lab co-operation.

Local issues: Ballard is fiercely anti-hunting but constituents hunt both foxes and deer.

The verdict: The numbers donÍt look good for Ballard, but strong personal profile could well see her through. Most prominent of just three LibDem women, BallardÍs defeat would be a major blow to party.

The candidates:

Jackie Ballard (LibDem): Has established herself more quickly than most of the 1997 intake. Fourth place in party leadership contest, winning strong reviews from national press for distinctive liberal approach. Found Ashdown leadership 'militaristic' and has questioned Charles KennedyÍs reluctance to promote women.

Adrian Flook (Conservative): Former stockbroker, aged 37, keen to stress local roots: 'My grandfather helped put Taunton on the national grid in the Forties.'

Andrew Govier (Labour): Local councillor will struggle to keep Ballard away from his votes.

1997 result: MP: Jackie Ballard (LibDem)
majority 2,433

LibDems 26,064
Conservatives 23,621
Labour 8,248
Referendum 2,760
(4.6 per cent swing Con to LD)

Tory target no 27
Swing required: 2 per cent

Fourth place in party leadership contest, winning strong reviews from national press for distinctive liberal approach. Found Ashdown leadership 'militaristic' and has questioned Charles KennedyÍs reluctance to promote women. Adrian Flook (Conservative): Former stockbroker, aged 37, keen to stress local roots: 'My grandfather helped put Taunton on the national grid in the Forties.' fields.headline: Portsmouth (North and South)
fields.trailText: Can Tories win naval war on two fronts?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Crucial naval battleground sees Conservatives fighting on two fronts.

The form: The now notorious Paulsgrove estate is something of an anomaly in relatively affluent Portsmouth North, Tory-held for 18 years. Hancock's majority almost counts as a landslide in traditionally ultra-marginal Portsmouth South, which includes Southsea and Portsea Island.

Local landmarks: Britain's premier naval port.

Key voters: 14,000 voters in the city are employed at the naval dockyard and the same number again outside the base. Both Rapson and Hancock are strong on defence.

Local issues: Tories will campaign on closure of Haslam military hospital in nearby Gosport.

The verdict: LibDem Mike Hancock's community politics will make him hard to dislodge in Portsmouth South but Labour's Syd Rapson will need a high Paulsgrove turnout if he is to hang on too.

The candidates
Portsmouth North:
Syd Rapson (Labour): Veteran Labour loyalist, aged 59. Described Paulsgrove anti-paedophile protests as 'democracy in action' while condemning violence. But then Rapson lives on the estate. Local councillor since 1971.

Christopher Day (Conservative): Euro-moderate, aged 39, in risk management for American Express. Came a distant second in Stoke last time.

Portsmouth South:
Mike Hancock (LibDem): Should handle electoral nerves better than most, having lost this seat by 242 votes in 1992 and by 205 in 1997 after representing it for the SDP from 1984 to 1987.

Philip Warr(Conservatives): Chartered surveyor and 'Keep the pound' man faces tough test on first electoral outing.

Expect one-man band campaigns for Darren Sanders (LibDem, North) and Graham Heaney (Labour, South).

fields.headline: Liverpool Walton
fields.trailText: Will the Labour heartlands come out to vote?
fields.body:
The lowdown: Are Labour's heartlands simply too safe to matter?

The form: Labour's fifth safest seat shows why New Labour could focus so heavily on Middle England. It took Neil Hamilton to lose the Tories' fourth safest seat last time, but there will be no seismic shifts here.

Local landmarks: Everton Football Club. Walton prison.

Key voters: Any that Labour can get out. Turnout was 59 per cent in 1997 and neighbouring Riverside did even worse with Britain's lowest turnout of all (51.9 per cent). A further big inner-city dip would reflect badly on Labour.

Local issues: Unemployment in Walton is 12.4 per cent, four times the national figure and 50 per cent higher than the Liverpool average. Breckfield is the 12th most deprived council ward in the entire country.

The verdict: They may not decide the result, but this election will see Labour's heartlands in the spotlight as never before: the issue goes to the centre of New Labour's claim that it can tackle social exclusion while delivering prosperity. Watch the turnout rather than the result.

The candidates

Peter Kilfoyle(Labour): Quit as Defence Minister to warn that the party should not take its 'heartlands' vote for granted, pre-empting the leadership's central concern with electoral apathy. If Liverpool has an elected mayor, will be among the frontrunners.

Kiron Reid(LibDem): Barrister, aged 29, law lecturer and city councillor for Anfield. Took on equally uphill task in Bootle last time.

Steve Horgan (Conservative): IT manager. Will focus on saving his deposit - and should just about make it.

1997 result:
MP: Peter Kilfoyle (Labour)
Majority 27,038

Labour 31,516
Liberal Democrats 4,478
Conservatives 2,551
Referendum 620
(3.4 per cent swing: Con to Lab)

webTitle: John Prescott:  Children pay for political errors

fields.headline: Children pay for political errors
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: When I came out of The Hague Conference on Global Warming last December I said I was 'gutted' that we had not reached agreement.
fields.byline: John Prescott, secretary of state for the environment
fields.body:
When I came out of The Hague Conference on Global Warming last December I said I was 'gutted' that we had not reached agreement. Why? First, because I felt we had missed a great chance to tie down a practical deal - after all, we had done the hard part of setting legally binding targets in Kyoto three years earlier. Second, because I feared this would give the incoming US administration an opportunity to pull away from it. Sadly, this seems to be so.

Earlier this year there were signs of hope. Only a month ago President Bush's new Environmental Protection Agency director agreed at the G8 meeting in Trieste that Kyoto was the way ahead. However, President Bush now seems to have unilaterally rejected the Kyoto Protocol 'because it exempts many countries from compliance and would cause serious harm to the American economy'.

The fact that climate change is taking place is now accepted by the scientific community. The latest UN scientific report says that temperatures could rise by up to 5.8 C over the next 100 years if no action is taken. The consequence will be rising sea levels inundating our coasts and more severe weather - floods, hurricanes and droughts.

Climate change is caused by industrial emissions. Today's biggest polluters were the first to industrialise and they have responsibility to take the first action to tackle climate change. The Rio Convention - signed by G.W.'s father President George Bush in 1992 - and the Kyoto Protocol both recognise this.

Kyoto was possible because Europe, the US and Japan in particular dedicated themselves to securing an agreement - encouraged by the courageous stance taken by Vice-President Gore.

But it is not true that developing countries are exempt from the Protocol. It calls on them to develop programmes to address climate change. In future decades all countries must do more. And many developing countries are already taking active steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, as I have seen for myself in India, China and South America. They recognise that environmental problems are a major concern for their populations, just as they are for ours, and that energy efficiency is good for the economy.

Bush doesn't want to destroy American jobs. We don't want to destroy British, German, Japanese or Chinese jobs. We want to tackle global warming in ways which will benefit our standard of living.

And the US cannot sit in glorious isolation. Europe has reached an agreement on fuel efficiency with the car manufacturers which applies to every firm in the global market. Fridges and freezers in European shops have energy efficiency markings which mean consumers can choose products which use less energy and are cheaper to run. US manufacturers ignore these measure at their peril, and Europe will introduce further measures in the future.

The ultimate irony is that just as Bush - the President of the world's most polluting nation - is rejecting Kyoto, Premier Zhu Rongji - President of the world's most populous nation - has recognised that the environment is a priority. China's latest five-year plan commits it to take 'measures contributing to slowing down the change of global climate'.

The challenge for the rest of the world is to persuade the American people that the threat of global warming is real and that the Kyoto targets are realistic because there are flexible ways to achieve them.

The challenge for America is to show it is a responsible nation, which will work with the rest of the world to beat this problem in ways that help the economy as well as the environment.

Some people have talked about immediate trade sanctions. That would be counter-productive. But the US administration is feeling the force of international opinion. It must know it cannot pollute the world while free-riding on action by everyone else. A vigorous debate is developing in the US and that, in itself, is a good sign.

All politicians have to live with their consciences, but whether American, European, African or Asian, it is children who have to live with their decisions. We owe it to our children to pass on our planet in better shape than we inherited it.

fields.headline: The world in 2050
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: It is the year 2050, and April blizzards have gripped southern England for the third successive year while violent storms batter the North Sea coast.
fields.body:
It is the year 2050, and April blizzards have gripped southern England for the third successive year while violent storms batter the North Sea coast. The Gulf Stream, whose warming waters once heated our shores, has long since disappeared, destroyed by a deluge pouring south from the melting Arctic ice cap.

In the United States, much of Alaska has turned into a quagmire as permafrost and glaciers disintegrate. In Colorado, chair lift pylons stand rusting in the warm drizzle, reminders that the nation once supported a billion-dollar ski industry, while the remnants of Florida are declared America's second island state.

Africa is faring badly. Its coastline from Cairo to Lagos is completely flooded and many of the major cities have been abandoned. Tens of millions of people have been forced to flee and are struggling to survive in a parched, waterless interior.

In Asia there is a similar, terrifying picture. Bangladesh is almost totally inundated and the East Indies have been reduced to a few scrappy islands. Tens of millions stand on the brink of death.

It is a startling scenario worthy of a science fiction disaster film. And it would be easy to dismiss, were it not for the uncomfortable fact that these visions are the result of rigorous scientific analysis by some of the world's most distinguished climatologists.

As the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) points out in its recent Climate Change 2001 report, global warming is likely to trigger a cascade of unpleasant effects: elderly people will suffer and die in smoggy, polluted cities; crops will fail; and wildlife and livestock will perish on a scorched and miserable planet. That report was the combined work of several thousand of the world's leading meteorological experts, scientists whose views George Bush has now dismissed as 'questionable' and whose work in creating the Kyoto protocol has been utterly undone.

The US decision to pull out of the international accord on climate change has caused predictable international alarm, though it is important to note it will have no direct effect on levels of carbon dioxide now circulating in the atmosphere. Kyoto merely pledged developed countries to restrict their industrial output. 'It was an excellent first step towards reversing climate change,' according to Southampton University's Professor Nigel Arnell. Kyoto was, in effect, a statement of intent. The industrial nations which had, after all, initiated the problem of global warming, would show their commitment by making the first crucial, self-sacrificing moves. Then the Third World could be drawn in, and the first decreases in carbon-dioxide emissions agreed over the next few years. 'Bush has now made the attainment of these next crucial steps much more difficult,' says Arnell. In fact, most experts believe he has made them impossible. If the West won't act, why should the rest of the world? If no action is taken, the consequences are likely to be calamitous. Before the industrial revolution, the atmosphere was made up of 250 parts per million of carbon dioxide. Now that figure has reached 366 and is already producing meteorological effects: a steady increase in devastating storms across Britain, rising sea levels, and dwindling glaciers and ice-caps. And that is just the start. Carbon dioxide levels will inevitably reach 450, even if governments closed every factory tomorrow. 'Plants absorb carbon dioxide and when they die they release that gas,' says Dr David Griggs of the IPCC's science working group. 'Similarly, the oceans absorb and release carbon dioxide.' These carbon dioxide stores mean that we could not stop atmospheric levels rising for future decades, no matter what we did. 'The climate is changing and will continue to change, regardless of what George Bush says,' comments Dr Mike Hulme of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change in Norwich.

In any case, closing down factories is not on the cards. With the nation responsible for a quarter of all global carbon dioxide emissions refusing to limit its output by the merest fraction, levels will inevitably reach 550 parts per million - double their pre-industrial revolution figure - by about 2050. By then the world's temperature will have increased by 1.4 degrees Centigrade, triggering the mayhem outlined in the IPCC report. 'It is very difficult to make hard predictions,' adds Griggs. 'All we can say is that the future is going to be very uncertain, highly variable.' Britain provides an excellent example of the problem. We may swelter - or, if icy Arctic waters divert the Gulf Stream, we may shiver. Either way, the consequences will mean millions of homes will be refused insurance, native wildlife will perish and great chunks of coastline will be inundated.

And, say meteorologists, it now looks as if there is nothing we can do about it.

fields.headline: Cleared for take-off
fields.standfirst:
Huge capital investment, crowded skies, working with bitter rival... Can the carriers that landed the deal to control our air space make a safe and successful go of it?

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Huge capital investment, crowded skies, working with bitter rival... Can the carriers that landed the deal to control our air space make a safe and successful go of it?
fields.body:
Next time your flight is delayed the pilot may not be so keen to blame it, with the usual shrug and heavy sigh, on air traffic control.

In one fell swoop a consortium of the UK's leading airlines have bought Britain's air traffic control system for £800 million. In the future it will effectively be their fault if you are going round in circles over the south of England waiting to land.

The Government believes it has chosen the safe option in the airlines, both technically and politically. But the signs are that the 5,700 employees of National Air Traffic Services (Nats) will lead a very different life in the private sector.

Nats insiders last week told The Observer they expected the new owner to cut management and administration jobs and, by reducing costs, lower the fees airlines have to pay to be guided through the skies, which are typically £350 for a Boeing 747 on a long-haul flight, £100 for a small aircraft flying domestically.

There is a shortage of radar controllers so they and their operational support staff and back-up engineers are secure. The airlines will avoid any moves that jeopardise front-line safety or curb capacity in the crowded air space.

But there are more than 1,100 staff in administrative departments such as finance and personnel who may not be needed in future.

One senior source told The Observer: 'There is flab in the organisation. Why would the airlines keep people in functions they can perform themselves? They will want to cut costs so they can lower the charges they have to pay for air traffic control.'

The airlines do not take over Nats until the summer and currently refuse to discuss future staffing levels, beyond denying they have drawn up any plans for job losses.

The Government pulled off a compro mise last week when it decided to sell 46 per cent of Nats to the Airline Group.

Controllers will own 5 per cent; the remaining 49 per cent will stay in the public sector. The Government is left clutching a so-called 'golden' share to protect national security in the event of war and to prevent ownership of our skies falling into foreign hands.

The airlines' stake in Nats will be equally divided between seven carriers: British Airways, Virgin Atlantic, British Midland, Easyjet and three leading charter airlines: Britannia, Airtours and Monarch. They will take over in June.

The airlines beat three other bids: from Serco, the UK facilities management group; from a consortium led by US aerospace leader Lockheed Martin; and finally from New Zealand's state-owned air traffic service provider.

A source close to the decision said: 'We were not concerned that the airlines had a safer bid than the others. But they do understand the industry and have a common aim with Nats for safety and high capacity in the skies.'

But given the storm of opposition to the part sell-off among the general public and in both Houses of Parliament, the airlines group's pledge to run the business 'not for commercial return' had huge influence.

The threat of a strike by controllers over the Easter holiday period immediately receded and the Government's decision played well to the gallery.

The source admitted: 'Politically that's true. It was a decision made more with hearts than with minds.'

To the unwary 'not for commercial return' could be read as non-profit making - a friendly co-op run by the airlines for no gain other than safe skies, public reassurance and the national good.

Far from it. Nats made a pre-tax profit last year of £63m on a turnover of £568m. The airlines are likely to be keen to improve on this by cost-cutting and by muscling in on lucrative future privatisation contracts overseas.

Criticisms from some observers that the airlines would not be as aggressive as their rival bidders in expanding abroad and pushing for cutting-edge technology were dismissed by supporters of the Airline Group. They were advised in their bid by the air traffic control organisations of the Irish Republic, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Iceland. Aerospace giant Boeing is also involved and will be looking at spreading state-of-the-art technology such as satellite navigation systems.

The Nats insider said: 'Not for commercial return just means not taking out windfall profits or paying dividends.'

Airlines group spokesman Paul Moore said any profits would be invested straight back into the air traffic control industry.

A heavy capital expenditure programme will be needed over the next 10 or 15 years if UK air space has any hope of accommodating a forecast doubling of passenger demand. Even if they do a deal to glean more of the RAF's air space now that the Cold War is long over, it will be a huge squeeze.

The Airline Group has pledged to invest £1 billion in the next seven years to upgrade the system and provide extra capacity. It will inherit a new £700m nerve centre at Swanwick in Hampshire that is already paid for. Swanwick is twice over budget and five years late and the airlines will immediately have to begin investing to upgrade it for the kind of aerial workload it will face in 10 years' time.

They will also need a new computer system for processing flight data to replace the one that broke down last summer, causing chaos and the airlines millions of pounds in delays. And a new £400m Scottish control centre is needed.'

It may seem improbable that seven rival airlines could come together to manage a business as unwieldy and fraught with controversy as air traffic control. But they stuck together 'through thick and thin' during the bidding, according to one observer, winning over Government and, once it became clear the sale would be forced through, the workforce as the least loathed of the bidders.

A new Nats board of directors will include representatives of the airlines, the Government and the staff.

Nats sources are adamant that international aviation law will prevent the owner-airlines from giving themselves or their alliance partners favourable take-off and landing times.

But there is an element of risk for the airlines: BA and Virgin are already seeing profits suffering. BA's share price dipped on the Nats news; with shareholders wishing that it would stick to the core business. But Commerzbank analyst Chris Tarry said it was good news that the airlines would be involved in producing a better air traffic control system.

Last year a quarter of BA's long-haul flights from Heathrow were delayed by almost an hour and almost a fifth of their European flights by half an hour.

Ian Wild, airlines analyst at SG Securities, says: 'It makes business sense. It is a vital part of the infrastructure that enables airlines to perform.'

Controlling and reforming Nats will go only a tiny way towards curing the airlines' delay headaches, however: Across Europe there are 31 national air traffic control systems, using no fewer than 22 different operational methods and technologies.

But buying Nats is at least the first leg of a very long-haul flight to what the airlines hope will be a safe, efficient, single European sky, with no ceiling to growth.

Nats insiders last week told The Observer they expected the new owner to cut management and administration jobs and, by reducing costs, lower the fees airlines have to pay to be guided through the skies, which are typically £350 for a Boeing 747 on a long-haul flight, £100 for a small aircraft flying domestically. There is a shortage of radar controllers so they and their operational support staff and back-up engineers are secure. The airlines will avoid any moves that jeopardise front-line safety or curb capacity in the crowded air space. But there are more than 1,100 staff in administrative departments such as finance and personnel who may not be needed in future. One senior source told The Observer: 'There is flab in the organisation. Why would the airlines keep people in functions they can perform themselves? They will want to cut costs so they can lower the charges they have to pay for air traffic control.' The airlines do not take over Nats until the summer and currently refuse to discuss future staffing levels, beyond denying they have drawn up any plans for job losses. The Government pulled off a compro mise last week when it decided to sell 46 per cent of Nats to the Airline Group. Controllers will own 5 per cent; the remaining 49 per cent will stay in the public sector. The Government is left clutching a so-called 'golden' share to protect national security in the event of war and to prevent ownership of our skies falling into foreign hands. The airlines' stake in Nats will be equally divided between seven carriers: British Airways, Virgin Atlantic, British Midland, Easyjet and three leading charter airlines: Britannia, Airtours and Monarch. They will take over in June. The airlines beat three other bids: from Serco, the UK facilities management group; from a consortium led by US aerospace leader Lockheed Martin; and finally from New Zealand's state-owned air traffic service provider. A source close to the decision said: 'We were not concerned that the airlines had a safer bid than the others. But they do understand the industry and have a common aim with Nats for safety and high capacity in the skies.' But given the storm of opposition to the part sell-off among the general public and in both Houses of Parliament, the airlines group's pledge to run the business 'not for commercial return' had huge influence. The threat of a strike by controllers over the Easter holiday period immediately receded and the Government's decision played well to the gallery. The source admitted: 'Politically that's true. It was a decision made more with hearts than with minds.' To the unwary 'not for commercial return' could be read as non-profit making - a friendly co-op run by the airlines for no gain other than safe skies, public reassurance and the national good. Far from it. Nats made a pre-tax profit last year of £63m on a turnover of £568m. The airlines are likely to be keen to improve on this by cost-cutting and by muscling in on lucrative future privatisation contracts overseas. Criticisms from some observers that the airlines would not be as aggressive as their rival bidders in expanding abroad and pushing for cutting-edge technology were dismissed by supporters of the Airline Group. They were advised in their bid by the air traffic control organisations of the Irish Republic, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Iceland. Aerospace giant Boeing is also involved and will be looking at spreading state-of-the-art technology such as satellite navigation systems. The Nats insider said: 'Not for commercial return just means not taking out windfall profits or paying dividends.' Airlines group spokesman Paul Moore said any profits would be invested straight back into the air traffic control industry. A heavy capital expenditure programme will be needed over the next 10 or 15 years if UK air space has any hope of accommodating a forecast doubling of passenger demand. Even if they do a deal to glean more of the RAF's air space now that the Cold War is long over, it will be a huge squeeze. The Airline Group has pledged to invest £1 billion in the next seven years to upgrade the system and provide extra capacity. It will inherit a new £700m nerve centre at Swanwick in Hampshire that is already paid for. Swanwick is twice over budget and five years late and the airlines will immediately have to begin investing to upgrade it for the kind of aerial workload it will face in 10 years' time. They will also need a new computer system for processing flight data to replace the one that broke down last summer, causing chaos and the airlines millions of pounds in delays. And a new £400m Scottish control centre is needed.' It may seem improbable that seven rival airlines could come together to manage a business as unwieldy and fraught with controversy as air traffic control. But they stuck together 'through thick and thin' during the bidding, according to one observer, winning over Government and, once it became clear the sale would be forced through, the workforce as the least loathed of the bidders. A new Nats board of directors will include representatives of the airlines, the Government and the staff. Nats sources are adamant that international aviation law will prevent the owner-airlines from giving themselves or their alliance partners favourable take-off and landing times. But there is an element of risk for the airlines: BA and Virgin are already seeing profits suffering. BA's share price dipped on the Nats news; with shareholders wishing that it would stick to the core business. But Commerzbank analyst Chris Tarry said it was good news that the airlines would be involved in producing a better air traffic control system. Last year a quarter of BA's long-haul flights from Heathrow were delayed by almost an hour and almost a fifth of their European flights by half an hour. Ian Wild, airlines analyst at SG Securities, says: 'It makes business sense. It is a vital part of the infrastructure that enables airlines to perform.' Controlling and reforming Nats will go only a tiny way towards curing the airlines' delay headaches, however: Across Europe there are 31 national air traffic control systems, using no fewer than 22 different operational methods and technologies. But buying Nats is at least the first leg of a very long-haul flight to what the airlines hope will be a safe, efficient, single European sky, with no ceiling to growth.

webTitle: Been there, outlawed it - banned the T-shirt

fields.headline: Been there, outlawed it - banned the T-shirt
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Our future is bracketed by two writers. George Orwell thought we would be destroyed by the things we hate. Aldous Huxley feared we would be undermined by the things we love. For much of the last century, Orwell seemed to have the upper hand. And although the forces of Big Brother (the UK Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act and the new EU Directive on cybercrime) are still alive and kicking the hell out of civil liberties, it's beginning to look as though Huxley's nightmare will dominate the twenty-first century.
fields.body:
Our future is bracketed by two writers. George Orwell thought we would be destroyed by the things we hate. Aldous Huxley feared we would be undermined by the things we love. For much of the last century, Orwell seemed to have the upper hand. And although the forces of Big Brother (the UK Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act and the new EU Directive on cybercrime) are still alive and kicking the hell out of civil liberties, it's beginning to look as though Huxley's nightmare will dominate the twenty-first century.

How come? Well, it's all to do with our lust for packaged entertainment, particularly films and recorded music.

The advent of digital technology, and especially the rise of the internet as a mass medium, created a formidable problem for the huge companies that control the 'intellectual property' embodied in movies and music.

Their initial responses to the challenge were clumsy and inept. Long after the MP3 horse had bolted, for example, the record companies tried to lock the stable door with their own - proprietary and controllable - file-compression software.

The world yawned and gave its answer in the shape of Napster, an MP3-fuelled file-sharing service that signed up 60 million users in its first 18 months of life.

Because Napster was a company seeking to make profits, it was easy to bring to heel. The existing laws of copyright proved sufficient for the purpose. What the furore over the case obscured, however, was the incredible lengths to which the copyright lobby is prepared to go to secure its intellectual property - and the implications of this for civil society.

What has emerged is a formidable three-pronged strategy to secure these property rights. The first - and most obvious - strand is aggressive use of existing copyright laws. The second involves the use of encryption and security technology to counter the technological challenge of MP3 and the like.

The third involves the effective suborning of compliant and ignorant legislatures (notably the US Congress and the European Parliament) to create a new legal framework that gives unprecedented privileges to copyright owners over other groups in society.

It's the combination of technology plus compliant legislatures that threatens to bring about Huxley's nightmare.

We're already seeing the effects of this with DVD discs. DVD movies are encrypted using a system called CSS and can be played only on devices that are equipped with approved decryption software.

The industry tries to use this to control who can see which version of each movie: DVD discs purchased in the US cannot be played on European DVD players. But the encryption system is relatively easy to crack. Now 'hacked' DVD players can be obtained (if you know where to look) and a decryption program (called DeCSS) is available on the net, so owners of Linux-based computers are able to play DVDs on their machines.

But here's where the double whammy strikes. The copyright lobby persuaded the US Congress to include a clause in the Digital Millennium Copyright Act that makes it illegal to write software like DeCSS. And not only are people being prosecuted for doing so, but a computer magazine is being sued in New York for publishing the DeCSS code.

The program is relatively small. It is possible to print it on a T-shirt - and indeed such garments already exist. Under the DMCA, wearing one in public may be a crime.

DeCSS has also been published as a haiku. Does this mean that certain kinds of poetry will eventually be outlawed simply to appease the holders of intellectual property? This stuff is no longer about technology, folks; it's about freedom.

john.naughton@observer.co.uk

The Arts Council is sponsoring a conference in Cambridge on this and related issues.

webTitle: The court of the demon king

fields.headline: The court of the demon king
fields.standfirst:
Internet mogul Cliff Stanford is taking a walk on the wild side with his new boats-to-pop stars investment vehicle. Profile by Jamie Doward

More net news
fields.trailText: Internet mogul Cliff Stanford is taking a walk on the wild side with his new boats-to-pop stars investment vehicle. Profile by Jamie Doward
fields.body:
In a few months' time Clifford Martin Stanford will walk across an area the size of a football pitch somewhere in the middle of what was once war-torn Bosnia.

As he negotiates what would seem to be the most mundane of feats, Stanford, the founder of Demon Internet, the internet service provider, and one of Britain's richest self-made millionaires, will be egged on by employees of Redbus, his fledgling conglomerate, which builds everything from boats to pop careers.

If Stanford completes his stroll successfully he will breathe a huge sigh of relief: the ground over which he is to walk is currently a minefield. But not for much longer if Stanford's latest company, Redbus Landmine Disposal Systems, does its job properly. The RLD system uses two devices: Bigfoot, a machine that stomps all over a minefield, detonating hidden explosives; and 'worm', a machine to chew through the soil, ploughing it up to detect booby traps.

Great in theory - but is Stanford just a wee bit nervous about how it will work in practice? Apparently not.

'I'd be very happy to walk out there. We want to send a team of footballers to play on the ground we're so confident the system works,' he says, stifling one of many yawns, the result of an early-morning commute to London from his home in Brussels.

The blueprint that led to Redbus LDS was one of 2,500 Stanford's company has received since it started life two years ago with a £15m cash pile - half of what Stanford earned from selling Demon to Scottish Telecom, now called Thus, for £66m. All of Stanford's businesses are branded around the Redbus name. 'We wanted a name that implied London and the UK but was pronounceable all over the world. And, as I said to somebody once, I needed a "vehicle" for investment.'

The Demon sell-off turned Stanford into an overnight celebrity. The walls of his office, just off Oxford Street, are plastered with news about himself, Demon and Redbus. Missing from the gallery, however, are the salacious details of Stanford's love life plastered over the News of the World last year. Predictably, the 1,200-word account of champagne-fueled romps with two table dancers in Claridges, in his Rolls-Royce and his private jet confirmed he had the 'demon touch'.

'Cliff doesn't have any inhibitions,' nude dancer Natalie said, breathlessly. 'Let me tell you - his bank balance isn't the only impressive thing about him. That man certainly has breathtaking assets.'

Larry Ellison, Oracle's flamboyant MIG-flying boss, could be in danger of losing the 'most interesting internet mogul' mantle at this rate.

Among friends and colleagues Stanford shrugs off the article: 'All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.' And if things had turned out differently, Cliff could have been a very dull boy. An accountant by training, Stanford taught himself to write computer code in his spare time.

He struck gold when he worked out that if he built an internet service provider he could charge others for providing access to the net to subsidise his own surfing. It was the first time anyone had attempted to bring internet access to Joe Public's desktop. 'I worked out that if we got 200 users we'd break even; with 400 we'd make a small profit.'

Nobody predicted that by 1998, when Stanford sold the business, Demon would have 250,000 subscribers.

Stanford, small and squat, with a smoker's voice, could have retired at 46. After the Demon sale he emigrated to Belgium, where he now lives as a tax exile - when he's not at his villa in southern Spain, that is. But he says the reason he founded Redbus was to 'put something back' by investing in innovative British businesses. 'What drives me is the fun of doing things and making people rich, helping ideas turn into businesses.'

Stanford says he wouldn't have been able to found Redbus if he hadn't left the UK to avoid capital gains tax: 'It's counter-productive. It's a bad tax. If they could stay here and keep that money, more people would do something with it back home.'

The first venture Stanford invested in was Redbus Interhouse, which specialises in building and running internet 'hotels', the datarooms that take care of firms' online activities. The company listed on the stock market last year via a reverse takeover. 'It was voted - and I have the certificate to prove it - the best-performing share of 2000 - which, considering the downturn in the tech market, is actually pretty impressive.'

The share price has subsequently taken a hammering. Shortly after it floated in March the share hit the 300p mark. Last Thursday, however, it fell 19 per cent to 84p on the back of disappointing figures. The company lost £6m last year - far greater than the £4.7m its house broker had predicted.

Nevertheless, Stanford says the company will turn a profit - excluding charges for interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation - this year. The float raised around £100m, which will be used to turn Redbus into the European market leader for web-hosting services.

But Interhouse, so far the only publicly quoted part of the Redbus empire, is one of the more prosaic members of Stanford's stable. There's Redbus Film Distribution, for example. Stanford recently sold a 51 per cent stake in the business in a deal that valued the firm at around $40m. Unfortunately the buyer, a Scandinavian company, has yet to stump up the cash. Stanford, however, believes that this will be sorted out and that the future is rosy.

Then there's Redbus WorkBoats, a company that builds platformed boats for use by divers, police and photographers. Stanford admits business has been slow: 'It's a new concept and it's taking time for people to realise that. It has yet to convince the world.'

He also has great hopes for Redbus Continuous Professional Training, currently in the business of helping dentists gen up on their knowledge, and Redbus Serraglaze, a firm that uses prisms to bounce light into rooms that don't see too much sun.

This is not to forget Girls@Play, the pop group that Redbus's investment arm is now backing. The group's first single charted at number 18 recently. Stanford had held a board meeting with the band shortly before The Observer arrived. ('It's great fun doing a board meeting with five girls, you know.') He has great hopes for the album: 'In my opinion they're the best girl band around by a long way. We had a bloody good single. They know their fans and their fans know them. If they do what the Spice Girls did we could make millions.'

Cliff Stanford, the demon king of pop. It has a certain ring about it. Perhaps Stanford will be featuring in the News of the World again before too long. And next time he'll be able to put the cutting on his office wall.

webTitle: No space as runways run out

fields.headline: No space as runways run out
fields.standfirst:
A coordinated plan is vital if airport capacity is to keep up with passenger demand forecast to double in just over a decade

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A coordinated plan is vital if airport capacity is to keep up with passenger demand forecast to double in just over a decade
fields.body:
When Tory luminaries Nicholas Soames and Francis Maude arrived at a Gatwick conservationists' meeting last month, one wondered if they had missed the turning to the local Conservative club. Not so.

These well-known figures with constituencies near Gatwick made a beeline for their local conservationists' annual meeting, keen to pledge their opposition to any expansion of the nearby airport.

No more runways here!

But they hadn't suddenly turned into rampant environmentalists. This was more the sort of local politics so widespread during 18 years of Conservative rule that it virtually paralysed air transport policy.

Not that the problem has eased in the past four years.Forecasters say demand for air travel to and from the UK will double by 2015 to more than 350 million passengers a year. Our airports have no hope of handling these numbers.

Laurie Price, an industry observer and director of the Aviation and Travel Consultancy, said last week: 'Someone, somewhere has to decide whether we accept that people's ability to travel where they want when they want by air is part of being an advanced society in the twenty-first century. If you do accept it, you have to bite the bullet on airport expansion.'

Even in the Thatcherite Eighties, the Tories' love of wealth creation and burning desire to see privatised British Airways and airports operator BAA flourish was not powerful enough for them to cover the south-east in new runways or airport terminals (roads and out-of-town shopping centres were another matter).

Of course, BA, BAA and others did prosper. Recent research shows that the aviation industry now contributes £10 billion a year to the economy. But all the long-term forecasts have made it clear for years that the business will have its wings clipped in future when growth is choked off because airports are bursting at the seams.

And yet the prospect of jeopardising all those true-blue parliamentary seats around Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted, by encouraging unbridled airport expansion, was just too much for the Tories while in power.

And this Labour Government has more or less ignored the topic until now.

Gwyneth Dunwoody, chairman of the Parliamentary Transport Select Committee, said: 'Aviation in this country is very close to saturation and we are short of airports and air space. We need at least one extra runway in the south-east.'

Meanwhile, many regional airports large and small have grown beyond all expectations, often hand in hand with partial or complete privatisation.

This type of uncoordinated growth has come to represent a sort of unofficial aviation expansion policy for the nation in the absence of an official one - greatly alarming local residents, who are often torn between a desire for tranquillity and the lure of jobs at the airports, and the wider green lobby.

Airports that were seen as mild jokes only six or seven years ago, such as Luton, London City, Prestwick, Liverpool, Bournemouth, Teesside and even Stansted, have enjoyed huge success thanks to a soaring air-travel market and the blossoming of low-cost airlines, leading to passenger growth averaging almost 200 per cent since 1994. Even outposts such as Humberside, Exeter, Norwich and Londonderry have sprung up, with growth of at least 50 per cent.

But there has been no national policy to pull it all together.

Labour has now issued a consultation document and is likely to publish an air transport White Paper in 2002, the first since 1986.

BA chief executive Rod Eddington has already warned that Heathrow is rapidly losing its pre-eminence as the leading aviation hub in Europe and that the British transport infrastructure was 'noticeably inferior' to that of Germany, France or the Netherlands, where airports have grown rapidly. It is only a question of time before Paris Charles de Gaulle overtakes Heathrow.

The Government has taken the message to heart and has indicated that it will show its colours later this year, assuming it is re-elected, on how much future demand should be catered for. And hopefully where.

As The Observer revealed last year, Labour is expected to back a fifth terminal at Heathrow this summer, after the public inquiry reported in December. Sources indicate this favours 'T5'.

But will the new government go as far as recommending a second runway at Stansted or Gatwick? About 65 per cent of passengers flying to and from the UK use airports in the south-east, and experts reckon 70 per cent of future demand originates south of an imaginary line stretching from the Wash to Bristol.

Some industry leaders fear the Government will duck the issue; others believe it could be emboldened by a second term with a strong majority. BAA has already made it clear that the decision is too big for one company and must be made by government.

Says Price: 'If they make a decision, they should do it early in the next Parliament so that the flames of protest have died down before the following general election.'

Most observers expect that in granting T5, a new runway will be ruled out for Heathrow.

Gatwick has a legal agreement with the local authority not to build another runway there until 2019 - although that clearly has not stopped local conservationists and their MPs from worrying that it might be overturned. But most observers agree that if the Government plumps for anywhere it will be Stansted, even though it was a ghost town until a few years ago and is where the big airlines least want growth to be. Owner BAA is making moves to expand it to take 25 million passengers, compared with 11 million last year. Another runway and terminal would take capacity up to about 60 million.

One source familiar with BAA and government strategic thinking said: 'You cannot totally rule out Gatwick, but it's a political hot potato. Stansted is practically the most manageable, environmentally the most sensible and politically the most tolerable for Labour.

'I think the pressure is going to be for another runway and if there is one, Stansted is the place.'

Britain's commercial runways and airport terminals will be able to accommodate about 270m travellers a year by 2010. This is assuming Heathrow gets T5, Stansted increases to 25m, others' stated expansion plans are carried out and one or two of the former RAF bases are developed. These well-known figures with constituencies near Gatwick made a beeline for their local conservationists' annual meeting, keen to pledge their opposition to any expansion of the nearby airport. Our airports have no hope of handling these numbers. Laurie Price, an industry observer and director of the Aviation and Travel Consultancy, said last week: 'Someone, somewhere has to decide whether we accept that people's ability to travel where they want when they want by air is part of being an advanced society in the twenty-first century. fields.headline: Railtrack loses Chunnel link
fields.standfirst:
Operator stripped of prestige project  Lead role for Bechtel condition of £1.5bn rescue

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack is to be stripped of its key role in the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link and replaced by US construction giant Bechtel.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to be stripped of its key role in the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link and replaced by US construction giant Bechtel.

The Government will end more than two years' uncertainty tomorrow by announcing that the whole of the £5.2 billion link between Kent and London's King's Cross station will finally go ahead and be finished by 2006, minus beleaguered Railtrack.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott will tell the network and signalling operator that it will receive up to £1.5bn of taxpayers' money to avert a financial crisis and a slump in its credit rating.

But Railtrack will have to appoint a new Government-approved director, whose prime job will be to ensure that it fulfils its public interest role.

Senior Government sources told The Observer that after the Hatfield crash last October, Prescott wanted to renationalise Railtrack, but was dissuaded. It was argued that as well as scaring off private investors, such a radical move would have paralysed the industry for three years while new legislation went through.

Prescott suggested the 'public interest director' as a compromise, and is determined to force a very reluctant Railtrack, to accept it.

No one has yet been approached to take the job, but names discussed in ministerial circles include Sir Malcolm Field, chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, and Lord (Richard) Faulkner, a Labour life peer who was on the old British Rail board.

The Government has agreed to pay some of Railtrack's state funds early on the new condition that it concentrate on fixing the network and fitting safety systems.

The company will agree to give up its monopoly on 'enhancement' projects designed to expand the network. The second leg of the tunnel link is one of them.

Railtrack saved the link when the consortium run ning the project - London & Continental Railways (LCR), led by Bechtel - ran out of money in 1998. It agreed to buy the first phase, into Waterloo, for £1.67bn from LCR on its completion in 2003.

Railtrack was given an exclusive option to back the second phase. This should be built between this summer and late 2006, taking the line into a super-station at Kings Cross St Pancras and shaving Eurostar journey time from London to Paris and Brussels to just over two hours.

Railtrack had refused to commit itself, partly as a bargaining chip to get more funds. Now enfeebled, it has been thrown off the project.

Apart from Bechtel, the firms in LCR include Ove Arup, Halcrow and UBS Warburg. Most of phase two will be paid for by subsidies and Government-backed bonds.

webTitle: Cornered dictator is left with nowhere to run

fields.headline: Cornered dictator is left with nowhere to run
fields.standfirst:
The disgraced Serbian leader is under siege

Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The disgraced Serbian leader is under siege.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele and Pazit Ravina in Belgrade and Peter Beaumont
fields.body:
A bitter little joke circulated in Belgrade after the end of Nato's war against Serbia in 1999. Slobodan Milosevic was having breakfast with his helmet-haired wife Mira in their villa-cum-bunker in the Dedinje suburb of the city when he noticed soldiers being deployed outside. 'They've come to arrest me and take me to The Hague,' Milosevic cried. His wife looked out of the window and reassured him: 'Don't worry, darling. It's only the frontier service patrolling our new borders.'

So it has come to pass. On Friday evening armed police in balaclavas, accompanied by an ambulance, appeared at Milosevic's gate.

By yesterday Milosevic's grand vision of a Serb-dominated Yugoslavia - for which more than a quarter of a million people died - had shrunk to the grounds of his villa; his armies to a motley handful of supporters still prepared to perish to protect him.

In this present version of events, there is no prospect of Mira's reassurance. The police who arrived at Milosevic's door had indeed come to arrest him and take him to a specially prepared cell for questioning over 'his crimes in office' - corruption and political violence at home - although not the international community's allegations of crimes against humanity.

Although his bodyguards drove off the initial police assault in 15 minutes of drunken firing - apparently with the tacit approval of the army chief of staff, Nebojsa Pavkovic, who commanded Milosevic's campaign in Kosovo - one thing is clear. A Rubicon has still been crossed.

The attempt to arrest Milosevic may have been a shambles, but the fact that it happened at all has shown the determination of the new Yugoslav authorities to draw the poison of the murderous Milosevic years. He may not yet be on his way to the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia to face war crime charges. But suddenly it seems that, despite their insistence that they will never hand him over, Yugoslavia's new leaders have taken the first step towards it.

Only Milosevic can now prevent the eventuality of a trial of some kind. And only then by taking the most drastic of actions. Yesterday the Yugoslav authorities revealed that Milosevic - who decried those ordering his arrest as 'Nato agents one and all' - had vowed to 'die rather than go to prison', and that he had stockpiled the weapons and explosives to back up his threat.

Whether he means to die in battle or take his life like both his parents remains unclear.

The chaotic scenes outside Milosevic's house are a far cry from the days when he could command the loyalty of hundreds of thousands of Serbs who would turn out to hear their leader speak after his first firebrand oration in Kosovo in 1987 as the secretary of the Serbian Communist Party, when he vowed to 'defend' Serb rights.

The brand of nationalism he concocted was what Serbs wanted to hear - casting them as the victims who would rise to claim their national inheritance anew. Under this banner they followed him in the wars he inspired - from Slovenia to Croatia and Bosnia to Kosovo. Each ended in humiliation for the Serb cause.

But the fiasco of the attempts to arrest Milosevic has revealed a split that remains at the heart of Yugoslavia's new 'democratic' government six months after the Balkans' most notorious dictator was pushed out of power.

Two men encapsulate the split, and their differences produced the bungle. Vojislav Kostunica, the new Yugoslav President, is an anti-Western nationalist who sees the war crimes tribunal in The Hague as a tool of American power. Although he despises Milosevic, he has consistently said he would not deliver him to The Hague. Zoran Djindjic, the Serbian President, is a pragmatist who wants to end Serbia's decade of isolation and bring it into the European mainstream.

Djindjic supported all Milosevic's wars but realised that the dictator would eventually have to stand trial abroad for war crimes if Serbia was ever to turn the page. His strategy was delay, insisting that Milosevic first be tried on charges of corruption and abuse of power at home. Delay has also had the advantage of giving ordinary Serbs time to get used to the idea that one day Milosevic would have to go to jail. So far Djindjic's strategy has worked. Recent polls show well over two-thirds of Serbs now think Milosevic's place should be in jail. The numbers who think that jail should be in The Hague is over 40 per cent, compared to single figures just six months ago.

Djindjic may have persuaded a large section of the Serbian public, but he failed to get Kostunica to shift and start co-operating with The Hague. A struggle has been going on behind the scenes in the past two months. Djindjic thought he had won when he, Kostunica and key Cabinet Ministers agreed in mid-February that Serbs who were not Yugoslav citizens and had taken refuge in Serbia should be handed to The Hague. The rest would first have to stand trial at home.

The test came 10 days ago when Milomir Stakic, the former mayor of Prijedor in Bosnia, who had been indicted for genocide, was arrested in Belgrade and sent to The Hague. Kostunica stunned his colleagues by calling it 'unacceptable'. A furious Djindjic went public to say that Kostunica was going back on what he had agreed. Stakic was not a citizen of Yugoslavia but of Bosnia. The clash over Stakic was a sign that a bigger clash over Milosevic was likely.

If the differences between Kostunica and Djindjic were merely personal, they might be resolved gracefully. But behind them looms the role of the army, and the future of many of the top officers who carried out Milosevic's vicious orders in Kosovo. They too may be candidates for The Hague.

Among them is General Pavkovic, Milosevic's commander in Kosovo, who was offered effective immunity if he changed sides. So he started to play on Kostunica's disagreement with Djindjic to have the arrest order thwarted. His position may be sabre-rattling, but it is causing serious anxiety in the Djindjic camp. The armed night-time clash between the special police sent in to arrest the former dictator and his body-guards was just a symbol of a bigger clash in the wings.

That clash, should it occur, may centre around the timing of the arrest to conform to an American deadline demanding Milosevic's surrender. For while the number of Serbs happy to see Milosevic brought before local - if not international - justice has been gradually rising, there are many who are deeply unhappy that it should be orchestrated to keep America sweet. Three weeks ago that American pressure was ratcheted up again as the US told the government in Belgrade that, if it expected American aid to continue, it had to arrest and imprison Milosevic by 31 March, and at the same time should assist in transferring to The Hague at least one person to be indicted on war crimes charges. Those demands were laid out in explicit detail in a three-page document handed over by the US Ambassador to Belgrade, William D. Montgomery, to Kostunica, Djindjic and other senior Serbian officials.

Now the world's attention is focused on what is happening inside Milosevic's house. 'If he's not drunk, he's certainly going to kill himself,' said a colonel in the Serbian army intelligence. He claims it is a thought that has been much on Milosevic's mind.

Since October, Milosevic has not left his villa except to attend a couple of stormy party meetings which took place at the Socialist Party headquarters in Novi Belgrade. In that time little information has come out of the closed walls of the presidential villa at Uzicka 1. But what has emerged has been consistent.

One household servant described Milosevic as 'drunk most of the time'. He added: 'He drinks lots of expensive whisky and makes long phone calls.' His wife Mira - who is in the villa with him - has been described as depressed and paranoid and to be consuming tranquillisers and sleeping pills for much of the time.

The life and crimes of Milosevic

In May 1999 The Hague tribunal charged Slobodan Milosevic with responsibility for killings, deportations, and violations of the laws of war in Kosovo.

Genocide
Carla Del Ponte, chief prosecutor in The Hague, is also believed to be close to issuing genocide charges against Milosevic in connection with the 1992-95 Bosnia war. In the case of Kosovo, Milosevic was head of state and commander-in-chief of Yugoslav forces, making it easier to pin the indictment on him, while in Bosnia he was formally the ruler of a separate country, complicating the case.

Embezzlement
Yesterday's arrest warrant concerns accusations of large-scale embezzlement by Milosevic, his family, and his regime associates, plundering Serbian assets over the past decade and allegedly salting fortunes abroad. The Serbian authorities believe this is the most promising first case against the ex-President.

Electoral Fraud
The Serbian government is also hoping to bring charges of vote-rigging against Milosevic, for example in connection with last September's ballot where victory was initially denied to the opposition, triggering the mass protests that toppled Milosevic.

War crimes
Separately from the tribunal in The Hague, the Serb authorities want to prosecute Milosevic for war crimes, perhaps against Kosovo, Bosnia,and Croatia, but mainly for the suffering he brought on his own people through disastrous military campaigns. They resulted in 700,000 ethnic Serb refugees moving to Serbia from Croatia, Bosnia, and Kosovo. Treason, say his domestic opponents.

Property fiddles
The least of the cases against him, but the most easily proven, is that he abused office to buy up state land behind his private home along the road from the government villa where he was holed up yesterday. The plot of land was bought for the knockdown price of £3,000 in March 1999 in breach of the regulations governing officials' purchase of state property.

Ian Traynor
