webTitle: You'll never take me alive, vows Milosevic

fields.headline: You'll never take me alive, vows Milosevic
fields.standfirst:
Nowhere left to run

Special report: Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader who launched a decade of carnage in the Balkans, was holed up in his villa last night with a score of heavily armed gunmen for protection, and vowing he would 'not go to prison alive'.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader who launched a decade of carnage in the Balkans, was holed up in his villa last night with a score of heavily armed gunmen for protection, and vowing he would 'not go to prison alive'.

His threat to self-destruct or go down fighting had an eerie ring, coming from a man whose parents both committed suicide and who started - and lost - more wars than any other modern ruler. More than 250,000 people died in Bosnia and Kosovo.

It came as the Serbian government announced that the former ruler, who tried to cling to power by falsifying election results, faced charges of corruption and abuse of power. He refused to accept a summons and ordered his guards to prevent his arrest by force.

A die-hard group of flag-waving civilian supporters gathered outside the house, denouncing the government as traitors and swearing at foreign journalists.

Last night the government announced that Milosevic was under house arrest until he agreed to appear before an investigating judge.

'When employees of the Ministry of Interior estimate it is possible to carry out the arrest of Slobodan Milosevic, it will be done. He will either come in by himself or we will take him in, with or without force,' said Dusan Mihailovic, of the Interior Ministry.

He added there was no current plan to send Milosevic to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, which has indicted him for atrocities committed in Kosovo in 1999.

Mihailovic's declaration was an effort to regain dignity for the government after a clumsy effort by special armed police to break into the villa early yesterday.

Speculation about Milosevic's imminent arrest was started by a loyalist MP from his Socialist Party last Friday afternoon. Police cars and an ambulance moved up to the villa's front entrance. Some hours later a convoy of four black Jeeps, one with tinted windows, drove to the Palace of Justice. It returned to the villa an hour later. Although radio stations reported Milosevic was in the car with tinted windows and a Deputy Prime Minister claimed the former strongman had been arrested, no one saw him get in or out of any of the vehicles.

It seemed unlikely the government would have captured him and let him go so easily, although some Belgraders wondered if the army leadership had threatened a coup to protect him. A court official tried yesterday to deliver the summons for the former leader to appear before the investigating judge but Milosevic refused it, saying 'I do not recognise these police and these authorities. All of them are Nato servants'.

The government then turned to force. Just before 3am reporters saw armed men get out of a white van and leap the boundary wall of the villa. Gunfire was exchanged between the raiders and men inside the house, and most of the raiders retreated. Two policemen and one civilian was injured.

The Police Minister, Dusan Mihajlovic, said the raid was thwarted by the head of the army unit guarding the ex-President's home. Milosevic told police who went to negotiate with him that 'he will not be taken to prison alive,' Mihajlovic said.

The government accepted the stand-off. 'If we used force, there would be victims', the Police Minister added.

Zoran Djindjic, the Serbian Prime Minister, who has been masterminding the operations said he had intelligence reports that the villa was packed with ammunition, arms and explosives.Zoran Djindjic, the Prime Minister, later denied that Milosevic had ever been taken to the Palace of Justice.

To deny the rumours of his arrest, Milosevic briefly appeared outside the back gate of his villa to talk to the group of about 50 loyal supporters who have kept a vigil for several days. 'We are the popular guard. What is happening here is a great tragedy. We are not war criminals. The man who resisted Nato is a hero,' an elderly man told me. He identified himself as Dragomir Majkic, deputy chairman of a Belgrade branch of the Socialist Party.

A few from the crowd were allowed into the villa. 'At the moment I am drinking coffee with my friends and I am very well,' Milosevic told a local radio station by telephone.

A court official tried to deliver the summons to appear before the investigating judge but Milosevic refused it, saying: 'I do not recognise these police and these authorities. All of them are Nato servants.'

The government then turned to force. Shortly before 3am reporters saw a white van drive up from which armed men emerged. They leapt over the villa wall. Gunfire was exchanged and the invaders retreated. Two policemen and one civilian were injured.

Mihailovic said the raid had been thwarted by the head of the army unit guarding Milosevic's villa.

The officer, told by police to reduce the size of Milosevic's official bodyguard to just one, had given the keys to the compound to Milosevic's private guards. He said a meeting had been held, 'but the problem could not be solved because of army obstruction'.

Milosevic had told police who went to negotiate with him that 'he will not be taken to prison alive'.

His private bodyguards are under the command of Sinisa Vucinic, a top member of the Yugoslav Left (JUL), which was founded by Mira Markovic, Milosevic's wife. She was in the villa with him.

But the government accepted the stand-off. 'If we used force, there would be victims,' the Police Minister said. Zoran Djindjic, the Serbian Prime Minister, said he had intelligence reports that the villa was full of ammunition, arms and explosives.

President Vojislav Kostunica summoned an emergency meeting of top military commanders and senior politicians yesterday. Afterwards, looking sombre and flanked by them all, he said they had agreed completely: 'Our purpose is to calm tensions. We want to prevent a state crisis. Whoever shoots at the police or commits crimes has to answer to the law. No one is above it, not even Slobodan Milosevic. One individual should not endanger the state and the system.'

The President did not directly say Milosevic would be arrested soon, but that was the clear implication.

During the day supporters were again allowed to approach the villa but their numbers had dwindled. Some Serbs were upset at the way the police bungled Milosevic's attempted detention. Others were annoyed that the government had acted on the eve of an American deadline for action. President Bush has to certify this weekend whether Serbia has complied sufficiently with the Hague tribunal to warrant an extra $50 million in US aid

webTitle: Writer forced out of home by IRA threats

fields.headline: Writer forced out of home by IRA threats
fields.standfirst:
Republican ex-prisoner says he faces death for condemning Good Friday Agreement as sell-out

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Republican ex-prisoner says he faces death for condemning Good Friday Agreement as sell-out.
fields.body:
An IRA prisoner turned author is being forced to leave his West Belfast home because of intimidation from former comrades.

Anthony McIntyre, who served 17 years in the Maze prison, said he was going to move out of the republican stronghold of Ballymurphy because he feared the IRA would try to kill him for speaking out against the Sinn Fein leadership. He has lived in the area since he came out of jail eight years ago.

McIntyre, a member of the dissident Irish Republican Writers Group, said he had to consider the safety of his partner and their new daughter. Last week the RUC visited McIntyre's home and told him to step up his security.

He has incurred the wrath of the Provisional IRA's leadership for condemning the Good Friday Agreement as a sell-out of republican principles. He said: 'The Sinn Fein leadership has created an atmosphere in which I could be killed, in which someone could take it into their heads that they are doing the right thing by attacking me. They might not sanction it themselves, but the atmosphere is there for someone to do some thing against me and make a name for himself. They have been spreading propaganda linking myself and the Writers Group to the Real IRA, even though I have said consistently that there is no justification for their violence.'

Protesters, who included Sinn Fein candidates in the coming local government elections, have twice picketed McIntyre's home. He has also been beaten up outside his house and told that the IRA would 'put one in his head' if he continued to criticise the Provisionals' leadership.

He described the atmosphere in the Ballymurphy area as akin to that in the H-blocks during the blanket protests of the late Seventies and early Eighties. 'It is the same tension, the same feeling that I may be kicked or beaten up at any time.'

He points to the killing of Real IRA member Joe O'Connor by the Provisionals last October as evidence that his former comrades would be prepared to kill him to silence dissent. Though they oppose the Real IRA, McIntyre and fellow ex-IRA veteran Tommy Gorman have called for a public, independent inquiry into O'Connor's murder. McIntyre, who has contributed a chapter to a book on the Good Friday Agreement to be published by Oxford University Press this Easter, rejected Sinn Fein charges that he is paranoid.

'If only it was just paranoia,' he said. 'Recently a leaflet was distributed around the area, which was a mock Real IRA newsheet. It was actually handed out by the Provisionals and made references to myself being a sponsor of the Real IRA. The campaign of demonisation against myself and my family has intensified and the fact the RUC paid me a visit underlines that the threat is serious.'

Carrie Twomey, McIntyre's partner, accused the Provisionals of denying him and the other republican writers free speech. Pointing to her five-week-old daughter, Twomey said: 'I want us to move out because I want my daughter to grow up knowing her father.'

McIntyre's chapter in Aspects of the Belfast Agreement is entitled 'The defeat of the Provisional IRA', which will no doubt infuriate republican leaders.

fields.headline: Census translates into Ulster Scots
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Explanatory notes have been written in Ulster Scots to help people in Northern Ireland complete the 2001 census, even though nearly all of them speak English.
fields.body:
Quhit sex ir ye?
(What is your sex?)

Explanatory notes have been written in Ulster Scots to help people in Northern Ireland complete the 2001 census, even though nearly all of them speak English.

The guidance papers have been drawn up under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement, which granted 'parity of esteem' to the dialect - or language, depending on your point of view - spoken by an estimated 250,000 people.

Ulster Scots is a variant of the Scots tongue, which was the language of the Scottish state until the Union of the Crowns in 1603, when it was progressively supplanted by standard English, though it survived in a poetic and literary tradition. In the old Scots orthography 'qu' had the value of the English 'w'.

Among the other Ulster Scots versions of census questions are: ' Quhitlike ir ye fur merryin ?' which in English translates as 'What is your marital status?' and ' Quhit kintra wur ye boarn in ?' which means, 'What is the country of your birth?'

Questions in English such as 'What religion, religious denomination or body were you brought up in?' translates as ' Quhik releegion, kirk or releegious curn wur ye raired in ?'

The possible answers are equally antique. For Roman Catholic read ' Roman Caithlick '; Presbyterian Church of Ireland, ' Presbytairin Kirk in Airlann '; Church of Ireland, ' Kirk o Airlann '; and the Methodist Church in Ireland is ' Methody Kirk in Airlann '.

Most Ulster Scots speakers come from the unionist community, while most Irish speakers would describe themselves as nationalist or republican. Under the agreement, Irish and Ulster Scots are granted 'parity of esteem'.

But if Ulster Scots speakers also speak Irish they are given the option of answering in another of their native tongues: ' Dae ya unnerstaun, spake or scrieve [write] Airisch Gaelick ?'

Lord Laird, the chairman of the Ulster Scots Agency, defended the decision to distribute thousands of Ulster Scots guides to the census. 'It's as simple as this: we are granted equal status as Irish because under the agreement the Government is obliged to include Ulster Scots translation if they do the same for Irish speakers. '

He has called for similar treatment for the estimated 20,000 Ulster Scots speakers in the Republic.

fields.headline: Arabs accuse US of betrayal
fields.standfirst:
As they bury their dead, Palestinians charge Bush with collusion in Israel's hardline tactics

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As they bury their dead, Palestinians charge Bush with collusion in Israel's hardline tactics.
fields.body:
Ona day of funerals in the West Bank yesterday, Palestinians and the Arab world accused the Bush administration of sanctioning a tough new Israeli offensive that is exacting the highest casualties in weeks. Six Palestinians were buried after the bloodiest clashes since mid-February, as Israel begins to enact its hardline policies.

'There had been a policy of restraint which in my view is over,' the Israeli Defence Minister, Binyamin Ben Eliezer, told Israel's Channel Two television.

As the flag-draped coffins were borne out of the mosques by chanting crowds, popular anger was directed not only at Israel but at the US, which the Palestinians accuse of a double betrayal in a week when Yasser Arafat's residence in Gaza City was hit by Israeli missiles.

Several key Gulf allies of the US, and lynchpins of its policy aim of forging regional stability, also accuse the administration of encouraging Israel by vetoing a United Nations Security Council resolution to send an international force to protect the Palestinians, and for President Bush's blunt demand that Arafat condemn violence.

'The blatant US bias towards Israel and its repressive practices against the Palestinian people... reveals the contempt of the United States towards Arab feelings and human rights,' wrote the al-Bayan newspaper of the United Arab Emirates yesterday. In Saudi Arabia, the al-Madina newspaper said the US veto was a blatant attempt to prevent anybody from arresting Israeli violence. 'This honest (peace) broker does not want anybody to intervene in the ring of death to ensure that the result was in favour of the stronger party,' it said.

Many Palestinians believe that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon travelled to Washington last month with the express purpose of winning US approval for tough new methods aimed at snuffing out an uprising in which nearly 450 people have died, almost all of them Arabs.

'Israel would not have dared to go ahead with the shellings and escalation without American approval, and without American consent on the use of its weapons, including the Apache helicopters,' said Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the Palestinian Legislative Council. 'We know they have an agreement not to surprise each other, and Israel immediately let the cat out of the bag when it said it told the Americans ahead of time.'

In Tel Aviv, a spokesman for the US embassy denied Ashrawi's claims that Washington had approved Wednesday night's air attacks on Ramallah and Gaza City. 'I want to make clear that there is no coordination between the United States and Israel with regard to their military actions against the Palestinians,' a spokesman said.

Among Palestinians, the American interventions last week are a bitter disappointment. They had taken hope from the new administration's public disavowal of President Clinton's micro-management of the peace process. 'On the one hand, the Americans say they do not want to intervene in the peace process. They want to leave it to both sides,' said Yasser Abed Rabbo, a senior Palestinian negotiator.

'But on the other hand, they are intervening in a very biased way when it comes to condemning the Palestinians. We feel this is not a good beginning for the new American administration.'

The latest US affront to Palestinian sensibilities arrived on Thursday, at about the same time as Arafat was touring the still smouldering site of Israel's missile attack, where four trailers in a dormitory for his Force 17 personal security guard where reduced to ruins.

'The signal I am sending to the Palestinians is stop the violence,' Bush told a press conference in Washington. 'I can't make it any more clear, and I hope that Chairman Arafat hears it loud and clear.' Bush made a similar call to Sharon, but his balancing act failed when he issued this directive to Arafat. 'The Palestinian leader needs to speak out publicly and forcefully in a language the Palestinians can understand to condemn the violence and terror.'

For Palestinians, the blunt language added to the snub delivered by Bush's pointed refusal to set a date for a meeting with Arafat, a huge insult for the man who was the most frequent foreign visitor to Washington during the Clinton administration.

'This way of putting things, and trying to dictate things, is humiliating to ordinary Palestinians,' Abed Rabbo said. 'It makes it even more difficult for Mr Arafat to deal with such an idea or such a suggestion.'

That certainly seemed so yesterday when the commander of Arafat's militias in the West Bank, Hussein Sheikh, threatened to take the uprising inside the borders of the Jewish state.

fields.headline: Bankers who must save Europe
fields.trailText: George W Bush makes Ronald Reagan look a bit of a leftie. Bush's refusal to sign the Kyoto protocol on controlling atmospheric pollution has really shaken the rest of the world. But he has been working on his right-wing reputation for months.
fields.body:
George W Bush makes Ronald Reagan look a bit of a leftie. Bush's refusal to sign the Kyoto protocol on controlling atmospheric pollution has really shaken the rest of the world. But he has been working on his right-wing reputation for months.

Not only are the President's proposed tax cuts blatantly aimed at alleviating the lot of the rich; the New York Times has been reporting that, for good measure, Bush has some proposals for vicious cuts in welfare and childcare provision for the poor. We now know that Bush's definition of compassionate conservatism is compassion for conservatives.

It has been suggested to me that some of the Bush tax cut proposals are now seen as compensation for all those ambitious people whose new economy and dotcom stocks did not do so well. Whether they are Bush proposals or Richard Cheney proposals is, of course, an open question. It seems that, at least before his latest heart attack, vice-president Cheney was chairing all the key Cabinet meetings and the president was usually distinguished by his absence.

The way the US seems to be going makes the European Union's emphasis on modernising its social model, rather than abandoning it, all the more sensible. The rapid erosion of the US economic 'miracle' also puts the debate about 'Anglo-Saxon capitalism versus the rest' into perspective (and it should never be forgotten that Saxony happens to be in Germany).

Having thought they had abolished the business cycle, the more arrogant and dewy-eyed commentators on the US economy are seeing it return with a vengeance. It was to provide a safety net for the victims of business cycles that the European social model was developed in the first place.

What the markets are gradually beginning to grasp is that the US economic miracle involved building up so many unsustainable imbalances - falling savings, a vast balance-of-payments deficit, a supposedly ever-rising stock market - that there had to be an adjustment. Whether this involves a long period of slow growth or an outright recession is anybody's guess. So much depends on confidence and people's reactions that at times like this economic forecasts are of limited value. Everybody is guessing.

But what history seems to show is that the bigger the boom, the bigger the bust.

While the US boom went on, its economy was the 'importer of last resort' and the locomotive for the rest of the world economy. Having recovered only up to a point from the Asian crisis of 1997, south-east Asian economies, heavily dependent on the US market, now face another very uncomfortable period.

But week by week it has also become apparent that the European and UK economies are far from immune from the US slowdown. It is remarkable, for instance, that despite all the downward revisions to European economic forecasts and some very gloomy surveys of future plans, the European Central Bank has kept interest rates at the level ruling since the autumn.

Last week the ECB's governing council was split, and interest rates remained unchanged, despite evidence that even some of the hawks thought inflation was no longer the main problem. The markets are now saying that a cut will probably come at the ECB meeting on 11 April.

It was Harry S Truman (well before Harold Wilson) who said a week is a long time in politics. It remains to be seen how long a fortnight is in terms of ECB internal politics. The weakness of the ECB is all too apparent. It does not even vote on such a crucial matter; it tries to achieve a consensus in circumstances where some member countries are more concerned about the buoyancy of their economies (at the moment, that is) than about the recession that could be staring every European country in the face if the ECB does not act to keep growth going.

The stagnation in the Japanese economy is a salutary reminder of how difficult it is to emerge from deflation, or falling prices. It would be unfortunate if the ECB overplayed its disinflationary hand at a time when the world economy is so finely balanced, and it is refreshing that two of the most formidable members of the ECB - Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of the Bank of France, and ECB chief economist Otmar Issing - seem to be aware of the danger.

But so far it has to be said that the ECB's behaviour in the recent crisis has provided plenty of ammunition for its enemies, of whom I should like to think I am not one.

In a plea of mitigation, it is said some ECB members were worried that, with US interest rates still higher than those in Europe, a cut now might weaken the euro further. But the euro fell anyway after last week's 'no change' announcement because the markets are increasingly concerned about the growth prospects for the euro zone.

In the medium term it is difficult to see how the dollar can retain anything like its present levels given the size of the US trade deficit. But the US adjustment problem comes after years of above- average growth; growth in the eurozone has been so modest for so long that the good news is there are precious few imbalances to worry about.

Whereas the US has to adjust, which means slow growth, possible recession, and a lower dollar, the euro zone has scope for reasonably robust growth; all it needs is a little encouragement from economic policy.

The ECB has a huge weight of responsibility resting on its shoulders.

webTitle: Buy and hold no longer holds good

fields.headline: Buy and hold no longer holds good
fields.trailText: 'Anyone invested in technology was a winner for the 12 months up to last spring. Since then, you won if you were bought practically anything else.'
fields.body:
For the past few years, only the nimble have done well out of equities. Anyone invested in technology was a winner for the 12 months up to last spring. Since then, you won if you were bought practically anything else.

Even in the past few weeks, when the bears have been grumbling, it has been possible to make money if you picked the right stocks. Companies such as Billiton, Marks & Spencer, Cadbury Schweppes and PowerGen have all risen, while Marconi, Prudential, Amvescap and Railtrack have fallen.

But in a real bear market even the most nimble will lose. The 1987 crash was indiscriminate: everything fell. Of course the falls were quickly corrected and, un-less you were lucky enough to spot both the top and bottom of the market - and even the professionals failed to do that - the best strategy, with hindsight, was to stay put and ride out the dips.

Fund managers are exhorting us to do the same this time round. Don't panic, they say. Equities are for the long term. If you continue putting money into the markets as they fall, your bravery will pay off in years to come. That depends on how severe this downturn gets. Anyone who invested at the end of 1972 - a full year before the crash of 1974 - had to wait 20 years before their portfolio regained its value in real terms. That is pushing long term to the extreme.

Things did not seem that bad at the time. Inflation in the Seventies and early Eighties was rampant, which made it look as if the value of a portfolio was rising. This time around, there may be no such protection. Deflation, not inflation, is the concern. Investors are unlikely to be bailed out by a surge in prices.

Even if the tremors do not turn into an earthquake, a buy-and-hold strategy of the kind that was so successful for much of the past two decades is unlikely to be so in future. The death of inflation means companies can no longer rely on price rises to boost profits. Overcapacity and the fact that business is increasingly global mean it will become harder for in-dustries to prosper, and in-creasingly important for investors to pick the winners.

Jeremy Batstone of Nat-West Stockbrokers thinks this means investors will need a much more active investment strategy. He suggests setting a target price for everything you buy, and selling - or at least taking most of the profits - when that is reached, regardless of whether it takes two days, two months or two years.

The market recovered some of its poise last week, leading some analysts to hope the worst is over. That is unlikely. There is still a real risk the US will plunge into recession. If so, we will feel the impact. As Tim Bond of Barclays Capital points out, that will put pressure on earnings, which can only feed through to share prices. Even the superfit should avoid the market for the next few months.

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Lie back and think of Japan

fields.headline: Lie back and think of Japan
fields.trailText: 'The geisha is, and has always been, the pretty painted face of Japanese patriarchy.'
fields.body:
The geisha is, and has always been, the pretty painted face of Japanese patriarchy. No amount of waffle about tradition, ritual, art, silken kimonos, tea ceremonies, and all those other things that make ignorant, sensation-greedy Westerners go weak at the knees, has been able to disguise the ethical fungus at the heart of geisha culture. We are always hearing that these white-faced dollies are not 'strictly prostitutes' and Western tourists are happy to snap away at these willow-pattern workers in a way they never would at the women of King's Cross. Nevertheless, geishas remain as they always were - satin-slippered throwbacks, trapped in a psychosexual halfway house between companion, hostess, servant and whore.

Strip away all the trimmings, the beauty, grace and mystery of what Liza Dalby, the first foreigner to become a geisha, called 'the flower and willow world', and you're left with the vulgar reality of a very peculiar brand of a glorified hostess, who is quite happy to bang their married john, and then pour him a nice post-coital cup of tea. Which explains why it would be impossible to transplant the geisha on to Western society. Our prostitutes would do the sex, in a skimpy kimono if necessary (whatever!), but they'd doubtless draw the line at putting the kettle on afterwards.

Bearing this in mind, if we are to look for geisha-parallels in Western culture, maybe we should stop gawping at the streets of King's Cross and look inside the staid homesteads of suburbia, as well as the 'self help' industry which serves them. For, it seems to me, that, unlike hookers, ordinary women of the West seem more than happy to go a bit 'geisha' if that's what it takes to rescue their sham-relationships. If you don't accept that, then just think about how often we've heard that domesticity is the new destiny, or subservience is the new pashmina? If you still don't buy it, then take a look at the latest of these tomes to be published here, The Surrendered Wife by US housewife and self-styled 'feminist and former shrew' Laura Doyle. Then find me a prostitute who would lower herself to read it.

Self-help books have long been the amyl nitrite, the gay-disco 'poppers', of the female psyche - addictive in their own way, but decimating millions of brain cells with every sour, hectoring, ill-informed hit. Such tomes like to give the lie that male-female dynamics can be handled like Rubik's Cubes - a few clumsy twists and it's all solved - and The Surrendered Wife is no different. Having read Doyle's book, and seen her ranting on Richard and Judy, I can tell you that she dresses up 'surrendering' very prettily, but, basically, she is arguing that bovine is the new emancipated. In her view, the woman should hand over financial power to the man, obey even if she doesn't agree, and say yes to sex even if she doesn't feel like it. And if the man doesn't feel like sex? 'Put on a negligee and lay on the bed with a book,' purrs Doyle. Down boys!

When relinquishing financial power, and kowtowing to men is suddenly promoted as the fashionable lifestyle choice, you know it's all gone horribly wrong. Moreover, at least the classic geishas got to exude mystery and history. Now we get twinsetted harridans sitting on daytime-TV sofas telling other women that the way forward is to lie around in baby doll nighties, reading improving literature.

Indeed, what's really interesting about all this is not how successful The Surrendered Wife is (there's a sucker born every moment and we're all watching Richard and Judy), nor how little it takes to throw generations of hard-won autonomy away, but how mundane and dowdy they have made geisha-style behaviour seem. Not to mention ugly and stupid. Even the dumbest hooker on the street knows where to draw the line between sex and love, and how to build a spiritual wall between her job and her essential self. By contrast, in the case of the geishas, both of the classic Eastern and new-style Western varieties, femininity itself seems to be up for sale.

 barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

webTitle: US Masters: Nicklaus goes for the Slam (1971-72)

fields.headline: Quad bugged the Bear
fields.standfirst: Dobereiner was right in 1973 - a 'Super Nicklaus' can succeed where Jack failed
fields.trailText: We have been here before. But only once. The Open at Muirfield in 1972 and Jack Nicklaus, having won the USPGA the year before and that year's Masters and US Open, had the chance for the only time in his record-breaking career to hold all four Major titles at the same time.
fields.body:
We have been here before. But only once. The Open at Muirfield in 1972 and Jack Nicklaus, having won the USPGA the year before and that year's Masters and US Open, had the chance for the only time in his record-breaking career to hold all four Major titles at the same time. To have beaten the world's best over 288 holes of golf in four consecutive titles. To ensure the victory roster read Nicklaus, Nicklaus, Nicklaus and Nicklaus. It would be an unprecedented achievement in the modern game.

In 1930 Bobby Jones had pulled off what way back then was described as 'the impregnable quadrilateral', but that was in the days when the Grand Slam included the US Amateur and British Amateur rather than The Masters and PGA. This is not to denigrate the achievement about which Jones wrote: 'I have been frequently confronted with the question, "Had I started out the year 1930 with the expectations or even hope of winning four major Championships?" I did not feel like saying that I had, because I felt reluctant to admit that I considered myself capable of such an accomplishment. Actually I did make my plans for that golfing year with precisely that end in view.'

Then, in 1953, Ben Hogan won all six tournaments he entered and might have won the Grand Slam had it not moved on from being impregnable to logistically impossible. The final match of the PGA tournament clashed with the second day of qualifying for the Open at Carnoustie at a time when everyone had to qualify.

So come 1972, with the '71 PGA already bagged, Nicklaus was set fair for a crack at the impossible challenge. He would write about looking forward to that year's itinerary: 'You always play your best on courses you like the most. Augusta National is Augusta National, enough said; Pebble Beach is my favourite course; Muirfield is the finest course outside the US.' When asked if it was possible to win all four, he replied 'yes' with no hesitation and complete assurance. He was happy to answer the question Bobby Jones had ducked.

Nicklaus won the 1972 Masters by three strokes, leading for all four rounds and ending up the only player under par for the tournament. It was convincing but not overly so. Nicklaus had led by five shots at the 11th and then three- putted three of the next four greens. He said afterwards: 'Trying to play safe is the worst thing in the world. I don't think I'd have looked so bad there at the last if I'd been forced to throw the ball at the hole.'

At Pebble Beach, Nicklaus again led from the off and was four clear going into the final nine. Again he stumbled and by the 12th Arnold Palmer had narrowed the lead to one shot. Then, at the par-three 17th, Nicklaus's one-iron hit the pin and the ball stopped five inches from the cup. Again he won by three strokes. There was only one side of the quadrilateral to go. Pat Ward-Thomas wrote in The Guardian that victory at Muirfield would be 'achievement enough to inspire wonder for generations to come'. He went on to suggest that Big Jack would be 'an even money chance' to win both the remaining Majors. Not even Tiger is that short a price.

Nicklaus said his plan was for 'an analytical, careful, conservative game, particularly in the Major championships which, I have learnt, are far more often lost than won.' His meticulous preparation was undone by an unsuitable pillow which left him with a pain in the neck. He resolved to be more cautious and to carry his own pillow on his travels.

Nicklaus shot a 70 in the opening round. For the first time in that year's Majors he was behind the field, the honour falling to an unknown Yorkshireman, Peter Topping. Nicklaus followed up with a 72 and a 71 to leave himself five behind Tony Jacklin and six behind Trevino, who chipped in from a bunker at 16 and chipped in again at the 18th for his fifth consecutive birdie and a score of 66.

On Saturday morning the pain in Nicklaus's neck had eased and, reckoning that he would need no worse than a 65 to win the tournament, he told his wife over breakfast: 'I'm going to win.' He played, by his own estimation, 'a nearly flawless back nine', with birdies the 2nd and 3rd and two par fives. He then birdied 10 and 11 to move to six under and into the lead.

'The running and roaring of the crowd became incredible,' he remembers. 'It was sending shivers down my back, there was a lump in my throat and tears on my cheeks. It fuelled my soaring confidence and I narrowly missed making my third consecutive birdie.' When he reached the 16th: 'I had a flashback to the final round in 1966 at Muirfield when I was tied for the lead and said I needed 3,4,4 to win and that is what happened.' This time he missed a six-footer to bogey the hole, failed to birdie 17th, and parred the last. He had shot a 66 .

Back down the field, Trevino and Jacklin were a shot ahead, standing on the 17th tee. Trevino drove into a bunker and finally made it to the fringe at the back of the green in four. Jacklin was 30 yards short of the green in two. As they approached the green, Trevino said to Jacklin: 'I'm through - it's all yours.' Jacklin hit a pitch to 18ft. Trevino chipped in. Jacklin three-putted. Trevino had won by a stroke. Jacklin would never compete in a Major again. Nicklaus congratulated Trevino and then went out and played tennis.

'The frustration and disappointment are more intense than I care to remember even now, a quarter of a century later,' he wrote. His Majors record from the start of 1971 read: second, second, fifth, first, first, first, second. Some streak. Unrepeatable, it was assumed - even Nicklaus never won back-to-back Majors again.

Had he been slightly less conservative, he might have conquered the quadrilateral. In 1973, having criticised Nicklaus for often 'pussyfooting around with irons off the tee', The Observer's Peter Dobereiner continued: 'One day a Super-Nicklaus will come along with no such inhibitions. Just imagine a golfer hellbent on blasting the cover off the ball with his driver and who then aimed to knock the flagstick out of the cup with his approach shot and who, moreover, had the technical ability to make this policy work. Once or twice a year Nicklaus is forced to play like this and when he does golf becomes a different game. One day there will surely be a player for whom such golf is normal. Then the whole specious Nicklaus-Jones argument can start again, except that it will be whether the new hero is as good as Nicklaus.' Enter Tiger Woods.

He would write about looking forward to that year's itinerary: 'You always play your best on courses you like the most. Augusta National is Augusta National, enough said; Pebble Beach is my favourite course; Muirfield is the finest course outside the US.' When asked if it was possible to win all four, he replied 'yes' with no hesitation and complete assurance. He was happy to answer the question Bobby Jones had ducked. Nicklaus won the 1972 Masters by three strokes, leading for all four rounds and ending up the only player under par for the tournament. It was convincing but not overly so. Nicklaus had led by five shots at the 11th and then three- putted three of the next four greens. He said afterwards: 'Trying to play safe is the worst thing in the world. I don't think I'd have looked so bad there at the last if I'd been forced to throw the ball at the hole.' At Pebble Beach, Nicklaus again led from the off and was four clear going into the final nine. Again he stumbled and by the 12th Arnold Palmer had narrowed the lead to one shot. Then, at the par-three 17th, Nicklaus's one-iron hit the pin and the ball stopped five inches from the cup. Again he won by three strokes. There was only one side of the quadrilateral to go. Pat Ward-Thomas wrote in The Guardian that victory at Muirfield would be 'achievement enough to inspire wonder for generations to come'. He went on to suggest that Big Jack would be 'an even money chance' to win both the remaining Majors. Not even Tiger is that short a price. Nicklaus said his plan was for 'an analytical, careful, conservative game, particularly in the Major championships which, I have learnt, are far more often lost than won.' His meticulous preparation was undone by an unsuitable pillow which left him with a pain in the neck. He resolved to be more cautious and to carry his own pillow on his travels. Nicklaus shot a 70 in the opening round. For the first time in that year's Majors he was behind the field, the honour falling to an unknown Yorkshireman, Peter Topping. Nicklaus followed up with a 72 and a 71 to leave himself five behind Tony Jacklin and six behind Trevino, who chipped in from a bunker at 16 and chipped in again at the 18th for his fifth consecutive birdie and a score of 66. On Saturday morning the pain in Nicklaus's neck had eased and, reckoning that he would need no worse than a 65 to win the tournament, he told his wife over breakfast: 'I'm going to win.' He played, by his own estimation, 'a nearly flawless back nine', with birdies the 2nd and 3rd and two par fives. He then birdied 10 and 11 to move to six under and into the lead. 'The running and roaring of the crowd became incredible,' he remembers. 'It was sending shivers down my back, there was a lump in my throat and tears on my cheeks. It fuelled my soaring confidence and I narrowly missed making my third consecutive birdie.' When he reached the 16th: 'I had a flashback to the final round in 1966 at Muirfield when I was tied for the lead and said I needed 3,4,4 to win and that is what happened.' This time he missed a six-footer to bogey the hole, failed to birdie 17th, and parred the last. He had shot a 66 . Back down the field, Trevino and Jacklin were a shot ahead, standing on the 17th tee. Trevino drove into a bunker and finally made it to the fringe at the back of the green in four. Jacklin was 30 yards short of the green in two. As they approached the green, Trevino said to Jacklin: 'I'm through - it's all yours.' Jacklin hit a pitch to 18ft. Trevino chipped in. Jacklin three-putted. Trevino had won by a stroke. Jacklin would never compete in a Major again. Nicklaus congratulated Trevino and then went out and played tennis. 'The frustration and disappointment are more intense than I care to remember even now, a quarter of a century later,' he wrote. His Majors record from the start of 1971 read: second, second, fifth, first, first, first, second. Some streak. Unrepeatable, it was assumed - even Nicklaus never won back-to-back Majors again. Had he been slightly less conservative, he might have conquered the quadrilateral. In 1973, having criticised Nicklaus for often 'pussyfooting around with irons off the tee', The Observer's Peter Dobereiner continued: 'One day a Super-Nicklaus will come along with no such inhibitions. Just imagine a golfer hellbent on blasting the cover off the ball with his driver and who then aimed to knock the flagstick out of the cup with his approach shot and who, moreover, had the technical ability to make this policy work. Once or twice a year Nicklaus is forced to play like this and when he does golf becomes a different game. One day there will surely be a player for whom such golf is normal. Then the whole specious Nicklaus-Jones argument can start again, except that it will be whether the new hero is as good as Nicklaus.' Enter Tiger Woods.

webTitle: The speeches were dire and there was much comment about dresses

fields.headline: The speeches were dire and there was much comment about dresses
fields.standfirst: But, says  Philip French,  the right films won
fields.trailText: But, says Philip French, the right films won
fields.body:
The 73rd Academy Awards were the occasion for less anger and controversy than for many years. As a result the event itself became the centre of criticism and discussion. As Lord Acton didn't quite say, business tends to corrupt and showbusiness corrupts absolutely, and this year there was as much attention paid to the Vivienne Westwood dress and décolletage of the BBC's arts correspondent as to the appearance of the stars. As is my custom, I didn't watch the presentations live on TV and by design I avoided any of the extended recordings. It was, of course, impossible not to see snatches of the acceptance speeches on the news and they were as incoherent, sentimental, self-serving and egotistical as ever. But then what do you expect from actors improvising on such occasions? From the bits I heard of compere Steve Martin he didn't do much better with his carefully scripted material.

But as I said, the awards them selves seemed pretty reasonable, and went to serious films. Gladiator is a work of grandeur, a movie that renews a tradition going back to the pre-Hollywood epics of the Italian cinema. Equally, Russell Crowe was a splendidly virile representative of stoic probity, and I'm glad to see that Jon Solomon, professor of classics at Arizona University, thinks highly of the film in a revised edition of his authoritative The Ancient World in the Cinema (Yale University Press, £16.50). I think it right that Steven Soderbergh won the Best Director Award ahead of Ridley Scott and Ang Lee, because Traffic, apart from exhibiting a sharp, controlling intelligence and sense of pace, was also photographed by him under a pseudonym.

Since the nominations were announced last month, I've seen Laura Linney in You Can Count On Me playing a character not entirely unlike Erin Brockovich. But while she provided formidable competition for Julia Roberts, I can see why the Academicians went for the more obviously incandescent star performance. As for the supporting players, Benicio Del Toro in Traffic is as deserving of his Oscar as predecessors like De Niro (Godfather Part II), Christopher Walken (The Deer Hunter), Gene Hackman (Unforgiven) or Kevin Spacey (The Usual Suspects). I eagerly look forward to seeing the other winner, Marcia Gay Harden, as the painter's wife in Pollock .

Had Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon not won the Best Foreign Language Film against such feeble competition, it would have been a disgrace, and I think it's time that this patronising and arbitrarily chosen category was abandoned. About the technical awards (of which Crouching Tiger took three), it is not easy for non-professionals to speak, though the craft sections of the Academy have always tended to be conservative. There was one near certainty, however, in an important, often overlooked category, the Documentary Feature. I doubt if anyone emerged from seeing Mark Jonathan Harris's Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport not positively willing it to win an Oscar.

webTitle: Forget Lourdes, get me a whore

fields.headline: Forget Lourdes, get me a whore
fields.standfirst: Jean Pierre Sinapi's challenging and wry film confronts the normally taboo subject of the sexuality of the handicapped
fields.trailText: Philip French: a wonderfully warm, funny picture, full of generosity and goodwill, and very well acted
fields.body:
One of the great clichés of our time is to refer to something as 'the last taboo'. The current Private Eye comes up with 13 examples found in the Guardian alone these past three years referring to subjects as different as female masturbation and reusing graves. Jean-Pierre Sinapi's Uneasy Riders, so its publicity material proclaims, 'confronts and overturns a final taboo: the right of the disabled to sex and love'.

Is this claim entirely true? There is, as I recall, a scene in Fanny Hill where the eponymous heroine and colleague have sex with a prodigiously endowed simpleton. More seriously, not to say solemnly, the cinema has in the past 50 years touched on the subject, if necessarily circumspectly, in such films as Fred Zinnemann's The Men and Hal Ashby's Coming Home, and there's the wonderful scene in Fellini's Amarcord where the insane uncle, on day release from an institution, climbs a tree and shouts out: 'I want a women' until he's coaxed down and taken away.

It is the case, however, that Sinapi confronts the sexuality of the handicapped with a rare frankness and good humour that has commended itself to the public and critics alike. His movie picked up the audience prizes at San Sebastian and Berlin last year, and at the London Film Festival it won the International Critics prize and the Satyajit Ray Award.

The film is set in a small, liberal residential hospital in Provence near a main road (the film's French title is Nationale 7) where the physically and mentally disabled mingle freely with a tolerant staff. Shot on digital video, it has the texture of a documentary and, in fact, a number of the supporting cast are disabled people, though in some cases acting as if they have different disabilities from their own.

The institution's problem child is René, a bearded malcontent in his late forties, confined to a wheelchair and raging eloquently and obscenely against the world and the hospital's staff. Not for him the bus trips to Lourdes. He'd rather stay in his room surrounded by coloured pin-ups and watching hardcore videos. Then one day, in a vulnerable moment, he confesses to Julsie (Nadia Kaci), an attractive new nurse, that he'd like to experience a prostitute before he dies.

She broaches the matter at a staff meeting and tensions come to the fore, though only the practising Catholics are able to articulate their objections. So Julie pushes ahead and makes some discoveries, one of them being that if she arranges for a prostitute for René, she could be charged with pimping, unless a doctor can be persuaded to state in writing that such services are physically and psychologically necessary.

She visits the prostitutes plying their trade in camper-vans along Nationale 7, measuring their doors to see if they're accessible to wheelchairs. Finally, she settles on Florele (Nadine Marcovici), a strident no-nonsense whore of a sort that might once have been termed 'brazen' but would now be called 'feisty'. Florele transforms René and soon his fellow inmates are demanding similar therapy.

There is much else going on at the home for Julie. A good-looking shrink is after her, but he's allergic to cats, so she has to get another would-be lover, the hospital's janitor, to take her cat for a month. There's also a problem with a second wheelchair-borne patient, the retarded Rabah (Saïd Taghmaoui from La Haine and Hideous Kinky), a gay Arab obsessed with Johnny Halliday. The local priest and a Catholic nurse are preparing Rabah for baptism, but a complication arises when he decides that he wants as his godmother at the ceremony the whore Florele.

The movie ends before some of the long-term problems can be confronted, and its tone is perfectly expressed in the sight of the priest and the whore jiving together at the home's New Year's Eve 2000 party, as if Christ and Mary Magdalene had taken to the dance floor. But it's a wonderfully warm, funny picture, full of generosity and goodwill, and very well acted.

webTitle: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire by JK Rowling read by Stephen Fry

fields.headline: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire by JK Rowling read by Stephen Fry
fields.trailText: Whatever the reason for JK Rowling wanting all 21 hours of Harry Potter's latest adventure recorded complete and unabridged, the result is depressing.
fields.body:
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
JK Rowling
Read by Stephen Fry
Running time 21hrs
Cover to Cover £49.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Whatever the reason for JK Rowling wanting all 21 hours of Harry Potter's latest adventure recorded complete and unabridged, the result is depressing.

The story starts well, with Lord Voldemort (a creature so hideous that even Rowling can't bring herself to describe him) returning from the dead. But after three hours of intimate detail about Harry's life with his cruel Uncle Vernon, it dawns on you that the fourth and longest of Rowling's books is little but a series of tedious, disjointed events with no interrelating factors, and this despite the author's claim that she has the next three Harry Potters plotted in her head.

Looking on the bright side, a lengthy reading is as suited to Stephen Fry as wallpaper music is to Superdrug. I also understand that the Quidditch World Cup final is important to young boys and girls, and suppose this is why the narration of the match between Ireland and Bulgaria takes up one whole side of a tape and a good deal of Fry's majestic breath and bombastic talent.

Yet Rowling is capable of much greater suspense and drama; this finally arrives when Harry mounts his broomstick to take part in the Triwizard Tournament at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.

Having spent a weekend of listening to 'kisses, deaths, battles, ghosts and resurrections', I could, as Harry Potter exclaims, 'do with a year off'.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A book crying out for the Woody Allen treatment, plus Between Camps, The Running Mate, Motherkind and Dream Stuff
fields.body:
Group: Six People in Search of a Life
Paul Solotaroff
Penguin £7.99, pp339
Buy it at a discount at BOL

For 11 years, Paul Solotaroff suffered from panic attacks and depression. Then he visited a charismatic psychiatrist called Charles Latham. A few judiciously prescribed pharmaceuticals and two years of group therapy later, and he'd transformed himself from an anxious recluse into a successful journalist with a 'sane and lovely' wife. Inspired by his cure, he inveigled his way into another of Latham's groups, this one fortuitously composed of individuals who'd be pretty glamorous even without therapy: an ex-model, a sex-addicted Wall Street millionaire, an embezzling Broadway producer and an alcoholic songwriter.

Solotaroff taped their sessions in order to produce a narrative that could have been titled Sicks and the City - if it wasn't such a bad pun. But then bad puns - or even good puns - have no place in this litany of sincerity and sharing. New York, neurotics: this is a book crying out for a touch of Woody Allen treatment.

Between Camps: Nations, Cultures and the Allure of Race
Paul Gilroy
Penguin £8.99, pp406
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A fearlessly complex exploration of how fascist and colonialist ideas about race have influenced the way we define identity in today's supposedly multicultural world. Gilroy's scrutiny of Nazi culture reveals afresh how fascism made a fetish of race. The radical surprise of the book is Gilroy's contention that this fetishisation is still being perpetuated by whites and non-whites alike.

He is fascinating on Marcus Garvey's peculiar admiration for the Ku Klux Klan: 'All races should be pure in morals and in outlook, and for that we, as Negroes, admire the leaders and members of the Anglo-Saxon clubs', and intriguing on the lingering 'commodification of blackness' in hip-hop, advertising and sport. Not many academics could discuss Snoop Doggy Dogg and Heidegger with equal authority; Gilroy's capacity to do so is at once a strength and the source of the occasional fantastically labyrinthine sentence.

The Running Mate
Joe Klein
Vintage £6.99, pp404
Buy it at a discount at BOL

By the author of Primary Colors, this is another satirical swipe at the US democratic process, although it has to be said that the shenanigans in The Running Mate look pretty muted beside the chaos US democracy inflicted on itself last autumn. Decorated war hero and genuine good sort Senator Charlie Martin is trying to do the impossible - run for the presidency at the same time as falling in love. Cue every variety of spin, slander and sorry betrayal.

Disappointingly, it appears that the American campaign trail is as lacking in glamour as our own humdrum affair, and the unremitting briefings and press conferences can all get a bit much. Even the senator grows weary: attending yet another Washington power dinner, he reflects: 'If there was a moment in life he truly loathed, it was the post-sorbet debate initiated by hostly glass-tinkling.' And just when you're flagging, along comes a line like that.

Motherkind
Jayne Anne Phillips
Vintage £6.99, pp292
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Kate is pregnant with her first child when she discovers her own mother's terminal illness. By the time Alexander is born, Katherine has come to live with Kate, her husband and her two tempestuous stepsons in order to die. Birth and death, it couldn't get more serious, but this is a subtle, tender novel that is often very funny about the subdued warfare of stepfamily life.

Phillips's achievement is to dispense with the obvious drama of high emotion in order to capture the strange feeling of suspension that so often occurs in its place. Kate navigates the new world of motherhood blanketed in a soft drowse of sleep-deprivation, as Katherine inches quietly towards an undemonstrative death. If the other characters are not always as fully realised, it seems a fair price to pay for such a lyrical study of what it is to become a mother and what it is to lose one.

Dream Stuff
David Malouf
Vintage £6.99, pp185
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A fine collection of stories which illustrate Malouf's enormous talent for invoking both the gentle rhythms of the everyday and the small epiphanies that occur when those rhythms are disrupted. A small boy yearning for the return of his father who is 'missing in action' in the Far East suddenly realises that he's never coming back. A girl growing up in a closed Pentecostal sect longs for her gay uncle who is out of reach, in Sydney, 'which Grandpa Morpeth says is Sodom'. A man savagely and incomprehensibly beaten in the street cannot shed the image of the day in his own childhood when he crawled under the front steps of the house to hold his dying dog in his arms.

Each of the nine stories in Dream Stuff encloses a moment of painful tension which feels all the more poignant for having been half-recognised and barely understood.

fields.headline: Modern boys and mobile girls
fields.standfirst: For sci-fi author William Gibson, Japan has been a lifelong inspiration. Here, the writer who coined the phrase 'cyberspace', explains why no other country comes closer to the future... or makes better toothpaste
fields.trailText: For sci-fi author William Gibson, Japan has been a lifelong inspiration. Here, the writer who coined the phrase 'cyberspace', explains why no other country comes closer to the future... or makes better toothpaste.
fields.body:
'Why Japan?' I've been asked for the past 20 years or so. Meaning: why has Japan been the setting for so much of my fiction? When I started writing about Japan, I'd answer by suggesting that Japan was about to become a very central, very important place in terms of the global economy. And it did. (Or rather, it already had, but most people hadn't noticed yet.) A little later, asked the same question, I'd say that it was Japan's turn to be the centre of the world, the place to which all roads lead; Japan was where the money was and the deal was done. Today, with the glory years of the bubble long gone, I'm still asked the same question, in exactly the same quizzical tone: 'Why Japan?'

Because Japan is the global imagination's default setting for the future.

The Japanese seem to the rest of us to live several measurable clicks down the time line. The Japanese are the ultimate Early Adaptors, and the sort of fiction I write behoves me to pay serious heed to that. If you believe, as I do, that all cultural change is essentially technologically driven, you pay attention to the Japanese. They've been doing it for more than a century now, and they really do have a head start on the rest of us, if only in terms of what we used to call 'future shock' (but which is now simply the one constant in all our lives).

Consider the Mobile Girl, that ubiquitous feature of contemporary Tokyo street life: a schoolgirl busily, constantly messaging on her mobile phone (which she never uses for voice communication if she can avoid it). The Mobile Girl can convert pad strokes to kanji faster than should be humanly possible, and rates her standing in her cellular community according to the amount of numbers in her phone's memory. What is it that the Mobile Girls are so busily conveying to one another? Probably not much at all: the equivalent of a schoolgirl's note, passed behind the teacher's back. Content is not the issue here, but rather the speed, the weird unconscious surety, with which the schoolgirls of Tokyo took up a secondary feature (text messaging) of a new version of the cellular telephone, and generated, almost overnight, a micro-culture.

A little over 100 years ago, the equivalent personal, portable techno-marvel in Tokyo would have been a mechanical watch. The printmakers of the Meiji period made a very large watch the satiric symbol of the Westernised dandy, and for the Japanese, clock-time was an entirely new continuum, a new reality.

The techno-cultural suppleness that gives us Mobile Girls today, is the result of a traumatic and ongoing temporal dislocation that began when the Japanese, emerging in the 1860s from a very long period of deep cultural isolation, sent a posse of bright young noblemen off to England. These young men returned bearing word of an alien technological culture they must have found as marvellous, as disconcerting, as we might find the products of reverse-engineered Roswell space junk. These Modern Boys, as the techno-cult they spawned came popularly to be known, somehow induced the nation of Japan to swallow whole the entirety of the Industrial Revolution. The resulting spasms were violent, painful, and probably inconceivably disorienting. The Japanese bought the entire train-set: clock-time, steam railroads, electric telegraphy, Western medical advances. Set it all up and yanked the lever to full on. Went mad. Hallucinated. Babbled wildly. Ran in circles. Were destroyed. Were reborn.

Were reborn, in fact, as the first industrialised nation in Asia. Which got them, not too many decades later, into empire-building expansionist mode, which eventually got them two of their larger cities vaporised, blown away by an enemy wielding a technology that might as well have come from a distant galaxy.

And then that enemy, their conquerors, the Americans, turned up in person, smilingly intent on an astonishingly ambitious programme of cultural re-engineering. The Americans, bent on restructuring the national psyche from the roots up, inadvertently plunged the Japanese several clicks further along the time line. And then left, their grand project hanging fire, and went off to fight Communism instead.

The result of this stupendous triple-whammy (catastrophic industrialisation, the war, the American occupation) is the Japan that delights, disturbs and fascinates us today: a mirror world, an alien planet we can actually do business with, a future.

But had this happened to any other Asian country, I doubt the result would have been the same. Japanese culture is 'coded', in some wonderfully peculiar way that finds its nearest equivalent, I think, in English culture. And that is why the Japanese are subject to various kinds of Anglophilia, and vice versa. It accounts for the totemic significance, to the Japanese, of Burberry plaid, and for the number of Paul Smith outlets in Japan, and for much else besides. Both nations display a sort of fractal coherence of sign and symbol, all the way down into the weave of history. And Tokyo is very nearly, in its own way, as 'echoic' (to borrow Peter Ackroyd's term) a city as London.

I've always felt that London is somehow the best place from which to observe Tokyo, perhaps because the British appreciation of things Japanese is the most entertaining. There is a certain tradition of 'Orientalia', of the faux-Oriental, that has been present here for a long time, and truly, there is something in the quality of a good translation that can never be captured in the original.

London, being London and whatever else, eminently assured of its ability to do whatever it is that London's always done, can reflect Japan, distort it, enjoy it, in ways that Vancouver, where I live, never can. In Vancouver, we cater blandly to the Japanese, both to the tour-bus people with the ever-present cameras and to a delightful but utterly silent class of Japanese slackers. These latter seem to jump ship simply to be here, and can be seen daily about the city, in ones and twos, much as, I suspect, you or I might seem to the residents of Puerto Vallarta. 'There they are again. I wonder what they might be thinking?'

But we don't reflect them back. We don't have any equivalent of the robot sushi bar in Harvey Nichols, which is as perfectly 'Japanese' a thing as I've seen anywhere, and which probably wouldn't look nearly as cool if it had been built in Tokyo or Osaka.

We don't have branches of Muji interspersed between our Starbucks (although I wish we did, because I'm running out of their excellent toothpaste). Muji is the perfect example of the sort of thing I'm thinking of, because it calls up a wonderful Japan that doesn't really exist. A Japan of the mind, where even toenail-clippers and plastic coat-hangers possess a Zen purity: functional, minimal, reasonably priced. I would very much like to visit the Japan that Muji evokes. I would vacation there and attain a new serenity, smooth and translucent, in perfect counterpoint to natural fabrics and unbleached cardboard. My toiletries would pretend to be nothing more than what they are, and neither would I. (If Mujiland exists anywhere, it's probably not in Japan. If anywhere, it may actually be here, in London.)

Because we don't reflect them back, in Vancouver, they don't market to us in the same way they market to you.

The trendy watch chains of London are the only places in the world, aside from Japan, where one can purchase the almost-very-latest Japan-only product from Casio and Seiko.

Because Japanese manufacturers know that you see them, in London. They know that you get it. They know that you are a market.

I like to watch the Japanese in Portobello market. Some are there for the crowd, sightseeing, but others are there on specific, narrow-bandwidth, obsessional missions, hunting British military watches or Victorian corkscrews or Dinky Toys or Bakelite napkin rings. The dealers' eyes still brighten at the sight of a tight shoal of Japanese, significantly sans cameras, sweeping determinedly in with a translator in tow. A legacy from the affluent days of the bubble, perhaps, but still the Japanese are likely to buy, should they spot that one particular object of otaku desire. Not an impulse-buy, but the snapping of a trap set long ago, with great deliberation.

The otaku, the passionate obsessive, the information age's embodiment of the connoisseur, more concerned with the accumulation of data than of objects, seems a natural crossover figure in today's interface of British and Japanese cultures. I see it in the eyes of the Portobello dealers, and in the eyes of the Japanese collectors: a perfectly calm train-spotter frenzy, murderous and sublime. Understanding otaku -hood, I think, is one of the keys to understanding the culture of the web. There is something profoundly post-national about it, extra-geographic. We are all curators, in the post-modern world, whether we want to be or not.

The Japanese are great appreciators of what they call 'secret brands', and in this too they share something with the British. There is a similar fascination with detail, with cataloguing, with distinguishing one thing from another. Both cultures are singularly adroit at re-conceptualising foreign product, at absorbing it and making it their own.

Why Japan, then? Because they live in the future, but neither yours nor mine, and somehow make it seem either interesting or comical or really interestingly dreadful. Because they are capable of naming an après-sport drink Your Water. Because they build museum-grade reproductions of the MA-1 flight jacket that require prospective owners to be on waiting lists for several years before one even has a chance of possibly, one day, owning the jacket. Because they can say to you, with absolute seriousness, believing that it means something, 'I like your lifestyle!'

Because they are Japanese, and you are British, and I am American (or possibly Canadian, by this point).

And I like both your lifestyles.

Enjoy one another!

 William Gibson is the author of All Tomorrow's Parties, and the forthcoming Pattern Recognition, both Penguin UK.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Martin Amis gets in his own criticisms first in this skillful memoir
fields.body:
Experience
Martin Amis
Vintage £7.99, pp386
Buy it at a discount at BOL

After just a day or so cruising through this autobiography - for it moves fast, with wit and structural grace, despite the deck being wet with footnotes, despite its heavy, shifting cargo of death and loss - the mind's eye is left with two vivid impressions, each stamped with subtlety (fresh) and honesty (weary).

One is of Martin Amis's own progression from adolescence - all flop and peeve, head snot-full of intellectual ambition - to the double-edged rewards of early middle age: success, fatherhood, self-knowledge, new teeth.

He gets in his own criticisms first, quietly upbraiding himself over confusions between 'its' and 'it's' and the difference between 'sex' and 'love'. He examines himself, and his pomposities and his heartbreaks, with a voice that's unmistakably his own; the humour tastily underdone, the literary learning worn with a welcome non-combative gentleness.

In parallel is the tale of his father's awkward lurch towards death. The son's attempts to understand his colossus of a father grow ever more insightful, ever more rigorous and at the same time - massively - ever more loving; and in dealing with the end of the father, the end of all the laughter he gave and the laughter he stole, the writing's triumph is, fittingly, absolute.

When first published (and acclaimed by some as Amis's finest work yet), the book drew criticism for the passages dealing with the death of his cousin, Lucy Partington, one of the victims of Fred West. And, yes, the anger Amis exudes can seem at times more of a writerly than a cousinly anger - but it's still anger, hot and glinting, and his job is, after all, to be a writer, not a cousin, so why on earth not?

These passages add spirit and nuance. And the main themes, of father and son, bounced along with a wealth of anecdote and lit-crit and gossip, form a unique tale, consummately told, of age, change, filial love and mortality, in circumstances - literary, moral, political, familial - never likely to be repeated. The spirit of honesty lunges at you and only the most cynical, or jealous, will want to parry.

fields.headline: 'It's a disaster for a novel to be topical'
fields.standfirst: Pat Barker talks to Robert McCrum about the balance between sincerity and trickery at the heart of the novel
fields.trailText: Pat Barker talks to Robert McCrum about the balance between sincerity and trickery at the heart of the novel
fields.body:
Ask Pat Barker a question

Observer: What is Border Crossing about?

Pat Barker: The young man at the centre of it, Danny Miller, is about 23. When he was 10, he committed murder. What interests me is not so much his violence as the fact that he has this particular personality structure, where it's very difficult for him to know where he stops and other people start.

Obs: Was there a specific moment of inspiration?

PB: It must be the only novel that has ever started in a television interview. This young man said, 'I have a severe borderline personality disorder, and that is why I'm good at interviewing people.' I was fascinated.

Obs: What did you mean to convey by Border Crossing?

PB: The fact of Danny's success, of a young man who is trying to cross over into territory that doesn't belong to him, to control his therapist. When he succeeds, he crosses the border. Simultaneously, the therapist, Tom, loses clinical detachment and becomes over-involved, and in the end complicit. It's the story of a good man sliding into complicity with evil.

Obs: Your work shows a great interest in psychotherapy and psychological states. Why is that?

PB: That balance between involvement and detachment is what novelists do. It's the ideal relationship between a novelist and a character, I think, total involvement and identity and empathy, stopping short of being autobiographical - in my case, anyway - but also quite detached. In some ways, the therapists in my novels are actually standing in for that. And the same would be true of all of the mediums of the books, of which there are an almost indecent number.

Obs: Do the mediums come from your family ?

PB: Well, it's through all the generations. My grandmother's first husband was a spiritualist medium. What fascinates me about that is the balance between conviction and sincerity and trickery, which is also something that novelists are very familiar with.

Obs: Initially, Border Crossing seems to be built on an outrageous coincidence. Was that a technical problem?

PB: It is tricky, yes. You can't have a coincidence at the beginning... well, I mean, perhaps you can have a coincidence in the first chapter. You certainly can't resolve the book on a coincidence.

Obs: On page 17, you write that, 'A coincidence is the crack in human affairs that lets God or the devil in...'

PB: I couldn't resist the aphorism. I don't think it means a damn thing. (Laughs)

Obs: Do you believe in God?

PB: I sometimes behave as if I do. I would find it hard to answer a bald 'Yes'. People ask me whether I believe in evil.

Obs: And you always seem to be drawn to rather troubled characters.

PB: Isn't that true of novelists in general? If you're in a restaurant and one couple in the corner are having a really blazing row and are obviously in the last few hours of the relationship, and you've got a middle-aged couple holding hands at another table, you know which one you want to be. But which are you paying attention to?

Obs: Do you think it's a good thing for a book to be topical?

PB: Absolutely not. It may be a good thing for a book to be contemporary. But I think it's a disaster for a novel to be topical. There's nothing deader than last year's news story.

Obs: Do you do a lot of research?

PB: I did an enormous amount for the [Regeneration] trilogy; very little research, really, for the other books.

Obs: This is your tenth novel. Have you ever been tempted to explore other literary forms?

PB: Tempted, yes, but not successfully. I suppose the likeliest thing for me to do is the short story. Can't write poetry - useless at that. What I get asked to do from time to time is screenplays.

Obs: You like dialogue?

PB: I like being able to go inside the character at any moment.

Obs: And do you like playing God in the novel?

PB: I don't think I do play God, because I always ask questions I don't know the answers to.

Obs: Can you recall when you knew you wanted to be a writer?

PB: I lived in Knaresborough at the time, and there's a wishing well. You dropped a penny and you wished. When I was 11, I dropped a penny in and wished to be a novelist. And my uncle bought me a pen.

Obs: So it wasn't a secret wish ?

PB: Even then, it was writing fiction that I wanted to do. My grandmother very sensibly said, 'Yes, but you've got to earn a living, dear.' There was a factory at the end of the street, so my idea at 11 was, I would work in the factory to earn my living, and I would write the novels in my spare time.

Obs: And what kind of books did you read when you were growing up, ?

PB: I didn't belong to the sort of family where the children's classics were laid on. I went to the public library and read everything I could get my hands on.

Obs: Were there books in your home?

PB: There was a shelf of encyclopedias which belonged to my grandfather.

Obs: Who are the writers you admire now?

PB: Contemporary writers, mainly poetry: Hughes, Heaney, Simon Armitage, Glyn Maxwell.

Obs: What do you take from poetry?

PB: Intensity of language. When I'm writing the first draft, I'm writing in a very slovenly way: anything to get the outline of the story on paper. I think it's very useful at the end of the day to remind yourself of how precisely language can be used, so that you don't slip into too lax an approach.

Obs: There's a comic sequence set in a provincial writing school which feels as though it's written from some kind of experience.

PB: Yeah, it was an experience of being a student.

Obs: Do you think you can teach writing?

PB: What you do with a young writer is to recognise the note in their voice when they are on song for the first time and applaud. That's what Angela Carter did for me.

Obs: What do you think is the purpose of fiction ?

PB: To enable people to think clearly and feel deeply about the same subject simultaneously. I don't believe it's froth on the surface. I think we were telling each other stories in a sort of disease-ridden, half-starved condition round the camp fire two and a half million years ago. It's a fundamental part of who we are.

Obs: Are you in the middle of your writing career?

PB: I've no idea where I am in my career. If I get totally fed up with the promotion side of it, I may be close to the end. In terms of writing, I've quite good ideas for the next two books. The ideas don't seem to stop coming.

Obs: What are you working on now?

PB: I don't really want to talk about it. I want to keep the steam in the kettle.

Obs: Your last book, Another World, was also haunted by the First World War, but in Border Crossing you're much more contemporary. And your picture of childhood is quite bleak.

PB: In Another World the character of Gareth is almost a Danny Miller in the making.

Obs: Does that bleakness come from your own experience, from something in your own past?

PB: It wasn't an untroubled childhood, and it couldn't be.

Obs: Why?

PB: I... I... I had no father; I didn't know who my father was. I was told he was dead. He may... he may have been dead - I don't know. He may have been killed in the war.

Obs: One might think that was a fantastic subject. Have you ever been tempted to explore your early life ?

PB: I've dipped into it, in a very disguised way, in several books. Even parts of Danny Miller are... I'm drawing on parts of my own childhood.

Obs: But you've never been tempted to explore your father's history or life?

PB: It wouldn't be possible. My mother didn't know who he was - which I found out on her deathbed. It was a very strange sensation, because it felt like losing two parents. She was already unconscious, on morphine. She was obviously going to die within a matter of hours. My sister told me. I knew instantly that it was the absolute truth.

I felt so sad that it was a truth my mother had never been able to tell me. She couldn't say, 'I haven't a clue,' because that would have seemed to her utterly disgraceful. It would not have seemed disgraceful to me, and I would not have judged her or condemned her. I would have thought, in the circumstances of wartime, she had lost a man she cared for deeply. He'd been killed, and within a matter of six weeks she went out on the town, got drunk, and then who knows? Yes, yes. It has taken me a long time to accept that my existence might not be an unqualified disaster.

 A televised version of this interview will be shown on Artsworld this afternoon at 5pm. Available on Sky Digital Channel 199. To subscribe call 08705 900 700.

 Ask Pat Barker a question
