This young man said, 'I have a severe borderline personality disorder, and that is why I'm good at interviewing people.' I was fascinated. Obs: What did you mean to convey by Border Crossing? PB: The fact of Danny's success, of a young man who is trying to cross over into territory that doesn't belong to him, to control his therapist. When he succeeds, he crosses the border. Simultaneously, the therapist, Tom, loses clinical detachment and becomes over-involved, and in the end complicit. It's the story of a good man sliding into complicity with evil. Obs: Your work shows a great interest in psychotherapy and psychological states. Why is that? PB: That balance between involvement and detachment is what novelists do. It's the ideal relationship between a novelist and a character, I think, total involvement and identity and empathy, stopping short of being autobiographical - in my case, anyway - but also quite detached. In some ways, the therapists in my novels are actually standing in for that. And the same would be true of all of the mediums of the books, of which there are an almost indecent number. Obs: Do the mediums come from your family ? PB: Well, it's through all the generations. My grandmother's first husband was a spiritualist medium. What fascinates me about that is the balance between conviction and sincerity and trickery, which is also something that novelists are very familiar with. Obs: Initially, Border Crossing seems to be built on an outrageous coincidence. Was that a technical problem? PB: It is tricky, yes. You can't have a coincidence at the beginning... well, I mean, perhaps you can have a coincidence in the first chapter. You certainly can't resolve the book on a coincidence. Obs: On page 17, you write that, 'A coincidence is the crack in human affairs that lets God or the devil in...' PB: I couldn't resist the aphorism. I don't think it means a damn thing. (Laughs) Obs: Do you believe in God? PB: I sometimes behave as if I do. I would find it hard to answer a bald 'Yes'. People ask me whether I believe in evil. Obs: And you always seem to be drawn to rather troubled characters. PB: Isn't that true of novelists in general? If you're in a restaurant and one couple in the corner are having a really blazing row and are obviously in the last few hours of the relationship, and you've got a middle-aged couple holding hands at another table, you know which one you want to be. But which are you paying attention to? Obs: Do you think it's a good thing for a book to be topical? PB: Absolutely not. It may be a good thing for a book to be contemporary. But I think it's a disaster for a novel to be topical. There's nothing deader than last year's news story. Obs: Do you do a lot of research? PB: I did an enormous amount for the [Regeneration] trilogy; very little research, really, for the other books. Obs: This is your tenth novel. Have you ever been tempted to explore other literary forms? PB: Tempted, yes, but not successfully. I suppose the likeliest thing for me to do is the short story. Can't write poetry - useless at that. What I get asked to do from time to time is screenplays. Obs: You like dialogue? PB: I like being able to go inside the character at any moment. Obs: And do you like playing God in the novel? PB: I don't think I do play God, because I always ask questions I don't know the answers to. My grandmother very sensibly said, 'Yes, but you've got to earn a living, dear.' There was a factory at the end of the street, so my idea at 11 was, I would work in the factory to earn my living, and I would write the novels in my spare time. I think it's very useful at the end of the day to remind yourself of how precisely language can be used, so that you don't slip into too lax an approach. Obs: Do you think you can teach writing? PB: What you do with a young writer is to recognise the note in their voice when they are on song for the first time and applaud. I don't believe it's froth on the surface. I think we were telling each other stories in a sort of disease-ridden, half-starved condition round the camp fire two and a half million years ago. It's a fundamental part of who we are. Obs: Are you in the middle of your writing career? PB: I've no idea where I am in my career. If I get totally fed up with the promotion side of it, I may be close to the end. In terms of writing, I've quite good ideas for the next two books. The ideas don't seem to stop coming. Obs: What are you working on now? PB: I don't really want to talk about it. I want to keep the steam in the kettle. PB: In Another World the character of Gareth is almost a Danny Miller in the making. Obs: Does that bleakness come from your own experience, from something in your own past? PB: It wasn't an untroubled childhood, and it couldn't be. Obs: Why? PB: I... I... I had no father; I didn't know who my father was. I was told he was dead. He may... he may have been dead - I don't know. He may have been killed in the war. Obs: One might think that was a fantastic subject. Have you ever been tempted to explore your early life ? PB: I've dipped into it, in a very disguised way, in several books. Even parts of Danny Miller are... I'm drawing on parts of my own childhood. Obs: But you've never been tempted to explore your father's history or life? PB: It wouldn't be possible. My mother didn't know who he was - which I found out on her deathbed. It was a very strange sensation, because it felt like losing two parents. She was already unconscious, on morphine. She was obviously going to die within a matter of hours. My sister told me. I knew instantly that it was the absolute truth. I felt so sad that it was a truth my mother had never been able to tell me. She couldn't say, 'I haven't a clue,' because that would have seemed to her utterly disgraceful. It would not have seemed disgraceful to me, and I would not have judged her or condemned her. I would have thought, in the circumstances of wartime, she had lost a man she cared for deeply. He'd been killed, and within a matter of six weeks she went out on the town, got drunk, and then who knows? Yes, yes. It has taken me a long time to accept that my existence might not be an unqualified disaster.  A televised version of this interview will be shown on Artsworld this afternoon at 5pm. Available on Sky Digital Channel 199. To subscribe call 08705 900 700.  Ask Pat Barker a question  Pat Barker was born in Thornaby-on-Tees in 1943. She won the Booker Prize for The Ghost Road in 1995. Border Crossing is her tenth novel.

fields.headline: Now for Sunday afternoon
fields.standfirst: After 42 years, Saturday Night, Sunday Morning's rebellious anti-hero Arthur Seaton is back. As for his creator, he never went away. Alan Sillitoe is still defying literary fashion and still writing for dear life
fields.trailText: After 42 years, Saturday Night, Sunday Morning's rebellious anti-hero Arthur Seaton is back. As for his creator, he never went away. Alan Sillitoe is still defying literary fashion and still writing for dear life
fields.body:
On his wall are several large framed maps - his 'dream world', way out beyond this west London book-lined flat. When he is stuck for words he dwells on maps and imagines the shape of the earth and loses himself for a while. On the mantelpiece is a polished horseshoe that his grandfather, a blacksmith with eight children, made many decades ago, and a gun: small and toy-like, but in the hand cold and heavy. He picks it up and with a disconcertingly theatrical flourish, crouches slightly and aims it at the window, eyes owlishly blinking.

On his neat desk, beside the pipe that is usually stuck firmly in his mouth and the cafetiere of strong, rich coffee (brewed to the same recipe for decades), is a hard-backed ledger/desk-diary (2001) in which he writes. He opens it up and shows me page after page of neat, looped script in blue ink.

It's a first draft, which he then types out, blackens with corrections, types out again, blackens again, and so it goes on until he no longer thinks 'trash!' when he reads it through. 'It's a washing process,' he explains; you have to get rid of the clutter, endlessly simplify, make the language 'clear, simple, good'. And with each novel he thinks: 'It's killing me. Never, ever again!' Yet he continues because he 'has to. I write in order to keep on living. Because I don't want to die; be brain-dead, emotionally dead. I write to live.'

It's all that Alan Sillitoe has done now for 50 years, written. He grew up in Nottingham in poverty. His father was an illiterate labourer, often unemployed, often drunk and violent, and he tyrannised the household. Sillitoe left school at 14, worked in factories, became an air traffic control assistant, joined the RAF, and then - all this by the age of 20, his life too like a melodramatic kind of fiction - discovered he had TB (often a killer, then). He spent 18 months in hospital, read widely and started to learn how to write.

From the age of 14 Sillitoe had had girlfriends. In his autobiography he describes lying with his teenage lover in front of the fire, having sex, while upstairs her mother and boyfriend were doing the same thing. He wasn't always faithful, and he seemed to move from one sexual relationship to the next with carefree swiftness. But then one day, back from hospital, he met the American poet Ruth Fainlight in a bookshop. She was already married but they 'liked each other', spent more and more time together and eventually ran off together, abandoning England (a country he says he loves but sometimes doesn't like much) and her husband. They've been together ever since, and have been married for nearly 50 years.

Over the next 10 years - all through his peripatetic twenties, when he lived with Ruth in France and Spain and wrote under orange trees - he wrote several novels. They were emphatically rejected by dozens of publishing houses, often coming back to him with no comment from the editor. Nevertheless, he put 'writer' on his passport and didn't think of giving up, and he can't tell me what gave him the faith to keep going. 'Call it an obsession,' he says.

In his autobiography he compares it to being underground, picking away blindly at a seam. Without writing, he says, his head would have 'burst from sheer misery'. He thinks he would have gone on producing fiction for the next decade, the one after that even, if he had not been successful. 'What else could I do?'

But, of course, he was successful. In Majorca Robert Graves encouraged him to write about what he knew: working-class life in Nottingham. When he was 30, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning was published (after several rejections, of course). Its anarchic hero, Arthur Seaton, is a factory worker in Nottingham: rebellious, dissatisfied, contemptuous of authority. With its descriptions of adultery, violence, poverty, attempted abortion even, the novel caused a thrilled uproar. Two years later it was made into Karel Reisz's landmark film. Sillitoe became known as one of the Angry Young Men (a label he loathes and despises), a working-class writer (a label he also hates), the uneducated raw talent from up North (ditto; he hates almost every label with a passion).

After Saturday Night and Sunday Morning came the equally successful The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner . He has written dozens of novels since but none have achieved the same cult status. Fame - which he never came to terms with anyway; it is 'somehow derogatory, not made by you but by the world, and one does not much trust the world' - ebbed. The style in which he was writing - stalwartly realistic, provincial and plain - was new for a while, but then came to seem outmoded, thrown into the shade by dazzling postmodern and multicultural voices. Sillitoe says he does not mind, though at the same time concedes that Saturday Night has dogged him as a writer - like the rock groups who are asked to play ancient hits by their audience when they want to move on. He says. listen, he's written much better books since then. 'All that was 40 years ago.'

So why has he now, after all these years of resisting, written a sequel, Birthday, in which Arthur Seaton reappears, middle-aged, married, full of memories? He pulls deeply on his pipe; his perky, lugubrious face is wreathed in smoke. Of course, he says, he was often asked to write Monday Night and Tuesday Morning, Tuesday Night and Wednesday Morning, and 'actually I did soon start writing a novel that continued the life of Arthur Seaton, but after about 100 pages, when I saw what I had, I thought: "I can't do this. It's the easy way out." I always thought I'd do it some time. I can have an idea and let it sink down into the mulch of my mind and God knows what huggermugger and argy-bargy it's up to down there, but it can reappear 10, even 25 years later. So it was that Arthur Seaton nagged away at me. "I'm still here, you know," he'd go. "Get back to work."

'And then, two or three years ago, I saw a way of doing it. I wanted to write about a woman whose husband had been injured in an industrial action and she looks after him for 20 years. And I wove the story of the Seaton brothers round her. I came at it obliquely - oblique is often the best way.'

Birthday is a triptych. It begins with the return of Arthur Seaton's brother Brian from London for a seventieth birthday party of an old flame; moves to an offstage death; ends with life continuing. It is all about revisiting memories; about ageing but not quite growing up; about the difficulty of change; about settling for what you don't really want. It's not a bitter or a pessimistic book, but it is sorrowful in a stoic and muted way (Sillitoe's daughter-in-law typed the final draft, and she wept).

Sillitoe is a great believer in stoicism. When he talks about his own childhood he refuses any kind of self-pity. He feels sorry for the father who used to beat him because, 'poor chap', he was doing the best he could, in his way. He says he was lucky in his own life - TB made him a writer; the struggle of his early years gave him his subjects. He tried to be a good father to his two children, both grown up now. He loved them, certainly - but I'd have to ask them how he did as a father.

He doesn't mind that people don't read him so much now - he just feels very lucky that the books gave him enough money to live on, and to still have a publisher; anyway, once he finishes a book, he lets it go. 'Vain regrets do no good,' he says briskly. He lives for the next one he is writing. He says that most of the time he simply doesn't notice getting older (he is in his seventies now), and when he does, he likes it because 'it's all experience, isn't it?; that's what you have in the end - memory, experience, imagination, skill. And at least I'm too old now to die young.'

Anyway, 'a writer has to believe he can live forever'. He wants to be the first novelist to publish a book at 95. He talks of Verdi and Matisse and Picasso. He believes in fate. He doesn't believe in God. He isn't scared of dying: 'The lights go out and that's it.'

Alan Sillitoe has always denied that Arthur Seaton was a version of himself, yet the two resemble each other in their ability to cut off from the past. Sillitoe's autobiography is full of unregretful partings. He learns to detach himself from his parents early on, not to love or trust them. He leaves girlfriends without a backward look. He leaves Nottingham blithely and England easily. He says that he had to become a 'different person' in order to become a writer.

He talks of himself as two people, 'bilingual'. He has both remained close to his working-class roots (he says that he wants to give a voice to these people from Nottingham) and yet apparently at the same time severed them without much sense of pain. Sillitoe agrees to this. He nods. 'Callousness,' he says pensively. 'Yes, call me callous. You're right. Maybe it has something to do with my childhood. I had to survive. I had a sense of adventure, but that's like callousness too I think. A type of selfishness, yes.'

He talks of a time a pure happiness, when he was a young man on a ship, very alone and looking out over the Bay of Biscay, and all he saw was emptiness rolling away over the horizon. 'Emptiness is a positive thing. You're going to have to fill it. There's adventure. I have always felt I was being driven - that's no excuse for callousness of course - and I don't fight against being driven, drawn along. It has sometimes been a slow, difficult current. But I knew if I fought it I would drown. Nobody wants to drown.'

There is an admirable persistence of purpose in Sillitoe - a refusal to move with the tides of fashion, an insistence on his own particular brand of social realism ('good, simple English'). 'I'll not,' he says, puffing vigorously, 'write a novel with the end at the beginning and with 50 pages unpunctuated [like Ulysses ]. I tell stories. I don't care if I'm radical or old-fashioned. I'm just a novelist; that's all I've ever been.

'Anyway, everything finds its own level in the end. And after a book is published, I just don't care any more. It can sink or swim. If it sinks, well, in a Darwinian sense then that's what it deserves. And if it swims, then it is lucky old me.'

Sometimes young writers send him manuscripts, asking his advice, or wanting his name for a puff on the back. He reads them carefully and writes back at painstaking length. 'I say, edit it, rework it, redraft it, send it back in two years. I say: read Stendhal, Dickens, Conrad, Dostoevsky, Chekhov. People write without ever reading. They think they can sit down and write a book, just like that, and be famous. I tell them to try again. They never come back to me.'

Hardly surprising, really. They leave him to his notebooks of neat looped script, his coffee, his gun, his horseshoe, his poet-wife, his dream-world maps, his obsessive need to be a writer still, known always for his past, peering through his pipe-smoke into the uncertain future, book by book until the lights go out.

fields.headline: A supreme storyteller
fields.trailText: On Tuesday, it will be the tenth anniversary of Graham Greene's death. It's hard, now, to recapture the spell Greene cast over a generation of readers.
fields.body:
On Tuesday, it will be the tenth anniversary of Graham Greene's death. It's hard, now, to recapture the spell Greene cast over a generation of readers.

In his later years, a self-conscious exile in the South of France, he managed to be both mysteriously elusive and at the same time extraordinarily omnipresent, popping up in unlikely places - at the bar of the Ritz Hotel, in a television studio in Communist Hungary or in the correspondence columns of the Times and the Spectator. My yellowing Penguin copies of his work proclaim him 'the Greatest English Writer of Our Time'. That's a claim Greene himself would have pooh-poohed, but it reflects the strength of his grip on the imagination of the fiction-reading public in the English-speaking world during his lifetime.

Since his death, the century has turned and the world he wrote about has largely vanished. The Cold War is over; spies in raincoats no longer kill time in the lobbies of Intercontinental hotels; Vietnam is just the glitziest corner of the global capitalist marketplace. The 'dangerous edge of things' he celebrated, and revelled in, is to be found elsewhere.

'Greeneland', too, has been redeveloped. Brighton, merged with Hove, has a conference centre and a marina. Publishing, which Greene knew well, has changed, too. When writers die, they usually suffer a temporary eclipse, particularly if they have been internationally famous. His paradoxical and aphoristic mind continues to exert its fascination.

One of last year's biggest films was Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair. A book about his long, little-known relationship with Catherine Walston and a memoir about his holidays on Capri were widely reviewed. Travels With My Aunt and The Comedians have been reissued as Modern Classics. There's a Graham Greene Birthplace Trust in Berkhamsted, where he grew up, and it's a safe bet that when the final volume of Norman Sherry's authorised biography comes out later this year, there will be another flurry of Greene mania. This week, BBC Knowledge is screening an anniversary Graham Greene night in tribute.

At this 10-year milestone, it's possible to attempt a sketch of Greene's likely place in English literature. He was, first of all, in film and in fiction, a supreme storyteller. If for nothing else, the author of The Third Man, The Honorary Consul and Brighton Rock deserves to be remembered as a master of sophisticated adventure narratives whose ancestry includes late Victorian writers such as Robert Louis Stevenson, Rider Haggard and Anthony Hope.

It may well be true that he simply provided clever variations on popular genres like the thriller and the detective story, but his constant wrestling with questions of good or evil versus right or wrong elevates his work above the world of pulp fiction. His contemporary, Evelyn Waugh, was keenly aware of the importance of the religious dimension to Greene's work. 'I wouldn't give up writing about God at this stage, if I was you,' he told his friend. 'It would be like PG Wodehouse dropping Jeeves halfway through the Wooster series.'

Waugh put his finger on another vital test of greatness - the ability to create memorable and lasting characters. Pinkie 'the Boy' in Brighton Rock; Scobie in The Heart of the Matter; the 'whisky priest' in The Power and the Glory and Pyle in The Quiet American. Greene scores well here.

More than individuals, he created an unmistakable cast of 'seedy', noirish characters - honest thieves and tender murderers - any one of whom could step without difficulty into almost any scene from his fiction.

Finally, there's Greene's voice. Open any page of a Greene novel and you know at once who the author is. The prose is bare and bleak, as clear, lethal and splintered as a pane of broken glass, and haunting in an unmistakable way.

Who but Greene could have written: 'One never knows when the blow may fall. When I saw Rollo Martins first I made this note on him for my security files: in normal circumstances a cheerful fool. Drinks too much and may cause a little trouble...'

Greene himself was always on the side of causing trouble and making mischief. He, more than many twentieth-century writers of stature, always took pleasure in a practical joke and would have relished a spoof on All Fools' Day.

fields.headline: Hardboiled Boston
fields.standfirst: Peter Guttridge rounds up the latest crime fiction with strong offerings from Dennis Lehane and George P Pelecanos
fields.trailText: Peter Guttridge rounds up the latest crime fiction with strong offerings from Dennis Lehane and George P Pelecanos
fields.body:
Mystic River
Dennis Lehane
Bantam £9.99, pp401
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Right as Rain
George P Pelecanos
Orion £9.99, pp298
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Company of Strangers
Robert Wilson
HarperCollins £12.99, pp464
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Flint
Paul Eddy
Headline £10, pp374
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Dennis Lehane is one of the wonder-boys of hardboiled US crime fiction. In the relatively short time since his Shamus Award-winning debut, A Drink Before the War, Lehane, a 35-year-old from Boston, has established himself as a major noir writer, the one Michael Connelly calls 'the heir apparent'. Like the late George V Higgins, his beat, in his five novels featuring private investigators Patrick Kenzie and Angela Gennaro, is blue-collar Boston.

With Mystic River, his first 'stand alone' novel, he stays in the working-class neighbourhoods to tell a powerful story of childhood friendship and inexorably doomed lives. In the Seventies, three boys are playing in the street when a car draws up. Dave gets into the car, Sean and Jimmy don't. What happens to Dave in the four days he's missing changes him and the nature of their friendship irrevocably. Fast forward 25 years. Sean is a cop, Jimmy is an ex-con running a café and Dave is struggling to fight his demons. Then Jimmy's daughter is savagely murdered.

For a time, I thought I was reading George P Pelecanos, the other hip noir chronicler of blue-collar lives. The same inarticulate but deep male friendships (tough men heavily sentimental in a Bruce Springsteen-lyric kind of way), the same struggle by them to make something good out of blighted lives, and the same sense of inevitable doom.

But not even Pelecanos has gone so far into the nitty-gritty of working-class lives to have a sequence where a character is doing the ironing and ruminating on the best kinds of iron to buy. Lehane does, but then that's of a piece with the rest of this marvellous book. He's content to go slow, even though he's writing a thriller, so that we get to know and really care about all his main characters. The result is enormously impressive: page-turning but thoughtful; moving in its sad inevitability. One of the finest novels I've read in ages.

Pelecanos, meanwhile, has written a western. Right as Rain is set in contemporary Washington and, as with his earlier novels, is plotted around the contemporary problems of drugs and drug-related violence in downtown DC. But it's still a western, complete with a score by Ennio Morricone.

Along with Seventies funk, Morricone and the soundtracks of other western movies is the preferred listening for Derek Strange, an ex-policeman making a quiet living as a skip-tracing private detective. When he's asked to clear up some lingering doubts about the death of an off-duty black cop at the hands of a white police officer in a street incident, he finds himself embroiled in something far more violent.

He's the retired gunslinger required to strap his gun on for one last time. (He already carries a Bowie knife in his kit.) He teams up with Terry Quinn, the quick-on-the-trigger white cop who fired the fatal shot, to uncover the complex reality behind that street incident. Quinn, an aficionado of western fiction, is the disgraced, guilt-ridden sheriff who has lost his badge but is determined to redeem himself.

The drug baron behind it all is called Cherokee. Also involved are a couple of country boys - father and son - who've converted their barn into a saloon with the jukebox playing country and western and a Colt pistol stashed behind the bar. That's the setting for a classic shootout involving those other western staples, the crooked sheriff and the cowardly deputy.

Pelecanos quotes from The Wild Bunch but he's thinking Leone rather than Peckinpah here. The result is a giddy mixture of Pelecanos's righteous fury at the way drugs have ravaged the poorer sections of the city he loves, an unflinching look at racism, and a high-energy thriller. Great.

Robert Wilson's The Company of Strangers is a big, meaty novel of love and deceit, a thriller which spans Europe from the final flickers of the Second World War to the collapse of the Berlin Wall. It's highly ambitious but Wilson, who upped the ante with his writing when he won the Gold Dagger for A Small Death in Lisbon, just about pulls it off.

Young, naïve mathematician Andrea Aspinall comes to Lisbon in 1944 to spy on a man suspected of involvement in making possible Germany's ultimate 'secret weapon'. She meets Karl Voss, military attaché to the German Legation, and they have an urgent, clandestine love affair that overshadows the rest of Andrea's life, whether living under the brutal Portuguese fascist regime or on spying missions to East Berlin.

There's a hint of David Hare's Plenty in Andrea's addiction to spying and, of course, in its world weariness and with one of its themes - the corruption of innocence - The Company of Strangers is redolent of John le Carré. But Wilson's intentions are different to Hare's and le Carré has stamped himself so authoritatively on the spy genre the redolence is hardly surprising.

Besides, Wilson has strengths that are entirely his own. He is brilliant at suggesting the unsaid, evoking the silent interstices between words, whether spoken by lovers or spies. Indeed, he links lovers and spies in their shared deceits and makes a connection, too, between English self-repression and efficacy at spying. He writes telling descriptions and precisely achieved set pieces - Voss's troubles with his own people and the consequent chase through the streets of Lisbon is as taut and tense a stretch of writing as you could wish for. And his sense of place is terrific.

For me, the ending stopped the novel being great. Not that it is unbelievable, because we know that such things happen, more that it is unpersuasive. Even so, with this novel Wilson vaults to the front-rank of thriller writers.

It grieves me to be less than effusive about Paul Eddy's debut thriller, Flint, especially since we share the same publisher, but I think the hype it has received raised expectations it couldn't hope to meet. The former editor of the Sunday Times Insight team received £1.2 million in advances for Flint from American, British and continental publishers plus around half a million for the film option from Columbia Pictures.

Some US critics have gone nuts for it, Time saying: 'Not since Modesty Blaise has spy literature seen a heroine as determined and spunky as Flint.' Its publisher, Headline, is comparing the eponymous Grace Flint to the grittier fictional characters Clarice Starling and Kay Scarpetta, whilst uber agent Ed Victor declared that she is 'the first fictional character he might want to sleep with'. Er, OK. Well, all I can say is - show me the money.

Flint is good - and an impressive accomplishment for a first novel - but it ain't that good. Undercover cop Grace Flint has been badly damaged, emotionally and physically, in a sting operation against a big-time money-launderer that has gone horribly wrong. Plastic surgery has restored her physically but can she cope emotionally with going back undercover, especially when the operation she's involved in brings her back in conflict with the man who almost destroyed her?

Eddy knows how to write page-turning, tense prose and whips through big setpiece scenes with gusto. Flint, although something of a composite, is an intriguing character I'd like to read more about (and presumably will). Eddy is good on detail of police and FBI procedures and tells a good story. So I recommend it, but don't expect too much.

 Peter Guttridge's Foiled Again was published last week by Headline, £17.99.

fields.headline: Has Asterix done Roman?
fields.standfirst: Asterix the Gaul is back after five years, but has it been worth the wait? Albert Uderzo attempts to breathe life into the old hero, while Roger Sabin examines the history of the comic
fields.trailText: Asterix the Gaul is back after five years, but has it been worth the wait? Albert Uderzo attempts to breathe life into the old hero, while Roger Sabin examines the history of the comic
fields.body:
Asterix and the Actress
Albert Uderzo
Orion £9.99, pp48

Comics, Comix & Graphic Novels
Roger Sabin
Phaidon £19.95, pp240
Buy it at a discount at BOL

How old is Asterix the Gaul? He has looked exactly the same since 1959 - and how old was he then? Old enough to have a moustache, strong enough to fight an army of Romans, clever enough to outsmart the pirates every time. He is small, it's true, but how about Obelix? Is he an overgrown child, an idiot savant? Or is he the same age as Gérard Depardieu, who played him in the movie? Asterix and Obelix have already survived one of their creators, the writer René Goscinny, and their other 'parent', illustrator Albert Uderzo, is now 73. Yet, like Dorian Gray, they never grow old and, like Peter Pan, they never grow up.

Goscinny died in 1977, just after completing Asterix in Belgium, a project the French might say would send anyone to his doom. Since then, Uderzo has announced on many occasions that Asterix will be no more. Behind the scenes, he has been involved in a law suit against the publishers over the rights to the backlist; he lost in 1994. And yet, every five years or so, Asterix undergoes a short-lived resurrection. Asterix and the Actress, the much-awaited new volume, is the first since 1996. The accompanying hype has been enormous: 300 million copies will be printed worldwide and all the old Asterix episodes are being reissued.

The pleasure of seeing these characters back again is immediate, and yet there's something strangely sad about the experience. They look the same, but they're not the same. The gags are hollow, their friends' names aren't clever; none of the new characters has the charm of, say, the little boy in Asterix in Spain or the hopeless architect in Asterix and Cleopatra. In an effort to maintain continuity with the classics, two characters from old adventures are given cameos - Tremensdelirius from Asterix and Caesar's Gift and Panacea from Asterix and the Legionary. But the effect is like meeting an old friend and finding they've lost their memory. Goscinny is sorely missed.

The story is fairly simple. It's Asterix's and Obelix's birthday - they were born on the same day an unknowable number of years ago. Their mothers come to pester them about marriage and their fathers send them presents that turn out to be the valuable belongings of a Roman consul, who needs them before he can stage his coup against Julius Caesar. The fathers never suspected the goods were stolen, but they are put in prison by the Romans, who then think of a cunning plan to get the sword and helmet back. They hire an actress, Latraviata, to pose as Panacea, a woman all the Gauls love. She plans to seduce Asterix and Obelix into returning the objects, but the real Panacea looms on the horizon and all hell breaks loose.

The plot allows Uderzo to produce numerous sets of doubles: the two fathers are grey-haired versions of their sons and the mothers are dressed in almost identical outfits. Panacea also comes face to face with her clone. It's as if, in the absence of a wordsmith, all Uderzo can do is draw more and more of the same, filling the frames with doppelgängers until the pictures descend into endlessly self-reproducing chaos. There is a manic, hall-of-mirrors quality about it and if you were in the business of over-interpretation, you might say Uderzo was compensating for the loss of his own double, Goscinny.

When Uderzo and Goscinny met in 1951, the latter had just come back from America, where he had been working with Harvey Kurtzman, who went on to found Mad comics. Goscinny's return was aptly timed. As Roger Sabin writes in Comics, Comix & Graphic Novels, it had recently been decided that France needed more patriotic cartoon heroes. American comics had been syndicated in Europe in the 1930s, and the Marvel superheroes had been brought over by GIs a decade later. But in 1949 the French government passed a law effectively banning US comics in order to encourage home-grown talent. Ten years later, the world's most famous Gaul was born.

Sabin's book is a wonderful reference work. It is full of glossy illustrations and gives a detailed account of comic art from its origins in seventeenth-century broadsheets, through the part played by 'X-rated' 'comix' in 1960s and 1970s counterculture, to its more recent renaissance in the form of graphic novels.

Sabin is very good at bringing out the ways in which comics have reflected the idiosyncrasies of various eras. For example, the first proper comic, a nineteenth-century publication called Ally Sloper's Half-Holiday, was sold at railway stations and, with a very Victorian sense of the macabre, advertised free life insurance to anyone who died in a rail crash and was found holding a copy. The publishers claimed to have paid up three times by 1892. In 1950s America, comics were burned in the streets after a book by a psychiatrist argued they encouraged juvenile delinquency. There were hearings in the Senate and in 1955 a 'Comics Code' was passed, which specifically outlawed any 'challenges to authority'.

Such laws are made to be broken, and perhaps the best chapter of Comics is the one that gives an account of Robert Crumb's seminal work of the 1960s. In 1968, Crumb became a hero in France, where he was thought of as an exemplary radical. He has now made Paris his permanent home.

Asterix, of course, was never meant to cover the same ground. And, yet, he did not escape political interpretation. His creators often complained that at every election parties of both Left and Right asked if they could use Asterix as their symbol. Eventually, Goscinny and Uderzo got their own back by parodying a presidential election in Caesar's Gift. Certainly, if any party did have Asterix on its side, it would be at an enormous advantage. Asterix is arguably the most well-known comic-strip character in the world, a fact which dawned on Goscinny some years before he died. He was on holiday and some strangers passed him in the street. As they walked by, he saw them tapping their heads and saying: 'These Romans are crazy!'

There is a manic, hall-of-mirrors quality about it and if you were in the business of over-interpretation, you might say Uderzo was compensating for the loss of his own double, Goscinny. When Uderzo and Goscinny met in 1951, the latter had just come back from America, where he had been working with Harvey Kurtzman, who went on to found Mad comics. Goscinny's return was aptly timed. As Roger Sabin writes in Comics, Comix & Graphic Novels, it had recently been decided that France needed more patriotic cartoon heroes. American comics had been syndicated in Europe in the 1930s, and the Marvel superheroes had been brought over by GIs a decade later. But in 1949 the French government passed a law effectively banning US comics in order to encourage home-grown talent. Ten years later, the world's most famous Gaul was born. Sabin's book is a wonderful reference work. It is full of glossy illustrations and gives a detailed account of comic art from its origins in seventeenth-century broadsheets, through the part played by 'X-rated' 'comix' in 1960s and 1970s counterculture, to its more recent renaissance in the form of graphic novels. Sabin is very good at bringing out the ways in which comics have reflected the idiosyncrasies of various eras. For example, the first proper comic, a nineteenth-century publication called Ally Sloper's Half-Holiday, was sold at railway stations and, with a very Victorian sense of the macabre, advertised free life insurance to anyone who died in a rail crash and was found holding a copy. The publishers claimed to have paid up three times by 1892. In 1950s America, comics were burned in the streets after a book by a psychiatrist argued they encouraged juvenile delinquency. There were hearings in the Senate and in 1955 a 'Comics Code' was passed, which specifically outlawed any 'challenges to authority'. Such laws are made to be broken, and perhaps the best chapter of Comics is the one that gives an account of Robert Crumb's seminal work of the 1960s. In 1968, Crumb became a hero in France, where he was thought of as an exemplary radical. He has now made Paris his permanent home. Asterix, of course, was never meant to cover the same ground. And, yet, he did not escape political interpretation. His creators often complained that at every election parties of both Left and Right asked if they could use Asterix as their symbol. Eventually, Goscinny and Uderzo got their own back by parodying a presidential election in Caesar's Gift. Certainly, if any party did have Asterix on its side, it would be at an enormous advantage. Asterix is arguably the most well-known comic-strip character in the world, a fact which dawned on Goscinny some years before he died. He was on holiday and some strangers passed him in the street. As they walked by, he saw them tapping their heads and saying: 'These Romans are crazy!'

webTitle: Observer review: The Bonesetter's Daughter and Five Quarters of the Orange

fields.headline: I ink, therefore I am...
fields.standfirst: Amy Tan dabbles in calligraphy while Joanne Harris delights in crêpes
fields.trailText: Amy Tan dabbles in calligraphy while Joanne Harris delights in crêpes
fields.body:
The Bonesetter's Daughter
Amy Tan
Falmingo £16.99, pp307
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Five Quarters of the Orange
Joanne Harris
Doubleday £12.99, pp431
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Amy Tan returns to the familiar territory of history, identity and cultural and familial relationships that she made her own in the phenomenally successful The Joy Luck Club and The Kitchen God's Wife. But The Bonesetter's Daughter is prefaced with a dedication that suggests more than the usual sprinkling of autobiography; like her protagonist, Ruth Young, Tan also discovered the real name of her mother and grandmother late in life and her grandmother's family name becomes that of Ruth's own grandmother.

Daughter of a Chinese mother, LuLing, and a dead American father, Ruth finds herself at 46 unsure of her direction and desires, frustrated by her inability to be intimate with the people in her life: 'Why did she feel she didn't belong to anyone? Did she unconsciously choose to love people who kept their distance? Was she like her mother, destined to be unhappy?'

Yet Ruth is blind to the extent of her mother's legacy until LuLing's incipient dementia sends her scurrying back to her own past. At first, Ruth attributes her mother's startling assertions to her illness, until LuLing chooses a family reunion to announce that neither her sister nor her mother are who they claim to be. The ferocity of her mother's conviction causes Ruth to return to the pages of Chinese calligraphy her mother had shyly given her months earlier, an account of her life beginning: 'These are the things I know are true.'

The novel's second section takes up the translation of LuLing's manuscript with the effect of stepping into a painting, back to the seemingly ancient Chinese village of Immortal Heart where LuLing spent her girlhood with her family of inkmakers and calligraphers.

One of Tan's recurring motifs is self-expression or its absence, though her symbolism can sometimes appear clanking. Ruth, who earns a living by ghostwriting new-age self-help books, suffers from an annual psychosomatic laryngitis and retreats into a literal silence that mirrors her permanent emotional state; LuLing, who has stalwartly refused to learn English and speaks the kind of pidgin that might earn a non-Chinese author accusations of crude racial stereotyping, reveals a sudden lyrical eloquence in her written account; LuLing's nursemaid, Precious Auntie, left with no voice after the suicide attempt that destroyed her face, is superlatively gifted in calligraphy and drawing. Truth and love are handed on via letters and stories, while conversations between mothers and daughters usually end in fury and misunderstanding. In time-honoured fashion, the wisest fortune-tellers are blind.

Yet Tan's portrait of a blighted family reconciled through an understanding of shared roots is perceptive and moving, and achieved with a light touch in spite of the weight of accumulated tragedy that haunts the three generations of women at its centre. Its emphatic moral is that to be free of the past, you first have to revisit and understand it.

Like Tan, Joanne Harris has learned the value of returning to plunder familiar settings and themes after the triumph of her film-adapted Chocolat, though in Five Quarters of the Orange she has abandoned Lasquenet, the fictional French village of her last two novels, for Les Laveuses, an equally beady-eyed community in the Loire Valley. Her narrator, Framboise Dartigen, returns to the village of her childhood in her sixties to rebuild her mother's farm, left derelict after a dark and unexplained incident during the war. Framboise hides her identity behind her married name, and overcomes the villagers' suspicions over her interest in the old farm when she opens a successful crêperie; gradually her narrative unfurls the events of her childhood that drove her family from their home.

Just as she did in Chocolat, Harris indulges her love of rich and mouth-watering descriptive passages, appealing to the senses with seductively foreign names, and evoking the textures and smells of food. These descriptions are suffused with a child's wide-eyed wonder that lends the story a magical quality, almost like a folk tale or a children's story. Even having the Occupation as a backdrop, Harris does not approach large themes in the way that Tan does; instead, she sets out to tell a story that proves, like her previous books, to be thoroughly enjoyable, if undemanding.

webTitle: Observer review: Border Crossing by Pat Barker

fields.headline: The evil that lurks in all of us
fields.standfirst: Pat Barker follows a good man as he slides into complicity with evil in Border Crossing
fields.trailText: Pat Barker follows a good man as he slides into complicity with evil in Border Crossing
fields.body:
Border Crossing
Pat Barker
Viking £16.99, pp224
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Despite its suggestive title, Pat Barker's latest novel does not revisit the warscapes of her Regeneration trilogy. Instead, it explores the equally troubled emotional battlefields of Danny Miller, who at the age of 10 was convicted of a chillingly heartless murder. Now 23, he is released from prison, though not from his sense of betrayal by child psychologist Tom Seymour, whose testimony at Danny's trial, that the boy understood the finality of death, ensured his imprisonment.

The story plunges straight in, literally, as Tom rescues a man from the sewage-choked Tyne only to discover that, by coincidence, the suicidal man is Danny. His marriage is disintegrating due to the lack of children, and now in walks one from the past.

Tom, who is writing a book on the moral sense of juvenile delinquents, agrees to see Danny to help them both come to terms with the past. Replacing departing wife Lauren, who recedes with the marriage to the periphery of Tom's life, the charming, manipulative Danny plays cat-and-mouse as they grapple with the legacy of his abusive childhood. The central relationship between Tom and Danny proves compelling. Increasingly aware that Danny's reappearance is no coincidence, Tom reconstructs what he can of Danny's experiences through interviews with him and his acquaintances, including Martha, the probation officer who looks after Danny and, increasingly, Tom.

As always in Barker's novels, all time is eternally present, and the aim is - 'pace Eliot' - to glimpse the primitive terror that, in this case, connects a vulnerable child with a horrific act. The parallels with the imminent release of Jamie Bulger's killers lend the story an urgent crackle that helps transcend the thriller conventions from which it draws its form.

Time proves unforgiving to all. Lauren battles against her body clock in her desire for children, while their marriage goes as limp as Tom, faced with the battery of thermometers and calendars. Both men battle against the discovery by the media of Danny's new identity, culminating in a climax that dramatically tests the reasons for his reappearance in Tom's life, and forces the psychologist once more to determine his fate. All that leaves is for Tom's emotional life to resolve itself, though a chance meeting years later scratches the surface of memory, a palimpsest from which the elderly victim's image can never be expunged.

Early on, Danny passes on to Tom the prison chaplain's line that coincidence was the crack in human affairs that lets God or the Devil in. Barker's intent is to show how small that crevice can be. That a crossed border remains a border, just viewed from a different perspective, lies at the heart of this hauntingly convincing novel that also questions redemption and the legitimacy of new beginnings. Few English writers now can match Barker's narrative poise, and she remains almost peerless in her articulation of the unspoken.

Barker's concern is more with how close we stand to evil, and the futility of prescriptive determinism, something Tom realises as he remembers how close he came, as a boy, to precipitating a child's death. Set in a moral landscape that is as bleak as the North East location, by the climax the windswept urban desolation is starting to regenerate. Perhaps these gusts carry the answer to the uncompromising inquiry of this splendidly awkward, compassionate novel.

fields.headline: Alan's 10 years of lonely torment
fields.standfirst:
Plight of elderly man locked in unheated attic and ignored by authorities exposes failure in care laws

Special report: abuse in our care homes
fields.trailText: Plight of elderly man locked in unheated attic and ignored by authorities exposes failure in care laws
fields.body:
If Alan could have shouted for help, there were plenty of people nearby who would have heeded his call: the police kept an eye on the quiet town of Kettering from their HQ opposite his bedroom window, the magistrates' court was next door and the church on the corner offered counselling and home visits to anyone who asked.

But Alan, who has a mental age of 18 months, could not tell anyone about his misery or the pain he was in. For 10 years he was locked in an unheated attic room at the London Road residential care home, left curled up on a plastic-covered chair in a small, ripped T-shirt, lying in his own urine and faeces.

When he was found during a routine annual inspection by Northamptonshire council in February 1999, one officer said she had never seen even an animal kept in such an appalling state. Another said his condition was an affront to human dignity.

Alan, dumped by his own county of Essex in the Northamptonshire home in 1989, was an 'out-of-county placement' - one of Britain's elderly abandoned, forced into isolation and vulnerable to abuse.

This was not an isolated case. Hundreds of highly vulnerable people are moved hundreds of miles without their informed consent to an alien neighbourhood where friends, family and carers find it hard to visit. These people are forced to rely on social workers from their home county travelling across the country frequently enough to spot any abuse before it starts.

But a total lack of legislation dictating the duty of care owed to out-of-county placements by their home authority means that these people are all too often failed both by their social workers and their host county.

Despite a recent White Paper forcing through a number of positive changes in the standard of care all residents can expect, the Department of Health admits the care owed to out-of-county placements is still obscured by 'very muddy water'. 'The home county has responsibility to keep an eye on adults in foreign care homes,' said a spokeswoman. 'But in practice, if someone moves far away, it's not very practical to send a social worker all the way across the country to check on them.'

Essex has about 240 people living in residential care homes as far away as Aberdeen, Cornwall and North Wales.

'We already know that abuse in residential care homes is far more common than most people like to admit,' said Ginny Jenkin, director of the campaigning organisation Action on Elder Abuse. 'But when vulnerable people, especially those who may have difficulty expressing themselves, are moved away from anyone who has direct responsibility for them, you increase the possibility of abuse enormously.' Alan had not received a single visit or inquiry from Essex since his care package was agreed with the Northamptonshire home 10 years ago. Routine and announced annual inspections by Northamptonshire council into the Kettering home concentrated on the home's administration record rather than on the quality of life of the residents and failed to discover Alan.

The Registered Home Tribunal established after Alan's discovery also found that the owner of the home, Edwin Freeman, had appropriated £19,000 of residents' money, had treated other residents in unacceptable ways and falsified medical records.

In addition, they reported that Freeman's wife, Sara, should never have been registered to run the home and was 'clearly unfit' to continue as a registered person.

'The conditions in which this resident was kept were an affront to human dignity,' the tribunal reported in January. 'For years, local authorities who should have been in a position to protect his human rights had ignored him and appear to have failed in their duty of care.

'He was subjected to degrading treatment; he was deprived of his liberty; his dignity was ignored, his right to property was compromised because of the way his finances were dealt with. He was in pain with a dental abscess and no effective action was taken to treat him.' The Freemans and their daughter, Charlotte Goodwin, manager at the home, were deregistered.

Both Northamptonshire and Essex authorities have set up an independent inquiry into the case. Alan has now moved into a small residential home in Essex with three other inmates. His condition, which Freeman claimed was hopeless, has improved considerably under intense training.

amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Shayler is a model spy for MI5 play

fields.headline: Shayler is a model spy for MI5 play
fields.trailText: Henry V, Macbeth and Hamlet, the great Shakespearean protagonists who strut before audiences at     Stratford-upon-Avon, are to be joined tomorrow by a new name, the former MI5 renegade, David Shayler.
fields.body:
Henry V, Macbeth and Hamlet, the great Shakespearean protagonists who strut before audiences at Stratford-upon-Avon, are to be joined tomorrow by a new name, the former MI5 renegade, David Shayler.

A new play by Paul Greengrass, the screenwriter responsible for ITV's upcoming film about Bloody Sunday and for the award-winning television dramatisation of The Murder of Stephen Lawrence , is to be premiered tomorrow night by the Royal Shakespeare Company.

Epitaph for the Official Secrets Act will also feature Shayler's girlfriend, Annie Machon, and the MI5's first woman director, Stella Rimington. 'It is a play about the year that MI5 first decided to recruit a new sort of agent,' explained Simon Reade, the RSC's dramaturge, referring to 1991, when the secret service briefly turned away from their established Oxbridge source of graduates and advertised for applicants from the wider population.

'The play starts with a reading of the advertisement that newspapers ran at the time,' said Reade, who developed the piece with Greengrass for its six-night run. 'The ad showed an empty chair under the words "Godot isn't coming".' The play then deals with some of the changes that followed as Rimington took control of an organisation that was fighting to redefine itself.

Machon and Shayler, both from the graduate intake that was then new, are identified only by their first names.

News of their theatrical debut came as a shock to Shayler and Machon, who are in London awaiting Shayler's trial on charges of breaching the Official Secrets Act. Machon said: 'It is rather alarming to find that we are both going to played by actors.'

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: New Caxton presses for a text revolution

fields.headline: New Caxton presses for a text revolution
fields.standfirst:
Radio, television, radar, computers...now Britain can announce another innovation, this time in the world of e-science,
   with plans for the world's first 'cybrary', or cyber-library.
fields.trailText:
Radio, television, radar, computers...now Britain can announce another innovation, this time in the world of e-science,
   with plans for the world's first 'cybrary', or cyber-library.
fields.body:
Radio, television, radar, computers...now Britain can announce another innovation, this time in the world of e-science, with plans for the world's first 'cybrary', or cyber-library. In a move that has won grudging praise from the US internet community - hitherto seen as the powerhouse for new e-thinking - a London dotcom entrepreneur has come up with the first 'big idea' for more than three years: a plan to store, on paper, all the books available on the net.

Research has shown that many people are put off reading literature on the net because of the bother of scrolling electronically through thousands of different screens. 'What I want to do instead,' says 21-year-old Lee Peters - who prefers to be known as CAX100 (Cax-'ton', after the father of modern printing) - 'is to introduce what I call the tactile dynamic.

'Thousands of people - millions, even - will, if this works out, be able to go to a public building and handle the texts, creating for the first time a real physical interface. We're going to download, at the start, the first 1,000 most "classic" texts - Shakespeare, I suppose, Kafka, Bridget Jones , Douglas Copeland, that kind of thing - and print them all out, making sure there's a break after every, say, 800 words or so, so they come out in "pages".

'We're trying to copyright a programme that will even number them as we go! Then we'll stick them inside some kind of binding, or at least some kind of handy plastic envelope, and leave them out on shelves for people to come along and borrow as and when they like.

'The beauty is that, now, people will be able to read this stuff anywhere - in the bath, in the bed, on the tube. Gone are the days when if you wanted to read something you had to go through the laborious business of logging on and searching and clicking and swapping screens and changing fonts and hoping your server doesn't go down. If this takes off, all that stuff will seem frankly prehistoric. Instead, you'll have people wandering around cities with the actual downloaded texts in their hands !

'Already we've had huge interest and big offers of backing. But it's not about the money, it's about literature. Although, eventually, the plan is to actually sell the bound downloads; we could have a chain of bound-download shops across the country!'

The main problem he faces is storage space. 'If we get enough stuff downloaded, that's going to be one mother of a lot of paper. We need big rooms, big halls.' He has been in discussion with councils in London, and there have been encouraging signs from Barnetstone and Flatford, both of which have, along with most other councils, carried out extensive public-library closure programmes.

'I can't comment officially,' said a spokesman for Flatford, 'but a few members are rather taken by the idea. fields.headline: Widow's flight into the past
fields.standfirst: The widow of a war pilot whose remains have been found in France tells Paul Harris of her life and loss
fields.trailText: The widow of a war pilot whose remains have been found in France tells Paul Harris of her life and loss
fields.body:
For sixty years Deborah Rogers got on with her life as a war widow. She raised her daughter on a tight budget and there was no time to look back at what might have been had her pilot husband not been killed on a mission over France.

Last week, the past flickered back into her life when she finally learnt that Flight Lieutenant Bruce Arthur Rogers - one of the glorious 'Few' who took to the skies in the war against Germany - was to be laid to rest six decades after he was killed in a dogfight in 1941.

Sitting in her Oxford flat last week, Deborah Rogers looks younger than her 85 years. But although her photo album is full of pictures of the handsome Flt Lt Rogers, and she still wears her wedding ring, she insists there is no room for mawkishness about their brief life together. 'It happened to so many thousands of people at that time,' she said. 'I don't think we were unusual at all.' However, her story does sound incredible to those who have grown up in the settled world of post-war Britain, harking back to a time when the future was uncertain, bombs fell upon London and the shadow of war hung over everything. It illustrates the high cost paid by ordinary people and the terrible hardships they endured.

Bruce Rogers was typical of the Few, the fliers whom Winston Churchill credited with saving Europe through their courage. The average life expectancy for a pilot in the Battle of Britain was just three weeks - Bruce was one of many who paid the ultimate price.

Shortly after the war's end, Deborah paid a visit to his grave in the village of Ambleteuse, not realising that only his dogtags and a few fragments of his body lay there. She spoke to villagers who had seen the crash and described how he had steered his stricken plane away from their houses. 'They said he made a point of bringing the plane down in a patch of waste ground and so avoiding all their houses and people,' she said.

So grateful were the residents that two elderly ladies placed fresh flowers on his grave until the day they died.

Ironically, Bruce Rogers was not even meant to have been on that fatal mission - but he had felt that the flight's leader was too inexperienced and so took the role himself. Rogers was a father-to-be and had already flown a year of missions - yet he was just 23 when he died.

He had met his wife-to-be at a drinks party in Oxford where both were studying French and Spanish. Deborah, the daughter of a Russian émigré, was instantly taken. They were rarely parted thereafter. Deborah's face still lights up when she talks about him. 'He was a very good dancer. But we mainly went to the cinema a lot. It was what people did in those days,' she said.

Outside her windows, Oxford's ancient stone colleges have changed little. But the city is full of bars and trendy restaurants, and young people throng the streets. The Oxford of the 1930s was a very different place. Students had to be in their colleges by 11pm, and had to ask permission to have guests of the opposite sex around for tea.

As graduation approached in 1939, it was clear that war was going to interrupt their lives. Bruce, a keen member of the university flying corps, faced a choice of joining the RAF or pursuing his dream of a diplomatic posting in Russia. He chose the RAF.

They married a year later, on the same weekend the Germans invaded Belgium and the real war began. The couple were to be together as man and wife for exactly one year, one month and one day before he was killed. It was a dangerous time. Once, when driving to an Ipswich airfield, they saw walkers in front of them suddenly dive into a ditch as a German plane flew over, strafing the road with its machine-guns.

'You could almost have reached out and touched it,' Deborah said. 'Afterwards people just got out of the ditch, brushed themselves down and said, "aren't we lucky no one was hurt?" It was just a time when things like that happened.' The couple moved across the country as Bruce flew from different airfields, living in quarters attached to the aerodromes. Friends were made and lost with a terrifying speed. 'To this day I still can't bear to hear the "Last Post" played. It just brings it all back,' Deborah said.

The story of the discovery of Bruce's remains by workmen digging a gas main prompted Deborah to look again at her wartime diaries. She found happy exclamation marks littering the pages when Bruce had an afternoon off or missions were cancelled due to bad weather. 'I would write something like "Today there is fog!" It meant Bruce would be safe,' she said.

Then came that fateful mission: the pilots' wives counted the planes out and counted them back. Three were missing, Bruce's among them. Although it would be months before he was officially declared dead, Deborah was never in any doubt. 'I knew he was gone. All along I had feared something like this would happen. Sometimes if they came down over the sea they had a chance, but not if they came down over land.' She was eight months pregnant at the time of her husband's death, and gave birth to a daughter, Catherine, six weeks later. It was time to get on with life and put the past behind her - until last weekend. 'I was knocked flat,' she said.

Deborah Rogers now plans to visit Bruce's grave again when the recently discovered remains are buried there.

However, what is important are her memories. 'He was a super chap, great fun. But it was 60 years ago now, practically a whole lifetime, and back then we were all so young.'

webTitle: Mystery surrounds death of man after Barrymore party

fields.headline: Mystery surrounds death of man after Barrymore party
fields.trailText: The troubled life of entertainer Michael Barrymore was at the centre of a new mystery last night after police announced a man had died following a party at the star's Essex home.
fields.byline: Tony Thompson and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
The troubled life of entertainer Michael Barrymore was at the centre of a new mystery last night after police announced a man had died following a party at the star's Essex home.

The man, who has not yet been identified, was found unconscious in a swimming pool at the rear of Barrymore's mansion in Roydon, near Harlow, just before 6am yesterday. The body, which was dressed only in a pair of boxer shorts, had no visible injuries and police are keeping an open mind about whether the death is suspicious.

Hypothermia and drowning are two of the possibilities being examined.

A spokesman for the entertainer said: 'Mr Barrymore is very upset over this tragic accident and his feelings go out to the young man's family.'

The man apparently arrived at the house at about 2.30am with friends. He had been at the Millennium Club in Harlow, a warehouse-type venue which plays garage and house music. After being found in the pool he was taken to the Princess Alexandra Hospital in Harlow but died at 8.32am.

According to one guest, the man announced in the early hours that he wanted to go for a swim. He was found floating in the pool a short time later. It was not known why the party was being held or whether the young man was an invited guest.

Barrymore lives in a large detached house on an exclusive development at the end of a quiet road. Yesterday, as the police continued their investigations, the large iron gates in front of the house were closed.

Several neighbours said they knew Barrymore and spoke to him when they saw him but none heard any noise to indicate the tragedy.

One woman, who also did not want to be named, said: 'There were no comings and goings as far as I was aware.'

The incident took place at the home Barrymore, 47, shared with his wife of 20 years, Cheryl, with whom he split in 1995 after 'coming out' as gay in a late-night radio interview.

Barrymore is one of Britain's most popular TV performers with shows including Strike It Lucky. Widely regarded as a workaholic, he is also thought to be one of the best paid TV comics, with a personal fortune running into millions.

The comic has admitted to battling alcoholism for years. Last year he said doctors had given him just months to live if he didn't stop drinking. Although he has had periods of sobriety, he has suffered regular relapses.

Two weeks ago he embarrassed a children's charity after appearing drunk on stage at a fundraising event at the Hilton Hotel, Park Lane, London.

Also this month it emerged that Barrymore had split with long-term boyfriend Shaun Davis, 24.

webTitle: Gucci lures Stella McCartney in fashion house coup

fields.headline: Gucci lures Stella McCartney in fashion house coup
fields.trailText: Stella McCartney, Sir Paul's designer daughter, is to trade in the famous name and fashion label that launched her reputation to create her own brand of clothes under the leather-lined auspices of Gucci.
fields.body:
Stella McCartney, Sir Paul's designer daughter, is to trade in the famous name and fashion label that launched her reputation to create her own brand of clothes under the leather-lined auspices of Gucci.

It is the ultimate seal of approval for the 30-year-old who, despite becoming Chloe's chief designer just two years after leaving college in 1995 and quadrupling their profits in as many years, has never quite shaken off accusations that she has got by with more than a little help from her friends.

According to the news magazine Time, McCartney is the latest jewel in Gucci's crown: in the past 18 months the group has set out to gather together the freshest and most fashionable designers in the industry, transforming itself into the third largest and one of the youngest luxury goods group in the world.

Her west London style of vintage-feminine mixed with sexy, sharp tailoring has already won McCartney the adulation of stars including Madonna, Nicole Kidman and Victoria Beckham.

Chloe tried to offset Gucci's lure by offering McCartney a £100,000-a-year deal over five years to stay with them, but well-placed sources on the fashion circuit maintain that a triumphant announcement by Gucci is now imminent. 'There's no question that it's going to happen,' said one. 'It's a great move for McCartney and we're expecting an announcement any day now. It could be as early as Monday.' Four years after taking the call from Chloe, McCartney is ready to branch out again, this time from a prime location on the Rue du Faubourg St Honoré currently owned by Pierre Cardin, an acquisition that scotches rumours she was poised to take over Gucci womanswear. Sources speculate that move fell through because of McCartney's refusal to work with either leather or fur, both materials which make up the bulk of Gucci's own-brand sales.

webTitle: Artists join the battle to beat midges

fields.headline: Artists join the battle to beat midges
fields.trailText: Midges may be small, but for the tourist industry in Scotland they are potentially lethal. In recent years the biting insects that plague the Highlands in the summer months have been unsuccessfully attacked from almost every angle. Now artists are to have their own run at the problem.
fields.body:
Midges may be small, but for the tourist industry in Scotland they are potentially lethal. In recent years the biting insects that plague the Highlands in the summer months have been unsuccessfully attacked from almost every angle. Now artists are to have their own run at the problem.

Tomorrow a £50,000 grant goes to the photographer Alison Hayes to fund Midge Bait, a project which is aimed at unravelling the mysteries of Culicoides impunctatus, or the Highland midge. The hefty grant, made by The Wellcome Trust, is one of several awards to be handed out as part of Sci-art, a collaborative programme that brings scientists and artists together.

Hayes and the film-maker David Mackenzie will be capturing the movements of the midge as it attacks for the first time and handing on the images to Dr Alison Blackwell, of the Centre for Tropical Veterinary Medicine at the University of Edinburgh.

'I have taken pictures of starlings swarming,' said Hayes, 'but my interest in midges started when I was about 14 on a family holiday in the Highlands.

'It was a wonderfully hot day, but as dusk fell we could not go out at all because of the insects. We had the window open just a little for air and they came in.'

Hayes and Mackenzie will be kitted out in layers of protective clothing for the project and are looking for volunteers to use as bait for the midges.

'We are thinking of wearing breathing apparatus too, because the midges are attracted by the carbon dioxide that animals breathe out,' said Hayes.

Initial research into the insects in the 1950s has been revived in recent years as the midges have affected tourism. Research carried out by Blackwell has revealed that 80 per cent of foreign tourists say they will not return to the area because of the bites they suffered.

The photographs will focus on the formation of attack. 'People have spoken of funnels and tried to draw them,' said Hayes, 'but no one has got a photograph. This pattern is formed by the males at the beginning of June and then the females fly into these swarms to mate. After this we think the females fly off looking for a blood meal.'

The project will cover scenic areas on Skye and Mull and will also examine a number of new solutions, including combinations of repellents and attractants.

'The lifecycle can be manipulated and there are repellents, of course,' said Blackwell, 'but most of these are chemically based and are becoming less and less popular. You are never going to be able to get rid of the Highland midge, and you wouldn't want to, but we need to know if they work on their own, or whether it is a communal attack.'

The team will also be testing an American prototype Midge Magnet, which attracts the insects with a cloud of carbon dioxide and then hoovers them up.

fields.headline: U-turn in police killing inquiry
fields.trailText: Two policemen could face murder charges after a U-turn by the Crown Prosecution Service over the shooting of an unarmed man just yards from his home.
fields.body:
Two policemen could face murder charges after a U-turn by the Crown Prosecution Service over the shooting of an unarmed man just yards from his home.

In a letter to the solicitors of Irene Stanley, whose husband, Henry, was shot dead by officers as he walked home from a pub in Hackney, east London, on the night of 22 September 1999, the CPS admit that they might have been wrong by refusing to hold an internal review into the killing.

'The CPS will conduct a further review of all the evidence and material submitted to it concerning the death of the late Mr Henry Stanley,' wrote Christopher Walker for the Treasury Solicitor. 'The CPS will consider whether there is a realistic prospect of securing a conviction in respect of any criminal offence.'

Henry, a 46-year-old father-of-three, was shot through the head and the hand. The policemen claimed Stanley was an Irish terrorist concealing a sawn-off shotgun in a shopping bag. Stanley, an unemployed Glaswegian decorator, never got a chance to show them the Queen Anne table leg he was carrying.

'Henry was my life for 30 years,' said Irene Stanley. 'When he was killed, I stopped functioning as a human being and started fighting to win justice.'

An internal police investigation was set up by the Police Complaints Commission to discover not only why the killing took place but why his family were not told of his death for more than 14 hours.

But when the PCA presented their evidence to the CPS last month, the CPS decided there was insufficient evidence to proceed and the case was dropped.

Stanley welcomed the change in the CPS's position. 'Suddenly it seemed there might possibly be hope.'
