An internal police investigation was set up by the Police Complaints Commission to discover not only why the killing took place but why his family were not told of his death for more than 14 hours. But when the PCA presented their evidence to the CPS last month, the CPS decided there was insufficient evidence to proceed and the case was dropped. Stanley welcomed the change in the CPS's position. 'Suddenly it seemed there might possibly be hope.'

webTitle: Tragic tycoon seeks solace with Aids victims

fields.headline: Tragic tycoon seeks solace with Aids victims
fields.standfirst: After a family suicide, Britain's second richest woman is joining a hospital ship in West Africa
fields.trailText: She is the nurse who became Britain's richest businesswoman, turning a £25,000 redundancy payment into a £1 billion international empire.
fields.body:
She is the nurse who became Britain's richest businesswoman, turning a £25,000 redundancy payment into a £1 billion international empire.

When she left her council house and moved into a £3 million castle, Stagecoach boss Ann Gloag had it all. But two years ago her life was devastated when her 28-year-old son, Jonathan, hanged himself in a forest near her home. Bewildered and distraught, Gloag disappeared from public life and quit the company she founded.

Now she is going back to her roots. She is swapping her Highland estate for a hospital in one of the world's poorest countries where she will treat Aids and cancer patients.

Ann Gloag, 58, arrived yesterday in Benin to start working for Mercy Ships, a charity that provides ship-based hospitals offering free medical and dental care to some of the world's poorest people. She decided to take the unpaid job on the 12,000-tonne SS Anastasis, moored off Cotonou, after a visit to West Africa last year.

Friends say she wants to 'start a new chapter' after 20 gruelling years which made her Britain's second-richest woman - only the Queen is wealthier - but which have cost her her marriage and, some say, the life of her son.

'She is still deeply traumatised by Jonathan's death, but getting back to work is her way of getting on with life,' one said. 'It is her way, perhaps, of acknowledging what has happened and of starting again and showing that some benefit can come out of it all.'

As she prepared to treat her first patient since she quit her job as a theatre nurse in Bridge of Earn hospital, near Perth, 20 years ago, Gloag said: 'I've been very fortunate in many ways. I enjoyed my years as a nurse. I enjoyed my years in business. Maybe if I can do something for these charities for a few years, it wouldn't be a bad idea.'

She has donated £4m of her fortune to buy a new hospital ship, the African Mercy, moored at Newcastle upon Tyne. She wants to raise £15m to refit and equip the ship. 'For me it's quite a big challenge to buy this ship and see the conversion through. I think I'll get a real buzz the day they launch it.'

It is more than a quarter of a century since Gloag began her nursing career at Glasgow's Royal Hospital for Sick Children. Her qualifications are now out of date, so she will spend this week carrying out basic duties, such as sterilising equipment or feeding undernourished babies so they are strong enough for surgery.

Conditions on the boat could not be more different from life in 24-bedroom Beaufort Castle, the baronial seat of the Clan Fraser, which Gloag bought 10 years ago. Temperatures can reach 35C, with near 100 per cent humidity. Food and water on board are strictly rationed.

During the day Gloag will treat Aids and cancer victims. Chronic eye infections, cataracts and cleft lips and palates are common. The ship has four operating theatres and beds for 100 patients. At night she will sleep in a bunk in quarters that also hold 400 doctors, nurses and crew. 'I am a terrible sailor, but I should be OK while the boat is moored,' she said.

Her return to the wards is the latest chapter in the remarkable life of a woman born in poverty in Perth. She left Perth High School with no qualifications, but enrolled as a trainee nurse and rose to become a sister. She quit her job in 1980 and used her bus driver father's £25,000 redundancy money to set up Stagecoach with her brother, Brian Souter.

They exploited Tory legislation deregulating the bus industry to undercut rivals. As Stagecoach began expanding rapidly, she let nothing stand in her way - not even her husband. Robin Gloag was on the Stagecoach board when the company was set up, but she and Souter voted him off after repeated clashes. The couple later divorced.

Gloag's ruthlessness earned her a £200m personal fortune which she spent lavishly. She holidayed with Richard Branson on his Caribbean island and drank Bollinger with Rupert Murdoch at his Christmas parties. She bought her yellow Bentley - registration 1Ann - from the Princess Royal.

But the good life came to a tragic end on the night of 18 September 1999 when her son left his Perthshire home, walked a few miles towards his mother's home, tied a rope to a tree and hanged himself. The suicide of a young man with a wife, three sons and the prospect of a vast inheritance all but destroyed Gloag. As she put it on the wreath of white lilies she laid at his funeral: 'From your heartbroken mum, I loved you so much. Till the day dawns and the shadows flee away.'

Afterwards she shunned all publicity. Friends say she was haunted by the thought that she could have prevented his death. 'She knew her son believed he could not live up to her success and she knew he had been badly affected by the divorce,' one said. 'She had all that money at her disposal, and was able to help complete strangers with her charitable instincts, but not Jonathan.

'She is a driven woman. Even when her business tactics were being criticised, she was convinced she had done no wrong. But after Jonathan's death I think she felt - for the first time - as if she might have made a terrible mistake.'

Last year she announced that she had had enough of big business and was quitting as executive director of Stagecoach. She was seen only a few times in public before she announced last week that she was going to Africa.

The Anastasis will remain off the coast of Benin until May. During that time doctors hope to carry out more than 1,000 operations and provide dental treatment for 3,000 people. john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: RAF crisis as hundreds of planes out of action

fields.headline: RAF crisis as hundreds of planes out of action
fields.trailText: The Royal Air Force is facing a serious shortage of frontline aircraft, with hundreds of jets grounded, dozens hit by computer problems and 80 so badly damaged in training they have been written off.
fields.body:
The Royal Air Force is facing a serious shortage of frontline aircraft, with hundreds of jets grounded, dozens hit by computer problems and 80 so badly damaged in training they have been written off.

New official figures from the Ministry of Defence on the state of the RAF's fleet last December reveal that:

 More than a third of the RAF's entire fleet of 747 aircraft is 'unserviceable'.

 Only two out of every five of Britain's fleet of 99 Tornado GR1 fighter bombers are ready for action.

 The RAF's fleet of 82 Tornado GR4 bombers is still dogged by software problems and limited to training duties.

 More than 50 Tornados and 20 Jaguars worth almost £1 billion have been so badly crippled in training exercises they are 'damaged beyond economic repair'.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrats' defence spokesman, who was sent the figures by Defence Minister John Spellar, described the situation as 'worrying'. He said: 'Urgent attention is required if the UK is to continue its current operational requirements and to be able to respond to any new commitments.'

One of the key problems is that the £1bn upgrade of the RAF's Tornado bomber is still facing software problems with its new laser-guidance bomb system. A report in tomorrow's Jane's Defence Weekly claims the problem will be fixed in 'weeks not months'. The RAF is desperate to deploy these planes to help enforce the no-fly zone over southern Iraq.

The shortage of frontline planes adds to the problems the RAF is having retaining and recruiting pilots amid stiff competition from commercial airlines which are offering 'golden hellos' of up to £30,000. Last year the National Audit Office reported that the armed forces were producing 18 per cent fewer pilots than needed.

Spellar denied there was any shortage of aircraft, stating that '82 per cent of aircraft are either serviceable' or could be brought back into service 'very quickly'.

fields.headline: Heroin epidemic grips the valleys
fields.standfirst: After the demise of mining, drugs are killing youths in towns where community spirit is already dead
fields.trailText: After the demise of mining, drugs are killing youths in towns where community spirit is already dead.
fields.body:
The picturesque hills and valleys of Wales, synonymous with male voice choirs, close-knit communities and fanatical rugby supporters, have become home to the fastest-growing drugs epidemic in the UK.

The results of a new study, to be made public this week, show that Wales is caught in the grip of an unprecedented heroin epidemic, with a massive surge in the number of users, seizures and those dying from overdoses. With rising unemployment, youths are using and dealing drugs as a way of getting by. 'Where there is no hope,' the saying goes, 'there's always dope.'

The picture painted in Human Traffic, a bleakly comic movie about five Cardiff friends who live for their drug-fuelled weekends, isn't so far from reality. In the South Wales police area, the number of people prosecuted for trafficking in heroin has risen 63 per cent in the past year. Across the county of Rhondda Cynon Taff, at least 12 addicts overdose each week, according to the latest figures.

In North Wales, drug sales became so blatant that last month the force launched Operation Decade, its biggest-ever crackdown, which led to 30 arrests in a few hours. In Dyfed-Powys, more dealers are arrested per 100 police officers than anywhere else in the country, while in Gwent a three-man gang will be sentenced next week for possession of a kilo of heroin - the force's largest single haul.

Further along the coast in Llanelli, the number of heroin seizures has for the first time overtaken the number of seizures of amphetamine. While cannabis remains the most widely used drug in the area, heroin now accounts for 10 per cent of seizures. Drug- trafficking offences have shot up by 70 per cent in a year.

With law enforcement split between four different forces, each of which uses different methods to compile statistics, accurate figures covering the whole of the country are virtually impossible to come by.

Across Wales it is believed that drug-related deaths are occurring at an average rate of one a week. While crimes such as car theft and burglary are down across the board, they have rocketed in the areas where drug use is highest. An increasing number of addicts, some as young as 13 or 14, are selling their bodies to pay for their habits.

For those living in smaller towns, such as Aberdare, where heroin use has traditionally been frowned on - last year a suspected dealer was firebombed out of his home on the Fernhill estate - the change has been shocking.

One former miner who declined to be named told The Observer: 'When the mines were open, things were very different. There was full employment and everyone was pulling together as one. If one of the young lads did something - broke into a house, stole a car or gave an old lady some cheek - we'd soon find out who did it and give them hell. Now the mines are gone, the sense of community's gone. People only look out for themselves. These days if you've got a job you're virtually a celebrity.'

This week South Wales police will release the results of new toxicology reports that are expected to link a number of recent deaths to the heroin epidemic. 'We need to gauge the size of the problem so we can tackle it most effectively,' says Detective Chief Superintendent Wynn Philips. 'We need education to reduce demand for heroin and look to the community to assist us. The drug is tolerated far more than it used to be.'

South Wales police are also looking to alter a policy they believe could be contributing to the number of deaths. At present, many addicts are reluctant to report overdoses because they know the police will attend the scene.

According to Roger Duncan of the Swansea Drug Project, there are a number of factors behind the sudden rise, including a crackdown on the use of amphetamine which, curiously, led many users to switch to heroin. Users of Ecstasy, which has always been disproportionately popular in Wales, are turning to heroin to help them 'come down' after a night of clubbing.

'In the last quarter we've had 86 people coming to see us with problems linked to heroin use. A couple of years ago, that number would have been just two or three. Five years ago, heroin was almost unobtainable in Swansea. I believe one reason we are getting so many deaths is because there isn't a history of usage in the area. It means a lot of people are very inexperienced and unaware of the dangers of mixing heroin with Valium or alcohol.'

Another factor is that dealers in Bristol and Liverpool have begun targeting Wales. Significant numbers of addicts trying to escape the drug scene have also moved to Wales, only to relapse and bring their addictions with them.

Janet Joyce, 37, was typical. Originally from Manchester, she lived a drug-free life until 18 months ago when she began a relationship with a heroin addict. Within a few months, she too had become addicted and the pair moved from Manchester to North Wales to get out of the drug scene. They soon fell back into their old ways and last week Joyce was jailed for three years for drug dealing.

In Aberdare and Mountain Ash, some pubs have boarded up their windows. Doctors' surgeries have been made into fortresses, with iron gates and security systems.

'It's getting so bad that nothing is safe,' says the former miner. 'The supermarket bricked up all its windows to stop people breaking in, but then they just smashed a hole in the wall. After that, they employed a security guard with a couple of Rottweilers. That worked for a couple of weeks, but then one night someone stole his dogs.'

webTitle: Smuggled meat threatens UK with catastrophic viruses

fields.headline: Smuggled meat threatens UK with catastrophic viruses
fields.standfirst: Hard-pressed officials are unable to intercept illegal imports carrying deadly diseases
fields.trailText: Thousands of tonnes of illegally imported meat are smuggled into Britain each year, risking outbreaks of deadly viruses such as ebola.
fields.body:
Thousands of tonnes of illegally imported meat are smuggled into Britain each year, risking outbreaks of deadly viruses such as ebola.

An Observer investigation has discovered the imports includes beef and pork from parts of Asia and Africa where foot and mouth disease is endemic, and illegal bushmeat such as monkey, elephant, anteater, antelope and rat. The food is sold - often openly - in shops and restaurants throughout Britain.

Illegally imported meat was thought to be responsible for the outbreak of swine fever last year, and last week the Government said it was responsible for the foot and mouth outbreak which is devastating the British farming industry and costing the country billions of pounds.

However, veterinary experts warned that the trade could cause several other serious outbreaks that not only affect farming, but could kill hundreds of people. The threats include not just food poisoning bugs such as salmonella and E.coli, but ebola and anthrax.

Professor Hugh Pennington of Aberdeen University and a government adviser on food safety said: 'There's a risk of a major food poisoning outbreak if it's coming in uncontrolled.' Tony Little, vice-president of the British Veterinary Association, said: 'Meat from the Third World is something you have to think quite seriously about. If it's being sold in markets circumventing all regulations, that's extremely serious.'

Seizures of illegally imported meat are running at around 200 a month, and sometimes result from tip-offs from baggage handlers who see blood dripping from suitcases. On one flight alone from Nigeria last year, 2,500kg of illegal meat was confiscated.

The fact that meat is still coming in from countries with endemic foot and mouth disease is an embarrassment to the Government as it steps up its slaughter campaign to rid British farming of the economically disastrous virus. Our investigation has shown potentially infected meat has been smuggled into the country throughout the crisis.

Government scientists believe the virus originated in infected imported meat from a Chinese restaurant being fed to pigs in untreated swill. But an environmental health source at Felixstowe, Britain's largest container port, revealed that last week customs stopped a consignment of illegal beef and pork from China, which had at least 20 foot and mouth outbreaks last year. It contained 100 cartons of meat mixed in with cereals, noodles and other non-meat products. The importer claimed no knowledge of the meat, which will make prosecution virtually impossible.

Officials warn that cutbacks mean they are so short staffed they can check only a tiny proportion of imports. Customs officials are also not allowed to inspect many non-food containers or containers from other European Union countries, which could hide meat smuggled across other borders.

'We catch a fraction of what is coming in,' said Doug Bloomfield, assistant director of environmental services at Suffolk Coastal District Council, which is responsible for Felixstowe. 'You only have to look at the foot and mouth epidemic now to see what a dangerous situation it is.'

The meat is destined either for private family use - often by ethnic minorities keen to enjoy traditional delicacies - or the catering trade. The investigation showed that illegally imported meat was openly on sale in shops in Brixton market in London, where bush meat for sale included rat, bat and monkey. Enforcement is so weak that a shop in Old Kent Road in London had a sign out in the pavement boasting: 'We Sell Bush Meat'. Only when it was alerted to the problem on Friday did Lambeth Council inspect Brixton Market, and confiscate illegal meat. Supermarkets in London and China Town in Manchester were also openly selling illegal meat. Newport supermarket in Soho was selling illegally imported pork, undeterred by Westminster Council, while the Wing Fat supermarket in Manchester was selling dried pork and beef from China.

The most dangerous illegal import is monkey meat, which caused an ebola scare at Heathrow airport last year. Customs sources say that 15 carcases of dead monkeys were found on 29 November hidden in a cargo of fruit and vegetables, which also contained an anteater and tortoise legs. Environmental health officers realised the monkeys could be carrying ebola, one of the deadliest and most contagious viruses known to man that kills nearly all its victims.

The customs inspection post and any vehicle that had been near the cargo was sprayed with disinfectant. 'I had my own car sprayed and it was pretty scary. The word they kept mentioning was ebola,' said the source. The monkeys had originally come from a flight from Cameroon that touched down in Geneva and were then transferred on to a Swissair plane to London.

Prof Pennington said it is quite possible to catch ebola from monkey meat while it is being prepared. 'Before you cook it, you cut it up and there could be an aerosol spray of the virus, or you could get the blood on you,' he said.

Little added: 'It's the nightmare scenario if you brought ebola in from Africa.'

Another danger from illegal meats is the Nipah virus, which affects and kills both pigs and humans, who die in agony within 48 hours. The virus killed 100 people in Malaysia last year and wiped out the pig industry before it was controlled.

A new strain of salmonella specific to the Gambia has been found in the UK, suggesting illegal imports of meat from that country. E.coli 0157 was unknown in the UK until the mid-Eighties, and may have entered through illegal imports.

Dozens of other diseases including anthrax, sheep pox, pseudorabies, and African horse sickness could all be imported.

Illegal importers are making huge profits by taking advantage of weak border controls: Customs and environmental health officers have faced severe cuts since 1993 due to the single European market. In Dover, the number of health officers has fallen from seven to one in just eight years. At the airports, the picture is even more bleak. Cargo manifests often say just 'mixed goods' or 'fruit and vegetables' and there is no law making it mandatory for such consignments to be checked. Most containers go through customs electronically. It can take just a few hours for a container of dangerous meat to get on to Britain's roads.

'Most of the containers are put on lorries and gone before we even get out of the office,' said Rose Armstrong, a spokeswoman for the Association of Port Heath Authorities. 'Airports are a great backdoor to get illegal meat into this country.'

The worst culprits are believed to be the state airlines of Nigeria and Ghana. Last year, Customs and officials from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food carried out raids on 14 flights from Nigeria or Ghana looking for illegal meat.

They recovered five tons of meat products ranging from dried fish to anteaters to antelope - potentially carriers of foot and mouth.

Clive Lawrance, head of Ciel Logistics - which oversees imports at Heathrow - organised one of the raids, including one in September on a DC-10 flight from Accra, Ghana. As the luggage was offloaded Customs and Maff officials checked it.

A total of 56 bags contained meat weighing about 1,388 kilogrammes.

Much of the meat was rancid and some was spilling out of the suitcases. If any viruses had been present it would have been ideal circumstances for contamination.

Maff is meeting next week with the Association of Port Health Authorities, the Food Standards Agency and Customs and Excise to tackle the issue. The Agriculture Secretary, Nick Brown, hinted that airlines may be fined for carrying illegal meat.

However, a spokesman for the FSA played down the threat. 'We take this seriously, and we actively investigate such allegations. But so far, there is no significant history of health concerns from illegally imported meat,' he said.

But Mac Johnston, professor of Veterinary Public Health at the Royal Veterinary College, said the risks were not remote: 'Earlier this year, the risk of foot and mouth disease was remote, but now we have it. The foot and mouth outbreak has shown the scale of the illegal trade. We need to learn these lessons.'

webTitle: Mozart sonata offers hope to epileptics

fields.headline: Mozart sonata offers hope to epileptics
fields.trailText: He may have been the greatest composer ever, whose genius drove him to an early grave and listeners across the centuries to tears of wonder and joy. Now Mozart could also hold the key to a medical marvel.
fields.body:
He may have been the greatest composer ever, whose genius drove him to an early grave and listeners across the centuries to tears of wonder and joy. Now Mozart could also hold the key to a medical marvel.

Doctors say his music can be more effective at treating epilepsy than pills, whereas pop and minimalist music have no effect. The only other music with similar properties is the warblings of the long-haired, mustachioed Greek-American star Yanni.

The Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine will tomorrow say the findings indicate Mozart's music could form a standard part of treatment of epilepsy, and calls for more research.

In the UK, 420,000 people suffer from epilepsy, or one in every 130. Previous studies have shown the impact music can have on healthy brains. Psychologists have claimed playing Mozart can make young children more intelligent, and older children study better. Record shops cash in on this research, selling Mozart CDs with labels saying: 'Your baby needs Mozart'. But now Mozart - in particular his piano sonata K448 - can also tackle actual illness. Twenty-nine patients with severe epilepsy were played Mozart, while their brain waves were measured. Twenty-three showed reduced epileptic activity.

In one male patient, the occurrence of epileptic brainwaves dropped from being present two-thirds of the time to being there only a fifth of the time. Two patients had epileptical brainwaves more than 90 per cent of the time, until the music had been playing for five minutes when it dropped to 50 per cent.

However, most of these patients reverted as soon as the music was stopped. To see if it could have a longer-term effect, an eight-year-old girl was played the Mozart sonata for 10 minutes an hour while she was awake. The number of seizures she had fell from nine in the first four hours of music to one in the last four hours. The next day she had just two seizures in almost eight hours.

Previous studies have suggested the music affects intelligence because of 'enjoyment arousal'. However, many patients were unconscious when played the music. A study on rats showed they also found it easier to complete mazes if they were played Mozart's sonata than if they heard nothing, or minimalist music by Philip Glass.

John Jenkins, professor of endocrinology at the University of London, who wrote the paper 'The Mozart Effect', thinks the music affects electrical impulses in the brain, which get disturbed in epileptics.

The sonata K448 was called 'one of the most profound of all his compositions' by Mozart authority Alfred Einstein. Sonata K488 is also known to be effective, as is a contemporary composition by Yanni.

webTitle: Cleese hands over 'Secret Policeman' shows to Izzard

fields.headline: Izzard keeps the Ball rolling into a new era
fields.standfirst: Cleese hands over legacy of Amnesty's 'Secret Policeman' shows, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: Cleese hands over legacy of Amnesty's 'Secret Policeman' shows, reports Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Recordings of The Secret Policeman's Ball were once passed among schoolchildren like contraband. The humour was surreal and rude, and parents did not usually approve.

Many of the biggest names in British stand-up comedy today developed the taste after seeing Peter Cook, Alan Bennett or Billy Connolly being absurd on grainy video tapes of the charity events run in aid of Amnesty International. Now one of those younger stars is seizing control, as John Cleese hands over to a new artistic director - Eddie Izzard.

To mark the fortieth anniversary of Amnesty, a charity launched with an appeal by the lawyer Peter Benenson in this newspaper in 1961, the human rights organisation is going back to its comic roots and re-launching its live benefit shows following a 10-year gap.

The passing of the Amnesty comedy baton took place in Santa Barbara, 100 miles north of Los Angeles, where Cleese now lives. He and Izzard met on a balcony of the Four Seasons hotel in Beverly Hills to tell The Observer about Amnesty's plans. The old name is going - Izzard's show will be called We Know Where You Live - but it is the direct heir to the many Secret Policeman's Balls that funded Amnesty through the Seventies and Eighties.

The early Balls and other Amnesty benefits provided some of the great comic moments of our time. Looking through the programmes Cleese has brought with him is like taking a roll call of the best of British comedy: Alan Bennett's T.E. Lawrence sketch, the Monty Python cast singing the 'Lumberjack Song', Peter Ustinov doing the Queen Mother at the Royal Ballet, Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, Rowan Atkinson's schoolmaster riff, Billy Connolly, Alexei Sayle, Robbie Coltrane, French and Saunders - with musical support by everyone from John Williams, Donovan and Lou Reed to Joan Armatrading and Jackson Browne.

Cleese enthuses about Peter Cook's famous satire on the judge's summing-up at the end of the trial of Jeremy Thorpe: 'Peter got very, very cross and wrote a piece overnight.' He also recalls the time his own daughter held Robbie Coltrane's idiot card upside down - 'the look of desperation that came over his face! And Ken Campbell, for god's sake, some of the best stuff I've seen on stage.'

The earliest shows were rare events but, since the days of Live Aid and Comic Relief, the public has become used to filling seats for good causes. Izzard has no worries about filling the 11,000 seats at Wembley Arena. The reason for such a big venue, he said, was because he wanted tickets at prices people could afford so it would not be an audience of the 'rattling jewellery brigade'.

Izzard first saw the Secret Policeman's Balls while at school and was happy to become involved with Amnesty later. Cleese, unable to organise the event this time because of of parental responsibilities in California, had suggested Izzard. 'I thought Eddie had the right touch because you can't put too heavy a hand on it.'

There are specific Amnesty cases that have relevance to the night, says Izzard, mentioning comedians U Pa Pa Lay and U Lu Zaw, jailed in 1996 in Burma (now renamed Myanmar) for making anti-government jests. 'They did some jokes about the government, got some laughs and seven years in jail.' They are now in a labour camp.

He also wants to highlight the case of musician and film-maker Ngawang Choephel, jailed in China for 'espionage and counter-revolutionary activities' while researching a documentary on traditional Tibetan performance, and of Venesa Lorna Ledesma, a member of the United Transvestites Association in Argen-tina who was arrested, tortured and murdered last year.

The change of title to We Know Where You Live has a point. 'It's normally used by gangsters against innocent individuals so I thought we should take it and use it against these dictators who run these countries,' said Izzard, who is still finalising the line-up for Wembley, dependent on who's in town that night.

'The shows were always a bit rough,' said Cleese nostalgically, 'which seemed to add something to them. People would just turn up at the door on the night. Barry Humphreys would be able to perform so Willie Rushton, say, would be asked if he minded dropping out for the evening and he would say "not at all, my love".'

Cleese is sad that Amnesty, now with more than a million members in 140 countries, remains as necessary as it was when it was founded. Its last annual report shows there were prisoners of conscience in 61 countries and executions taking place in 31 countries. 'Growing up in the Sixties when satire started, one really thought this kind of insane behaviour would eventually be laughed off the world stage, but I'm not sure that much progress has been made,' said Cleese. 'You see how many absolutely awful people there are in charge who only want to be in power. You've just got to see what happened in the American elections. It's extraordinary how immoral most of it is.'

Amnesty hopes the event, to be shown on television at a later date, will not only raise funds but also recruit to the cause a new generation who may first hear ofAmnesty, as Izzard did, through the shows. 'We Know Where You Live' is at Wembley Arena on 3 June, tickets from Wembley Arena, 0870 7331050

fields.headline: First blood to Arsenal
fields.standfirst: Arsenal Pires 70, Henry 87 Tottenham Hotspur att: 38,121 :   2 0
fields.trailText: At least Tottenham will get their chance for significant revenge when these two teams meet again in next Sunday's FA Cup semi-final. Their supporters will not be able to stomach another match like this, though, and Glenn Hoddle will have to be at his miraculous best to restore confidence before the Old Trafford showdown.
fields.body:
At least Tottenham will get their chance for significant revenge when these two teams meet again in next Sunday's FA Cup semi-final. Their supporters will not be able to stomach another match like this, though, and Glenn Hoddle will have to be at his miraculous best to restore confidence before the Old Trafford showdown.

That is where the real prize is on offer, of course, but the goals from French connection Robert Pires and Thierry Henry said nothing of the emphatic nature of this Arsenal victory. Tottenham can take heart from the fact that no other side have won at Highbury this season, but little else.

The 128th League match between London's bitterest rivals started like so many before it, with neither side able to string a pass together against relentless tackling. Arsenal were the form team, but, as so often when local honour is at stake, it counted for nothing for a while.

Man for man and pound for pound Arsenal looked very much the heavyweights, but never underestimate the strength of a pumped-up little 'un and Tottenham initially gave as good as they got.

The balance of power began to shift Arsenal's way, though, after Henry struck a post in the seventh minute and Tottenham were soon playing more survival, than attacking, football. Martin Keown, in his first game after two months out with a groin injury, created the chance when he split the Tottenham defence with a sublime pass from the outside of his right foot.

Henry beat Gary Doherty to the ball but then the Spurs defender appeared to have won with a last-gasp lunge, before the French striker recovered to cut a shot on to the inside of Neil Sullivan's near post before the ball jetted across the face of goal to safety.

With Ray Parlour wide on the right and Pires on the left, Arsenal sensed an opportunity to exploit the gaps offered by Tottenham's three-man defence.

One such attack led to Arsenal's next best chance, in the 30th minute, when Henry played Pires into a good position on the left of the area, but he hesitated and his shot lacked conviction and direction, enabling Sullivan to make a comfortable block.

With half-time in sight, Tottenham were still holding their shape and belief, but with five players in the starting line-up aged 21 and under, their potential for a costly lapse in concentration always seemed greater.

So it came as a surprise when one of the Tottenham fledglings, Simon Davies, nearly scored seven minutes before the break after leading Tony Adams and Lee Dixon a merry dance. Davies broke from midway inside the Arsenal half and sent Dixon and Adams tumbling with a weaving run into the area, but his shot ultimately deflected a foot wide as Dixon dashed back to block.

Arsenal were back on top at the start of the second half, although they were still making Sullivan look good with some sluggish finishing. The Spurs keeper proceeded to make genuinely good saves from Sylvain Wiltord, Dixon and substitute Kanu. And he appeared so invincible to Wiltord that the Frenchman passed when he should have shot in front of an open goal.

He was finally beaten by a world-class Pires finish in the 72nd minute. The Frenchman cut in from the left and curled a right-foot shot beyond Sullivan and into the opposite corner of the net. Henry's goal, 10 minutes later, was equal in quality. He carried the ball from the centre circle, shimmied past Chris Perry on the edge of the area and slipped a shot under Sullivan.

Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon (Luzhny 83), Keown, Adams, Cole, Vieira, Parlour, Lauren (Kanu 67), Pires, Henry, Wiltord. Subs not used: Manninger, Ljungberg, Edu.

Tottenham Hotspur: Sullivan, Gardner, Young, Doherty, Perry, Thelwell, Freund, Iversen, Davies (Etherington 79), Korsten (Piercy 67), Ferdinand. Subs not used: Walker, Hillier, Ferguson.

Referee: P Durkin (Dorset).

One such attack led to Arsenal's next best chance, in the 30th minute, when Henry played Pires into a good position on the left of the area, but he hesitated and his shot lacked conviction and direction, enabling Sullivan to make a comfortable block. With half-time in sight, Tottenham were still holding their shape and belief, but with five players in the starting line-up aged 21 and under, their potential for a costly lapse in concentration always seemed greater. So it came as a surprise when one of the Tottenham fledglings, Simon Davies, nearly scored seven minutes before the break after leading Tony Adams and Lee Dixon a merry dance. Davies broke from midway inside the Arsenal half and sent Dixon and Adams tumbling with a weaving run into the area, but his shot ultimately deflected a foot wide as Dixon dashed back to block. Arsenal were back on top at the start of the second half, although they were still making Sullivan look good with some sluggish finishing. The Spurs keeper proceeded to make genuinely good saves from Sylvain Wiltord, Dixon and substitute Kanu. The Frenchman cut in from the left and curled a right-foot shot beyond Sullivan and into the opposite corner of the net. Henry's goal, 10 minutes later, was equal in quality. He carried the ball from the centre circle, shimmied past Chris Perry on the edge of the area and slipped a shot under Sullivan. fields.headline: United run into Anfield iron
fields.standfirst: Liverpool Gerrard 16, Fowler 41   Manchester Utd att: 44,806 :   2-0
fields.trailText: This match might have meant more to Liverpool than Manchester United, as Sir Alex Ferguson rather smugly suggested, but the champions in waiting would be unwise to ignore the warnings of conceding a double to their North-West rivals for the first time since 1979.
fields.body:
This match might have meant more to Liverpool than Manchester United, as Sir Alex Ferguson rather smugly suggested, but the champions in waiting would be unwise to ignore the warnings of conceding a double to their North-West rivals for the first time since 1979.

Roy Keane, in particular, caught a glimpse of the future in this comprehensive defeat. For the past decade the United midfielder has been the acknowledged master of that department, the undisputed boss, the engine every manager would choose to power his team. Here he was usurped by Steven Gerrard, scorer of a magnificent first goal and maker of a second, who was so far ahead in the man of the match stakes he seemed to reduce everyone else on the pitch to Subbuteo size.

Keane is normally the player head and shoulders above the rest, but running, tackling, passing and even finding time to shoot from his own half, 20-year-old Gerrard had every angle covered. If he can play this well for England, even on a part-time basis, the next few years could be bright indeed for Sven-Göran Eriksson. He was notionally deployed on the right, a Gérard Houllier ploy to get Danny Murphy further forward through the middle, but did more or less as he pleased - and certainly pleased his supporters. The reception when he came off four minutes from the end was deafening.

'If Stevie has space he goes for it,' Houllier said. 'His game is made of power and energy, and he can now score goals with his head, from close in or from distance. He only scored two last season, but has eight already this season. A defensive midfielder who can give you 10 to 15 goals a season is very valuable.'

Which is exactly why everyone was fighting for the services of Keane eight years ago, and why Liverpool's biggest battle in seasons to come might be hanging on to their most conspicuous asset.

'He's a Scouser, he's not going anywhere,' Houllier has said, but if Gerrard continues to score goals as sumptuous as the one which put United behind after 15 minutes, Liverpool will soon have more to deal with than tentative £15 million offers from Roma.

Both sides had had chances in an open and enjoyable frantic first few minutes, before a poor clearance from Fabien Barthez was knocked into Gerrard's path by Robbie Fowler. Despite being 30 yards from goal Gerrard did not hang about. From the moment he received the ball it was obvious he would shoot, and strangely it was equally clear he would score. Barthez, getting the ball back far more quickly than he wanted it, could only watch as Gerrard's drive arrowed into his top right corner. 'It was a fantastic goal,' Ferguson graciously conceded.

United had Ryan Giggs back, but rested Andy Cole, Jaap Stam, Paul Scholes and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. They are not the only ones with a big European game coming up, however, and Liverpool rested Michael Owen and gave Patrik Berger his first game since November. Houllier will play Owen in Barcelona on Thursday, of course, but he would also like to break his one-game-per-week rule and play Gerrard. 'If he's fit I'd like to use him, but I will not play him if he is not 100 per cent fit,' he said.

With Bayern Munich visiting Old Trafford on Tuesday, United could never be 100 per cent focused on this game, even without the international travelling which affected Keane and explained one or two of their absentees. 'If we had come here chasing the league I would have fielded a different team,' Ferguson said. 'But the fact is I didn't have to, so I did what was sensible considering the position we are in.'

United were contesting the game until Gerrard's strike, then they lost the plot, although they did take the game to Liverpool in the second half. By that stage they were two goals down, Fowler having accepted Gerrard's pass and taken advantage of Gary Neville's slip to send a left-foot shot high into Barthez's net. Considering the Liverpool captain had fallen over when presented with a better opportunity three minutes earlier, that Emile Heskey wasted another Gerrard invitation with a weak shot which Barthez tipped round a post, and that Gary Neville got away with a blatant handball in the area, United could not have complained had they been three or four goals down at the break.

Presumably words were said at half-time, for United made a much better fist of the second half as Liverpool began to sit back on their lead. The outcome could have been quite different had a 65th-minute goal from Dwight Yorke stood, though the striker's sidefoot from Phil Neville's cross was ruled offside, somewhat harshly in view of replays which revealed another linesman on another day might have deemed him level. Liverpool were forced to cling on for the last 20 minutes after Murphy collected a second yellow card for a late challenge on Denis Irwin, but they still might have added a third goal had Heskey made better use of Gerrard's 50-yard pass or Nick Barmby kept a late shot a couple of feet lower.

'We've made a good start to the week, but this doesn't mean we are now at United's level,' Houllier said. 'When they put us under pressure in the second half we could understand why they are so far ahead in the league.'

Liverpool : Westerveld, Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Gerrard (Owen 86), Murphy Hamann, Berger (Barmby 69), Heskey, Fowler (McAllister 69). Subs not used: Arphexad, Traore.

Manchester United : Barthez, P.Neville, G.Neville, Brown, Irwin (Silvestre 71), Beckham, Keane, Butt (Scholes 75), Giggs, Sheringham (Chadwick 71), Yorke. Subs not used: Goram, Fortune.

Referee: G Poll (Tring).

United's remaining fixtures 10 April Charlton (H) 14 April Coventry (H) 21 April Man City (H) 28 April Middlesbrough (A) 5 May Derby (H) 13 May Southampton (A) 19 May Tottenham (A)

Despite yesterday's defeat, United remain on target to set a Premiership record for the fewest goals conceded. In 1997-98 United leaked just 26 goals.

fields.headline: Sixteen going on fiftysomething
fields.trailText:
The Sound of Music Children: After They Were Famous ITV
Little Women: A Day in the Life of a Tweenager BBC2
Walk On By BBC2
fields.body:
The Sound of Music Children: After They Were Famous ITV
Little Women: A Day in the Life of a Tweenager BBC2
Walk On By BBC2

Last week, Sir Norman Wisdom was in Albania and Lee Evans was on BBC1. After viewing the latter's desperate new sitcom, So What Now? I can't help feeling this was the wrong way around. In another intriguing juxtaposition last week, it was also revealed that the link between Rodgers and Hammerstein and Muddy Waters is not as tenuous as one might imagine. But let us start at the very beginning which is, of course, a very good place to start. An engrossing After They Were Famous rounded up the child stars of The Sound of Music and persuaded them to revisit Salzburg for the first time in 35 years, though sadly not to don dirndl and lederhosen. They turned out to be an immensely easy-going, sane and likeable bunch of forty- and fiftysomethings, still friends (indeed, seemingly closer than many siblings) and remarkably unscrewed-up by having starred in the Most Successful Movie of All Time. Though not in Austria, where it closed after three days amid cries of 'Nazis? Us? Auf Wiedersehen my arse!'

Most of the seven grew up with an ambivalent relationship to the movie, particularly during their teens, when having 'Do-Re-Mi' on your CV must have been only slightly less cool than boasting about your six-month tour in 'Nam. Now, though, even the quiet one, Duane Chase, a geologist who played Kurt, has come to terms with the extraordinary influence the film has exerted, not only on the billion people who are alleged to have seen it (where do they get these figures?), but on those who lived it too. These days, Duane's favourite hobby is climbing. Ev'ry mountain, presumably.

At such impressionable ages, a nine-month shoot (it took one whole month to film the 'Do-Re-Mi' scenes alone) was bound to leave it's mark. Fourteen-year-old Nicholas Hammond (Friedrich and, much later, Spiderman in a costume arguably more embarrassing than lederhosen) grew up to discover that when you belong to the world's happiest filmic family, expectations of 'a perfect wedding, a perfect relationship and a perfect family don't serve you well', though he is the only junior Von Trapp to have made a successful career in the business.

Meanwhile, Charmian Carr (Liesl) was a fraud - the girl who sang 'I am sixteen, going on seventeen' was 21 and thus closer to Julie Andrews's age than those of her faux-siblings, but even she grew up expecting life to be a bit more Rodgers and Hammerstein than it turned out to be. Now a 56-year-old super-glamorous divorced interior decorator (she worked on Michael Jackson's Neverland ranch. No prizes for guessing his favourite movie), Charmian admits that 'there isn't that ideal family. It doesn't exist'. Aside from the birth of her daughters and her grandchild, she still counts the ovation she received from the crew after dancing through the filming of 'Sixteen Going On Seventeen' with a sprained ankle as 'one of the most thrilling moments of my life'.

The Sound of Music was the second film I ever saw (after The Jungle Book) and, for a sibling-free only child with a rich interior fantasy life, it was truly the cinematic incarnation of heaven. What was most fascinating and touching about this programme, then, was discovering that the cast had been seduced almost as much as the audience. At the end of the show, charming Nicholas said that the experience of making the documentary had forced him to 'look at my childhood from the perspective of a 50-year-old. And in a funny sort of way I feel like I'm saying goodbye to this film now'. By the time Nicholas, Charmian, Angela, Heather, Debbie, Duane and Kym sang 'So long, farewell, auf Wiedersehen, goodbye...' there wasn't a dry eye in my house, so perhaps we all were.

I don't know what, if anything, little girls make of The Sound of Music these days. Probably they are too busy worshipping Kym from Hear'say to be greatly inspired by Kym Karath's Gretl. BBC2's Little Women: A Day In The Life of a Tweenager ('media-savvy pre-teens' explained the editor of Cosmo Girl) looked set to confirm one's suspicion that Britain is breeding playgrounds full of mini-Britneys - terrifyingly knowing, belly-button-baring poptots who can spot the difference between Clinique and Laboratoire Garnier, a pair of Jimmy Choos and Manolo Blahniks, and invariably favour Madonna's Music over The Sound of Music 's soppy singing nun.

But, somewhat surprisingly, the programme revealed that underneath, say, 11-year-old Lauren's preternaturally lip-glossed veneer of sophistication ('that's the trouble with these tops, they fall down' she observed of her boob tube. Ah, but not for long, my love) she was, really, just an 11-year-old, albeit an 11-year-old whose language was 16 going on 17. Lauren even admitted that she wanted a horse - even more than she wanted a leopard-print basque, Leonardo DiCaprio and a Brit award - which was exactly what I wanted when I was 11. 'What kind of look are you going for?' asked the director, as 10-year-old Alex riffled through her smalls drawer. 'Biker babe,' Alex said without missing a beat, bless her little leathers. Meanwhile, Leigh, eight, and Georgia, seven, were in the back of a taxi with Leigh's dad. 'We're going to Harrods, shopping for clothes,' explained Leigh before immediately turning to her best friend and asking the very important consumerist question 'do you prefer big cats or little cats?' 'Kittens,' replied the winsome little poppet. Inside the store, as he flashed his plastic, Leigh's dad was asked why he spent so much on clothes for an eight-year-old who might only wear them half a dozen times. 'Because I can,' he replied with a wry smile. Roll on the recession, eh!

Funny thing, this, but though we might not shop very much, we get far better pop music during recessions. During the last one, for example, Stock, Aitken and Waterman's 1980s' chart domination suddenly gave way to the Stone Roses and the Happy Mondays, who, in turn, begat the likes of Pulp, Blur and Oasis. Who may now be waiting in the wings ready to reach for the stars and oust Steps in the process? Which brings me neatly back to the beginning (which is a very good place to end) and the very best documentary series currently on TV, BBC2's Walk On By.

Week three and this well-nigh definitive history of popular song has only just arrived at early Elvis, but what a blinding journey it's been so far. Littered with riveting archive footage of ancient Appalachian hillybilly banjo ensembles and honky-tonk bluesmen waking up one mornin' and findin' a hole in their bucket, relevant anecdotage is also provided by a staggering array of ageing musical legends (only Elvis was missing and he had an excuse).

There was Loretta Lynn, Van Morrison, Ray Charles, BB King and even Keith Richards (helpfully captioned 'musician') on hand to explain how 'blues is a beautifully flexible music for such a limited form' and then demonstrate why. Here, too, was Jerry Wexler (captioned 'senior producer, Atlantic Records' which doesn't even come close to describing his place in the grand scheme of popular music) recalling the 1930s, when the description '"Race music" was an honourable designation', and a couple of black guys would describe a third party as 'a Race man to the bricks, a proud promulgator of negritude'. And if that isn't the most gloriously mellifluous musical sentence uttered during the whole of terrestrial TV's output last week, then I'm Muddy Waters. 'Somehow,' Wexler continued, 'down the line, "Race" seemed to imply separation and inferiority and so we changed it to rhythm and blues...' And when he says 'we', he means 'I'.

From Rodgers and Hammerstein to Muddy Waters, then? Well, there's not much separating The Sound of Music 's yodelling from that of country star Jimmy Rogers, who died in 1933 and whose music was the first to be described as 'white blues' - the pioneer crossover hitmaker (and I'm afraid I just threw Muddy in there to blues the waters a bit). Walk On By is absolutely unmissable television - possibly even for Britney fans, but especially for a TV critic whose brilliant lyricist of a father has written words that have been sung by Ray Charles and Elvis and which never fail to send shivers down my spine each time I hear them. Yes, just like the Von Trapps, we Fletts are practically black - and, obviously, very, very proud.

The Monkey's Mask (94 mins, 18) Directed by Samantha Lang; starring Susie Porter, Kelly McGillis

2001: A Space Odyssey (149 mins, U) Directed by Stanley Kubrick; starring Keir Dullea, Gary Lockwood, William Sylvester

Zhang Yang's Shower is the work of an independent company set up in China by the American producer, Peter Loehr, to cater for the young urban Chinese audience with movies that eschew rural and historical subject matter. It's a brisk, enjoyable affair on themes of tradition and family about a successful young businessman, Da Ming, returning to Beijing to visit his dying father, Liu, who runs a decaying community bathhouse in an old suburb with the help of his mentally retarded younger son, Er Ming.

Liu's bathhouse is a place where people can relax, feel good about their bodies, chat, play mah-jong, and gamble on fights between trained crickets. Liu doesn't just massage his visitors - he keeps the peace, reconciles couples, and (through his young son) helps an aspiring opera singer to confront his stage fright. Of course the place is about to be torn down to make way for a shopping mall, and Da Ming realises the importance of his father's life and values and comes to accept responsibility for his younger brother.

Western audiences might see in Shower a coming together of some familiar plots from European and American films. On the one hand there's the story of the self-centred businessman who finds redemption in caring for a mentally retarded brother after a father's death - the story of Rain Man and the Dogma production Mifune. On the other there's the tale of people fighting to keep open a community bath in the face of a faceless progress - the plot of both Steaming, the Nell Dunn play filmed by Joseph Losey, and the recent Italian film, Hamam - The Turkish Bath .

The week's two American films are about very different stages of the post-war black experience. The better of the two is George Tillman Jr's earnest, plodding Men of Honour, an inspirational movie based on the career of Carl Brashear (Cuba Gooding Jr), a Kentucky dirt-farmer's son, who joins the navy in the late 1940s and discovers that the only work he's given is cooking on a destroyer. A formidable swimmer, he comes to admire Billy Sunday (Robert De Niro), Master Chief Navy Diver, and determines to be the first black man to get into diving school.

At every stage he's obstructed by the virulent racism of officers, petty officers and fellow ratings, not least Sunday himself, a sadistic Southern bigot. But by sheer determination he makes it through one masochistic confrontation after another, culminating in his demand to have a damaged leg amputated so that he can get back into diving with a prosthetic leg. The painful finale resembles the end of On the Waterfront where the crippled Brando is driven on by his priest to lead the dockers back to work.

Gooding Jr is impressive as this inner-directed character, making his way in a world where white men make the rules and arbitrarily interpret them. In contrast Save the Last Dance has a white heroine, the 17-year-old Sarah (Julia Stiles), who is brought to Chicago by her negligent father after her dedicated mother's death, and put into a school almost entirely black. Most of her fellow pupils regard her with suspicion or contempt, but one of them, an 18-year-old with a baby son, takes her under her wing, giving Sarah a crash course in African-American talk and a sartorial makeover so she can attend a hip hop club.

Her new friend's brother (Sean Patrick Thomas), top scholar in the school and with a scholarship to Georgetown University, both teaches her the basics of hip hop and break-dancing, and encourages her to resume her dancing ambitions and to audition for Juilliard with a black-inflected contemporary dance in her repertoire. The movie is contrived and sentimental, but emotionally it goes for the same targets as Billy Elliot and in much the same way.

The week's two films from the British Isles are both directed by Irishmen. Gerard Stembridge's About Adam is fairly entertaining. Paddy Breathnach's Blow Dry is one of those native comedies that should be buried with others of its ilk in a long, deep trench in the remote countryside, were there not more pressing calls for the space.

About Adam is set in a cheerful, affluent, guiltless Dublin where debonair Adam (Stuart Townsend), owner of a fashionable art gallery dealing in photographs, seduces three beautiful sisters and their brother's fiancée, and more-or-less seduces their virgin brother and spirited widowed mother. It's a little like a lite version of Pasolini's Theorem with Adam as a priapic social chameleon, and at the end doesn't amount to much. But it's nicely told by Stembridge and attractively acted. Kate Hudson, Frances O'Connor and Charlotte Bradley are gorgeous as the contrasted sisters. As a singing waitress at a trendy restaurant Hudson handles some evergreen numbers with authority.

The author of the screenplay for Blow Dry is undisclosed but the opening credits state rather mysteriously that it's 'Based on the screenplay Never Better by Simon Beaufroy', who wrote The Full Monty. In fact it has a Full Monty and Brassed Off sort of story in which some dispirited provincial barbers decide to compete in the National British Hairdressing Championships when they're held in the town hall at Keighley in Yorkshire.

A snarling Alan Rickman gets together with his ex-wife and co-stylist Natasha Richardson who left him for a lesbian partner (Rachel Griffiths) and now has terminal cancer. They intend to challenge an old rival, preening Bill Nighy, who's made it big in London.

As a comedy Blow Dry is an utter failure and indeed for much of the time it goes for pathos and doesn't try to be funny. In addition to the running theme of Richardson's cancer, the film also hits us with senior citizen Rosemary Harris's blindness. At least the bad taste of the film-makers matches that of the camp creations of the hairdressers. Not since Ishtar has there been a worse film with so much talent on either side of the camera.

From Australia comes an odd noir thriller, Samantha Lang's The Monkey's Mask, ridiculous but watchable. The formidably freckled Susie Porter plays a Sapphic private eye, hired by a well-off couple to find their daughter, a university student who wrote erotic verse and had sex with every poet in Sydney. The search, which becomes a murder investigation, takes her into Australia's bizarre literary world of posing, untalented poets, and into the bed of a bisexual professor of literature played by the voluptuous Kelly McGillis. The film's best line is delivered by McGillis: 'You're a great fuck, but you're a very ordinary detective.' We are expected to recognise this as a paraphrase of a remark Marlene Dietrich makes about Orson Welles in A Touch of Fear .

Finally two blasts from the past. The first is Bela Tarr's monochrome Damnation, made in 1987 during the final heroic decade of serious Hungarian cinema, but never previously shown here. It's a misanthropic allegory taking place in constant rain in a decaying small town where a listless Karrer (played by Miklos Szekely, one of Hungary's most distinguished actors) has an affair with a singer at the Titanic Bar, involves her husband in some smuggling racket, and shops them to the police. The central symbol of life's absurdity is the ever-moving cable overhead constantly transporting tipping buckets of industrial waste back and forth from an electricity plant to a slag heap. The film is almost literally hypnotic - you want to leave, but you feel compelled to sit and watch.

The other old movie is Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey of 1968, back in a new print. So often do I watch it in part or whole on TV that - unlike his A Clockwork Orange - I hadn't noticed its absence from the cinema where it should be seen.

webTitle: Sorry, Bart, Malcolm's the boy now

fields.headline: Sorry, Bart, Malcolm's the boy now
fields.standfirst: America's favourite dysfunctional family - cartoons aside - has now arrived in Britain.  Stephanie Merritt  reports
fields.trailText: America's favourite dysfunctional family - cartoons aside - has now arrived in Britain. Stephanie Merritt reports
fields.body:
Q. Identify the following television character: he's a mischievous 10-year-old from a quirky family in small-town America; he delights in tangling himself in unintentionally disastrous schemes and creates havoc wherever he treads, provoking the wrath and covert respect of his naive father; he spends his days alternately tormenting and protecting his siblings and his nerdy, bespectacled friend; he infuriates and outwits his teachers and floors the adults around him with his own tilted logic.

Obvious, isn't it? Until I tell you he's not a cartoon figure but a real live wide-eyed pre-teen, and if you lived in America your unhesitating answer would have been Malcolm in the Middle.

Malcolm Wilkerson may bear a resemblance to Bart Simpson, but the 'live-action Simpsons' tag that critics attached to the show at the beginning of its successful first series doesn't do it justice. Malcolm in the Middle is unlike any other contemporary sitcom, and seems to have found that optimum combination of elements so wanting in recent British television comedy - perceptive casting, outstanding acting and innovative direction brought to scripts that blend verbal jousting and slapstick in much the same way as Matt Groening does with The Simpsons.

In the States, Fox worked the inevitable comparisons to its advantage, choosing to screen the first series on Sunday nights right after The Simpsons. It attracted the biggest viewing figures for a premiere (22.4 million) since the debut of Groening's cartoon a decade ago. Last year this unusual sitcom ended up second only to ER in the crucial 18-49 ratings demographic and pocketed two Emmys from five nominations. Malcolm has joined Bart as a national anti-hero for every generation.

But the real similarities are in the writing rather than the characters. The scripts share The Simpsons ' undercurrent of intellectual humour, while Malcolm himself is a kind of hybrid of siblings Bart and Lisa, an unusually gifted troublemaker in a bizarre family. The eldest brother, Francis, has been sent away to military school to curb his anarchic tendencies, while the three youngest are left at home with Lois (Jane Kaczmarek), a mother who wouldn't be out of place in an Almodóvar film, and Hal (Bryan Cranston), the unperturbable father who sits calmly reading his paper while his family creates Armageddon around him.

There's boy's boy Reese (Justin Berfield), 11, the unutterably cute little one, Dewey (Erik Per Sullivan), six, and, of course, the reluctant genius Malcolm (Frankie Muniz) in the middle. 'Dysfunctional family sitcom' is another easy label slapped on by critics and promoters, though Jane Kaczmarek, who was nominated for the Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Emmy, prefers the term 'eccentric'. 'This family is so highly functional,' she says. 'They eat dinner together every night. Sure, there's a sense of craziness. But there's also a sense of truth.'

The series started life with impressive credentials - created by executive producer Linwood Boomer (Third Rock From the Sun and Red Dwarf) and directed by Todd Holland of The Larry Sanders Show, with a theme tune composed especially by They Might Be Giants - but it's the talent of the relatively unknown child actors that gives the show its hyper-energy. Muniz , 15, looks like a child but brings an aggrieved knowingness to the part with his big, expressive eyes and frequent asides to camera.

The direction is fast and slick (over 600 edits per half hour), with jaunty camera angles and swift cuts, but the show is filmed with a single camera and without canned laughter. Much of the show's cleverness lies in the subtlety of detail - it takes a while to notice, for example, that the houses either side of the Wilkersons' on their picket-fence street both sport For Sale signs, and the dialogue never draws attention to it.

In the first episode, the plot template is introduced. Malcolm is horrified to discover he has an IQ of 164 and is to be moved into a 'gifted class'. The source of this genius is the subject of much speculation; his mother shaves his father's back in the kitchen and answers the front door topless to his teacher ('they're just boobs, lady - you see them in the mirror every morning'), while Malcolm and Reese are content to pass their time trussing up their little brother and dodging the school bully. Malcolm confides to the camera: 'In my school, being a genius is like being radioactive', as the camera swoops up for an aerial shot of the playground revealing his classmates standing at a distance in a perfect circle. There's a touch of South Park, too, in the irreverent jokes at the expense of Stevie Kanarban, the black, wheelchair-bound fellow-genius who attempts to befriend Malcolm: 'You'll be friends with that crippled boy and like it,' Lois tells her son, though over the next few episodes Stevie turns out to be a more ingenious straight man than Milhouse, his Simpsons equivalent.

Amid all the high-velocity antics, there are moments of poignant reflection on the assault course of family life and the way love often misguidedly shows itself as aggression, criticism or Chinese burns; the trick to surviving families is to know how to look for this between the lines.

Fox has already commissioned a second series of 28 episodes, and the show is so popular in the US it's now being screened twice weekly with a feature film version in development. Investing in such an important new comedy is a big statement for BBC2 and suggests it is catching up with Channel 4 and Sky, which have long monopolised the import of successful US sitcoms.

Malcolm in the Middle has the same high production values and polished scripts as Friends and Frasier and is a far cry from our own recent sorry efforts at US-style sitcoms: the spectacularly poor Coupling, Baddiel's Syndrome or Lee Evans's So What Now ? Cheering as it is to see the BBC taking a chance on innovative comedy, you have to wonder why nothing of Malcolm's standard is being produced over here.

Malcolm in the Middle starts on Friday, BBC2

webTitle: Forget Lourdes, get me a whore

fields.headline: Forget Lourdes, get me a whore
fields.standfirst: Jean Pierre Sinapi's challenging and wry film confronts the normally taboo subject of the sexuality of the handicapped
fields.trailText: Jean Pierre Sinapi's challenging and wry film confronts the normally taboo subject of the sexuality of the handicapped
fields.body:
Uneasy Riders (90 mins, 15) Directed by Jean Pierre Sinapi; starring Olivier Gourmet, Nadia Kaci, Saïd Taghmaoui

One of the great clichés of our time is to refer to something as 'the last taboo'. The current Private Eye comes up with 13 examples found in the Guardian alone these past three years referring to subjects as different as female masturbation and reusing graves. Jean-Pierre Sinapi's Uneasy Riders, so its publicity material proclaims, 'confronts and overturns a final taboo: the right of the disabled to sex and love'.

Is this claim entirely true? There is, as I recall, a scene in Fanny Hill where the eponymous heroine and colleague have sex with a prodigiously endowed simpleton. More seriously, not to say solemnly, the cinema has in the past 50 years touched on the subject, if necessarily circumspectly, in such films as Fred Zinnemann's The Men and Hal Ashby's Coming Home, and there's the wonderful scene in Fellini's Amarcord where the insane uncle, on day release from an institution, climbs a tree and shouts out: 'I want a women' until he's coaxed down and taken away.

It is the case, however, that Sinapi confronts the sexuality of the handicapped with a rare frankness and good humour that has commended itself to the public and critics alike. His movie picked up the audience prizes at San Sebastian and Berlin last year, and at the London Film Festival it won the International Critics prize and the Satyajit Ray Award.

The film is set in a small, liberal residential hospital in Provence near a main road (the film's French title is Nationale 7) where the physically and mentally disabled mingle freely with a tolerant staff. Shot on digital video, it has the texture of a documentary and, in fact, a number of the supporting cast are disabled people, though in some cases acting as if they have different disabilities from their own.

The institution's problem child is René, a bearded malcontent in his late forties, confined to a wheelchair and raging eloquently and obscenely against the world and the hospital's staff. Not for him the bus trips to Lourdes. He'd rather stay in his room surrounded by coloured pin-ups and watching hardcore videos. Then one day, in a vulnerable moment, he confesses to Julsie (Nadia Kaci), an attractive new nurse, that he'd like to experience a prostitute before he dies.

She broaches the matter at a staff meeting and tensions come to the fore, though only the practising Catholics are able to articulate their objections. So Julie pushes ahead and makes some discoveries, one of them being that if she arranges for a prostitute for René, she could be charged with pimping, unless a doctor can be persuaded to state in writing that such services are physically and psychologically necessary.

She visits the prostitutes plying their trade in camper-vans along Nationale 7, measuring their doors to see if they're accessible to wheelchairs. Finally, she settles on Florele (Nadine Marcovici), a strident no-nonsense whore of a sort that might once have been termed 'brazen' but would now be called 'feisty'. Florele transforms René and soon his fellow inmates are demanding similar therapy.

There is much else going on at the home for Julie. A good-looking shrink is after her, but he's allergic to cats, so she has to get another would-be lover, the hospital's janitor, to take her cat for a month. There's also a problem with a second wheelchair-borne patient, the retarded Rabah (Saïd Taghmaoui from La Haine and Hideous Kinky), a gay Arab obsessed with Johnny Halliday. The local priest and a Catholic nurse are preparing Rabah for baptism, but a complication arises when he decides that he wants as his godmother at the ceremony the whore Florele.

The movie ends before some of the long-term problems can be confronted, and its tone is perfectly expressed in the sight of the priest and the whore jiving together at the home's New Year's Eve 2000 party, as if Christ and Mary Magdalene had taken to the dance floor. But it's a wonderfully warm, funny picture, full of generosity and goodwill, and very well acted.

More seriously, not to say solemnly, the cinema has in the past 50 years touched on the subject, if necessarily circumspectly, in such films as Fred Zinnemann's The Men and Hal Ashby's Coming Home, and there's the wonderful scene in Fellini's Amarcord where the insane uncle, on day release from an institution, climbs a tree and shouts out: 'I want a women' until he's coaxed down and taken away. It is the case, however, that Sinapi confronts the sexuality of the handicapped with a rare frankness and good humour that has commended itself to the public and critics alike. His movie picked up the audience prizes at San Sebastian and Berlin last year, and at the London Film Festival it won the International Critics prize and the Satyajit Ray Award. The film is set in a small, liberal residential hospital in Provence near a main road (the film's French title is Nationale 7) where the physically and mentally disabled mingle freely with a tolerant staff. Shot on digital video, it has the texture of a documentary and, in fact, a number of the supporting cast are disabled people, though in some cases acting as if they have different disabilities from their own. The institution's problem child is René, a bearded malcontent in his late forties, confined to a wheelchair and raging eloquently and obscenely against the world and the hospital's staff. Not for him the bus trips to Lourdes. He'd rather stay in his room surrounded by coloured pin-ups and watching hardcore videos. Then one day, in a vulnerable moment, he confesses to Julsie (Nadia Kaci), an attractive new nurse, that he'd like to experience a prostitute before he dies. She broaches the matter at a staff meeting and tensions come to the fore, though only the practising Catholics are able to articulate their objections. So Julie pushes ahead and makes some discoveries, one of them being that if she arranges for a prostitute for René, she could be charged with pimping, unless a doctor can be persuaded to state in writing that such services are physically and psychologically necessary. She visits the prostitutes plying their trade in camper-vans along Nationale 7, measuring their doors to see if they're accessible to wheelchairs. Finally, she settles on Florele (Nadine Marcovici), a strident no-nonsense whore of a sort that might once have been termed 'brazen' but would now be called 'feisty'. Florele transforms René and soon his fellow inmates are demanding similar therapy. There is much else going on at the home for Julie. A good-looking shrink is after her, but he's allergic to cats, so she has to get another would-be lover, the hospital's janitor, to take her cat for a month. There's also a problem with a second wheelchair-borne patient, the retarded Rabah (Saïd Taghmaoui from La Haine and Hideous Kinky), a gay Arab obsessed with Johnny Halliday. The local priest and a Catholic nurse are preparing Rabah for baptism, but a complication arises when he decides that he wants as his godmother at the ceremony the whore Florele. The movie ends before some of the long-term problems can be confronted, and its tone is perfectly expressed in the sight of the priest and the whore jiving together at the home's New Year's Eve 2000 party, as if Christ and Mary Magdalene had taken to the dance floor. But it's a wonderfully warm, funny picture, full of generosity and goodwill, and very well acted.

fields.headline: Everyone's talking about...
fields.standfirst: Michelle Rodriguez, Latina boxer chick
fields.trailText: Here's a mini-morality tale: this week, Michelle Rodriguez won the debut performance gong at the Independent Spirit awards for her visceral incarnation of a boxer in Girlfight. Meanwhile, she is working on Resident Evil, based on the computer game. In just four films, the 22-year-old has gone from a tough feminist story set in the Bronx to a tacky action movie.
fields.body:
Here's a mini-morality tale: this week, Michelle Rodriguez won the debut performance gong at the Independent Spirit awards for her visceral incarnation of a boxer in Girlfight. Meanwhile, she is working on Resident Evil, based on the computer game. In just four films, the 22-year-old has gone from a tough feminist story set in the Bronx to a tacky action movie.

But that's unfair. As she pleads: 'Give me space to make mistakes, because I'm young and can be dumb at times.' And it is worth giving her a break, because she is so good in Girlfight she will surely do great work again.

The 2000 Sundance winner - about to get its much-delayed British release - is the kind of film that makes stars. Director Karyn Kusama was looking for a female Brando, and you can see why she choose Rodriguez. She exudes intensity and complexity as the high-school girl who sneaks behind her dad's back to become a boxer.

She was born in Texas, spent time in the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico and ended up in Jersey City, where she saw an ad for a 'female Latina boxer chick'. She hadn't acted, nor had she boxed, but she went to the audition anyway. In the end, she got so far into the part that she mistook herself for a fighter. 'When it started reaching a point where I was walking outside and daring people to push me, I left.'

Since Girlfight, she has finished two films: the Spike Lee-produced 3A.M. and The Fast and the Furious, about LA car gangs. She claims she is proud of her bad teeth and crooked nose, and as long she remains so, she will stand out from the starlet crowd.

Girlfight opens on 20 April

Five things about Michelle Rodriguez

1. She had never acted before Girlfight

2. She spent four months learning to box

3. She is of Dominican/ Puerto Rican extraction

4. Her family are Jehovah's Witnesses

5. Costumes for her last film were 'too slutty'
