fields.headline: Just another rock'n'roll brand
fields.standfirst: Forget 'My Generation'. These days it's more a case of 'talkin' about my corporation' as adverts and pop music merge into one
fields.trailText: Forget 'My Generation'. These days it's more a case of 'talkin' about my corporation' as adverts and pop music merge into one
fields.body:
'It's just not cool enough,' Russell Ramsey is telling me. He's just listened to a tape of three of my favourite songs - unknown pleasures from Dwight Twilley, Kak and Cotton Mather - and now he's breaking it to me that my music taste doesn't cut it in the real world. 'It's not edgy, and it's not hip.' I've suspected this might be the case for some time now, but I always imagined that confirmation would come from an anarchic nephew. Not an advertising executive.

Ramsey is creative director on the Levi's account at the advertising agency BBH. I'm 'pitching' songs to him as potential soundtracks for the next Levi's ad, to be shown at the end of the year. In an attempt to learn more about the clandestine world of ad soundtracks, I'm posing as an 'executive music sourcer', someone employed solely to advise ad agencies on the rate of the nation's musical pulse, and pretending that all my three tracks are by new, cutting-edge artists (they were actually recorded in 1974, 1968 and 1998). But Ramsey isn't biting. 'The songs here are too happy,' he complains. 'Our target audience prefers something darker, cooler.'

In the eras of psychedelia and punk, the concept of manufacturers of automobiles, jeans and bathroom products acting as arbiters of musical cool would have been inconceivable. But ever since Nick Kamen flexed his buttocks to the strains of Marvin Gaye's 'I Heard It Through The Grapevine' in 1986, a seismic shift has taken place in the relationship between pop and advertising. Jingles have died out. 'The word is never even used today,' says Ramsey. In the late Eighties and early Nineties, old favourites such as Ben E King's 'Stand By Me', The Clash's 'Should I Stay Or Should I Go' and Steve Miller's 'The Joker' achieved better sales on their re-release than on their original release, all thanks to ad (over)exposure.

Contemporary songs followed in their wake, and a high-profile ad campaign has become a near-guarantee of chart success as a study of the Guinness Book of Hit Singles will attest. America's Business Week newspaper has described advertising as 'the new top 40 radio'. In No Logo, Naomi Klein's anti-branding bestseller of last year, she points out that 'a major ad campaign for Gap or Nike penetrates more nooks and crannies of the culture than a video in heavy rotation on MTV or a cover article in Rolling Stone.'

Ad songs traditionally have the stigma of the one-hit-wonder attached to them (Stiltskin, Babylon Zoo and Mr Oizo soundtracked Levi's ads and haven't been heard of since), but after Moby - a credible dance artist with right-on political beliefs - agreed to lease every song from his 1999 album, Play, to sell more than 600 different products, pop's view of ads has become less sceptical. Soundtracking a commercial has become not only a practical way of establishing a career but of launching one too. Aphroheads (Hula Hoops), Kinobe (Kronenbourg) and Pepe Deluxé (Levi's) are three examples of barely known groups currently using ads to kick-start a fanbase.

Does it depress them that this is the easiest way to gain exposure? 'Not at all,' says James Spectrum from Pepe Deluxé. 'Companies are starting to choose upcoming small artists for ads. Traditionally, only the major artist backed by major companies could get that much exposure.'

'There's been better music on adverts than on Top Of The Pops for years now,' says Mark Blackburn, from Kinobe.

For an increasing number of musicians, an ad isn't so much a 'sell out' as another platform for their own brand. 'I think every self-sufficient artist should turn their music into a brand,' says Spectrum. 'Pepe, as a group, has a strong image or brand and everything we do fits the picture.'

Whether this is conquering the system from within or just self-deluding subservience is up for debate. There's no doubt, though, that it's a mutually convenient scenario for the advertising and music industries that, just as pop has become increasingly manufactured, commercials have become increasingly artistic in their ambitions. The current Ford Mondeo advert features a dreamy procession of brave new world imagery and Dazed and Confused styling, almost managing to make its soundtrack, 'World Looking In' by trip-hop band Morcheeba, seem unpretentious (some feat). 'From Morcheeba's point of view,' says Tracie London-Rowell, director of media licensing at Chrysalis Music, 'the Mondeo campaign is one of high creative impact using beautiful and interesting images that complement an atmospheric track to its full extent.'

How long before music videos and adverts become one inescapable mass? 'It probably wouldn't be an exaggeration to say that 99 per cent of music video directors direct commercials as well,' says Cara Brady from EMI's video division. Vaughan Arnell, Jonathan Glazer, Dawn Shadforth, Chris Cunningham and Roman Coppola are all respected directors who divide their time between music and ads. The Fun Lovin' Criminals declined to make a video for their last single, 'Loco', preferring to star in the Miller beer ad which they soundtracked. Robbie Williams not only sold his music to ads for Pepsi, E-Plus mobile phones and Dreamcast computer games, but his image as well. All we need now is a few more of these and a text bar at the bottom of the screen with the name of the artist and track, and MTV becomes redundant.

'Pop videos and ads are already starting to become the same thing,' says Spectrum. 'Smaller artists will soon be forced to pay the ad companies if their music is used on big name ads. Many companies have started to realise that they are giving the artists both free promotion and money, and have started paying the artists less and less.'

Musicians seem more inclined than ever to see an ad as an art form. A source at EMI, who prefers to remain anonymous, tells me a story about Lenny Kravitz who, following the release of his album 5, found his career at an all-time low: 'The album had stiffed, and Lenny was offered a Peugeot ad for his single, 'Fly Away'. He was approached three times, and he said he didn't do ads. The ad company told him their ads were art, and showed him three examples of their previous work. Lenny called back and said he'd do it. Not long afterwards he had a number one single.' How many of the flamboyant rebel rockers from the past, who Kravitz so slavishly imitates, would want to admit that a car manufacturer rescued their career?

Obviously, some products (cars, clothes) are cooler than others (Toilet Duck, haemorrhoid cream) for a band to get their music behind. Yet it's becoming increasingly difficult to track down a band who hasn't helped sell something somewhere along the line. Among the few are self-styled corporate anarchists Chumbawumba who 'didn't have any hesitation' turning down close on $1 million from Nike, who wanted to use their single, 'Tubthumping', for their 1998 World Cup campaign. 'It depresses us that a piece of music becomes nothing more than a piece of music to flog a lifestyle,' says their singer, Alice Nutter. 'I loved that Moby album until it became one big car advert.'

Australia's Nick Cave also operates on a no sell-out basis.'I get letters from people telling me they've been married or buried their best friend to my songs,' he has said recently, 'and I don't want them to look at the TV and see they buried their friend to a Cornetto ad. I feel some sense of responsibility about that.'

Where ad songs once exploited nostalgia, these days they don't even give us a chance to develop the nostalgia in the first place. Morcheeba's 'World Looking In' has only just been released as a single, yet, thanks to several months of heavy rotation, you'd be hard pushed to associate it with anything other than cars and preposterously well-dressed future families who take five showers a day. The branding of music means nothing is personal or precious any more. The musician gains sales from increased exposure. The corporation gains kudos from associating itself with something 'cool'. The consumer gains a migraine and a recurring nightmare featuring a dancing Hula Hoops packet.

Back on the phone, Russell Ramsey is telling me why Kak's psychedelic fuzz anthem, 'Electric Sailor', is unsuitable for the cutting edge, insouciant world of advertising. 'It's too fast, not cool, and they're obviously trying too hard,' he explains. Something tells me that Kak, who recorded the song in late-Sixties San Francisco when corporations were the enemy, won't be losing too much sleep over this news.

webTitle: They've got no strings to hold them down

fields.headline: They've got no strings to hold them down
fields.standfirst: Britain's string quartets prove there is plenty of scope left for experiment
fields.trailText: Britain's string quartets prove there is plenty of scope left for experiment
fields.body:
Duke Quartet Bishopsgate Hall, London EC2
Kreutzer Quartet Wigmore Hall, London W1
Goldberg Ensemble Festival St John's, Wolverhampton

If you want adventure, just find a good string-quartet concert. That might sound perverse. Their musical menu tends to be regarded as safely stuck in the eighteenth-century conventions from which the form originally sprang. Since Haydn wrote nearly 80 quartets, Mozart 23 and Beethoven 16, you could programme several years' worth of sublime music without needing to step outside that magic triangle. Some groups never do. Others regard Bartok (six) or Shostakovich (15) as the nearest they wish to venture up the north face of modernism.

Yet string chamber music is an area bubbling with activity. Regular readers may begin to tire of the alacrity with which I return to the subject. But the trend is impossible to ignore. Young British groups, following the pioneering example of the Arditti Quartet, are especially fearless in their choice of repertoire, as two concert this week demonstrated. The Duke Quartet, who worked with Blur on the soundtrack of the film Trainspotting (what credential could be more hip?) are regular interpreters of the music of Kevin Volans (b.1949). Now, with the City Music Society, they have commissioned a quartet from the South African composer, his sixth. They gave its world premiere at Bishopsgate Hall on Tuesday, with a repeat performance two days later.

Volans, now resident in Ireland, studied with Stockhausen in the 1970s. (It was Stockhausen, you may recall, who was so frightened of string quartets that when eventually he came to write one he scored it for four helicopters, TV and audio relay equipment as well.) Volans now prefers to follow the less restrictive musical signposts of his native Africa rather than the grids and compass points of the European avant-garde. Neither style is evident in this new piece. The apparently static surface texture and lack of any discernible melody nevertheless suggests a non-Western mood. Not for Volans the outward journeys and safe returns of Western sonata form. Absent, too, is the dialogue between instruments at which this combination of two violins, viola and cello so excels.

Instead, the experience of hearing the piece is like watching footprints disappear in dry sand. Such is the auditory effort required of the listener to notice if anything is going on through the work's 17 minutes duration. Colour takes priority over argument. The players perform against their pre-recorded selves, sometimes leading, at others responding. Sustained chords shift in and out of focus, rocking gently in quiet, puff-like explosions. The result is a work of hypnotic simplicity.

A lingering query was whether the musicians enjoyed playing a piece whose passion is so imperceptible and disembodied? No wonder they let rip at such a breathless pace, and with such febrile intensity in Beethoven's 'Opus 95 in F minor'. This gifted quartet may not have the most mellow of sounds (it was not easy to judge in this hall), but they were never less than ardent.

Drama was scarcely in short supply in George Rochberg's 'String Quartet No3' (1972) played by the Kreutzer Quartet, another British group acclaimed for its eclectic repertoire. The lithe American octogenarian was in attendance and won warm applause for this pivotal work. Rochberg had been a dedicated serialist who came to realise he needed a more expressive mode. He began to write tunes and harmonies, to plunder the past, when to do so was to invite scorn.

The third quartet opens abrasively, as if with a barrage of electric shocks. By the expansive slow movement, the music has become richly eloquent, drawing on Beethoven's 'Opus 132'. The Kreutzer players have an enviably warm and relaxed sound which can, if required, turn trenchant as if at the flick of a switch. They were equally dextrous in the world premiere of David Matthews's 'Aubade', a sharply focused version of his chamber orchestra piece reviewed here a fortnight ago, and in his illuminating transcription of Beethoven's 'Piano Sonata Op.101'. Their Mozart (K590) was less convincing.

The English string tradition provided a focus for a three-day, three-city, three-year initiative in Manchester, Wolverhampton and Leeds organised by the Goldberg Ensemble and the Society for the Promotion of New Music (SPNM). Leeds and Manchester are no strangers to such events. For Wolverhampton, however, not noted as a centre of musical innovation unless I haven't been paying attention, the Goldberg's arrival marked a brave new departure.

This West Midlands town has recently been awarded city status. One result has been a vigorous programme of cleaning and rebuilding. Once sooty Victorian civic buildings such as the Grand Theatre now glow pink. The event took place (in part) in St John's Church, a gracious Georgian edifice situated in a forlorn area. Urban renewal is under way. Dwindling as a place of prayer, it has huge potential as a concert hall.

I watched an SPNM workshop imaginatively run by this season's artistic director Steve Martland working with new string works by two composers, Hywel Davies and Robert Broadley. Martland has a surgeon's eye for pinpointing any compositional weaknesses. Nonetheless he offers his comments in the spirit of sympathetic collaboration. String players require highly detailed instructions as to the sound they are meant to produce. Notation is a highly approximate tool. Much of the session was devoted to this tricky matter. Martland questions were bracingly direct: why did you write it like this? Why not put in a bass line? Don't you think the musicians will find it irritating to play?

No other country in the world has an SPNM, active here since 1943. Nor is any likely to have a Steve Martland. To find both in such an unexpected place has surprised me into setting a new flag on my cultural map for the city of Wolverhampton.

The players perform against their pre-recorded selves, sometimes leading, at others responding. Sustained chords shift in and out of focus, rocking gently in quiet, puff-like explosions. The result is a work of hypnotic simplicity. A lingering query was whether the musicians enjoyed playing a piece whose passion is so imperceptible and disembodied? No wonder they let rip at such a breathless pace, and with such febrile intensity in Beethoven's 'Opus 95 in F minor'. This gifted quartet may not have the most mellow of sounds (it was not easy to judge in this hall), but they were never less than ardent. Drama was scarcely in short supply in George Rochberg's 'String Quartet No3' (1972) played by the Kreutzer Quartet, another British group acclaimed for its eclectic repertoire. The lithe American octogenarian was in attendance and won warm applause for this pivotal work. Rochberg had been a dedicated serialist who came to realise he needed a more expressive mode. He began to write tunes and harmonies, to plunder the past, when to do so was to invite scorn. The third quartet opens abrasively, as if with a barrage of electric shocks. By the expansive slow movement, the music has become richly eloquent, drawing on Beethoven's 'Opus 132'. The Kreutzer players have an enviably warm and relaxed sound which can, if required, turn trenchant as if at the flick of a switch. They were equally dextrous in the world premiere of David Matthews's 'Aubade', a sharply focused version of his chamber orchestra piece reviewed here a fortnight ago, and in his illuminating transcription of Beethoven's 'Piano Sonata Op.101'. Their Mozart (K590) was less convincing. The English string tradition provided a focus for a three-day, three-city, three-year initiative in Manchester, Wolverhampton and Leeds organised by the Goldberg Ensemble and the Society for the Promotion of New Music (SPNM). Leeds and Manchester are no strangers to such events. For Wolverhampton, however, not noted as a centre of musical innovation unless I haven't been paying attention, the Goldberg's arrival marked a brave new departure. This West Midlands town has recently been awarded city status. One result has been a vigorous programme of cleaning and rebuilding. Once sooty Victorian civic buildings such as the Grand Theatre now glow pink. The event took place (in part) in St John's Church, a gracious Georgian edifice situated in a forlorn area. Urban renewal is under way. Dwindling as a place of prayer, it has huge potential as a concert hall. I watched an SPNM workshop imaginatively run by this season's artistic director Steve Martland working with new string works by two composers, Hywel Davies and Robert Broadley. Martland has a surgeon's eye for pinpointing any compositional weaknesses. Nonetheless he offers his comments in the spirit of sympathetic collaboration. String players require highly detailed instructions as to the sound they are meant to produce. Notation is a highly approximate tool. Much of the session was devoted to this tricky matter. Martland questions were bracingly direct: why did you write it like this? Why not put in a bass line? Don't you think the musicians will find it irritating to play? No other country in the world has an SPNM, active here since 1943. Nor is any likely to have a Steve Martland. To find both in such an unexpected place has surprised me into setting a new flag on my cultural map for the city of Wolverhampton.

fields.headline: Bonny and Clyde
fields.standfirst: The desire to make Glasgow miles better continues as a new generation of architects regenerates the city
fields.trailText: The desire to make Glasgow miles better continues as a new generation of architects regenerates the city
fields.body:
BBC Scotland project Pacific Quay, Glasgow

I spent Thursday in Glasgow trying to help the BBC choose an architect for its new Scottish headquarters. The corporation is planning to move from its old home in the city's leafy West End, the Glasgow of Roy Jenkins more than Rab C. Nesbitt, to Pacific Quay, a derelict dock on the edge of Govan. It's the kind of jump that needs to be handled with care if it is not going to provoke the same outcry that exiling radio news to White City did in London.

The most compelling image any of the competitors produced was a grainy, black-and-white photograph unearthed by the Anglo-German team, Sauerbruch Hutton. It was like a vision from a parallel universe, a Glasgow packed with ships from end to end of its river front, in which dock basins on either side of the Clyde transformed what is actually quite a narrow river into a limpid lagoon, spreading deep into the city. It might as well have been a photo of a herd of dinosaurs snacking on extinct varieties of fern.

The ships, funnels looming over dock walls and the giant cranes that could lift railway locomotives off a quay and swing them on to the deck of a freighter, spoke of a time when Glasgow was a swaggering, mettlesome city, where fortunes were made in a hurry and spent equally hurriedly on building a great stone city. It's not just the ships that have vanished. The entire landscape is scarcely recognisable.

The city has visibly shrivelled, reverting to scrub in places. What little new development there was in the 1970s plumbed ever bleaker depths of mediocrity. Perversely, most of the dock basins were filled in and what little water there is left is undisturbed by traffic and marked by floating debris of polystyrene chip boxes and discarded shopping trollies.

Painfully at first, and sometimes to its own surprise, Glasgow is getting a second wind now. The glories of its Victorian centre and its culture-led regeneration strategy gave it another chance. Having successively demolished its original stone tenements and dynamited the concrete towers that replaced them, the city is rebuilding the Gorbals for a third time. It is making up its mind whether it has the boldness to give Zaha Hadid her first chance to build in Britain since the Cardiff Bay Opera House fiasco.

Hadid has emerged as the front-runner, alongside the much more conventional practice of RMJM, in a recent competition to design an innovative housing project on Glasgow Green, the follow-up to the year of architecture in 1999.

If Hadid is picked for the job, she will build a cluster of serpentine apartment blocks swooping out of Glasgow's East End. And on Pacific Quay, Glasgow's most ambitious Millennium Commission-funded project, the Science Centre, is about to open for business. Following in the footsteps of Frank Gehry's Bilbao Guggenheim, Building Design Partnership has designed Britain's first titanium-clad building on a dock pier, surrounded on three sides by water, next to the site that the BBC will occupy.

Part of it houses an Imax cinema, a building type beloved of bureacratic Lottery junkies everywhere struggling to inject a little magic into their schemes for urban regeneration, but unsure as to exactly where to find it. An Imax is just perfect for this kind of thing. For architects, it lends itself to making the kind of funny shapes that they can con vince themselves are avant-garde. And for the adminstrators, there is a reliable supply of new material to project on screen to keep the punters coming back for more, without any of the bother of coming up with anything themselves.

Glasgow's Imax is mercifully not a mirrored sphere like so many of them, from Bristol to Paris. It looks, instead, like a soft tennis ball that has been gently squeezed. It is positioned to play off the sharply sculptural form of the Science Centre's exhibition building that sits on the dock wall like an ocean liner. At the far end is a tower designed originally by Richard Horden, but completed by BDP, that offers visitors a spectacular view over the city. It is designed ingeniously to rotate slowly in the wind, shifting direction like a sail.

These are three giant objects, not unimpressive in themselves, but landmarks rather than cityscape. They conduct a dialogue of a kind with each other and with Norman Foster's not entirely successful Bacofoil-wrapped conference centre across the river.

It's easy to see why BDP and Foster designed their buildings in the way that they did. How else could they make a place out of this ruined waste-tip of a landscape, where the only new life in 40 years had been the building of a lumpen exhibtion hall and an enormous car-park? They were out to make commanding gestures, more like logos than architecture and, as such, they served their purpose.

But what Glasgow needs now is fabric, rather than yet another landmark. And that is what the BBC's new building can be. It offers the prospect of bringing 24-hour-a-day life to the river.

It's a place that will attract the public to studio performances. It's a place that will accommodate programme-makers and administrators. And, as such, it needs to do a lot of things at the same time. It needs primarily to be somewhere the BBC staff will enjoy working. It needs to represent the organisation which, for all its critics, is a major institution in Britain's public and cultural life. It also needs to address the difficult context in the city, but not at the moment part of it.

Two firms - David Chipperfield and Dutch-based practice Mecanoo - have gone forward for a final decision next month, beating a strong field including Richard Rogers as well as Sauerbruch Hutton and Glasgow architects Page and Park. Chipperfield enjoys a high reputation abroad, but it would be his first major building at home.

Stuart Lipton, chairman of the Commission for Architecture, has taken to laying in to developers who hire what he calls 'trophy architects' to secure planning permission for controversial schemes and then drop them for more biddable and obscure replacements with their consents safely in their pockets.

I had always thought that trophy architecture was more to do with the habit that some cities, ambitious to make their mark, have of persuading Richard Meier to design them a museum or hiring Santiago Calatrava to do a signature footbridge on the basis of who they are, rather than for what they will design.

But that is not what is happening on Pacific Quay. All the finalists put a lot into thinking about the specifics of the place and the client - and the two finalists stand a real chance of doing something important for Glasgow.

fields.headline: Her new career starts here
fields.standfirst: Despite illness, Barbara Thompson's musical days are far from over, writes long-time friend  Dave Gelly
fields.trailText: Despite illness, Barbara Thompson's musical days are far from over, writes long-time friend  Dave Gelly
fields.body:
When Barbara Thompson steps out in front of her band, Paraphernalia, at Ronnie Scott's tomorrow night, it will be the start of her final week as a performing musician. Parkinson's disease is putting an end to one of the most remarkable playing careers in European jazz.

For the best part of 35 years, her distinctive saxophone and flute style - warm, open, immensely accomplished but never flashy - has been a constant presence. Jazz fashions and ideologies have come and gone but Barbara has just blithely carried on being Barbara, always herself, always contemporary. Virtually everyone in the land has heard her, although most people probably don't realise it. Heard Andrew Lloyd Webber's Variations, the opening music to The South Bank Show? That's Ms Thompson's flute. Watched A Touch of Frost lately? That haunting soprano saxophone that steals in at intervals behind the action - there she is again.

I'd recognise her anywhere, but then I've known her for a very long time, since 1965, in fact. The first proper jazz ensemble she ever played in was the New Jazz Orchestra. I was in it too, and we sat next to one another in the saxophone section. She married the drummer, my pal Jon Hiseman. The three of us even ran a quintet together for a while, and Barbara tried valiantly to teach me the flute, a doomed enterprise if ever there was one.

She was very young when she first arrived, only just 20. Her father was chief registrar of the Court of Criminal Appeal and she had been educated at a private establishment for young ladies in Harley Street. There was an air of genteel vagueness about her which contrasted strangely with her obvious talent and high-flying ambition.

She formed her own band in 1977 and called it Paraphernalia ('property which the law allowed a married woman to keep and treat as her own' - OED). It has been in existence ever since and many rising young musicians have passed through its ranks. From its beginnings as a pure 'fusion' band, Paraphernalia developed its own unique, eclectic approach and gathered a large and devoted following, especially in Germany, Switzerland and Austria. It is probably fair to say that the two most widely recognised British jazz names in these countries are Barbara Thompson and Courtney Pine.

In a week's time her performing days will come to an end. Barbara explains how it came to this: 'I think it was about seven years ago that I first noticed something. I was playing the Variations at a charity concert and one of the twiddly bits didn't quite come off. I just put it down to a lack of practice, but it wasn't that.

'Other things began giving trouble and I was getting neckaches and stiffness, too. Eventually, I went to see a neurologist and he diagnosed mild Parkinson's. I did what everybody does, went and looked it up, and got the absolute horrors. I was still playing OK, with medication, although it was physically painful, and I'd more or less resigned myself to keep taking the pills and carrying on as usual.

'I still wasn't absolutely sure I had Parkinson's. There were none of the tremors that you normally associate with it. I took some homoeopathic medicine and vitamins and felt a lot better.'

But in the end, Parkinson's was diagnosed. She also learned that regular, heavy doses of medication did more harm than good in the long run. 'All this time, Jon and I had kept the whole thing secret. There were these injections I could take that completely dispelled the symptoms for about an hour - just long enough to play one set. But if the previous band overran, I'd be in trouble. And the injections made me sick, so I had to rest before going on, and we were lying to people, saying I had a bad back. And, you know, needles and all that - goodness knows what they were really thinking. In the end it all became too much.

'We told the band the truth then, and it gradually got around. I could always tell if someone knew. They'd say, "How are you?" in a meaningful kind of way and offer you the comfy chair. But I'm not a cripple. I have still got more delicate movements than most other people. I could actually carry on playing for quite a long time, but I won't play below my best.'

The Ronnie Scott engagement comes at the end of a month-long European tour, and she has been taking the minimum doses necessary to be able to keep playing. When she stops, she hopes to be able to get by on far less. Fortunately, she has a parallel career as a composer which she can turn to.

Barbara published her first composition, a piece for flute and piano, while still at music college, and her list of works is long and impressive. It includes a saxophone concerto, commissioned by the Hanover Radio Symphony Orchestra; settings of Philip Larkin (Love Songs in Age) and Coleridge (I Yet Remain); and a percussion suite for Evelyn Glennie (Rhythms of the Gods). In 1996 she was appointed MBE for services, not just to jazz, but to music.

'At 56, my musical life is definitely not over, but playing was the fun part and I shall miss it. It was very sad having to tell the guys in Paraphernalia that this was the end, after 28 years. It'll really come home to me when we get rid of all the touring stuff, the PA and the truck, and the house starts looking like a house again, not an equipment store.'

At present, she is writing her first musical, based on George DuMaurier's novel Trilby. Having worked closely with Andrew Lloyd Webber, on and off over the years, she says she has a pretty good idea of how much work has to go into the task.

'You just have to keep working away at it from the bottom up, throw away most of it and rewrite the rest. What has really saved my life is the computer. Writing scores by hand would be torture for me now, but the technology makes it easy. If you look on the bright side, you could say that if you're a musician and you're going to get Parkinson's, now's the time to get it.'

Barbara Thompson and Paraphernalia are at Ronnie Scott's, London W1 from tomorrow to 7 April

fields.headline: No ordinary John
fields.standfirst: Politics is child's play in the RSC's thrilling King John. Elsewhere, it's a walk in the woods
fields.trailText: Politics is child's play in the RSC's thrilling King John. Elsewhere, it's a walk in the woods
fields.body:
King John Swan, Stratford
A Russian in the Woods The Other Place, Stratford
Luminosity Barbican Pit, London EC2

Suddenly King John, one of the least performed of Shakespeare's plays, is all the rage. Last month, Northern Broadsides belted it out in Halifax. Now it's at the Swan. And in Gregory Doran's marvellous new production, it comes up shrewd and playful and pertinent. Shot through with humour and despair, this study of political shenanigans presents diplomacy (alias spin) as a series of playground games played for high stakes; it involves a trio of sorrowful women and a host of cynical men.

From the moment that Guy Henry's febrile, flippant King John arrives late to greet the French Ambassador - the trumpets are on their second fanfare and the nobles are rolling their eyes in exasperation - it's clear that the throne is in insolent hands. He rushes in, putting on his crown as if he were pulling on a baseball cap; later, he dangles it in his hand and wags it reprovingly.

Instability is the key to Henry's clever, comical performance, which is enhanced by his tendency to spin out the verse in long, warbling lines. He can behave like an infant having a temper tantrum: stamping his foot at the papal emissary. He can produce cadenzas of high camp: flicking his hands, puffing his cheeks, pretending to swoon as he pronounces the word 'excommunicate'. And he can slither with ease into vicious wiliness.

Why? Because the main principle governing these characters is political expediency: 'commodity', as it's called by the only plain-speaker - Jo Stone-Fewings's strong, yeomanlike Bastard. And this is made clear - terrifically and blackly - in Doran's production, where as soon as anyone sounds lofty, someone else yawns: at one point, characters gabble their speeches over each other in their eagerness to get themselves heard. David Collings is horribly believable as the unctuous papal legate, writhing with mirth as he sets his lethal traps.

King John can easily be staged as a dry discourse on this theme: that's not the case here. Stephen Brimson Lewis's lovely, almost bare design - a bleached wood throne set against a bare brick wall that's coloured white or striped with gold by lighting - is filled with drumming action. Battles are fought to the sound of trumpets by men brandishing flags like bayonets; there's a thrilling theatrical coup when the baby-faced Arthur swoops to his death from the upper gallery. And the three most sympathetic and eloquent characters - all women, played to the hilt - prove once more that Shakespeare was no male chauvinist.

The RSC is on a roll. The saga they've made of the Shakespeare Histories has proved to be compulsory theatre. And now, with Peter Whelan's new play, they're supplying a pungent evocation of a more recent past. Whelan's 1996 play The Herbal Bed took off from Stratford to the West End and Broadway. A Russian in the Woods also deserves a life beyond The Other Place.

A young national serviceman arrives in Berlin in 1950. His job is to guard a deserted army education centre, housed in a once elegant, now dilapidated villa - beautifully conjured up by Simon Higlett's design, with its clutter of army paraphernalia and its shattered, gilt-touched plaster. He has peeped at a Soviet base from the train, and is full of curiosity about the Russians (Turgenev and Chekhov are his bedtime reading). He goes for a walk in the woods, is greeted by a Soviet soldier - and fails to reply. He meets an alluring German girl - and fails to have an affair with her. He runs into a young American soldier, who's not what he seems - and fails to have a homosexual fling. Each encounter involves the possibility of betrayal, and raises questions about what makes someone into an enemy.

You could find two apparently old-fashioned things in this: a rite-of-passage play, and an issue play. You could uncover a novel in the rapid twists of its plot and its study of military peculiarities (such as the cap badge which announces that someone works in secret intelligence). You might also detect autobiography: Whelan was himself a national serviceman in Berlin. But this is a dramatist with a sure touch: what you're aware of while watching is an atmospheric excursion, both bitter and wistful, which wears its complications and its larger resonances lightly.

Robert Delamere, who declared himself a director to watch when he directed The Force of Change at the Royal Court last year, consolidates his growing reputation. Anthony Flanagan makes a promising stage debut as the cross and sensitive young man; Anna Madeley manoeuvres delicately between sweetness and desperation. Louis Hilyer is constantly engaging as the Flash Harry with a secret life.

Alongside their cycle of Shakespeare's Histories, the RSC is running a series of plays by twenty-first century playwrights looking at Britain's past and present. You could make a case for A Russian in the Wood s being one of these. But it's difficult - even this RSC roll has its bumps - to make the case for Luminosity.

The title is a hostage to fortune. You expect the play to cast light, the actors to be radiant, the design to shine. But Nick Stafford's play, directed in the Pit by Gemma Bodinetz, is so furrowed with good intentions and so clogged with over-explicitness that its plot becomes clouded, and everyone behaves rigidly: even the astute Susan Engel is barely able to glimmer.

A young black artist looks into the history of her adoptive white liberal family. Plonk: she finds an ancestor of theirs who engaged in the slave trade. Plonk: she also finds an ancestress of mixed race. Plonk: her investigations turn up some handy metaphors - 'There is no blackness within diamonds - only colours.' Plonk: the question of the family's responsibility for its past is laboriously debated. The characters are pieces of prose that have been cut up and marched around the stage. Kandis Cook's minimal, anti-evocative design - a scoop of glittering stones scattered at the front of a bare white set - looks like something you might find in the foyer of a bank.

Last month, Northern Broadsides belted it out in Halifax. Now it's at the Swan. And in Gregory Doran's marvellous new production, it comes up shrewd and playful and pertinent. Shot through with humour and despair, this study of political shenanigans presents diplomacy (alias spin) as a series of playground games played for high stakes; it involves a trio of sorrowful women and a host of cynical men. From the moment that Guy Henry's febrile, flippant King John arrives late to greet the French Ambassador - the trumpets are on their second fanfare and the nobles are rolling their eyes in exasperation - it's clear that the throne is in insolent hands. fields.headline: Becks? There's posh
fields.standfirst: It's the country's richest art prize. So where's the controversy?
fields.trailText: It's the country's richest art prize. So where's the controversy?
fields.body:
Beck's Futures Two ICA, London SW1 until 20 May

Beck's Futures, the massive art prize that nobody yet loves to hate, is to be awarded on 10 April. There will be beer, speeches and sizeable cheques for each of the short-listed artists. And despite the fact that one of them likes to work with catfood and dental-floss, don't expect any tabloid outrage. There will be no spats or recriminations, no critical calumny, no fanged abuse from the art world.

This doesn't mean that the show of short-listed art at the ICA is a miracle of incontestable talent. Nor is it because the prize, despite being the biggest in Britain, has not yet made it into our TV schedules. It's more because the event centres on private patronage and is, in its second year, still so new and unchallenged. If an art-loving brewery decides to spend its beer money on up-and-coming artists - 'Tomorrow's talent today' runs the slogan, canny in its caution - then who's going to quibble with that?

Well, plenty of people might if the competition ran by the customary rules, according to which a small group of judges, usually gallerists and curators, offer further preferment to an equally small group of artists by ignoring all conflicts of interest. But Beck's is no closed shop. The judges, including Zadie Smith this year, and Jarvis Cocker last, don't choose from the art shows they just happen to have seen. They make their selection from a vast list of candidates supplied by nearly 200 nominators, most of them fellow artists. So two things can already be said in favour of this award - it doesn't take dictation from museums or markets and it must say something about what today's artists prize.

To find out what they prize you need only consult the catalogue, in which artists talk about each other with absolute reverence: 'Brian Griffiths's art is evidence of a magic seldom realised beyond childhood' (he makes large and artless toys out of tissue paper, glue and cardboard). 'D.J. Simpson's works casts the readymade panel in the role of pigmented object that is desired belatedly but unsarcastically' (Simpson works with a routing plane, gouging lines out of laminated board).

At the ICA, Simpson 0is showing a panel so big it has to be propped against the wall. The incised lines, which expose the rippled layers of wood beneath the shiny black Formica, amount to a kind of painterly abstraction by other means. The craftsmanship is superb - manoeuvring that inflexible tool through such resistant material - and the effect is both austere and seductive. But this is hardly one in the eye for Paul Klee, as claimed by his admirers in the catalogue.

Simpson, at 34, is apparently tipped as a potential winner of the £24,000 overall award. He has had solo shows in London, Amsterdam and Dusseldorf. Griffiths has quite a bit of career behind him too, his earliest endeavours long since collected by Charles Saatchi. Simon Bill up and came several years ago, although the oval paintings at the ICA are by far his best, with their deadpan humour and simple facture. In Arabeggsque, an exotic fledgling hatches out of the canvas; in Threw a Monkey in the Sea, the monkey's puzzled face appears in sea-green cameo, as if pressed up against a submarine porthole.

But nobody, not even the most dogged footslogger of Hoxton and Shoreditch, could be familiar with all the work in this show. Gemma Iles, for example, is still a student at the Royal College of Art and her photographic tableaux - mute relationships between non-committal figures - aren't quite as mysteriously unresolved as they one day might be. Clare Woods, in her twenties, has mastered the art of Gary Hume, though her subject matter is pure Blair Witch Project - deep woods in sepulchral darkness. Presumably, Hume doesn't find this homage, since he is one of this year's judges.

Dan Holdsworth is still turning out melodramatic intimations of doom. His photographs of deserted hypermarkets and cliff edges by night, strategically customised with overlays of sinister red light, pile cliché on menacing cliché. David Burrows's work acts as a kind of comic antidote, the aftermath of something that never actually happened.

Burrows's works with what he calls 'plastic-foamtastic', a brightly coloured material normally used for bath toys. He uses it to create cartoon crime scenes that are later photographed - arson at a party, clothes, furniture, pizza boxes, all going up in Disneyfied flames. The fantastical blossoms he has made for the gallery floor double as slo-mo explosions, joke bombshells going off in a flurry of multicoloured petals.

Tim Stoner's paintings also borrow something from other media. He skims his imagery from leisure-industry ads - families skipping through the brine, folk dancing beneath the bunting - and then reduces the motif to a silhouette, backlit with an eerie, end-of-the-world glow. Or is it just sunlight? Apparently clear and simple, his pictures are irreducibly strange, their precision skilfully undermined by his method that gives each painting the blurred and ghostly look of a misaligned, three-colour screenprint.

Tomorrow's talent turns out to look remarkably like today's: quirkish, low-volt, opposed to movements and, I suppose, unsarcastic. None of these artists would be out of place in a commercial gallery, though that's not saying much in this bulimic market. What Beck's Futures gives them is a broader public address in London, Edinburgh, Liverpool and New York, where this show ends its tour. The prize itself is irrelevant. All that matters in an overcrowded art scene is visibility and patronage.

webTitle: They've conquered the NME. Now for those GCSEs

fields.headline: They've conquered the NME. Now for those GCSEs
fields.trailText: Sugababes Notre Dame Hall, London
fields.body:
Sugababes Notre Dame Hall, London

When A1 beat favourite Craig David at this year's Brits, he wasn't the real victim that night. The Best Newcomer Award should have gone to Sugababes, the soulful north London trio just shy of their GCSEs. When their spunky debut single 'Overload' landed in the Top 10 last autumn, the music press breathed a sigh of relief. Here, at last, was a teen sensation with panache and talent. Most importantly, they weren't recruited through the small ads by a rapacious Svengali.

The band was born when Mutya Buena and Keisha Buchanan met Siobhan Docherty at a party and discovered a shared love of harmonies and soul divas. While borrowing their empowering attitude from American R&B royalty such as Destiny's Child and En Vogue, there was a distinctly British feel to their impressive album One Touch, which was partly produced by former Massive Attack collaborator Cameron McVey. It was more than just the sharp two-step beats and sweet interchangeable vocals - their lyrics had attitude but were neither bombastic nor explicit. They could be dismissive, as in the sly track 'Same Old Story', but didn't try to be too streetwise.

These girls are accessible rather than aspirational. While their American cousins are label queens, Sugababes, no doubt partly due to their age, are high street chic. That's not to say they have much in common with the cheap'n'cheerful confection that is Billie Piper. Or the Spice Girls, who failed when they tried to reinvent themselves as soul divas. The obvious comparison is with All Saints, with whom they share a record label, production team and dress sense. But the Saints were never that credible after their first album, relying instead on forests of newsprint to boost sales.

Sugababes look more like the real thing, but tonight is only their third live appearance. Their credibility is bolstered by NME 's sponsorship of the current three-date mini-tour for invited fans only (a sign of the time, but what - you have to wonder - do the music paper's readers think of this strange relationship?)

Predictably, the striking thing about Sugababes is their doe-eyed appearance. Of course, they're young but you don't expect them to look so fresh-faced. Even in trendy made-up and clubbing gear they wouldn't pass an ID check.

As accomplished as they seem to be in the recording studio, they are understandably tentative performers, which makes them rather endearing. They amble onstage without fanfare, singing 'Look at Me'. This song about over-protective parents includes the line: 'I know I'm still young with no life experience/ But can't I learn from my mistakes not yours.' It seems particularly apt. While their four-piece band get happy and funky behind them, the trio look like they are concentrating too hard to really enjoy themselves. This has the effect of making them seem as cool and aloof as those backing singers in the Human League. Occasionally they flash finger signs at each other to get in position for the next stage of choreography.

At the end of the gig Mutya has a nervous giggle with the other two that suggests she's glad it's over and there were no cock-ups.

Of course they're not really standoffish. They invite a boy on stage halfway through the set, plonk him on a stool, and coyly slink around while he gazes up at them in adoration. Things further improve during the stylish minor key R&B of 'Overload'. Sadly, that bouncy snare sound is absent but it's still a winning rendition.

During the En Vogue flavoured 'The Real Thing', the girls, increasingly loose- limbed, start to strut. For the encore, 'Run for Cover', they strike Charlie's Angels poses and start vogueing. But that's the last song. On the evidence of tonight, Keisha is the most natural and confident performer and Siobhan is the most bashful. Of course, these are early days for the band and their assurance is certain to rise along with their record sales. Overall, this has been an efficient albeit slightly awkward performance. They're still a band to watch - but just give them a bit more time.

webTitle: A drip, drip, drip of slow torture

fields.headline: A drip, drip, drip of slow torture
fields.standfirst: Designer Butoh for new-age audiences at Sadler's Wells
fields.trailText: Designer Butoh for new-age audiences at Sadler's Wells
fields.body:
Sankai Juku Sadler's Wells, EC1
Phoenix Dance Company Richmond Theatre, Surrey
English National Ballet New Victoria Theatre, Woking

Sankai Juku have become the style queens of the Butoh performance circuit. Based in Paris, they now have little in common with the Japanese 'dance of darkness' that developed after the Second World War. Instead of images of death and deformity, Sankai Juku deal in universal uplift. Their semi-naked figures are bathed in golden light, their white body-powder supplied by the luxury cosmetics firm, Shiseido. This is designer Butoh for new-age audiences.

Hibiki, by the company's director and principal performer Ushio Amagatsu, is more installation art than dance. Water drips into giant contact lenses which serve as refracting pools of light. Fine sand covers the stage, bearing the traces of five slow-moving male acolytes. Amagatsu is slowest of all. Red seeps from his ears, his brain bleeding from intense concentration. It's make-up, lipstick for the lobes.

Sadler's Wells guarantees a captive audience. Tightly packed seats with no central aisles mean that only those on the peripheries could sneak away during the 85-minute show. Some slept, others wept, moved by their contemplation of the stage picture. For me, it was water torture. As soon as the performers speed up, they turn into poor contemporary dancers; they rely on slowness to engender respect.

Amagatsu presents himself for admiration, as though his limited range of gestures and grimaces were a spiritual gift. His curtain calls are a giveaway. He milks the central spot, curtseying again and again with conspicious humility. Then, as the sententious music swells, he waves majestically, acclaiming a standing ovation as we lurch to our feet and struggle for an exit.

In marketing terms, Sankai Juku has the advantage of a brand image, even if it means that each show is much like the last. Phoenix Dance Company , based in Leeds, has lost its identity and its funders' support. It is to close after the current tour ends in May. As its name promises, however, it is to be relaunched by next year. The tour programmes celebrate its 20-year existence, combining elements of the repertoire from the past 10 years.

A film collage covers pauses for costume changes between extracts in 19: Rewind and Come Again. Part-documentary, part-fantasy, the film makes more sense if you know the company's history. Phoenix began as a black boy-band of dance students, telling the world what it was like to be them. They grew up, split up; girls came in, matured, moved on; the made-in-Leeds brand blurred as the group embraced dancers and choreographers from elsewhere.

The outstanding works were by Americans (Bebe Miller, Tom Jobe, Shapiro and Smith) who had no direct connection with the company's roots. In this collage context, the British in-house pieces don't speak for themselves, nor do the dramatic dances to inspirational texts. A young black student in the Richmond audience chatted to her friend about a duet 'to that politician talking'. The speech is Martin Luther King's 'I have a dream', used by Gary Lambert for his 1990 Longevity, already ancient history.

The company's education projects will keep going during Phoenix's closure. The search is on for a new artistic director, following the abrupt departure of Thea Nerissa Barnes. The dancers (from Africa, Europe and Jamaica as well as Britain) give the touring show everything they've got. Phoenix flickers brightly in its death throes.

English National Ballet has, temporarily, split into two groups to tour to smaller theatres. The chamber ballets worked well in Woking, as part of the town's fourth Dance Umbrella. There is a lack of boldness, however, that makes the company look politely English, which most of its dancers are not. Part of the problem is sluggish playing by the pared-down orchestra: Apollo, Balanchine's early Stravinsky ballet, needs rigorous playing as well as dancing to make its sun-god soar.

The Grand Pas from Paquita should be an extravagant showcase, sending the audience home laughing. In Derek Deane's absence through illness, some of the dancers have lost their sparkle; Erina Takahashi in the leading role is a pearl rather than a diamond. In the ranks, though, there is enough young talent to make you smile with pleasure.

He milks the central spot, curtseying again and again with conspicious humility. Then, as the sententious music swells, he waves majestically, acclaiming a standing ovation as we lurch to our feet and struggle for an exit. In marketing terms, Sankai Juku has the advantage of a brand image, even if it means that each show is much like the last. Phoenix Dance Company , based in Leeds, has lost its identity and its funders' support. It is to close after the current tour ends in May. As its name promises, however, it is to be relaunched by next year. The tour programmes celebrate its 20-year existence, combining elements of the repertoire from the past 10 years. A film collage covers pauses for costume changes between extracts in 19: Rewind and Come Again. Part-documentary, part-fantasy, the film makes more sense if you know the company's history. Phoenix began as a black boy-band of dance students, telling the world what it was like to be them. They grew up, split up; girls came in, matured, moved on; the made-in-Leeds brand blurred as the group embraced dancers and choreographers from elsewhere. The outstanding works were by Americans (Bebe Miller, Tom Jobe, Shapiro and Smith) who had no direct connection with the company's roots. In this collage context, the British in-house pieces don't speak for themselves, nor do the dramatic dances to inspirational texts. A young black student in the Richmond audience chatted to her friend about a duet 'to that politician talking'. The speech is Martin Luther King's 'I have a dream', used by Gary Lambert for his 1990 Longevity, already ancient history. The company's education projects will keep going during Phoenix's closure. The search is on for a new artistic director, following the abrupt departure of Thea Nerissa Barnes. The dancers (from Africa, Europe and Jamaica as well as Britain) give the touring show everything they've got. Phoenix flickers brightly in its death throes. English National Ballet has, temporarily, split into two groups to tour to smaller theatres. The chamber ballets worked well in Woking, as part of the town's fourth Dance Umbrella. There is a lack of boldness, however, that makes the company look politely English, which most of its dancers are not. Part of the problem is sluggish playing by the pared-down orchestra: Apollo, Balanchine's early Stravinsky ballet, needs rigorous playing as well as dancing to make its sun-god soar. The Grand Pas from Paquita should be an extravagant showcase, sending the audience home laughing. In Derek Deane's absence through illness, some of the dancers have lost their sparkle; Erina Takahashi in the leading role is a pearl rather than a diamond. In the ranks, though, there is enough young talent to make you smile with pleasure.

fields.headline: We're just dieting for it...
fields.standfirst: Why do women want to look like skeletons, asks  Gaby Wood . Is the celebrity-obsessed media to blame, or is body-sculpting just the new DIY?
fields.trailText: Why do women want to look like skeletons, asks  Gaby Wood . Is the celebrity-obsessed media to blame, or is body-sculpting just the new DIY?
fields.body:
If you invented a game called fantasy glossies, in which imaginary magazines had to be put together using the most marketable elements of everything on the newsagent's shelf, you might, in the more surreal stages of it, come up with something that fused the popularity of dieting mags with the celebrity voyeurism of Hello! As a joke, to show the blatant truth of these publications' appeal, you might call it 'Celebrity Bodies'. Clearly, this game has been played in the offices of Emap Publications, and the winner has been put straight into production.

Celebrity Bodies was launched last Thursday - with a cover that screams 'Geri: the TRUTH behind this body!' - and has instantly come under attack. The anorexia debate has reared its head again, while the magazine's editor, Alison Hall, explains that her publication, which reveals slimming secrets of the stars, is encouraging exercise and 'nutritionally sound diets'. 'I think everybody wants a beautiful body,' Hall told me. 'We are reflecting public interest. We've researched it. People want the celebrities, they want the diets. We're not forcing it on the public.'

And that is precisely what is interesting: why is there a demand for it? The magazine itself is cheap, bright and cheerful, and therefore arguably less 'damaging', in terms of portraying an unattainable look or lifestyle, than something like Vogue. On the other hand, Vogue is clearly about dreaming of glamour, whereas Celebrity Bodies claims you can have it, if only you follow the meal plans. Hall says that 25 to 35-year-old women, the target market for Celebrity Bodies, 'are on a diet probably more than any other age group. I think it's around 48 per cent'. (That is, 48 per cent of women in that age group are on a diet at any given time.) 'And then you look at the celebrity market,' Hall continues, 'and their circulation has increased by about 142 per cent in the last year.'

There's no point in attacking Hall's new magazine as the root of something dangerous: clearly, it is a symptom rather than a cause. But what, exactly, is going on?

Celebrities are the saints and gurus of our age. They get thinner and thinner before our eyes. They are not the next Gandhi or Bobby Sands, they are not the descendants of medieval nuns - and yet here is Geri Halliwell, performing a new kind of disappearing act for all to see, never saying if it is a protest or a prophesy. This week, OK! magazine printed a photograph of Geri coming out of a meeting of Overeaters Anonymous; Liz Hurley was recently quoted as saying that she worries about her weight; and Uma Thurman announced some weeks ago that she thought she was fat. It is often said that the famous encourage anorexia in the rest of us, but the equation works the other way, too: with the eyes of the world upon them, who wouldn't become obsessed with their looks? We adore our celebrities - devour them even, and as we consume their image, they shrink in size, as if we were starving them by our gaze.

In Franz Kafka's short story 'The Hunger Artist', the eponymous hero sits in a cage in the centre of town for 40 days - the longest his manager thinks he can remain popular in any one place - then moves on to the next stop on his tour. At one time, the narrator tells us, the hunger artist was extremely popular: people would reserve seats, and come to see him 'because it was fashionable'. But after a while, the fashion wore off, and he ends up a forgotten circus attraction. 'Perhaps it was not his fasting at all that had made him so extremely emaciated,' Kafka writes, 'perhaps what had so emaciated him was simply dissatisfaction with himself.' He starves himself until he is literally invisible, and when the circus manager wonders why an empty cage has not been put to some use, he finds the tiny hunger artist buried beneath the straw. The artist's last words are that his act should not be admired, because 'I have to fast, I can't help it'. It turns out not to have been a performative feat, but a psychological ailment instead.

Hunger artists, or body artists, is what celebrities have become. They are often admired more for their bodies than for what they do; now, with this new magazine, even when there is little to admire about their work, at least we can revere their fitness regime. But what is the nature of their 'art'? Are we applauding something we should be helping to treat?

In her book called The Hunger Artists, Maud Ellmann traces this phenomenon back to the end of the war in Vietnam. 'Having left America in 1970,' she writes, 'I found when I returned in 1978 that the anti-war protestors of the 1960s had become the health fanatics of the 1970s, and that all the passions that had fuelled their activism had been redirected inward into a preoccupation with their own physique, intensified by phobias about the toxins, like additives, cholesterol and calories, which threatened to invade the body, cloaked in the benevolent disguise of food. In a sense the war had come home, for it was now our bodies that were under siege, rather than those of the Vietnamese; and only the most unremitting vigilance could save us from the chemicals bombarding us from every supermarket shelf.'

You could extend this theory to suggest that the battle within women's bodies is now raging because of the absence of any strong political causes. Equally, you could say that guilt, post-war or otherwise, is the most consistent feature of our relationship to our bodies. Jane Fonda, Ellmann's prime example, admitted only recently that she had suffered from anorexia and bulimia for 25 years.

Yet so much polemical attention is devoted to actual, physically visible eating disorders that evidence of something much more fundamental is ignored. To focus so obsessively on the body - whether the message is about being thin or being fat - is already a form of mental disorder. As Florence Nightingale wrote, as early as the 1850s: 'One would think women had no heads or hearts, by the total indifference of the public towards them. Our bodies are the only things of any consequence.' The problem is that the female body is so much in the foreground - not, like in the nineteenth century, as a vision to be admired, but as a theatre of the most self-destructive narcissism.

What is really dangerous about the omnipresent celebrity body is not that it causes eating disorders but that it makes them harder to diagnose. How can women who really have a problem know they are ill when the whole world is colluding with them, and everything points to the idea that their beliefs about themselves are right?

fields.headline: Watch with amazement
fields.standfirst: We stare at it, we argue with it, we love it, we hate it, yet the most popular medium of our age is still not acknowledged as a great civilising force.  Melvyn Bragg  says it's time we celebrated TV
fields.trailText: We stare at it, we argue with it, we love it, we hate it, yet the most popular medium of our age is still not acknowledged as a great civilising force.  Melvyn Bragg  says it's time we celebrated TV
fields.body:
The claim of the old Panorama on the BBC - a bold claim then, rather wistful repeated now - was that television is a 'window on the world'. I would say that it is not so much a window as a mirror - the mirror - and, in some ways, the maker of our society.

The previous form you can compare it with - apart from radio, but radio is its older sibling, its bloodline - is the novel. There, in what Henry James called that 'loose and baggy monster', was, and is, the capacity to incorporate everything. In the novel you could, and can, find the tough and the tender, the adventurous and the domestic, the intellectual and the visceral, the panoramic and the microscopic, the sexy and the chaste, war and peace. But although the novel has ambitions to let nothing escape its elastic kingdom, it is difficult to see how we can find analogies in print for Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?, or Match of the Day, or News at Ten - that ever-rolling narrative - or Cilla Black. In any competition in size, television wins.

Is it an art? Well, artists certainly work in it: writers, directors, actors, cameramen, film and tape editors. Whether an agglomeration of artists turns a medium into an art form is a nice point. No doubt theses are on their way.

The fact that on this one medium you can see and hear the crisis in the Middle East, the grace of a football match, the wit of a Python, the world of a Bennett, the hushed expertise of David Attenborough means it is a different order of communication, not outstripping all others - by no means - but through its unique combination of mass appeal and minority grip, able to reflect and act on society in ways never before thought possible.

At the heart of it there is an interesting paradox. We all talk about 'television' or 'the telly' as if it were one thing. But we rarely say 'print'. We talk of 'the novel', even those who feel a little queasy that all the variety of novels can be sheltered under one umbrella, but if we were to talk of 'print', we would have to include newspapers, of course, and thousands of magazines, textbooks, poetry, history, philosophy, theology, psychology, play texts. Go into a big bookshop or newsagent: that's print.

To say: 'I saw this terrible or marvellous thing in print the other day' or: 'I can't bear/don't watch print' would be ridiculous. Yet television is every bit as various as print - its several strata of drama, the plays of Dennis Potter, the explosions of Jimmy McGovern or Lynda La Plante, the probing of Lucy Gannon, Alan Bleasdale's volcanoes, Alan Bennett's fine brushstrokes, Alan Plater's disturbing reality, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton, John Cleese, on it goes; Victoria Wood's shrewd use of comedy, the teams on the Street, EastEnders, The Bill - each with its own line, style, attack. And this is only the beginning.

There are documentaries, often with directors of the highest order - social, political and arts documentaries fit to stand alongside the feature films or the plays of the day. There is the ingenious funfare of entertainment, threading in traditions which go back to the ancient strollers and medieval travelling players. There are horror stories - real and imagined - as grisly as any Grimm, and fairy stories imagined and real as 'Rapunzel', as strange as 'Rip Van Winkle', as boisterous as 'The Three Bears'. And sport - the display of excellence on so many fields, legends of often unimaginable achievement, coming into our houses. There is the dark side; when has prostitution and its accompanying violence ever been examined as often or watched by so many? When has the black past - Hitler, Stalin - and the bleak present - East Timor, Aids, famines - been as well reported, as relentlessly fed into minds which sometimes do not know how to, do not want to cope with it.

Perhaps this is the reason for the paradox. We want to keep this thing tame. We need to keep it under control. So we lump it all together and call it television, the telly, hoping thereby to pretend it has so much less of the influence than it clearly has. Perhaps we fear it. And so we use the sameness of the delivery system - that tame little box - to be dismissive of it. Perhaps we are ashamed of the hold it has on us - or, if not on us, then on the nation at large. For even if we claim we do not much watch it, what is the latest conversation at the water cooler?

It is Vanessa Feltz in Celebrity Big Brother and poor Darius, dumped from Popstars and then dumped on by the world and its mother. It is those terrible pictures of that earthquake in India, that avalanche of mud in Italy; it is the arrival of our new heroine yachtswoman or Steven Redgrave's fifth gold in five Olympics. It is the awful sight of those cattle and sheep being slung onto funeral pyres with echoes of Viking burials, medieval plagues, terrible massacre. Perhaps that secret shame breeds guilt for, after all, what are we doing but just watching, sitting and watching? It's a state of mind and body that we do not resent so much in an uncomfortable theatre, say, watching a depressingly poor play but which easily moves us to guilt if we are on the couch watching an excellently scripted edition of Morse.

In a sense, by trivialising the medium, we can trivialise the message, and that, I believe, is what is really going on in our relationship with television. We do not want it to have the importance in our lives which, in the lives of so many - people of all classes, types, backgrounds, incomes, tastes, aspirations, ambitions - it does have. This, probably, is why self-appointed elites are so quick to downgrade and dismiss television: they do not like its power, its hold on the people, just as the high-born admirals hated Nelson's command of the ordinary seamen - 'and yet the whole Fleet loved him, damn their eyes'. Television is a force which seems to threaten their hold on the reins. Yet television does not threaten older forms. It often gives them new life.

The history of television is very like that of other new media. Thus the novel, which began life in the fertile gutters of melodrama and sensation, was dismissed as a gross intruder into the salon of letters until great practitioners and passionate readers simply swept it into power. A parallel story describes the early cinema. What those forms have in common is that they are new, they rely mostly on the common people coming on board to get under way. And all of them have, initially most of all, a mesmerising quality.

So the big and, to some, the frightening, the inconceivable and unacceptable message is that television is our real national theatre. It is British filmmaking sometimes at its best. It is the true UK comedy store and national stadium for sports. It is the planet at a switch and the stars in their constellations; and it takes us right back to the fire at the mouth of the cave, warming us and protecting us.

Yet, as David Chater wrote in the Times recently: 'There is a common assumption that television rots your brain, destroys your attention span and ruins your health.' He described the concern of his friends for his mental health after hearing that he had become a television critic. The response of his friends is not uncommon, I suggest, among those whose assumption is that only they hold the keys to real cultural truth, quality and worth. As Chater pointed out: 'A great deal of television in this country is of astonishingly high calibre.'

His list of such programmes was impressive. Any fair-minded and intelligent viewer could come up with a similar list. Why is it, then, that Chater's undoubtedly intelligent friends chose to be so ignorant, prejudiced and snobbish? Snobbish is easy - it's still the wearisome badge of authority worn by those desperate to be different without the talent to be distinctive. I even know people who announce proudly that they never watch television as if that alone is the equivalent of a first-class honours degree. Once again, I suggest, this asinine or panic-stricken reaction is, in fact, a tribute to the force of a new medium so strange and yet so ordinary that it is very difficult to grapple with.

What in the broadest terms is the message of that medium at the moment? It is both traditional and remarkable. It is that we want to see ourselves, warts and all. In every society the elite has wanted to see itself in its culture: pharaohs begat monuments to pharaohs; Greeks begat sculpture and drama and philosophy reflecting the ideas and dilemmas and images of that most extraordinary of peoples; Elizabethans begat stories of monarchs and nobles, though the rise of the gentry showed through, as did the demands of the groundlings in the shape of the comic characters. But, largely, until quite recently, ordinary people, what used to be called working-class people, were, in our art and literature, caricatures, clowns, servants - or absent. Mostly the latter.

On television they have, for the first time in the history of our culture, taken over the world. We see ourselves, us, the mass. We are now the cultural equation, we are centre stage. We see ourselves in EastEnders or Coronation Street ; we see ourselves in Popstars and Big Brother ; we see ourselves in The Royle Family , watching them watching; we see ourselves on Cilla and Barrymore - but it goes further. Ordinary people are now called in for what were once thought of as positions above them. For example, 'ordinary' farmers com ment on foot and mouth; 'ordinary' witnesses tell us of train crashes, earthquakes, wars. 'Ordinary' lads play football, which demonstrates the beautiful game of our time and commentators strive to be as ordinary as they can manage, to reflect the voice of the crowd.

The airwaves seethe with phone-ins, the referendum of the ratings becomes a sometimes brutal instrument of democracy in organising the schedules; at last, those who were quite recently called 'the great unwashed' now rule the waves, and not before time. Television is the New World, the America of the arts.

Moreover, the demand is that the people be as unmediated as possible. Of course there is art and craft in the construction of Coronation Street, EastEnders, The Bill, Big Brother, but the important issue is that it seems real. No matter that Ken Barlow has had a more varied love life than Valentino (mind you, he does live in Lancashire), he must retain ordinariness. That is the point. If the term had not been appropriated for political purposes, I would call this the 'People's Art Form'.

There is of course at the moment - these are early days, it is a new medium - plenty to carp about. Even if there were not, we British would truffle it out. From having had the largest empire the world has ever known, which depended entirely on self-confidence, we have gone instantly to the top of the league of complainers - about ourselves. And television has joined the weather as a part of our daily moan.

And there is cause for criticism. The medium at present has no place for the message - the life, the style, the character - of introverts, the quieter, the more thoughtful, the less drunk, the less unlicensed. These people are often those who make the world go round. Think of Darwin, of Freud, Newton, their reach through the centuries. Although television can deal brilliantly with such figures in documentary form, its current tone is anti-introvert. Loudness, gregariousness, lad- and ladettishness are imperative. You must be larky, joshy, noisy, especially if you are young. Where are the series called Men Behaving Philosophically or Women Thinking Deeply or The Examined Life, The Stiff Upper Lip? Perhaps the form itself, like much cinema and theatre, cannot finally give to that introverted part of us the same satisfactions we derive from novels and poetry and music. But I do feel it ought to try harder.

Similarly, it is proving dif ficult for television fully to serve minorities. One problem is that minorities are so numerous and television is so expensive and, until recently, limited in its space. This is now changing radically. Look at the minority to which I have devoted my television career - the arts. The fight is on to convert the indisputable wide interest in the arts - more people went to the Tate Modern one Saturday afternoon (75,000) than saw the game at Wembley - into an integrated audience which fills a whole channel. It's out there. The conversion is the challenge, as with any new faith.

At one stage, no one would have called the novel art, nor film, nor radio. So what of television itself? Let's go to the least likely art form, the bedrock of television, the belittlingly named soap opera. Has that saturating message from the medium a claim as art? It is, I think, fun to couple it with its polar opposite, the latest art as in artefact, sculpture, conceptual work. For instance, is Coronation Street likely to be more valued and influential in the long run than the urinal named as art by Marcel Duchamp? Because Duchamp declared a urinal to be art so it was, agreed thousands of artists following him, thousands of critics, hundreds of dealers,museums and collectors. Tracey Emin's unmade bed is in a direct line from the urinal. Duchamp's urinal is an important, even key icon of twentieth-century art.

But might Coronation Street - whose characters would not be too struck on Duchamp's lavatory and the idea that it is worth several million pounds - also be art? Might the flag-bearer of the big message on television for the last 40 years outlive the lavatory?

Martin Scorsese once said that if he wanted to know what late twentieth-century culture was like, he would record the whole of a few weeks on television and that would tell him. When Peter Brook, the distinguished theatre director, and his friend, the late Poet Laureate Ted Hughes, went to Africa and India to conduct their experiments in basic theatre reaching for the profound, they extolled, as so many do, the village storyteller, the man - most often a man - who told the tales which kept the community enthralled, tales very local, rich in particular reference; endless tales, tales which were deeply sown into the fabric of the lives of those they addressed.

It sounds rather like Coronation Street, although of course it takes a gulp of faith to admit it. So: will it be the lavatory or the Street?

It's tempting to say at last the people will decide.

This is an edited extract of Melvyn Bragg's Edward Boyle Memorial Lecture, given at Leeds University, which can be seen tonight on Artsworld at 9pm, and again on Monday at 4pm. Available on Sky Digital 199. To subscribe call 08705 900 700
