There are documentaries, often with directors of the highest order - social, political and arts documentaries fit to stand alongside the feature films or the plays of the day. There is the ingenious funfare of entertainment, threading in traditions which go back to the ancient strollers and medieval travelling players. There are horror stories - real and imagined - as grisly as any Grimm, and fairy stories imagined and real as 'Rapunzel', as strange as 'Rip Van Winkle', as boisterous as 'The Three Bears'. And sport - the display of excellence on so many fields, legends of often unimaginable achievement, coming into our houses. There is the dark side; when has prostitution and its accompanying violence ever been examined as often or watched by so many? When has the black past - Hitler, Stalin - and the bleak present - East Timor, Aids, famines - been as well reported, as relentlessly fed into minds which sometimes do not know how to, do not want to cope with it. Perhaps this is the reason for the paradox. We want to keep this thing tame. We need to keep it under control. So we lump it all together and call it television, the telly, hoping thereby to pretend it has so much less of the influence than it clearly has. Perhaps we fear it. And so we use the sameness of the delivery system - that tame little box - to be dismissive of it. Perhaps we are ashamed of the hold it has on us - or, if not on us, then on the nation at large. For even if we claim we do not much watch it, what is the latest conversation at the water cooler? It is Vanessa Feltz in Celebrity Big Brother and poor Darius, dumped from Popstars and then dumped on by the world and its mother. It is those terrible pictures of that earthquake in India, that avalanche of mud in Italy; it is the arrival of our new heroine yachtswoman or Steven Redgrave's fifth gold in five Olympics. It is the awful sight of those cattle and sheep being slung onto funeral pyres with echoes of Viking burials, medieval plagues, terrible massacre. Perhaps that secret shame breeds guilt for, after all, what are we doing but just watching, sitting and watching? It's a state of mind and body that we do not resent so much in an uncomfortable theatre, say, watching a depressingly poor play but which easily moves us to guilt if we are on the couch watching an excellently scripted edition of Morse. In a sense, by trivialising the medium, we can trivialise the message, and that, I believe, is what is really going on in our relationship with television. We do not want it to have the importance in our lives which, in the lives of so many - people of all classes, types, backgrounds, incomes, tastes, aspirations, ambitions - it does have. This, probably, is why self-appointed elites are so quick to downgrade and dismiss television: they do not like its power, its hold on the people, just as the high-born admirals hated Nelson's command of the ordinary seamen - 'and yet the whole Fleet loved him, damn their eyes'. Television is a force which seems to threaten their hold on the reins. Yet television does not threaten older forms. It often gives them new life. The history of television is very like that of other new media. Thus the novel, which began life in the fertile gutters of melodrama and sensation, was dismissed as a gross intruder into the salon of letters until great practitioners and passionate readers simply swept it into power. A parallel story describes the early cinema. What those forms have in common is that they are new, they rely mostly on the common people coming on board to get under way. And all of them have, initially most of all, a mesmerising quality. So the big and, to some, the frightening, the inconceivable and unacceptable message is that television is our real national theatre. It is British filmmaking sometimes at its best. It is the true UK comedy store and national stadium for sports. It is the planet at a switch and the stars in their constellations; and it takes us right back to the fire at the mouth of the cave, warming us and protecting us. Yet, as David Chater wrote in the Times recently: 'There is a common assumption that television rots your brain, destroys your attention span and ruins your health.' He described the concern of his friends for his mental health after hearing that he had become a television critic. The response of his friends is not uncommon, I suggest, among those whose assumption is that only they hold the keys to real cultural truth, quality and worth. As Chater pointed out: 'A great deal of television in this country is of astonishingly high calibre.' His list of such programmes was impressive. Any fair-minded and intelligent viewer could come up with a similar list. Why is it, then, that Chater's undoubtedly intelligent friends chose to be so ignorant, prejudiced and snobbish? Snobbish is easy - it's still the wearisome badge of authority worn by those desperate to be different without the talent to be distinctive. I even know people who announce proudly that they never watch television as if that alone is the equivalent of a first-class honours degree. Once again, I suggest, this asinine or panic-stricken reaction is, in fact, a tribute to the force of a new medium so strange and yet so ordinary that it is very difficult to grapple with. What in the broadest terms is the message of that medium at the moment? It is both traditional and remarkable. It is that we want to see ourselves, warts and all. In every society the elite has wanted to see itself in its culture: pharaohs begat monuments to pharaohs; Greeks begat sculpture and drama and philosophy reflecting the ideas and dilemmas and images of that most extraordinary of peoples; Elizabethans begat stories of monarchs and nobles, though the rise of the gentry showed through, as did the demands of the groundlings in the shape of the comic characters. But, largely, until quite recently, ordinary people, what used to be called working-class people, were, in our art and literature, caricatures, clowns, servants - or absent. Mostly the latter. On television they have, for the first time in the history of our culture, taken over the world. We see ourselves, us, the mass. We are now the cultural equation, we are centre stage. We see ourselves in EastEnders or Coronation Street ; we see ourselves in Popstars and Big Brother ; we see ourselves in The Royle Family , watching them watching; we see ourselves on Cilla and Barrymore - but it goes further. Ordinary people are now called in for what were once thought of as positions above them. For example, 'ordinary' farmers com ment on foot and mouth; 'ordinary' witnesses tell us of train crashes, earthquakes, wars. 'Ordinary' lads play football, which demonstrates the beautiful game of our time and commentators strive to be as ordinary as they can manage, to reflect the voice of the crowd. The airwaves seethe with phone-ins, the referendum of the ratings becomes a sometimes brutal instrument of democracy in organising the schedules; at last, those who were quite recently called 'the great unwashed' now rule the waves, and not before time. Television is the New World, the America of the arts. Moreover, the demand is that the people be as unmediated as possible. Of course there is art and craft in the construction of Coronation Street, EastEnders, The Bill, Big Brother, but the important issue is that it seems real. No matter that Ken Barlow has had a more varied love life than Valentino (mind you, he does live in Lancashire), he must retain ordinariness. That is the point. If the term had not been appropriated for political purposes, I would call this the 'People's Art Form'. There is of course at the moment - these are early days, it is a new medium - plenty to carp about. Even if there were not, we British would truffle it out. From having had the largest empire the world has ever known, which depended entirely on self-confidence, we have gone instantly to the top of the league of complainers - about ourselves. And television has joined the weather as a part of our daily moan. And there is cause for criticism. The medium at present has no place for the message - the life, the style, the character - of introverts, the quieter, the more thoughtful, the less drunk, the less unlicensed. These people are often those who make the world go round. Think of Darwin, of Freud, Newton, their reach through the centuries. Although television can deal brilliantly with such figures in documentary form, its current tone is anti-introvert. Loudness, gregariousness, lad- and ladettishness are imperative. You must be larky, joshy, noisy, especially if you are young. Where are the series called Men Behaving Philosophically or Women Thinking Deeply or The Examined Life, The Stiff Upper Lip? Perhaps the form itself, like much cinema and theatre, cannot finally give to that introverted part of us the same satisfactions we derive from novels and poetry and music. But I do feel it ought to try harder. Similarly, it is proving dif ficult for television fully to serve minorities. One problem is that minorities are so numerous and television is so expensive and, until recently, limited in its space. This is now changing radically. Look at the minority to which I have devoted my television career - the arts. The fight is on to convert the indisputable wide interest in the arts - more people went to the Tate Modern one Saturday afternoon (75,000) than saw the game at Wembley - into an integrated audience which fills a whole channel. It's out there. The conversion is the challenge, as with any new faith. At one stage, no one would have called the novel art, nor film, nor radio. So what of television itself? Let's go to the least likely art form, the bedrock of television, the belittlingly named soap opera. Has that saturating message from the medium a claim as art? It is, I think, fun to couple it with its polar opposite, the latest art as in artefact, sculpture, conceptual work. For instance, is Coronation Street likely to be more valued and influential in the long run than the urinal named as art by Marcel Duchamp? Because Duchamp declared a urinal to be art so it was, agreed thousands of artists following him, thousands of critics, hundreds of dealers,museums and collectors. Tracey Emin's unmade bed is in a direct line from the urinal. Duchamp's urinal is an important, even key icon of twentieth-century art. But might Coronation Street - whose characters would not be too struck on Duchamp's lavatory and the idea that it is worth several million pounds - also be art? Might the flag-bearer of the big message on television for the last 40 years outlive the lavatory? Martin Scorsese once said that if he wanted to know what late twentieth-century culture was like, he would record the whole of a few weeks on television and that would tell him. When Peter Brook, the distinguished theatre director, and his friend, the late Poet Laureate Ted Hughes, went to Africa and India to conduct their experiments in basic theatre reaching for the profound, they extolled, as so many do, the village storyteller, the man - most often a man - who told the tales which kept the community enthralled, tales very local, rich in particular reference; endless tales, tales which were deeply sown into the fabric of the lives of those they addressed. It sounds rather like Coronation Street, although of course it takes a gulp of faith to admit it. So: will it be the lavatory or the Street? It's tempting to say at last the people will decide. This is an edited extract of Melvyn Bragg's Edward Boyle Memorial Lecture, given at Leeds University, which can be seen tonight on Artsworld at 9pm, and again on Monday at 4pm. fields.headline: Non, je ne regrette rien...
fields.standfirst: I've been persecuted by a fascist, my son nearly drowned in an oil barrel and I earn a labourer's wage. Am I happy? You betcha
fields.trailText: I've been persecuted by a fascist, my son nearly drowned in an oil barrel and I earn a labourer's wage. Am I happy? You betcha
fields.body:
Sam Taylor moved with his wife, Odile, and their three children - Oscar, five, Milo, three, and Paul-Emile, 21 months - from a semi in Hertfordshire to a 'maison de matre' in rural south-west France in January. This is the second of a series of bulletins on their new life.

Spring has sprung in southern France. It's 10 weeks since we arrived here, and in that time the trees have started budding, sun shining, birds singing and the boys and I have emerged from our cocoons. Odile has had fewer problems integrating with village life, being a) French, b) female and c) not sociopathically shy.

Indeed, by the time of her birthday in early February, she was able to nip down to the mairie in order to post a letter and come back three hours later tipsy on the local aperitif, Floc de Gascogne, and with enough gossip to fill a newspaper.

To begin with, most of the gossip concerned the house's previous owner, Monsieur D, whose departure was celebrated with a giant village fete. It took us a while to work out why this smoothly charming man was so disliked, but then we found the fascist newspapers in the boiler room and the FN and Le Pen stencils in the barn. Our postman, a garrulous Communist, was particularly scathing in his judgment.

In time, we grew to loathe Monsieur D with the same intensity as our fellow villagers. Because, unfortunately, when we moved in, Monsieur D did not entirely move out. He left us vast piles of wood, barns full of rubbish, and - for three days - his poor hunting-dog locked in a cage.

For weeks and weeks, we put on strained smiles as he drove his Jeep and trailer into our garden every morning and slowly took away his wood. Then things started turning nasty. He ran over the boys' trike and didn't apologise. He put a padlock on a barn door and refused to remove his rubbish. I got angry and yelled insults at him in French (not grammatically correct perhaps, but with enough force to make him blanch).

One day, the boys discovered a barrel full of used engine oil which he had thoughtfully left for us in one of the barns. They got covered in the black toxic stuff and Paul-Emile narrowly avoided falling headfirst into it. We mentioned this little incident to Monsieur D and he told us to sue him if we wanted to.

Odile then made use of her knowledge of local gossip to comment sarcastically on his private life. He had a chainsaw in his hands when she did this, but thankfully he didn't kill her, and opted instead to leave and never return. We celebrated with a bottle of Floc, relieved finally to have the whole property to ourselves, though I did regret never having used the phrase ' cochon de fasciste ' to his face.

That, however, is the only thing that prevents me being able to declare: ' Je ne regrette rien. ' Because despite all the turbulence of these first two months, none of us ever finds ourselves pining for our old life in England. Odile misses her friends and I miss my tennis partners, but... constant rain, traffic smog, full-time work, office politics, foot and mouth? Er, non merci. I wake up every morning, open the shutters, breathe in the unpolluted air, feel the sun on my face and get a strange light feeling inside my chest as I think about the day's work, if work is the right word.

In the first weeks, this consisted mostly of looking after the kids and buying things for the house. Rugs, furniture, plants, tools, lamps. That sort of thing. Every day the place felt more like ours, apart from the creeping shadow of Monsieur D outside. Then the temperature rose and I started using the tools: sawing wood, digging with a pickaxe, removing large rocks from the earth and hurling them on to a pile. One gloriously hot afternoon was spent shovelling cow manure into the vegetable garden; another two wrenching a tree root from the earth.

Now, these are not the sort of activities I ever attempted at home in England, where I would break into a cold sweat at the mere sight of a hammer. But there is a kind of perverse glamour to manual labour in a warm country. You toil, you sweat, you stand back with a cold drink and survey the fruits of your labour.

You look at the mountains and listen to the birds and feel at one with nature. And you dream of the rewards you will get in a month or two, when your beans and melons and purple sprouting broccoli shoot up from the soil. In terms of time spent and financial value gained, it is sub-minimum wage, obviously, but the satisfaction I got when I lifted up that tree root like the head of a vanquished foe... well, you can't buy that. Still, I think I may borrow a Rotovator to dig the next potager.

Occasionally I worry about money, but no more often than I did in England, when I was earning four times more than I am now. Not having a mortgage helps; ditto a social life. And I'm writing a novel, so a period of penury prior to its success is only to be expected. Anyway, life costs less here: food and drink are much cheaper, of course, and in a month's time we will have chickens and a grapefruit bush, so at least that will be breakfast taken care of. I'm still keen on the idea of rearing a pig for meat, but Odile's convinced the children will fall in love with it and we will never be able to turn it into sausages, chops and paté.

One question our friends ask us is: have we changed? I don't know really. The biggest difference for me is that I have a lot more energy during the day and I feel a lot more tired by late evening. I concentrate better and feel more relaxed. I spend more time outside and I use my body more. I wear old, dirty jeans all the time instead of just most of the time. I read books instead of newspapers. And I haven't been ill since I got here (having spent half my winters in England suffering with asthma).

The biggest difference for Odile is being able to wander round the garden in knickers and wellies without having to worry about what the neighbours will think. She loves the extra space, the slower pace of life, the absence of traffic, the warmer weather, being able to speak her native language. And the only downside is she sees a lot more of me.

So, our lives have changed, but I don't think we have. Our children have changed enormously, though. Paul-Emile now laughs at huge angry dogs (there are parts of rural France where huge angry dogs outnumber people) but startles at the distant sound of a car engine. Oscar and Milo have grown closer to each other in the face of adversity. They still squabble over toys occasionally, but more often go on about how much they love each other.

Oscar puts his arm round Milo's shoulders every morning when they walk into the school playground. Neither of them cries. They still want to speak English - or just run riot in the garden - when they come home, but they have overcome their xenophobia regarding French books and videos. Milo says proudly that he is 'becoming French'.

At the moment, my French is still slightly better than theirs, but it won't be for long. Before I came here, I imagined studying for an hour a day, but in reality it's been less than an hour a week. I read Tin-Tin and Asterix and Le Petit Prince and I've listened to a CD containing reports on Chirac and the new Grand-Duc of Luxembourg. But all of this is of limited use when your primary need is to figure out the mumbled jokes of the slipper-wearing mums outside the school gates. However, I think that in the past week I may have killed two oiseaux with one pierre. In short, I have joined a tennis club and had proper conversations in French with the other players.

Now all I need is to start playing doubles with the head of the Securité Sociale. At least then they might decide to give me medical cover without charging me more in payments than I'm earning. Yes, I'm afraid the notorious French red tape has wrapped itself around us and is being pulled tight.

Honestly, you go to all the trouble of marrying a bloody Frenchwoman and what does it get you? Rien! Still, at least when the local farmers start moaning about the government, I can join in with true passion. And that, as any French person will tell you, is far more important than correct grammar.

webTitle: Should I ditch my principles and opt for a private school?

fields.headline: Should I ditch my principles and opt for a private school?
fields.trailText: I am a professional, married woman with two young children. The eldest, who is four, has just started at our local primary school. It's a school that I was keen for her to attend because it has a mix of racial and social cultures and as a white, middle-class family, I thought it important for her to go to a local school that was representative of the cultural and social mix of the society in which we live. The ethos of the school itself is entirely in keeping with our own principles and values.
fields.body:
I am a professional, married woman with two young children. The eldest, who is four, has just started at our local primary school. It's a school that I was keen for her to attend because it has a mix of racial and social cultures and as a white, middle-class family, I thought it important for her to go to a local school that was representative of the cultural and social mix of the society in which we live. The ethos of the school itself is entirely in keeping with our own principles and values.

Having met some of the other parents and children though, I'm becoming increasingly uneasy that our liberal values are not widely held. I'm worried that along with the accent and vocabulary of her peers she will also pick up what appears to be a very narrow-minded, uneducated attitude. I want my daughter to be able to adapt and to fit in with her friends at school but I don't necessarily want her to model her behaviour on theirs. I want her to like them but not be like them.

Am I worrying unnecessarily? Or am I a hypocritical snob who should abandon her flimsy principles and send her children to private school?
P.J. of London

Let me dispel the notion that private schools are havens where standards are high, teachers models of rectitude and learning, children all come from liberal-minded families, and where your little ones will be protected from the sins and sordidness of the world. The only difference is that the richer sectors of society who can afford school fees are in the habit of erring more expen sively and exorbitantly, and with greater facility for cover-up.

At such a place, your daughter would acquire polished manners and a genteel accent, but she will rub shoulders with a much narrower class of society, with all its prejudices, than in the public sector. My medical colleagues who, almost without exception, send their children to private schools tell stories of the endemic use of drugs, the core of disrupters and troublemakers, the decline of discipline and ever younger age of rebellion.

It's an excellent plan to send her to a thoroughly mixed school as long as there are enough children sufficiently near to her own section of society to whom she can immediately relate. Out of her element entirely, she is at risk of rejection, bullying and maybe long-term alienation.

Monitor the state of her mind and her capacity for making friends. Be prepared to reconsider if she doesn't mix, but give her time.

As soon as children step out of the front door they are faced with a challenging world, where deceit and dissimulation are so sophisticated that young people have difficulty telling these qualities apart. For this reason I believe that you are better advised to bring your children up in the real world. The instinct to cocoon achieves less than controlled exposure. Children should learn about the contentious stuff while you are still around to guide them.

There is much evidence that character essentials and many personal beliefs like religious affiliations and political leanings have a major inherited component. Sterling qualities of personality can only expand when put to the test, as muscles only develop when used.

So don't be afraid of her mixing with all sorts and conditions of people. An overprotected child is a stunted individual, and nowadays may be more harmed by this than by any external influence.

Readers' replies

I think your daughter will already be quite set in her ways and imbued with your cultural values. However, the school environment is important because your daughter will spend plenty of time there. She will also be functioning much more independently among her peers. I would not be deterred by your comments about the school. Overall, it sounds like a good enough place to learn, with a good mix of children from different backgrounds. Given the necessary support, your daughter will find out what is best for herself. She will be encouraged further if she can regard her mother as a person with whom she can share her difficulties.
N.E.G. of Swindon

Next week's dilemma

My 13-year-old daughter often babysits for my friend and neighbour (M) who lives across the road. We have been friends since our youngest children were born and we have just started a small catering company together. Last week, when my daughter returned from my friend's house, she smelt of cigarette smoke.

When I questioned her about it, she denied she smoked but finally blurted out that my friend had left two cigarettes in a packet for her for the evening.

I am furious. Neither my husband or myself smoke. M does. How dare she encourage my daughter to take up this habit which she knows I have very strong feelings about. I can't bring myself to talk to M out of the feeling that she can't have any regard for me if she is willing to give my children cigarettes. However, our friendship and new business are at stake.

But do I want this kind of person with these kinds of principles in my life?

fields.bodyText: I am a professional, married woman with two young children. The eldest, who is four, has just started at our local primary school. It's a school that I was keen for her to attend because it has a mix of racial and social cultures and as a white, middle-class family, I thought it important for her to go to a local school that was representative of the cultural and social mix of the society in which we live. The ethos of the school itself is entirely in keeping with our own principles and values. Having met some of the other parents and children though, I'm becoming increasingly uneasy that our liberal values are not widely held. I'm worried that along with the accent and vocabulary of her peers she will also pick up what appears to be a very narrow-minded, uneducated attitude. I want my daughter to be able to adapt and to fit in with her friends at school but I don't necessarily want her to model her behaviour on theirs. I want her to like them but not be like them. Am I worrying unnecessarily? Or am I a hypocritical snob who should abandon her flimsy principles and send her children to private school? P.J. of London Let me dispel the notion that private schools are havens where standards are high, teachers models of rectitude and learning, children all come from liberal-minded families, and where your little ones will be protected from the sins and sordidness of the world. The only difference is that the richer sectors of society who can afford school fees are in the habit of erring more expen sively and exorbitantly, and with greater facility for cover-up. At such a place, your daughter would acquire polished manners and a genteel accent, but she will rub shoulders with a much narrower class of society, with all its prejudices, than in the public sector. My medical colleagues who, almost without exception, send their children to private schools tell stories of the endemic use of drugs, the core of disrupters and troublemakers, the decline of discipline and ever younger age of rebellion. It's an excellent plan to send her to a thoroughly mixed school as long as there are enough children sufficiently near to her own section of society to whom she can immediately relate. Out of her element entirely, she is at risk of rejection, bullying and maybe long-term alienation. Monitor the state of her mind and her capacity for making friends. Be prepared to reconsider if she doesn't mix, but give her time. As soon as children step out of the front door they are faced with a challenging world, where deceit and dissimulation are so sophisticated that young people have difficulty telling these qualities apart. For this reason I believe that you are better advised to bring your children up in the real world. The instinct to cocoon achieves less than controlled exposure. Children should learn about the contentious stuff while you are still around to guide them. There is much evidence that character essentials and many personal beliefs like religious affiliations and political leanings have a major inherited component. Sterling qualities of personality can only expand when put to the test, as muscles only develop when used. So don't be afraid of her mixing with all sorts and conditions of people. An overprotected child is a stunted individual, and nowadays may be more harmed by this than by any external influence. Readers' replies I think your daughter will already be quite set in her ways and imbued with your cultural values. However, the school environment is important because your daughter will spend plenty of time there. She will also be functioning much more independently among her peers. I would not be deterred by your comments about the school. Overall, it sounds like a good enough place to learn, with a good mix of children from different backgrounds. Given the necessary support, your daughter will find out what is best for herself. She will be encouraged further if she can regard her mother as a person with whom she can share her difficulties. N.E.G. of Swindon Next week's dilemma My 13-year-old daughter often babysits for my friend and neighbour (M) who lives across the road. We have been friends since our youngest children were born and we have just started a small catering company together. Last week, when my daughter returned from my friend's house, she smelt of cigarette smoke. When I questioned her about it, she denied she smoked but finally blurted out that my friend had left two cigarettes in a packet for her for the evening. I am furious. Neither my husband or myself smoke. M does. How dare she encourage my daughter to take up this habit which she knows I have very strong feelings about. I can't bring myself to talk to M out of the feeling that she can't have any regard for me if she is willing to give my children cigarettes. However, our friendship and new business are at stake. But do I want this kind of person with these kinds of principles in my life? webTitle: So how dare they say Geordies are dim?

fields.headline: So how dare they say Geordies are dim?
fields.standfirst: They've got the best beer, the best nightlife, the best-loved footballers, and the best inventor ...but they still say Geordies are thick
fields.trailText: The city that gave us Paul Gascoigne, the Tyne Bridge and Brown Ale also has a less attactive feature. Newcastle has the lowest number of university educated people in the country.
fields.body:
The city that gave us Paul Gascoigne, the Tyne Bridge and Brown Ale also has a less attactive feature. Newcastle has the lowest number of university educated people in the country.

New figures from the Office of National Statistics reveal that Tyne and Wear, which includes the cities of Newcastle and Sunderland, has the smallest number of people with a degree. Only one in 10 has a university qualification, compared to a national average of one in six and a figure for London of one in four. Although jokes about Geordies not being very bright are legion (particularly among neighbours in Yorkshire) the figures mask a serious North/South divide when it comes to the best educated people in the country. An analysis of numbers of people with no qualifications reveals that nearly 20 per cent of people in Tyne and Weir have never passed a school exam compared to 15 per cent in London and 11 per cent in the south-east of England. Only Merseyside and the Birmingham area have worse records on the number of people with no qualifications than Newcastle.

The figures will reignite the debate about the depth of the gulf between the richer, better educated South and the poorer less well qualified North. In 1999, the Prime Minister caused a storm of protest when he suggested in a speech that the North-South divide was a simplistic argument. Tony Blair said that differences in education and economic attainment in places just a few miles apart were as stark.

'It shows that the spiral of inequality between the North and South goes far wider than simply job prospects,' said Jim Cousins, the MP for Newcastle Central. 'The North East has the highest number of people with no qualifications and the south east has the lowest. Then when you come to degrees that position is reversed. With the best will in the world that is going to take many years to correct.'

The Office of National Statistics asked people between the ages of 16 and 60 for their qualification details as part of the Labour Force Survey last summer. Across the UK, over 15 per cent of people surveyed said they had a degree or an equivalent qualification. In Tyne and Wear that figure fell to 10 per cent, compared to 24 per cent in London and 18 per cent in the south east of England. An official from the ONS said that it was the first time that such a break down of the figures had been attempted.

Other regions in the North faired little better than their Tyneside neighbours. South Yorkshire, which includes Sheffield and Doncaster, had a university educated rate of 11 per cent, while West Yorkshire, dominated by Leeds and Bradford, had a figure of 14 per cent. Merseyside, including Liverpool, achieved 12 per cent, while Manchester was just below the UK average at 14 per cent.

'These figures reveal what is becoming known as the William Hague phenomenon,' said Denis MacShane, the Labour MP for Rotherham in South Yorkshire. 'There was a local man from Rotherham who got a good local education and then immediately quits the area for the bright lights of the South East.

'London is the powerhouse that sucks up much of our natural talent. It will be such an important issue after the election, how do we keep the talent in the regions where it was nurtured?'

There was also bad news for Scotland, which prides itself on having the best education system in the UK. Despite such praise, only 14 per cent of the adult population have a degree, more than a full percentage point behind England. Wales fared less well at 12 per cent, the same as Northern Ireland.

'If you look at America or countries on the European continent there is much more of a balance in where the qualified talent is. We have to learn some lessons from that,' MacShane said.

The great cities of the North have struggled to reinvent themselves after much of their industry collapsed in the 1980s. Now serious concerns are being raised that the education divide is creating an unsustainable split between London and the south east of England and the rest of the UK. A highly qualified workforce is seen as one of the key demands for a booming economy.

On Friday Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland Secretary and MP for Hartlepool in the North East, demanded that more was done to improve prospects in the region. 'Certainly there are sharp differences in performance between communities within the north east region. But the statistics show that a large performance gap between regions remains,' he said. 'London and the South East is the richest region in the European Union, admittedly with its own pockets of poverty and social exclusion - but in every other part of the United Kingdom standards of living are below the European average.'

fields.headline: The perfect leading man
fields.standfirst: Takeshi Kitano
fields.trailText: Takeshi Kitano.
fields.body:
The most important thing is his presence. Without presence, you cannot be a leading man, no matter how skilful you are as an actor. Some leading men trade on their glamour and charisma, and others on portraying ordinariness the audience can identify with. I personally think charisma is more important. To lead a film, an actor should have a strong enough charisma to absorb the audience and make them oblivious to how he is in real life.

For example, the first film in which I played a serious role was Nagisa Oshima's Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence. I was becoming huge as Beat Takeshi, a television comedian, but I thought that people would be impressed to see me portray a different persona. So I sneaked into a cinema to see how the audience would react. When my character appeared on screen, the entire audience burst into laughter. I was devastated. My image as a comedian prevented them from seeing the character I was trying to play. So after that, I decided to stick to dark characters in films. It took me 10 years of playing serial killers and rapists to be perceived as a serious actor among the Japanese public.

I think Toshiro Mifune in Kurosawa's films is as perfect as you can get. In terms of Western actors, I would mention Joe Pesci in GoodFellas, or anything with Robert De Niro, but I have to watch their films with subtitles and that's not an ideal way to judge an actor's performance.

In general, though, I don't expect too much of actors. It's up to the director's ability to make characters look believable in scenes. The ideal actor is the one who does exactly what the director tells him without asking questions. And when I'm on the set of other directors' films, I try to be as obedient as possible. And, of course, it goes without saying that no actor is easier to handle for the director, Takeshi Kitano, than his obedient actor, Beat Takeshi.

 Takeshi Kitano is Japan's leading film director, best-known here for Hana-bi and Brother (currently on release). As Beat Takeshi, he is a hugely successful film and television actor and stand-up comedian.

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: Go
fields.trailText: Go.
fields.body:
Go is the name of an exhibition and book by award-winning Magnum photographer Bruce Gilden who, between 1995 and 2000, shot a collection of noirish images of Tokyo and Osaka's seedier subjects. His photographs are of members of the yakuza , or Japanese mafia, as well as the city's homeless, prostitutes and biker gangs, and they're rivetting in that the portraits introduce a cast of characters who so obviously have tales to tell. 'I'm always looking for characters,' comments GiIden. 'For people who, in one sense or another, stand out from the others.'

The men posturing here are yakuza, 'from an area in Tokyo that has the most expensive real estate in the world,' says Gilden. 'And they are tough guys! They're not that easy to get close to, but someone knew someone...'

Gilden is also interested in people who lead double lives, 'specifically women who have double lives,' he says. 'For instance, I photographed one women who is both a novelist and a prostitute; she's written seven books about people in the profession like herself.' Gilden was very taken with her. 'She has done almost everything in the sex industry and she's just this very well-adjusted person.'

For Gilden, the bigger point of the project, though, is to try and define a culture through his photographs. 'This is my vision of one segment of Japan,' he says. 'And it has my guts in it.'

 Go will be on until 12 May at the Photofusion Gallery, 17a Electric Lane, Brixton, London SW9 (020 7738 5774). The accompanying book, Go (£30, Trebruk UK in conjunction with Magnum Photos), will be on sale at the exhibition.

fields.headline: Loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: Uni-qlo
fields.trailText: ... Uni-qlo.
fields.body:
Never heard of it. But you will, you will. The name combines 'unique' and 'clothing' and the brand has become a household name in Japan. In 1997 there were five Uni-qlo stores; by February this year, there were 487, all selling cheap but high-quality fashion staples. Last year, Uni-qlo sold 300m items of clothing in Japan: that's three each for every man, woman and child in the country.

But why should this concern me? Tadashi Yanai, the entrepreneur who built his family tailoring company into an empire, is planning to open a chain of 50 Uni-qlo shops in the UK. The first four will be in London this summer, designed by Sir Terence Conran. After which the concept will spread faster than you can say 'Starbucks': 10 new shops are planned every six months, starting with Birmingham, Manchester, Leeds, Glasgow and Cardiff.

So what's the big idea? Uni-qlo concentrates on stylish basics: sweaters, fleeces, puffa jackets, plain T-shirts and trousers. 'Our items are designed to work with designer brands such as Gucci or Prada,' says Yanai.

Haven't we seen this before? Has Uni-qlo spotted a Gap in the market? Yes, but Gap, Next and M&S should be worried about the prices. Uni-qlo is seriously cheap: well-made jeans and shirts are around £11. They also come in a huge choice of colours: this winter there were more than 40 different shades of fleece, at £7 a go.

How do they manage this? Uni-qlo buys in bulk, and the clothes are made by sub-contractors in China. The chain is also looking into Eastern Europe and Mexico.

So does everyone in Japan love Uni-qlo? There are always snobs. But the high-fashion label has some gorgeously fluffy red frocks in its current collection made from recycled Uni-qlo fleeces.

How will it go down with the fashion set here? These days, even Vogue puts the odd Top Shop item on its pages. Let's face it, everybody loves a bargain.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... taking up sumo wrestling
fields.trailText: ... taking up sumo wrestling.
fields.body:
As you would expect, Japan's national sport is wreathed in ritual. It is not simply enough to wrap your loins in a mawashi (about 20m of silk that costs £1,000, available only in Japan) and start pushing other people around. Wrestlers, or rikishi , are recruited young (from 15 to 19 years old). As well as eating, sleeping and training, the aspiring wrestler will attempt to understand the arcane rules and structures of sumo.

They hope to join a stable of rikishi , always led by a retired wrestler (oyakata). To run a stable of wrestlers, the oyakata has to have competed in a certain number of tournaments (bashos) and be a Japanese national. And to have bought the rights to the stable (there are only 105 in existence), for between £698,000 and £1,400,000.

Those on the lowest rungs don't earn a salary, but may be paid a bonus of £450 to £630 per tournament. At the journeyman juryo level you are paid £5,000 per month, while the big stars at the highest level (the makuuchi) pull in more than £6,300 per month. A yokozuna will make more than £14,000 per month and maybe millions of pounds in commercial endorsements. In the past 300 years, about 60 rikishi have attained this honour, which is bestowed by the Yokozuna Deliberation Council on successful wrestlers deemed to be of sufficiently good character.

The aim of the sport seems deceptively simple: push the other guy out of the circle on the dohyo. At the start of the tournament, the rikishi enter wearing hand-embroidered silk aprons, costing about £3,500. A yokozuna will then drive evil spirits out of the dohyo by stamping his feet. During the matches, the liberal spraying of salt over the ring serves the same purpose - in the course of one day, 90lb of salt may be thrown, so it is probably wise to stockpile some.

Given that the average weight of a top rikishi is 335lb, it's fortunate that they don't pay for their food (or accommodation - the stable owner picks up the considerable tab) and as well as winning about £69,750 per tournament, they also receive prizes such as a year's supply of fish.

Mawashi £1,000
Kesho-mawashi apron £3,500
Stable stock £698,000 to £1,400,000
Salary £0 to £14,000 per month
Salt £2 per 500g
Annual membership of British Sumo Federation £10
Hiring a sumo wrestler £1,000

webTitle: The Japan issue: Sex, tea and tourism

fields.headline: Sex, tea and tourism
fields.trailText: Dee O'Connell offers the statistics that define a nation.
fields.body:
 With 127m people living on nearly 7,000 islands, Japan is the ninth most populous country in the world.

 Society is leaving its traditional roots and heading towards singledom. The Japanese are marrying later and staying married for a shorter time. In 1971, women married at 24; now they wait until they are 26. They are 53 per cent more likely to divorce than they were 10 years ago.

 Thirty years ago, one fifth of households were made up of three generations. This has fallen to 11 per cent. The number of single-person households has risen to a quarter.

 The Japanese could be persuaded to take only half of their holiday entitlement in1998. It took 10 years to reduce the legal working week from 48 hours to 40 in 1997. One fifth of Tokyo workers spend more than 90 minutes getting to the office. In 1999, 1m people lost their jobs due to downsizing.

 Suicide was the sixth highest cause of death in 1998. Japan's National Police Agency attributed 18 per cent of suicides to financial difficulties, an increase of nearly 70 per cent on the previous year.

 The sex industry in Japan is worth ¥4trillion (£275m) a year.

 Each year, the Japanese buy 2.1bn comics, consume 1.3kg of green tea per household and spend ¥2.7bn (£27m) on Hello Kitty merchandise.

 Figures back up the stereotype of Japan as a nation of avid tourists: 15.8m overseas trips are taken annually; 470,000 Japanese visited the UK in 1999 and spent and average of £61 a day each. Over 60,000 Japanese live in Britain, the third biggest Japanese community overseas.

webTitle: The Japan issue: Sex and the city

fields.headline: Sex and the city
fields.standfirst: Tokyo's sex industry caters to myriad male fantasies. There are even clubs where men  grope female 'passengers' on fake subway carriages. Gaby Wood explores the paradox of a  highly structured society with an unbridled appetite for sex
fields.trailText: Tokyo's sex industry caters to myriad male fantasies. There are even clubs where men grope female 'passengers' on fake subway carriages. Gaby Wood explores the paradox of a highly structured society with an unbridled appetite for sex.
fields.body:
The scene is one David Lynch would have envied: curvy red velvet seats swoosh around walls beneath curtains of cut-glass beads; the lighting is a dim, dark pink. Every outfit is culled, in a postmodern sort of way, from some stock American look: the women at the door are dressed the way air stewardesses were in the 60s; the men standing guard are like elegant bellboys; the hostesses are required to wear short skirts, and one of them is a perfect imitation of Audrey Hepburn; the girls who clear the tables are darting about, their long, fishnet legs topped by bunny outfits in baby-pink satin.

Until last year, Tokyo's nightlife or sex life barely made a mark on the average Briton's brain - a geisha might have been imagined, or someone might have repeated the well-worn myth that schoolgirls sell their knickers on the street. But now it conjures up, first and unforgettably, the name of a dead girl. In the long months when Lucie Blackman was missing, attention was focused not just on her disappearance, but also on her circumstances - on the mysteries, to British minds, of the place that she had gone from. Where was the Roppongi district and what was it like? What was a bar hostess expected to do? Was she part of the Tokyo sex industry, and what, if she was, would that mean?

I have come to try and separate the myths of sex - and sexism - in Tokyo from the facts, but the territory turns out to be hard to navigate. Every corner seems to throw up some new paradox that makes it impossible to import and impose Western views. Convenience stores sell glossy magazines that look at first glance as though they could be some version of Smash Hits. They are, in fact, full of teenage girls in swimsuits or hitched-up school uniforms. But at least one in 20 Tokyo high-school girls has been involved in prostitution: if they choose to earn money that way, can we call it exploitation? Papers advertising prostitutes are read unabashedly on the subway. And yet there are other forms of regimentation: within minutes, a visitor to the city will notice that no one crosses the street at a red light, even if the street is clear, and also that if one person does jaywalk, a huge crowd will follow blindly behind. Angela Carter, who lived in Japan for some years, once wrote that 'Few societies lay such stress on public decency and private decorum. Few offer such structured escape valves.'

And here, next door to the seamy club where Lucie Blackman worked, is this high-class joint, the David Lynch masterpiece, which must be about as structured as escape valves get. Glove is the largest hostess bar in the whole of the Tokyo region. It employs 100 hostesses every night, and, unlike many others in Roppongi, is frequented and run mostly by Japanese people. As far as I can tell, there is only one foreign hostess, an Eastern European, and I seem to be the only woman in the club who is not working.

'I've learnt a lot about men since I've been working here,' says Mae, one of the hostesses sent to entertain us.

'Like what?'

'Well, before I came here I didn't think all men were stupid. But now I know they are.'

All of the five hostesses I speak to have a similar attitude. They are sweet, polite, and yet wonderfully cynical. There is nothing, on the face of it, to leave you saddened, and on this evidence you would hardly include the practice of hostessing under the umbrella of the sex industry at all.

In fact, Anne Allison, author of Nightwork: Sexuality, Pleasure and Corporate Masculinity in a Tokyo Hostess Club, makes an important distinction between hostesses and other nightworkers. Other outfits may be staffed by no-pan (meaning 'no panties') singers and waitresses, or girls whose job is to cover men in suds at 'soaplands', or the performers of oral sex in 'pink cabarets'. But one of the universal rules of the hostess service, no matter how classy or sad the bar, is that 'while alluding to sex, [it] cannot proceed to genital penetration or oral sex; and the service is conducted primarily at the level of conversation'.

The heartland of the sex industry is further north, in Kabukicho, an area named after a theatre that was planned here and never built. Near a warren of alleyways famous for its tiny bars, is an endless sprawl of modern streets. Towering, tacky neon announces the delights to be found behind drab curtains in small rooms. Much of the prostitute population is made up of Thai or Filipina women - and teenagers in school uniforms, girls dressed up like office workers or women posing as other people's wives are here for the taking.

I have heard about a relatively new kind of sex club, which simulates the environment of a subway train - taped train noises are pumped into the room and girls hold on to handles hanging from the ceiling as the punters feel them up - so men who might otherwise molest women in real life can confine it to a fantasy. We embark on a search for one of these 'Image Clubs'. We have no address, only a name and a price list, which, in our quest for directions, we show to strangers in the street. 'Shinjuku Peachy Assed Girls' School,' it reads, 'entrance ¥1,000 [£10]. Choice of room ¥2,000. Ripping pants off a school-girl ¥2,000. Two Polaroids ¥2,000. Taking the pants home ¥2,000. Our speciality is the train room - it's so realistic!' Our impromptu guides barely bat an eyelid.

The Image Club train feature is the underground reflection of an underground phenomenon: molesters on the subways, or chikan, are incredibly common in Tokyo - a survey conducted this year found that 72 per cent of teenage girls had been groped on their way to school - and only recently have the police started to take it seriously. Now women are encouraged to report incidents to station staff, while previously, as one former Tokyo resident tells me, they were too ashamed of being harassed to draw attention to it. On the internet, girls now post advice for each other: always have a safety pin to hand in case you need to defend yourself. In December last year, one subway line experimented with a single segregated car for women at night. Plain-clothes policewomen have been hired to patrol certain lines, and posters have been put up to remind people that 'molestation is a crime'. Last year, 1,854 men were arrested for molesting women on trains.

Samu Yamamoto, an expert in these matters, thinks it's possible that the train rooms in sex clubs have arisen in response to the crackdown on the real trains. 'The customers at Image Clubs are mainly doctors or lawyers or teachers,' he tells me, 'professionals who can't do that kind of thing on the train, so they do it where they legally can.'

Yamamoto, now a middle-aged man, has been groping women on trains since he was 17. At the peak of his activity, he would ride around Tokyo from morning until night, and molest about 10 women a day. He is famous in Japan because he wrote a memoir about his experiences, Diary of a Chikan, in 1996. The book received so much attention that he wrote another, Peeper, the same year, and in 1998 he came up with Confessions of a Chikan. When his books were published, he became a kind of cult hero, and he now writes about the sex industry for various magazines. Even his wife, whom he claims he met by molesting her on the subway, thinks he is just a journalist.

Yamamoto has become a kind of sexual philosopher - he has strong views about male and female sexuality, he knows about the sex industry, he is interested in the 'addiction' that made him a chikan, what makes, as he puts it, 'desire overcome reason'. But he is also an emblem of a certain contemporary situation. He became a pop cultural figure at a time when women's rights were still something of a joke and now he laments the fact that young women have become more independent, or - as he prefers to say - more selfish. Yamamoto embodies the transition, or two-way traffic, between sexual fantasy and sexist reality. For instance, he is now a director of porn videos: he films people being molested on trains. He also contributes illustrations to adult comics. His family still believes that his memoirs are a fiction. In Yamamoto's career, as in Tokyo itself, fantasy is not hidden underneath reality - the two coexist side by side.

My attempt to get into an Image Club was doomed to failure, since they only admit Japanese men. So I ask Yamamoto if he's been to the train rooms, and what he makes of this curious parallel reality. He tells me he went to one for 'research'. 'I found it boring,' he says. 'It's different from reality, because the girls are standing in front of you, prepared to be felt up - it's their job. Whereas as a professional, I was prepared to be caught. The environment is like a stage set. I found it totally unexciting; there was no thrill.'

If, in the sex industry, little has altered, then the speed with which changes are being made for women on other echelons is surprisingly fast. 1999 saw the passage of a Basic Law for Gender Equality, and an Equal Employment Opportunity Law. An anti-stalking law was passed last year, and this month, Japan's first law on domestic violence will be submitted. Some months ago, there was a dramatic victory for equal rights when, in the most high-profile sexual harassment, or seku-hara , case Japan has ever seen, the once- popular governor of Osaka pleaded guilty to the indecent assault of a 21-year-old member of his campaign staff. 'I did not sense the woman was annoyed,' he said in his defence, 'because she did not resist much when I slipped my hand inside her pants.' He was forced to resign and was replaced, symbolically, by a woman.

And yet Professor Sumiko Iwao, a member of Japan's Office for Gender Equality, said recently that 'Japanese women are still not sure what feminism is'. Even the word seku-hara is an import from the West, an abbreviation of the term 'sexual harassment'. I ask Dr Dolores Martinez, who teaches anthropology at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London, if she thinks feminism has reached Japan. 'Japanese feminists would say it has,' she replies. Martinez says that many of them believe too much of imported feminism is based on Western agendas, and that Japan must set its own. 'For example, the fact that menstrual leave was introduced - that women are entitled to take two days off work a month - was seen as a great victory, whereas in the West, women are unlikely to draw attention to the fact that they menstruate.' Fewer women are concerned about the sex industry than they might be in the West, Martinez explains, partly because a large percentage of those workers are not Japanese, and partly because Japanese feminists have other axes to grind. 'Their political activism is related to the protection of the environment, or improving conditions within the family home - issues that we might not necessarily call feminist.'

There is a reason for this internal logic. Mika, a 38-year-old Japanese woman, worked as a designer in an architects' firm in Tokyo, then married a South African; they have a young child and live in London. 'Life for women in Japan is not just a question of women's rights,' she says, 'the whole culture is involved. It might look unequal to an outsider, but women have power in the home, including financial power. The woman has total power over how the money is spent, and over the children's education, for example.

'I see old friends in Japan and they have absolute security, whereas here women are expected to be breadwinners as well. In Japan the man is the breadwinner, and women can concentrate on everything inside the home and the family. Japanese women have such a comfortable lifestyle. Japanese women live much longer than men. Actually, more pressure is on the man, that's why there is so much suicide, and so many disappearances. In society we don't have many rights, but in the family we do.'

I ask if she thinks it matters, then, that the career situation is not equal.

'I don't know,' Mika replies. 'What is a woman's happiness? If you have a dream to be a doctor or a lawyer, maybe Japan is not a good place, but that's changing. In my case, I am happy to be with my child.'

As ever, the myths and superficial facts of sexism, and sex, are nowhere near the complicated truth. Though Mika is a long way from Tokyo's nightlife, her words of confidence might just as easily have been expressed by the hostesses at Glove - by Anna, for example, who told me that she feels she works too hard, but doesn't mind because she earns good money; or by Mariko, who teaches in a primary school by day and works as a hostess to make up her salary. All of these women have chosen how to live their lives. 'In some ways,' Mika says of Japanese women, 'if you see deep inside, we have freedom.'

 Additional reporting by Jonathan Watts.

webTitle: The way we live now: Comic relief

fields.headline: Last of the action heroes
fields.standfirst: Comic relief
fields.trailText: Comic relief.
fields.body:
As you detach yourself from the tide of bodies flowing down pretty much any Tokyo pavement, you'll see the mangas sitting in neat piles outside newsagents and general stores. They look like comics, and visiting Westerners often mistakenly refer to them as such. But these are not comics: to millions of Japanese readers, they are portals to a parallel universe. The literal translation of manga is 'irresponsible writing'. If you want to know what's really going on in the minds of Japanese people, this is the place to look.

At home, manga artists are treated like rock stars. They are wealthy and celebrated and teenagers dream of emulating them, because they've beaten the system, made a mockery of the endless hours of homework and graft that shape most people's weeks. It is estimated that 10 per cent of all books and magazines published in Japan are mangas. On the subway during rush hour you will see pinstriped businessmen reading financial manga, in which chisel-jawed players storm into boardrooms and avert corporate meltdown at the 11th hour. On the stands, sports, cookery and kids' editions sit next to piles of the voluminous teen weeklies such as Young and Shonen Jump . The latter can be 3in thick and are claimed to sell up to 5m copies per issue. Inside, there will be lengthy stories centred around anything from dealers in fake antiques to psychiatrists who use ESP to cure people, to rival gangs of cheerleaders. Some are drawn by fans.

There are also plenty of hyperreal adult tales of hardware-encrusted space travellers and, in the ones aimed at teenage boys, lots of warped, adolescent sex of a sort that wouldn't be acceptable in UK teen mags. 'It's tolerated on the page because it's escapism,' says the editor of one such title.

It's not until you enter one of the manga superstores, however, that you come to appreciate the extraordinary breadth of manga culture. Comic Station Shibuya is arranged on three floors and claims to house 120,000 different mangas; the first thing you see as you hit the foyer is dozens of Polaroids of junior manga fans dressed as their favourite superheroes. Grown-up fans, or otaku (the least imprecise definition of which is 'nerds'), scoff at such childishness, having themselves graduated to a form of rarefied sci-fi frequently laced with opaque, existential dialogue that would make Milan Kundera blush. They regard their stuff as art - it is - and it's here in quantity. There are also racks devoted to monsters, music and some of the extreme pornography.

Ask why comics and the animated ('anime') films they spawn are so popular, and you'll get a variety of responses. Some artists will point out that the Japanese 'alphabet' is pictorial rather than phonetic, meaning that the population is brought up to think in terms of pictures rather than syntax. Katsuhiro Otomo - creator of the long-running cyber-punk morality tale, Akira , and the most celebrated artist of all - will explain that in Japanese society, there is no delineation between high and low culture. This is why attempts to bring it to the global mainstream have met with resistance, he adds. Mamoru Oshii, who directed the brilliant film adaptation of the Ghost in the Shell series, which had been earmarked for an international audience, has a more sombre take on the whole thing.

'I don't think Japanese people could get through life without distractions such as manga,' he suggests. 'Their houses are tiny, the country is small, but with so many people. Japan is a tough place to live, so people can live in the world of manga for a while and it makes their daily life a bit more tolerable. It's like a Walkman - you cut the world out, it's a means of escape.'

The conventions of modern manga were laid down in the 20 years after the Second World War by a man named Osamu Tezuka, who was besotted with Disney. This is said to explain why most of its heroes are Caucasian in appearance, with saucer-like eyes and extravagantly long legs. In the 70s, as political radicalism swept across Japan's campuses, there was a call for less reliance on American traditions. What appears now, in manga if not anime, is a mix of the two cultures, although there is still a bias towards idealised Western-looking women, just as there is a clear taste for Western models in advertising. Junco Ito, a woman who managed the cult artist Buichi Terasawa, has a simple theory about this: 'Japanese men have a thing about Western women.' Does she mind? 'It can be irritating. You get used to it.'

It's hardly surprising, then, that the only place where manga conventions are regularly broken is in the women's sector. On an average visit to Comic Station Shibuya, 70 per cent of the customers might be female. Some carry armfuls of shojo manga, the beautifully drawn, romantically inclined stuff which is aimed at girls, but others browse the work of female artists such as Rumiko Takahashi - one of the most revered of all the manga artists, a multi-millionaire with an estimated 80m books in print - and the CLAMP collective, keepers of the futuristic Tokyo Babylon stories. These are identifiable by the fact that they sport strong female characters who look Japanese and tend to keep their clothes on longer. Junco Ito suggests that manga is one of the few areas of Japanese life where women can compete with men on an equal footing.

Nevertheless, both sexes favour what they call 'realism', which looks to us like sci-fi or hyperrealism . This nearly always involves a 21st-century megatropolis in a state of moral and social decay; technology is running out of control and the country is haunted by sinister religious sects and the constant threat of terrorism and computer crime... a realm which is nothing at all like present-day Tokyo, honest.
