On the subway during rush hour you will see pinstriped businessmen reading financial manga, in which chisel-jawed players storm into boardrooms and avert corporate meltdown at the 11th hour. On the stands, sports, cookery and kids' editions sit next to piles of the voluminous teen weeklies such as Young and Shonen Jump . The latter can be 3in thick and are claimed to sell up to 5m copies per issue. Inside, there will be lengthy stories centred around anything from dealers in fake antiques to psychiatrists who use ESP to cure people, to rival gangs of cheerleaders. Some are drawn by fans. There are also plenty of hyperreal adult tales of hardware-encrusted space travellers and, in the ones aimed at teenage boys, lots of warped, adolescent sex of a sort that wouldn't be acceptable in UK teen mags. 'It's tolerated on the page because it's escapism,' says the editor of one such title. It's not until you enter one of the manga superstores, however, that you come to appreciate the extraordinary breadth of manga culture. Comic Station Shibuya is arranged on three floors and claims to house 120,000 different mangas; the first thing you see as you hit the foyer is dozens of Polaroids of junior manga fans dressed as their favourite superheroes. Grown-up fans, or otaku (the least imprecise definition of which is 'nerds'), scoff at such childishness, having themselves graduated to a form of rarefied sci-fi frequently laced with opaque, existential dialogue that would make Milan Kundera blush. They regard their stuff as art - it is - and it's here in quantity. There are also racks devoted to monsters, music and some of the extreme pornography. Ask why comics and the animated ('anime') films they spawn are so popular, and you'll get a variety of responses. Some artists will point out that the Japanese 'alphabet' is pictorial rather than phonetic, meaning that the population is brought up to think in terms of pictures rather than syntax. Katsuhiro Otomo - creator of the long-running cyber-punk morality tale, Akira , and the most celebrated artist of all - will explain that in Japanese society, there is no delineation between high and low culture. This is why attempts to bring it to the global mainstream have met with resistance, he adds. Mamoru Oshii, who directed the brilliant film adaptation of the Ghost in the Shell series, which had been earmarked for an international audience, has a more sombre take on the whole thing. 'I don't think Japanese people could get through life without distractions such as manga,' he suggests. 'Their houses are tiny, the country is small, but with so many people. Japan is a tough place to live, so people can live in the world of manga for a while and it makes their daily life a bit more tolerable. It's like a Walkman - you cut the world out, it's a means of escape.' The conventions of modern manga were laid down in the 20 years after the Second World War by a man named Osamu Tezuka, who was besotted with Disney. This is said to explain why most of its heroes are Caucasian in appearance, with saucer-like eyes and extravagantly long legs. In the 70s, as political radicalism swept across Japan's campuses, there was a call for less reliance on American traditions. What appears now, in manga if not anime, is a mix of the two cultures, although there is still a bias towards idealised Western-looking women, just as there is a clear taste for Western models in advertising. Junco Ito, a woman who managed the cult artist Buichi Terasawa, has a simple theory about this: 'Japanese men have a thing about Western women.' Does she mind? 'It can be irritating. You get used to it.' It's hardly surprising, then, that the only place where manga conventions are regularly broken is in the women's sector. On an average visit to Comic Station Shibuya, 70 per cent of the customers might be female. Some carry armfuls of shojo manga, the beautifully drawn, romantically inclined stuff which is aimed at girls, but others browse the work of female artists such as Rumiko Takahashi - one of the most revered of all the manga artists, a multi-millionaire with an estimated 80m books in print - and the CLAMP collective, keepers of the futuristic Tokyo Babylon stories. These are identifiable by the fact that they sport strong female characters who look Japanese and tend to keep their clothes on longer. Junco Ito suggests that manga is one of the few areas of Japanese life where women can compete with men on an equal footing. Nevertheless, both sexes favour what they call 'realism', which looks to us like sci-fi or hyperrealism . This nearly always involves a 21st-century megatropolis in a state of moral and social decay; technology is running out of control and the country is haunted by sinister religious sects and the constant threat of terrorism and computer crime... a realm which is nothing at all like present-day Tokyo, honest.

fields.headline: Counter culture
fields.standfirst: Despite the country's much publicised economic downturn, Japan's voracious shoppers are showing no signs of easing up. If anything, the recession has given them a new lease of life. Sheryl Garratt buys into the Tokyo shopping experience
fields.trailText: Despite the country's much publicised economic downturn, Japan's voracious shoppers are showing no signs of easing up. If anything, the recession has given them a new lease of life. Sheryl Garratt buys into the Tokyo shopping experience.
fields.body:
The tall, round tower of the 109 store in the Shibuya area of Tokyo has long been a local landmark, a popular meeting place close to the vast transport hub of Shibuya station. But the crowd milling around it has changed radically in recent years. Now 109 Shibuya is the domain of teenage girls, who roam in packs around its floors of tightly packed concept boutiques, each with its own themed decor and loud, matching soundtrack. There is a bewildering choice of styles on offer: hippy chic at the Love Boat Drug Store, 'I love New York' jumpers and preppy college jackets at the Rocky American Market, and other shops selling everything from pseudo punk to 50s bubblegum, classy pastel coats and Rolex watches to turquoise fishnets and cheap pink wigs. As well as row after row of the impossibly high 12in platform boots every other customer seems to be wearing. To get a picture of the atmosphere, imagine a big, busy branch of Top Shop on a Saturday afternoon. Triple the crowds, the noise, the chaos, top it with a floor of themed cafés so that shoppers can chill and check out each other's outfits, and you're somewhere close.

But then add in the celebrity shop assistants. Known as 'charisma girls', these slim young women were originally intended to model the style of the boutique they worked in, to show shoppers how to put the look together. Then teen magazines began to publish their style tips and run interviews, and suddenly they were stars in their own right: some now even have fan clubs.

When it comes to fashion, the colour and energy in Tokyo right now is extraordinary, especially after the tasteful but dull uniformity we've come to accept in our own street style. Western styles from every era are sampled and remixed with local trends to emerge as something new. The old variations on black, white and beige have given way to a riot of vivid colour: clashing patterns, Day-Glo accessories, bright combinations that shouldn't work but somehow do. There has been a boom in custom-tailoring and personalised accessories, and people no longer look solely to big-name designers for their inspiration. 'Ten years ago, people wore labels,' explains trend-spotter Yuko Suzuki, who compiles fashion reports for the Sensu agency. 'Now they are more interested in putting designer gear together with cheaper things to co-ordinate a whole look.'

It's a boom time for hairdressers, too. Hair colour was once only for the very adventurous or for kids enjoying a year of nonconformity in Europe before settling down back home. But now hair comes with extensions (dreadlocks or natural-looking), permed into Afros, spiked, curled, braided, as well as coloured in every possible way - for men as well as women.

As for style tribes, Tokyo's young seem to be creating and discarding them faster than we Brits can manufacture boy bands. The cute kogaru fashion themselves after a cartoon character called Sailor Girl, with ultra-short skirts and rusu-sokusu ('loose socks') drooping over clumpy shoes and clinging, as if by magic (but actually by glue) halfway between knee and ankle. The tandoori-tanned, pink-lipped, blonde-tipped Hawaiian Tropics ganguro ('dark face') look that caused such a sensation a year or so ago is pretty much over now, as is the more outrageous yamanba look named after a ghostly mountain witch and created by adding white lipstick, eye shadow and hair to a tanned face. The latest look now is one-kei ('big sisters'), girls wearing a slightly tongue-in-chic ladylike style known as new-tra ('new traditional').

But there are new ones all the time. In a society where conforming, being part of a group is so important, such shows of individuality have caused concern. Last year, when the novelist Hamki Murakami wrote about the 'sadness and disgust' he felt about the kind of girls who shop in 109 Shibuya, he was echoing the feelings of many older people. And in a way, they are right to be nervous. They are looking at the new Japan.

For the old Japan, the recession seems never-ending. For a while it looked as if the economy might finally be emerging from its 10-year slump, but then in March the Nikkei stockmarket index fell to its lowest point for 15 years, and few pundits are predicting a fast recovery. This year saw yet more politicians resign after being caught with their hands in the till, and Prime Minister Mori looks set to stand down - with his job simply going to the next grey man in line. Experts seem to agree that Japan is stagnating, and big changes will be needed before its economy moves again.

But if the country is in recession, someone seems to have forgotten to tell the shoppers in Harajuku. On the main artery, Meiji-dori, home to some of Tokyo's most expensive retail space, the young, hip department store Laforet is undergoing an expensive new refit. Now that regulations restricting the size of all outlets but the vast department stores have been relaxed, crowds flock into the big new flagship stores opened by Gap and its cheaper, more colourful Japanese counterpart Uni-qlo, while nearby, the vast new Sephora store is like a glossy three-floor shrine to expensive cosmetics. Queues form outside the Prada and Gucci stores at weekends, and the number of Louis Vuitton bags being carried by ordinary-looking office ladies is quite extraordinary.

Mark Dytham, the Tokyo-based British architect whose company Klein-Dytham Associates is overseeing the Laforet makeover, says that life after the bubble burst hasn't all been bleak. 'The worst years were from 1992 to '94, but everyone still seemed to have a fair amount of money. All the ridiculous things stopped, like guys taking £600 taxi rides home. But there were still a lot of new cars, and everybody had full bags of shopping. I don't think they've ever had negative growth here, ever.'

Indeed, while the economy has stagnated, individual savings have increased - by 2 per cent last year alone. With the old certainties of full employment and a job for life crumbling away, the problem isn't a shortage of cash: it's persuading people to spend it. Bargain-hunting has become fashionable after the downturn. Cheap noodle bars and ¥100 shops have proliferated, the discount supermarket chain Carrefour has moved successfully into Japan, and designer discount outlets are proving popular.

But it's about quality as well as price. Vuitton bags are still popular because they are perceived as the best, the craftsmanship that goes into them making them good value. Meanwhile, the Uni-qlo chain has expanded rapidly over the past two years by selling cheap clothes which are also well designed.

For many young Japanese, the uncertainty of the past few years has offered new freedoms. With rents for tiny urban apartments soaring to new heights, many have chosen to remain in the family home. The high disposable income they often enjoy as a result has turned them into a powerful force.

There are other effects, too. 'As they're not necessarily going to get a job straightaway when they leave university, it's OK for the young to lounge around for a bit before they start work,' says Dytham. 'They are travelling more, they're setting up their own cafés and shops. Even in business circles, there's a big push of independent young people doing their own thing.

'It's a great time to be here - people are open to all sorts of things. All that old side of Japan is disappearing, except in politics, where it's still 80-year-old guys. But even there, we know a lot of younger guys in the government who are bilingual, trilingual, ready to jump in when the opportunity arises.'

It's in the narrower streets of Harajuku behind Meiji-dori that this new Japan is most visible. This is where Tokyo's young and hip go to shop, and shops, hairdressers, cafés, bars and new businesses have taken over not only the premises at street level but also many of the apartments above and basements below. With space at a premium, the design of these shops has to be inventive. In the tiny, narrow four-floor showcase for the thriving 20471120 label, goods are imaginatively crammed into every inch of space available. To show as much as possible in the limited window space, they have dresses gracefully rotating on an automated rail. A metal fairground-style wheel turns slowly through the ground and first floors, displaying shoes, bags and accessories. 'I want to communicate with the customers,' laughs Masahiro Nakagawa, 20471120's designer and the older of the two brothers behind the enterprise. 'I like entertainment.'

In Harajuku, the arrival of a new type of trainer or hard-to-get item will cause queues down the street, and most of the shops are so small that shoppers are willing to wait in line for 30 minutes or more at weekends just to get in and look around. The ultra-cool A Bathing Ape store in Harajuku has a dividing rail down its narrow entrance corridor like the start of a theme park ride, allowing those leaving to get out past the queue.

Set up in 1993 by Nigo, a former fashion stylist and drummer in the Tokyo Sex Pistols, Ape is a line of streetwear which pays homage to Nigo's favourite film, Planet of the Apes . The clothes are well designed, with lots of little details such as the 'Ape shall not kill ape' labels inside every garment, and the shops now sell other items such as camouflage tape, cushions - even dog baskets.

But in the end, casualwear is pretty much the same everywhere: variations on a theme of T-shirts, sweatshirts, trousers and trainers. The main thing being sold here is the concept, the attitude behind it, and with this Nigo has built his brand into a big business without any help from the big traditional clothing companies. Instead, he has the Nowhere Corporation, a loose alliance of friends who started their casualwear shops at roughly the same time, each with a different concept. A Bathing Ape has its simian SF theme; Neighbourhood goes for military chic, Bounty Hunter's angle is punky anarchy, Real Mad Hectic has a New York graffiti feel, Undercover goes for revolutionary graphics and glories under the motto 'Fuck You Generation'. The labels collaborate on one-off projects, put references to each other in their window displays, have shops in the same buildings and attend each other's parties. But most importantly, they all exude a seemingly effortless cool that they somehow have managed to retain as their ranges have expanded to include homewear and children's clothing and their shops have spread across Japan.

'They have an amazing understanding and approach to the whole supply-and-demand equation,' says Sudeep Gohil, who works for the British advertising agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty in Japan. 'They know that kids want to buy their shirts, so they won't sell them, on purpose. If they decide for some reason that they're not going to sell shirts one week, they cover them up and won't sell them to you.'

Which, of course, makes them all the more desirable. Both Ape and Undercover now share a flagship store near Comme des Garçons, Issey Miyake and Yohji Yamoto's stores in the upmarket area of Aoyama, where T-shirts are displayed in clear plastic racks like artworks and Nigo's signature ape-head logo is picked out in mosaic on the floor.

But the Nowhere shops in Harajuku are determinedly underground - literally, in some cases, as they are hidden in basements with no signs on the street to show where they are, with forbidding-looking unmarked metal doors often serving as another barrier to those not in the know. These stores are about more than buying a T-shirt: shopping in them is an experience, and customers feel part of an elite. When A Bathing Ape recently opened its first shop outside Japan, in a defiantly unfashionable part of Hong Kong, it only served to enhance the brand's mystique: apparently, the shop will only sell to customers with a Hong Kong passport.

Revolver is the latest new label to emerge, showing similar skill in selling to a generation supposedly more immune to marketing. Taste-makers began to notice them when the hip band YKZ (Yakuza Kickz) began wearing their clothes. There were no press releases, no magazine spreads, but slowly word got around that Revolver had a shop. Not that you'd recognise it as a shop, even if you happened to walk past it. Situated in an apartment on a narrow Harajuku back alley, Revolver has no sign on its blank white door. But if you ring the bell - and they're in the mood to let you in - the door slides open and you step into a dark, enclosed lobby. When the door slides shut behind you, you may feel a moment of panic as you realise that you're completely closed in, but then a side door swishes open like an air lock and the shop is finally revealed. If you're really lucky, they may even condescend to sell you something.

Some cool shops seem to have worked so hard on their concept, on creating gorgeous, innovative interiors, that the stock seems almost secondary. Only a few carefully chosen items are displayed: 12 trainers on a pristine wall. Astonishingly, these are the places with the biggest weekend queues of all.

The big corporations are now starting to acknowledge that consumers born in the 60s and 70s are behaving differently. So in August 1999, a group of companies including Toyota, National Panasonic and the brewers Asahi banded together to launch a new brand, WiLL, aimed specifically at these stubbornly individualistic sons and daughters of the baby boomers. Sold under the orange WiLL logo and all advertised by the same agency, the products have little in common except that they attempt to embody a 'spirit of fun' and show 'true quality' in an effort to appeal to younger consumers. There's Toyota's compact Vi town car, a new sweet beer from Asahi, a 'Relax' range of ice cream and sweets, a funky folding bike, room deodorisers, Panasonic mini-disc players with transparent covers to allow the owner to personalise it with their own pictures and designs.

The cute curves and pastel colours of many of the products were designed specifically with young women in mind, but the team behind the WiLL project admits it has a long way to go before they capture these elusive new markets. WiLL is failing to give consumers strong enough reasons to buy in, the big idea that will make them stand out from the rest.

Meanwhile, shopping centres are attempting to draw in custom with a few big ideas of their own, designed to appeal to ever-narrower niche markets. After the success of teen emporiums such as 109 Shibuya and Laforet, Ikspiari - the Disney Mall next to Tokyo Disneyland - has a 'parents' alley' with adult stores, but is mainly designed with children in mind. Tonde Mun Sijan is a Korean-style mall on the third and fourth floors of Shibuya's Parco department store, where the normally reticent Japanese - who rarely return even defective goods to a shop for fear of seeming impolite - are encouraged to haggle over prices as if they were in a Korean market. Whether the goods actually work out any cheaper is, in a way, beside the point: it's a game, a fun experience, a reason to go to this particular mall rather than any other.

Most extraordinary of all is the Venus Fort out on Tokyo Bay, a shopping mall - or rather, 'entertainment complex' - apparently designed specifically for women. The temperature is kept a little warmer than most malls and the air is gently perfumed, but it's the kitsch decor that really astonishes. We girls apparently like to shop in something resembling an Italian renaissance town, with stone porticos, cobbled streets, classical statuary and fountains, plastic plant life and staff dressed in strange knickerbockers and feathered caps. In the central 'skywalk', a realistic-looking sky gradually changes over the period of an hour from cloud-dappled blue to a glorious sunset, then after a brief period of darkness you can enjoy a glorious new dawn.

It's 9.30am inside the vast Ginza branch of the Takashimaya department store. The elevator girls in their bright-blue uniforms are putting on their matching berets and gloves, checking their reflections and doing some last-minute cleaning and polishing in the already spotless, shiny lifts. By 9.50am, they are standing in two long, straight lines outside the elevators. They bow deeply to each other, then do a series of choreographed eye exercises before practising some of the poses and announcements they use when operating the lifts. Finally, the music for the opening ceremony strikes up. Just before 10am, two of the uniformed girls open the doors and a third one strides out to greet the assembled shoppers. Talking into a microphone, she thanks them for coming so early, announces any special events planned for the day, and tells them what type of rose - the symbol of the store - is displayed on the counter by the entrance today. Then she returns inside and, a minute later, the store doors are finally opened with a flourish. As the customers trickle in, the elevator girls and senior store staff stay by the door for a few minutes, bowing to each person walking past.

This elaborate opening ceremony takes place every day at Takashimaya, a chain with 19 branches across Japan and a history that goes back 120 years. On the day I witnessed it - a bitterly cold morning at the end of January- the whole thing was performed for the benefit of just five customers.

In the Japanese department store, service means everything. As the old lifts have been replaced with new, automatic ones, deputy manager Tetsuo Yamaguchi says it would have been easy to phase out the elevator girls. 'But the customers want us to retain the old-fashioned system. It helps older people feel more comfortable.'

But despite the old-fashioned service, Tokyo's department stores are far from archaic. The Times Square branch of Takashimaya boasts an IMAX cinema, and until Sega's recent restructuring, it had a Segaworld computer-games arcade. Most big department stores have art galleries on their upper floors, with changing, museum- quality shows, and they also have craft clubs, demonstrations, and endless ingenious ways of tying visitors closer to their store.

In November last year, Takashimaya began selling the second-generation Aibo, the first product from Sony's new entertainment robot division. A sophisticated machine that sells for £1,500, it recognises 50 different voice commands, answers to the name you select for it, plays with its ball and 'learns' behaviour depending on how it is treated. The first generation was sold through the internet only, mainly to computer geeks. But Takashimaya found a surprise new audience: in a city where few apartments are big enough for a real pet, affluent older ladies found the robot a clean, trouble-free companion. The store has sold nearly 7,500 of them.

Vittorio Radice, the energetic Italian now in charge of reinventing Selfridges, likes to travel. 'You have to see what's available, and learn,' he says. 'See if there's something out there you can use.' Last October, he went to Tokyo for the first time in four years, and was bowled over by the changes he saw. 'Somehow, recessions bring creativity, and at the moment there's creativity in everything they do in Japan. Everything is new and fresh. Artists, product designers, concept stores, books, music - it's all so much more free and less controlled than it is here. So I said, "Why don't we bring some of this energy to London?"'

The result is Tokyo Life, a month-long production starting on 1 May in which Selfridges is turning Japanese. The conveyor-belt sushi chain Yo! Sushi has already opened up in the food hall, and a 24-hour Japanese-style convenience store will be built in one of the windows. There will be art installations, live webcam links with Tokyo streets, and Japanese fashion, food and gadgets.

But for Radice, this is more than a one-off promotion. In the 90s, New York department stores such as Barney's had a big influence on British retailers. Now, he feels Tokyo is showing the way ahead. 'The Japanese are concentrating more on the concept, the environment, the message. They are far more advanced. You have to capture the imagination of the customer if you want them to consume with your brand, in your environment.'

Instead of offering goods, he says, shops will have to offer experiences. 'These could be in the shape of a spa or a shoe shine, a travel agent or a dentist. You could have 20 hairdressers all lined up, all providing a different style. You could put 300 PlayStations out there and charge £1 an hour to play them instead of selling games.'

This, he feels, will be the future for the fusty old department store, a prime chunk of city space that now needs to be filled with interesting things to do as well as goods to buy. Shops no longer just want to sell us stuff. They want to be theme parks, leisure centres, showcases for new ideas. Will consumers buy it? In Japan, it seems they already have.

A metal fairground-style wheel turns slowly through the ground and first floors, displaying shoes, bags and accessories. 'I want to communicate with the customers,' laughs Masahiro Nakagawa, 20471120's designer and the older of the two brothers behind the enterprise. 'I like entertainment.' In Harajuku, the arrival of a new type of trainer or hard-to-get item will cause queues down the street, and most of the shops are so small that shoppers are willing to wait in line for 30 minutes or more at weekends just to get in and look around. The ultra-cool A Bathing Ape store in Harajuku has a dividing rail down its narrow entrance corridor like the start of a theme park ride, allowing those leaving to get out past the queue. Set up in 1993 by Nigo, a former fashion stylist and drummer in the Tokyo Sex Pistols, Ape is a line of streetwear which pays homage to Nigo's favourite film, Planet of the Apes . The clothes are well designed, with lots of little details such as the 'Ape shall not kill ape' labels inside every garment, and the shops now sell other items such as camouflage tape, cushions - even dog baskets. But in the end, casualwear is pretty much the same everywhere: variations on a theme of T-shirts, sweatshirts, trousers and trainers. The main thing being sold here is the concept, the attitude behind it, and with this Nigo has built his brand into a big business without any help from the big traditional clothing companies. Instead, he has the Nowhere Corporation, a loose alliance of friends who started their casualwear shops at roughly the same time, each with a different concept. A Bathing Ape has its simian SF theme; Neighbourhood goes for military chic, Bounty Hunter's angle is punky anarchy, Real Mad Hectic has a New York graffiti feel, Undercover goes for revolutionary graphics and glories under the motto 'Fuck You Generation'. The labels collaborate on one-off projects, put references to each other in their window displays, have shops in the same buildings and attend each other's parties. But most importantly, they all exude a seemingly effortless cool that they somehow have managed to retain as their ranges have expanded to include homewear and children's clothing and their shops have spread across Japan. 'They have an amazing understanding and approach to the whole supply-and-demand equation,' says Sudeep Gohil, who works for the British advertising agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty in Japan. 'They know that kids want to buy their shirts, so they won't sell them, on purpose. If they decide for some reason that they're not going to sell shirts one week, they cover them up and won't sell them to you.' Which, of course, makes them all the more desirable. Both Ape and Undercover now share a flagship store near Comme des Garçons, Issey Miyake and Yohji Yamoto's stores in the upmarket area of Aoyama, where T-shirts are displayed in clear plastic racks like artworks and Nigo's signature ape-head logo is picked out in mosaic on the floor. But the Nowhere shops in Harajuku are determinedly underground - literally, in some cases, as they are hidden in basements with no signs on the street to show where they are, with forbidding-looking unmarked metal doors often serving as another barrier to those not in the know. These stores are about more than buying a T-shirt: shopping in them is an experience, and customers feel part of an elite. When A Bathing Ape recently opened its first shop outside Japan, in a defiantly unfashionable part of Hong Kong, it only served to enhance the brand's mystique: apparently, the shop will only sell to customers with a Hong Kong passport. Revolver is the latest new label to emerge, showing similar skill in selling to a generation supposedly more immune to marketing. Taste-makers began to notice them when the hip band YKZ (Yakuza Kickz) began wearing their clothes. There were no press releases, no magazine spreads, but slowly word got around that Revolver had a shop. Not that you'd recognise it as a shop, even if you happened to walk past it. Situated in an apartment on a narrow Harajuku back alley, Revolver has no sign on its blank white door. But if you ring the bell - and they're in the mood to let you in - the door slides open and you step into a dark, enclosed lobby. When the door slides shut behind you, you may feel a moment of panic as you realise that you're completely closed in, but then a side door swishes open like an air lock and the shop is finally revealed. If you're really lucky, they may even condescend to sell you something. Some cool shops seem to have worked so hard on their concept, on creating gorgeous, innovative interiors, that the stock seems almost secondary. Only a few carefully chosen items are displayed: 12 trainers on a pristine wall. Astonishingly, these are the places with the biggest weekend queues of all. The big corporations are now starting to acknowledge that consumers born in the 60s and 70s are behaving differently. So in August 1999, a group of companies including Toyota, National Panasonic and the brewers Asahi banded together to launch a new brand, WiLL, aimed specifically at these stubbornly individualistic sons and daughters of the baby boomers. Sold under the orange WiLL logo and all advertised by the same agency, the products have little in common except that they attempt to embody a 'spirit of fun' and show 'true quality' in an effort to appeal to younger consumers. There's Toyota's compact Vi town car, a new sweet beer from Asahi, a 'Relax' range of ice cream and sweets, a funky folding bike, room deodorisers, Panasonic mini-disc players with transparent covers to allow the owner to personalise it with their own pictures and designs. The cute curves and pastel colours of many of the products were designed specifically with young women in mind, but the team behind the WiLL project admits it has a long way to go before they capture these elusive new markets. WiLL is failing to give consumers strong enough reasons to buy in, the big idea that will make them stand out from the rest. Meanwhile, shopping centres are attempting to draw in custom with a few big ideas of their own, designed to appeal to ever-narrower niche markets. After the success of teen emporiums such as 109 Shibuya and Laforet, Ikspiari - the Disney Mall next to Tokyo Disneyland - has a 'parents' alley' with adult stores, but is mainly designed with children in mind. Tonde Mun Sijan is a Korean-style mall on the third and fourth floors of Shibuya's Parco department store, where the normally reticent Japanese - who rarely return even defective goods to a shop for fear of seeming impolite - are encouraged to haggle over prices as if they were in a Korean market. Whether the goods actually work out any cheaper is, in a way, beside the point: it's a game, a fun experience, a reason to go to this particular mall rather than any other. Most extraordinary of all is the Venus Fort out on Tokyo Bay, a shopping mall - or rather, 'entertainment complex' - apparently designed specifically for women. The temperature is kept a little warmer than most malls and the air is gently perfumed, but it's the kitsch decor that really astonishes. We girls apparently like to shop in something resembling an Italian renaissance town, with stone porticos, cobbled streets, classical statuary and fountains, plastic plant life and staff dressed in strange knickerbockers and feathered caps. In the central 'skywalk', a realistic-looking sky gradually changes over the period of an hour from cloud-dappled blue to a glorious sunset, then after a brief period of darkness you can enjoy a glorious new dawn. It's 9.30am inside the vast Ginza branch of the Takashimaya department store. The elevator girls in their bright-blue uniforms are putting on their matching berets and gloves, checking their reflections and doing some last-minute cleaning and polishing in the already spotless, shiny lifts. By 9.50am, they are standing in two long, straight lines outside the elevators. They bow deeply to each other, then do a series of choreographed eye exercises before practising some of the poses and announcements they use when operating the lifts. Finally, the music for the opening ceremony strikes up. Just before 10am, two of the uniformed girls open the doors and a third one strides out to greet the assembled shoppers. Talking into a microphone, she thanks them for coming so early, announces any special events planned for the day, and tells them what type of rose - the symbol of the store - is displayed on the counter by the entrance today. Then she returns inside and, a minute later, the store doors are finally opened with a flourish. As the customers trickle in, the elevator girls and senior store staff stay by the door for a few minutes, bowing to each person walking past. This elaborate opening ceremony takes place every day at Takashimaya, a chain with 19 branches across Japan and a history that goes back 120 years. On the day I witnessed it - a bitterly cold morning at the end of January- the whole thing was performed for the benefit of just five customers. In the Japanese department store, service means everything. As the old lifts have been replaced with new, automatic ones, deputy manager Tetsuo Yamaguchi says it would have been easy to phase out the elevator girls. 'But the customers want us to retain the old-fashioned system. It helps older people feel more comfortable.' But despite the old-fashioned service, Tokyo's department stores are far from archaic. The Times Square branch of Takashimaya boasts an IMAX cinema, and until Sega's recent restructuring, it had a Segaworld computer-games arcade. Most big department stores have art galleries on their upper floors, with changing, museum- quality shows, and they also have craft clubs, demonstrations, and endless ingenious ways of tying visitors closer to their store. In November last year, Takashimaya began selling the second-generation Aibo, the first product from Sony's new entertainment robot division. A sophisticated machine that sells for £1,500, it recognises 50 different voice commands, answers to the name you select for it, plays with its ball and 'learns' behaviour depending on how it is treated. The first generation was sold through the internet only, mainly to computer geeks. But Takashimaya found a surprise new audience: in a city where few apartments are big enough for a real pet, affluent older ladies found the robot a clean, trouble-free companion. The store has sold nearly 7,500 of them. Vittorio Radice, the energetic Italian now in charge of reinventing Selfridges, likes to travel. 'You have to see what's available, and learn,' he says. 'See if there's something out there you can use.' Last October, he went to Tokyo for the first time in four years, and was bowled over by the changes he saw. 'Somehow, recessions bring creativity, and at the moment there's creativity in everything they do in Japan. Everything is new and fresh. Artists, product designers, concept stores, books, music - it's all so much more free and less controlled than it is here. So I said, "Why don't we bring some of this energy to London?"' The result is Tokyo Life, a month-long production starting on 1 May in which Selfridges is turning Japanese. The conveyor-belt sushi chain Yo! Sushi has already opened up in the food hall, and a 24-hour Japanese-style convenience store will be built in one of the windows. There will be art installations, live webcam links with Tokyo streets, and Japanese fashion, food and gadgets. But for Radice, this is more than a one-off promotion. In the 90s, New York department stores such as Barney's had a big influence on British retailers. Now, he feels Tokyo is showing the way ahead. 'The Japanese are concentrating more on the concept, the environment, the message. They are far more advanced. You have to capture the imagination of the customer if you want them to consume with your brand, in your environment.' Instead of offering goods, he says, shops will have to offer experiences. 'These could be in the shape of a spa or a shoe shine, a travel agent or a dentist. You could have 20 hairdressers all lined up, all providing a different style. You could put 300 PlayStations out there and charge £1 an hour to play them instead of selling games.' This, he feels, will be the future for the fusty old department store, a prime chunk of city space that now needs to be filled with interesting things to do as well as goods to buy. Shops no longer just want to sell us stuff. They want to be theme parks, leisure centres, showcases for new ideas. Will consumers buy it? In Japan, it seems they already have.

webTitle: The Japan issue: London thrills me

fields.headline: London thrills me
fields.standfirst: Hiroyuki loves Camden market; Ayako has a weakness for Bond Street and Mayuko has an eye for a bargain at Spitalfields. Kate Mikhail asks 15 Japanese Anglophiles why the capital is their number one attraction
fields.trailText: Hiroyuki loves Camden market; Ayako has a weakness for Bond Street and Mayuko has an eye for a bargain at Spitalfields. Kate Mikhail asks 15 Japanese Anglophiles why the capital is their number one attraction.
fields.body:
Camden market on a Sunday afternoon, and the Japanese are out in force. Scruffy biker boys - all leather jackets and chunky boots - mingle with sharply dressed trendies and downbeat student types. It may be grey and cold, but the pavements are packed.

The Japanese are well ensconced in London - from the coachloads of shoppers which descend on Piccadilly Circus to the restaurant owners of Brewer Street and the students who flock over here on a yearly basis. The old London stereotypes of Bond Street junkies and futuristic fashion victims may be largely redundant, but the Japanese still like a good English label, and their love affair with shopping and the capital is as strong as ever.

Hiroyuki (Hiro) Koda, 23, and Sachie Hoshino, 24, are both students and Camden regulars, drawn by Camden's irresistible indie chic, the lure of vinyl - Hiro is stocking up for his DJ slot at the Ritzy in Brixton - and the impressive range of trainers. 'I love this shop,' he says as the two, hand in hand, dart into the trainer store Offspring to scan the latest range. Hiro's been here three years and plans to stay 'as long as I can'. Sachie's only been here a year and is still struggling with the language, but hopes to stay until she's fluent. Long-term visas are a problem, especially once courses come to an end.

Roughly 650,000 Japanese make their way to England each year, and 80 per cent of them wind up in London at some point. And when they come, they like to shop: the half-million who are just tourists spend more than £400m. Clothes are a top priority. Appearance is important, and whether you're a salaryman or a clubber, you have to look the part.

Both Teruyoshi Kawaguchi, 19, who likes to DJ and party in London's clubs, and Mayuko Shino, 19, who prefers to stay in and cook Japanese food with her friends, came to study at the Vidal Sassoon hairdressing school: a mecca for young Japanese visitors who hang around outside its nondescript entrance a short stroll from New Bond Street, smoking cigarettes and posing for photographs under the Vidal Sassoon door sign. They are outgoing and lively and confident about their futures; Teruyoshi intends to move into make-up ('I want to live in Paris or New York and do make up for fashion shows'), while Mayuko would like to settle in London as a full-time hairdresser.

The Japanese may be smitten with London, but you only have to wander into a supermarket to see the influence Japan is having over here. Japanese ingredients, take-out sushi and even full-blown supermarket sushi bars are now commonplace. Karaoke bars, loud and raucous variations of their Japanese counterparts, look set to stay, while noodle joints, conveyor-belt sushi bars and tatami-matted Japanese restaurants are opening all over the place.

The Japanese may be brand-crazy fans of English fashion from Paul Smith, Vivienne Westwood and Antoni & Alison to the more classic image of Burberry and Mulberry, but a number of Japanese designers are now well established in the UK. There's the Michiko Koshino store in Soho - white walls, chrome fittings, red floor, natty toys and gadgets, and distressingly desirable clothes - and Hysteric Glamour in Covent Garden's Neal Street. Plus the big three: Yohji Yamamoto, Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garçons and Issey Miyake.

Chikala Funada, 23, is a graphic design student at St Martins and an assistant photographer who works part time at the Michiko Koshino shop. He was born and raised in London and speaks fluent Japanese, English and French, as well as a little Spanish. And although he's always lived in the West, he understands why Japanese youth migrate to London. 'The Japanese culture is inspired by Confucianism. You have to respect your elders, whereas here you can talk to an older person as if they are your friend. It is much less formal.'

If there's one place in London the Japanese migrate to, it's Piccadilly Circus. Here you have the Japan Centre and the upmarket Mitsukoshi department store, where Western faces are rare, and non-Japanese can pretend they've suddenly been beamed into the depths of Tokyo. The Japan Centre is a compact, colourful blast of everything Japanese. There's a bento-box counter in the entrance, books, magazines and Hello Kitty accessories on the ground floor, a well-stocked supermarket in the basement and a travel agent and internet café on the first floor.

Round the corner in lower Regent Street, Mitsukoshi's discreet entrance looks more like that of a smart hotel than a classy shop and restaurant. But for the Japanese living in London and those on a six-countries-in- a-week whirlwind tour of Europe, it is home from home, but with London prices. Mitsukoshi is one of the biggest department stores in Japan, and although this is London, shoppers are greeted in Japanese and prices are given in both sterling and yen.

There used to be two other Japanese department stores nearby: Sogo and Isetan, but both went under with the Japanese recession. Mitsukoshi has halved over the past five years, with shoppers more likely to buy a tin of tea or box of shortbread biscuits than a Burberry coat.

Just a short walk away, there's the more integrated face of Japan in London in Brewer Street, which is packed with Japanese restaurants, including Kulu Kulu, possibly the smallest conveyor-belt sushi bar in the capital, always filled with a reassuring number of Japanese diners. Close by, resident Japanese stock up on supplies in the Arigato grocery store, or grab a bite to eat in the café - a handful of chairs squeezed into one corner.

Sisters Rii, 13, and Yui, 14, are in London for two days with their mother as part of a six-day package tour of Europe. Open any Japanese teen magazine and you will see their look staring back at you: bunched hair, knee-high socks, brightly coloured clothes and platform trainers. It's their first trip to London and they're enjoying themselves looking for souvenirs. And what do they enjoy doing back home in their spare time? They pause, for quite some time. 'Shopping,' says Rii. 'Shopping and basketball,' says Yui.

webTitle: The Japan issue: The £120,000 tuna and other fishy tales

fields.headline: The £120,000 tuna and other fishy tales
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt visits the world's biggest fish market
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt visits the world's biggest fish market.
fields.body:
It's 3am in Tokyo and Tsujiki market, the central clearing house for most of the food consumed in this great city, is starting its working day. To an outsider, it all looks vaguely menacing. A man, clearly drunk, is screaming at some police on the street. Past the squad car in a dark, shadowy space the size of several aircraft hangars, trucks are roaring in and out and crates of fruit, vegetables and fish are being loaded on to forklifts and wooden handcarts. Further in, the lights get brighter and the stalls begin - long, dense aisles of them going back as far as the eye can see, and all selling fish.

Established as Tokyo's central wholesale market after the Great Kanto earthquake of 1923 destroyed most of the city's private food markets, this is now the biggest fish market in the world, with a mind-boggling five million pounds of seafood (worth around £19m) passing through every night of the week except Sunday. After the order that characterises even Tokyo's most crowded urban spaces by day, the anarchy of this night-time world comes as something of a shock. Fork-lifts shoot up and down the wider aisles, the drivers screaming warnings to men in their way, but rarely slowing down. Huge ice-making machines rattle noisily before suddenly gushing waterfalls of cold cubes into waiting crates. The colour, the chaos and the noise are a sensory overload, but I realise something is missing. I can smell cigarette smoke, coffee, green tea and a vague whiff of the nearby ocean. What I can't smell is fish. It's a sign of the freshness and cleanliness which the market, built beside the ocean on land reclaimed from Tokyo Bay 300 years ago, is famous for.

By 4.30am, the canned coffee stall is doing a roaring trade and the middlemen are unpacking the night's new arrivals to display on their tightly packed stalls. Giant crabs, their massive claws restrained with elastic bands, lie stupefied on beds of ice. Scallops fidget in their shells. Live fish are kept in huge glass or metal tanks. Produce comes to Tsujiki from more than 60 different countries, and here you'll find every kind of seafood you could imagine - along with several you really couldn't. There are crates of writhing eels. Bright red squid. Metal counters piled high with colourful octopuses. Indonesian prawns, Chinese swimming crabs, Scottish salmon - and repulsive cream and black slug-like creatures protruding from shells in their watery tanks that had me so aghast that nearby workers hooted with laughter. But most of all, there's the tuna. Tsujiki's daily auction sets the price and standards for tuna worldwide, and is one of Japan's greatest spectacles.

At the very back of the market the bodies are being arranged in neat rows on wooden pallets on the floor. The tail section of each is cut off and laid alongside, exposing some flesh for the buyers to examine. In the warehouse behind them, the cheaper, frozen tuna are treated less delicately. Kept at -60 C to stop the precious oils turning rancid, they are completely solid, their sparkling white carcasses bouncing as they hit the ground and a ghostly white mist of dry ice rising from them to settle across the floor. The empty wooden crates nearby tell how far they have travelled: 'Caught by MV Amoria, Cape Town South Africa'; 'Richardo Fuentes, La Palma, Spain'; 'Tuna of the Indian Ocean 'Sri Lanka'; 'Quantas Australia air express'.

Getting them to market in the best condition has become a science in itself. On some boats, a steel rod is passed down the spine immediately after the fish is caught to flush out the enzymes which begin the process of decay; others are experimenting with acupuncturists who can relax the fish enough to keep it alive while they head for shore. Seven wholesale companies operate from the market, all of which lay out their goods near the wooden staging where the auctions are held, marking each fish with a red number.

Tonight, there are just over 500 fresh tuna being sold, all laid out in order of importance. The prized bluefin come first, the source of the most expensive sushi cuts: the delicate toro taken from the fattiest areas around the belly, and the very finest, fattiest otoro - which only the very rich can afford to eat. Then come the bigeye tuna and finally the cheaper yellowfin. Sizes vary depending on age. Some are the size of cows, others the size of a large cat. A mature, five-year-old bluefin can weigh in at over 1,000lb, but since these cost so much that ad-hoc consortiums often have to be formed to buy them, the wholesalers prefer tuna weighing in at 280-380lb. These younger fish are also less likely to have suffered injuries that could reduce their value.

The bidders walk through the rows, checking the date and place where each fish was caught, then crouching with their torches to examine the flesh more carefully. It should be firm, deep red and marbled with fat. They may also touch the cut tail section and put their hands into the belly slit to feel for fat content. At exactly 5.30am, the bells ring out and the auctions begin. The buyers don hats with yellow plastic tags attached displaying their licence numbers, and those bidding for the bluefin stand up on the wooden bleachers in front of the auctioneers' crude podiums. Prices are conveyed by a series of complex finger movements, and the auctioneers' frenzied screaming is almost impossible for outsiders to understand.

Early in January, a new record was set at Tsujiki when a 444lb bluefin sold for £120,000. At that price, it would apparently have been impossible for any restaurant to sell it for a profit: the buyer was probably willing to pay a such a premium to boast that he'd bought the first catch of the year. After bluefin are sold, the auctioneer begins to walk through the rows of bigeye and yellowfin followed by the buyers, shouting out bids in a voice so rhythmic it threatens to turn into song. Assistants write out invoices on the spot, and the wooden pallets start to empty as the tuna are heaved on to handcarts and disappear. Some go to the nearby stalls where they're carved up into to smaller pieces, the precious belly cuts displayed in glass cases to entice the sushi restaurateurs who are already arriving to buy that day's produce; others travel back across Japan, and even back to Narita to put in a few thousand more airmiles before being consumed. (The string of Nobu restaurants in Europe and the USA, for instance, buys fish here three times a week.)

Afterwards, I make my way to the market's oldest sushi restaurant. It's just 6.15 on a bitterly cold morning, but there's a queue of people outside, stamping their feet and peering impatiently through the steamed-up glass of the tiny restaurant's sliding door. There's a young couple in club clothes who've clearly been out all night; and family bringing their two-year-old to sample the freshest fish you can eat without catching it yourself. A Tokyo-based salaryman in a suit tells me he grew up in the Aomori area, by the coastal villages where some of the most prized tuna is landed. But the fish went straight from the boats to Tsujiki, so this will be the first time he's ever sampled tuna this fresh. This restaurant, he says, is reputed to have the best sushi in Japan. 'Best in world!' adds one of the clubbers with a grin.

Finally, I get to squeeze past the seven other diners in the tiny, narrow hut and take my place at the sushi bar, facing some huge, live prawns which squirm accusingly against the glass. The chef keeps up a constant banter with the customers, and there is much laughter, debate and loud appreciation of the food. It is indeed the best sushi I've ever tasted, washed down with sake and miso soup rattling with baby clams. The tuna melts on the tongue. The mackerel tastes of ocean spray. When I ask to try one of the prawns, the chef holds one up for my approval, slices it expertly, and within seconds it is in my mouth. The woman next to me jabs the leftover tail with her chopstick and the muscle spasms, making it move.

'Still alive,' she jokes.

'Call an ambulance!' I reply.

She translates this for the benefit of the other diners and the place erupts with laughter. For one enjoyable moment, I'm the wittiest woman in the world, eating the best sushi in the world. Or perhaps it was just the sake.

By the time I step out through the restaurant's tiny kitchen and back into the market, it is daylight and the atmosphere has changed. The warehouses where the auctions took place are empty except for a few men hosing down the spotless floors with sea water. Outside by the road, another tier of stalls is now opening to sell fresh food and all kinds of cooking equipment to the public. The area's sushi restaurants are popular at lunchtime, but by then Tsujiki's working day is over. By mid-afternoon, the wholesalers are already heading out to Narita airport to meet the new arrivals and choose the best for that night's auction.

 Thanks to sushi master Nobu Matsuhisa and Mark Edwards, executive chef at Nobu.
fields.bodyText: It's 3am in Tokyo and Tsujiki market, the central clearing house for most of the food consumed in this great city, is starting its working day. To an outsider, it all looks vaguely menacing. A man, clearly drunk, is screaming at some police on the street. Past the squad car in a dark, shadowy space the size of several aircraft hangars, trucks are roaring in and out and crates of fruit, vegetables and fish are being loaded on to forklifts and wooden handcarts. Further in, the lights get brighter and the stalls begin - long, dense aisles of them going back as far as the eye can see, and all selling fish. Established as Tokyo's central wholesale market after the Great Kanto earthquake of 1923 destroyed most of the city's private food markets, this is now the biggest fish market in the world, with a mind-boggling five million pounds of seafood (worth around £19m) passing through every night of the week except Sunday. After the order that characterises even Tokyo's most crowded urban spaces by day, the anarchy of this night-time world comes as something of a shock. Fork-lifts shoot up and down the wider aisles, the drivers screaming warnings to men in their way, but rarely slowing down. Huge ice-making machines rattle noisily before suddenly gushing waterfalls of cold cubes into waiting crates. The colour, the chaos and the noise are a sensory overload, but I realise something is missing. I can smell cigarette smoke, coffee, green tea and a vague whiff of the nearby ocean. What I can't smell is fish. It's a sign of the freshness and cleanliness which the market, built beside the ocean on land reclaimed from Tokyo Bay 300 years ago, is famous for. By 4.30am, the canned coffee stall is doing a roaring trade and the middlemen are unpacking the night's new arrivals to display on their tightly packed stalls. Giant crabs, their massive claws restrained with elastic bands, lie stupefied on beds of ice. Scallops fidget in their shells. Live fish are kept in huge glass or metal tanks. Produce comes to Tsujiki from more than 60 different countries, and here you'll find every kind of seafood you could imagine - along with several you really couldn't. There are crates of writhing eels. Bright red squid. Metal counters piled high with colourful octopuses. Indonesian prawns, Chinese swimming crabs, Scottish salmon - and repulsive cream and black slug-like creatures protruding from shells in their watery tanks that had me so aghast that nearby workers hooted with laughter. But most of all, there's the tuna. Tsujiki's daily auction sets the price and standards for tuna worldwide, and is one of Japan's greatest spectacles. At the very back of the market the bodies are being arranged in neat rows on wooden pallets on the floor. The tail section of each is cut off and laid alongside, exposing some flesh for the buyers to examine. In the warehouse behind them, the cheaper, frozen tuna are treated less delicately. Kept at -60 C to stop the precious oils turning rancid, they are completely solid, their sparkling white carcasses bouncing as they hit the ground and a ghostly white mist of dry ice rising from them to settle across the floor. The empty wooden crates nearby tell how far they have travelled: 'Caught by MV Amoria, Cape Town South Africa'; 'Richardo Fuentes, La Palma, Spain'; 'Tuna of the Indian Ocean 'Sri Lanka'; 'Quantas Australia air express'. Getting them to market in the best condition has become a science in itself. On some boats, a steel rod is passed down the spine immediately after the fish is caught to flush out the enzymes which begin the process of decay; others are experimenting with acupuncturists who can relax the fish enough to keep it alive while they head for shore. Seven wholesale companies operate from the market, all of which lay out their goods near the wooden staging where the auctions are held, marking each fish with a red number. Tonight, there are just over 500 fresh tuna being sold, all laid out in order of importance. The prized bluefin come first, the source of the most expensive sushi cuts: the delicate toro taken from the fattiest areas around the belly, and the very finest, fattiest otoro - which only the very rich can afford to eat. Then come the bigeye tuna and finally the cheaper yellowfin. Sizes vary depending on age. Some are the size of cows, others the size of a large cat. A mature, five-year-old bluefin can weigh in at over 1,000lb, but since these cost so much that ad-hoc consortiums often have to be formed to buy them, the wholesalers prefer tuna weighing in at 280-380lb. These younger fish are also less likely to have suffered injuries that could reduce their value. The bidders walk through the rows, checking the date and place where each fish was caught, then crouching with their torches to examine the flesh more carefully. It should be firm, deep red and marbled with fat. They may also touch the cut tail section and put their hands into the belly slit to feel for fat content. At exactly 5.30am, the bells ring out and the auctions begin. The buyers don hats with yellow plastic tags attached displaying their licence numbers, and those bidding for the bluefin stand up on the wooden bleachers in front of the auctioneers' crude podiums. Prices are conveyed by a series of complex finger movements, and the auctioneers' frenzied screaming is almost impossible for outsiders to understand. Early in January, a new record was set at Tsujiki when a 444lb bluefin sold for £120,000. At that price, it would apparently have been impossible for any restaurant to sell it for a profit: the buyer was probably willing to pay a such a premium to boast that he'd bought the first catch of the year. After bluefin are sold, the auctioneer begins to walk through the rows of bigeye and yellowfin followed by the buyers, shouting out bids in a voice so rhythmic it threatens to turn into song. Assistants write out invoices on the spot, and the wooden pallets start to empty as the tuna are heaved on to handcarts and disappear. Some go to the nearby stalls where they're carved up into to smaller pieces, the precious belly cuts displayed in glass cases to entice the sushi restaurateurs who are already arriving to buy that day's produce; others travel back across Japan, and even back to Narita to put in a few thousand more airmiles before being consumed. (The string of Nobu restaurants in Europe and the USA, for instance, buys fish here three times a week.) Afterwards, I make my way to the market's oldest sushi restaurant. It's just 6.15 on a bitterly cold morning, but there's a queue of people outside, stamping their feet and peering impatiently through the steamed-up glass of the tiny restaurant's sliding door. There's a young couple in club clothes who've clearly been out all night; and family bringing their two-year-old to sample the freshest fish you can eat without catching it yourself. A Tokyo-based salaryman in a suit tells me he grew up in the Aomori area, by the coastal villages where some of the most prized tuna is landed. But the fish went straight from the boats to Tsujiki, so this will be the first time he's ever sampled tuna this fresh. This restaurant, he says, is reputed to have the best sushi in Japan. 'Best in world!' adds one of the clubbers with a grin. Finally, I get to squeeze past the seven other diners in the tiny, narrow hut and take my place at the sushi bar, facing some huge, live prawns which squirm accusingly against the glass. The chef keeps up a constant banter with the customers, and there is much laughter, debate and loud appreciation of the food. It is indeed the best sushi I've ever tasted, washed down with sake and miso soup rattling with baby clams. The tuna melts on the tongue. The mackerel tastes of ocean spray. When I ask to try one of the prawns, the chef holds one up for my approval, slices it expertly, and within seconds it is in my mouth. The woman next to me jabs the leftover tail with her chopstick and the muscle spasms, making it move. 'Still alive,' she jokes. 'Call an ambulance!' I reply. She translates this for the benefit of the other diners and the place erupts with laughter. For one enjoyable moment, I'm the wittiest woman in the world, eating the best sushi in the world. Or perhaps it was just the sake. By the time I step out through the restaurant's tiny kitchen and back into the market, it is daylight and the atmosphere has changed. The warehouses where the auctions took place are empty except for a few men hosing down the spotless floors with sea water. Outside by the road, another tier of stalls is now opening to sell fresh food and all kinds of cooking equipment to the public. The area's sushi restaurants are popular at lunchtime, but by then Tsujiki's working day is over. By mid-afternoon, the wholesalers are already heading out to Narita airport to meet the new arrivals and choose the best for that night's auction.  Thanks to sushi master Nobu Matsuhisa and Mark Edwards, executive chef at Nobu.

fields.headline: Gut reactions
fields.standfirst: Why colon life is a battle between good and bad bacteria, how to stop bones breaking, and Japanese gentian's gentle action
fields.trailText: Why colon life is a battle between good and bad bacteria, how to stop bones breaking, and Japanese gentian's gentle action.
fields.body:
Most of you have probably accepted that eating organically can be a positive component of a healthy lifestyle, but have you considered going one step further and making pre- and probiotic foods a part of your daily life? Many studies, including seminal research carried out by Dr Minoru Shiroto, a professor at Japan's Imperial Kyoto University, have concluded that including pre- and probiotics in your diet can reduce your chances of succumbing to disease, particularly gastrointestinal cancer. Indeed I'm so excited by these studies that I must ask you to forgive me for reiterating some issues that I discussed in a recent column.

The colon houses over 400 different species of live bacteria, some of which produce toxins that can cause serious illnesses, while others - probiotics, particularly lactobacilli and bifido bacteria - have health-giving benefits. Because probiotics are found in live yogurts, a small pot a day can help to sustain a healthy bifido and lactobacilli presence in the colon, thereby alleviating irritable-bowel symptoms and assisting the body to recover from stomach upsets and food poisoning.

During their journey through the digestive system, probiotic bacteria are, however, exposed to several aggressive environmental factors, not least the fierce stomach acids that kill many of them before they reach the colon. And even when probiotic bacteria have made it to the colon, they will disappear almost as soon as you stop eating live yogurt, enabling the bad bacteria to take a hold. This is when the less ephemeral prebiotics can play a valuable role by encouraging the growth of good bacteria and banishing the bad. The two main prebiotics are the non-digestible oligosaccharides (NDOs) inulin and oligofructose, the richest nutritional sources of which are chicory root, Jerusalem artichokes, leeks, salsify, onions, wheat, bananas and other fruits, vegetables and grains. Not only do prebiotic foods travel directly to the colon without being digested by the enzymes within the digestive system, but, once there, they act as growth-enhancers for good bacteria, which in turn secrete enzymes that break down the prebiotics into bad-bacteria-inhibiting acids like butyric acid, which can both slow down the development of abnormal cells and help to kill established cancers.

I recommend you also include plenty of prebiotic foods in your diet. Remember that the fresher the vegetables, the higher the inulin content, and that it's best to increase the amount of prebiotics in your diet slowly to avoid being plagued by wind.

Nutrition news: Hone your bones

New research into preventing osteoporosis by Horiuchi et al, at the Tokyo Metropolitan Hospital's department of endocrinology, has found that women who have a diet that is rich in soya protein have both a higher bone-mineral density and a lower level of bone resorption than women who consume less soya, both of which decrease the risk of them developing osteoporosis.

While calcium plays a leading nutritional role in warding off the development of osteoporosis, many people worry about consuming too many dairy foods (the best-known sources of this mineral) because of the high levels of saturated animal fat they contain, an overconsumption of which can lead to heart disease. If you share this concern, consider soya products, such as tofu, which provide a good source of calcium in an easily digestible form.

Your questions

I have a hiatus hernia, but every time I try to go on a low-fat diet, which I gather is advisable, I find I lose too much weight, which I can ill afford to do. Can you help?
Janet Coburn, Leeds

It's true that reducing your intake of fatty foods can help to relieve some of the symptoms associated with hiatus hernias, such as reflux and heartburn. As you have found, however, reducing your fat intake can lead to weight loss. Another way of receiving a concentrated source of calories is to eat more sweet foods that don't contain much fat. You could add honey or sugar to drinks, snack on sweets, or end meals with desserts which aren't rich, such as frozen yogurts and sorbets. You could also increase your intake of low-fibre, starchy foods such as pasta, rice, potatoes and white bread.

Eating small meals often is healthier than having a few large meals a day anyway, so snack regularly, but watch acidic citrus fruits. Another tip is not to aggravate your symptoms by drinking too much liquid while eating. Because spicy foods, alcohol and lying down immediately after eating will worsen your symptoms, stick to milder foods, limit your alcohol intake and give your body time to digest your supper before going to bed. You could also enlist the aid of gravity to ward off night-time reflux by propping yourself up with pillows.
