fields.headline: Yen and the art of making mischief
fields.standfirst: If you thought chopping a cow in half pushed the boundaries of contemporary art, you haven't met Tatsumi Orimoto, otherwise known as Bread Man, a performer who has travelled the world with a bloomer tied over his face. Gaby Wood meets the Japanese artists who are causing a sensation in their own country
fields.trailText: If you thought chopping a cow in half pushed the boundaries of contemporary art, you haven't met Tatsumi Orimoto, otherwise known as Bread Man, a performer who has travelled the world with a bloomer tied over his face. Gaby Wood meets the Japanese artists who are causing a sensation in their own country.
fields.body:
Tatsumi Orimoto is, at 55, a grand old man of Japanese contemporary art. He has made his name with a performance piece, or live sculpture, which involves wrapping several loaves of bread around his head, tightly, with twine. The configurations are not accidental: there is a large oval bloomer at the front where his face should be, and at least six baguettes jutting out at various angles from the centre. Orimoto must scarcely be able to see behind this leaven elephantiasis, and yet he wanders about the world shaking hands, boarding trains, challenging people to accept him. You might call it street theatre of the absurd. He has been to Turkey, Nepal, Germany, and, with a photographer, documented each performative moment: the time he was chased by homeless people in New York, or thrown out of a restaurant in Moscow for wasting food; the occasions when he was laughed at by students or ignored by passing tourists as he posed at the foot of Big Ben. 'Bread Man', Orimoto says now, is a project that will continue until he dies.

This May, as part of the Tokyo Life exhibition at Selfridges, Orimoto will exhibit some of his photographs, and walk along Oxford Street as Bread Man. But for now, he is back in Kawasaki, the city outside Tokyo where he grew up. He lives with his mother in a small, traditional Japanese house. His mother has Alzheimer's, and while looking after her, he has made her the subject of his work; she is now known as Art Mama.

When I speak to Orimoto on the phone, he says he will meet me at Kawasaki station, since the directions to his house are rather complicated. 'Will you recognise me?' he asks. I pause, trying not to laugh, and wondering if I will recognise him without the bread. I am not sure how seriously Orimoto takes himself, but as soon as we meet, all concern is dispelled. 'I'm a very funny guy,' he tells me in passing. He has a round, smiling face and flowing grey hair. He has just bought us lunch and is riding a clapped-out old bicycle. As we enter his house, he indicates one of his early works on the doorstep: it's a leafless bonsai in a plant pot, with two old Converse sneakers hanging from its branches. 'Shoe-tree,' he says.

Orimoto's mother has just woken up from her mid-morning nap, and, as we join her on the electrically heated carpet, Orimoto gets out piles of papers and seemingly endless albums of photographs. 'This is my bible,' he says, handing me two thick yellow plastic volumes. Inside are postcards he has produced, of each of his performances - a documentary of his life as Bread Man.

When Orimoto finished school in Kawasaki, he tried to get into art college six years in a row and failed: 'My teacher said, Tatsumi, you are already an artist, not a student.' He emigrated to America, where he met Korean-born artist Nam June Paik, often dubbed the father of video art, and fell in with the Fluxus group in New York - Paik, John Cage, Yoko Ono. Orimoto, then a painter, had never heard of performance art, and though he has fond memories of meeting Joseph Beuys, he wasn't sure he understood it. 'They did very funny things,' he tells me. 'They would say, "Come to a party", and I'd bring beer, and there would be a barbecue - but they weren't cooking meat. They were cooking bricks, and serving them on plates!'

'I was looking for my style,' Orimoto says, and about 10 years ago he found it. A Christian friend told him that in the Bible 'bread means body', and that gave Orimoto an idea. If Marcel Duchamp could call a toilet a fountain, he explains, then 'bread means not food: it is sculpture'.

Seven years ago, Orimoto's father died. His mother's role, until then, had been to look after the patriarch, and at that point she found herself at a loss. Her body packed up, she developed Alzheimer's, and her son had to come back to look after her. He couldn't travel as much, and Bread Man's happenings dwindled. Then one day Orimoto realised: 'This, my daily life, is art.' He photographed his mother wearing enormous papier-mché shoes ( Small Mama + Big Shoes ), or out on her daily walks around the neighbourhood. As the tag line to one of his shows has it, 'the existence of my Mama is art'.

One piece is a picture of his mother and two of her friends sitting on a sofa at home. They are all wearing huge rubber tyres round their necks. By way of explanation, Orimoto makes a link between the junk people leave in the streets, and his mother's generation, who have been ignored by their children. There is a well-documented problem in Japan: how to care for its legions of elderly people. 'After very hard work,' Orimoto says gnomically, 'very broken body.' His brother, who lives 10 minutes away, never looks after his mother. 'The younger generation, they throw away everything.'

I ask how much his mother knows about what he is doing. 'My mother has no education - maybe she cannot understand contemporary art,' he says, 'but she believes in me, and I believe in her.' And sometimes, the drowsy person before us proves herself to be very sharp. 'When I'm preparing photographs for an exhibition,' Orimoto goes on, 'she says, "If somebody buys a photograph, you have to give me half the money!"'

Orimoto says that 'sometimes, I'm very tired from holding my bread on my head', and that he doesn't like performing Bread Man in Japan because people see him as dirty, or dangerous. In fact, he is only just beginning to be recognised in his own country, and many younger artists are hardly aware of his work.

But this is perhaps more to do with the culture of Tokyo than with Orimoto himself. All of the artists I interviewed pointed out that contemporary art is not recognised as a discipline by the average man or woman in the street, and that it's very hard to be an artist here for that reason. Even the word they use to describe themselves is not Japanese: they all call themselves 'artists', because the Japanese word seems dated. There may be a long aesthetic tradition, but it is not experimental. A generation younger than Orimoto's has found different ways of dealing with this problem: Maywa Denki is a pair of artists who masquerade as an electronics company, slipping art to the masses in the guise of something more familiar; Masato Nakamura, the most straightforwardly 'white cube' artist of them all, constantly probes and questions Japanese identity. He is the founder and key member of an artists' collective, Command N, which will also be exhibiting at Tokyo Life. They have an office in Akihabara, the electronics district of Tokyo, and aim to make art in the context of a new technological world. They have simultaneously 'hijacked' 32 TVs in electrical shops with video works, and at Selfridges they will present a spoof real-estate project, selling virtual views of Tokyo. Each of these artists has a way of looking at their culture and their capital city in a new, refracted light.

Masato Nakamura's work is in fact made of light. Whether it's a glowing shape in a wall, a sculpted set of barber-shop lamps or an intervention on the roof of a Tokyo taxi, all of it draws on the brightness of this 24-hour city.

As the daylight dims, the interpreter and I meet Nakamura in Command N's office in Akihabara. The streets are crowded with multicoloured, skyscraping neon lights. Below the signs, there are warrens of electronics shops, filled like sci-fi havens with minuscule surveillance cameras and bits of circuitry and chips for unimaginable machines. In the office, some members of Command N are setting up an exhibition in a space the size of a small stairwell. Nakamura, a tall, trendy man in his late thirties, takes us in his Volvo to his home, miles away in a suburb so quiet it feels like a movie set. As we arrive, his Korean wife Shin Myeong eun - also an artist and a member of Command N - comes round the corner with their two-year-old son. We go for dinner at a restaurant nearby, and Nakamura begins to speak about his work.

The piece that he will exhibit at Tokyo Life, in a new gallery space specially designed by architect David Adjaye, is called Minimal Selves . It is a series of nine monumental light boxes - beautiful, colourful, rectangular abstractions. Though Nakamura says he doesn't care if people in London see them as purely abstract works, what they are is the logos of the various convenience stores to be found on every street corner in Tokyo. Nakamura contacts the companies, and in most cases they put him in touch with their lighting manufacturers and supply the lights themselves. These 24-hour shops - 7-Eleven, Lawson, Family Mart, am/pm and so on - have become an undeniable feature of city life, but more than that, their effect is insidious. Unlike corner shops here, Japanese convenience stores operate on a sophist-icated computer tracking system, so they can follow trends and cater to changing tastes: they know how to make themselves indispensable.

And yet, once Nakamura has rearranged the neon signs into art, not everyone recognises the lights and colours that have already become embedded in their subconscious. The effect, according to Nakamura's gallerist, can be strangely subliminal. Nakamura is like a postmodern, Japanese version of Dan Flavin or James Turrell.

Nakamura compares himself to Andy Warhol, and explains that 'the difference between me and Warhol is that Warhol only made use of commercial images in the context of the art world, whereas I work within the commercial world itself'. And here we enter an area that is rather grey. Warhol's works were about consumerism, whereas Nakamura refuses to be drawn on whether he means to criticise commerce, or comment on it at all. And, moreover, he is often not free to comment, because the companies are involved in the art. The works, wonderful when seen as radical subversions, can seem disappointing when empty of political content.

This is not true of the convenience-store works so much as of his most famous piece, a version of which he will take to the Venice Biennale this year. mm is a gigantic Stonehenge-like circle made up of McDonald's symbols in bright-yellow neon. To anyone familiar with anti-corporate thinking, this appears to be a brilliant piece of satire. But in fact McDonald's is sponsoring the exhibition. Nakamura explains when I ask about this that he had to draw up an agreement between McDonald's and himself: the company has the right of veto over who buys the work, and where it is exhibited.

For the Biennale, Nakamura tells me, 'I am supported by McDonald's US, McDonald's Japan and McDonald's Italy. I risk being criticised for that, but I think it's OK because it's art.' Some may see this as naive, others might go so far as to call it politically irresponsible. Far from debunking global capitalism, Nakamura has made himself its slave, and mm , by extension, is not a criticism but a kind of hymn.

After dinner, Nakamura and his wife take us to their studio space. Nakamura's light boxes are already packed up and ready to leave for London, while her paintings are leaning against the walls - she is putting the finishing touches on them in time for a show. They are all different colour combinations of the same thing: rows and rows of garish poodles, in various states of unshavenness. Shin Myeong eun explains that once, these hairstyles had a function (to help the poodles swim and make them more aerodynamic), but now they have become merely decorative. Hence her paintings, which seem to be about poodles, are really about art itself, which has lost its function and become purely decorative. Meanwhile, their toddler has found a box full of plastic poodle sculptures, mini Jeff Koons-like extensions of his mother's paintings. He starts playing with one of them, but his parents try to explain that it's art. The kid doesn't look convinced.

Masato Nakamura makes a distinction between serious contemporary artists in Japan and those, like Maywa Denki, whom he dismisses as 'entertainers'. Dressed in light-blue uniforms, and calling themselves the 'President' and 'Vice-President' of the Maywa Denki company, Masamichi and Nobumichi Tosa make artworks and give musical performances. They have a contract with Sony Music, and are represented not by a gallery, but by the most successful agent of comedians in Japan. It's true that they are hilarious. And yet the objects they make - 'nonsense machines' built to look like parts of fish, a ventriloquist's dummy operated by a revolver, or shoes that tap-dance by remote control - are philosophical toys of which the Surrealists would have been proud.

I catch up with them in Paris, where they are performing in the Galerie du Jour, owned by Agnès b. She has designed the uniforms for the show, and playing to a packed house is Nobumichi Tosa, the company's vice-president. Tosa has some sort of flying machine strapped to his back, which turns out to be a set of curious castanets on metal wings. While he performs a Baron Münchhausen version of the flamenco, his two assistants accompany him on guitar-like drum systems built in the shape of a carp. They strike increasingly complicated beats, and at one point introduce robots whose heads automatically fly off as the others cheer. Then Tosa steps into the remote tap shoes and stands stock still as the shoes, equipped with finger-like drumming attachments, work their mad magic on their own. The other performers dance around the stage mechanically. They are completely straight-faced; the audience is in stitches.

In the neighbouring rooms, the 'nonsense machines' from the 'Naki', or fish, series are exhibited as if in a natural history museum gone strangely wrong. There is an electrical extension cable in the form of a fish skeleton, and a large birdcage with goldfish swimming at the bottom. There is a binocular device that simulates the vision of fish and carries the instruction: 'for use in fleeing from reality'. There are keyrings made in the image of the Tosa brothers and packed in plastic like ordinary toys, and there is a sketchbook contain ing 1,000 varieties of imaginary fish - airplane fish, bicycle fish, mermaid fish, elephant fish, blimp fish, fish wearing trousers. Maywa Denki aims to eventually draw 10,000 species of nonsense fish.

fields.bodyText: Tatsumi Orimoto is, at 55, a grand old man of Japanese contemporary art. He has made his name with a performance piece, or live sculpture, which involves wrapping several loaves of bread around his head, tightly, with twine. The configurations are not accidental: there is a large oval bloomer at the front where his face should be, and at least six baguettes jutting out at various angles from the centre. Orimoto must scarcely be able to see behind this leaven elephantiasis, and yet he wanders about the world shaking hands, boarding trains, challenging people to accept him. You might call it street theatre of the absurd. He has been to Turkey, Nepal, Germany, and, with a photographer, documented each performative moment: the time he was chased by homeless people in New York, or thrown out of a restaurant in Moscow for wasting food; the occasions when he was laughed at by students or ignored by passing tourists as he posed at the foot of Big Ben. 'Bread Man', Orimoto says now, is a project that will continue until he dies. This May, as part of the Tokyo Life exhibition at Selfridges, Orimoto will exhibit some of his photographs, and walk along Oxford Street as Bread Man. But for now, he is back in Kawasaki, the city outside Tokyo where he grew up. He lives with his mother in a small, traditional Japanese house. His mother has Alzheimer's, and while looking after her, he has made her the subject of his work; she is now known as Art Mama. When I speak to Orimoto on the phone, he says he will meet me at Kawasaki station, since the directions to his house are rather complicated. 'Will you recognise me?' he asks. I pause, trying not to laugh, and wondering if I will recognise him without the bread. I am not sure how seriously Orimoto takes himself, but as soon as we meet, all concern is dispelled. 'I'm a very funny guy,' he tells me in passing. He has a round, smiling face and flowing grey hair. He has just bought us lunch and is riding a clapped-out old bicycle. As we enter his house, he indicates one of his early works on the doorstep: it's a leafless bonsai in a plant pot, with two old Converse sneakers hanging from its branches. 'Shoe-tree,' he says. Orimoto's mother has just woken up from her mid-morning nap, and, as we join her on the electrically heated carpet, Orimoto gets out piles of papers and seemingly endless albums of photographs. 'This is my bible,' he says, handing me two thick yellow plastic volumes. Inside are postcards he has produced, of each of his performances - a documentary of his life as Bread Man. When Orimoto finished school in Kawasaki, he tried to get into art college six years in a row and failed: 'My teacher said, Tatsumi, you are already an artist, not a student.' He emigrated to America, where he met Korean-born artist Nam June Paik, often dubbed the father of video art, and fell in with the Fluxus group in New York - Paik, John Cage, Yoko Ono. Orimoto, then a painter, had never heard of performance art, and though he has fond memories of meeting Joseph Beuys, he wasn't sure he understood it. 'They did very funny things,' he tells me. 'They would say, "Come to a party", and I'd bring beer, and there would be a barbecue - but they weren't cooking meat. They were cooking bricks, and serving them on plates!' 'I was looking for my style,' Orimoto says, and about 10 years ago he found it. A Christian friend told him that in the Bible 'bread means body', and that gave Orimoto an idea. If Marcel Duchamp could call a toilet a fountain, he explains, then 'bread means not food: it is sculpture'. Seven years ago, Orimoto's father died. His mother's role, until then, had been to look after the patriarch, and at that point she found herself at a loss. Her body packed up, she developed Alzheimer's, and her son had to come back to look after her. He couldn't travel as much, and Bread Man's happenings dwindled. Then one day Orimoto realised: 'This, my daily life, is art.' He photographed his mother wearing enormous papier-mché shoes ( Small Mama + Big Shoes ), or out on her daily walks around the neighbourhood. As the tag line to one of his shows has it, 'the existence of my Mama is art'. One piece is a picture of his mother and two of her friends sitting on a sofa at home. They are all wearing huge rubber tyres round their necks. By way of explanation, Orimoto makes a link between the junk people leave in the streets, and his mother's generation, who have been ignored by their children. There is a well-documented problem in Japan: how to care for its legions of elderly people. 'After very hard work,' Orimoto says gnomically, 'very broken body.' His brother, who lives 10 minutes away, never looks after his mother. 'The younger generation, they throw away everything.' I ask how much his mother knows about what he is doing. 'My mother has no education - maybe she cannot understand contemporary art,' he says, 'but she believes in me, and I believe in her.' And sometimes, the drowsy person before us proves herself to be very sharp. 'When I'm preparing photographs for an exhibition,' Orimoto goes on, 'she says, "If somebody buys a photograph, you have to give me half the money!"' Orimoto says that 'sometimes, I'm very tired from holding my bread on my head', and that he doesn't like performing Bread Man in Japan because people see him as dirty, or dangerous. In fact, he is only just beginning to be recognised in his own country, and many younger artists are hardly aware of his work. But this is perhaps more to do with the culture of Tokyo than with Orimoto himself. All of the artists I interviewed pointed out that contemporary art is not recognised as a discipline by the average man or woman in the street, and that it's very hard to be an artist here for that reason. Even the word they use to describe themselves is not Japanese: they all call themselves 'artists', because the Japanese word seems dated. There may be a long aesthetic tradition, but it is not experimental. A generation younger than Orimoto's has found different ways of dealing with this problem: Maywa Denki is a pair of artists who masquerade as an electronics company, slipping art to the masses in the guise of something more familiar; Masato Nakamura, the most straightforwardly 'white cube' artist of them all, constantly probes and questions Japanese identity. He is the founder and key member of an artists' collective, Command N, which will also be exhibiting at Tokyo Life. They have an office in Akihabara, the electronics district of Tokyo, and aim to make art in the context of a new technological world. They have simultaneously 'hijacked' 32 TVs in electrical shops with video works, and at Selfridges they will present a spoof real-estate project, selling virtual views of Tokyo. Each of these artists has a way of looking at their culture and their capital city in a new, refracted light. Masato Nakamura's work is in fact made of light. Whether it's a glowing shape in a wall, a sculpted set of barber-shop lamps or an intervention on the roof of a Tokyo taxi, all of it draws on the brightness of this 24-hour city. As the daylight dims, the interpreter and I meet Nakamura in Command N's office in Akihabara. The streets are crowded with multicoloured, skyscraping neon lights. Below the signs, there are warrens of electronics shops, filled like sci-fi havens with minuscule surveillance cameras and bits of circuitry and chips for unimaginable machines. In the office, some members of Command N are setting up an exhibition in a space the size of a small stairwell. Nakamura, a tall, trendy man in his late thirties, takes us in his Volvo to his home, miles away in a suburb so quiet it feels like a movie set. As we arrive, his Korean wife Shin Myeong eun - also an artist and a member of Command N - comes round the corner with their two-year-old son. We go for dinner at a restaurant nearby, and Nakamura begins to speak about his work. The piece that he will exhibit at Tokyo Life, in a new gallery space specially designed by architect David Adjaye, is called Minimal Selves . It is a series of nine monumental light boxes - beautiful, colourful, rectangular abstractions. Though Nakamura says he doesn't care if people in London see them as purely abstract works, what they are is the logos of the various convenience stores to be found on every street corner in Tokyo. Nakamura contacts the companies, and in most cases they put him in touch with their lighting manufacturers and supply the lights themselves. These 24-hour shops - 7-Eleven, Lawson, Family Mart, am/pm and so on - have become an undeniable feature of city life, but more than that, their effect is insidious. Unlike corner shops here, Japanese convenience stores operate on a sophist-icated computer tracking system, so they can follow trends and cater to changing tastes: they know how to make themselves indispensable. And yet, once Nakamura has rearranged the neon signs into art, not everyone recognises the lights and colours that have already become embedded in their subconscious. The effect, according to Nakamura's gallerist, can be strangely subliminal. Nakamura is like a postmodern, Japanese version of Dan Flavin or James Turrell. Nakamura compares himself to Andy Warhol, and explains that 'the difference between me and Warhol is that Warhol only made use of commercial images in the context of the art world, whereas I work within the commercial world itself'. And here we enter an area that is rather grey. Warhol's works were about consumerism, whereas Nakamura refuses to be drawn on whether he means to criticise commerce, or comment on it at all. And, moreover, he is often not free to comment, because the companies are involved in the art. The works, wonderful when seen as radical subversions, can seem disappointing when empty of political content. This is not true of the convenience-store works so much as of his most famous piece, a version of which he will take to the Venice Biennale this year. mm is a gigantic Stonehenge-like circle made up of McDonald's symbols in bright-yellow neon. To anyone familiar with anti-corporate thinking, this appears to be a brilliant piece of satire. But in fact McDonald's is sponsoring the exhibition. Nakamura explains when I ask about this that he had to draw up an agreement between McDonald's and himself: the company has the right of veto over who buys the work, and where it is exhibited. For the Biennale, Nakamura tells me, 'I am supported by McDonald's US, McDonald's Japan and McDonald's Italy. I risk being criticised for that, but I think it's OK because it's art.' Some may see this as naive, others might go so far as to call it politically irresponsible. Far from debunking global capitalism, Nakamura has made himself its slave, and mm , by extension, is not a criticism but a kind of hymn. After dinner, Nakamura and his wife take us to their studio space. Nakamura's light boxes are already packed up and ready to leave for London, while her paintings are leaning against the walls - she is putting the finishing touches on them in time for a show. They are all different colour combinations of the same thing: rows and rows of garish poodles, in various states of unshavenness. Shin Myeong eun explains that once, these hairstyles had a function (to help the poodles swim and make them more aerodynamic), but now they have become merely decorative. Hence her paintings, which seem to be about poodles, are really about art itself, which has lost its function and become purely decorative. Meanwhile, their toddler has found a box full of plastic poodle sculptures, mini Jeff Koons-like extensions of his mother's paintings. He starts playing with one of them, but his parents try to explain that it's art. The kid doesn't look convinced. Masato Nakamura makes a distinction between serious contemporary artists in Japan and those, like Maywa Denki, whom he dismisses as 'entertainers'. Dressed in light-blue uniforms, and calling themselves the 'President' and 'Vice-President' of the Maywa Denki company, Masamichi and Nobumichi Tosa make artworks and give musical performances. They have a contract with Sony Music, and are represented not by a gallery, but by the most successful agent of comedians in Japan. It's true that they are hilarious. And yet the objects they make - 'nonsense machines' built to look like parts of fish, a ventriloquist's dummy operated by a revolver, or shoes that tap-dance by remote control - are philosophical toys of which the Surrealists would have been proud. I catch up with them in Paris, where they are performing in the Galerie du Jour, owned by Agnès b. She has designed the uniforms for the show, and playing to a packed house is Nobumichi Tosa, the company's vice-president. Tosa has some sort of flying machine strapped to his back, which turns out to be a set of curious castanets on metal wings. While he performs a Baron Münchhausen version of the flamenco, his two assistants accompany him on guitar-like drum systems built in the shape of a carp. They strike increasingly complicated beats, and at one point introduce robots whose heads automatically fly off as the others cheer. Then Tosa steps into the remote tap shoes and stands stock still as the shoes, equipped with finger-like drumming attachments, work their mad magic on their own. The other performers dance around the stage mechanically. They are completely straight-faced; the audience is in stitches. fields.headline: Kelp is at hand
fields.standfirst: These days real seaweed fans know their kombu from their nori, finds Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: These days real seaweed fans know their kombu from their nori, finds Sybil Kapoor.
fields.body:
Anthropologists could have a field day analysing why one man's food is another man's poison. Civet cat, for example, cooked with snake and chicken is considered a delicacy in Kuala Lumpur but not in Britain. Clearly, much depends on the social image of an ingredient. In Japan, seaweed is an essential element in cooking. It is admired for its beauty, taste, texture and nutritional value. Here, many still regard it as a food fit only for fish and nut-crunching hippies. Such Western attitudes, however, are slowly being eroded by the appearance of sushi in sandwich shops and by chefs such as Mark Edwards and Peter Gordon, who incorporate Japanese ingredients into their cooking.

Thus, the glamour babes who hang out in Nobu can cut their pearly whites on a Mark Edwards salad of turbot sashimi, which has been marinated between slices of kombu (dried kelp). This contains a natural form of glutamic acid, which enhances the taste of other ingredients. Alternatively, they may choose to drape themselves at Providores in Marylebone, which Peter Gordon is opening this summer, and nibble a salmon roll wrapped in nori (a marine algae that is dried in sheets), dipped in a beer batter, deep fried and served with a dipping sauce.

As Rob Shipman, sous chef at Nobu, explains: 'We experiment by applying Japanese ideas to Western recipes. We might add some kombu to an ordinary chicken stock to intensify its flavour, or leave a piece in tomato water (tomato juice drained overnight through muslin) to make a consommé or jelly.' It adds a deliciously deep, saline note.

The Japanese cultivate and eat more than 20 varieties of seaweed, of which wakame, kombu and nori are the most popular. Kombu, the best - and most expensive - is speckled white with dried mineral salts. Washing will destroy these and some of its complex flavour, so wipe with a clean damp cloth instead.

Wakame seaweed is a calcium-rich, lobe-leafed Undaria pinnatifida that belongs to the brown algae family. You often find its vibrant green leaves floating in miso soup. It is sold dried as a frond or in small pieces. If you buy a frond, soak it for 20 minutes in tepid water, then cut away its tough ribs. Its leaves taste wonderful in salads - just scald in hot water after soaking, then plunge into cold water. Otherwise, drop it into clear soups and simmer for a minute - any longer and it will turn to mush. 'It also makes an excellent sauce for noodles,' explains Peter Gordon. 'Just purée it and flavour to taste with sesame oil, lime juice, sesame seeds, spring onions and cashew nuts.'

It is only a matter of time before every foodie will be garnishing their dishes with a julienne of toasted nori and flavouring their roast chicken and root vegetables à la Peter Gordon with dried kelp. After all, you can now buy nori-wrapped sushi from your local supermarket.

 For further information on seaweed, try Japanese Cooking: a Simple Art by Shizuo Tsuji (£17, Kodansha). Anyone intrigued by civet cat might enjoy Big Snake by Robert Twigger (£7.99, Phoenix). Providores, 109 Marylebone High Street, London W1, is due to open in August. Nobu, 19 Old Park Lane, London W1 (020 7447 4747)

fields.headline: Voting for reiki
fields.standfirst: After the furore of 1998's 'Lobbygate', Derek Draper had many questions to ask of himself. Reiki helped him find some answers
fields.trailText: After the furore of 1998's 'Lobbygate', Derek Draper had many questions to ask of himself. Reiki helped him find some answers.
fields.body:
I never consciously decided to try reiki, indeed I'm not sure I'd even heard of it when I first lay down next to Barbara Ann, who was to become my regular healer and eventual teacher. I had booked my appointment thinking that reiki was, in fact, shiatsu. Don't ask me how I got them mixed up.

After a bad bout of depression in late 1998, I had been trying out different ways of living. I had discovered that the hard-work hard-play lifestyle had not made me happy. The more money I earned, the more politicking I got up to, the more sex I had, the more drugs I tried, I still felt a growing sense that my life was empty and pointless.

During a spell in The Priory, I had tried yoga and discovered a sense of peace, especially during the more meditative breathing exercises. I'd also found a cranial osteopath who seemed able to shift the chemicals around inside my brain, quite perceptibly, improving my mood with the lightest pressure.

Now, I wasn't relying exclusively on 'alternative' remedies. I was taking a strong antidepressant (Venlafaxine) and having regular therapy, but I felt that the other things I was trying were, literally, complementary.

I took up aromatherapy and even bought one or two crystals. Sceptics will claim that any effect these remedies had were 'all in the mind', but that doesn't devalue them. That was where my depression was, too. Then a friend suggested shiatsu and I thought: 'Why not give it a try?' Somehow, though, I ended up picking up a leaflet for reiki - my mind had transposed the two.

So that is how I ended up sitting cross-legged next to Barbara Ann, who began to briefly explain what reiki was. I soon realised that it wasn't the simple massage I had expected. She was talking of 'energies', 'healing' and 'the light'. She seemed to radiate pleasant feelings, and when she asked me to lie down, I thought, 'Well, I may as well give it a go.'

She placed various crystals around, and on, my body, which lay on a soft mat on the floor, my head and knees lifted slightly by small pillows. She lit some incense and put on some dreamy music. I closed my eyes. I felt Barbara Ann kneeling behind my head. She placed her fingers on my temples. I took a deep breath. It was like someone was shining a warm light into my body, through my skull, down my neck and into my chest. I took a really deep breath, then another, and my body relaxed.

These feelings and the ones that followed are not easy to describe. They are also not easy to explain. If someone had described them to me, I would have been sceptical. I don't expect to convince anyone of the power or efficacy of reiki by writing about it. It is something that has to be experienced. Part of its potency for me that first time was, I am sure, due to my not having any preconceptions about what was going to happen. My mind and body did not 'expect' a particular experience and so maybe they were more open than they otherwise would have been to what happened.

Reiki is, in layman's terms, a form of spiritual healing. Like any system of healing, different practitioners explain it in diverse ways, and I am no expert, but the bare bones of the theory are this: we are beings made of energy (so far, physics would agree), and we are connected to the universal source of energy - what some would call nature, others the universe, some God. That energy flows through us, though sometimes our consciousness and bodies create blockages, and we close off to the energy. Reiki healers channel the energy - focusing it, if you like, in concentrated form - and send it into the person being healed. There it interacts with body, mind, spirit and emotions, providing holistic healing.

Reiki is a Japanese word that is not easy to translate. The first part means spirit or soul, the second, cosmic energy (this aspect is also known as 'chi' or 'prana' in yoga). Together the word means 'God-directed lifeforce energy' (with God defined in the way relevant to you).

It is this pure, positive energy that flows through the body during reiki healing. It's hard to imagine but incredibly easy to experience. When the energy started flowing through me, it was like being bathed in warm, soft white light. It was not a subtle feeling. As Barbara Ann moved around me, placing her hands on my chest, my abdomen, my legs, bursts of the energy would ripple luxuriously through my body. My mind went to another place, ordinary humdrum thoughts were banished, and I experienced feelings I'd never felt before: of being deeply at peace, and being connected to something vast, beyond the mere me. I ceased to be conscious of the boundary of my body. I seemed to exist beyond my skin.

I later learnt that I had become conscious of my aura, the energy field that surrounds each of us. fields.headline: Raw talent
fields.standfirst: Roll your own sushi, says Sue Webster. It's easier than you would think
fields.trailText: Roll your own sushi, says Sue Webster. It's easier than you would think.
fields.body:
I realise every serious, seven-year-apprenticed sushi chef will write in to protest about this, but I'd just like to say that making sushi is a piece of cake. (Well, no worse than making pastry, anyway.) And Alex Ward, proprietor of the largest Japanese food store in the south of England, Midori (19 Marlborough Place, Brighton, 01273 601 460) agrees. 'Everyone wants to make their own sushi now,' he says, noting that Japanese food has overtaken Thai in the past 18 months as the most popular Oriental cuisine. He advises on all the necessary ingredients: sushi rice, nori (sheets of seaweed), sushi su (rice vinegar), wasabi (fiery green horseradish-like paste), pink pickled ginger and soy sauce for dipping. The only implement you need is the sushi mat, for rolling. The raw fish used must be in superfresh condition, so choose your local supplier carefully.

Midori is not licensed, which is a pity, given that a sushi feast is nothing without sake or Japanese beer, but this is not a problem that affects The Jasmin, a Japanese shop in the Stanton House Hotel (The Avenue, Stanton Fitzwarren, Swindon; 01793 861 777) that sells frozen fish, dried goods and fresh produce, including tofu and daikon. This very English hotel also has a Japanese restaurant, the Rosemary.

Most larger branches of Tesco, Safeway, Waitrose and Sainsbury stock Japanese noodles and savoury condiments - sweets are harder to come by. Andrew Cook runs an outpost of Mountfuji International near Shrewsbury (01743 741 169) which offers a nationwide mail-order service on hundreds of products, including sweets such as yokan. Made from sugar, red beans and agar, yokan (75p per 50g stick or £4.12 for a gift pack) is alleged to enhance the flavour of green tea, though Cook maintains the better-quality green teas 'are less bitter or bland' than cheaper varieties. He has just launched www.japanesetea.co.uk, selling Sencha tea direct from the plantation to Britons keen on its proven health benefits.

Other reputable companies offering Japanese ingredients by mail order include Clearspring Direct (020 8746 0152). Many Chinese grocers sell some Japanese items. Arigato (50 Brewer Street, London W1; 020 7287 1722) sells dried, fresh and frozen goods as well as sushi. In Leeds, Harvey Nichols (107-111 Briggate; 0113 204 8888) boasts a big range of products, including a swish sushi set (£17.95) which makes a lovely gift.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: mastering the art of spacing out, and how to pack in piles
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: mastering the art of spacing out, and how to pack in piles.
fields.body:
A Japanese friend of mine - transatlantic, transpacific entrepreneur and promoter in the fashion and music business, and partner to a magazine publisher and mother, who does, it must be said, bear a striking resemblance to Yoko Ono both in looks and demeanour, and who is one of the hardest-working people on the planet - somehow never manages to lose her composure.

Stoical and unfussily serene, she takes whatever life throws her way with the apparent equipoise and containment of a Zen master.

Treating her over the years, I have been struck by her absolute humility in being able to accept and respect the irony of a comparatively clumsy Westerner practicing Oriental medicine and teaching Oriental life strategies. But more, I was surprised by how she readily admitted to feeling extraordinarily stressed and internally quite out of kilter, when all along I'd assumed her to be a reincarnation of the Buddha herself.

What was really remarkable, though, was how quickly during treatment she would sink into what can only be described as 'Zen mode'. With only the slightest prompting, she became empty. Empty of self and therefore entirely available and receptive to treatment almost instantly, as if she'd been trained to do so as a child. There were fewer layers of social defences to dissolve before we got down to that necessary place of stillness where the healing takes place.

I've found it the same with all the Japanese people I've had the pleasure to work with - including even the nervous teenage student with mobile phone, minidisc, dyed-tangerine hair, exotic skateboardwear and IBS who mixed up 'r's and 'l's and giggled almost continually in between, or the overstressed banker with a propensity for bowing endlessly, attending wild, drunken karaoke nights, maintaining underage schoolgirl 'mistresses' and stomach ulcers. It seems far easier for them to get to that 'Zen space' than for us internally baggage- laden Westerners.

I first encountered the 'Zen space' in Tia Honsai, my Aikido master when I was just a lad. He was also a healer who had learned to channel 'ki', the Japanese version of 'chi', or life force. He called it 'super ki' and claimed it had the power to stop a locomotive as well as heal the gravest disease, but to access it, one had to learn to completely still one's thoughts and fine-focus the now-empty mind on the area to be healed. Then one had to merge one's consciousness with the 'pure consciousness' of the universe, thus overriding the local mind, and think about 'one point', the tanden, 2in below the navel, the acupuncture point that controls the 'sea of breath', or 'hara', where 'ki' is generated.

In fact, to develop 'hara' is considered crucial to being a fully rounded person. In the practice of Zen archery, for instance, the master observes the student's tanden, ignoring the target board altogether, yet can predict a bullseye accurately every time according to the archer's visible degree of hara-centredness or 'one-pointedness'.

In this empty minded, hara-centred mode, Tia Honsai believed us to be indestructible. If there was 'no-mind', as the Zen Buddhists call it, what or who could there be to destroy?

To help the Zen student achieve this imperturbable no-mind state, the master or 'roshi' asks a non-linear question - a koan - designed to make the mind momentarily crash. Something like: 'When a tree falls in the forest and there is no one there to hear it, does it make a noise?' or that old favourite: 'What is the sound of one hand clapping?' The student would be sent away to contemplate the koan and expected to come back with an answer. If a logical, linear response was attempted, the student would be sent away again to reconsider, perhaps with an admonishing tap on the forehead from the roshi's stick. If, on the other hand, the student returned with a non-rational, lateral response, showing an appreciation for the innate 'isness' or 'suchness' of a tree falling silently or the improbable thwack of a hand clapping the air - perhaps playfully tweeking the roshi's nose as his answer - the student would be considered to have 'got it'.

Zen aficionados also talk of developing 'beginner's mind', that ability to remain fresh in every new moment, uncluttered by prejudices gathered from past experiences. Every experience is new, no matter how many times you've been there before. Like a baby, you absorb without judgement and never allow yourself to be deluded into becoming jaded.

Look at a Zen garden or the interior of a traditional Japanese home - the inspiration behind our own Western ideas of minimalist design. The spacious unclutteredness is meant to represent the serenity of an empty and therefore tranquil beginner's mind.

But it would be misguided to believe that all Japanese people are potential Zen adepts, just as it would be to believe all Westerners are potentially great footballers. Indeed, the Japanese are the most prolific inventors and consumers of gadgetry designed to distract from inner silence of any nation on earth. But beneath the face of pocket robots, micro cameras, drunken karaoke sessions and instant noodles, the potential for reaching the 'Zen space' seems culturally programmed from birth into every individual.

We, though blessed with many other fine attributes (our quirky sense of humour, for one), are however not so well-endowed in the Zen sense. We find it hard to be empty of self. If you don't believe me, try now sitting 'sazen', meditation-style, preferably with back straight but relaxed (on the floor with knees bent and buttocks perched on heels is best but in an armchair will do), and eyes three-quarters open. Allow your breathing to settle down and deepen, then quite purposefully proceed to think about absolutely nothing for 20 minutes.

If you find that level of inner stillness hard to achieve, don't commit hari kari over it. Instead, consider a visit to a practitioner of shiatsu, and have your Zen done for you while you lie there and relax.

This is a mildly rambling (like the streets of Tokyo) Barefoot Doctorsan bidding you a fond sayonara till next week.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot Doctor, For some years I have suffered from infrequent (but painful) attacks of piles. Usual medicines clear them up, but is there any advice you can give to prevent or even eradicate them once and for all? I am 36, male and drive two hours a day, usually with early cold starts. Cheers.
JH, Gloucestershire

Interestingly, early cold starts, according to Oriental medicine affect your spleen - it's the organ believed to be off-balanced by not sleeping through till at least 7am. The spleen is also ascribed the function of holding things in place against the earthward gravitational pull and is therefore responsible for preventing prolapses of any kind, especially piles. Treatment consists of stimulation of spleen meridian points in the lower leg by needling or pressure and needling of the crown of the head to stimulate a pull through the torso to lift the piles back up, so to speak. Any competent acupuncture specialist can treat this prophylactically - it would probably require a treatment every three weeks or so.

It also helps to regularly practising inverted yoga postures (shoulder stands, head stands and hand stands) while rhythmically squeezing and releasing the anal sphincter muscles nine times or so at a slow, steady tempo.

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com

fields.headline: Class warrior
fields.standfirst: You don't need wellies and a labrador to enjoy Toyota's RAV4. Nick Mickshik tests a 4x4 for the masses
fields.trailText: You don't need wellies and a labrador to enjoy Toyota's RAV4. Nick Mickshik tests a 4x4 for the masses.
fields.body:
RAV4 GX
Price £18,495
MPG 32.1
Engine size 1998cc
BHP 147
Max speed 115mph
0-60mph 10.6 seconds
Driven wheels 4

I confess that I have been coveting a RAV4 since the original models were launched to such acclaim in the mid-90s. Each year when that difficult, lonely time for the motorist comes around (MOT and service) I consider with increasing seriousness laying my ancient Nissan Micra to rest and taking the quantum jump from anonymous, functional motoring to automotive style statement.

Not being of the generation at which the RAV4 is primarily aimed, however, there has always been a shade too much cognitive dissonance to overcome. Like coming to trainers or class A drugs in your thirties, there is a deal of baggage to be handled in making such a dramatic leap in the lifestyle stakes. So why the attraction? It is not, despite the excitement it caused when it first came out, because of the car's looks. Certainly, the rugged-but-sporty Tonka toy styling holds an appeal but, as someone who tends to say 'a red one' when asked what kind of car I drive, I am not that much interested in the look of the thing.

Nor is it anything to do with the permanent four-wheel drive feature, supposedly giving the RAV off-road capabilities. Like the vast majority of drivers who also happen to be non-farmers, the idea of taking your own £18,000 Tonka toy across sliding mud fields or wet hillsides is not particularly attractive. Supposing it gets stuck and you have to get your trainers muddy?

And I don't think the appeal is down to the RAV's undoubted performance qualities, even though in comparative tests with rivals the new models, like their forerunners, tend to come top or near top in most categories and best overall.

There are yet other factors that might persuade you if you were faced with a difficult choice. Fuel economy is very good for its class, but not at the expense of performance: a top speed of 115mph puts it beyond the reach of most competitors. And when exhaust emission is taken into consideration - as I suspect it might be by a growing percentage of its target market - the RAV, like all new Toyotas, excels, with the lowest CO 2 reading in its class.

But these are all really plus points, the icing on the cake. The true appeal of this car lies in its king-of-the-road, high-up driving position and fortress feel. Long the preserve of the Barbour-wearing, Land Rover-driving class and its tragic imitators, the real achievement of the RAV and its ilk is to democratise the natural feeling of superiority the elevated driving position confers and make it available to the Nike-shod masses.

This, at any rate, was the theory which four fully grown adults put to the test on a long weekend break on the Norfolk coast in the five-door GX model.

The first thing we noticed, and continued to notice throughout the trip, was the level of comfort in both front and back seats. A 200-mile unbroken stretch of mixed A-road, motorway and urban sprawl presented no problems in terms of comfort for driver or passengers. The car proved so comfortable, in fact, that there was none of the jockeying for position for the front passenger seat to be expected on any long-distance trip, and a couple of us who are normally susceptible to car sickness even found we could read in the rear seats for lengthy periods without feeling queasy.

The longer the weekend went on, the more we appreciated the car. Whether we had just done a long, wind-swept walk or stopped for fish and chips, we were always happy to climb in, settle into the enveloping fortress of comfort and peer down contentedly at the world speeding by.

A few points could be made on the debit side. The most important concerns not just the RAV4 but the so-called sports utility vehicle in general. Having more or less the same wheel base as your standard small car or saloon but being that much taller, the SUV - as our manual baldly, hilariously pointed out - has a greater tendency to roll over. Seeing it in black and white, however, meant that the thought was never far from our minds when driving, particularly in any kind of cross-wind, although I'm sure that greater acquaintance would banish this particular doubt.

The second minus point concerns the rear (fifth) door. In general, the build quality of the RAV4 is pretty good for its class, with a chunky, reassuring feel. But the rear door closes in very tinny fashion, introducing an unexpected off note that lingers in the memory. It sounds trivial but, when you come back from a picnic in a quiet country park and find yourself next to a Freelander or Shogun, you don't want the Wellingtons to think you're cheap when you pack away your ghetto blasters and baseball bats. Last on the debit side is the alienating name. Why 'RAV4'? While the false tenet has long held sway in advertising and marketing that the surreal, the elusive and the unexplained are synonymous with hipness and desirability, and while I accept that any three-letter-name car must be aimed at the generation who first wore trainers in primary school and who will stop taking class A drugs in their 30s, I cannot help but wish that Toyota had found some other silly possible acronym that was less off-putting.

These are really no more than quibbles, however, when the balance sheet is totted up. The fact is the car itself did not disappoint for a minute. Whether sailing down country lanes, sprinting down the motorway or disdainfully inviting run-of-the-mill, vertically challenged saloons to stand aside on the school run, the RAV4 is a great car. Living with it for a few days enabled me to get over all my semiological reservations concerning branding and I would certainly own one.

Chunky, funky and actually quite spunky, it is, in a word, 'Ravtastic'.

fields.headline: Going with the grain
fields.standfirst: Massaged by women, soothed with music... rice has no higher calling than sake
fields.trailText: Massaged by women, soothed with music... rice has no higher calling than sake.
fields.body:
Whatever anyone says, sake is not wine, it's beer. Wine is made from fruit; beer is produced from grain. Sake is made from rice. Gyoza chicken dumplings and an ochoko ceramic sake cup are the new lunchtime pie and pint. Sake is hot right now. Well, warm. It takes a little time, a Japanese mood of ritual, to heat the ceramic flask in a pan of warm water. I like the sense of 'fixing a drink'. A hand-made drink. I like mine the traditional way, at about 40 C (blood temperature, as they say in Japan). This brings out the character of the sake. I have found flavours reminiscent of grass, flowers, apples, lychee and grape.

Yo Sushi, where the dishes arrive on a conveyor belt, presents its sake warm. So does Wagamama. Nobu favours a warm temperature for Hakusan sake ('made by Japanese people in the Napa Valley'), but goes to the opposite extreme with its Hokusetsu 10-year-old ('aged in Sado Island, Japan, to the sound of soothing music'). The Hokusetsu is served chilled (5-8 C), in a bamboo cup taken from the fridge, and provided at £29 for 300ml.

Temperature is not a question of age or nationality, but of robustness versus delicacy. In all drinks, I favour the authenticity of the robust, fearing that the delicate may turn out simply to be bland. I even like the smoky, medicinal, sweet Nigori sake. This is unfiltered, the sake counterpart to a cloudy wheat beer. The sole example I have found in this country is Momokawa Pearl, and that is available only in bars (see www.distinctivedrinks.com).

Nobu has a Sake Martini, garnished with a ('very thin') slice of cucumber. The sake plays the supporting role reserved for vermouth. The actual booze is vodka. I like the sound of Nobu's summer cocktails, made with sweeter sakes, vodka and crushed strawberries. I prefer the booze to shochu, the distilled counterpart to sake.

In Japan, a handful of restaurants are beginning to offer sakes as apéritif. I have been presented with the flowery Awa-Nigori ('Pale and Misty') before a meal and the peppery Chikamatsu-no (named after a classical author) as a digestif. Both are produced by Japan's oldest sake-maker, Shirayuki ('White Snow of Fuji'), which dates from the 1600s. Before that, sake was the dew formed on sacred chrysanthemums. (It is said to have been first made in China.)

Shirayuki is at Itami, near Osaka. There is considerable rivalry with the Niigata prefecture farther north. I side with Hyogo, because I have never been to Niigata. At the oldest of Shirayuki's five breweries, a man with a headband, looking like a samurai or at least a sushi master, shouted instructions. Four young Japanese women, dressed rather like nurses, kneeled to massage a bed of steamed rice in a cedar-lined, sauna-like room. While watching this, I thought I felt the earth move. Later, I discovered there had been an earthquake.

The 'nurses' were folding in koji, a mould that grows on rice and converts the starches into sugars. 'The rice must be steamed to the right degree,' explains Hiroshi Matsukawa, production director of Shirayuki. 'Every grain should have a hardcrust but be soft inside. When they're being kneaded, we want the grains to be scratched to allow the koji to penetrate, but not too much. That is a matter of experience and sensitivity of judgment, so this sake will be very expensive. For the consumer, that means a very complex fruitiness of flavour.'

I bet you haven't had Shirayuki sake, either. Now there's a hand-made drink...

fields.headline: Orient yourself
fields.standfirst: Four japanese restaurants beyond London
fields.trailText: Four japanese restaurants beyond London.
fields.body:
Izakaya Japanese Tavern Mermaids Quay, Cardiff Bay (02920 492 939). 'Japanese tavern' is an attempt to translate 'izakaya' - the sort of informal watering hole Iestyn Evans wanted to recreate in the principality after a decade of living in Japan. The restaurant he has created with his Japanese wife is an amalgamation of all his fondest memories, including the cheery shouts, the drama and authentic 'home cooking'. Staff wear 'hapi' jackets and scuttle back and forth with various combinations of tapas-sized dishes from a menu listing 55 items besides soups, noodles and salads. Prices are kept low; you can eat well and go home tipsy for £20.

Fusion 41 Byres Road, Glasgow (0141 339 3666). Glasgow's first and still funkiest sushi bar may have Albanian chefs, but locals reckon the fare is 'fantastic'. The name alludes to the availability of ramen bowls, tempura, teriyaki and the like, in addition to every type of sushi. Sushi costs from £1.95 to £3.75 per portion, so the bill depends on how greedy you are - but everyone from Billy Connolly to impecunious students seems to be able to afford to hang out there.

Edamame 15 Holywell Street, Oxford (01865 246 916). This little gem of a place seats 30 people at an absolute squeeze and is so perfectly suited to a university town full of discerning, adventurous youngsters with scant cash that it is always full to bursting. Opened by Peter and Mieko Galpin 18 months ago, Edamame only opens for lunch from Tuesday through Thursday, and dinner on Friday and Saturday - but since lunch costs around £6 to £7 and dinner rarely more than £12, including sake or Asahi beer, some customers appear every day. Indeed, regulars' badgering for sushi became so persistent that the Galpins finally gave in a few months ago - they now offer salmon sushi only, for £6.

Yumi 2 West Court, Edinburgh (0131 337 2173). Relocated a few years ago from a cosy basement location, Yumi incarnates a traditional Japanese restaurant within a high-ceilinged Victorian villa in the West End. Diners (surprisingly young, given the £50 per head price tag on dinner) relish the chance to stay all evening in such spacious (and smoke-free) surroundings. The restaurant is named after the owner's kimono-clad wife; he is known as 'Mr Yumi'. Staff are unfailingly helpful, offering endless variations on the 10 set menus and explaining dipping and wrapping processes. There are even origami animals to take away 'for good luck'.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Writer David Mitchell met Keiko Yoshida while they were both teaching at a school in Hiroshima. Despite cultural differences, both share a love of all things Japanese - except, that is, David's attempts to speak it
fields.trailText: Writer David Mitchell met Keiko Yoshida while they were both teaching at a school in Hiroshima. Despite cultural differences, both share a love of all things Japanese - except, that is, David's attempts to speak it.
fields.body:
David Mitchell: I went to Japan in 1994 intending to stay there for one or two years, but I'm still there. Countries capture the imagination for sometimes intangible reasons, and I was drawn by the image of Japan, though I'm hard-pressed to say what that was now, as it's been displaced by the reality.

I teach English in Hiroshima, where Keiko and I live, and I write as well. We met four years ago at a previous school. Keiko proofreads what I write and looks after me; she shares my work and accommodates the demands it places on me. If we go out to a restaurant, for a so-called date, and I'm deep in the dark period before a deadline, all I want to talk about is the book, because that's what I'm obsessed with. Keiko doesn't just put up with me, she encourages me, and that's the best thing.

A more direct way that Kei helps me is simply with on-the-spot interpreting work with people I would otherwise probably not be able to communicate with, or not as well, and that can be invaluable. She has also helped me understand the Japanese culture in many ways. Keiko's patient and explains things I don't understand and she lets me practise my extraordinarily awful Japanese with her, and hopefully by doing that it will get less extraordinarily awful, and that in itself is empowerment for me.

I think maybe I make more of an effort to eat up Japanese culture, partly out of deference to Kei, to show that I take her culture seriously and that I'm not just another pushy Westerner.

We don't go to Tokyo, if we can help it. Hiroshima's urban enough for us, we're both country people. I love the Japanese countryside - being up in the mountains or on the islands, which are beautiful. There are still large pockets where you can kid yourself that you're in a much more civilised century than you are.

I feel completely at home here, though I realise that in the eyes of most Japanese I'm about as Japanese as George W Bush. It's definitely my home for the time being - but when you're 32, nothing is completely permanent.

Keiko Yoshida: I got to know David because we worked in the same school in Hiroshima, though in different parts of the school. I knew him by reputation from the students and other teachers. Some English schools say, 'This is America and we don't talk in Japanese', which can make foreign English teachers seem arrogant, but David is not like that.

He's very considerate, fair and kind, and he tries to understand people.

We live together for half of the week, as my mum is not well, so I stay with her Monday to Friday and then stay with David for the weekend.

He thinks I support him a lot with his work, but I don't think I'm helping him at all. I really enjoy our conversations. It's very exciting to see how he progresses with his work. I'm a really big fan of Haruki Murakami and have read everything he's published. I want to know what Haruki Murakami thinks, but it usually takes about a year before books are published once they've been written, so he's always one year ahead of me, but with David I can see every stage of his work: before he rewrites it, while he rewrites it and then after he's rewritten it - it's all very exciting.

I know a lot about Japan, but when you live in a country you don't get all the information. David knows a lot more about the country by reading things published outside Japan, so I find out many things through his eyes. At the weekends we go to small islands on the fishermen's coast. We usually find islands by chance - in fact, lots of things happen by chance because we just go there and see what happens.

We never argue, but we talk a lot. We have to discuss things whenever we've got any small problem because we lose a lot of the nuances in each other's language, and I don't want to miss any nuances, as much as that's possible. So when he looks unhappy or says something I don't understand, I want to know what's happening. I think we talk more than other couples as a result - we have to talk. We don't want to have any misunderstandings.

We have to discuss things whenever we've got any small problem because we lose a lot of the nuances in each other's language, and I don't want to miss any nuances, as much as that's possible. We don't want to have any misunderstandings.

fields.headline: Colour codes
fields.trailText: Citing  Mona Lisa as the reverse side of inter-racial love in the movies (Review, last week), Elvis Mitchell raises the virtually unexplored theme of black women and white men relationships in films.
fields.body:
Citing Mona Lisa as the reverse side of inter-racial love in the movies (Review, last week), Elvis Mitchell raises the virtually unexplored theme of black women and white men relationships in films.

Notwithstanding Clint Eastwood's love interest with Vonetta McGee in The Eiger Sanction, which looked ground-breaking in 1975 but viewed today is merely titillating, why have so few film-makers viewed inter-racial love from this angle? With black women increasingly seeking white partners and more prominent/dominant in global business 'affairs', perhaps a modern storyline could be developed by one of our more enterprising British studios.
N. Gansell
London N13

As director of the National Theatre, Trevor Nunn is investing his huge talent and expertise in the subsidised sector (News, last week). His contract enshrines the accepted principle that the director of a subsidised theatre should not earn more from a commercial transfer of a production than the theatre itself.

Trevor Nunn's critically acclaimed production of My Fair Lady is drawing many people to the National for the first time, thus fulfilling a key Arts Council and Government requirement. Its West End transfer will generate substantial financial income for the National. It should also be seen in the context of the vibrant current and future National repertoire.

London SW1

fields.headline: Galeras tragedy
fields.trailText: As the wife of the late Professor Geoff Brown, the UK geologist killed during the eruption of Galeras volcano, Colombia, in January 1993, I am distressed at the content of your article 'Fatal volcano trip row boils over' (News, last week).
fields.body:
As the wife of the late Professor Geoff Brown, the UK geologist killed during the eruption of Galeras volcano, Colombia, in January 1993, I am distressed at the content of your article 'Fatal volcano trip row boils over' (News, last week).

As a geologist myself, I am confident that what happened on 14 January 1993 (not 16 January, as your article states) was a tragic accident that could not have been predicted at that time. Trying to apportion blame is unproductive, distressing to both the survivors of the eruption and the relatives of those who died, and symptomatic of a society that prefers to seek scapegoats rather than accept responsibility for its own actions.
Evelyn Brown
Loughborough, Leics

fields.headline: Time for kids
fields.trailText: Today I'm on holiday, caring for my two-year-old daughter who is suffering a virus. I don't begrudge spending one of my 'holidays' doing this, as I know she'll be better in a day or two.
fields.body:
Today I'm on holiday, caring for my two-year-old daughter who is suffering a virus. I don't begrudge spending one of my 'holidays' doing this, as I know she'll be better in a day or two.

But what if she was very sick, and required a long stay in hospital? Once we use our holidays, there is no mechanism that would allow her mother or me to stay with her during work hours. What is needed is an extension of maternity / paternity leave that would allow parents to care for their sick children.
Shaun Hughes
Cambridge

fields.headline: Work for equality
fields.trailText: The uncomfortable truth is that all of us hold some very deep notions that sexual equality is difficult. One taboo Will Hutton (Comment, last week) forgot to mention is the taboo on speaking about how women's attitudes and actions may contribute to the problem.
fields.body:
The uncomfortable truth is that all of us hold some very deep notions that sexual equality is difficult. One taboo Will Hutton (Comment, last week) forgot to mention is the taboo on speaking about how women's attitudes and actions may contribute to the problem.

Interestingly, this same issue of The Observer has a book review by Amelia Hill where she states: 'Children are replacing marriage as the romantic fantasy of young women.' If this becomes the (albeit, distorted) stereotype of young women, can employers ever take young college women seriously?

Sex is fun and healthy, but I think we take for granted that sex stirs up very powerful emotions - we are not machines. People get confused: when is it OK to express your sexuality and when not? For example, should we have restrictions on workplace romance? Can men and women learn to flirt with each other at the club on Saturday, and then be detached and professional on Monday morning?

The transition from a male-dominated society to an open and fair one will take work. We men have more work to do, but everyone has a responsibility to help change the many negative attitudes that exist.
Loren Taylor
Zurich
Switzerland

 Will Hutton said communists favoured dictatorship over equality. At the height of the Hitler war, as most Western women repined in non-combatance, Soviet Russian women fought and died as fighter pilots, tank commanders and counter-intelligence officers. The next time totalitarianism threatens democracy, what may we expect from Western women imbued with pacifist feminism?
Douglas Rome
Summerhill, Dumfries

fields.headline: Talk of the Tyne
fields.standfirst: Geordies thick? Howay, man
fields.trailText: We are all inordinately self-conscious about our backgrounds. But whatever unwelcome hand might already have been dealt us in the lottery of class, colour or sex, we now have new statistics categorising our intelligence by birthplace too.
fields.body:
We are all inordinately self-conscious about our backgrounds. But whatever unwelcome hand might already have been dealt us in the lottery of class, colour or sex, we now have new statistics categorising our intelligence by birthplace too. However, while new figures from the Office of National Statistics might suggest that people from Newcastle upon Tyne are less well educated than anywhere else in Britain, children from the North-East still have a heart-warming catalogue of role-models from their regional capital to emulate.

George Stephenson was one of the most significant contributors to Britain's industrial revolution and its influence upon the rest of the world. And the Charlton brothers, Bobby and Jack, were superlative footballers and World Cup winners. Heroic Grace Darling rescued nine survivors of the SS Forfarshire in 1838. Thomas Burt made history as the first working man to be elected to Parliament.

A pantheon of other Geordies - from Catherine Cookson to Jimmy Nail, from Bryan Ferry to Steve Cram - have contributed to Britain's varied cultural tapestry in the last century. And the literature generated from their home city does not just include TV series like Ian La Frenais' Auf Wiedersehen, Pet and The Likely Lads - the Venerable Bede was penning his bestsellers as long ago as 673.

It should all be more than enough to make up for Paul Gascoigne.

webTitle: Letters:  What do economists know about marriage?

fields.headline: What do economists know about marriage?
fields.trailText: It is always sad to see eminent and once progressive commentators arguing for illiberal causes on the basis of evidence that they would not countenance in their own areas of competence.
fields.body:
It is always sad to see eminent and once progressive commentators arguing for illiberal causes on the basis of evidence that they would not countenance in their own areas of competence.

Economists Bob Rowthorn and Paul Ormerod rely largely on American findings concerning differences between married people and single, cohabiting, divorced and separated people (Comment, last week) to argue that marriage is not only good for your health, but also for your economic and emotional well-being. They go as far as to suggest it is usually better for couples to stay together for the sake of the children, even when one or both partners are unhappy.

But these findings cannot properly be used to arrive at such conclusions. Partly, that is because marriage in the United States is not typical of marriage elsewhere in the Western world (for instance, the post-war, US divorce rate is twice as high as those of Britain and Western Europe). Partly, it is because of the high degree of self-selection inherent in the data. The adverse effects of unhappy and abusive marriages do not show up in such findings precisely because it is these kinds of marriages that are most likely to terminate in divorce and separation.
Francis Castles
Professor of Social and Public Policy
University of Edinburgh

 So, 'serious violence among married couples is uncommon'. Really? Rowthorn and Ormerod must tell us why they are so sure about that, for nobody else is. Totting up the numbers in domestic violence has never been much of a priority, except to some womens' groups and a few researchers. And the figures they've come up with so far always freeze one's blood. It is a base and long-standing practice to glibly single out 'serious violence', as if all the rest, the 'less serious violence' (the kind which doesn't quite put you in casualty?) should remain decently obscured behind closed doors; just like in the safe, comfortable past.
Una Freeley
London N8

 What Rowthorn and Ormerod fail to acknowledge is that research on cohabiting, married and lone parents does not prove that marriage is better for children. All it proves is that working-class and wageless parents are more likely to cohabit, while lone parents live on lower incomes. Consequently, if children in cohabiting or lone-parent families experience less stable and less successful lives then this is because they are poorer.

Moreover, it is also likely that, given that the heterosexual nuclear family is socially constructed as 'normal', individuals living in other family arrangements, such as gay couples or lone parents, experience the corollary of 'abnormal', perhaps in the form of homophobic or stigmatising treatment. So it is the context in which family relationships are played out that matters, not whether parents are married.
Charlie Cooper
Faculty of Social & Life Sciences
Lincolnshire & Humberside University

 It is sad to read my old mate Bob Rowthorn patronise me and tens of thousands of others in 'cohabiting unions'. But it's even sadder that he and Paul Ormerod have taken up the mantras of the moral Right and blame our social problems on the 'values of the 1960s generation'.

Rowthorn wants stability in relationships, above all marriage. The old, progressive Bob would have addressed the socio-economic issues - the UK with the longest working hours in Europe; women paid on average one-fifth less than men - and called for reform: a 35-hour week, enforcement of maximum working hours and Equal Pay legislation. He would have addressed the equality issues: extend paternity leave; improve childcare; champion men doing the housework.

Instead, he is obsessed by the superiority of marriage. He condemns cohabiting as unstable because 'the option of breaking up is consciously preserved'. But divorce law reform means this is true of marriage too. So to get his desired stability you've got to force people to stay in unsatisfactory marriages. Those who want to join born-again Bob need to understand denying divorce is the goal.
Jon Bloomfield
London EC1
