webTitle: Leader: Why the US is not fit to run the world

fields.headline: The US is not fit to run the world
fields.standfirst: We must help Europe take on the job
fields.trailText: We must help Europe take on the job.
fields.body:
In the nineteenth century, it would have been regarded as the precursor to a declaration of war. If a powerful state said it must reconfigure its defence and weapons structure specifically in order to fight and win a war on the terrain of a second weaker state, the bellicose message would have been unambiguous. If there were no provocation or excuse, its malevolence would have been evident to all.

But this is precisely how George Bush's new government has threatened China. His new Secretary of Defence, Donald Rumsfeld, a Cold War veteran, says America needs new, long-range nuclear bombers with which to 'fight and win a nuclear war' in the Far East, a plain reference to China. In the delusions of Washington right-wing think-tanks, the battle for global supremacy in the twenty-first century will be between China and America, even though China is decades away from having even the nuclear capacity of the UK.

This is the frightening universe inhabited by the key policymakers of the Bush administration and it goes someway to explaining the President's unilateral decision last week to pull out of the Kyoto Protocol on climate change. Not merely does America come first - 'We will do not do anything that harms our economy,' said Mr Bush - but the world in which America is put first is seen through a mist of demagogy masquerading as the new realism. This now threatens the entire fragile fabric of world affairs.

In the Bushite world-view, concern about climate change is a socialist plot distorting scientific evidence to justify an assault on the American way of life. Communist China is a growing menace. America is so beset by rogue states like North Korea that international treaties governing missile use must be torn up to allow the US to construct a unilateral missile defence system.

Even when the diplomacy of South Korea opens up the possibility of North Korea giving up plans to build missiles in exchange for food and aid, the offer is rejected. It would prejudice the rationale behind the new missile defence system. Mr Rumsfeld has also accused the Russians of being 'a nation of [nuclear] proliferators', disregarding Russia's near exemplary record on proliferation. The Cold War may be over but the Bushites need to ignore Russia's painful path towards democracy and capitalism if it is to remain an arch enemy.

This dangerous distortion of reality results not only from the corruption of the conservative mind. Another cause is no less sinister. The Petroleum Club of Houston, Mr Bush's Texan oil backer, is now central in forging American energy and environmental policy. The defence contractors, also large campaign donors, are agitating successfully for the orders that will flow from the national missile defence system. The Business Round Table, another major campaign contributor, is getting immediate payback from suspension of pro-worker legislation and an astonishingly regressive tax reduction package.

For Britain, this is a decisive moment. Our reflex action is to stand beside our closest ally, to win trust and to attempt to influence from inside. It is a view born of the long-held belief that, in the last resort, America will do the right thing. But the America that is emerging after winning the Cold War is not the America that offered the world enlightened and broadly liberal leadership from the 1930s onwards. It is an America that is reverting to the conservatism and unilateralism of earlier in the last century.

The most urgent task now is to fill the leadership void that the US is creating under its new President. This means a significant new role for the European Union. The EU could offer North Korea the food and aid it requires in exchange for relinquishing its missiles. The EU with Russia, China, India and Japan could forge the climate change convention - without the US. The euro-zone could stabilise the world economy.

If the US wants to play hardball, the EU can play hardball back. And the majority of US citizens who voted for a different President with a different set of political priorities and who are now as alarmed as the international community would know that they have allies abroad. That Britain should pursue a pro-European foreign policy is not now just a matter of national interest - it has become a matter of global interest.

fields.headline: Abortion death hunt muzzles 'Atomic Dog'
fields.standfirst: For three years after a doctor was shot, the FBI was kept at bay by a suspect using a secret email system
fields.trailText: For three years after a doctor was shot, the FBI was kept at bay by a suspect using a secret email system.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy in New York, Henry McDonald  in Belfast and Stuart Jeffries in Paris
fields.body:
Devout 'Clive Swenson' attended 7am mass in Jersey City most days before going to work as a carpenter on a building site. Fellow workers noted his religious fervour and flashes of a keen intelligence.

Four hundred miles away in a Buffalo suburb Dr Barnett Slepian, an obstetrician who performed abortions, was shot dead in his kitchen as he chatted to his wife and one of his four children. The fatal bullet, from a high-powered rifle, was fired through a window late at night.

After the killing in October 1998, the man called Swenson vanished from Jersey City, leaving little more than some fast-food cartons and an undertaker's calendar.

Over the next two and a half years the FBI followed his trail, via Newark airport, a computer link in Brooklyn, across Ireland and to Brittany where the alleged killer - real name, James Kopp - was arrested last week.

Kopp was well-known in militant anti-abortion circles, where he was nicknamed Atomic Dog. Drawn to the cause after a girlfriend had a termination, he used his practical skills in the Seventies and Eighties to design intricate locks that protesters fastened to abortion clinic doors.

This weekend he is being held in the Breton city of Rennes, refusing to answer interrogators' questions. He had been run to ground after an extraordinary operation by police and the FBI.

His connection with the militants would have made him a suspect even if a jogger had not noticed his Chevrolet near the murdered doctor's home in the suburb, Amherst.

The car, later found at the airport, contained a hair that closely matched Kopp's. FBI agents discovered a Russian-made sniper's rifle buried behind the doctor's house.

The trail led to America's shadowy, loose-knit group of violent anti-abortion activists and, in particular, to a Brooklyn couple, a convicted abortion clinic bomber called Dennis Malvasi and his wife Loretta Marra. They were also arrested last Thursday and charged with conspiracy to aid, fund and shelter Kopp.

Several weeks ago, the FBI learnt Kopp was in Ireland, living cheaply under false identities. He had been there at least since March last year, doing a series of menial jobs.

He worked for a week as a temporary typist at the City of Dublin Skin and Cancer Hospital, adorning his desk with religious statuettes. He had shaved off the goatee beard pictured on a poster putting him on the FBI's 'Ten Most Wanted' list.

Irish pro-life groups yesterday denied they had harboured him. But an FBI spokesman said: 'He did not leave the US without assistance, and he did not remain a fugitive without assistance.'

Kopp fled Ireland one step ahead of the police on a ferry to Britanny on 12 March. He had two Irish passports as well as his own US document.

fields.headline: Timor camps lose UN lifeline
fields.trailText: Thousands of East Timorese refugees will be left stranded across the border in squalid camps in Indonesian West Timor unless relief efforts are stepped up,  writes Matthew Brace in Dili.
fields.body:
Thousands of East Timorese refugees will be left stranded across the border in squalid camps in Indonesian West Timor unless relief efforts are stepped up, writes Matthew Brace in Dili.

The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is winding down its operation on the island and will shut down by the end of the year.

Since October 1999 almost 180,000 refugees have returned - but up to 100,000 remain, scattered in more than 220 locations.

In the nine months until the December deadline only half look likely to make it home. The UNHCR's senior emergency officer in East Timor, Bernard Kerblat, said: 'This is a decision of the UNHCR. To me it would be preferable if we could stay, but due to resource constraints 31 December is our deadline.'

Kerblat said the camps were riddled with disease and the refugees faced daily intimidation from militia guards.

'Certain dark forces partisan to Indonesia want to maintain the status quo of this refugee crisis as proof of their strength,' he said. 'UNHCR wants to disband these camps once and for all. We want these refugees either to be allowed to become fully fledged Indonesian citizens or to be repatriated to East Timor.'

UNHCR has had no access to the camps since September last year, when three of their officials were murdered in West Timor. Increasingly, they have turned to the clandestine repatriation of refugees. A network of church workers and pro-democracy activists has been working to smuggle out those most at risk. A number of sympathetic West Timorese oustide the camps have risked their lives to help.

Most refugee escapes are by land and sea. Crucial to the UNHCR operation is the Patricia Anne Hotung, a former Australian naval vessel now owned by a Chinese millionaire and donated to the relief effort, but its future role in the humanitarian effort is in doubt. There is a chance that the owner might sell it to the Chinese navy.

Reports from camp staff say conditions are worsening by the day. Food supplies are erratic, drinking water systems a disaster, and intimidation and abuse rife.

fields.headline: World's opium source destroyed
fields.standfirst: Luke Harding  in Hadda sees dramatic evidence of the war being waged on the drugs trade by the hardline Taliban
fields.trailText: Luke Harding  in Hadda sees dramatic evidence of the war being waged on the drugs trade by the hardline Taliban.
fields.body:
The mud-walled village of Hadda in south-eastern Afghanistan used to consider itself lucky. The farmers who live here had not one but two lucrative sources of income.

There were the Buddhist relics that could be dug out in darkness from the many ancient stupas or shrines that littered the undulating valley and its jagged white mountains. And there was opium, a crop that flourished in neat plots, transforming the landscape every April into a sea of green and red.

But this year things are different. In a development that has gone unnoticed and unrewarded by the international community, Afghanistan's fundamentalist Taliban rulers have dramatically ended the country's massive opium trade, The Observer can reveal - a move that has also plunged Hadda's farmers into despondency and debt.

Western sources in Kabul yesterday confirmed poppy production in Afghanistan had virtually ceased. This follows an edict issued last year by the Taliban's reclusive leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, declaring opium to be un-Islamic.

The first Hadda's farmers knew of it was when a group of black-turbaned soldiers armed with Kalashnikovs turned up in their village. 'The Taliban came here and saw there were poppies. They hit some of the people and told them they would be taken to prison and tortured if they planted more seeds,' farmer Abdul Rashid said.

'Then the elders of the village talked to them and told the Taliban we would destroy the poppies ourselves. It took us four days to do. We used a tractor and cows to plough up the fields.'

In neighbouring villages around the orange-scented town of Jalalabad, and in the fertile Helmand valley, which used to produce half of the country's opium, it is the same story. Driving through southern Afghanistan last week, The Observer found no evidence of poppy cultivation.

The trade last year produced 75 per cent of the world's heroin. It has now vanished. The distinctive plants that grew by the roadside have disappeared. They have been replaced by fields of lush but worthless wheat. 'I used to have one-and-a-half acres planted with poppy. Now we have nothing,' farmer Hussain Gul complained.

'I have to feed a family of 14. Should I buy clothes for my children? Should I feed them? Should I take them to the doctor?' he asked.

Farmer Khan Afzal added: 'I blame the Americans because they promised they would help us. But they didn't. They have given us no assistance.'

In Hadda, last year's opium crop was destroyed by hail. But the previous year Afzal and other smallholders who leased between one and eight acres of land made a profit of around £350 each, a fortune in Afghanistan where the average monthly salary is £3. Since the ban on poppy production was imposed, the price of a kilo of opium has soared from 3,000 Pakistani rupees (£35) to 40,000 (£470), sources say.

To date, this has had no discernible effect on the international heroin market, thanks to massive stockpiles in countries such as Pakistan, Iran and Turkey where the raw opium is refined. Intelligence experts from Britain and America believe the fall in production could lead to a worldwide shortage and price rise, although in reality production in countries such as Burma and Colombia is likely to increase to satisfy demand.

For a few farmers, the Taliban ban has led to even greater wealth - those with stockpiles of dark brown resin hidden in wet plastic bags have seen their income increase. But the ban has caused massive hardship to ordinary Afghans, already left reeling under the burden of war, drought and Soviet occupation. Skilled labourers who would descend on the Helmand valley every spring to harvest the milky-white opium are now jobless.

Faiz Ahmed Faiz, the Taliban's foreign affairs spokesman, yesterday said his Islamic government had completely eradicated poppy cultivation. 'It was an epic task,' he said. 'The response to this tremendous achievement from the international community was unexpected. They imposed more and more sanctions on us.'

The Taliban had begun by reducing opium production by a third, using religious scholars to convince the people. They then totally wiped out 'this menace' two months ago, he added.

The reality is more complex. Hashar, as the crop is known locally, has been growing in Afghanistan for centuries. The farmers of Hadda yesterday said poppies had flourished in their ancient valley for as long as they could remember: since the time of Afghanistan's deposed King Zahir Shah 30 years ago.

But under the Taliban, production increased spectacularly - to the point where Afghanistan became the world's largest opium producer, supplying 80 per cent of Europe's heroin.

The crop was trucked across Pakistan's deserts. It was then taken by boat across the Arabian Sea from the port of Gwadar. It also left the country via Iran, ending up in eastern Turkey, and in convoys through Afghanistan's lawless northern neighbours, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan. The Taliban collected an estimated $20 million in opium taxes.

Late last year, Mullah Omar appears finally to have agreed to Western demands to end opium production. He had hoped for some concessions in return, including diplomatic recognition. Instead, the United Nations imposed more punitive sanctions on Afghanistan in January because of the country's refusal to extradite the alleged Saudi terrorist Osama bin Laden.

The move badly backfired. Mullah Omar responded by destroying Afghanistan's two giant Buddhas, a disaster that many observers believe could have been averted.

Sceptics have questioned whether the Taliban have genuinely eradicated poppy cultivation. But all the evidence suggests they have. 'All the indicators are that they have done it. The prices have increased dramatically,' one informed UN source in Kabul admitted last week.

The UN's Drug Control Programme (UNDCP), meanwhile, which compensated farmers who switched from opium to other crops, was scrapped in December because of a lack of funding from the US and other donors.

Hadda's farmers are now praying for a change in policy - or a change in government. 'We don't have anything,' Rashid lamented yesterday, staring glumly at his green wheat field as rain fell. 'All the young people have gone to Pakistan. Ninety per cent of this area used to be cultivated with poppy. How much money can you make from wheat?'

Of the 3,000 people who had lived in Hadda, only 300 were now left, he added.

Even the trade in looted Buddhist statues had dried up. Between the second and seventh century Hadda was one of the most sacred spots in the Buddhist world, where pilgrims came from across central Asia to venerate a fragment of the Buddha skull and one of his teeth. But the hundreds of crumbling stupas dating from that era had already been ransacked, Rashid explained, by Soviet soldiers and the Mujahideen.

Their contents had been taken across the border to the frontier town of Peshawar. Only the wheat was left and a few goats. 'We are miserable. We have nothing. We have been forgotten by the world,' he said.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: KeyWorld Holiday Investment Bond
fields.trailText: KeyWorld Holiday Investment Bond.
fields.body:
Contact 0800 085 6050 or www.keyworldinvest.com

Aim To provide holidays worldwide at a discount.

Bells & whistles The company claims investors will get an effective financial benefit of anything between 25 and 60 per cent on their original investment through cheaper holidays.

How it works Three-quarters of your money buys units in a property fund, investing in holiday property, which is entered on the RCI register of timeshares in more than 3,600 resorts. KeyPoints can be used to pay for accommodation on the RCI register. Your number of KeyPoints depends on the amount you invest - a £5,000 investment would get 3,731 KeyPoints. These are renewed every year without any further investment, but there are annual charges for managing the property. You can carry points forward to the next year or 'borrow' from the following year's allocation. The scheme has been set up as a single-premium life policy underwritten by Criterion Life and is designed to run for 75 years. You can encash all your units in the seventh year and their value will be calculated as a percentage of the property fund. But for the first three years the redemption value is zero, in the fourth year 25 per cent, fifth year 50 per cent and sixth year 75 per cent. When the last named investor dies, the bondholder's estate is entitled to 101 per cent of the redemption value.

Minimum £2,000

Charges 25 per cent is a set-up fee. Annual membership £99; management fee calculated on the number of KeyPoints held, initially 15p per point. On a £2,000 investment this would equate to £224 in management fees.

Tax Not treated as withdrawals from the bond, so not taxed.

Should you invest? Liz Walkington of RJ Temple says: 'We won't be recommending this to our clients. It's quite inflexible, you have to wait a long time before you can take your money out, and the charges are very high.' Michael Aaron of David Aaron Partnership is no keener. 'You're tying money up, and with so much competition in the holiday market it's doubtful if the benefits would be that great. I would be very wary.'

Points out of 10 Walkington - 1, Aaron - 3.

webTitle: Only the brave and wealthy need apply

fields.headline: Only the brave and wealthy need apply
fields.standfirst: Venture capital trusts play hard and fast, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Venture capital trusts play hard and fast, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you are a higher-rate taxpayer and prepared for the possibility that you could lose all of an investment, you may want to consider a venture capital trust.

Regarded as the preserve of the very wealthy, they could appeal to people who pay tax at 40 per cent. 'We don't think they should be regarded as particularly high-risk,' says John Spiers of independent adviser Bestinvest. 'The worst have been dull investments.'

As they launched in 1995, it is early to judge their performance. Mavis Seymour of accountant BDO Stoy Hayward says: 'I don't think they have turned out to be risky - but, of course, the story isn't over yet. Nobody has yet made a loss on VCT shares.' In one of the biggest success stories so far, a hi-tech VCT paid out a £1 dividend per share - tax-free .

You can invest up to £100,000 in VCTs each tax year. You get income tax relief at 20 per cent on your investment, there is no tax on dividends nor capital gains tax when you sell. But the investment must be held for a minimum three years to qualify for tax relief. One reason why they are so attractive to the very wealthy is that investors can postpone existing CGT liabilities by investing in a VCT within 12 months of the day they realised their gain.

You invest in a VCT by buying ordinary shares in it. It is similar to an investment trust and must be quoted on the Stock Exchange.

There are strict rules governing the independence of VCT directors and the experience of the fund managers.

The VCT invests in small unquoted businesses, but it cannot put more than £1m into a single company. This enforced diversification for funds larger than a few million reduces the risks.

Funds with £20m that invest in 20 businesses are typically seeing a few duds among their holdings, but these have been balanced by good performers.

So, how much will VCTs be hit by the queasiness of stock markets? Some have specialised in hi-tech, and many general funds include some hi-tech firms. Seymour says fund managers tend to avoid start-ups, however, going instead for businesses at least three or four years old.

She is more worried about realising value in these firms: 'A general recession may stop businesses going to the Alternative Investment Market if they don't think they'll get a good price for their company. This may slow down the realisations.'

Most VCT managers ex-pect to invest in a business for three to five years. But Seymour says: 'Some people are saying this looks like a good investment for retirement. They usually get a dividend every year.'

She thinks VCTs could be worthwhile investments for people who want to put in the minimum £2,000 or £3,000 that most VCTs allow - but only if they could live with the possibility of losing it all.

However, Martin Churchill of Allenbridge says people should invest in VCTs only if they already have an equities portfolio of £50,000. Spiers adds that a VCT investment should be less than a quarter of the overall equity investments.

Whether smaller investors should dip their toe into this market is debatable. There is a view that smaller investors should keep out, and certainly no one is encouraging basic-rate taxpayers to take this road. But some higher-rate taxpayers with less available cash but a tolerance for risk could benefit. There are several schemes available, most of which will close by the end of the tax year.

Spiers highlights 'Northern 2' and 'Leisure & Media' as two that would appeal to more cautious VCT investors. Although the market will dry up after 6 April, a batch of new offerings is likely in the autumn - building up to another main season next year.

fields.headline: Brown turns council tax ratchet
fields.standfirst: 'Cynical' government moves are blamed for the 6.4 per cent hike, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: 'Cynical' government moves are blamed for the 6.4 per cent hike, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Council taxes go up today by an average of £1 a week for much of middle England, an increase of about 6.4 per cent. The average bill is now £901 a year for a band D home in England and £710 in Wales, says the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy (Cipfa).

But there is a huge variation in what people pay in different parts of the country. The most expensive councils ask their citizens for two or three times the amount levied in other areas. Ironically, some of the wealthiest regions charge the least, while poorer areas pay far more.

Council tax in the affluent Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, for instance, is about half the size of the Liverpool band D bill of £1,171. The lowest chargers tend to be Conservative councils, and the higher ones are more likely to be Labour or Liberal Democrat held, or areas where no party has overall control.

Surprisingly, perhaps, London boroughs are not the most expensive. None charges more than £1,000 for band D - a threshold for the average semi which is broken by several councils outside the capital, including Coventry, Manchester, Salford, Bristol, Redcar, Bolsover, Burnley and Hartlepool.

But although councils take the flak for the size of their bills, their control over its size is less than complete. About 75 per cent of local government spending comes as Treasury grants, and only the other 25 per cent is from council tax.

Treasury cash made up a larger proportion of the total in 1993, when only 21 per cent was raised locally.

Tony Travers, council tax expert at the London School of Economics, says: 'The Treasury - under both Conservative and Labour gov ernments - has almost cynically worked out that they can get away with an increase of about 6 per cent a year on council tax bills, even though that is way ahead of inflation.

'The Treasury is trying to shift part of the burden off the national exchequer and on to council taxpayers. My hunch is that the Treasury thinks it can nudge the council tax element up to 30 per cent.'

Council tax bills have been rising by about 6 per cent a year since the mid-Nineties and are likely to stay at this rate, despite the fact that inflation is about 2 per cent. It is also possible that London bills will grow faster than this over the next parliament.

Although it is little understood by the public, there is much controversy behind the scenes about the way central funding is allocated among town halls. London is seen as having been favoured politically by Westminster, so the Government is under pressure to be more helpful to the Labour strongholds north of Watford. It is hard to see that there will be much grieving in Redcar - average bill £1,081 - if the 5,000 well-off residents of the City of London have to pay more than their current £579.

Another reason why town halls do not have complete control of the council tax bill is that they collect money for other services such as the police, fire service, parish and county councils. Only 13 per cent of a bill levied by Canterbury city council, for instance, can be spent by that council; about 80 per cent goes to the county council, and another 7 per cent to the police authority.

Many Labour strongholds are starting to emulate the efficient running on which Conservative councils have prided themselves. Labour-run Newport in south Wales is always one of the lowest billers each year. Like many others, it is benefiting this year from devolution. When it used to get its central government money via the Welsh Office, the uses to which it could put the money were often restricted. Now that its money comes through the Welsh Assembly, it has more discretion.

Even Liverpool, once a Labour stronghold and now the country's biggest biller at band D, is -under Liberal Democrat control - espousing privatisation and promising a better deal in future. This is the third year its levy has been frozen at £1,171.

Spokesman Matt Finnegan says: 'We've been overpeopled, with costs that were too high and with a quality of services that was too low.'

Liverpool has laid off 1,800 of its 24,000 staff in the past year, and last month, announced an outsourcing joint venture with BT worth £500 million over the next decade to handle much of its administration, including payroll and human resources. It says this is 'a first for local government in Europe', and expects other councils to follow suit.

But cheapness is clearly not the only issue. Many residents will be concerned at signs of services deteriorating if councils are badly run or try to cut costs too quickly. Local authorities frequently hit the headlines with stories about raising charges for caring for the elderly and infirm, jacking up car parking costs, restricting bin collections to fortnightly pick-ups and all sorts of unpopular measures.

Sudden disasters, such as the recent floods, can also add to their budgets.

For most authorities, education eats up most of the money, often accounting for more than a third of spending. Social services is usually the second-biggest spender.

This year's overall average rise of 6.4 per cent is not surprising, according to the Cipfa. Chief executive Steve Freer says: 'It is a difficult balancing act which each individual council must judge based on local needs.

Council tax accounts for about 3 per cent of all taxes raised by government. But while others are raised more discreetly - VAT is added on to the cost of purchases and PAYE is deducted from our pay - it is highly visible.

The forthcoming elections will allow voters to punish or thank their councillors for the bills and the quality of services. But this tax is a national issue too, and Chancellor Gordon Brown plays a far more important role in setting it than he might have us believe.

To appeal or not to appeal...

There are two grounds for appealing against a Council Tax bill - the underlying valuation of your property, and the amount you have been asked to pay.

Disputes over the value of the property may relate to the band it is in. There are eight different bands - from A to H - and residents have sometimes been successful in arguing for a lower band. An appeal should be made to a valuation tribunal.

A further ground for appeal is that the building is partly residential and partly business - and you disagree with the council about the way it does the split.

Another common disagreement would be where the local authority says there are two people living in a property but only one admits to living there full-time. The people involved should put their complaint to the council in writing if they do not agree with the council's assessment. If they do not like the council's response - or do not get a response - they can then take their case to the valuation tribunal.

Citizens' advice bureaux have considerable experience in advising on this type of appeal and can help you fill in the forms and make your submission.

Do you qualify for exemption?

There are at least 23 categories of residential property exempted from Council Tax - but before you get too excited, you should understand that most are rather specialist.

Diplomats, soldiers and their spouses living in barracks and married quarters, unoccupied boat moorings, vacant caravan pitches and empty vicarages can all qualify for a zero rate.

A more useful exemption is that for houses solely occupied by full-time students. Another useful one for people who have entered the buy-to-let market is the 50 per cent reduction in a Council Tax bill for six months if the property is unoccupied and unfurnished.

Far bigger numbers of people will qualify for a 25 per cent reduction: anyone living alone can get this discount.

And then there are the splendidly bizarre rules that could provide the framework for a novel. For instance, you can still qualify for the 25 per cent single person discount if you share your home with a nun or a member of a visiting military force.

webTitle: Money writes: Renewal problems just won't subside

fields.headline: Renewal problems just won't subside
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building	society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice	for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
When Eagle Star asked for £631 to renew the insurance on our suburban semi, I found a cheaper policy with Norwich Union. In 1977 we suffered subsidence, and the back of the house was underpinned. I declared this on the proposal form, but Norwich Union asked for an engineer's report.

The structural engineers we commissioned advised us to go through the motions of making a new claim, so Eagle Star would send a loss adjuster. Our engineer just inspected the property visually, but the loss adjuster dug holes and took soil samples.

Both told us they could find no evidence of any further subsidence, but the written reports were so carefully worded, in order not to commit anyone, that Norwich Union would not accept us. We appear to be stuck with Eagle Star, which refuses to reduce the premium.
MC, West Kirby

You have been given appallingly bad advice by your own engineer, which has left you worse off than before. You might think that, because there was no new subsidence, you have a clean bill of health which is attractive to other, cheaper insurers. But making a false claim has done the opposite. Even though this recent claim was a dummy, it counts as a real claim on your file. Although Eagle Star did not have the expense of structural repairs, it had to pay £1,000 for the loss adjuster's survey.

Whenever you apply for building insurance in future you must now declare a second subsidence claim in 2000. There is no point explaining to a new insurer that it was only a mock claim because that makes you look dishonest.

The second claim does not increase your Eagle Star premiums, but you'll be unlikely to get another insurer to take you on with two subsidence claims on your record. You should complain to the engineer about this bad advice and, if that gets you nowhere, contact his trade association.

Transfer value: Members only

I took out a Scottish Life endowment policy with my Halifax mortgage in 1986. In 1994, I paid off the mortgage but kept the policy going, and it was reassigned to me.

I've been paying into the policy for 14 years and it has been in my name for the past seven, yet Scottish Life says I do not qualify as a member and will not qualify for £500 compensation if the proposed transfer to Royal London takes place.
MH, Birmingham

Norwich Union, Scottish Widows, Scottish Amicable and Scottish Equitable paid benefits to mortgage endowment policyholders when they demutualised. Scottish Provident and Friends Provident will when they convert later this year.

Yet Scottish Life policyholders lose membership when a policy is assigned to a lender and cannot be reinstated. The insurer acknowledges that its rules are unusual, saying this was deliberately done when it mutualised in 1968 to repel approaching asset strippers.

Some Scottish Life customers benefit from the oddity: unlike other demutualisations, those with non-profit and unit-linked policies and both holders in joint-life policies are treated as members, assuming the policies have not been used as security for a mortgage.

Scottish Life could allow policyholders to vote for a rule change but those with an assigned policy are not members, so cannot vote; the rest would be voting to dilute their own payouts.

But it is not all bad news. Your policy will earn extra bonuses on demutualisation, worth around £3,500.

Service contract: Cooking with gas

In January, I realised that I had not had my annual British Gas 3-star service check for 1999/ 2000. The documentation said it would be arranged by British Gas. I was offered a £30 refund but only as a discount on next year's contract.
PS, Banstead

British Gas confirms that it takes responsibility for contacting customers to arrange the annual service, but admits some fall through the net.

In compensation, the company is sending you a cheque for £60, double the original offer. It will treat the service you eventually arranged in January as last year's missed visit and will give you another service next November.

Mail order: Sign of the times

I cannot get to the shops and often buy by mail. Recently Parcel Force made me sign on an electronic gadget where one can see neither one's signature nor what it relates to.

Parcel Force will not accept a manuscript signature: if I do not sign, it returns the parcel to the sender. In all my 85-and-three-quarter years I have never signed anything without seeing what it was.
PJ, Crediton

Parcel Force says you ought to be able to see your signature, and the number of parcels you sign for, on the handheld computer as the text is larger than on the old printed sheets. If you have a problem seeing the writing, ask the driver to adjust the contrast on the screen.

Before you sign, the driver swipes the barcode on the parcel on to this gadget and types in your name. Your signature matches up with that information, which the driver transmits back to the central computer.

During transmission, the information is encrypted so your details are kept secure. No one can intercept the message or copy your signature.

Foreign banking: Can Tessa travel?

I have a Tessa with Bank of Ireland but, after reading about the difficulties of closing overseas savings accounts when someone dies, I wonder if I should move it when it matures. I do not want my family to pay charges to access my money after I die.
AF, Motherwell

You will not have a problem with Irish accounts. Bank of Ireland says there are no charges for closing any of its accounts when an overseas customer dies.

If your total estate is less than £5,000, your executors do not need to produce letters of administration or, in England and Wales, probate.

Tessas are a UK-only product (Bank of Ireland's is based here) so the issue does not even arise.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Maxwell: I'll fight DTI bid to punish me

fields.headline: Maxwell: I'll fight DTI bid to punish me
fields.trailText: Kevin Maxwell vowed this weekend to fight 'to the last' further government attempts to punish him over the £400 million looting of the Mirror newspaper pension funds.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell vowed this weekend to fight 'to the last' further government attempts to punish him over the £400 million looting of the Mirror newspaper pension funds.

His defiance came amid a growing row, as City advisers to crooked media tycoon Robert Maxwell looked set to escape any further sanctions over their role in the 1991 flotation of Mirror Group Newspapers (MGN).

Top City investment banks Goldman Sachs and Samuel Montagu, now owned by HSBC, were savaged in a long-awaited Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) report into MGN last Friday.

This weekend the DTI said any further action would be limited to possible disqualification proceedings to bar Kevin, his brother Ian and other Maxwell associates criticised in the report from company directorships.

Any further penalties would be down to financial regulators, DTI sources said. However, sources close to the City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority (FSA) indicated that there were no plans to pursue firms or individuals slated in the report.

'We've had quite an opportunity to review this,' one City regulator said. 'Our conclusion is that there is nothing materially new which we did not already know.'

Maxwell advisers, including Goldman Sachs and auditor Coopers & Lybrand, have already been fined over their role in respect of MGN. Samuel Montagu, however, has so far escaped and the DTI's criticism of Goldman went far beyond the previous regulatory inquiry, in 1993.

This weekend, Goldman defended its dealings with Maxwell, saying it had been misled by the crooked tycoon.

The Maxwell brothers and other associates were acquitted in 1996 of any criminal wrongdoing over the fleecing of the MGN pension funds.

But lawyers for the DTI are now examining the 800-page report to see whether there are grounds for barring them as company directors.

'That would be vindictive,' Kevin Maxwell told The Observer. 'I've always accepted my share of responsibility in all I've been through. They have to take account of my human rights. I have to work. If they don't believe me, I will fight.'

The inspectors recommended further tightening of pension fund and Stock Exchange rules, plus regular rotation of auditors, to prevent similar abuses in future.

This weekend, however, senior MPs voiced anger at the report's timing, ahead of a general election, and the lack of further City action.

'We will take an active role in future reforms of company law,' said Martin O'Neill, chair of the House of Commons Select Committee on Trade and Industry. 'As part of that we will look at fraud and the laxity of financial services regulation in this country in the past.'

webTitle: Power giants blow fresh wind into renewable energy

fields.headline: Power giants blow fresh wind into renewable energy
fields.trailText: A major increase in the UK's capacity to generate electricity from windpower will be signalled next week, when the Crown Estates grants leases to 17 new offshore projects, writes Oliver Morgan.
fields.body:
A major increase in the UK's capacity to generate electricity from windpower will be signalled next week, when the Crown Estates grants leases to 17 new offshore projects, writes Oliver Morgan.

Costing some £1.5 billion, the wind turbines are expected to generate 1700 megawatts, quadrupling the output from UK wind farms. Britain currently has only one offshore plant, at Blyth in Northumberland.

The turbines, built on platforms anchored to the sea bed, will help the Government reach its target of 10 per cent of energy coming from renewable sources by 2010. Wind power is expected to provide half the total - implying output of 6,000MW.

Ministers favour offshore projects because they do not run into planning problems and can involve the use of larger turbines.

The sites to be leased include the Bristol Channel, the Solway Firth, Teesside, Humberside, Skegness, and the Kentish Flats.

Companies involved include Shell, Hyder, Powergen, British Energy, and US energy operator Enron.

The projects will attract government funding, as generating costs are higher than for nuclear or fossil fuels. Last month, Tony Blair announced £100m in aid for renewable energy.

fields.headline: HLS faces new onslaught
fields.trailText: Big drug firms including Bayer, Novartis and Roche are to be targeted by animal rights campaigners protesting against Huntingdon Life Sciences, the drug testing company.
fields.body:
Big drug firms including Bayer, Novartis and Roche are to be targeted by animal rights campaigners protesting against Huntingdon Life Sciences, the drug testing company.

Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac) is to turn its focus on HLS's customers in a fresh attempt to close the company down.

The campaigners last week successfully frightened off the two stockbrokers who make markets in HLS shares - Winterflood Securities and Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein.

They will now devote resources to attacking the company's client list, which includes a raft of blue-chip names.

Greg Avery, spokesman for Shac, said: 'We're really going to step up targeting companies connected to HLS. The City now doesn't want to go anywhere near the company, so now we're looking at Huntingdon's customers.'

He added: 'Six weeks after we upgraded Winterflood and Dresdner to the top of our list they pulled support.'

The loss of the marketmakers has meant it is more difficult to trade HLS's shares.

However, in a written statement, Huntingdon claimed to be unmoved: 'The effect on the day-to-day business of the company is negligible.

'This is particularly the case following the long-term refinancing of the company in January by the Stephens Group, a resolute US backer.'

But a company insider admitted HLS was disappointed by the City's actions: 'These people have realised that by focusing on one company at a time they can make them crumble. We've survived 18 awful months, but the City hasn't been so resilient.'

The collapse of the marketmakers' support for Huntingdon comes after institutions which held shares in HLS, including Merrill Lynch and HSBC, sold their stakes.

On Friday, British Biotech wrote to Shac to make it clear that it had severed links with HLS. A letter sent to Shac by Elliot Goldstein, chief executive of British Biotech, said: 'In June 2000, British Biotech decided not to place any further research projects with HLS. Research projects initiated prior to that decision have now been terminated.'

webTitle: Market slump to trigger cull of 20,000 City jobs

fields.headline: Market slump to trigger cull of 20,000 City jobs
fields.trailText: Nearly 20,000 jobs are to go in the City by the end of 2002 as the UK financial services sector feels the pinch from the global share price meltdown, says a respected business thinktank.
fields.body:
Nearly 20,000 jobs are to go in the City by the end of 2002 as the UK financial services sector feels the pinch from the global share price meltdown, says a respected business thinktank.

The latest briefing from the Centre for Economics and Business Research, out tomorrow, estimates that a slump in deals in this bear market will see the number of people employed in City jobs fall from 302,500 to 292,600. Another 10,000 are likely to be lost in support services.

Cuts are expected because there are too few deals and initial public offerings (IPOs) in mergers and acquisitions after the flop of the Orange flotation. Work is also drying up for City professional services and legal firms.

'There's not a lot of work and it's all very tense. The jobs merry-go-round has stopped and lots of us are going to fall off,' said one City investment banker.

Merrill Lynch is poised to axe 8 per cent of staff in its investment banking division, according to reports in the US press. CSFB is believed to have deferred its entire crop of graduate entrants.

The cuts will have a knock-on effect on house prices in the south-east. The CEBR predicts a 3 per cent decrease and a 5.6 per cent drop in commercial rents.

'These numbers should be seen as predicting a mild setback after a strong boom rather than as gloom and doom,' declared Doug McWilliams of the CEBR.

 City economists are betting on an interest rate cut at Thursday's meeting of the Monetary Policy Committee. A majority of 30 economists polled by Reuters predicted a 0.25 per cent cut in lending rates.

webTitle: BT and Vodafone aim to share 3G network costs

fields.headline: BT and Vodafone aim to share 3G network costs
fields.trailText: Cash-strapped BT wants to team up with Vodafone in a move which would see the two companies build their next-generation mobile networks together. The arch-rivals are desperately looking for ways to cover the massive cost of winning 3G licences. Telecoms experts say the move to work in partnership could save the firms up to £2 billion over 10 years.
fields.body:
Cash-strapped BT wants to team up with Vodafone in a move which would see the two companies build their next-generation mobile networks together. The arch-rivals are desperately looking for ways to cover the massive cost of winning 3G licences. Telecoms experts say the move to work in partnership could save the firms up to £2 billion over 10 years.

A BT insider said the talks were at an early stage, and admitted the company was looking at a similar deal with One2One. 'We'd be keen to do a deal for both financial and environmental reasons,' he said, pointing out that shared mobile masts would be popular with the green lobby.

Mounting debts have threatened the position of BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman Sir Iain Vallance. The company wants to raise up to £10bn through a rights issue, but the City is demanding that heads roll in the boardroom first. A showdown was expected last month when institutional investors were due to meet the pair at a private dinner but the meal was postponed.

Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, recently met Chancellor Gordon Brown to raise concerns about soaring costs. Gent is understood to be angry that Vodafone ended up paying six times more than it expected for its 3G licences.

He has lobbied Brown to consider relaxing industry rules so that mobile phone companies can increase tariffs and increase the return on their investments.

webTitle: BA ready to foot householders' bill for Heathrow runway

fields.headline: BA ready to foot householders' bill for Heathrow runway
fields.trailText: British Airways has offered to foot the bill for knocking down up to 3,500 houses around Heath-row Airport for a new runway, Joanna Walters writes . The airline has told the Government and airports owner BAA that it would reimburse them for compensating any householders forced to move if a new runway was built in the south-east - but is known to be particularly keen on Heathrow.
fields.body:
British Airways has offered to foot the bill for knocking down up to 3,500 houses around Heath-row Airport for a new runway, Joanna Walters writes . The airline has told the Government and airports owner BAA that it would reimburse them for compensating any householders forced to move if a new runway was built in the south-east - but is known to be particularly keen on Heathrow.

The Government is 'evaluating' a new full-length runway at Heathrow to increase capacity to more than 100 million passengers a year. It would mean destroying 3,500 houses north of the airport, at a cost of at least £1 billion.

A mini-runway for short-haul flights, requiring demolition of just 'a few hundred' properties, and extra runways at Gatwick, Stansted and Luton are also being studied. The Government will decide whether to build a new runway next year, and will make no plans at Heathrow until it decides whether to give the go-ahead for Terminal Five. The BAA wants a new runway at Heathrow ruled out BA fears Heathrow could be overtaken by Paris and Amerstdam.

webTitle: Shrinking Arcadia to abandon its Principles

fields.headline: Shrinking Arcadia to abandon its Principles
fields.trailText: Arcadia will this week announce that it is to sell some of its best known high street names, including Hawkshead, Racing Green and Principles, to concentrate on its core Top Shop, Evans and Dorothy Perkins chains.
fields.body:
Arcadia will this week announce that it is to sell some of its best known high street names, including Hawkshead, Racing Green and Principles, to concentrate on its core Top Shop, Evans and Dorothy Perkins chains.

Warehouse, Wallis and Miss Selfridge are also likely to be sold over the next 12 to 18 months, although Stuart Rose, who took over as chief executive last November, will not put a formal 'for sale' tag on them yet.

He will, however, announce that he is pulling out of the Dial home shopping joint venture with Littlewoods, and Zoom, the internet service provider it set up in 1999.

Rose believes Arcadia has too many brands - 15, even after last year's closure programme - but his desire to sell peripheral chains has been hampered by lack of interest from buyers. The stores are mainly leasehold, so there are not enough assets to interest venture capitalists. Their results are too poor to attract trade buyers.

Rose is hoping that continued improvements in trading at the chains, largely a result of the BrandMax programme of store closures and rebranding put in place by the previous management, means he will eventually manage to sell.

Sales across the group rose by 4.3 per cent over Christmas, far better than the City had expected, and the momentum is believed to be continuing. Rose will use Thursday's results presentation to outline his strategy for the core chains, positioning them to take advantage of the disarray at Marks & Spencer.

He will, however, resist the temptation to launch a rights issue. Arcadia's shares have soared from 51p to 171.5p since Rose took over, helped by improving sales at the store chains and by a group of Icelandic investors, who have taken a 20 per cent stake.

There had been specula tion Rose would take advantage of the rising share price to secure Arcadia's financial position. Borrowings by its August year-end are expected to exceed £200 million, more than half its net assets, while profits are less than three times its interest bill.

Selling the smaller chains would require asset write-offs, which would worsen the financial position. Analysts say some of the chains will have to be given away.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Gates signs Sega
fields.body:
Gates signs Sega

Microsoft has thrown down the gauntlet to Sony in the battle for the $20 billion global videogames market. At the Tokyo Games Show, Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman, signed up Japanese giant Sega to produce 11 games for the launch of the Xbox console in autumn.

Microsoft has earmarked $500 million for marketing the Xbox in a bid to loosen Sony's tight grip on the sector with its PlayStation 2.

Sega was forced from the hardware business after poor sales of its Dreamcast. After a deal with telecoms company NTT, Xbox will allow games to be played online.

Baird faces new bid

Troubled textiles company William Baird could soon face a renewed bid approach from venture capital firm Alchemy Partners.

Alchemy, which has a near-30 per cent stake in Baird, owner of brands such as Windsmoor and Dannimac, attempted an £88m management buyout in January. The deal was called off after disagreements arose over the company's debt levels and Baird's share price took a hammering. Alchemy is now understood to be considering a renewed bid.

Hope for steel plant

The future of Corus's threatened Lackenby steel mill on Teesside could be secured as part of negotiations over the company's plans to cut 6,000 jobs and close UK plants.

Last week Corus executives met union leaders to discuss a Government- and industry-funded plan to keep plants open.

The firm made it clear that it still plans closures. However, sources close to the talks indicated a possible reprieve for Lackenby. They said the potential for industrial action on Teesside was higher than in Wales, where other plants are threatened.

BMW hires 1,800

BMW is recruiting 1,800 workers to help build the new Mini at its Cowley plant near Oxford. They will join 2,500 gearing up to produce the car, starting from next month. The staff will be on temporary contracts at first.

fields.headline: Sons and financiers blamed
fields.standfirst: Kevin's conduct was 'inexcusable' while Goldman Sachs was motivated by profit
fields.trailText: Kevin's conduct was 'inexcusable' while Goldman Sachs was motivated by profit
fields.body:
Nine years after their appointment, the DTI inspectors could be expected to be scathing about the Maxwell brothers' role in the Mirror Group flotation, despite their 1996 High Court acquittal, writes Paul Farrelly .

Kevin Maxwell, indeed, bore 'heavy responsibility', they said, in making sure MGN still ran as Captain Bob's private fiefdom. He failed to put the interests of MGN's pension funds before the needs of his father's foundering private empire. His conduct, inspectors Sir Roger Thomas and Raymond Turner found, was 'inexcusable' throughout.

Ian, the older brother, is rebuked far more mildly: he was inexperienced and signed documents without considering their full implications.

The same can hardly be said for Coopers & Lybrand, Maxwell's long-standing auditors, who bore the main responsibility for failing to report abuse of the pension funds and the serious inaccuracy of MGN's prospectus.

One senior partner said of an auditor's expected role: 'The first requirement is to continue to be at the beck and call of RM [Robert Maxwell], his sons and staff, appear when wanted and provide whatever is required.'

Samuel Montagu, MGN's merchant bank, is slated over MGN's unfitness for flotation and for failing to warn investors that Maxwell ran MGN as his private piggy bank. Montagu's team, led by corporate finance head Ian McIntosh, failed to ask the right questions and heed Maxwell's tricky history.

'MGN's unsuitability for listing was the result of failures for which Samuel Montagu were responsible,' the inspectors found. 'Had these been discovered... the changes would have been made or the flotation abandoned.'

The main responsibility, however, for pandering to the bullying Maxwell's demands lay with MGN's board, chaired by Sir Robert Clark. After the April 1991 flotation there were four board meetings before his death, during which directors allowed him to walk all over them. 'The board of MGN did not have effective control over management of MGN,' the report says. 'RM's sole signatory authority for an unlimited amount over MGN's bank accounts continued.'

Labour peer Lord Donoghue, a Maxwell company director, also comes in for criticism, as do other City advisers and regulators. Law firm Clifford Chance did not read board minutes; brokers Salomon Bros and Smith New Court, headed by Sir Michael Richardson and now part of Merrill Lynch, failed to make the proper checks; the Stock Exchange and Imro, the pension fund watchdog, were plain docile.

The most withering new criticism, however, is reserved for Wall Street's top investment banker, Goldman Sachs, over Maxwell's secret deals to manipulate the price of shares in MGN and the Maxwell Communications Corporation.

Ex-Goldman partner Eric Sheinberg acted for Maxwell frontmen to buy the shares, which raised prices, and told the inquiry he did not know the tycoon was the real buyer.

The inspectors did not believe him. They were 'satisfied that the deals were in reality done between RM and Mr Sheinberg'. He was 'motivated by the very large profits that he perceived would be made ... the resulting trading relationship was very profitable for Goldman Sachs [£8m from MCC shares and £15m from other trades].'

Senior Goldman management must have known the tycoon was behind overseas buying by Liechtenstein trusts, but did not tell the regulators, they added.

In all, Maxwell spent £344m vainly propping up MGN and MCC shares. Of the £250m raised by the MGN flotation, £210m went to pay off debt, £18m to Maxwell, £9m to advisers and just £7.5m to the newspaper group.

Crimes and punishments

What happened to whom in the Maxwell saga

Kevin and Ian Maxwell
Acquitted unanimously of fraud in a Serious Fraud Office-led trial in 1996. A judge also ruled that a second proposed criminal trial against Kevin Maxwell would be unfair and not in the public interest.

Larry Trachtenberg, Albert Fuller, Robert Bunn and Michael Stoney
All four of Captain Bob's key finance men were also acquitted following the 'not guilty' verdicts in the first trial. Stoney was later thrown out of the accountancy profession.

Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte
The Mirror Group and Maxwell's auditor - now part of PriceWaterhouseCoopers - was censured and fined £1.2 million by the Accountants' Joint Disciplinary Tribunal. Even with £2.1m of costs, the penalty was a fraction of the estimated £21m CLD earned from Maxwell from 1988. Paid £68m out-of-court to settle claims by administrators of Maxwell Communication Corporation (MCC).

Goldman Sachs
Dealt for Maxwell in Mirror and MCC shares, and was fined £160,000 in June 1993 by the Securities and Futures Authority for breaches of regulatory rules. Again the fine represented only a fraction of its profits from Maxwell.

Invesco MIM
City fund manager, now part of Amvescap, found to have breached rules in share transfers from the Maxwell pension funds. Was fined £750,000 with the addition of £1.6m costs.

fields.bodyText: Nine years after their appointment, the DTI inspectors could be expected to be scathing about the Maxwell brothers' role in the Mirror Group flotation, despite their 1996 High Court acquittal, writes Paul Farrelly . Kevin Maxwell, indeed, bore 'heavy responsibility', they said, in making sure MGN still ran as Captain Bob's private fiefdom. He failed to put the interests of MGN's pension funds before the needs of his father's foundering private empire. His conduct, inspectors Sir Roger Thomas and Raymond Turner found, was 'inexcusable' throughout. Ian, the older brother, is rebuked far more mildly: he was inexperienced and signed documents without considering their full implications. The same can hardly be said for Coopers & Lybrand, Maxwell's long-standing auditors, who bore the main responsibility for failing to report abuse of the pension funds and the serious inaccuracy of MGN's prospectus. One senior partner said of an auditor's expected role: 'The first requirement is to continue to be at the beck and call of RM [Robert Maxwell], his sons and staff, appear when wanted and provide whatever is required.' Samuel Montagu, MGN's merchant bank, is slated over MGN's unfitness for flotation and for failing to warn investors that Maxwell ran MGN as his private piggy bank. Montagu's team, led by corporate finance head Ian McIntosh, failed to ask the right questions and heed Maxwell's tricky history. 'MGN's unsuitability for listing was the result of failures for which Samuel Montagu were responsible,' the inspectors found. 'Had these been discovered... the changes would have been made or the flotation abandoned.' The main responsibility, however, for pandering to the bullying Maxwell's demands lay with MGN's board, chaired by Sir Robert Clark. After the April 1991 flotation there were four board meetings before his death, during which directors allowed him to walk all over them. 'The board of MGN did not have effective control over management of MGN,' the report says. 'RM's sole signatory authority for an unlimited amount over MGN's bank accounts continued.' Labour peer Lord Donoghue, a Maxwell company director, also comes in for criticism, as do other City advisers and regulators. Law firm Clifford Chance did not read board minutes; brokers Salomon Bros and Smith New Court, headed by Sir Michael Richardson and now part of Merrill Lynch, failed to make the proper checks; the Stock Exchange and Imro, the pension fund watchdog, were plain docile. The most withering new criticism, however, is reserved for Wall Street's top investment banker, Goldman Sachs, over Maxwell's secret deals to manipulate the price of shares in MGN and the Maxwell Communications Corporation. Ex-Goldman partner Eric Sheinberg acted for Maxwell frontmen to buy the shares, which raised prices, and told the inquiry he did not know the tycoon was the real buyer. The inspectors did not believe him. They were 'satisfied that the deals were in reality done between RM and Mr Sheinberg'. He was 'motivated by the very large profits that he perceived would be made ... the resulting trading relationship was very profitable for Goldman Sachs [£8m from MCC shares and £15m from other trades].' Senior Goldman management must have known the tycoon was behind overseas buying by Liechtenstein trusts, but did not tell the regulators, they added. Larry Trachtenberg, Albert Fuller, Robert Bunn and Michael Stoney All four of Captain Bob's key finance men were also acquitted following the 'not guilty' verdicts in the first trial. Stoney was later thrown out of the accountancy profession. Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte The Mirror Group and Maxwell's auditor - now part of PriceWaterhouseCoopers - was censured and fined £1.2 million by the Accountants' Joint Disciplinary Tribunal. Even with £2.1m of costs, the penalty was a fraction of the estimated £21m CLD earned from Maxwell from 1988. Paid £68m out-of-court to settle claims by administrators of Maxwell Communication Corporation (MCC). Goldman Sachs Dealt for Maxwell in Mirror and MCC shares, and was fined £160,000 in June 1993 by the Securities and Futures Authority for breaches of regulatory rules. Again the fine represented only a fraction of its profits from Maxwell. webTitle: Compass to lose out as bidders go cool on hotels

fields.headline: Compass to lose out as bidders go cool on hotels
fields.trailText: Hopes of a £3.5 billion cash injection for Compass Group from the sale of 250 hotels are set to be dashed.
fields.body:
Hopes of a £3.5 billion cash injection for Compass Group from the sale of 250 hotels are set to be dashed.

Fears of a world economic slowdown have forced bidders for the Le Meridien, Posthouse and Heritage chains to revise down their final offers.

Compass, the world's biggest contract caterer, demerged from Granada earlier this year. It wants the sale wrapped up within three weeks and expects it to fetch £3.5bn.

Analysts expect quoted Scottish-based Macdonalds Hotels to win Heritage for £290m and Bass to seize control of Posthouse for £830m.

But sources close to Marriott, the American hotel giant, say it is lowering its £2.2bn offer for the 120-strong Le Meridien chain, which includes hotels by London's Hyde Park and Piccadilly.

Marriott's main rival is Guy Hands at Nomura, who bid £2bn. Sources close to Hands said this weekend he is 'reconsidering his pricing'.

The other contender for Le Meridien is Bass, which bid £1.7bn. Industry sources say it is unlikely the former brewing giant will shift.

Compass last week com pleted the sale of its upmarket Signature hotel chain. Property firm London & Regional bought the Strand Palace Hotel and the Regent Palace Hotel for £98m. In total all six Signatures raised £315m.

Compass is selling because the company is highly rated as a catering firm but the City feels it has been bogged down by low-growth hotels.

Compass inherited the hotels from Granada, which bought them from Forte in 1996 for £3.8bn in one of the most bitter takeover battles of the Nineties.

webTitle: How the City ignored alarm bells on Maxwell

fields.headline: How the City ignored alarm bells on Maxwell
fields.standfirst: Danger signs were there, but Mirror boss was still able to bully and bribe bankers
fields.trailText: Danger signs were there, but Mirror boss was still able to bully and bribe bankers
fields.body:
One word screams through the Department of Trade and Industry's long overdue report into the Mirror flotation like Blackpool through a stick of rock: Pergamon, Pergamon, Pergamon.

In their greed for the multimillion-pound fees generated by a dealmaker like Robert Maxwell, supposedly blue-chip City banks did not just ignore the first time the crooked tycoon was hauled before DTI investigators in the early 1970s. One of them, Mirror flotation sponsor Samuel Montagu, admitted to the DTI that nothing would have changed even if they had.

Such was the willingness, too, of the Stock Exchange to forget Maxwell's previous form - instead relying on the good standing of those same forgetful banks and brokers - that it profoundly failed in its duty as a regulator.

As the DTI inspectors make clear, all involved in the fateful 1991 Mirror Group flotation - the Maxwell sons, Kevin and Ian, the Mirror board and its highly paid City advisers - failed shareholders and the Maxwell pensioners, who lost £425 million as the tycoon looted their funds.

Yet there was not one, but three, Pergamon reports to go on. Over three years, in a series of delicious installments, they chronicle Maxwell's cavalier conduct in running his original publishing business. The first in 1971 produced the damning verdict: 'He is not in our opinion a person who can be relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a public company.'

The leopard, as the Mirror inspectors point out, did not change his spots. But even for those of a forgiving disposition, remarks in the final Pergamon report should have set early alarm bells ringing.

'We are convinced that it was Maxwell's overall purpose to establish an artificially high value for Pergamon's shares in the stock market,' the inspectors concluded in 1973. 'And we are convinced that the exaggerated claims, the overstatement of profits and some of the transactions between Pergamon and the family private companies were all means to that end.'

Until he fell off his yacht in the Canaries in November 1991 Maxwell was clearly up to his old tricks again. Indeed, during the inspectors' inquiries it emerged that then Trade and Industry Secretary Peter Lilley had received complaints before Maxwell died about dealings between Captain Bob's other public company, Maxwell Communications Corp, and Wall Street bankers Goldman Sachs.

After scything through the City establishment, Friday's report reserves a sting in the tail for the DTI itself. In the final paragraph, the inspectors lament that many of their recommendations for tightening regulation had been made 10 years ago: in a report into the 1990 crash of the Bestwood property group, where the pension fund was also fleeced. 'There is a public interest in knowing what the response has been to recommendations made,' the Mirror inspectors complain.

In the Mirror aftermath this weekend, critics go much further. Ten years on, at a cost of £8m, what was the point of the report, especially if little action is taken against those criticised? And, if everyone, including the DTI, ignores the findings, what is the point of reports at all?

'Apart from publishing juicy but largely academic details, it's hard to see the value in these inquiries,' said one senior financial regulator. 'My main criticisms are cost and timing. They take so long because the DTI is so timid. It's injected into civil servants' bones as they go in.'

Mirror Group Newspapers will line up on the Department's dusty shelves as 'Inspectors' Report Number 116' and may be among the last of a dying breed. The first inquiry after the old Board of Trade took on powers to investigate company affairs in 1948 was conducted into the obscure firm of A Reyrolle & Co in 1949. Probes two and three peered into more familiar names: Bristol Rovers Football Club in 1951 and the Savoy Hotel in 1953.

Over the decades, ministerial curiosity grew into a roaring trade for the barristers, solicitors and accountants co-opted as government inspectors. In the Fifties just seven firms found themselves under the magnifying glass, in the Sixties 25, and during the Seventies no fewer than 37 cases merited attention, among them Lonrho and the Court Line travel crash.

The next two decades saw DTI meddling level off: 22 and 21 were published in the 1980s and 1990s respectively. But the free-wheeling Eighties, certainly, were the heyday for the DTI's sniffer dogs, taking in the battle for Harrods, the Guinness takeover, the Blue Arrow shares scandal and Minorco's hostile bid for Consolidated Gold Fields.

DTI engagements have certainly left deep scars. The 1970s probe into Lonrho prompted Edward Heath to label Rowland 'the unacceptable face of capitalism'. After the 1988 Harrods report - which found that the 'phoney pharaoh' misrepresented the source of his wealth - Mohamed al-Fayed still does not have his UK passport.

The announcement of an inquiry often has dramatic effects. In 1988 it led to a shake-up of NatWest's top brass over the bank's involvement in the Blue Arrow affair. In 1991 the news was enough to prompt resignations at Norton, the collapsed motorcycle company.

But apart from slinging mud, the DTI is hard-pressed to recount when an inspectors' report actually changed anything. Fayed still has Harrods, Rowland kept Lonrho, and in 1974 Maxwell retook control of Pergamon.

Ernest Saunders & Co were roundly trashed (again) 10 years after the event, when the Guinness report finally appeared in 1997. However, no further action - such as disqualification of directors - was proposed. In 1993 the second Blue Arrow report cleared NatWest's top brass after all and concluded that share-dealing laws - surprise! - were a mess. Four convictions had already been quashed by the Court of Appeal, as may yet happen with Guinness after a European ruling curbing the use of evidence gained under DTI inspectors' powers to compel co-operation.

Embarrassingly, too, in 1998 the DTI not only lost its highest-profile disqualification case - against John Gunn, the former head of the collapsed British & Commonwealth financial empire, but the court also overturned the findings of the DTI's £7m 1994 report against him. 'The case against me was about retribution, not discovery,' Gunn said this weekend. 'They wanted a scalp after failing with Blue Arrow.'

This weekend, just two inquiries remain unfinished - that into the 1993 collapse of the Queen's Moat Houses hotel group, and last year's demise of Geoffrey Robinson's TransTec - as cases are increasingly passed to the Serious Fraud Office or new Financial Services Authority.

Despite the delays, these high-profile DTI reports still have the benefit that they are published. Most, like those into alleged insider dealing - including the Mirror Slickers inquiry - never will be.

Against that, however, has to be set the expense: the Mirror report alone cost as much as this year's entire budget for the SFO.
