webTitle: The view backstage of the Corus line

fields.headline: The view backstage of the Corus line
fields.standfirst: Oliver Morgan on how union hopes for a retraining lifeline were raised, then dashed, by the steelmaker
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan on how union hopes for a retraining lifeline were raised, then dashed, by the steelmaker
fields.body:
At about 5pm last Monday Michael Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC steel union, took a call at his Gray's Inn Road office. To his left sat a bronze bust of Nye Bevan, Welsh firebrand and hero of the 'Old' Labour left.

On the line was Stephen Byers, Trade and Industry Secretary and member of the Blairite right. Leahy was desperate for the implausible - New Labour backing an Old Labour cause: state aid for steel jobs. Byers had good news. He would support a plan proposing subsidies for retraining 6,000 workers threatened in a restructuring package by steel giant Corus through the European Commission.

This was a triumph. Government backing was a crucial piece in a complicated jigsaw Leahy and the ISTC high command were constructing to save jobs.

To help gain Byers' support he had even commissioned Cherie Blair to map a legal route through the Brussels jungle and overcome DTI scepticism. 'Keeping it in the family,' he had said the week before when he handed over the legal opinion to Byers.

With this in his back pocket, Leahy prepared for a crunch meeting the next morning with Corus's top executives, led by the phlegmatic Sir Brian Moffat.

Byers had also placed a call to Moffat, but the reception was different. A furious Moffat called Byers' actions 'outrageous' and 'blatant electioneering'. Moffat was not about to change his view that the domestic market for carbon steel was in decline. To pretend his cutbacks were unnecessary would be a 'cruel hoax'. At 10am on Tuesday a union delegation arrived at Corus's Great Marlborough Street HQ in London's West End. Leahy was accompanied by his trusted lieutenant - pipe-smoking Irishman Eddie Lynch - and four ISTC members. Together with Bob Shannon, steel negotiator of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, and officials from the MSF, GMB and T&G, Leahy plotted tactics.

The unions' Plan A, costed at up to £90 million, was to cut hours at threatened plants, with training packages when workers were off shift funded by the Government, Corus and the union. The key was to ensure that Corus rethought its plans on job and plant cuts, while waiting to see if demand rose. Plan B was a smaller £11m retraining package that would have accepted massive redundancies and closures.

At the same time Moffat and his executives - Tony Pedder, head of strip products, Alan Johnson, head of personnel, and divisional chief Chris Hollick - were deciding their line. At 11am the two sides met in the fifth-floor boardroom.

On 1 February, the 6,000 losses had been announced peremptorily, and on 14 February Corus curtly agreed to give unions time to come up with alternatives. On 8 March the Llanwern plan was secretly discarded by managing director Nick Cragg. Similar rejections followed for other plants, all well before the 27 March deadline for discussions.

Had the atmosphere now changed? 'Before, they were not prepared to listen, even though they said they would,' said one union man. 'This time Moffat was more engaged, asking questions. To be frank, I don't think they had anticipated Byers backing our plans.'

There was little warmth, however, and unions knew Moffat was not a man for Damascene conversions. 'We felt we were not going to change his position through force of argument. But Moffat, though he gives little away, seemed a little less sure of his position. They were in a box, they had come under enormous political, community and media pressure... they realised they had to listen.'

In fact Moffat probed hard. He observed the unions were proposing capacity cuts at Llanwern from 3 million tonnes to 1 million. How was he going to manage the plant, with employees who were not working because of the cut rubbing shoulders with others still working flat out. Who was to pay for it?

At midday the meeting adjourned for an hour. When they reconvened, Corus said it still wanted wide-scale redundancies, but Leahy and Shannon said this was unacceptable. Then came what looked like a breakthrough. Corus agreed to revisit the issue, and to a tripartite working party to pilot the in-work training package through the EU with government and the unions.

Both sides agreed to a joint statement saying that although capacity reductions were inevitable, a working party would be set up. After four hours, the meeting ended. Compared with previous discussions, this seemed like progress. The unions were jubilant, talking of a turning point. They had until mid-May to hammer out proposals.

But the next day newspapers carried reports that Corus's position had not budged. The unions were angry, believing Corus had reneged. But, a Corus spokesman told The Observer: 'It was always going to be the case that there would be different nuances in the way the agreement was presented.' Corus says the restructuring package was not renegotiated at the meeting, and attention focused on keeping people on the Corus payroll after plant closures while retraining them.

The all-round acceptance of capacity cuts in the statement was the wrinkle Corus needed to hold its position. The City was pleased: Corus shares rose. DTI officials were not surprised. 'We are very sceptical about what Corus will do. Perhaps they were worried about strikes (threatened by Leahy when local plans were rejected) , which led them to be positive during the talks.'

Leahy said last Wednesday: 'This is very upsetting for us. It appears they are double-talking and briefing the financial press because they are concerned with shareholders and their bankers rather than their workers and communities. It is very different to the meeting. We would not have signed up to that joint statement if nothing had changed.' So, what happens next? For Byers the next flashpoint will fall conveniently after an election (assuming it is held on 3 May).

As for Corus, cynics believe last Tuesday only underlines its determination to press ahead, while acknowledging it has to avoid further public relations embarrassments. But the unions must continue to hope that there will be agreement to a retraining package by both Corus and Brussels. That would give them perhaps another year to talk in the hope of salvation.

Whatever happens, the meeting won't happen in Great Marlborough Street. Corus is moving out. Cost cutting, apparently.

Key Dates

February

1 Corus announces plant closures and 6,050 job losses. Shares rise 9 per cent.

2 Corus says it will listen to fresh ideas from unions.

7 Tony Blair urges Corus to rethink.

9 Unions meet Blair to present rescue package.

14 Corus starts statutory 90-day consultation with unions. Gives more time to propose rescue. AEEU proposes retraining in telecoms company Exi. ISTC attacks plan.

March

2 Blair again urges Corus to rethink.

8 Corus rejects Llanwern rescue, followed by Ebbw Vale, Shotton and Bryngwyn.

14 Trade and Industry Select Committee criticises Corus's business strategy.

15 Corus unveils £1.3billion pre-tax loss for 15 months to December 2000.

16 Llanwern and Ebbw Vale unions request strike ballot.

19 Unions meet Byers and present Cherie Booth opinion.

20 MPs call for Moffat to be stripped of his knighthood.

21 Blair again backs unions.

26 Byers backs union plan; Corus accuses him of electioneering.

27 Corus meets unions.

Then came what looked like a breakthrough. Corus agreed to revisit the issue, and to a tripartite working party to pilot the in-work training package through the EU with government and the unions. Both sides agreed to a joint statement saying that although capacity reductions were inevitable, a working party would be set up. After four hours, the meeting ended. Compared with previous discussions, this seemed like progress. The unions were jubilant, talking of a turning point. They had until mid-May to hammer out proposals. But the next day newspapers carried reports that Corus's position had not budged. The unions were angry, believing Corus had reneged. But, a Corus spokesman told The Observer: 'It was always going to be the case that there would be different nuances in the way the agreement was presented.' Corus says the restructuring package was not renegotiated at the meeting, and attention focused on keeping people on the Corus payroll after plant closures while retraining them. The all-round acceptance of capacity cuts in the statement was the wrinkle Corus needed to hold its position. The City was pleased: Corus shares rose. DTI officials were not surprised. 'We are very sceptical about what Corus will do. Perhaps they were worried about strikes (threatened by Leahy when local plans were rejected) , which led them to be positive during the talks.' Leahy said last Wednesday: 'This is very upsetting for us. It appears they are double-talking and briefing the financial press because they are concerned with shareholders and their bankers rather than their workers and communities. It is very different to the meeting. We would not have signed up to that joint statement if nothing had changed.' So, what happens next? For Byers the next flashpoint will fall conveniently after an election (assuming it is held on 3 May). As for Corus, cynics believe last Tuesday only underlines its determination to press ahead, while acknowledging it has to avoid further public relations embarrassments. But the unions must continue to hope that there will be agreement to a retraining package by both Corus and Brussels. That would give them perhaps another year to talk in the hope of salvation. Whatever happens, the meeting won't happen in Great Marlborough Street. Corus is moving out. Cost cutting, apparently. Key Dates February 1 Corus announces plant closures and 6,050 job losses. Shares rise 9 per cent. 2 Corus says it will listen to fresh ideas from unions. 7 Tony Blair urges Corus to rethink. 9 Unions meet Blair to present rescue package. 14 Corus starts statutory 90-day consultation with unions. Gives more time to propose rescue. AEEU proposes retraining in telecoms company Exi. ISTC attacks plan. March 2 Blair again urges Corus to rethink. 8 Corus rejects Llanwern rescue, followed by Ebbw Vale, Shotton and Bryngwyn. 14 Trade and Industry Select Committee criticises Corus's business strategy. 15 Corus unveils £1.3billion pre-tax loss for 15 months to December 2000. 16 Llanwern and Ebbw Vale unions request strike ballot. 19 Unions meet Byers and present Cherie Booth opinion. 20 MPs call for Moffat to be stripped of his knighthood. 21 Blair again backs unions. 26 Byers backs union plan; Corus accuses him of electioneering. 27 Corus meets unions.

fields.headline: Soho split: bohos vs bankers
fields.standfirst: Now is not the time for bragging in Soho wine bars, reports Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Now is not the time for bragging in Soho wine bars, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Every few years foot-in-mouth disease visits some sector of the business community, and the consequences are usually disastrous. This year it is the turn of Scottish banking to become infected after Sir George Mathewson, executive deputy chairman of Royal Bank of Scotland, was hit by a virulent strain.

Mathewson's flippant suggestion that the £759,000 bonus he received after RBS bought NatWest 'wouldn't have given you bragging power in a Soho wine bar' was almost up there with Gerald Ratner's infamous prawn sandwich gaff. The comment helped ignite a smouldering row, and the press jumped in with glee. By the time Mathewson waded in with his now infamous remark, the National Association of Pension Funds was on the warpath.

In addition to Mathewson's special bonus, the NAPF was concerned that he and three other directors, including Sir Iain Vallance and Sir Angus Grossart, are to land bonuses totalling £2.5 million because their bank bought another.

NAPF wants investors to vote Vallance and Grossart off the board at the next annual meeting. But the urgent question being asked in the Square Mile is exactly which bars in Soho frequented by Mathewson have a clientèle which would be unfazed by a cool three quarters of a million pounds.

The Observer took a random walk down Soho's Old Compton Street, stopping at a range of hostelries, to find out. It is clear that Sir George doesn't mix with regulars at the Pitcher & Piano too much on his sojourns in the capital.

'I would have to be working for 25 years to earn that,' said Otto Dresel, a bar manager enjoying a lager with barista Brad Callaghan. 'I'd be impressed by that,' Brad adds, before asking how much Mathewson earns in a normal year.

The Observer consults the company's 1999 accounts, the latest year available. '£836,000,' the two are told. 'Well as he's not that short of money why doesn't he redistribute it?' Otto asks. Very boho Soho.

Elsewhere in the bar, though, avarice has a friend. 'I'd like to meet his wife,' says Paul Barratt, a television producer. Why? 'Because she'll get all his money,' he says, sinisterly.

The upmarket, fashionable Café Bohème is bitterly divided. John Laycock, the general manager, does a few sums and concludes: 'I'd have to do 9,600 double shifts to earn that. I reckon he's doing all right. What did he get it for?' His bank bought another bank, The Observer explains. 'Well if we went and bought Bar Soho next door I don't think there's any chance I'd get a bonus,' Laycock says ruefully.

'It's offensive to belittle money. Even £1 is a lot to someone with none,' argues Peter Bach, another TV producer. 'It seems like a great deal to me,' says Lucy Clay, who works in post production.

'But does he get any job satisfaction?' asks Dichon LeVinse, a scriptwriter. 'People in the arts do it because they love it.' Costas Alexakis, who works for Nova Scotia bank and is from Greece, said: 'There aren't huge bonuses in Greece. You'd expect some bonuses in banking but not to this extent.'

But the Mathewson camp is bolstered by support from James Wilkins, an e-security consultant with accountant KPMG. 'These people work phenomenally hard. I know people who know this chap, and I know he has an extremely punishing schedule.'

Drinkers in the exclusive Teatro bar agree. One portly regular opines: '£760,000 is fuck all for someone running what people say is the best bank in Europe. It's only something like a penny off every customer.'

So Mathewson is right. Choose the right wine bar and his bonus is small beer. He may care to buy Teatro's regulars a drink. Best to stay clear of the Pitcher & Piano, though.

webTitle: Layers of guilt peel off to reveal vipers in the Square Mile

fields.headline: Layers of guilt peel off to reveal vipers in the Square Mile
fields.trailText: The Maxwell report tars the City with the dirtiest of brushes. Anybody reading its damning conclusions could be forgiven for thinking the Square Mile is a nest of vipers ready to collude with any crook, facilitate any fraud, and pillage any pension fund.
fields.body:
The Maxwell report tars the City with the dirtiest of brushes. Anybody reading its damning conclusions could be forgiven for thinking the Square Mile is a nest of vipers ready to collude with any crook, facilitate any fraud, and pillage any pension fund.

It is not even as though the City was hoodwinked by a particularly shrewd operator. Robert Maxwell had already been damned in one DTI probe, and his obvious character flaws and criminal tendencies - visible even to the fabled one-eyed Albanian - should have put him straight on a City blacklist. To the best of my knowledge, only one bank, then called SG Warburg, refused out of principle to act for him.

The inspectors identify several levels of guilt, with the greatest culpability reserved for Maxwell himself. The fraudster bullied and bribed his way to the top, taking in gullible financial journalists, investment bankers and stockbrokers, before rifling his own pensioners' retirement money. In this, the DTI found, his sons Kevin and Ian bore a great deal of responsibility, as did several members of the Mirror board.

The next layer of guilt covers the auditors, Coopers & Lybrand, and investment bank Samuel Montagu, which brought the Mirror to market on a fatally flawed prospectus. Maxwell senior no doubt did his best to conceal the true state of financial affairs at the Mirror from his advisers, but these were the City's finest, and they should have spotted the holes in the figures. Of course, they may have been distracted by Captain Bob's juicy fees.

The next culprit is Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank renowned for its near-masonic ethos and its single-minded lust for profit. Goldman, too, maintains that it was lied to, but the bank - known for its aloof arrogance - must have got up the inspectors' noses. The DTI comes very close to saying ex-Goldman partner Eric Sheinberg aided and abetted Maxwell in dealings that ramped the Mirror shares.

Goldman Sachs, once again, may have been too dazzled by the sacks of gold heading its way from Maxwell to notice. Enough other culprits are named to give the impression that the whole City was at it, but another must be added- that of the Financial Services Authority itself.

For the FSA to say it can take no action against any of the guilty parties named in the report is the grossest insult to the army of investors and pensioners who lost money because of Maxwell.

Why can't it? In the same way that a negligent hospital management or fraudulent local authority can be taken to court, the FSA should sue the guilty financial institutions, and demand the highest possible damages for their transparent negligence. This would be a mighty incentive for other accountants, banks or stockbrokers to go over the books with the finest of tooth combs in future.

As it is, the FSA's craven inaction represents the ultimate failure of self-regulation, and is final proof that the City cannot be allowed to govern itself any longer.

The DTI may puff up its chest and make macho noises about banning the Maxwell brothers from directorships, but its bravado will be exposed when the pair hire the best lawyers in town to fight the bans, as they have promised.

Anyway, neither seriously intends to join a mainstream British plc board again, being quite happy to run their operations from places like Bermuda and Russia.

The DTI joins the guilty list in another sense. The report took 10 years and cost £8m, yet is published amid the furore of pre-election speculation that is bound to stifle serious debate on the scandal. By publishing now, Stephen Byers has helped ensure that the lessons of Maxwell will not be learnt.

Nobody emerges with any credit. But in the long run, the City will suffer most damage. If nobody carries the can, it will be shown to be what its critics always allege - a casino where the odds are stacked, the tables rigged, and the punters fleeced.

webTitle: Recession, what recession? It's all in your mind

fields.headline: Recession, what recession? It's all in your mind
fields.standfirst: A confident UK could see off a US-led downturn, writes  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: A confident UK could see off a US-led downturn, writes Faisal Islam
fields.body:
When US television companies have trouble filling advertising slots during the Oscars ceremony, it's clear there's a problem in the economy. When the adverts that do run include a mini talk show where the head of stockbroking firm Charles Schwab seeks to soothe jumpy investors, it's clear the problem is becoming very serious.

The investment banks are also getting involved. In full-page ads headlined 'The storm before the calm', Merrill Lynch tells Americans that 'our research analysts expect the market to rally this spring'. If bankers and brokers are trying to reinvigorate investor confidence through applied psychology, they are not alone. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Chairman, made his first stab at this inexact science when he cut the interest rate in between Fed meetings in January.

Collectively, US investors and consumers are in the psychiatrist's chair, as financial 'shrinks' seek answers to a miasma of questions: To what extent do consumers feel 'poorer' having seen their share portfolios halve in value? Are things different in Europe? Have investors become more risk-averse in the wake of the burst of the tech bubble? Have they abandoned belief in the 'new economy'? Are British investors more sensitive to negative business sentiment from the US today than they were during the last US downturn?

In financial forecasting, many assumptions are being made about the answers to these essentially emotional questions. Put another way, the divergent forecasts of the potential for recession in the US are explained by a mix of economics and assumptions about consumer and investor behaviour.

The pessimism over the US situation is rooted in the feeling that consumers won't spend, won't invest, and will start to save, thereby translating a confidence-led slowdown into a genuine recession. It's down to the 'wealth effect' - the extent to which changes in asset prices affect spending behaviour.

The comparative resilience of the UK economy can be put down to its lower sensitivity to share prices. Although the table below shows some adverse effect - and certainly more than in other European countries, the principal determinant of the 'wealth effect' in Britain is house prices, not share prices. Specific sectors, such as the City, will take a hit, but the overall effect of share falls is small compared with the US.

'Over $4 trillion has been wiped off people's wealth in the US,' John Llewellyn, global chief economist at Lehman Brothers, points out.

If decreases in spending after a reduction in wealth mirror the spending boom on the way up, consumer spending will fall by 1.6 per cent of US GDP. But there's no simple equation. If, as is plausible, aversion to risk has grown since the Nasdaq slump, the effect could be amplified considerably as US consumers batten down the hatches and throw their money into savings accounts.

US households' net worth suffered its first fall in a quarter of a century last year. Such a fall has happened on only three previous occasions in the past 50 years, and all have presaged a substantial increase in savings and the emergence of recession, according to HSBC research.

Also giving grounds for pessimism is the effect of falling share prices on the willingness of businesses to take investment risks. Stephen King at HSBC, one of the first City economists to predict a US hard landing, sees a retrenchment in corporate and consumer spending behind an unstoppable drop to recession. 'The fall in the Nasdaq is a proxy cost for the availability of investment funds,' he says. The Nasdaq's soaring value, rather than low interest rates, was the source of an investment and jobs boom in the tech sector especially. So slashing interest rates may prove an ineffective way of bolstering business investment plans.

'Corporates will cut back significantly in the next few months. When layoffs pick up, already weak consumers will have to contend with increasing job insecurity.' Layoffs are on the rise: according to surveys, they have doubled to more than 100,000 a month since December.

This is not the case in Europe. Although British markets are down, they haven't fallen as far as those in the US. The UK's 'misery index', which is unemployment plus inflation, stands at a 30-year low.

Even if the US tumbles into recession, the UK is unlikely to follow, because most of its trade is with continental Europe - and it was never flying so high in the first place. The eurozone trades mainly with itself. The economic risks to this position come mainly through a global slowdown following escalating problems in both Asia and the US.

Specific sectors will suffer. The Centre for Economics and Business Research predicts that 20,000 jobs will go in the City by the end of next year as bear markets restrict the flow of deals at investment banks.

But another lurking fear about the UK economy brings us back to the psychiatrist's chair. 'In addition to trade linkages, you should not underestimate psychological connections,' says Llewellyn of Lehman Brothers.

In 1998, financial difficulties in Thailand, a small player on the global stage in terms of trade linkages, eventually froze US bond markets for two weeks. The extent of the contagion is impossible to measure, but, for example, our sensitivity to US economic distress may have changed in recent years.

A huge growth in media coverage of US business may have altered that relationship. But confidence depends on a lot more than economics. Is it coincidence that there is record consumer confidence in France when US fortunes suffer? There are analysts who still believe the increase in consumer confidence in France since 1998 was triggered by its football team's victory in the World Cup. The relationships between asset prices, the wealth effect, confidence, and spending are constantly evolving and cannot be assumed.

As Llewellyn says: 'There are much wilder swings in consumer confidence now. History may give you a false sense of confidence.'

We will need a lot more therapy before we can stop the recession nightmare.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Still looking for a port in a storm? Why not take a fresh look at pharmaceuticals, one sector that should weather recession, and at Glaxo SmithKline in particular.
fields.body:
Still looking for a port in a storm? Why not take a fresh look at pharmaceuticals, one sector that should weather recession, and at Glaxo SmithKline in particular.

Despite a sharp bounce of late, our number one drug company's shares still languish at much the same level as a year ago. At current prices the yield on GSK is about as high as on inflation-linked bonds, despite the firm's far faster growth rate.

Last week, brokers at both ends of the spectrum - Goldman Sachs and Charles Stanley - were singing GSK's praises. Despite recent market moans, Goldman now sees strength in GSK's drugs pipeline. The launch next month of GKS's Advair/Seretide respiratory treatment, with potential global sales of £1.5 billion by 2005, may give the stock a short-term fillip.

Goldman has a price target of £20.50, against £18.37 now, while Charles Stanley thinks they should be worth £21.50.

More to bank on

Broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney's latest banking review highlights Royal Bank of Scotland as the sector's pick following recent weakness in the shares.

RBS shares recovered a great deal of ground in the bounceback last week. But at £15.84, SSSB still reckons they are worth buying at up to £18.

Elsewhere in the sector, analysts at specialist broker Fox-Pitt Kelton rubbish talk of Lloyds TSB needing Abbey National to recover growth momentum.

At 692p, Lloyds TSB is showing a loss against the 749p at which we recommended the shares in January as one of our tips of the year. So although we have a vested interest, we do like FPK's fundamental analysis.

As the broker points out, the bank's double-digit earnings growth continues; and it has the lowest risk profile of any major European bank, yet one of the lowest ratings. At current levels, indeed, the stock stands at a 30 per cent discount to its UK peers and, FPK reckons, nearly a 40 per cent discount to fair value.

Benefits from any Abbey deal are exceeded by its own efficiency programme and growth in Scottish Widows, wealth management or general insurance. At these levels, too, it looks as if Lloyds stands to gain whether the Abbey bid is blocked (relief at not overpaying) or given the green light. The shares are a buy.

Net loss

The same, however, cannot be said for NetBenefit, one of the great white hopes (or hypes) of the internet bubble. At 30p, shares in the internet services company are a pale shadow of the £25 they reached last year.

The firm is now shifting its focus into high-end internet domain management services, while at the same time restructuring to cut overheads and improve cash flow.

Broker Granville Baird reckons it will be a tough trick for new chairman John Parcell to pull off. Even if Parcell is positioning NetBenefit for a sale, it is hard, to see where the buyers might be. In the current climate the shares should be sold, Granville Baird says.

The right line

One management team trying to boost confidence in the current climate is the board at Carphone Warehouse. On Friday, chairman and CEO Charles Dunstone and two of his co-directors nipped into the market to snap up £500,000 of stock, stopping the rot in Carphone Warehouse shares at the end of the week.

At 132p, however, they remain just off their low since the float and way down on December's 220p peak. The chain remains the UK's strongest in mobile phones, has a respected management team and has already shown its ambitions to gain real scale in continental Europe.

Telecoms worries will clearly weigh on the firm, but Carphone Warehouse is a retailer, not a hi-tech stock. Tuck away, like the directors.
fields.bodyText: Still looking for a port in a storm? Why not take a fresh look at pharmaceuticals, one sector that should weather recession, and at Glaxo SmithKline in particular. Despite a sharp bounce of late, our number one drug company's shares still languish at much the same level as a year ago. At current prices the yield on GSK is about as high as on inflation-linked bonds, despite the firm's far faster growth rate. Last week, brokers at both ends of the spectrum - Goldman Sachs and Charles Stanley - were singing GSK's praises. Despite recent market moans, Goldman now sees strength in GSK's drugs pipeline. The launch next month of GKS's Advair/Seretide respiratory treatment, with potential global sales of £1.5 billion by 2005, may give the stock a short-term fillip. Goldman has a price target of £20.50, against £18.37 now, while Charles Stanley thinks they should be worth £21.50. More to bank on Broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney's latest banking review highlights Royal Bank of Scotland as the sector's pick following recent weakness in the shares. RBS shares recovered a great deal of ground in the bounceback last week. But at £15.84, SSSB still reckons they are worth buying at up to £18. Elsewhere in the sector, analysts at specialist broker Fox-Pitt Kelton rubbish talk of Lloyds TSB needing Abbey National to recover growth momentum. At 692p, Lloyds TSB is showing a loss against the 749p at which we recommended the shares in January as one of our tips of the year. So although we have a vested interest, we do like FPK's fundamental analysis. As the broker points out, the bank's double-digit earnings growth continues; and it has the lowest risk profile of any major European bank, yet one of the lowest ratings. At current levels, indeed, the stock stands at a 30 per cent discount to its UK peers and, FPK reckons, nearly a 40 per cent discount to fair value. Benefits from any Abbey deal are exceeded by its own efficiency programme and growth in Scottish Widows, wealth management or general insurance. At these levels, too, it looks as if Lloyds stands to gain whether the Abbey bid is blocked (relief at not overpaying) or given the green light. The shares are a buy. webTitle: What if I should die before I get old?

fields.headline: What if I should die before I get old?
fields.trailText: What will happen to my pension if I die before I retire?
fields.body:
What will happen to my pension if I die before I retire?

IF you are a member of a company final salary scheme, there is likely to be provision for your spouse to get a pension worth a half or a third of yours. But rules vary and you might want to speak to the administrators. Some schemes pay pensions to a same-sex or cohabiting partner

If you are a member of a company 'money purchase' scheme, your partner or dependants should get the value of your fund. Many employers also provide a 'death in service benefit' - usually two to four times your salary.

You should let the administrators know who you want to receive these payments. And you should also make sure they have up-to-date add-resses. If you move to a different job but leave pension-scheme assets behind, you should make sure your heirs know how to contact your old employer about the pension.

If you have personal pensions in place, you should ensure the provider knows who you want to inherit your fund. There could be inheritance tax (IHT) implications too. They can pay the fund direct to the heir without attracting IHT. But without a name, they will usually pay the pension to the rest of your estate, which means paying IHT if your net wealth on death is more than £242,000.

webTitle: A strategy at last. But don't get on your Marks just yet

fields.headline: A strategy at last. But don't get on your Marks just yet
fields.trailText: Thirteen months to the day after he arrived at Baker Street, Marks & Spencer chairman Luc Vandevelde has admitted what customers have known for years: the group is in desperate trouble. But will the package of measures announced last week be enough to save it?
fields.body:
Thirteen months to the day after he arrived at Baker Street, Marks & Spencer chairman Luc Vandevelde has admitted what customers have known for years: the group is in desperate trouble. But will the package of measures announced last week be enough to save it?

Everything he proposes is eminently sensible. The European stores are not just losing money, they are a positive distraction from the main issue of getting British sales moving in the right direction. Closing them is the only option.

The US businesses may be profitable but they are some way from making a decent return on investment. The old management would doubtless have sold them already had it not been for the embarrassment of having to take a huge loss on them.

M&S is a retailer, not a property company, so it does not make sense to have billions tied up in property assets. A sale and leaseback of half of them is a good start to managing the business more efficiently.

Likewise, the proposals for the high street business sound sensible. M&S desperately needs to regain its old strength in supplying quality classics at reasonable prices, rather than high fashion. Its stores need to shed their dowdy image.

Vandevelde - not to mention his predecessor Sir Richard Greenbury and erstwhile chief executive Peter Salsbury - have long stressed the importance of getting the clothing offer right again. But none of them has been able to do it.

Indeed, things keep on getting worse. The 6.5 per cent fall in sales for the nine weeks to 24 March - rising to 7.7 per cent after adjustment for Mother's Day - is worse than it has been since Vandevelde took over.

The much-vaunted store revamps have failed to impress customers and even the limited refurbishments that are now planned will cover only 120 stores by the year end.

Roger Holmes, recruited as head of the UK retail business at the start of the year, may have been the catalyst for the change in strategy but he, too, has yet to show that he can fill the stores with decent merchandise at the right price.

His background may be at B&Q-to-Comet group Kingfisher, but he is still regarded as more of a management consultant than a retailer.

On the positive side, however, the group has recruited Yasmin Yusuf, lauded as one of the brightest talents in British retailing, and George Davies, who founded Next and is the brains behind Asda's popular clothing ranges.

Analysts remain sceptical about the chances of it succeeding, but investors were impressed enough to mark the shares up again, leaving them at a premium to the sector. The group now has a strategy but, to justify the premium, the strategy has to work. Wait for evidence before you buy.

Not so cheerful

Stakeholder pensions will become available for the first time on Friday. Take-up is expected to be slow and most pundits predict that the Government will have to make them compulsory to have much of an impact on retirement provision.

Even so, Deutsche Bank predicts that, by 2011, the pensions market will be worth £103 billion, up from £46bn in 1999, of which 48 per cent will be stakeholders.

Stakeholder pensions have to be simple, transparent and, above all, cheap - charges are a maximum of 1 per cent. For companies used to being featherbedded with high charges and cost loading that will come as a shock - and the effect will not be confined to stakeholder products.

The arrival of cheap stakeholder pensions will put pressure on other products, which will look very expensive in comparison with cheap stakeholders.

That effect is already being seen - margins at most life companies are falling. Britannic and Prudential have decided they can no longer afford their expensive door-to-door salesforces.

Some - Legal & General, CGNU and Prudential among them - have been working hard to position themselves for the new era. L&G has linked with Alliance & Leicester, Barclays and the Forum for Private Businesses; the Pru has links with unions and chambers of commerce.

All are making heavy use of the internet, not just to sell the products but to help us track how much our pensions are worth, where they are invested and what would happen if we decided to retire early or increased our contributions.

The hope is that these links will allow them to sell enough pensions to make them profitable, even at this cutthroat charging level.

In all, 40 companies have registered an interest in selling stakeholder pensions. Even if all of them do, it is unlikely they will all be around in 10 years' time. L&G predicts that, eventually, there will be only five to 10 serious players left.

It intends to be one of them. Indeed, David Prosser, L&G's chief executive, has staked his reputation on the promise to maintain double- digit returns to shareholders, despite falling margins on products.

Insurance accounting is so opaque that it will take years before the impact on profits of the stakeholder pensions is clear. But buyers would be wise to bet on the best-prepared, such as L&G , Pru and CGNU.

Softly, softly

Even allowing for the fact that we have a bear market, this has been a bad couple of months for software companies such as Logica and CMG. Both have seen their shares fall by around 40 per cent since February, when investors started to fret that their predictions for growth in the mobile phone industry were not quite as exciting as they seemed.

The whizzy messaging and other communications services that are so key to CMG and Logica's valuations may not, therefore, be quite as exciting as the market had hoped.

On the face of it, the share price collapse has left them looking reasonable value. Logica, for example, once again stands on a price-earnings ratio of around three times the market average - not bad given that analysts are forecasting earnings growth of up to 25 per cent for the next two years.

The trouble is, there is a big risk that these forecasts will not be met given the speed of the slowdown in telecoms demand. If earnings growth slows, the prop for the premium valuation disappears. It is far too early to go bottom-fishing yet.
